Though the expediency of the internet has condensed the measure of instant success from “overnight sensation” to “mid-afternoon phenom
column4: ” Phantogram offer a case study that slow-and-steady can still win the occasional race. Theirs is the sort of popularity that’s easy to overlook: the New York duo’s 2010 debut full-length for Barsuk
column5: Eyelid Movies
column6: quietly seeped out into a post-chillwave marketplace overrun with atmospheric synth-pop acts
column7: and yet here they are four years later headlining 3
column8: 000-cap venues like New York’s Terminal 5 and the Hollywood Palladium. Sure
column9: a few surprise collaborations with the likes of Big Boi and the Flaming Lips may have helped raised their stock in the interim
column10: but
column11: without the benefit of a runway breakout single or viral video
column12: their exponential audience expansion appears to be more a product of old-fashioned word-of-mouth than click-of-mouse.

column1: That said
column2: you could be forgiven for not noticing Phantogram’s ascent because their music likewise rarely calls attention to itself. Upon forming Phantogram
column3: Sarah Barthel and Josh Carter famously dubbed their dream-pop/hip-hop fusion “street beat
column4: ” and while it was likely meant to connote their music’s gritty edges and nocturnal ambience
column5: the label also anticipated how easily Phantogram’s songs would be absorbed into the soundtrack of our day-to-day lives. From Urban Outfitters in-store playlists to prime placements on teen TV dramas
column6: Phantogram have achieved a sort-of unobtrusive ubiquity that's made them the new frontrunners of background music.

column1: But on their second full-length
column2: Phantogram look to graduate from the subliminal to the substantial. Voices is the band’s first offering under their new deal with Republic/Universal
column3: and in sharp contrast to the Bon Iver-esque log-cabin origin myth surrounding Eyelid Movies
column4: this one was recorded in L.A. with M.I.A./Santigold producer John Hill. While such a transition for an indie-reared act may not carry the same significance as it would have 20 years ago
column5: Voices is nonetheless a quintessential
column6: 1990s-style major-label debut: more heavy-handed and more expensive-sounding
column7: and also exceedingly self-aware of its mission to deliver the goods at this crucial juncture in the band’s career. As a result
column8: the more playful spirit introduced on 2011’s stopgap Nightlife EP (and its stellar single “Don’t Move”) has been all but extinguished; in its place is a band that’s more serious and driven
column9: but also more stiff.

column1: Though Phantogram now employ a drummer in concerts
column2: the beats here are locked into precise
column3: mechanistic
column4: unwaveringly mid-tempo patterns. So it often falls on Barthel to raise the temperature and quicken the pulse. As we witnessed in her hair-pulling onstage cameos with the Flaming Lips last year
column5: she’s not afraid to place herself in a vulnerable position in service of a song
column6: and on Voices' most immediately arresting tracks—in particular
column7: the back-to-back
column8: arena-rattling R&B bangers “Black Out Days” and “Fall in Love”—she invests her performances with a heightened sense of desperation that feels raw and real. Likewise
column9: her wistful turn on “Bill Murray” serves as the album’s emotional center; though it doesn’t seem to have anything to do with the iconic actor
column10: the song's soft-focus synth washes and hazy-headed romantic longing would be right at home on the Lost in Translation soundtrack.

column1: As the album title suggests
column2: the songs on Voices are united by themes of inner turmoil and psychosis
column3: but the yearning intensity isn’t always there to back them up. “Howling at the Moon” squanders a tough clanging groove on a tame
column4: buzzkill chorus that undermines the feral desire expressed within; on the skittering
column5: Massive Attack-like “Bad Dreams”
column6: Barthel sums up her mental state by shouting out the title of Buñuel and Dali's Un Chien Andalou
column7: but the effect is decidedly less convincing than Black Francis’ invocation of the same. And though Phantogram favor an alchemical approach to music-making
column8: Barthel and Carter remain oddly discrete personalities
column9: avoiding the sort of he-said/she-said interaction that could lend their music more tension. Barthel may handle 80 percent of Phantogram’s vocals and command 99 percent of the attention
column10: but Carter is still trying to find his voice amid the band’s intricately layered productions. His spotlight-seizing turns here—the Phil Collins-via-In Rainbows pomp of “Never Going Home” and the repetitiously overwrought “I Don’t Blame You”—reek of overcompensation
column11: forsaking the more effective
column12: shadowy presence he presented on the Eyelid Movies highlight “Running From the Cops” for blown-out power balladry.

column1: Since the release of that first album
column2: the indie-pop/R&B crossover zone Phantogram inhabits has become considerably more crowded with mega-hyped breakout acts
column3: and Voices responds accordingly to these higher stakes with a bolder
column4: more assertive approach. But while its standout tracks are strong enough to ensure Phantogram maintains its current altitude
column5: there are a lot of places to turn to for this sort of thing these days
column6: and this album ultimately underwhelms next to the pure-pop punch of Haim
column7: the cutting lyricism of Lorde
column8: or the radiant grandeur of Chvrches. As much as Voices tries to get in your head
column9:
it too easily recedes to back of mind. 

"|19009.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19009-phantogram-voices/|6.0|Stuart Berman

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20236/homepage_large.ae6ca352.jpg|Small Town Heroes|32080.0|Hurray for the Riff Raff|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2014-02-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:49.350615|"

“Delia’s gone
column2: but I’m settling the score
column3: ” Alynda Lee Segarra sings on “The Body Electric
column4: ” the centerpiece of Hurray for the Riff Raff’s new album
column5: Small Town Heroes. Over tense eddies of fiddle and sympathetic acoustic strums
column6: her dry husk of a voice sounds more resigned than outraged
column7: as she realizes she's too late to save Delia. Several decades too late
column8: as the case may be: The Delia she’s singing about is the title character in the popular murder ballad ""Delia's Gone""
column9: written by Dick Toops and Karl Silbersdorf and recorded by Bob Dylan
column10: Harry Belafonte
column11: Waylon Jennings
column12: and multiple times by Johnny Cash. “The Body Electric” seeks to rescue Delia and so many other murder-ballad victims
column13: offering an empathetic—and feminist—reading of an American folk tradition that lives on today in contemporary covers of “Banks of the Ohio” and “Knoxville Girl"". Murder ballads allow us to act out dark urges
column14: using history to guard us against accusations of sociopathy or misogyny. But Segarra laments our fascination with such abject subject matter: “Shoot me down
column15: put my body in the river
column16: ” she sings
column17: “while the whole world sings
column18: sings it like a song/ The whole world sings like there’s nothing going wrong.”

column1: For Segarra
column2: a Bronx-born Puerto Rican who gravitated toward Bikini Kill before discovering Woody Guthrie
column3: the past is not a thing to be revered. Rather
column4: it must be endlessly
column5: aggressively interrogated. Small Town Heroes borrows liberally from old-time traditions
column6: including Appalachian reels
column7: Big Easy R&B
column8: and Piedmont blues
column9: yet these songs put a fresh and wily spin on old sounds and ideas. Segarra rewrites Jesse Fuller’s “San Francisco Bay Blues”
column10: retitling it “The New SF Bay Blues” and changing the subject from a wronged woman to a brokedown touring van: “You’ve been a good old wagon/ You got me there in style”). “Crash on the Highway” subtly rewrites Roy Acuff’s “Wreck on the Highway”
column11: its two-step beat evoking the boredom and frustration of backed-up traffic. These are songs about touring as rambling; instead of hitchin’ rides and jumpin’ trains
column12: Segarra and Hurray for the Riff Raff are gigging around the country in a cramped van.

column1: Small Town Heroes may not sound like what you’d expect from a New Orleans album
column2: yet it is anchored in that city’s sense of musical adventure. Segarra learned her trade playing in street bands and busking on corners
column3: which has given her a broad musical vocabulary. She arranges and produces these songs as eloquently as she writes them
column4: often using just a few instruments to convey a surprisingly full sound. “Blue Ridge Mountain” opens the album with her clawhammer banjo and what sounds like a clogger working together as a makeshift rhythm section
column5: with Yosi Perlstein’s spry fiddle dancing around them. “No One Else” is built on a folk-rock foundation
column6: yet it pitches and yaws on a rolling piano bassline that might have been learned from an old Fats Domino or Professor Longhair record.

column1: With Small Town Heroes
column2: Segarra proves herself one of the most compelling stylists in a folk revival full of suspicious acts either too beholden to tradition or too uncritical to make much of it. Perhaps the biggest difference between Hurray and its peers is attitude: Segarra understands that these styles don’t need to be revived
column3: so she’s not playing dress-up and isn’t concerned with projecting any sense of rustic authenticity. Instead
column4: she understands that these old sounds still thrum somewhere deep in the American subconscious
column5: even if our relation to them changes with each passing year. With the whole country as its geographical and historical backdrop
column6: Small Town Heroes is an album about how life and music intersect. Rather than play to her record collection
column7: however
column8: Segarra takes the records out of their sleeves
column9: scratches them up
column10:
and makes the old music speak to new concerns.

"|19031.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19031-hurray-for-the-riff-raff-small-town-heroes/|7.8|Stephen M. Deusner

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20214/homepage_large.3614bfd1.jpg|Breaks My Heart Each Time|28582.0|Leyland Kirby|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Apollo']|2014-02-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:49.935508|"

The Apollo label
column3: home of brave ventures into ambience since the early 1990s
column4: has housed such a prodigious array of talent that calling it a ""subdivision"" of parent label R&S almost feels like an insult. It's a sentiment James Leyland Kirby would no doubt agree with
column5: as he sheds various aliases (V/Vm
column6: the Caretaker
column7: and the Stranger among many others) to head out under his own name for his debut EP for the imprint. Kirby often borrows liberally from other sources
column8: so here he aligns those impulses with his surroundings by revisiting sounds that mirror the earlier Apollo releases
column9: giving acres of space to tinny drum machines and soft synth lines that echo into eternity. Anyone familiar with Apollo releases such as Biosphere's Microgravity or even Aphex Twin's Selected Ambient Works 85-92 should find a warm glow of familiarity overcoming them on a cursory glance at Breaks My Heart Each Time.

column1: Kirby's known for his adept way of flitting through contrasting styles
column2: tying on various genres as if he was trying on a new coat or hat. Crucially
column3: he's a picky dresser
column4: and one with a depth of knowledge and intuitive feel for the musical worlds he immerses himself in. There's not always a logical pattern to the paths he chooses
column5: but occasionally there's something resembling a handoff between one record to the next
column6: forming subtle links between his creations. The title track of this release peeks out from behind a blanket of fuzz that feels like a distant cousin to his Caretaker work
column7: although its innards are remarkably different. Here
column8: Kirby plays with elegance and antagonism
column9: the former represented by sheets of drifting synth
column10: and the latter emerging in the piston-like machinery stamped across its surface.

column1: Working in contrasts is something of a theme for Kirby—his V/VM output skewered bland pop on a spike
column2: while his Caretaker releases find light and dark impulses running through the grooves of scratchy old 78rpm records. His explorations here aren't so different
column3: with the minimal beauty of ""Diminishing Emotion"" picking up an undercurrent of isolationist fear as it slowly unravels. Breaks My Heart also deals in pure thrills. ""Staring Down the Sun"" is a dysfunctional club banger that expertly captures the feel of nascent computer music
column4: resembling a paean to the trials and tribulations of running Cubase on Windows 95
column5: its manic race to the finish resembling the panicked wait to see if a save button's progress bar can beat out a blue-screen meltdown. ""Last Ditch Legacy"" is similar
column6: but more joyous in execution
column7: skirting closer to the sunnier outlook of Mixmaster Morris's work for Apollo.

column1: Where Kirby succeeds on Breaks My Heart is by digging in hard to the era he's sourcing. He's working with a familiar sound palette here
column2: but it's more than simple tribute fare—there's a feel for the duality of emotions that runs through that early Apollo work
column3: whether it’s in the mixture of playfulness and sensitivity that runs through Ambient Works 85-92
column4: or in the way something like ""Stella's Cry"" by Jam & Spoon set up an optimistic buffer to the darker ambient dreams of a track like ""Cloudwalker II"" by Biosphere. There's a sense of care and affinity here
column5: of someone playing around with material that clearly means a lot to them. Naturally
column6: Kirby’s already moved on
column7: prepping another volume of his Intrigue & Stuff series and plotting a full-length release for Apollo in the not-too distant future. Here
column8:
he achieves the rare feat of demonstrating exactly how to emulate your heroes without becoming overawed in the process.

"|19010.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19010-leyland-kirby-breaks-my-heart-each-time/|7.2|Nick Neyland

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20199/homepage_large.083bc916.jpg|Blame Confusion|31876.0|Solids|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Possum']|2014-02-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:50.151493|"

Montreal's Solids operate at one of two speeds: pretty fast
column2: and stupid fast. The young duo's debut LP
column3: Blame Confusion
column4: is a gaussian blur
column5: 37 minutes of speed limit violation
column6: drawing equally on hardcore blister
column7: dream-punk
column8: and raucous cusp-of-the-1990s indie rock. But while Solids don't want for momentum
column9: between their relentless propulsion and the billowing reverb that envelops much of Blame Confusion
column10: they can sometimes lose the song amidst the static.

column1: Drummer Louis Guillemette and singer/guitarist Xavier Germain-Poitras' two-men-and-a-pedal-board set-up has a kindred spirit in No Age; not the tense
column2: peculiar No Age of last year's An Object
column3: but No Age at their most purely tuneful. You might even hear Blame Confusion as a kind of correction to the aggressively experimental An Object; it's something like a No Age record without the ambient passages or the rhythmic left-turns. The occasional rhythmic disruption or burst of static notwithstanding
column4: Blame Confusion mostly just goes
column5: breathlessly careening through its 10 songs at a mostly breakneck clip.

column1: But it's a lack of rising action that gets Blame Confusion into trouble. Whenever Guillemette gets a rhythm up to highway speed
column2: he punches the cruise control; once set
column3: tempos rarely dip
column4: or bend
column5: or do much of anything in the third minute they weren't already doing in the first. And Germain-Poitras' chugging riffs never seem to develop much over the course of these songs; he'll occasionally squeeze a gestural solo or a twinkly little outro into the mix
column6: but it's never quite bold enough to cut through the thick patina of fuzz hanging over Blame Confusion. Most of these songs fall into two categories:  ""Almost Crimes""-style bob-and-weavers like ""Laissez Faire"" or choppy punchers like ""Not Complaining."" But no matter which type of Solids song you find yourself listening to
column7: they're all pretty much the same: a driving—yet somehow static—rhythm
column8: a generous coating of feedback
column9: and a distortion-strangled Germain-Poitras vocal. Solids' perpetual motion would be well served by bolder melodies or trickier rhythms. But
column10: time and again
column11: they opt for a path that's too straight and awfully narrow.

column1: For his part
column2: Germain-Poitras tears into opener ""Over the Sirens"" and the revved-up ""Cold Hands"" like a phlegm-ridden Mac McCaughan. Sadly
column3: these outbursts are short lived. Germain-Poitras he sings most of the rest of Blame Confusion in a weary
column4: faintly stoned voice that frequently gets itself lost in the fog
column5: and his lyrics—from the school of generalized discontent—rarely seem to rise above the fray long enough to give you much to go on. Between its reverb-ensconced sonics
column6: its consistent rhythmic charge
column7: its borderline-nebulous melodies
column8: and Germain-Poitras' intermittently passionate
column9: infrequently audible vocals
column10: wide swaths of Blame Confusion quickly start to bleed together. And whether it's the moony near-ballad ""Haze Away"" or the all-too-infrequent squeal of a solo
column11: you'll probably find yourself clinging to anything on Blame Confusion resembling a break in the fuzz-coated monotony. The hard-driving Blame Confusion
column12: in too big a hurry to stop and take in the scenery
column13:
simply lets too much whoosh by in the periphery.

"|18995.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18995-solids-blame-confusion/|5.8|Paul Thompson

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20234/homepage_large.aacbeb7c.jpg|As The Stars|32078.0|Woods of Desolation|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Northern Silence']|2014-02-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:50.742337|"

Known as D.
column2: the musician behind Woods of Desolation has been a prolific member of the Australian metal community for years
column3: gaining notoriety for two now discontinued projects
column4: Forest Mysticism and Grey Waters (with Tim Yatras of Germ). Woods of Desolation’s catalog serves as a logical bridge between the rawer
column5: stripped-down black metal of Forest Mysticism and the atmospheric bummer rock tendencies of Grey Waters—the latter’s influence is given a place of honor on As the Stars. While the band’s always embraced black metal’s melodic potential
column6: the shift from depressive black metal toward something brighter and more refined has been underway for years. The sophomore album
column7: 2011’s Torn Beyond Reason
column8: toyed with shoegaze
column9: and now this third album rocks far more than it rages. That said
column10: As the Stars is still wonderfully atmospheric and melancholy in the deepest of ways.

column1: While Woods of Desolation is ostensibly a one-man operation
column2: D. has a history of collaboration. This album was created with the help of several musicians
column3: including Ukrainian drummer Vlad (Drudkh)
column4: and fellow Aussies bassist Luke Mills (Nazxul
column5: Pestilential Shadows) and vocalist Old of Drohtnung
column6: which left D. free to concentrate on those sublime ringing guitar tones that drive the album forward and upward. Post rock’s trademark tremulous builds and joyous crashing crescendos make up a huge part of the seven compositions
column7: lending a triumphal feel to the overarching despair.

column1: Shades of Katatonia’s mournful benchmark Brave Murder Day swim through the gloomy buildup on “This Autumn Light” and “Withering Field”
column2: while D unabashedly recalls Alcest’s earliest
column3: finest work with many of his more grandiose moments. Seminal Australian depressives Austere leave a mark as well
column4: but given that two members have also played in Woods of Desolation at various points
column5: it could almost be seen as more of a continuation than an outright homage. By now this style of “post black metal” could never be accused of outright originality (it’s all been done before
column6: circa 2007) but the listener is at least owed quality
column7: and Woods of Desolation are happy to deliver. As black metal’s edges continue to soften
column8: it’s heartening to come across a band like this who appreciates their roots but is utterly devoid of consternation about their stylistic decisions. Woods of Desolation have lightened up considerably since 2006
column9: but are living proof that not all progress need be disappointing. They’re far better now than they were then
column10: and As the Stars makes it clear that the band is fully aware of it.

column1: Despite his top shelf assistance
column2: this is still D.’s baby. Old’s vocals are robust and appropriately creaky and Vlad has clearly imparted a little bit of the magic from his main gig into those drum fills
column3: but D.’s virtuosic guitar playing is the primary focus. Sad melodies rendered in tremolo spill forth over a misty landscape of ghostly howls and crashing cymbals to conjure up beauties like “”Anamnesis” with its perky post-punk beat and closing paen “Ad Infinitum” which shines so brightly it feels more like a beginning than an end. The rough spots have been sanded down
column4: polished
column5: and allowed to sparkle
column6: and the result is intoxicating.

column1: Woods of Desolation is a name that should be on the lips of every fan and critic that went apeshit over Deafheaven last year. I’m not about to make a direct comparison between Antwon’s housemates or the fairy-blind French and Woods of Desolation
column2: though
column3: as it must be noted that the latter still stand comfortably within the black metal camp
column4: even with D.’s love for post rock and shoegaze. But it’s beautiful and devastating in that way that all the best albums are
column5:
and that in and of itself is worth some attention.

"|19029.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19029-woods-of-desolation-as-the-stars/|8.0|Kim Kelly

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20152/homepage_large.737a1388.jpg|Burn Your Fire for No Witness|29064.0|Angel Olsen|['Rock'
column2:
'Folk/Country']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2014-02-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:51.441617|"

“Hi-Five”
column3: the third song on Angel Olsen’s second album
column4: Burn Your Fire for No Witness
column5: has got to be one of the most cheerful songs ever written about being lonely. A twangy electric folk tune that begins with an invocation of its muse
column6: Hank Williams
column7: the song is all stomp-and-rollick until it stops to catch its breath for a moment in the bridge. “Are you lonely too?” Olsen warbles. A beat later
column8: her band’s back in full Technicolor
column9: and the next line hits like a title card in an old “Batman” episode: “HI-FIVE!/ SO AM I!”

column1: Olsen’s voice is enchanting; it sounds like the result of a spell that called for Leonard Cohen’s blood
column2: Buffy Sainte-Marie’s larynx
column3: and a still-operational old-timey microphone emblazoned with radio call letters. Her songs are powered by a strange
column4: anarchic electricity
column5: always flickering on the edge of blowing out. By the laws of the unique universe she creates on her records
column6: Wanting
column7: Waiting
column8: and (probably the most popular pastime in her songs) Thinking are not passive stances but active ways of being in the world; unruly emotion is a virtue. “You don’t sing so high and wild
column9: ” she sneers at one point to a detached lover
column10: and in an Angel Olsen song this is an insult so harsh it’s almost obscene. This guy may as well be dead.

column1: Olsen first gained notice as the stand-out eccentric in Bonnie “Prince” Billy’s mysterious band the Babblers (given that all six of them were known perform in hooded pajamas and sunglasses
column2: this is saying something). In 2010
column3: she released an arresting tape on Bathetic called Strange Cacti
column4: which gave off the impression that she’d recorded it after falling down a well
column5: trying to sing loudly and cavernously and urgently enough to be found. And she was
column6: more or less—her cult following multiplied with the release of 2012’s excellent Half Way Home
column7: a surreal and lyrical collection of folk songs that sounded a bit like Vashti Bunyan playing a midnight game of Ouija. Most of the songs on Half Way Home were driven by Olsen’s hushed acoustic guitar
column8: so her 2013 single “Sweet Dreams” was a thrilling left turn—a swirling
column9: psych-pop reverie. To overpower the percussion and charred electric guitars
column10: she sang even wilder.

column1: Burn Your Fire for No Witness picks up where “Sweet Dreams” left off
column2: blossoming into a fuller
column3: louder sound and embracing punchier song structures. It’s not as weird or raw a record as Half Way Home
column4: but producer John Congleton manages to sand the rough edges off Olsen’s music without quite taming it. She and her band (Joshua Jaeger on drums and Stewart Bronaugh on bass and guitar) talk to each other effortlessly: On the great lead-off single “Fogiven/Forgotten”
column5: the kick drum accents her open-hearted declarations like expertly placed exclamation points (“I don’t know anything!/ But I love you!”)
column6: and as the energy of “Lights Out” mounts
column7: she passes the baton to Bronaugh for a perfectly timed solo. The blown-out
column8: full-band energy enlivens Olsen
column9: kindling an intensity that’s always been present in her songs and fanning the flames even higher.

column1: On repeated listens
column2: subtler highlights emerge. ""Enemy"" hangs like a spiderweb in the album's quietest corridor—an intricate wisp of a song that she patiently spins into something hallowed and heartbreaking. Then there’s “White Fire”
column3: a sparse
column4: nearly seven-minute incantation that sounds like a lost Songs of Leonard Cohen cut but gradually accumulates an atmosphere of its own. When Olsen switches into ballad mode
column5: she fares best with hushed
column6: minimal arrangements. The echoing percussion and shimmering chords of “Dance Slow Decades” cloak the song in a relatively ill-fitting grandeur; the demo is probably more of a gut-punch. Same goes for the indistinct closer “Window”
column7: which sounds a bit too much like someone trying to write a Feist song. Still
column8: that last one feels like such an anomaly that it only underscores how distinct Olsen’s songwriting is across the rest of the record. Burn Your Fire for No Witness conjures the past without ever imitating it
column9: swirling its influences into something intimate
column10: impressionistic and new.

column1: “I wish it were the same as it is in my mind
column2: ” Olsen laments in “Enemy”; this is pretty much the central conflict in every Angel Olsen song. The people she writes about daydream vividly
column3: mumble reassuring mantras to themselves (""Some days all you need is one good thought strong in your mind"")
column4: and get so caught up in the songs stuck in their heads that they accidentally walk past their own houses. And yet
column5: even as she longs for deep connections and hi-fives from strangers
column6: Olsen knows too well that dreamers are usually loners. Not that she really minds. If she seems unafraid of—even superhumanly amped about—loneliness
column7: it’s because her songs find an almost beatific peace in solitude. “If you can’t be psyched about your own thoughts
column8: ” she said in an interview a few years ago
column9: “Then how are you supposed to have a meaningful interaction with anyone?” It’s a point she’s carried over into her music
column10:
honed in seclusion but now ready for more people to bear witness to its peculiar charms.

"|18956.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18956-angel-olsen-burn-your-fire-for-no-witness/|8.3|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20235/homepage_large.dc1fb364.jpg|The Soul Is Quick|32026.0|Hands|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ecstatic']|2014-02-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:51.996163|"

Axel Willner likes to get locked down in a feeling
column2: creating music so tightly constricted it resembles an immovable force that's had him pinned down for much of his career. His work as the Field is all bright gestures condensed into minimal shapes
column3: executed with an adherence to repetition that's so single-minded it's hard not to wonder what listening to it over and over again during its conception must do to his brain. Hands is a new project from Willner that offers an escape from the lack of space in his music as the Field
column4: if not from the ever-recurring patterns. It broadly fits into the plague-like spread of darker sounds across the electronic underground. If the Field is all vivid colors
column5: Hands never makes it past monotone grey. Billed as a noise project
column6: Hands actually has more in common with musicians taking subtle cues from noise and expanding them into other spaces
column7: such as the night terrors of Demdike Stare or the cloudier L.I.E.S. material.

column1: Something Willner revealed about this four-track release is that it was recorded before last year's Field album
column2: Cupid's Head
column3: which might explain that LP's tormented bent at times. Although nothing there gets as murky as The Soul Is Quick
column4: where a bank of fog rolls in from the offset and only leaves in the dying minutes of the final track. Each composition here is an episodic offshoot of the title ""Beelitz-Heilstätten""
column5: a Berlin sanatorium and tuberculosis clinic that counts Adolf Hitler among its most famous patients
column6: and Rammstein among clients seeking a suitably grim backdrop for filmed work. It's split into four parts
column7: but the joins between ""Pt. 6"" and ""Pt. 7"" are barely perceptible
column8: while the second pairing (""Pt. 10"" and ""Pt. 11"") offer only tiny forward motions throughout. Willner clearly likes going nowhere regardless of the form his music takes.

column1: Much of the space created in the The Soul Is Quick feels tangible
column2: resembling a place Willner has created to retreat into. When voices emerge toward the end of the final track it's both disturbing and startling
column3: making it feel like there are others trapped down here with him
column4: wandering amid his soupy drones. ""Hello? Hello?"" a panicked voice cries at one point
column5: pitching it close to the helplessly lost vocal samples Burial deploys on his Rival Dealer EP. It's an effective way of closing out the trail of loneliness that sluggishly routes through this music like a prisoner dragging a ball and chain across a dusty yard. Willner finds some kind of comfort in dead weight—on ""Pt. 6"" and ""Pt. 7"" the overall feel is one of being overcome
column6: of things closing in around him. It's among the saddest music he's made
column7: although there is a lighter touch at times
column8: with ""Pt. 10"" gaining a lighter hue as it picks up a filmy rhythm a third of the way through.

column1: The softer
column2: gentler tones that Willner brings into this music further distance it from the ""noise"" bracket Hands has mystifyingly been shunted into. When this collection of tracks begins it's more in line with the crestfallen leanings of Flying Saucer Attack’s earlier work
column3: in particular ""Oceans"" from Distance
column4: which also triggers drones tinged with a strange duality
column5: where beauty and thunder sit uneasily across the table from one another. For someone who doesn't change much
column6: at least in his guise as the Field
column7: there are strides being taken here
column8: lending a sense of latent potential being fulfilled after years of being boxed into a much smaller corner. Nothing much happens in The Soul Is Quick—it's possible to wander in and out
column9: picking up a thread you left dangling a few minutes before. That's where Willner excels
column10: in creating these supple moments where you can get totally enveloped in what he's doing
column11: or check out from the world for a while
column12:
or just leave him running in the background and marvel at how slowly he moves through time when your focus returns to him.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20200/homepage_large.27684d3d.jpg|Somewhere Else|32052.0|Lydia Loveless|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bloodshot']|2014-02-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:52.648264|"

In the first song on her third full-length
column2: Somewhere Else
column3: Lydia Loveless goes to a party
column4: does some blow
column5: calls up an ex
column6: and tries to break up his marriage. A few songs later
column7: she compares herself to Paul Verlaine
column8: the 19th-century French poet whose relationship with the teenage Arthur Rimbaud was notoriously violent. On another song
column9: our heroine drinks herself to sleep while dreaming of an old lover and his talents between the sheets. Never leery of casting herself as the homewrecker
column10: the other woman
column11: or the spurned lover
column12: Loveless writes lyrics that are frank (“I just like it so much better when we’re coming to blows”) and often explicit (“Don’t stop giving me head”). Her songs are based in country
column13: but she tweaks the forms and formulas of the genre with a bleary belligerence that is
column14: more often than not
column15: directed at herself. Her self-destructive streak makes Somewhere Else both a bracing and a deeply harrowing listen.

column1: Loveless hails from Columbus
column2: Ohio
column3: and she's so far the most visible member of a very musical family: Both sisters are in local groups
column4: and before she had to fire him
column5: her dad played drums in her backing band. After a slick debut and a more countrified follow-up on Bloodshot Records (which earned her a shout-out from Richard Hell)
column6: Somewhere Else sounds like the lyrical and musical culmination of a short career spent kicking at the conventions of alt-country. The album takes more risks than its predecessors did
column7: showcasing a rough-and-tumble bar-band sound that dispenses with the twang in favor of barbed guitars and rowdy rock rumble. Loveless and her band recall the West Coast cowpunk attitude of early 80s acts like Lone Justice
column8: plus the sexual candor of heyday Liz Phair.

column1: Loveless’ frankness threatens to make a her a novelty
column2: but there’s some sharp humor and deep hurt here. “When I was 17 I'd follow men around with my head jammed way in their ass
column3: ” she sings on “Chris Isaak”
column4: and it sounds ridiculous. Fortunately the next line is
column5: “Oh
column6: what I wouldn’t give to still be able to conjure up energy like that”—which implies that making a wreck of your life is preferable to doing nothing at all with it. Even as Somewhere Else descends into romantic mania
column7: Loveless keeps her wits about her. She sings “Head”
column8: arguably the album’s best and most urgent track
column9: as though her despair had turned sexual. Loveless storms into the chorus
column10: turning the repeated lines into a potent hook and delivering an abrasive guitar solo that conveys what the lyrics cannot.

column1: Perhaps Loveless knows she needs to find a better hero than Verlaine
column2: who remains the epitome of tortured-soul creativity
column3: yet on “Verlaine Shot Rimbaud” she craves the heady inspiration as much as the violent intensity of affection: “I just wanna know that I'm the one that makes you write that shit.” Halfway between French Romantic and Nashville outlaw
column4: Loveless’ songwriting can come across sometimes as overly bleak and therefore sensationalistic
column5: yet Somewhere Else makes such boldness a virtue
column6: as thought decorum blunts creative expression. So it’s all the more curious that the album ends with an upbeat cover of Kirsty MacColl’s postpunk/girl-group anthem “They Don’t Know”
column7: a song about romance as a form of rebellion. Loveless doesn’t radically depart from the original
column8: retaining the structure
column9: tempo
column10: tone
column11: even the exclamation of “Baby!” halfway through. As a B-side or even a mid-album track
column12: such a modest interpretation might be negligible
column13: but after so many songs about tortured relationships and roiling regret
column14: the song is almost triumphal as a closer
column15: especially when Loveless testifies
column16: “Now that I’ve found good love
column17: I’m gonna make it last.” Then again
column18: “They” might as well be “You
column19: ” as Loveless perhaps suspects her audience of tsk-tsking her love life. She doesn’t need your concern
column20:
just your ears. 

"|18996.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18996-lydia-loveless-somewhere-else/|7.3|Stephen M. Deusner

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20233/homepage_large.54ab10fe.jpg|Dizzy Heights|1491.0|Neil Finn|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kobalt'
column2:
'Lester']|2014-02-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:52.837617|"

It’s been a dozen years since Neil Finn’s last solo album
column3: but that means next to nothing. In the time between 2002’s One All and the new Dizzy Heights
column4: the New Zealander has released three Crowded House records
column5: one Finn Brothers full-length
column6: a record with Aussie singer-songwriter Paul Kelly
column7: a Split Enz live album
column8: and a collection of songs by his global side project 7 Worlds Collide
column9: which brought artists from all over the world (but mainly England and America) to New Zealand for a few informal sessions. Age has not
column10: obviously
column11: slowed him down
column12: as Finn refuses to spend his 50s doling out event releases
column13: intimate small-club tours
column14: or—god forbid—more career retrospectives.

column1: Also
column2: Dizzy Heights is solo by default. He may get his name on the spine
column3: but Neil is backed by a small army of Finns: His wife Sharon plays bass
column4: while sons Liam and Elroy play guitar and drums. (Brother Tim
column5: however
column6: takes a breather this time around.) The abundance of family here is almost a corrective to the presence of Dave Fridmann
column7: a fine but occasionally overbearing producer whose imprint on Dizzy Heights is evident in the fuzzy low end of the title track
column8: the tendrils of guitar that creep out of “Impressions”
column9: and the percussive synths on “White Lies and Alibis”. At times he seems to be as much of a guiding personality as Finn himself—or at the very least a collaborator. But really
column10: who’s keeping score? Rather than a blah album of retrospective singer-songwriter fare
column11: which Finn has shown he can do in his sleep
column12: Dizzy Heights is an album of sunny psychedelia and woozy pop grandeur.

column1: Whether it’s the narcotized R&B on opener “Impressions” or the cough-syrup showtunery of “Lights of New York”
column2: the production gently coaxes the songs into new shapes
column3: which makes this an ambitiously wide-ranging entry into Finn’s sprawling catalog. Sonically
column4: the album strives to live up to its title
column5: and its sequencing emphasizes vertiginous shifts in style and sound. Following the aerodynamic pace of “Flying in the Face of Love”
column6: with its full-band sound and bass-forward groove
column7: Dizzy Heights transitions into the darkly spare
column8: deeply tense “Divebomber”
column9: which nicely tweaks those aviation-themed lyrics. As the song lifts off
column10: Finn’s only accompaniment is the sound of jet engines
column11: a literal but effective manifestation of the song’s central metaphor. Musically
column12: it recalls some of the sound collages Pink Floyd assembled on The Wall and The Final Cut
column13: yet the song summons a strange and specific sense of foreboding even before Finn and Fridmann unleash the bombastic strings.

column1: The emphasis here is clearly on sound over song
column2: as Finn and Fridmann are more fascinated by texture than lyrics or even melodies. Often the vocals are buried deep within the production
column3: another instrument in the family’s formidable arsenal. That’s not necessarily a complaint either. An exceptional melodist
column4: Finn is not always a precise and exacting lyricist
column5: and he addresses only hazy conceptions of “love” and “loss” throughout Dizzy Heights
column6: dropping a few clunkers along the way. Possibly the worst: “C’mon
column7: baby
column8: I want your love to be/ based in real life
column9: better than TV.” Or
column10: maybe “I think Howard Hughes would love to be on the internet.” And yet
column11: as a singer he’s a strange and compelling presence on this album
column12: with a strong falsetto on “Recluse” and loose
column13: off-the-cuff delivery on the title track. Finn sounds best when Dizzy Heights is at its dizziest
column14: when he has to completely rethink how his voice fits a song. On the other hand
column15: he sounds slightly less engaged on the more straightforward tunes
column16: which perhaps don’t offer the same heady challenges. Either way
column17: this is not the singer-songwriter album you’d expect from him at this stage in his career
column18:
for better or for worse.

"|19028.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19028-neil-finn-dizzy-heights/|6.9|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20198/homepage_large.9cda6f65.jpg|Cheatahs|28209.0|Cheatahs|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Wichita']|2014-02-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:53.510590|"

If you equate ambition with novelty and invention
column2: Cheatahs’ self-titled debut sets the bar as low as any record you’ll hear in 2014. Though the multinational
column3: UK-based quartet works within a very narrow stylistic range on Cheatahs
column4: there’s no specific genre that defines it so much as a time frame. You know when you hear it
column5: you heard it perfected sometime between 1990 and 1994 and it really hasn’t gone anywhere since. You’ll get lots of shoegaze
column6: squalling indie rock and good ol’ alt-rock in various ratios
column7: and every single sound on Cheatahs is taken from that span
column8: with two exceptions: there’s a tiny riff throughout “Fall” that’s a verbatim pull from Wheat’s “Breathe” or Caribou's ""Skunks"" and the coda on “The Swan” could pass for Interpol’s “PDA"". Otherwise
column9: if Cheatahs hadn’t ruined the illusion by performing live and everything
column10: you could conceivably posit this record as an Avalanches sample collage that limited itself to a college radio station’s playlist during the bridge to the Clinton era.

column1: Then again
column2: any fan of kung fu movies or hamburgers know that novelty and invention aren’t required to make a genre exercise enjoyable. Yes
column3: the guitars and Nathan Hewitt’s bedheaded vocals sit entirely within a Moore-Mascis-Shields triangulation
column4: and the bass is almost never as loud as it could be. So Cheatahs distinguish themselves with mundane
column5: crucial songwriting choices—play the oldies a little faster than you remember
column6: throw in a melody you haven’t quite heard yet. The fundamentals of shoegaze facilitate the latter
column7: as its predilection for altered tunings makes it easy to come across unusual chords and progressions. Meanwhile
column8: the saturated distortion and slow-release vocals make these modulations much smoother than they’d otherwise be if played clean. And so it’s not the velocity of “Geographic” that makes it so instantly appealing
column9: nor is it the volume
column10: but rather the way it handles the curves.

column1: Otherwise
column2: Cheatahs derives its pleasures from recall that’s instantaneous
column3: but not specific. There’s a trebly
column4: ascending arpeggio on “Mission Creep” and you can’t quite place the exact Ride song you heard it on
column5: so hey
column6: it’s like a new “old Ride” song! Ditto for the gelatinous chords on “Leave to Remain” that weren’t on Isn’t Anything or Loveless
column7: maybe it was one of the EPs you missed out on. You know Swervedriver were supposed to strap shoegaze ‘cross some engines
column8: but if you never actually heard their music
column9: then you can rest comfortably thinking “Get Tight” is probably what they sounded like.

column1: Because we should be real here: if any of those names are unfamiliar to you
column2: there’s a good chance you weren’t checking for Cheatahs in the first place. Along with parallel revivalists Jagwar Ma
column3: Eagulls and Temples
column4: they’ve proven that conjuring a certain bygone
column5: guitarcentric era of UK rock can be enough to make a debut “highly anticipated.” And by offering these small tweaks
column6: they can still offer a real pleasure and a new way to experience this incredibly familiar music
column7: sort of like your long-time partner deciding to use a slightly different kind of body soap.

column1: Yet
column2: knowing something that small could make a big difference
column3: it’s disappointing to realize that Cheatahs barely try to make any sort of meaningful alteration to what came before. Most of their kind don’t either
column4: but the best use shoegaze as a bridge or an off ramp. For example
column5: Yuck’s debut continues to gain stature for having successfully connected Dinosaur Jr. with Teenage Fanclub and Elliott Smith; that is not an easy task. On Ghost Blonde
column6: No Joy simply played louder than everyone else
column7: and by last year’s Wait to Pleasure
column8: it merged Lush with Siouxsie
column9: Cocteaus and the Cure. There are many passages on Cheatahs resembling those of DIIV’s Oshin
column10: which drove shoegaze backwards into post-punk and ambient.

column1: Cheatahs allow you to namecheck the Drop Nineteens for the first time in at least a decade
column2: but that’s about it. They’re hardly alone
column3: as this style of music is about as puritanical as it gets—you don’t hear any bands cutting this sound with hip-hop or folk
column4: nor has there ever been any explicitly political shoegaze band to my knowledge. It’s an ego-decimating genre that never really had much space for personality. Maybe Cheatahs are just confident that an enjoyable genre piece is more than enough or maybe you just want to get the sounds of Loveless or Nowhere or Souvlaki without having to acknowledge the baggage. And so
column5: Cheatahs might not be a very ambitious record
column6:
but it is kinda ballsy.

"|18994.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18994-cheetahs-cheatahs/|6.5|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20229/homepage_large.61f141ec.jpg|Adhesive|30923.0|Container|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Liberation Technologies']|2014-02-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:54.137994|"

Working at the crossroads of techno and noise
column2: Container's Ren Schofield has released two albums—both titled LP—that prove his music as wily and elusive as it is brutal and unyielding. Last year saw him release an EP on the Venice-based experimental label Morphine Records. Adhesive
column3: a new four-track EP
column4: once again finds Shofield crossing the pond
column5: this time via Liberation Technologies
column6: a Mute sub-label that to date has traded mostly in techno's darker arts
column7: including a resurrecting Surgeon's long-running side project
column8: British Murder Boys. Schofield's most realized work yet
column9: Adhesive's four tracks are simultaneously giddy and rotten
column10: boggling techno's customary propulsion with lingering
column11: heady rhythms and puzzling clamor.

column1: Most purveyors of noisy machine music use the rhythm section to propel a song
column2: with oversaturated bass drums and deteriorating snare cracks spurring the track forward
column3: but also grounding it. Schofield's best pieces avoid this
column4: relying on buoyant
column5: tricky rhythms
column6: albeit those built from the same sonic material as those of his peers. Most techno operates on a linear plane
column7: pummeling forward at all costs; Schofield music hovers menacingly. The kick drum on ""Complex"" knocks around eighth notes in a pattern that most resembles krautrock's motorik rhythm. ""Slush"" offers its kicks in a hypnotic fury. The title track's double-time crash stirs up a lot of dust but doesn't actually go anyplace. This is techno re-imagined as a car unable to rev itself out of a snow bank: the total bafflement of violent
column8: kinetic energy.

column1: Schofield fills out his compositions with all manner of rhythmic noise
column2: never settling on anything as gauche as a lead melody. Instead we're treated to ""Complex""'s hoary synthesizer pulse and ""Glaze""'s whinnying gashes of distortion. It's in these elements that Schofield's roots as a noise artist show. Nothing on Adhesive feels generative or truly random
column3: but there's not a lot of organization either—storms of noise bristle against a brooding
column4: muscular concentration of drums. ""Glaze""
column5: especially
column6: is a thrilling track whose thumping kick drums form something of a hook
column7: requiring one of Schofield's finest little pots of chaos to distract your attention.

column1: There's a playfulness to Adhesive that belies the nature of its sounds—still scraped-knee burn—and sets the EP apart from Schofield's previous work. Adhesive sounds more fully formed
column2: less home-cooked than LP
column3: and while that record's ragamuffin noise was part of its charm
column4: Schofield is potent and mischievous enough to succeed even as he better understands what he's doing. There's plenty of clamor to be found here
column5: but Schofield deploys it to disorient
column6: not menace. Most techno is futuristic
column7: or dystopian
column8: or both; Adhesive is oddly present
column9:
content to bash around in its treehouse and happy that anyone might want to stop by.

"|19024.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19024-container-adhesive/|8.0|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20197/homepage_large.3f2e3305.jpg|A Place That Doesn't Exist|30155.0|Willis Earl Beal|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hot Charity']|2014-02-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:54.641056|"

Willis Earl Beal is the kind of guy who doesn’t need a rudder
column2: the kind of guy who will push off into unknown waters just to see what’s out there. His atypical origin story doesn’t peg him as an outsider artist in the traditional sense—releasing an EP on your SoundCloud page usually precludes one from being labeled an outsider artist—but more importantly Beal defines himself as an outsider through his hermetic music. Like
column3: say
column4: Jandek
column5: Beal dislodges himself from culture
column6: and stays unimpeded by form
column7: fidelity
column8: or trends. It is so far what has made every Beal record such a joy to listen to.

column1: The joy from this free A Place That Doesn’t Exist EP isn’t always from the music on it—though there are some quite brilliant moments—but more so from the plot development in Beal’s career. The leap from busted lo-fi recordings on Acousmatic Sorcery to having XL (Adele’s label) put out the well polished Nobody knows. was a whiplash move. This EP is not a full retraction of his major label sound
column2: but Beal takes several deep breaths in order to make smaller music. The songs here rely less on bluesy moans to convey emotion.

column1: Similarities between Tom Waits and Beal are duly noted
column2: but where Waits can come across like a charlatan narrator of the wacky carnival of life
column3: Beal more often is a part of the carnival. Mythical beginnings notwithstanding
column4: what draws people to Beal is how well he hawks his kind of anachronism. You almost believe that the intrusive record static found throughout the record was something Alan Lomax did his best to try to remove. Most of the songs on the EP feature a mid-fi Beal working firmly in the folk medium
column5: giving the songs a macabre baroque feel to it. Think Bert Jansch if he always wore a cape and cowl. “Bright Copper Noon” is one of the first Beal compositions that benches his voice to a broken waltz thick with synths
column6: but “Babble On” inverts the whole thing
column7: and keeps the fingerpicked lounge-folk behind Beal’s double-tracked soul tenor.

column1: All the instrumentation and arrangements sound like they're clogging Beal’s id. There’s nothing quite so primal
column2: so sexually explicit as ""Too Dry To Cry"" or as revealing as “Evening’s Kiss” so everything here comes out a bit heady and knock-kneed. This leads to new forms
column3: like “The Axeman” a story about a tiny figurine that haunts Beal until he decides to set it on fire. The storytelling frame makes it more an exemplum of Beals’ demented nature
column4: like a preacher moralizing about his own lost soul in a parable of what not to do if you think your toys are silently mocking you.

column1: No
column2: Beal’s fringe side comes out directly on the antagonist “Toilet Parade (Ode To NYC)”
column3: which
column4: for its titular accuracy
column5: is kind of a bummer in its faux performance art execution. The half-hour EP closes with two spoken-word performances
column6: one tender (“Hazel Eyes”) and one very much not. The final track literally speaks to Beal's obsession with being a 21st century nowhere man. In a spirited monologue
column7: with a cadence somewhere between a mystic sidewalk preacher and a character on campy sci-fi TV show
column8: Beal describes the curled
column9: uncanny objects in his world: heat rashes
column10: floating red lights
column11: skinflint pirate ladies. It all leads to the end
column12: a condemnation of the academic industrial complex: “School is for me another useless
column13: required step on the road to a place that does not exist.”

column1: It’s exciting
column2: though it certainly doesn’t jive with the nocturnal vibe of the rest of the album. Beal’s obsession with being “nobody” from “nowhere” isn’t a bid for anonymity and mysteriousness
column3: it’s more an anxiety and separation from the world. Ironically
column4: it's an anxiety stemming from not being on the outside. Is this angst a key to why he’s hiding behind more instrumentation
column5: why his carnal growl is absent through the album? Is that why this latest offering is so mannered and scattered? There’s enough mystery baked in his songs he really doesn’t need the “outsider” label. And by the joy in plot development I mean that Beal
column6: like the prolific Waits and Jandek before him
column7: will hopefully be known more for the final shape of his trajectory as an artist. If the end path is as fascinating and demented as the individual mile markers
column8:
it’s all we can hope for.

"|18993.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18993-willis-earl-beal-a-place-that-doesnt-exist/|6.6|Jeremy D. Larson

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20134/homepage_large.efc00446.jpg|Acoustic at the Ryman|632.0|Band of Horses|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brown'
column3: Acoustic at the Ryman can't be just a simple live album
column4: as that storied concert hall in Nashville carries far too much cultural and historical baggage. Band of Horses played a two-night stand there in April 2013
column5: and their decision to unplug their electric guitars in favor of acoustic suggests a knowledge of the venue's long life as the home of country music. It's certainly an impressive name on the album cover
column6: and definitely the most compelling aspect of this pallid set. Seemingly intended to legitimize the band's music—specifically
column7: their two most recent albums of diminishing-returns bro rock—the venue conjures up a very specific musical legacy that Band of Horses simply cannot live up to.

column1: The red-brick tabernacle on Fifth Avenue in Nashville was built in 1892
column2: but it wasn’t known as the Ryman Auditorium until the 1900s
column3: when it was renamed after a local businessman
column4: saloon proprietor
column5: and riverboat captain. It wasn’t known for country music
column6: however
column7: until 40 years later: The Grand Ole Opry radio show relocated to that space when it outgrew nearby War Memorial Auditorium. Broadcast hundreds of miles in every direction
column8: the show became so popular that the Ryman was soon identified as the home of country music—or
column9: as it is currently billed
column10: the “mother church.” The country music industry
column11: if not necessarily the music itself
column12: eventually outgrew the venue
column13: and in the early 1970s
column14: the Opry moved to a theme park outside of Nashville
column15: which held more fans in its megachurch-like auditorium. For two decades
column16: the Ryman sat downtown empty and neglected
column17: and was nearly torn down. Thanks to the efforts of local artists and fans—including Emmylou Harris
column18: who filmed a series of concerts there in the early 1990s—the building was refurbished and reopened as a concert hall and museum
column19: its rustic ambience and wooden pews providing a stark contrast to the hermetic confines of Opryland.

column1: Especially in a town that saw young hat acts displacing established artists
column2: the Ryman became a local symbol of the industry’s neglect of its own legacy. In some ways
column3: the venue is a sanctuary not unlike Preservation Hall in New Orleans or the Old Town School of Folk Music in Chicago
column4: where certain ideals survive alongside the music. But its emphasis on country has broadened to include all types of what is now considered Americana and roots music. Neil Young and Erasure both recorded concerts there in the 2000s
column5: and the stage has hosted younger acts like Coldplay
column6: Mumford & Sons
column7: and Wilco.

column1: Recording an album at the Ryman—and branding the record as such—signals a certain populism that Ben Bridwell and the band have embraced awkwardly over the last few years and albums. They didn’t “sell out
column2: ” necessarily
column3: but by trying to puncture indie rock’s notorious insularity
column4: they’ve shed the eccentricities that once defined and distinguished them. Nowadays they sound more America than Americana. Their reverence for the venue explains the acoustic set-up
column5: which makes Acoustic a pretty wan live souvenir
column6: alternately granola-crunchy and sappy-soggy. Aside from the rich sound of the room—which subtly mimics the vocal reverb Band of Horses was known for ca. 2006—there’s not much in the music that nods to the venue or screams “country music
column7: ” and that’s fine. Preferable even
column8: as who wants to hear Band of Horses play “Ring of Fire”? But the Ryman—or at least the idea of the Ryman—does reinforce the self-seriousness of Bridwell’s songwriting
column9: which means lyrics of “Factory” and “Slow Cruel Hands of Time” sound even hokier here than they did on the studio albums. Worst is (still) “Neighbor”
column10: which is sort of The Room of folk rock songs. But at least Tommy Wiseau never endorsed hackeysack anarchy or wrote a line like “Now if Bartles & Jaymes didn’t need no first names/ We could live by our own laws in favor.” Sung a cappella at the Ryman
column11: it all sounds so much more ridiculous.

column1: Acoustic has all the ponderousness of a forgotten episode of MTV Unplugged
column2: and that setting only highlights Band of Horses’ worst tendencies. “Slow Cruel Hands of Time” and “Detlef Schrempf” sound ambitiously dour
column3: the heavy mood sucking all the air out of the songs. “Wicked Gil”
column4: an upbeat number from Everything All the Time
column5: gets slowed down to a shambling pace that replaces its urgent hook and tangle of guitars with a kind of aw-shucks resignation: “I know evil people will say things
column6: ” Bridwell sings like he’s throwing up his hands. On the other hand
column7: more recent songs like “Slow Cruel Hands” and “Factory” were downbeat to begin with
column8: so they just sound redundant in this setting. And if you’ve ever wondered what “The Funeral” might sound like hunted-and-pecked on a piano
column9: you’re in luck
column10: I guess.

column1: Acoustic sounds like the culmination of a H.O.R.D.E.-ward trajectory Band of Horses have been tracing since their second release: beefing up their sound
column2: abandoning the outsize moments that distinguished their debut
column3: yet maintaining that same I-love-you-man rock romanticism. It’s either the most depressing career arc or the greatest indie-rock trolling of the twenty-first century. Coming at the nadir of that trajectory
column4: Acoustic sounds shot through with a weird desperation
column5: or perhaps a hope that the venue will lend these songs some gravity and legitimacy. It doesn’t. It can’t. On this live album
column6:
the Ryman is just a room with good acoustics. 

"|18938.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18938-band-of-horses-acoustic-at-the-ryman/|3.6|Stephen M. Deusner

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20194/homepage_large.96cf2f26.jpg|All Love's Legal|4850.0|Planningtorock|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Human Level']|2014-02-14 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:56.639836|"

Planningtorock's message of gender equality and sexual freedom on All Love's Legal seems simplistic and dated at first. But in 2014
column3: the simplest messages are often the most urgent ones. Western media coverage of the Sochi Oympics has brought attention to Russian anti-gay violence and legislation. But we're also sharing a planet with at least five countries where even vaguely defined homosexual behavior is worthy of the death penalty. Jam Rostron
column4: the multimedia artist behind Planningtorock
column5: sings ""You can't illegalize love"" on the title track on All Love's Legal. That slogan could fit on a t-shirt
column6: but that's not necessarily a bad thing. Nuance isn't translating so well today.

column1: Rostron's musical work
column2: a kind of art-house house
column3: has always been a smart platform for direct intentions. Her debut album Have It All laid down the small set of tools—violin
column4: keyboards
column5: drum machine
column6: heavily processed vocals—that she would also use on her followup W. Setting aside Rostron's collaboration with the Knife
column7: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13974-tomorrow-in-a-year/"" target=""_blank""><i>Tomorrow
column8: in a Year
column9: she's only gotten better at the balance. On All Love's Legal she refines further
column10: adding or subtracting beats and strings until finding the right tension between her unambiguous gender politics and her unknowable voice.

column1: Despite the sparse instrumentation and arrangement
column2: Rostron's songs evoke huge
column3: cavernous spaces. By manipulating the attack and echo on her strings and synths
column4: she creates the clouds of theatrical fog that cling to the melody on ""Human Drama"". You can hear the empty stage surrounding her. The bass and drums songs
column5: like ""Misogyny Drop Dead"" and ""All Love's Legal""
column6: drift out of sync
column7: tugging at each other and galloping separately. Even the most straightforward dance track
column8: the irresistibly in-sync ""Let’s Talk About Gender Baby""
column9: feels off
column10: but in a good way. Rostron repeats the titular phrase over her usual brooding bass line
column11: but she extends the syllables a little too long
column12: slurring her words on either the world's most self-aware dancefloor or your college's drunkest women's studies discussion section.

column1: Even artists that resist sex and gender classification will adopt genre conventions when making their music. Putting aside the creator
column2: the lyrics
column3: or even the voice
column4: there's something that seems unidentifiable in All Love's Legal. The instrumentation is neither pretty nor ugly
column5: human or not human
column6: masculine nor feminine. Rather than trading on identification (""I'm just like you
column7: you're just like me!"")
column8: Rostron opts for alienation. It's a bold strategy—the impersonality of the music prohibits anyone from rejecting the message and accepting the messenger. There's no distinction between the two.

column1: All Love's Legal isn't as bleak as all that
column2: though. There's an organic
column3: humanistic ethos operating behind her music: we are all people
column4: and we're all moved by the same primal passions and stimuli. Planningtorock as a multimedia project is committed to pushing that idea as far as it can go. It's undanceable dance music sung by an arid
column5: semi-digitized voice. It asks you to abandon the kind of categorical thinking that divides man from woman and gay from straight. This sounds like the kind of message that pop music has come to embrace. But rather than deliver that message in an instantly metabolized treacle-pop ballad or an arena-ready club anthem
column6: Rostron's music demands that you confront what abandoning deeply-entrenched ways of thinking about gender and desire would actually feel like—it doesn't sound too comfortable
column7: and it shouldn't. (This is
column8: by the way
column9: the ocean that separates ""Same Love"" from Planningtorock's ""Public Love"".) Gender may be a ""lie
column10: as Rostron sings on ""Human Drama""
column11: but it's a lie that
column12: for most people
column13: rests at the core of our sense of self. So if we're truly going to come together
column14: Rostron seems to say
column15:
we're going to have to come undone first.

"|18990.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18990-planningtorock-all-loves-legal/|7.5|Jessica Suarez

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20226/homepage_large.446eb5c0.jpg|Est...Folle|1532.0|Brigitte Fontaine|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Superior Viaduct']|2014-02-14 00:00:00|1968|2016-06-11 16:47:57.192135|"

Three years ago
column2: I found myself conducting a phone interview with Beck Hansen about 1960s French music
column3: his disinterest audible over the line. But at the mention of the curious French chanteuse (as well as novelist
column4: actress
column5: playwright
column6: and poet) Brigitte Fontaine and her decades-long musical collaboration with Kabyle musician Areski Belkacem
column7: he noticeably brightened. That Hansen was a fan of the singular musical vision enacted by Fontaine and Belkacem was obvious
column8: and in terms of 90s alt-rock icons
column9: he was not alone: Fontaine’s oeuvre was a touchstone for the likes of Sonic Youth (Fontaine’s vocal affect and influence can clearly be heard in Kim Gordon’s songs)
column10: Björk
column11: Jarvis Cocker
column12: and Stereolab
column13: to name but a few.

column1: And yet only with these recent reissues of Fontaine’s groundbreaking third and fourth albums—1968’s Est…Folle and 1971’s Comme à La Radio—is her music domestically available in the US. By the time Fontaine made her recorded debut in 1965
column2: she was already a published playwright and actress
column3: appearing on numerous Parisian stages. Nearly 30 years of age by the time of the release of her breakout third album
column4: Fontaine was a world away from French pop music’s stables of Yé-Yé girls
column5: hewing slightly closer to the brooding chanson of Jacques Brel. Drawing on her experimental theatrical background
column6: she began penning songs that abandoned standard pop rhyme schemes
column7: using her artful pacing and a form of spoken word delivery that put her earthy
column8: Marlene Dietrich intonation to the most effective use.

column1: Within an album or two
column2: Fontaine would be deep in avant-garde jazz and nascent world music hybrids
column3: so in hindsight Est…Folle sounds the most traditional
column4: even though it’s nothing of the sort—in fact
column5: the title translates to “Brigitte Fontaine is crazy” and its cover features Fontaine’s striking dark eyes emanating from a big white question mark. Recorded in the studio with composer/arranger Jean-Claude Vannier—who would soon add orchestral heft to France’s greatest rock export
column6: Serge Gainsbourg’s Histoire de Melody Nelson—Est…Folle is playful and charming
column7: even if it offers few hints at the curveballs ahead.

column1: Opener “Il Pleut” finds Fontaine in the most opulent orchestrations of her career
column2: sounding like a precursor to Melody Nelson
column3: Vannier applying garlands of strings and metallophones as a tympanum keeps the beat. “Le Beau Cancer” could be a jaunty number from the stage while “Je Suis Inadaptée” finds Fontaine's sultry voice sparring with woodwinds. Elsewhere
column4: “Comme Rimbaud” speeds along on a peppy backbeat and frantic tambourines. The 11 songs that comprise Folle move with alacrity
column5: with only two lasting longer than 3:30. Were it the lone album Fontaine ever recorded
column6: it would be one of French pop’s more curious statements.

column1: But as she began to work closer with proto-freak-folk/songwriter Jacques Higelin (he wrote one of Est…Folle’s songs) and her soon-to-be lifelong collaborator Areski Belkacem
column2: her music mutated into something stranger and more wondrous. Comme à la Radio stems from the musical/theatrical works the three undertook at the end of the 1960s
column3: where Fontaine’s husky spoken verses went atop spare and propulsive rhythms that drew on folk and Arabic and African instrumentation. The album’s coup comes in the form of Brigitte Fontaine and Areski bringing in the fiercely defiant jazz group the Art Ensemble of Chicago
column4: who had decamped to Paris for a few years.

column1: From the opening notes of that muscular walking bassline provided by Malachi Favors
column2: the title track is a startling hybrid of avant-garde sensibilities—both of the free jazz and French rock variety—that entrances rather than excludes. The Art Ensemble could abstract and abandon structures with the best of American jazz ensembles of the late 60s
column3: but here they play in the pocket to mesmerizing effect
column4: from the lyrical horn lines provided by the frontline of Joseph Jarman
column5: Roscoe Mitchell
column6: and Leo Smith to the throbbing undertow provided by Favors and Belkacem
column7: the rhythms foregrounded
column8: the brass weaving in and around Fontaine’s seductive spoken lines for eight snake-charming minutes.

column1: Or rather
column2: her words only sound seductive to non-Francophone speakers
column3: for Fontaine’s lyrics for “Comme à la Radio” comment on that acute sense of alienation and horror in the modern world
column4: with lines about thousands weeping
column5: police beating a young man
column6: an alcoholic doctor
column7: repeating a line that translates as “It’s cold in the world” in a whisper that sends shivers. Throughout the album
column8: the Art Ensemble and Areski deploy hand percussion
column9: bowed bass
column10: bouzouki
column11: shenai
column12: sitar
column13: lute
column14: and muted brass to suggest Bedouin caravans
column15: African tribal music
column16: sub-Saharan buzzing
column17: all of it beguiling and mysterious
column18: feeling at once as if sounding from a great distance and via Fontaine’s hushed delivery
column19: intimate.

column1: The numbers featuring the Art Ensemble’s contributions remain some of free jazz’s most evocative crossovers
column2: but what makes Comme a la Radio one of the era’s most striking documents is that even without the jazz musician guests
column3: it’s a haunting acid-folk album underneath the brass. The album’s most stunning moments come when Areski handles all of the music around Fontaine’s vocals. There’s the ghostly shenai and bouzouki adding an exotic cast to the fragile incant of “L'Été L'Été”
column4: or the strange strings on the harrowing album closer
column5: “Lettre A Monsieur Le Chef De Gare De La Tour De Carol”
column6: the sawed strings and buzzing drones—urged faster and faster by the hand drums and wordless vocals of Areski—build to a hypnotic and feverish climax. Both “Lettre” and the bonus track “Le Noir C'Est Mieux Choisi” remain some of the most beatific dark folk songs ever recorded
column7:
regardless of language.

"|19022.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19022-brigitte-fontaine-estfolle-comme-a-la-radio/|7.3|Andy Beta
