column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20218/homepage_large.b4060f75.jpg|Cilvia Demo|31721.0|Isaiah Rashad|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Top Dawg Entertainment']|2014-02-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:57.831338|"

The previously Los Angeles-centered TDE crew's adoption of a Southern member isn't so strange. Since they already feel like a modern iteration of the Dungeon Family approach that has seeped into the second-generation Cali gangsta
column2: finding an inverse in Isaiah Rashad makes perfect sense. He's an OutKast fan from the South who's also comfortable in the context of a West Coast that gave us Labcabincalifornia and Me Against the World the same year. While his BET Hip Hop Awards Cypher appearance last year was a bit of an advance notice
column3: the abrupt arrival of his voice in full proves at least one thing: Top Dawg has scouts that'd make Billy Beane lose his damn mind.

column1: Rashad's background draws from a few different sources. While he rode around Chattanooga bumping No Limit classics through the speakers of the '95 Civic he nicknamed “Cilvia”
column2: he did so knowing that the real scene and all the networking opportunities to advance were some 120 miles down I-75 to Atlanta. His style wound up developing with the outside influence of already known artists
column3: but laced with the personal
column4: true-to-self approach that typically comes from having to impress peers and friends instead of a scene wracked with hypebeasts. And with the development that comes when your subject matter demands introspection from the get-go
column5: Cilvia Demo is as much a revelation as labelmate Kendrick Lamar's breakthrough Section.80—only this time
column6: there's also a <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17253-good-kid-maad-city/"" target=""_blank""><i>good kid
column7: m.A.A.d city to look up at and aspire to.

column1: That may come in time
column2: maybe sooner than we think; Cilvia Demo already shows an MC who isn't afraid to lay every anxiety and frustration bare and winds up looking stronger for it. There isn't a clear delineation between Rashad's moments of struggle and his times of strength—these are songs where one typically tests the other
column3: where Hennessey and Jagermeister are less the celebratory ingredients of VIP sections than the coping mechanisms for figuring shit out. Few lines seperate the verse-starting come-on “Baby
column4: can you sucky on my dick/ I know it's big enough” and the admission “I done grown up for my child sake” in “Webbie Flow (U Like)
column5: a song where his swagger and his responsibilities get tangled up in his own self-recognition. The vivid despair of “Heavenly Father""
column6: where the one point of hope in a litany of suicidal thoughts and dead-end burnout is the question of “If I give my story to the world/ I wonder if they'd book me for a show
column7: ” still persists in the mind when a tribute to the similarly introspective Scarface
column8: “Brad Jordan""
column9: has him spitting the rhetoric of invincibility. And there's a line on the title track where he worries about having his own kid look at him the same way he looked at his deadbeat dad; it hits even harder once you've taken in the lyrics about his own feelings about his father. It should all be instantly familiar to anyone dealing with “I'm 21
column10: now what” introspection (or memories thereof).

column1: His headspace comes through so strongly you could easily overlook that Rashad can also put together some fucking verses. There's a single line in the title track that could sum up why his lyrics sink in so deep—“'93 Til be cool for Emmett”—that packs the thematic merging of South and West
column2: racist trauma and artistic resilience
column3: oppressive violence and expressive freedom
column4: all in six words. He can rattle off dense internals with double-meaning followups (“Soliloquy”'s line “Leave the bodies on the cul-de-sac
column5: follow me the cult is back” opens the door for a Jim Jones meta-reference)
column6: he's got his share of punchlines (a pistol in “Menthol” “knock caps like it's senior year”)
column7: his hooks draw blood (“Tranquility for a Brutus/ And hard road for a Caesar”)
column8: and he mixes personal details and pop-culture namedrops so naturally that even his Vince Vaughn and Larry David shout-outs seem like matter-of-fact acknowledgements than celebrity punchlines.

column1: As for his voice
column2: Rashad's prone to conjuring up influences in a way that makes part of his stylistic blueprint clear. Along with the aforementioned Scarface shout-out
column3: “West Savannah” makes the OutKast connection implicit; same for “R.I.P. Kevin Miller” and Master P. Throw in how he first started modeling his flow off a young Lil Wayne
column4: and that's the base for a strong Southern itinerary that he's managed to make his own. He's turned those reference points into something more slippery and reflective
column5: and whether his clear
column6: subtly needling
column7: percussive drawl is hyped up or worn down
column8: he rides the beat with a sharp sense of timing. There are some occasional deliberate hitches in his flow that play up the unmediated
column9: conversational yet still beat-driven cadence of his voice to an extent that it's hard to even break it down into component parts. It just is
column10: and it can't and shouldn't be anything else.

column1: At least a little of that could be the production talking
column2: granted: the slate of beats on Cilvia Demo unites into a consistently immersive
column3: complete album package that's just as ruminative as the lyrics. It draws from a downtempo vibe that swaps out Southern hip-hop's deep soul for noir jazz while retaining that certain cruising-speed dream-state glide. Post-Dirty South in the same way that previous TDE high points have been post-g-funk—indebted but transcendent—there's a consistent thread of deep
column4: often heavily reverbed pianos and brittle yet steady off-kilter snares that make up for the South being the only American hip-hop region to never really give that whole Soulquarian thing a shot. That it pulls it off with a 10-producer committee full of relative unknowns is worth noting. Half of them have Cilvia Demo as their only Discogs credit
column5: but their work stands out: Ross Vega's muted
column6: melting-organ and screw-drum-lope opener “Hereditary”; Joseph Stranger's glow-bass 98 Dilla minimalism for the title cut; a grip of ethereal ghost-church beats by the Antydote (“Ronnie Drake”; “West Savannah”; “Banana”) that make him almost as much of a blindside breakout as the headliner.

column1: Cilvia Demo ends with a remix of “Shot U Down""
column2: the name-maker that dropped last fall and remains the definitive moment of Rashad's career in a sort of “first result in Google autocomplete” kind of way. First single
column3: last track—it's a fitting place for both
column4: initially placing Rashad in an introductory context back in September and now
column5: on this album
column6: feeling like the culmination of a debut full-length that could go down as the best all year. The remix features some TDE co-signs in the form of Jay Rock and ScHoolboy Q
column7: who contribute strong verses in embattled gangsta/money hustler mode
column8: respectively. They're a welcome connection to Rashad's new place in hip-hop
column9: but they're also added attractions rather than skeptic-comforting legitimizers. Rashad's already the real thing
column10: even if his strengths lie in coming to terms with how to turn that real thing into a righteous thing. Now that he's arrived
column11:
watching him hit his next destination's going to be exhilarating.

"|19014.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19014-isaiah-rashad-cilvia/|8.2|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20190/homepage_large.49b6343b.jpg|Animal Heart|6523.0|Nina Persson|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['The End']|2014-02-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:47:58.388739|"

Even discounting Nina Persson’s scattered covers and one-offs
column2: the Cardigans’ move toward singer-songwriterly maturity on Long Gone Before Daylight was a solo effort in spirit if not in personnel. And Persson’s two albums as A Camp—the first with the late Mark Linkous of Sparklehorse and the second with husband Nathan Larson—were solo in everything but the name. While the Cardigans were never all about Persson
column3: she was the major draw; she got pegged as a heroine of coldhearted warm pop: summery melodies whose sun rays just might skewer anyone who basks. She's won countless devotees
column4: from the wordy-sweet Swedish indie acts for whom the Cardigans are canon to those who knew the band from soft-rock radio and Romeo + Juliet. Entire swaths of music are cut from Persson’s cloth; she is a known quantity.

column1: For better or worse
column2: this lets Persson get away with an album like Animal Heart
column3: one that isn’t much of a statement. She has so many strengths to coast on. Her voice still frays so beguilingly well at the end of a phrase. She still has a way with production filigrees
column4: with letting a bridge dissolve into dreamy guitar licks or tucking a watch-this sparkle beneath a verse and then a cruel barb beneath the line. And she still knows how to write a great chorus. The title track here stands among her best
column5: a gorgeous continuous springtime melt of an indie-pop song with a subtle
column6: urgent energy. It’s the most straightforward pleasure on an album more concerned with Persson’s tricksy songwriting. “Catch Me Crying” is like a torch song illuminated by firefly lights and surprisingly busy: over-keeled melodies
column7: over-anxious percussion and synths
column8: over-ragged vocals
column9: and far too much repetition for “you’ll never catch me crying for you—again” to read as anything but ironic. “Forgot to Tell You” is the same tack from the opposite approach: a Sunday kind of breakup song
column10: pleasant like an afternoon on the porch; everything’s so nice-nice
column11: you hardly notice she’s shrugged the poor guy off with “so I might just forget about you now” then slunk away with a smile.

column1: But with so many midtempo tracks so removed from the glam of
column2: say
column3: Super Extra Gravity or Gran Turismo
column4: everything inevitably blurs together. Even at the track level Persson doesn’t quite manage the balance. The concept doesn’t help
column5: as she only half-commits to the metaphor suggested by the record's title. “Food for the Beast” has a commanding chorus (even if it’s constantly one skank away from becoming Swedish reggae)
column6: but it’s pretty clearly a retread of the title idea. Beyond that are fish and bird metaphors seemingly there just to get Persson out of class Mammalia
column7: and “Jungle” is a nadir: tinny and terrible like a demo recording from whichever machine spat out Toto songs in the 1980s. One wonders why she even needed the concept at all. It’s baby-songwriter stuff from an artist who’s better off mature.

column1: “Mature” can be code for “acoustic”
column2: and while nothing on Animal Heart is quite like A Camp at its faux-Americana twangiest
column3: the remnants of that sound remain strong. “The Grand Destruction Game” has fun with its confessional tropes and stock lovers—wayward sailors and elegant gangsters and other men who mainly exist in folk songs share headspace with “the cross-eyed lead singer of a bad boy band.” The hymn-like “Burning Bridges for Fuel” simmers with an exhausted resilience that’s sequenced far too early. The title of “This Is Heavy Metal
column4: ” sounds like a joke; thankfully
column5: it’s neither a Lordi cover nor particularly ironic
column6: but in instead a wry piano ballad whose singer the parade has passed by. Persson drowses through auburn piano chords and wry lines: “I would like to sell now/ My life is going well now/ My bones are at an all-time OK
column7: ” could be the lonely final scene to a both-ends-ablaze Cardigans single. It’s mesmerizing
column8: the sort of thing you want to hear albums more of; it also sounds utterly resigned
column9: as a song if not a career statement. If there’s an upshot
column10:
Persson’s a good enough writer to compose herself another act.

column6: seeing as how about 75% of White Pony was about the same exact shit. And let’s not forget this a genre where Dave Gahan and Trent Reznor are setting the lyrical gold standard.

column1: And yet
column2: I’ve watched Moreno change...into kind of a creep
column3: and considering the wincing awkwardness of it all
column4: I had to check the credits to make sure Lopez wasn’t still working with Jonah Matranga. The first line on “†his is a †rick” is “something’s changed in your face I notice/ a different sparkle in those crazy eyes
column5: ” and from that moment going forward
column6: Moreno’s guyliner’d leering just puts you on the defensive. And it’s hard to enjoy even the good parts of †††
column7: knowing it’s probably a matter of seconds before Moreno spits game like “I gotta tell you something/ I wanna view your dreams/ I wanna pull out your crazy/ pour it over me” or “you make a godly servant/ protect your Bible between your knees.” There’s a 65% chance that “fron†iers” is a love song about strippers
column8: and no one should have to guess about that sort of thing. This is not the same guy who responsible for a track that somehow allowed Maynard James Keenan to sound kinda seductive.

column1: That said
column2: there are good moments here—“†elepa†hy” is something genuinely new
column3: scratching a disco itch and a good deal of ††† isn’t so far off from the booming R&B-metal of the Weeknd’s Kiss Land
column4: albeit with slightly less laughable lyrics. New single “†he epilogue” manages a slinky
column5: KROQ-ready chorus
column6: “blk s†allion” earns its name as an electro inversion of White Pony
column7: while the screaming fits in “bi†ches brew” and “†his is a †rick” prove that ††† would’ve been better off had Moreno just bore his fangs the whole way through. That’s about enough for an EP
column8: but at 15 tracks
column9: ††† fails to establish much flow or continuity or variety
column10: or...oh
column11: fuck it—it’s just too damn long
column12: the longest record Moreno’s ever made unless you think all 32 minutes of silence and hidden tracks at the end of Around the Fur “count.”

column1: Is this is a bad time to mention that Moreno announced Deftones will be taking the rest of 2014 off while he focuses on †††? Hardly. If anything
column2: it shows another reason why it’s so easy to stick with the guy
column3: he keeps this stuff away from his main gig. And really
column4: they’re in a good state—Diamond Eyes and Koi No Yokan found Deftones as vital and influential as ever
column5: having recovered from their murky
column6: muddled post-White Pony albums and the tragic
column7: eventually fatal car accident suffered by bassist Chi Cheng in 2008. While ††† may be on the same scale as Deftones
column8: they’re not a replacement
column9: and it stands to reason that Moreno can ascend to the heights of their previous work. But on †††
column10:
it’s like he never had wings.

Sam Shackleton's career began in the shadows and he's pretty much remained there since. He looked for inspiration past Britain's borders
column2: to Berlin and beyond
column3: at a time when dubstep's nucleus remained embedded deep within a South London postcode. Alloying a steely rhythmic exoskeleton to a sound still largely regarded as a ghostly mutation of 2-step
column4: the run of 12""s on his Skull Disco label successfully ushered the first wave of techno-dubstep hybrids into clubs before it folded in 2008.

column1: That sombre tone and gloomy imagery has become a hallmark since
column2: pressed everywhere from a fêted Ricardo Villalobos remix through to more recent work
column3: incorporating uncommon instrumentation and Middle Eastern motifs. The producer crafts detailed headspaces and then erodes their parameters
column4: invoking a level of uncertainty and crumbled-spliff paranoia. His exacting focus on dread makes his extensive
column5: and often brilliant
column6: catalogue somewhat foreboding. It also instils immediate apprehension when approaching this perplexing new EP
column7: his first after a nearly two year absence.

column1: Freezing Opening Thawing's opener may be the most dramatic outlier in Shackleton's entire body of work
column2: although not without some precedent: his sprawling ""Mukuba Special"" re-work on a 2010 Congotronics compilation is the nearest relative. There
column3: the contrast between growling sub-bass and brittle guitar notes was the sonic manifestation of two worlds meeting. Here
column4: the title track crams a head-spinning mesh of synthetic sounds into the heavily treated topline
column5: hoovering up anything vaguely earthen and leaving behind a complete void of low-end.

column1: The result is startling: marimba and mbira lines dart across one another at high velocity; oscillators spin out of control; the infectious lead is so over-processed that whatever its original components
column2: it finishes up as sequenced distress signals escaping short-circuiting mainframes. Once it finally locks into a convulsing
column3: serpentine rhythm
column4: Shackleton begins layering stranger noises still: Transylvanian hammer horror riffage
column5: clattering hooks
column6: no-wave synth stabs. For someone who has admitted to spending months at a time perfecting a single drum loop
column7: the torrential hail feels cast off at random
column8: triggered in real-time on an ironing-board's worth of cheap circuit-bent instruments. It's the sound of Shackleton cutting loose in delirious
column9: utterly entrancing fashion.

column1: Given the sensory overload
column2: the pair of tracks that follow offer some breathing room and a human touch. Chinking metallurgy and a collapsing bassline warm up ""White Flower With Silvery Eye""
column3: ushering in a more linear progression before ducking out for a Deliverance-style showdown between two diametrically opposed percussive factions: digitized blip versus palmed drum skin. That odd juxtaposition is magnified on ""Silver Keys""
column4: which begins with a grim monophonic MIDI dawn chorus and ends closest to a traditional Shackleton piece
column5: closing out proceedings on a dark and ritualistic stomp. As opposed to the scabrous Coil-style feedback splayed across 2012's Music for the Quiet Hour
column6: here the rich didgeridoo drone is somewhat comforting against the eerie melody; unusual but not necessarily unnatural.

column1: Precious little unity binds Freezing Thawing Opening: the tracks are bright and glossy
column2: fully blanched of color
column3: and a sterility hangs in the atmosphere. Any attempt at human connection is paltry
column4: even by Shackleton's standards. But in spite of the EP's innate weirdness every track remains supremely danceable and this could be his most groove-centric release yet. He's bound to continue as the chin-scratcher's choice
column5: but if anything
column6:
this EP's about face will only add to Shackleton's peculiar magnetism.

"|18976.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18976-shackleton-freezing-thawing-opening-ep/|7.5|Gabriel Szatan

Afterhours is the project from Los Angeleno Nicholas Crozier Malkin
column2: an outift inspired by his ""Field Recordings of the Afterhours"" radio show on Chinatown's KCHUNG radio. Broadcasted on Sunday mornings
column3: the show aimed diverse
column4: low-key music at people still up from the night before
column5: acting as a salve for hangovers and a reprieve for benders. Lowlife
column6: Malkin's first album and second release for LA-based Not Not Fun
column7: is a foggy
column8: sampladelic ode to Malkin's hometown and all of the red-eyed
column9: busted heads scrambling around it.

column1: Lowlife is an entirely downtempo affair
column2: built out of narcoleptic soul loops
column3: frazzled static
column4: and distant
column5: echoing vocal samples. It's slippery music that exists in the crevices between instrumental hip-hop
column6: deep house
column7: and trip-hop. Fittingly
column8: it's the kind of music that could be used to fill spaces that you don't necessarily realize need to be filled: coffee shops
column9: hip restaurants
column10: hair salons. That's not a slight: Lowlife is coolly passive and unchallenging by design. Anything more might further fry its intended audience.

column1: ""Lovesick""
column2: which at nine minutes constitutes more than a quarter of Lowlife's 33-minute runtime
column3: is the album's spectacular centerpiece. Relying on a short congo loop and a velvet bassline
column4: Malkin mixes in bits of dialogue
column5: street noises
column6: and a lugubrious moan to devastating effect
column7: finding a touch of Theo Parrish's elegance (though not his complexity). If most of Malkin's music is about the comedown
column8: ""Lovesick"" is the party: a series of seemingly trivial exchanges and gestures that
column9: you realize later
column10: ended up being a pretty good night. ""Lovesick"" is familiar musically
column11: but its luxe momentum is rare
column12: and it belongs in heady DJ sets and after-after-party mixtapes alike.

column1: The remainder of Lowlife isn't nearly so deft or assertive
column2: and while none of its six tracks are failures
column3: there's little risked and little gained. The styles range from dusky ambience (""Outcome""
column4: the post-""Lovesick"" chillout) to ornery
column5: rain-soaked glitch (""Spit at the Mirror""). ""Night and Day""'s ambling breakbeat and mournful horns are basically lounge music
column6: which is what we might call Afterhours if it lacked some of its experimental impulses.

column1: You'll never be sorry you're listening to Lowlife
column2: though you won't often realize you are. Its slight construction and total commitment to vibes makes it unlikely to jar or disrupt. Compare Lowlife's smokey
column3: city-at-night evocations to
column4: say
column5: those of Burial
column6: and understand how modest this record really is. Malkin
column7: though
column8: proves a potent sampler
column9:
and ""Lovesick"" offers a glimpse of how arresting his music can be when he attempts something a little more ambitious.

Noel Gallagher of Oasis
column2: squinting recently at the bounteous musical landscape
column3: dubbed the new Kettering-based quartet Temples ""the best new band in Britain."" If you've read anything about Temples
column4: you've likely this already absorbed this fact. That is because—and forgive the bluntness—Noel Gallagher's endorsement is easily the most remarkable thing about Temples
column5: who offer a studious recreation of psychedelic rock so devoid of an individual personality that the only way to discuss them is to check off the high-profile industry legends who have endorsed them and the legendary records they crib from.

column1: This sounds harsh and damning
column2: but Sun Structures is not a bad album. Singer/bassist Thomas Warmsley and guitarist/vocalist James Bagshaw
column3: the leading forces behind the group
column4: come by their obsessions honestly
column5: which
column6: when it comes to influences
column7: is the only thing that matters: They talk about their love of the Byrds
column8: the Nazz
column9: and Marc Bolan in interviews with intelligence and feeling
column10: and Sun Structures reproduces the sounds of its era with a painstaking
column11: granular attention to detail. If you were inclined
column12: you could isolate every snare crack and background ""ahh"" and source it right back to a specific two-second snatch of a classic psych record.

column1: Which also points to why it's difficult to feel invested in Temples: This is pretty much all you can do with Sun Structures. There is nothing here to absorb about psychedelic music that Temples haven't already absorbed for you
column2: and without imparting their own ideas. They are Tame Impala minus the sneaky modernizing touches
column3: Foxygen sapped of irreverence. There are moments to admire on Sun Structures
column4: but very little to remember and less to love: ""Shelter Song"" has pretty good chorus motion
column5: in the way you might appreciate how two pieces of a modular shelving unit snap in place. ""Keep in the Dark"" is a good
column6: strong T. Rex pop-rock tune
column7: easily the most memorable four and a half minutes of Sun Structures' hour-long running time. And the keening
column8: glassy guitar riff on ""Mesmerise"" is one of the few moments where Temples channel something close to actual euphoria. Euphoria  should always be a byproduct of good psychedelic music; if it's missing
column9: you should check the dosage.

column1: Temples are phenomenally successful for a fledgling band. They've already notched opening slots for Suede
column2: Kasabian
column3: the Rolling Stones. Given their mastery of sound and the strength of their execution on Sun Structures
column4: it's easy to imagine bigger successes in the future—awards-show slots
column5: tribute shows
column6: commercial syncs. But when you're operating within a strict template
column7: you have to find some distinctive way to fill it out—a felicitous phrasing here
column8: an unexpected chord change there. Without those elements
column9: there's little on Sun Structures to remind you that you are
column10: in fact
column11:
listening to a new band called Temples.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20117/homepage_large.ae33dde0.jpg|Hotel Valentine|759.0|Cibo Matto|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Chimera']|2014-02-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:04.248350|"

Blame the extended hiatus they took after their too-brief heyday if you want
column2: but Cibo Matto are hard to separate from the late 90s notion of cool. The association with Shibuya-kei chic expanded into international-minded polyglot goodwill
column3: the consciously high-concept Michel Gondry music video (the time-bending DePalma-gone-palindrome “Sugar Water”)
column4: the collaborations with a then-emergent Sean Lennon
column5: the playful but well-composed hip-hop-adjacent eclecticism—it's hard to imagine Yuka Honda and Miho Hatori becoming minor sensations at any other time
column6: no matter how casually their style nodded to the eras preceding them. They still made individual strides in the ten-plus years following a breakup that left 1999's Stereo*Type A
column7: their last significant work as a team
column8: and continued to embody a stay-posi NYC boho philosophy that's all but disappeared from the city's current hipster-panic atmosphere. But is a new Cibo Matto album a brand-renewing nostalgia trip
column9: or something deeper than that?

column1: It only takes a brief acknowledgement of the conceptual thrust behind Hotel Valentine to get the feeling that their reunion has a more intent purpose than mere let's-get-the-band-back-together restlessness. There's a story to tell
column2: even if it's a sort of indirect one that might have a lot more meaning than it lets on. It goes like this: there's a hotel with a ghost in it
column3: and... well
column4: the rest of the details are a bit more elusive
column5: and intentionally so. The spirit isn't a threatening one
column6: unless you count the bit in “MFN” when it's clear it doesn't want to be harassed by the only person who can see it (“Don't tell me what to do
column7: I'm a ghost/ Don't throw the fuckin' oyster shells at me”). All the other blanks can only really be filled in by the music itself
column8: which Honda and Hatori have put together in a way that sounds like their old collaborative identities answering for what their cross-cultural peers and successors have done in the intervening years.

column1: If the eye-popping neon palette of GEORGIA's video for “MFN” evoked artists of a Mad Decent bloodline rather than the old Grand Royal-era phase of transcontinental pop-cool
column2: much of the album does the same at subtler frequencies. It's less a direct homage than a parallel
column3: maybe
column4: but the Cibo Matto aesthetic operated on similar enough principles that Hotel Valentine's occasional leanings towards deep-bass microhouse revival (“Empty Pool”) and M.I.A.-goes-!!! dance-punk (“10th Floor Ghost Girl”) seem like foregone (and natural) conclusions. Fortunately
column5: the moments of genre blueprint-crumpling idiosyncrasy—the rickety but sinuous acid-jazz charge of “Emerald Tuesday”; the title track's codeine Tropicalia; the swooning acoustic-guitar soul of closer “Check Out”—are just as engaging
column6: and in ways that sound both unconcerned with trendwatching. They reveal how many possibilities Cibo Matto have always been open to.

column1: But it's the mood of Hotel Valentine that stands out the most. The allusive nature of their lyrics sometimes lets slip the occasional glibly funny detail or observation
column2: like how the ghost notes in “Lobby” that the afterlife's advantages—not having to worry about radiation
column3: guns
column4: or criminalized marijuana—don't entirely cancel out the fact that you still can't really go out and do things. The setting of a hotel as a transitory living space merges the exploratory thrill of travel with the disconnect of not really living where you are. And the paranormal angle to this album is simultaneously odd and mournful
column5: with enjoyable quirks like Hatori's deadpan rapping throughout and some characteristically goofy interjections from Reggie Watts on “Housekeeping” offset by more uncertain perspectives and anxious melodies. There's hints of a more ambivalent
column6: somewhat lost entity in this hotel
column7: floating around with a confused purpose (“Check In”)
column8: a displaced sense of awareness (“Déjà Vu”)
column9: and an identity crisis that puts its movements and communications in an American/African/Brazilian mishmash but still leaves it without a traceable source (“10th Floor Ghost Girl”).

column1: And not all of that might even belong to the ghost alone. Make of that what you will when it comes to metaphorical statements—this could easily be a concept record about the disorientation and need to find connections that arise with the pop artist's idea of a global influence. But that's up to a lyrical interpretation that requires more clarification from the authors than they've decided to give. If you really do need it laid out
column2: “Empty Pool” is probably the most explicit: “In an empty pool I was swimming alone/ But I felt someone calling me/ The only thing I found was the world that I know/ My heart was floating”. The rest isn't so easily figured out—but when a musical partnership has always been this skilled at synthesizing so many different ideas and sounds
column3:
the interpretation should be just as wide open.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20142/homepage_large.f657ec97.jpg|Hardcore Traxx: Dance Mania Records 1986-1997|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Strut']|2014-02-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:04.909865|"

Club music is easy to mock. Most people know someone skeptical or dismissive of it
column2: a class clown-type who'll derisively mimic a cut by huffing ""uhnt-chk-uhnt-chk-uhnt-chk"" while goofily nodding his head. Heed this warning: Paul Johnson's ""Feel My M.F. Bass"" will be a boon to this person. Shrill and stone-stoopid
column3: the song's refrain repeats as such: ""Feel my moth-er-fuck-ing bass in your face/ Feel my moth-er-fuck-ing bass in your face."" The rhythm
column4: composed on a then-cheap
column5: probably discarded drum machine
column6: goes ""uhnt-chk-uhnt-chk-uhnt-chk"" except when it goes ""unt-uhnt-uhnt-uhnt."" The bass line sounds like...well
column7: there is no bass line. But if you dropped this little chunk of rhythmic coal on the South or West side of Chicago in 1994
column8: or if you drop it just about anywhere in Europe in 2014
column9: people go wild.

column1: ""Feel My M.F. Bass"" is a standout track from Hardcore Traxx: Dance Mania Records 1986-1997
column2: the first-ever compilation to honor Chicago house music's coarse
column3: brilliant
column4: and suddenly trendy prodigal son. Best known for lewd
column5: raw
column6: high-tempo tracks—a style known then and now as ghetto house—Dance Mania churned out dozens of classic singles that rarely escaped the Midwest. The label was
column7: essentially
column8: primed to run as a modest small business: attract a dedicated
column9: local following by using its paltry resources to shake as many asses as possible.

column1: Ray Barney and Duane Buford started Dance Mania in 1985
column2: running it through the 1990s. When Barney resurrected the label recently
column3: he did it for the same reason he made so many of the choices that shaped Dance Mania: it seemed like a practical business decision. European DJs
column4: it turned out
column5: were paying hundreds of dollars for Dance Mania 12""s
column6: and Barney had shelves full of unbought records in his basement.

column1: This uptick in popularity found influential Russian DJ Nina Kraviz saying things like
column2: ""Sometimes I think that my only purpose of DJing is to play Dance Mania records!"" to anyone who would listen. (Her loving
column3: abstract ode to the label
column4: ""Ghetto Kraviz""
column5: was a smash.) Boysnoize curated a tribute album. When art-damaged misfit Actress toured America late in 2013
column6: he brought Dance Mania mainstay Parris Mitchell with him. The label's earliest shoutout remains its biggest: ""Teachers""
column7: Daft Punk's 1997 ode to their producer heroes not only namechecks many of Dance Mania's principals
column8: it openly apes the Parris Mitchell Project's ""Ghetto Shout Out!!""

column1: The first third of Hardcore Traxx traces DM's early years
column2: when it was releasing good but familiar first-wave Chicago house: diva-scorched anthems that implore you to jack your body and submit yourself to ""house nation."" After failing to land the type of European hit that buoyed peer labels like Traxx and DJ International
column3: Barney—who
column4: after college
column5: helped turn his father's popular South side record store into a record distribution hub—leveraged his network of DJs to cater to the local market. Unable to afford studio time
column6: Dance Mania producers recorded their tracks in their homes
column7: often with little more than a drum machine and a sampler. The crass mantras needed not appeal to radio jocks and helped attract an audience increasingly interested in hip-hop.

column1: Like garage rock or blues or any art that's trying to accomplish a lot with very little
column2: a surprising amount of weirdness ensued. There's lots of grunting and wheezing on Hardcore Traxx; rappers sound like cartoons and MCs like carnal preachers. Dance Mania is a testament to the power of the riff. In the best DM tracks every single element functions as a hook: Uhn-chk-Uhn-chk-Ride-me-baby. Whether you find dance music far too repetitive or you live for old Traxx 12""s
column3: you will remember Dance Mania's tracks
column4: as they are among the catchiest and most brazen of their kind
column5: alternately hypnotic and disruptive.

column1: For much of the 90s
column2: DM's local focus shielded it from Europe's abandonment of first-wave American dance musics. The label just kept churning out tracks
column3: eventually fostering ghetto house offshoots juke and footwork (footwork legends RP Boo and Traxman recorded for the label). Declining vinyl sales shuttered the label in 2001
column4: but even that seems like a blessing. Dance Mania is one of the few early house labels to remain on good terms with most of its artists.

column1: The success of ghetto house and Dance Mania was built on a really simple concept. You could hear Traxmen & Eric Martin's ""Hit It from the Back"" in a field rave in Wisconsin for the same reason you could hear it in a seedy Chicago club: it was (and still is) really good at making people grind their bodies against one another. The surge in popularity overseas no doubt stems in part from the fact that ghetto house is perhaps the only large American dance subgenre not to have been co-opted by Europe in the 1990s. But the local flavor—that of a neighborhood shop—persists. To hear ""Ghetto Shout Out!!""'s call and response—""Cabrini-Green in this motherfucker? Hell yeah!""—is to hear how DM helped get off a lot of people who really
column2: really needed to get off. And those who didn't need to get off
column3: too. Say this about anyone who mocks ""Feel my M.F. Bass"": he will be feeling this lethally catchy
column4:
modestly conceived motherfucking bass in his face for days.

"|18947.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18947-hardcore-traxx-dance-mania-records-1986-1997/|8.5|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20188/homepage_large.79cc66ff.jpg|You're Gonna Miss It All|31933.0|Modern Baseball|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Run for Cover']|2014-02-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:05.130158|"

Modern Baseball’s You’re Gonna Miss It All is a sophomoric album in multiple ways. It’s the Philadelphia band’s second full-length
column2: for one thing. Beyond that
column3: Brendan Lukens recently finished his second year at Drexel University
column4: and he never lets you forget what 21-year-old college students are often like—culturally literate
column5: if not necessarily “book smart
column6: ” blurring the line between introspective and self-obsessed
column7: impressed by their capacity for clever wordplay and emotional awareness while knowing both of those qualities conspire to prevent people from saying what they actually feel. And due to the all of the aforementioned
column8: Lukens is kinda full of it
column9: too. He won’t exactly lie to you
column10: but he’ll tell you what he aspires to be while doing the exact opposite. Observe this howler from “Fine
column11: Great”: “I hate having to think about the future/ when all I want to do is worry about everyone but me.”

column1: There’s a fine semantic misdirection here
column2: and he knows it: it’s a song about how much of a pain in the ass it is to have people care about you
column3: and all he really wants is for everyone to worry about someone other than Brendan Lukens. He can do that just fine
column4: great? Along with fellow MB songwriter Jacob Ewald
column5: Lukens frets over the past
column6: future
column7: and especially the present. He thinks about the next five minutes
column8: the next morning
column9: and whether his death will be cool enough to get a mention from Jim Gardner on Channel 6 Action News. And he worries a hell of a lot about himself
column10: and how other people figure into that. It’s a lot to endure because people in Lukens’ situation get drunk most every night
column11: stumble into relationships
column12: and run from their problems. If you’re in this emotionally combustible state
column13: you’ll relate to You’re Gonna Miss It All directly and deeply. If you at least recognize it in retrospect
column14: you can just as easily appreciate its wealth of infectious songs that are both sharply observed and sharply written.

column1: About that last descriptor
column2: Lukens describes himself as “sharp as a tack/ but in the sense that I'm not smart just a prick.” These songs are often funny and can induce wincing recalls of your most embarrassing romantic fuck-ups
column3: but Lukens doesn’t seem all that concerned about being liked or admirable. If he’s pissed at you
column4: he’ll probably just say “fuck you.” If he’s excited about the fact that you sat next to him on the couch instead of ignoring him like the last time you hung out
column5: he’ll add “niiiice” as an aside. He likes metaphor
column6: but he's much better at literalism
column7: so the aspirational poetics of “Notes” don’t hit as squarely as the times where he describes a lonely Friday night as “no better time for exercise wishing you were still my girlfriend.”

column1: Which explains why Modern Baseball have namechecked Tokyo Police Club and Los Campesinos! as formative influences. That much is conveyed through similarly short and spiky songs that don’t quite fit as pop
column2: punk
column3: or pop-punk. You’re Gonna Miss It All mostly concerns itself with wasted time
column4: but it doesn’t waste much itself
column5: dense with both hooks and lyrical barbs. Likewise
column6: Ewald’s nasal
column7: nerdy
column8: and needy vocals bring to mind not only David Monks and Gareth David
column9: but elder prose-songwriting bards like Craig Finn and John Darnielle. To say they can be a dealbreaker is an understatement: upon hearing him pronounce “accoutrements
column10: ” “DIY ethics
column11: ” and “Mommy and Daddy’s data plan” in the same song or getting a little too Urkel-esque with the hook from “Broken Cash Machine” (“why did I do that?”) some people might flat-out refuse to even reach the bargaining table.

column1: Like pretty much every guitar band these days that doesn’t immediately scan as “indie rock
column2: ” Modern Baseball have been lumped into “emo”—and yes
column3: considering Modern Baseball are probably Weezer fans and are caught up in girl problems of their own making
column4: that label sticks to an extent. Thing is
column5: the actual music of You’re Gonna Miss It All is just about everything but emo
column6: mostly some code-splitting of the pop-punk double helix. There’s shout-and-whoa power-pop (“Charlie Black”)
column7: prim twee (“Going to Bed Now”)
column8: folky punk (“Your Graduation”)
column9: all built around sturdy choruses. One thing Modern Baseball do have in common with their trendpiece peers is that they’re getting attention because they’re much
column10: much better at making music than they were two years ago. This is evident in the songwriting
column11: which is more confident and ambitious
column12: but just as importantly
column13: the production. You're Gonna Miss It All was mastered by Will Yip (basically the Steve Albini of this scene) and engineered by Jonathan Low
column14: a guy who’s worked on the National’s records. So needless to say
column15: it’s going to sound a lot more professional than Sports
column16: a charmingly amateur affair that seemed content to be passed around amongst Modern Baseball’s Facebook friends.

column1: And that’s crucial
column2: since Modern Baseball are a band that deserves to engage a wider audience. Nonetheless
column3: Lukens is  still dealing in small stakes. He tries to think himself into a relationship he’s trying to talk and drink himself out of. When he does make a move
column4: he worries about sticking around too long because her roommates might hear them. He goes to apartment parties
column5: drinks because he drank the night before
column6: can think of little besides the smell of garlic and coffee on his breath and goes from “living like a king without you” to “living like a piece of shit without you” in about a minute. Considering their common Philadelphia homebase
column7: a fun exercise is to imagine You’re Gonna Miss It All as the other side of the stories told on Waxahatchee’s Cerulean Salt.  Of course
column8: the narrators are totally mismatched
column9: but all of their songs are dysfunctional anyway. Kate Crutchfield may be singing about many of the same things
column10: but she sounds wearier
column11: wiser
column12: someone you’d ensure with your secrets and seek out for advice. I don’t know if I’d trust Brendan Lukens to complete a beer run for a case of Keystone Lite
column13: he’d probably come back with a six-pack and a funny story about the girl he met from his old high school along the way—these are the small
column14:
relatable pleasures of which a Modern Baseball song is made.

"|18984.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18984-modern-baseball-youre-gonna-miss-it-all/|7.2|Ian Cohen

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20185/homepage_large.3a09bb06.jpg|Soak|1527.0|Foetus|['Experimental'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ectopic']|2014-02-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:48:05.851981|"

Listening to J.G. Thirlwell’s work as Foetus is disorienting. When I stick my head under the sonic shower of his new record
column3: Soak
column4: it induces the same dizziness as many high-speed style-mashups do
column5: such as the frantic blasts of Naked City
column6: the hyper-cutting sample-barrages of John Oswald’s Plunderphonics
column7: or the cartoon scores of Carl Stalling. Which is weird
column8: because Foetus' music isn’t really a mashup. Soak—much like it’s 2010 companion piece
column9: Hide—is basically full-on rock'n'roll
column10: albeit of the theatrical
column11: sometimes even symphonic variety.

column1: What makes Soak so dizzying is not shifts in style
column2: but tone. Stretches of restraint jump into moments of crashing bombast; broad melodrama mixes with maudlin strings and sad vocals. The leaps aren’t disorienting because they’re fast—though they can be—but because they’re so big; Thirwell loves bounding over the top with his escalating crescendoes
column3: orchestrated swells
column4: and dramatic effects. Add his ever-growing skills as a composer and arranger—he’s currently serving that role for Adult Swim’s long-running Venture Bros.—and you get music that’s both precise and unpredictable
column5: both painstaking and audacious. You get “Halloween/Turbulence”
column6: which somehow sounds like a 70’s TV mystery theme
column7: a Kraftwerk outtake
column8: and a Carl Orff cantata.

column1: The bewildering effect of such tonal chopping makes it hard to judge Soak objectively. Do I like “Kamikaze”’s meld of the Beatles and the Flaming Lips because it’s as good as those groups
column2: or because I’m amazed that Thirlwell can evoke them? Does the Tom-Waits-as-horror-flick growl of “Warm Leatherette” really quicken my pulse
column3: or just sound like it should? All I can say for sure is Soak puzzles me in an exhilarating way
column4: even when I don’t find it memorable or pleasurable. When it actually is a pleasure
column5: as during the Bonanza-style horn-driven climaxes of “Spat
column6: ” it’s palpably thrilling. But it’s always interesting
column7: if only because of the anticipation for what musical histrionics Thirlwell might plunge into next. Which makes it pretty hard not to pay attention to Soak when it’s playing.

column1: That’s not the case with The Blue Eyes
column2: Thirwell’s soundtrack for a movie of the same name. If Soak is disorienting to a fault
column3: this album is the opposite—eminently clear about its intentions
column4: about the emotions it’s trying to convey and the response it hopes to evoke. (One track of scary
column5: Hitchock-worthy strings is called “Stabber”). It's rather typical soundtrack music
column6: constructed to complement and accent visuals by finding the universal notes that reflect them. On those terms
column7: it’s successful—Thirlwell’s a pro with expressive sonics
column8: and he’s especially good at darker-toned moments. Pieces such as the rumbling “Muted World” and ghostly “Long View” are thoroughly chilling
column9: certainly adding depth to any pictures. But ultimately the music on The Blue Eyes is too conventionally filmic to provide a full experience by itself. It feels more in service of someone else’s images than capable of inspiring them on its own.

column1: In other words
column2: I’d rather watch the imaginary film that Soak projects in my head than the actual one that The Blue Eyes soundtracks. That’s partially due to the fearless unpredictability of the former—whatever movie it could accompany would likely look different every time I’d watch
column3: and even once I’d gotten used to the plot the editing would still surprise me. Maybe you can think of Foetus’ music as the bombast-rock equivalent of Choose Your Own Adventure books—the beginnings and middles of songs are not that unusual on their own
column4:
but the mix-and-match that JG Thirlwell puts them through makes the ends worth sticking around for.

"|18982.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18982-foetus-jg-thirlwell-soak-the-blue-eyes-ost/|6.9|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20206/homepage_large.9ecaa34f.jpg|Tranquilizers|29336.0|Dog Bite|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Carpark']|2014-02-11 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:06.572908|"

In their second offering as a band
column2: Dog Bite leave little evidence of growth or
column3: more importantly
column4: purpose. It’s the Atlanta-based side-project of Washed Out keyboard player Phil Jones
column5: whose love for all things wavy invites poor choices musically and lyrically at every turn. Where there’s a chance for a new color in his palette
column6: Jones opts for the same icy guitars and the vaguest of moods. Where there’s a chance to have a song about something concrete
column7: Jones opts for the most basic existential quandaries. He sets the bar so low yet still manages to trip over it and fall into a space once fertile with chillwave and shoegaze bands that's now an airless voidscape with salted soil and a decrepit sign that reads: “Vibes.” This is the environment Dog Bite creates
column8: much like last year's Velvet Changes only more torpid and morose. Welcome.

column1: Jones said he was inspired by a new set of sounds on this record
column2: soul guys like Otis Redding and Isaac Hayes. This is apparent on Tranquilizers insofar as Otis Redding and Isaac Hayes are categorized as musicians much in the same way as Dog Bite
column3: Frédéric Chopin and Nikki Sixx are also categorized as musicians. Beyond that
column4: the analogue gets a little muddy. The sounds of Stax records filtered through a complex pedal board short-circuited with a bottle Codiene might get you there. But any actual soul on the record is obfuscated by a pastiche of effects-laden synths and guitars that don’t play music so much as they play at music
column5: writing toward a feeling or an impression. Jones said of the album
column6: ""I<span>t’s music that just wants to hang out a little bit
column7: talk about the universe
column8: and then go home."" Which is to say the album strives to have the same kind of relationship as you had with Gavin
column9: the guy who always wore a baja hoodie and had a Volcano vaporizer he called Mount Doom.

column1: Luckily there’s “Wonder Dark”
column2: one of the only songs whose textures are varied enough to raise an eyebrow. It has shape to it
column3: it bellows a bit with the arrangement
column4: and the guitars start to resemble something like coiled tension. But just as quickly as it arrives
column5: Tranquilizers slips back into laminated shoegaze with ""Dream Feast"" and the rest. It's cavernous
column6: yes
column7: but a bass-heavy production with delayed treble guitar is dynamic once
column8: not over and over again.

column1: Take
column2: too
column3: the rhetorical questions that Jones offers throughout in his anemic half-baritone voice. “Where do we go?” and
column4: “So what am I supposed to be?” are some hooks highlighted on the record
column5: statements so vapid and feckless they make the bulk of Twitter on any given day seem Pulitzer-worthy. Even in performing music so instantly categorizable and comfortable
column6: Dog Bite pretend to be lost souls who just want to ask the big questions. “Please help me” goes the chorus to “Royals” as a kind of meta-comment as the album slogs on at the same sub-marine trip-hop tempos on into its 30th minute.

column1: Tranquilzers does very little to reinvigorate or recontextualize chillwave or shoegaze and does even less to signify innovation on its own terms. Its main crime is that it's aggressively safe and begs to be classified as nothing other than a rank and file Washed Out side project. Late last year
column2:
Jones put up a mixtape of personal influences which include dusty groove artists like Byrdie Green and Dorthy Ashby. It's beyond frustrating that the sharp mood of those reggae and soul songs that influence Jones are spread out paper-thin in monochromatic streaks. Toro Y Moi have moved on to lean disco-funk and Washed Out put a focus on textural variation by using over 50 different instruments on Paracosm. Dog Bite are about as late to the vibe party as possible. To say the songs are lifeless is to only pinpoint part of the problem—they are absent of the stuff that make music enjoyable to listen to.

"|19002.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19002-dog-bite-tranquilizers/|3.2|Jeremy D. Larson

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20103/homepage_large.f6bf4906.jpg|Little Red|29414.0|Katy B|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2014-02-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:07.258927|"

In the grand narrative of post-millenial British pop
column3: Katy B is a crucial plot point. London’s culture of pirate radio stations has produced some of the world’s most vital music over this period
column4: but those scenes—be it garage
column5: grime
column6: dubstep
column7: or funky house—inevitably faced the glass ceiling that is the country’s pop charts. To be sure
column8: tracks from the underground did eventually hit big: garage architect Artful Dodger scored massive pop hits with Craig David
column9: while Dizzee Rascal and Wiley did the same for grime. But none of those breakthroughs were as smooth or as sudden as that of the singer Kathleen Brien
column10: whose debut single
column11: “Katy on a Mission”
column12: shot straight out of the funky scene into the top five.

column1: In doing so
column2: she set the precedent for the rapid rise of artists like Jessie Ware
column3: Disclosure
column4: and Rudimental
column5: the latter two of which defined British pop music in 2013 while also making quicker and more legitimate inroads in America than any of their peers before them. Katy certainly benefited from the groundwork laid by others over the years
column6: but she proved that full-on pop stardom could be immediate. But now she is trying to write a new chapter: the artist who exploded out of the London underground and then crafted a sustainable career on her own terms
column7: without relying on newer trends or reliable pop heavyweights.

column1: Well
column2: that second part is more like 98% true. Two songs on her sophomore album
column3: Little Red
column4: find Katy B collaborating with Guy Chambers
column5: the co-architect of obscenely massive singles and albums by Robbie Williams. But you wouldn’t know that without looking closely at the credits; Little Red is purely the work of a singer redefining her voice. Though it can initially feel understated and even closed off
column6: with repeated listens it detaches Katy B from a specific sound and establishes her as a pop star with a coherent point of view.

column1: The most visible example of this
column2: if not quite the best
column3: is the current single “Crying For No Reason”
column4: one of the cuts co-written with Chambers. A ballad that threatens to blossom into a disco song but never does
column5: it'd be hailed as perfectly left-field if it was Adele’s comeback single (and it could be). But in the context of Katy’s career
column6: it strips away the thump of house that has been her essence. She chooses to let the single live or die on her ability to sell the song vocally
column7: and the soft grace with which she hits the slowly escalating notes is something like watching a gymnast: Katy steps carefully but with strength
column8:
never launching herself into the chorus but instead opting for a churning build. Her stunning performance of the track on Graham Norton’s late night show is a study in confidence and the power of tension.

Like “Crying For No Reason”
column9: Little Red hangs on moments that reveal themselves over time. “All My Lovin’” sounds at first like one of her most generic songs
column10: a ballad that flirts with American dubstep’s crushing drops. But the way Katy’s vocals rise out of the chorus is sublime
column11: and by the time the synths start to slyly sound like a vocoder
column12: it's one of the album's standouts. “Tumbling Down” is another mid-tempo song
column13: but Katy sings the chorus melody like a feather slowly fluttering to the ground.

column1: There are bangers
column2: too. “Aaliyah”
column3: the Ware duet carried over from Katy’s late-2012 Danger EP
column4: is her most smartly-written song but also works as pure dancefloor euphoria. On “Everything”
column5: Katy dons the crown of the diva over a tech house beat
column6: and there she finds the sweet spot where yearning and control meet. Then there's “Emotions”
column7: the album’s showstopper. It is yet another ballad
column8: but this one turns up the drama almost immediately
column9: with big synth stabs and tightly coiled strings. The climax is the one point where Little Red suddenly seems to become fully aware of the broader musical context: the drum'n'bass beat nods toward Rudimental smashes like “Waiting All Night”
column10: but “Emotions” is constructed as a slow burn and thus has much more emotional resonance.

column1: All that said
column2: Little Red may be seen as a slight step down by many
column3: and that’s not without reason. The album kicks off with the perfectly adequate but hardly spectacular duo of “Next Thing” and “5 AM”; “Sapphire Blue” and “Still” are two more ballads that sandwich “Emotions” and neither quite reveal their charms
column4: with “Still” being particularly gloopy in a Celine Dion way. And though Katy has potentially charted the course for the rest of her career with Little Red
column5: it lacks the inherent thrill of its predecessor On a Mission
column6: an album of UK dance sounds aimed squarely at the top of the charts.

column1: Still
column2: this is a deft step for Katy B. She sheds the schoolgirl innocence that accented her debut and dives deeper into herself
column3: probing love
column4: lust
column5: sorrow
column6: glee
column7:
and power dynamics from all angles. Little Red is not the best album it could have been—a few of the bonus tracks should have made the album proper—but Katy displays a vision for her career that suggests an exciting future.

"|18907.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18907-katy-b-little-red/|7.8|Jordan Sargent

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20105/homepage_large.00d2fc69.jpg|Emmaar|5199.0|Tinariwen|['Global']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anti-']|2014-02-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:08.022288|"

Tinariwen’s identity as a band is tightly bound up in the Sahara. They are named for the vast empty spaces traversed by the Kel Tamashek (aka Tuareg)
column2: traditional nomads for whom modern borders have been problematic. The band formed in Libya while in exile from Mali
column3: and has always made music that passionately evokes its home; their last album was recorded in the open air of that desert. Such an arrangement was not possible this time. The political situation in Mali made returning to the northern desert untenable
column4: and though they’ve been driven from power in most places
column5: the specter of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb—an organization ideologically opposed to music—still looms across a large swath of the Sahara.

column1: The band instead set up a studio at a house in California’s Mojave desert near Joshua Tree National Park. Time in the Mojave hasn’t removed the Sahara from them
column2: though—this music still moves like a sandstorm. Even at slow tempos it swirls with motion
column3: and nearly all of its forward drive comes from the guitars and bass
column4: with percussionist Said Ag Ayad able to frame the beat rather than having to provide all of it. The group trades off lead vocals and sings in unison
column5: and the four guitarists seem more capable and versatile than ever. There are phrases and rhythms here that wouldn’t have been heard in their music previously.

column1: That growth extends to their album-making craft as well. They’ve become excellent at balancing feels and flow. “Toumast Tincha” opens the album with this sort of hovering feel that only this band can really do
column2: guitars scattering like dust devils while Saul Williams provides a strange
column3: understated spoken word intro. The album then kicks into a higher gear for “Chaghaybou
column4: ” and it’s just the first example of how well-paced it is. A few other Americans drop in. Chavez’ Matt Sweeney and the Red Hot Chili Peppers’ Josh Klinghoffer melt right into the guitarscape
column5: but Nashville session fiddler Fats Kaplin lights up “Imdiwanin ahi Tifhamam” with a fiery performance that brings hints of his hometown to melodies from Al-Andaluse.

column1: It is in some respects hard to be a band like Tinariwen
column2: releasing albums in a Western marketplace where the initial attention you received had a great deal to do with the novelty of your sound. Remaining true to your identity while also evolving and keeping an audience that’s always a moving target interested in you is a tough gig. On Emmaar
column3:
Tinariwen are up to the task.

"|18909.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18909-tinariwen-emmaar/|8.1|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20195/homepage_large.c639c023.jpg|Slip Away|29016.0|Total Slacker|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Black Bell']|2014-02-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:08.574623|"

The sound and aesthetic Total Slacker developed on Thrashin’ was unsustainable. They made a series of bold
column2: primary colored choices on that album
column3: and had they gone down a similar path for a second LP
column4: it would've been a complete slog. Only a few songs on Thrashin' transcended the “cartoon slacker” mire. It was an album that heavily referenced the 1990s
column5: and not simply because of their guitar sound. They had lyrics about “Full House” and Crystal Pepsi. They slapped a Jurassic Park logo on the cover. One of their more contemporary subjects was a song about going on a “MySpace date”. Everything about it felt like a caricature built from memories steeped in Pogs
column6: slap bracelets
column7: and TGIF reruns.

column1: Thankfully
column2: the band largely stepped away from the caricature they created for themselves and adopted a new aesthetic for Slip Away. But they haven’t left the 1990s at all: They’ve launched themselves wholeheartedly into shoegaze territory. Largely gone are the defined guitar textures of their previous LP. Now
column3: a plucked string rings for a bit longer
column4: and when the entire band kicks in for full force
column5: it’s one big gauzy mass of sound.

column1: But if you take a moment to recall a successful record in the shoegaze canon
column2: Slip Away crumbles quickly. Despite being only 37 minutes
column3: it feels twice as long. Everything spins in place ad nauseam without much sense of movement. Sure
column4: there's some passion here
column5: but it's hard to take seriously when it's about fighting the babysitter's boyfriend (on a track called ""Fight the Babysitter's Boyfriend""). Singing from the perspective of a little kid
column6: he delivers cringe-worthy things like
column7: ""I know you've got a mustache/ But you've been treating my babysitter real bad"". Nothing about the song is particularly funny (except the noodly guitar solo toward the end)
column8: so it's hard to say whether or not the band's attempting satire. Further muddling things is a sincere-sounding rallying cry for high self-esteem that clearly doubles as an extended masturbation reference (""Touch Yrself"").

column1: ""Super Big Gulp"" and ""Thighmaster"" both coast on nostalgic references. There's nothing substantial in the way of narrative
column2: humor
column3: or insight
column4: and sonically
column5: the songs stay the monotonous course. Then there's ""Who Killed Kennedy""
column6: which opens with a chug and launches into a series of conspiracy theories regarding JFK's assassination. At one point
column7: Tucker Rountree goes full Drunk Uncle
column8: singing
column9: ""I think Facebook travelled back in time
column10: / think about it
column11: who could have organized the crime.""

column1: It's not all bad. ""See Right Through"" has a strong central guitar and bass line
column2: and the melody and lyrics are perfectly suited to Rountree's nasal vocals. ""Keep the Ships at Bay"" has muscle and drive
column3: which largely makes up for how repetitive it is. They show the most promise on ""Out of Body Experience""
column4: where they pick up the pace and turn up the power to deliver an exciting central hook. The song never gets stale or overstays its welcome—it's a legitimately captivating track with a melody that works well with Rountree's voice. His harmony at the chorus with Emily Oppenheimer is nice and somewhat restrained—a good look for this band. It's a welcome indication that they're capable of so much better than what they offer on Slip Away. They get bogged down by lame references
column5: alluding to popular culture
column6: glorifying Big Gulps as an American icon
column7: and dare I say it
column8: being the band that smokes weed at the Olive Garden. Somewhere behind all that stuff
column9:
there's still potential.

"|18991.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18991-total-slacker-slip-away/|4.5|Evan Minsker

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20112/homepage_large.6939c59f.jpg|Longhena|31991.0|Gridlink|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Handshake
column3: the American/Japanese band Gridlink's pedigree is unrivaled. Vocalist Jon Chang and guitarist Steve Procopio joined the band
column4: which was formed by guitarist Takafumi Matsubara
column5: following the demise of their highly esteemed Discordance Axis. Procopio played live guitar when Rob Marston wasn't able
column6: and being able to replicate those songs is laudable. Drummer Bryan Farjado plays in Kill the Client
column7: Phobia
column8: and Noisear
column9: and bassist Teddy Patterson III was the longtime bassist for Burnt By the Sun. Gridlink even had a brief moment in the pop culture spotlight when their music was featured on an episode of Homeland
column10: fittingly during an interrogation scene.

column1: Their 2008 debut Amber Gray and 2011's Orphan
column2: both released on Hydra Head
column3: were hyper-technical
column4: futuristic albums so dense they could be called “full-lengths” despite their short running times. The two
column5: combined
column6: clock in at around 24 minutes
column7: and feel like classics of the genre. But nothing lasts forever
column8: especially in a genre where 30 minutes counts as a double LP. Gridlink split up following the completion of their third record
column9: Longhena
column10: and while it's a shame that they are no more
column11: they ended their career with a record insurmountable by themselves or their peers.

column1: A cursory look at Longhena's numbers may suggest that Gridlink was calming down. It's their longest record at 22 minutes
column2: and features a couple songs that break the two-minute mark. But Longhena is by far their most intense album
column3: fueled by the fact that it was their last. You can hear that attitude in everyone's playing. Chang's screams are as much of a impenetrable wall as the noise he's in tandem with and also fighting against. Matsubara
column4: who is the sole guitarist here
column5: expunges notes with lethal precision
column6: but varies up his riffing more. Some of the more melodic elements from Hayaino Daisuki
column7: the demented party thrash-grind hybrid side project of Gridlink
column8: appear on Longhena. “Stay Without Me” is catchy in the way Mick Barr playing the Ratt songbook would be catchy. Like the rest of the band members
column9: Matsubara knew this was Gridlink's final stand
column10: so he takes risks that garner huge dividends.

column1: Mostly
column2: the bulk of Longhena is still ultracompact flares of humans replicating the madness of machinery without the sterility. They're the metal equivalent of nanotechnology—Matsubara packs in so much information without bloat. Chang
column3: who's been neck-and-neck with the title for “Metal Poet Laureate” with Pig Destroyer's J.R. Hayes
column4: fuses timeless themes of personal loss with the impersonal carnage of modern warfare. This line from the title track is particularly gutting: “The plate caught the round/ but inside I'm still bathed in shrapnel/ with concentration absent of doubt/ revel in the unimaginable slaughter.” He's coping with his cosmic insignificance while still forming a resistance against it.

column1: Grindcore is not a genre in which the word “beautiful” is used. Production is best left to a minimum
column2: the more xeroxed the better. Lyrical themes revolve around every heinous form of destruction—in broad strokes
column3: with no room for subtleties. Repulsion
column4: one of the style's founding fathers
column5: forged their filth in the basements of Flint
column6: Michigan
column7: which was and still is the hallmark of urban decay brought on by corporate recklessness. Yet
column8: there are a couple moments on Longhena that could be described as “beautiful.” Right off
column9: the opening riff of “Constant Autumn” shows a range many bands can't conceptualize
column10: much less harness. Matsubara sands down what would appear on a lush black metal record into a riff sleek in delivery and devastating on impact. Never has such exuberant joy been communicated in grindcore.

column1: The third song
column2: “Thirst Watcher”
column3: is an instrumental piece consisting of Matsubara's clean guitar and and Pittsburgh-based composer Joey Molinaro's violin. He recorded a violin version of Discordance Axis' 2000 album The Inalienable Dreamless in 2011
column4: so his presence is not only fitting from a compositional point of view
column5: but it's heartening to see a fan get to contribute to his inspiration's passing gasp. While “Watcher” is sonically different from anything Gridlink has ever recorded
column6: it still hangs on that same sheer wire of sanity that the rest of their songs do. The delicacy is just more upfront. Molinaro's violin also appears on “Autumn” and closing track “Look to Winward”
column7: where in the latter it floats on the end of the song and gives a sense of closure not just to the album
column8: but Gridlink's career as a whole.

column1: Gridlink were a band that had no interest in sculpting false idols to kneel before. Putting it simply
column2: they played only how they could play
column3: and no one could match. Longhena fulfills the promise of Discordance Axis' discography and Gridlink's own first two records by pushing the potential of their own limits and what grindcore can be. Chang asks on “Ketsui”: “Are the fangs in our hearts now gone
column4: or is it anger that keeps us alive?” Sometimes
column5: metal and hardcore needs to be reminded that forging your own path is commendable above all
column6:
and Longhena is that reminder.

"|18916.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18916-gridlink-longhena/|8.0|Andy O'Connor

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20146/homepage_large.64b16c1d.jpg|Galore|31729.0|Thumpers|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-02-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:09.811331|"

Let’s table the discussion of what Thumpers sound like for a second and acknowledge the most important aspect of the UK duo’s debut album Galore: it has been dying to meet you. Could not be more excited. Think of when you’re visiting a friend’s house for the first time and they warmly warn you about how their bull mastiff can be awfully playful around new friends. It could be doing absolutely nothing all day and the moment you step in the door
column2: they spring into action to waylay you with slobbering affection. And if you act surprised
column3: or god forbid
column4: resist it
column5: you’re going to look like kind of an asshole. Sound familiar? Got that? Still in? Cool
column6: because that’s pretty much what happens the moment you press play on Galore.

column1: As far as what it sounds like
column2: well
column3: if the name “Thumpers” brings to mind the adorable rabbit from Bambi doing his thing on giant floor toms
column4: you’re on the right track. The fifth track on Galore is called “Come on Strong”
column5: and it’s the record’s thematic mission statement
column6: filled as it is with extroverted melodies
column7: booming
column8: insistent drums and glimmering production. It’s cute
column9: percussive
column10: motormouthed music that’s particularly prevalent and successful in Thumpers’ neck of the woods. But
column11: god bless Thumpers
column12: they don’t want to alienate a single one of you
column13: so singles like “Unkinder (A Tougher Love)” and “Dancing’s Done” bound forward like Winnie the Pooh and his gang
column14: and for better or worse
column15: they forgo the eccentricities of their peers—they aren’t as glitchy as Alt-J
column16: as annoyingly overstuffed as Everything Everything
column17: or as flaccid as Two Door Cinema Club. By the same token
column18: they aren’t as adventurous as Bombay Bicycle Club or dancefloor-oriented as John Hamson
column19: Jr.’s former gig Friendly Fires.

column1: In fact
column2: Thumpers sound downright American—partly because they draw a lot of their sounds from post-Feels Animal Collective
column3: but also due to their shock and awe policy of performing cannonballs without any concern for the splashback. Though a field recording of London’s idyllic Regent’s Canal graces opener “Marvel”
column4: look at the cover
column5: for crying out loud. These songs take place in swimming pools
column6: but their aw-shucks attitude suggest they’re swimming holes. Likewise
column7: even if the dominant theme in these songs are making your most treasured summer memories right now
column8: they’re so stoked about them that they’re just going to drop Galore right in the middle of February. They just can’t wait three more months.

column1: But the charm offensive can turn flat-out offensive if Galore catches you on the wrong day
column2: and if that’s the case
column3: you can look smack in the middle of the tracklist for the culprit: “Now We Are Sixteen” [ft. Summer Camp]. Not so much the song itself
column4: though its dippy coed balladry does make for the weakest song here. Just read the title. If 2009’s obsession with the rudimentary aspects of nostalgia now triggers a certain kind of PTSD
column5: Galore can be a pretty bad trip. The first words Marcus Pepperell sings are “stay young” and throughout he tries to speak in the language of hormonal teens: “we’re tired but ripe
column6: ”  “bed jumping
column7: him and her are full of passions tonight
column8: ” Or
column9: there’s the irrepressible and extremely grating superball arrangements of “Tame” and “Roller”
column10: which remind you of just how masterfully Merriweather Post Pavilion danced in a hippie-indie drum circle without just bouncing around the room.

column1: No genre or band has ownership of the sound of a wet
column2: hot American summer—you can hear it in any number of rock acts from Japandroids to Mikal Croninspecifically
column3: or most strains of hip-hop
column4: country or pop music. Yes
column5: there’s pretty of sunlight on Galore
column6: but no heat or friction
column7: as everything from the production to Pepperell’s enunciation is so glassy that all of these somersaulting hooks might as well be gibberish. Sometimes
column8: they are—“Tame” literally is built on “hummina
column9: hummina.”

column1: The real issue is more inherent in their accurately and unfortunately named collaborators on “Now We Are Sixteen”: no matter how enthusiastic and endearing Thumpers are on Galore
column2: they’re camp counselors. Sure
column3: they’re invested and they relate and they’ll do everything in their power to facilitate your good time. Problem is
column4: there’s a disconnect: they can’t join you. And they’d prefer it if you kept the fun good and clean
column5: so your parents don’t find out. And then you remember the sage lesson Thumpers’ namesake had imparted by his parents: ""If you can't say something nice
column6: don't say nothing at all."" Good advice
column7: but not the kind of earnest
column8:
rule-following that leads to the sort of adventures Galore so badly wants to be a part of.
