The question of whether Marissa Nadler's elegant folk music ought to soundtrack our dreams or haunt our nightmares has been a thread through her uncannily cohesive catalogue. With six albums in 10 years and never a misstep
column2: Nadler has grown her own perceptive language—she's an old-soul lost in time like Sibylle Baier
column3: but her music is blackened and more literary. Her songs have come steeped in misery and macabre
column4: cobwebs and ashes
column5: but Nadler is not a doomy aesthete merely for gloom's sake. She is devoted to Leonard Cohen and Joni Mitchell
column6: and her music understands folk tradition. While her songs sound isolated and spiritually vintage
column7: as if beamed from the grayscale interior of a Victorian home
column8: her stories have been generous
column9: selfless tales
column10: heavy with metaphor and imagery. Nadler's poetic temperament and steady grace point to a darkness within us all—though her singing always seems to hone on mortality not for the purpose of crushing
column11: existential missives
column12: but in order to protect us.

column1: Each of Nadler's albums has signaled subtle evolution. After channeling a bewitched Hope Sandoval and establishing a gothic heart
column2: her sound became gorgeous and nuanced on 2007's III
column3: broke from the freak-folk tag on 2009's astounding Little Hells
column4: and incorporated sing-song Gillian Welch-inspired country pop on 2011's gleaming Marissa Nadler. Still
column5: she has never let her dark essence slip away—this is a singer whose first record mixed traditional English balladry with an arrangement of Edgar Allen Poe's ""Annabelle Lee"" and a song about the death of Virginia Woolf. ""I once was young and I once was strong
column6: she sang then
column8: at age 23 on ""Box of Cedar"". Nadler's music has been tinged by country blues and murder balladry
column9: by people who died alone and old loves who creep her memory. But empathy has defined her work. See
column10: for example
column11: Nadler’s tender treatment of the recurring figure Mayflower May
column12: a lonely and reflective old woman
column13: or the 20th-century siamese twin circus performers Daisy and Violet (2011's spellbinding<a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G32BgjbRNAM"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""> ""Daisy
column14: Where Did You Go?"" explores what happened to Violet when Daisy died first
column15: an especially harrowing piece of historical subject matter).

column1: Nadler's self-described ""dreadfully shy"" wallflower persona fits in well with these earlier records
column2: filled with swaths of muted color and third-person characters. July is another side of Marissa Nadler; if she sounded older back on Little Hells
column3: Nadler is younger and bolder now
column4: in confessional mode. Here are intimately personal accounts of misread desire
column5: an empty heart set by winter blues
column6: and years wasted on a lover who could do no right. ""I called you when I was drunk all the time
column7: Nadler sings on the quiet
column8: finger-picked ""Holiday In""
column9: stranded on a mountain in winter
column10: recalling a depleted love. This is the ""beer/thank-you"" of Nadler's new honest approach. ""I'd rather watch crime TV than see you again
column11: she sings. It is a shocking but humanizing charm to hear Nadler reference even basic technologies in song. More so than any of Nadler's records
column12: July is a self-knowing and zenlike advocate of change; ""I know better now/ I don't get as high
column13: she sings on the intensely detailed breakup song ""Firecrackers
column14: pointing blame at herself as she steadies her own romantic mess of ghosts and lovers.

column1: July is more tactile thanks to new producer Randall Dunn
column2: best known for his work with metal bands such as Earth
column3: Sunn O)))
column4: and Wolves in the Throne Room. (Dunn has also worked on folkier projects for Akron/Family and Six Organs of Admittance
column5: but Nadler has ties to the black metal community
column6: having collaborated with Xasthur and Locrian.) The pairing befits Nadler's sound. Like black metal
column7: her songs are atmospheric
column8: austere
column9: and engulfing. At times
column10: Nadler's resonant acoustic strums are coated thick
column11: as if emboldened by the deep ebony outline of a Sharpie marker. Her gothic touchstones return more deliberately melodic
column12: and the audible strength of her voice lends to a more idiosyncratic sound; even the quiet acoustic songs and piano ballad sound like they are set up on-stage. There are textured synths and the occasional electric guitar underneath
column13: and the dramatic orchestral strings that underpin ""1923"" offer the song a sense of grandeur—""I called you from another century/ To see if the world had been kind and sweet
column14: Nadler sings
column15: offering not just an impressionistic line but a pointed one that sums up an essential idea about her work. It's Nadler's stacked
column16: carefully pronounced harmonies
column17: though
column18: that really make these songs stand so tall.

column1: The forward movement of July can be entrancing and propulsive: ""Drive"" and ""I've Got Your Name"" are evocative Americana road songs
column2: the former cast with a cruel road-weary disaffection that she medicates naturally: ""Still remember all the words/ To every song you ever heard
column3: Nadler sings
column4: conjuring more direct
column5: intuitive emotions than usual. There are grittier details here
column6: too: ""Changed in a rest-stop into my dress/ Made sure not to touch the floor/ I've done that kind of thing before
column7: she sings from the side of the I-95. Nadler always sounds like a journeying soul poet
column8: but here she makes her rootless experience clear
column9: as on the piercing ""Holiday In"": ""You have a girl in every state/ I know I'm in the way.""

column1: ""Dead City Emily"" is July's hypnotic centerpiece
column2: the realization of Nadler and Dunn's work at the stone-cold polar vortex of folk structure and doom metal mood. Nadler's rain-streaked music has an overcast glow here
column3: one that comes with a first snowfall
column4: the realism of dead leaves and paralyzing ice. Nadler has few direct contemporaries—Bill Callahan
column5: Sharon Van Etten
column6: or Alela Diane come to mind—but here
column7: on July's most extreme song
column8: she could sensibly share bills with
column9: say
column10: Iceage or Deafheaven. The song’s fictional conversation is made of inner-strife
column11: trapped in a devil town and a dead-end love
column12: jaded towards the innate beauty of trees or birds—images Nadler has used throughout her songbook. Nadler typically speaks through female figures
column13: and while there is struggle in this exchange
column14: there is also power
column15:
like she is teaching another woman or warning her in secret. July's stories are rich with such wisdom.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20119/homepage_large.8f332501.jpg|Chorus EP|30806.0|Holly Herndon|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2014-02-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:11.804646|"

Holly Herndon’s work thrives on the tension between abstraction and accessibility. Large chunks of her full-length debut
column2: Movement
column3: reflected the Mills College graduate’s grounding in academia. Early on
column4: electronic music was mostly the product of state-funded institutions like universities and public radio due to the vast resources needed to acquire and maintain the equipment. The people who had access to the machines in the 1950s and 60s were artists
column5: theorists
column6: and technicians
column7: and not always in that order. Coming out of the world of 20th century classical music
column8: which had happily abandoned the possibility of mass appeal
column9: artists like John Cage and Milton Babbitt pursued electronic music with an exploratory zeal that often abandoned ideas conventional musicality. That electronic music from the academic world can often be described as dry and clinical is not a sleight—the pleasures are there
column10: they just happen to be more cerebral. About half of the excellent Movement (""Breathe""
column11: ""Dilato"") worked this side of the room. But then there were tracks like ""Fade"" and the title track
column12: which applied Hendon’s brilliant textural ear and vocal manipulations to a context where rhythm and melody were equally important.

column1: Chorus
column2: Herndon’s new two-song EP
column3: essentially amplifies the extremes of her musical personality and pushes the tension almost to the breaking point. The title track already has the feel of minor landmark
column4: as she chops and processes her voice into disorienting shapes while retaining its human core. In terms of her basic palette
column5: she’s operating in a terrain not too far from Oneohtrix Point Never’s latest
column6: R Plus Seven; ""Chorus"" has some of the cool
column7: clean
column8: and disconcertingly empty cast of an early computer’s 8-bit soundbank
column9: and the fragments of her vocal evoke hand-keyed early sampling
column10: where you’d play the shifted pitches on a keyboard. Using these vaguely retro tools
column11: she’s crafted a sleek futuristic pop song with an experimental bent that is ultimately deeply emotional.

column1: The B-side
column2: ""Solo Voice""
column3: comes from a different place. It takes tiny shards of syllables and sets them ping-ponging between the speakers; as was often true on Movement
column4: the massive amount of space means you sometimes wonder if the piece has ended only to have more notes emerge from the silence. It comes over like an art object as much as a piece of music
column5: and it has its own kind of steely beauty despite its vastly more abstracted feel. The basic elements of ""Chorus"" and ""Solo Voice"" have much in common
column6: but the difference in how they work is significant
column7: which speaks to Herndon’s expansive range as a composer. As two sides of her aesthetic are pushed to new heights on this 12""
column8:
the possibilities of her future music seem vast indeed.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20207/homepage_large.9128a689.jpg|Instant Alpha|31997.0|Feadz|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ed Banger']|2014-02-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:12.328025|"

Feadz
column2: aka Fabian Pianta
column3: has been a longtime pillar of French house. He emerged in the late 90s alongside Mr. Oizo (whose excellent
column4: deranged 1999 album Analog Worms Attack was a Feadz co-production)
column5: accompanied Uffie during her stint in the spotlight from ""Pop the Glock"" onwards
column6: and put in work for both BPitch Control and Ed Banger
column7: two of the most vital
column8: tastemaking labels of the 00s. Throughout that time
column9: he's managed to build a following as both an influential DJ and a jack-of-all-trades producer who can dabble in just about any corner of dance music there is.

column1: If his full-length debut
column2: Instant Alpha
column3: highlights anything
column4: it's the limits of how far mere dabbling can get a producer—especially if that artist tries to fuse all his limited tricks together. Instant Alpha betrays a sound that staples together the most immediate
column5: surface-level pleasures of an accumulated jumble of styles and expects the in-your-face bits to prop up otherwise hollow-sounding tracks. Electro's Euro-slick decadence
column6: trap's chest-out wildness
column7: Southern rap's low-end throb
column8: grime's raw low-budget futurism
column9: house's lifeblood pulse
column10: bass music's rhythmic elasticity—these ideas are all melted down and left to congeal on the counter
column11: leaving a burnt yet cold pile of goo that sort of resembles a cursory club jam.

column1: The main culprit is the impatient
column2: almost assaultive way Feadz rolls out his beats. I say ""beats"" when a more accurate term would be tics—machine-gun kicks are shoved out into wide-open spaces where they're subjected to water-drip bloops
column3: hyperactive stammering vocal snippets
column4: strobing synthesizers that hiccup until they puke
column5: and incessant empty-calorie hooks (like this unattributed winner from ""Papercut"": ""I spit fire like I tongue-kissed a dragon""). The line between that kind of thing being big dumb fun and a big dumb headache is almost invisible
column6: but with a whole lot of momentum-shifting jumpiness and not a lot of time to build organically and gradually to a crescendo—most tracks are less than 3 1/2 minutes—it all feels too anxious and bristly to soundtrack anything short of a mindstate aided by moon rocks and vodka
column7: and even then it might sour your mood.

column1: Want a florid description of how the music's supposed to make you feel? ""The Purpose"" has you covered there
column2: as the distorted voice of TTC's Teki Latex relays the agenda of a man who sounds like a benevolent megalomaniac of a DJ ambassador: ""Connecting minds together through an invisible network of vibrations
column3: creating euphoric states
column4: projecting childhood memories inside your brain
column5: but taking you to yet unknown places."" You'll also get a good sense of the sound via the list of obvious influences. For instance
column6: <span>""Electric Empire""
column7: featuring guest vocalist Kito
column8: is a thematic hybrid of Daft Punk's roll-call ""Teachers"" and GZA's ""Labels"" wordplay (""It's a house without a home/ Uptown in 'Techno City'/ With Mo'Wax than you can think of in your Metroplex Fantasy"").

column1: There might be the occasional inspired rhythm track under all this mess—""Metaman"" and ""Eastside"" at least prove that Feadz knows his way around an 808 (or a simulacrum thereof)—but it's nothing you can't get from countless other artists who choose not to bury those beats in over-the-top hyperactivity like a parodic attempt at the next ""Harlem Shake"". It's all signifiers and nothing signified
column2:
exploring the possibilities of cross-genre dance music the same way mashing an action figure and a Barbie doll together explores sex.

"|19003.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19003-feadz-instant-alpha/|4.3|Nate Patrin

column2: 'Experimental'

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['White Rainbow']|2014-02-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:12.888885|"

As White Rainbow
column4: Portland's Adam Forkner was a darling of a time when indie rock was just beginning its dalliance with synth music. Records like 2007's Prism Of Eternal Now
column5: with their makeshift rhythms
column6: devotionally droning ambience
column7: and spiralling melodies now feel lovably antiquated—listen back and you can hear Merriweather Post Pavilion in their bones. After a hiatus that lasted several years
column8: White Rainbow returns with a self-released album
column9: Thru.U
column10: where he attempts to update his hippietastic sprawl with a more modern template and a newfound sense of irony. The result is a bizarre
column11: occasionally confusing record of new age trap and psychedelic pop.

column1: Funnily enough
column2: ""Batman Palace"" picks up where his old material left off—sweeping melodies and iridescent synths—albeit juiced up with some jittery beats. Halfway between Washed Out and DJ Rashad
column3: its half-sung
column4: half-hummed melodies and blanketing synths have all the baked-afternoon complacency of someone who just discovered chillwave. From there it gets different. Where Forkner used to bury the heart of his songs in slowly unfolding drones
column5: now everything is front-and-centre
column6: shoved forward by the rhythms. ""Killswitch"" is an uplifting trap number with an almost cinematic breadth to it—imagine one of the more melodic old White Rainbow tracks and plug in some Lex Luger hi-hats to get an idea. If that sounds a bit silly to you
column7: that's how it comes out on the record
column8: too.

column1: Often it seems like Forkner is grabbing at contemporary sounds around him to try and fix himself back into a niche—after all
column2: four years off the market must make it hard to find your place again
column3: especially in a world as fickle as electronic music. But his grasping is amateurish; on ""Don't Wait""
column4: the drizzly synth lead clashes badly with the drums
column5: while the centerpiece ""Be the Dancer Be the Dreamer"" sets itself up to be one of those epic White Rainbow corkers but ends up twiddling its thumbs between tip-toeing around and trying to break out into a bigger dance number
column6: while Forkner's vocals fail to make much of an impression at all.

column1: The album's second half slows down to a gentler place. ""Plane 2 Sea"" and ""Only 4 Us"" are bite-sized pop ditties with goofy vocals
column2: and ""Touchdown"" is a lead-footed stomper with whiffs of the L.A. instrumental hip-hop scene. These tracks fare better than the experiments on the first half
column3: but there's something inconsequential about them—it's almost like Forkner is joking around
column4: an idea only reinforced by silly moments like the slapbass interlude ""Cuban Egg"". There's nothing wrong with artists taking themselves less seriously
column5: but from an act who was responsible for emotional epics like ""Warm Clicked Fruit""
column6: his particular brand of antidepressant is a hard one to swallow.

column1: Thru.U is disappointingly slight for a comeback album
column2: but it's also a relief
column3: because there are glimmers of the old brilliance in there. It just feels like he's having trouble expressing them. After the faux-80s ballad ""Terminator Failed""
column4: Forkner brings the album to a glorious finish with the lengthy ""Screen Blind""
column5: which builds over seven minutes of ecstatic synthesizer. It's one of the few tracks on the LP that retains the scope of his old work
column6: but it's brushed and bevelled with a distinctly modern brightness—a hopeful reminder of his past triumphs
column7:
and enough to convince you that maybe he just needs some time to get back on his feet.

"|18983.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18983-white-rainbow-thruu/|6.0|Andrew Ryce

As Chief Keef has transformed from WorldStar novelty to scapegoat for Chicago’s noxious realities
column2: “Chiraq”—a lawless yin to Black Portland’s sunny yang—has been poked and prodded from reasonably safe distances. A slew of documentaries have
column3: with varying degrees of delicacy
column4: danced around the question: which came first
column5: the scary music or the scary city? (The answer is obvious; the question
column6: fruitless.) Meanwhile
column7: consumers of this music—drill
column8: the flinty

But to moralize drill is to miss the point: it’s radical not necessarily because of what its artist espouse

column1: Still
column2: after over a year of monopoly over the city’s rap scene
column3: drill’s ubiquity threatened to neuter its potency. Things grew weird. And after the 1000th unwieldy Young Chop imitation
column4: is it any wonder Keef cannonballed straight into the sound’s murky deep end post-Finally Rich? Out of the exhaust from the scene’s fission emerged
column5: in essence
column6: its antithesis: bop
column7: a chirpy
column8: hyper-saturated romp through major keys and egregious Auto-Tune paired with a goofily swaggy (though no doubt athletic) dance. Incubated on Chicago’s west side in late 2012
column9: popularized over last summer
column10: and currently going national
column11: there are still relatively few comprehensive entry points to the sound
column12: apart from savvy YouTubeing. Enter DJ Moondawg

column14: stupid!” drops on tapes like Keef’s star-making “Back From The Dead” and Lil Durk’s “Life Ain’t No Joke”

column1: Spanning from its infancy (hits like Stunt Taylor’s “Fefe On The Block” and “Fiesta
column2: ” one of bubbling duo Sicko Mobb’s first records) to just-surfaced exclusives (a pair of tracks from promising newcomer King Deazel and “What to Do”
column3: a delirious new cut from mainstay Lil Chris)
column4: the movement’s roughly year-long history is concisely but thoroughly mapped over the tape’s 13 tracks. There are transformations over time
column5: most notably with Sicko Mobb
column6: bop’s weirdest and quickest-rising act (they recently signed with Stargate’s Sony/ATV imprint). “Fiesta”
column7: a twangy
column8: tinny
column9: blues-inflected bit of alien ringtone rap
column10: sounds miles away production-wise from their latest
column11: “Zoom Zoom”
column12: on which they fully realize their pop potential without sacrificing too much of the frenzy. But overall
column13: the sound is consistent: Auto-Tune-drenched sing-raps
column14: a fixation with melody often evocative of nursery rhymes
column15: aggressively bright synths
column16: frantic percussion. On first listen
column17: it’s slightly jarring
column18: verging on campy. But its DNA is familiar: the garbled romanticism and extreme vocal manipulations of contemporary Atlanta
column19: where Future is king; the experimental physicality of Chicago dance music from house to juke to footwork; the meme-friendly grassroots nature of regional dance trends from jerking to the nae nae; melodic
column20: triumphant mid-2000s swag rap. In particular
column21: Soulja Boy’s “Zan With That Lean Pt. 1” and F.L.Y.’s 2009 “Jamboree” album (yeah
column22: the “Swag Surfin” dudes) contain much of bop’s blueprint.

column1: Those in search of lyrical miracles can quit while they’re ahead: there’s little to be found in the way of “bars” here. Even from a quick scan of the explicitly dance-party-centric titles (“fefe
column2: ” short for fiesta
column3: is the scene’s preferred term for party)
column4: it’s clear the aim is an escape from the cerebral
column5: a celebration of the body and spirit. As with most dance-friendly swag rap
column6: the songs can feel fluffy
column7: their utilitarian lyrics primarily directing or detailing the turn-up and little else; “Kemo Step” and “Dlow Shuffle” are purely instructional
column8: a new generation of DIY Cha Cha Slides. In fact
column9: it makes more sense to consider the tape as an exhibition of dance music as much as rap music
column10: particularly as the logical evolution of footwork warped from saturation in a rap-centric environment (as evidenced by bop forefather DJ Nate’s transformation from spazzy footwork ingenue to rap-crooner). As such
column11: dancing
column12: fucking
column13: and bacchanalia aren’t filler content: they’re the entire point. Often
column14: near-oppressive vocal processing blurs words into indecipherable jumbles—after 15 listens
column15: I’m without a clue as to what the hook of “Zoom Zoom” says at all—but semantics are unnecessary here. As with much of the melody-obsessed
column16: experimental young Atlanta rap (and
column17: increasingly
column18: with Keef)
column19: the voice is a tool for conveying emotion rather than information. Across the board on the tape
column20: that emotion is unadulterated jubilance.

column1: We Invented the Bop points to a different way to face the seriousness of “Chiraq” as it stands: playful
column2: ecstatic
column3: and sure
column4: perhaps frivolous escapism. But the frivolous is endowed with a new sense of poignancy here. In a vacuum

column6:
it’s an active defiance of perpetuated violence; its aggressive positivity feels as vital now as Keef’s chronicles of nihilism did in 2012.

column4: into complex musical webs. McGuire wrote
column5: played
column6: and produced everything here

column11: 68-minute set

column13: 000-word series of lyrics
column14: essays
column15: and acknowledgements that position this music as a sonic parable. “This is the story that turns in the heart of all mankind
column16: ” he writes
column17: “the quest of the individual seeking the answers to the great mysteries of life.” The text follows a character from birth into the confusion of adolescence and the worry of young adulthood

column19: honesty

column3: ” “interpersonal chaos

column6: Along the Way bends somewhat to the will of the narrative its notes espouse: Opener “The Awakening” feels like a sunrise
column7: and closer “Turiya (The Same Way)” suggests a Ratatat-ready celebration of what’s been learned. The 12-minute “The Instinct” unfurls a rather literal rendering of its accompanying drama. “The individual does not flinch
column8: and rides right into the heart of the beast

column1: McGuire
column2: however

column4: especially when it involves existential anxiety or despair. Just before the record’s midpoint

column11: and drops out to find himself. Aside from gobs of distorted bass and chord patterns that don’t always resolve

column13: the supposedly troubled portions of the narrative still sound hopeful

column15: he rarely pulls it into the sounds. That’s something of an easy way out

column3: perhaps more exactly

no braggadocio; this is only the very sincere statement of a person doing his best to work through the worries of living and share any delight he’s stumbled upon along the way.

column13: knotty cataracts spilling over refracted dub and jazz
column14: noise and abstraction. It was a primer for Guardian Alien’s broad musical reach
column15: suggesting a group whose interests were as wide as the psychedelic sky above. It was
column16: in earnest

column1: Spiritual Emergency follows the noble freak/free music tradition of pitting one or several sides of short takes against one sidelong epic. The album’s first half links four divergent improvisations
column2: while Guardian Alien commits the flip to an extended
column3: excited span that starts near silence and ends in paroxysmal explosion. The structural decision places Guardian Alien in an idiomatic continuum that includes John Coltrane
column4: Patty Watters
column5: Frank Zappa
column6: Art Ensemble of Chicago
column7: and Amon Düül II. It also spotlights the band’s admirable willingness to tinker with most anything: That first side includes a duet for chopped-and-stacked samples and percussion that might recall the Books and an electric guitar drone that stretches and then drifts into the distance
column8: like Bardo Pond on a lunch break. “Mirror” is a drum-and-noise tirade that mirrors Lightning Bolt
column9: while opener “Tranquilizer” bounds between rhythms and samples
column10: effects and instruments like a warm-up jam from the salad days of Gang Gang Dance or Black Dice. That tizzy of activity and references
column11: mind you
column12: happens in an erratic 20 minutes—not enough time for any of the ideas to congeal into something greater or for the pieces to feel like more than loose leaves from the Guardian Alien’s collective notebook. Momentarily intriguing but never quite transfixing
column13: they are exercises in exercising.

column1: Their slightness comes in bas-relief to the audacious title track
column2: the new pinnacle of Guardian Alien’s limited output. “Spiritual Emergency” begins with a reading by Stanislav Grof from Spiritual Emergency: When Personal Transformation Becomes A Crisis
column3: a book that argues for working through freak-outs of faith rather than treating them like mental illness. Guardian Alien takes the idea as precept here
column4: rising and falling in and out of momentum and confusion. They struggle to keep the rhythm and find the groove
column5: to build from basic ideas into something grand. Drewchin’s voice drifts like a ghoulish invocation. Gann winds through the hyperactivity with a sterling desert-blues riffs
column6: daring the quintet to follow him into the distance. They do for a bit
column7: idling into a land of jam-band torpor just ahead of the 16-minute mark. But it’s a feint: All at once
column8: the band bursts forward
column9: drums and voices and guitars surging into the ecstasy of volume. It’s a new peak for Guardian Alien
column10: a breakthrough that shows their ability to be mutually focused and wild
column11: composed and chaotic. It’s exhilarating
column12: liberating stuff
column13: a deserving entry in the sidelong canon it follows.

column1: As with “Spiritual Emergency”
column2: Mitral Transmission succeeds because of its singular direction and focus. For years
column3: Milford Graves—the border-defiant drummer
column4: medicine man
column5: scientist
column6: and theoretician who played on many ESP Disk albums that shape Guardian Alien’s larger aesthetic—has recorded and analyzed the heart beats of musicians in his Queens basement laboratory. “His heart research can help anyone
column7: ” wrote New York’s Mark Jacobson in 2001
column8: “but mostly he works on musicians
column9: ‘so they hear how they sound naturally
column10: let them compare that with what they’re playing.’” Graves invited Fox into his lair for one of these sessions
column11: connecting him to sensors and software that allowed Fox to listen to the beat and pitch of his own body. He used that data as the basis for Mitral Transmission’s four compositions
column12: wondrous instrumentals that fascinate with or without their biosynthetic context.

column1: These tracks float occasionally toward the negative connotations of “new age music
column2: ” with long stretches of steel drum radiance
column3: plucked harp patterns
column4: softly pattered rhythms
column5: and nebulous tones that suggest a breeze across a meadow. But the music’s too busy and prickly for somnolence. Just when the motion starts to settle
column6: Fox adds a brief shock of noise or a new trace of rhythm to upset the system ever so slightly. “Heartbeat cycles with asymmetrical time values are more healthy
column7: ” Graves once told Wavelength Magazine. “This asymmetry is called the chaotic heartbeat.” Fox’s interlocking meters and melodies shape a pinwheel sort of gamelan
column8: spinning forever into new moments of wonder. Less esoteric than its origins suggest
column9: the music lands somewhere between an acoustic recasting of Four Tet’s coruscant electronica and Matmos’ alien-but-accessible trip.

column1: Mitral Transmission is a fascinating album
column2: then
column3: a would-be footnote that reveals Fox’s willingness to mine most anything for sound. Sometimes
column4: as on the first half of Spiritual Emergency
column5: that process can lead to messy results. But elsewhere
column6:
it’s the power pushing Guardian Alien and Fox past their past associations and into a wonderfully strange and unpredictable future.

At last
column2: Greg Fox might’ve drummed himself past parenthetical suffixation. For the last two years
column3: the wildly prolific Fox has worked with a dozen projects
column4: from his own electronic rampages as GDFX to the spirited explorations of the improvisation-and-academia sublimation squad Zs. There’ve been stints with the drum militia Man Forever and the arid punk band Cy Dune
column5: treks with garage weirdos PC Worship and sets with stylistic jester C. Spencer Yeh. But through most all of this
column6: Fox’s name has been chased by one thorny apposition: (ex-Liturgy). For all the talk of treatises and transcendentalism
column7: Fox was Liturgy’s locomotive
column8: powering their metal with his relentless and intricate drumming. Fox hasn’t been in the band since October 2011
column9: but the association is just now
column10: at last
column11: beginning to peel from his side.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20060/homepage_large.b8140080.jpg|Angel Guts: Red Classroom|4683.0|Xiu Xiu|['Rock'
column3: Jamie Stewart released his most purposefully disturbing record as Xiu Xiu: not Knife Play
column4: not Fag Patrol
column5: and not <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13933-dear-god-i-hate-myself/""><i>Dear God
column6: I Hate Myself. That would be Fabulous Muscles
column7: which placed Stewart's NC-17 lyrical deviance within the context of streamlined
column8: not-quite pop songs and
column9: as a result
column10: gave us something more unsettling than his cover art—a Xiu Xiu record presumably meant for mass consumption. It’s remained his most accessible work and not coincidentally
column11: his strongest. But its bold extroversion has also made it an outlier amongst his overall oeuvre: in the time since
column12: individual Xiu Xiu songs have been shocking
column13: disgusting
column14: catchy
column15: affecting
column16: and kinda hilarious. But taking the longview
column17: the project itself has become kinda predictable. Or at least reliable
column18: as Xiu Xiu albums of nearly equal quality arrive to nearly equally positive reviews like clockwork—if La Forêt or The Air Force didn’t convince you
column19: I don’t see how Women As Lovers or Always were going to do the trick. Point being that Xiu Xiu still makes potent
column20: interesting art. The unconverted just need a new way in.

column1: Angel Guts: Red Classroomacknowledges that possibility
column2: bearing the promise of being the most dark and bleak Xiu Xiu album
column3: but those claims read like ""new tastier recipe!"" on a can of Chunky Soup: an unquantifiable way of enhancing what it was supposed to be in the first place. You won’t mistake Angels Guts as the work of anyone else
column4: but after a curiously tame Nina Simone covers album
column5: Stewart wisely places himself in the lineage of depraved art-rock titans equally drawn to literal and figurative human bondage. He opened for Swans during their tour for The Seer
column6: which is a tremendous cosign: you need to be antagonistic and artistically pure enough to appeal to Michael Gira
column7: but you also need the balls to open for the most intimidating live band on earth playing an autoharp by yourself. Stewart acquitted himself tremendously and Thor Harris returns the favor by contributing percussion to Angel Guts
column8: most notably the bells on “El Naco” which recall his own work on the doomsaying “Avatar”. On a macro level
column9: you might hear Angel Guts capturing the same juxtaposition of dissonance
column10: decaying beauty
column11: and eerie calm of The Seer and condensing it into three-minute pieces on its instrumental bookends.

column1: While Stewart’s more-emo-than-emo
column2: hypothermic quavering is as sui generis as ever
column3: you can also hear echoes of Scott Walker’s defiled operatics during the dramatic rise of “Stupid in the Dark” and “A Knife in the Sun”. Most often
column4: you hear Suicide; for people who weren't ""there"" the first time around and only know them as a namedrop
column5: that means a twisted metal cacophony of rudimentary drum machines
column6: industrial squealing
column7: and hypnotic synth lines. Co-opting that sound makes you no more outre than Sky Ferreira
column8: though the metallic poisoning pervades the entirety of Angel Guts rather than one song
column9: making subtle diversions even more challenging to spot: avian swoops punctuating the nearly psychedelic “Lawrence Liquors
column10: ” “Adult Friends”’s juddering techno
column11: even calypso during “Bitter Melon”.

column1: Of course
column2: if we’re going to talk about the “bleakest” Xiu Xiu album to date
column3: it’s probably going to be a result of the lyrics. You won’t be disappointed. As far as the source of Angel Guts: Red Classroom's title
column4: I hate to quote the press release
column5: but we’d be better off assuming neither of us has previously seen the “Japanese erotic noir” film of the same name
column6: which explored “racialized sex
column7: double suicide
column8: double penetration
column9: criminality
column10: fear of physical harm.” You know
column11: like a Xiu Xiu album. This is most likely the inspiration behind “Black Dick”
column12: which could’ve also been called “white ass
column13: ” “yellow titties”
column14: or “brown pussy
column15: ” except Stewart chose the one lyric that makes for the most Xiu Xiu-ian chorus: “black DICK! DICK! DICK! DICK! DICK!” On first glance
column16: it’s more eye-rolling or “shocking” than actually shocking
column17: giving you the impression that Stewart is simply playing to type. Of course
column18: he knows this and manages to be pretty funny about it during the whole thing
column19: describing the accoutrements of the aforementioned as “one cheek like Jesus/ the other like Hey-Zeus
column20: ” and “one ball like a skull/ the other ball like Bullet Bill
column21: ” so now you have to grasp the dichotomy of Stewart juggling Japanese ""Roman porno"" fare and Super Mario Wii on a Friday night.

column1: The laughs aren’t new
column2: nor are they isolated
column3: as “Cinthya’s Unisex” and “Adult Friends” actually find Stewart’s horrifyingly grim outlook appropriate for the subject of aging and desperate hookups
column4: although spiked with the requisite S&M  (“you reduced your breasts to a more tasteful size D/ when I touch them it is like a lobster crawling under my arm”). What does constitute a new wrinkle is  the physical sense of place
column5: as opposed to the general squalor pervading Xiu Xiu’s music. Though the sounds and themes of Angel Guts gives one the impression of New York in the “glorious shithole” 80s
column6: it’s actually Stewart’s “Los Angeles album
column7: ” as he recently relocated across the country after four years in North Carolina.

column1: But this isn’t like Liars’ Sisterworld
column2: a cultural critique from a cantankerous transplant. Stewart drew inspiration from a gang-infested
column3: horrifying part of Los Angeles he “unwittingly” moved to
column4: reflected in the true crime stories of “Stupid In The Dark” and the poisoned hysterics of “El Naco” (“ants in the kimchi!/a worm in my stool!”). And yet
column5: something about his plausible deniability gets to why Angel Guts can prick the surface without getting under your skin. How could he not know what he was getting into? We’re talking about a touring musician who has the curiosity to find the deepest recesses of Japanese erotic noir
column6: you don’t think he could check Westside Rentals?

column1: As a result
column2: Angel Guts can occasionally feel like stunt journalism
column3: and you wonder how much skin Stewart has in the game
column4: so to speak. Or whether the move really sparked much new at all: the apocalyptic suicide fantasy of “New Life Immigration” feels like a continuation of Fabulous Muscles’ “Little Panda McElroy”
column5: yet another Xiu Xiu love song that essentially expresses the emotion as “I hate everyone but you
column6: ” which is
column7: in fact
column8: a lyric from “Cinthya’s Unisex.”

column1: Which is to say that Angel Guts is yet another strong
column2: occasionally frustrating record restrained by Stewart’s consistency. Xiu Xiu albums feel safe
column3: not in the sense of being conservative
column4: but protective—a place where you can shout “black DICK! DICK! DICK! DICK!” without any sense of judgment or risk
column5: even if you don’t know why you're doing so in the first place. And that can be a little disappointing
column6: considering how vital Stewart can and should be. Outcasts surely discover Xiu Xiu every year
column7: and he’s become a touchstone for his peers—he’s collaborated with Grouper
column8: been covered by Shearwater
column9: acknowledged as a main influence by Perfume Genius
column10: and you can hear echoes of his confrontational
column11: confessional songwriting in Baths’ Obsidian and Majical Cloudz's Impersonator
column12: two of last year's most unique and compelling singer-songwriter records. But those artists are bringing the drama to an audience who might not otherwise expect it
column13: and that feels more daring than Angel Guts
column14: which comes off like a closed circuit
column15:
another satisfying way to meet Stewart on his own terms. He’s even better when he tries to meet us halfway.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20133/homepage_large.b4cb47e5.jpg|Worth EP|31699.0|Mas Ysa|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Downtown']|2014-02-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:18.261890|"

Last April
column2: Deerhunter played a surprise show at the Carrack Modern Art in Durham
column3: North Carolina. The ferocious decibels flooded the narrow upstairs gallery
column4: and its wooden floorboards quaked as the audience
column5: excited to be so close to an indie-famous band
column6: bounced in response. But while most of what I can recall of Deerhunter's set is a bone-rattling roar
column7: an unknown opening act left a much sharper impression. Mas Ysa—pronounced something like ""mass EE-sah
column8: his manager told me that night—is the moniker of Thomas Arsenault
column9: born in Montreal but now based in New York. He was playing one of his very first shows outside Brooklyn
column10: and he had yet to release a stitch of music
column11: not even a stray demo online.

column1: At the Carrack
column2: Arsenault stood inside an archipelago of hardware
column3: microphone in hand
column4: and with minimal overt showmanship
column5: he used them to confidently command a roughly half-hour set. Dark-haired
column6: dressed simply in a white t-shirt and cuffed jeans
column7: he had a mutedly striking presence—a hint of the emo heartthrob
column8: a hint of Fugazi-like reserve. His sturdy stature conveyed coiled power
column9: anchoring the nervous urgency of his music
column10: which moved seamlessly between 80s synth-pop and contemporary techno or indie electronic styles. He wove together volatile vocal-led anthems with refreshing ambient and post-classical interludes. The music had something of Xiu Xiu's attenuated warble
column11: M83's world-beating drive
column12: Perfume Genius' insomniac emotion. But mostly
column13: it introduced a new artist of uncommon definition and focus
column14: an impression strengthened by how closely this impressive debut EP replicates the feel and flow of the live set.

column1: First came the single ""Why"" last fall
column2: which shows off one side of Arsenault with its anxiously propulsive drum programming
column3: cramped synth lines
column4: and hooky vocal tantrums. It was followed by ""Years"" last month
column5: which shows off the opposite side. Arsenault's wounded voice fills a cavernous space sketched out with loose
column6: slow bass and a distant mirage of bowed strings
column7: which lift into a gentle threnody at the end
column8: like the unrelenting turn of a nightmare. It's the same kind of eloquent instrumental gesture that Arsenault uses between longer songs to inflate the EP to generous proportions
column9: and for once
column10: interstitial doesn't mean skippable. These little dreams for gamelan-like tuned metal or pitch-shifting piano feel individual rather than desultory; my only complaint about something like ""Vanya""
column11: a darkly lustrous braid of low wind instruments and bright drones that rivals Colin Stetson
column12: is that it stops after only a minute.

column1: The gulf in tone between ""Why"" and ""Years""
column2: which lie near the beginning and at the end of the record
column3: is filled in not onlywith these fine shades
column4: but also with a couple songs that reach the emphatic heights of the singles. ""Shame"" is a convulsive avalanche with outpouring vocals in the vein of ""Why""
column5: though it differentiates itself with an intensely angular rather than linear thrum. ""Life Way Up From"" mirrors the atmospheric ""Years"" but is even more vivid
column6: especially when weird
column7: whorled synth colors start shining through the glassy blocks of the melody as the song proceeds. The diversity is smoothed over by the specter of Arsenault's attention
column8: which presides with a quiet gravity
column9: a resistance to error and chance. He precisely executes his musical ideas and leaves the bloodletting to his lyrics
column10: faintly petulant spasms of romantic denunciation and guilt. Mas Ysa was definitely the biggest suprise about Deerhunter's surprise show
column11:
and the strong follow-through of Worth should land his prospective first LP high on most-anticipated shortlists.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20129/homepage_large.cbffdb96.jpg|Deleted/Fool EP|31877.0|Jerome LOL|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Friends of Friends']|2014-02-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:18.934651|"

Jerome LOL
column2: née Jerome Potter
column3: first was recognized playing with sound and image on Tumblr as a curator
column4: remixer
column5: and collagist. These three terms are all in the same family of art-making
column6: relying as they do on primary source artistic material—sometimes to make something new
column7: sometimes to reveal hidden characteristics in an original work. But there’s an important distinction to be made between curating
column8: remixing
column9: and creating collages
column10: and it is in moving along the spectrum that Potter has found his voice
column11: as exemplified beautifully on the new EP Deleted/Fool.

column1: Jerome LOL has been identified as a representative of the Seapunk movement
column2: a well-documented combination of 90s fashion
column3: internet 1.0 imagery
column4: early aughts R&B
column5: and house music. Two years ago
column6: Seapunk (a style with which Potter has repeatedly said he never personally associated) was visible enough to gain recognition from The New York Times and The Guardian
column7: if only so they could greet the movement with a kind of “look what the internet has belched up” bemusement. One of the early things that set Potter apart was his refusal to give in to the knee-jerk outrage that so often accompanies the mainstream’s swift co-opting of any happening subculture. Instead
column8: he spoke intelligently about the creative intention behind his art
column9: using an incident in which Rihanna was said to have stolen his aesthetic as a platform to introduce his music to a wider audience.

column1: During his rise in 2011 and 2012
column2: Potter released music as a member of the LOL Boys
column3: alongside Markus Garcia
column4: a collaborator whom he met on an online message board. But the two broke up in September 2012 to work on their solo careers
column5: and the split has benefited Potter
column6: allowing him to zero in on the sounds he’s interested in playing with. Deleted/Fool is a collection of R&B tracks
column7: punctuated with swirling dancehall rhythms and the dulcet California synths that Classixx used to such great effect on last year’s Hanging Gardens. The songs feature vocals from the Chicago singer Angelina Lucero
column8: a former LOL boys favorite
column9: as well as the vocalist and DJ Sara Zagarino. Zagarino
column10: who appears here as Sara Z
column11: is particularly noticeable on the EP’s first and catchiest track
column12: “Deleted”
column13: her voice coolly inhabiting the spaces between mellow synths and an undeniable shuffling handclap
column14: the kind that has powered other semi-anonymous singers (Lumidee
column15: anyone?) to prominence.

column1: The LOL boys’ allegiance was always to something like house music
column2: though they were happy to explore
column3: thinking of the genre as a foundation instead of a religion. Even the latter two tracks on <i>Deleted/Fool
column4: which more closely resemble house than their fellows
column5: have a diversity of rhythm and sound that place them in the pop sphere. “Fool” plays with the beat constantly
column6: pulling it out to replace it with rainbow-brite synths and adding coiling rhythms to the steady pounding bass. It’s important to note that none of these choices seem arbitrary: on the EP’s final track
column7: “True”
column8: Lucero’s voice comes in singing about “little voices” with a reticence that emphasizes the words
column9: and the track continues to grow and shrink in direct relation to its lyrics.

column1: Potter is a denizen of the internet
column2: so much so that in describing the first LOL boys tour he could say “we brought it into the irl-sphere” without sounding like he was making a joke. One of the small
column3: fun touches on these tracks is the way that he reconciles life on a laptop with real emotion: the bridge on “Deleted” is formed of a series of commands (control
column4: escape
column5: command
column6: delete) that evoke a person desperately trying to escape from something

column11: orchestras
column12: and harsh-noise masters enrich their typical amplifier worship. And during the last two decades

column3: at its best

column5: drum-machine percolators

column7: Red Wedge politics—never very pronounced in his songs—in among an atmosphere of spilled pints. The reissue of High Land comes with copious bonus tracks

column9: which sounds raw and robust compared to the album version’s clean
column10: sharp shimmer. Of the three single B-sides included
column11: “Queen’s Tattoo” is the most intriguing
column12: a twangy
column13: galloping romp that predates Morrissey’s first flirtation with rockabilly
column14: the Smiths’ “Rusholme Ruffians”
column15: by three years. On the other end of the spectrum are the 12” dance mixes of “Walk Out to Winter” and “Oblivious”. As curiosities go
column16: they demonstrate just how pliable Aztec Camera’s riffs and rhythms were; as new-wave floor-fillers
column17: they don’t hold a candle to any given album track by
column18: say
column19: Spandau Ballet. The handful of live radio sessions
column20: on the other hand
column21: capture a barely-legal Frame at his immaculate
column22: brassy best.

column1: Following the success of High Land
column2: Frame had to grow up quickly. He did so
column3: but always in a good way. For the rest of the 80s
column4: Aztec Camera became a more calculated concern
column5: with a rotating cast of session musicians that would include everyone from members of Dire Straits to—perhaps inevitably—a future (if fleeting) guitarist of the Smiths
column6: Craig Gannon. By 1986
column7: the Postcard-inspired C86 movement was splitting the difference between Aztec Camera and the buzzsaw punks that preceded them. Frame responded by removing his own guitar almost entirely from the equation with Aztec Camera’s biggest hit
column8: 1988’s “Somewhere in My Heart.” Despite a back-to-basics rally in the 90s
column9: Aztec Camera folded in 1995; Frame
column10: now fifty
column11: still enjoys a respectable solo career. High Land is not only his first statement of intent as a songwriter
column12: it’s his most innovative
column13: his most influential
column14: and his most timelessly vivid. Peaking early can be bittersweet
column15:
but the album is all the better for it.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20178/homepage_large.bbf28c96.jpg|The Life Stains|31798.0|DJ Dog Dick|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['HOSS']|2014-02-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:48:23.289190|"

Society plays a cruel joke on us when it comes to silly stuff. As a kid
column2: your natural love of the goofy is indulged and even encouraged. But once you “mature
column3: you’re supposed to take art seriously only if it’s serious
column4: or if it’s humorous in a clever or sophisticated way. Otherwise
column5: it should be dismissed as novelty. Even an ostensibly silly artist like “Weird Al” Yankovic needs the weight of parody to earn respect; it’s hard to imagine him winning Grammies if his music were just about food.

column1: The problem with this paradigm is it oversimplifies art
column2: and ignores how silliness can be serious and intelligent work can be goofy. Max Eisenberg understands this. “I’ve never been afraid to play the part of the fool
column3: ” he said in a 2012 interview. “You need to show the awkward
column4: stupid parts of existence as much as you need to show the brilliant
column5: austere parts.” Perhaps that philosophy is what led him to a moniker as silly as DJ Dog Dick
column6: and surely it’s what’s made him both serious craftsman and fearless goofball.

column1: The Life Stains
column2: the first DJ Dog Dick album
column3: is a full-on expression of Eisenberg’s artistic attitude. It opens with its two silliest tracks: “Our Kin”
column4: a Dr. Demento-ready song featuring farting tuba and “cartoon voices
column5: ” and “Hello Cruel World”
column6: an over-the-top skit recreating a delirious baby delivery. But as the album progresses
column7: sneaky craft bleeds in
column8: and humor and gravity meld into something not so easily pegged. Part of that is due to Eisenberg’s stylistic diversity. He began DJ Dog Dick as an avant-rap project
column9: and you can hear hip-hop in almost every track. But there’s also clear influences from R&B
column10: art-pop
column11: tearful balladry
column12: new wave
column13: electronica
column14: and noise.

column1: The latter is an integral part of Eisenberg’s musical DNA. His first solo tour was with notorious French performance arist Jean-Louis Costes
column2: and in the mid-00s he was a member of the singular Baltimore noise outfit Nautical Almanac. Those experiences gave him not only an appreciation of sonic absurdity - the idea that anything can be music - but an ear for textures and layers. This gives a density to tunes like the clanging “Pedigris” and the robo-rapped “Monkey.” It also elevates the minimalism of “Fourth of July”
column3: technoid throb of “Sharing Scars
column4: ” and freak-psych of “Why’s a Dog?” into the territory of surreal masters such as Liars and Butthole Surfers.

column1: What’s most surprising about The Life Stains is how Eisenberg morphs his avant-leaning skills into a weirdo-pop sensilbilty. Quite a few tunes here bear the uncommon combo of well-honed hook and curveball angles that marks the farther-out work of Todd Rundgren
column2: or the farther-in side of R. Stevie Moore.  That’s clearest on the album’s shiniest gem
column3: the virally catchy “Grease That I Got”. Over pushing bass and escalating treble
column4: Eisenberg paints love as a viscous liquid ready to boil. “The grease that I got likes to hiss and pop a lot
column5: ” he warbles. “What I chopped is in the stock pot
column6: burner don’t stop.”

column1: That’s some clever verbiage
column2: but it’s delivered without a smirk. In fact
column3: irony is refreshingly absent on The Life Stains. Eisenberg always comes off earnest even when he clearly wants you to laugh. At the same time
column4: his wackiness constantly threatens to go insane. For me that unhinged edge is a huge part of the DJ Dog Dick charm; for those less inclined toward musical dementia
column5: it could take getting used to. But open your mind to the possibility that silly music can be deep
column6:
and you might find The Life Stains worming its way into a new brain-hole.

"|18974.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18974-dj-dog-dick-the-life-stains/|6.9|Marc Masters

Back in the mid-2000s
column2: when every rhythmically inclined indie rock act was outfitting their stage set with an auxiliary floor tom for intermittent bashing
column3: Brooklyn’s Aa (a.k.a. Big A
column4: little a) differentiated themselves by loading up on so much percussive firepower
column5: the band could host their own Boadrum reenactment. All that extra thump was in service of John Atkinson’s stated goal of fronting “the ultimate loft party band
column6: ” however
column7: Aa’s fractious treatment of groove is not exactly the stuff of which all-night dance-athons are made. If anything
column8: their 2007 debut
column9: gAame
column10: was more like the sound of a loft party getting busted—doors knocked down with battering rams
column11: bells ringing
column12: tripped-up beats
column13: and panicked confusion. And coming from a band whose M.O. seems fairly simple and primal on the surface—bash the shit out of drum
column14: scream a lot—gAame was a strategically structured affair
column15: one that was as interested in ominous builds and intensifying atmospheres as chaotic
column16: ecstatic release.

column1: So given their meticulous ethic
column2: it’s not a complete surprise that it’s taken Aa seven years to release a proper follow-up (though day jobs and domesticity inevitably got in the way
column3: too). But where the band once rolled out the extra drum kits to set themselves apart from the post-millennial post-punk pack
column4: this time out
column5: Aa are able to stand out just by showing up—in the intervening years
column6: their many peers have variously broken up
column7: gone soft
column8: turned more electronic
column9: or more eccentric
column10: or become a top-draw festival acts
column11: all while the lingering
column12: sedating fog of chillwave still permeates wide swaths of the underground. Though not the magnum opus its protracted gestation period might suggest (it clocks in at just over a half hour)
column13: VoyAager bears evidence of a painstaking refinement. The album’s roots date back to 2009’s interim Glossy EP
column14: whose two lengthy tracks have been pared down for inclusion here
column15: a distillation that exemplifies VoyAager’s more considered approach: the crater-stomping clatter is harnessed into more controlled outbursts
column16: the jagged edges buffed by more omnipresent synths
column17: the post-hardcore vocalizations tempered into more upbeat exhortations.

column1: On a purely sonic level
column2: VoyAager is spectacular
column3: its expertly sculpted 3-D sound world situated somewhere between the grandiose digi-symphonies of Fuck Buttons (ascendant opener “Promsac” could’ve been spooled off the second side of Slow Focus) and the industrialized
column4: technicolor throttle of early Nine Inch Nails (see: the predatory Reznorian prowl of “Mossy
column5: ” a truncated Glossy reprise). But as with gAame
column6: there’s still some uncertainty about how exactly vocals fit into the mix
column7: and whether they can drive a song or just serve as another dissonant detail amid the melee. While the band evinces a newfound fondness for unison
column8: wordless harmonies
column9: the individual melody lines are deliberately obscured by droning AutoTune effects or synth-smeared deliveries (or
column10: in the case of ""Gowntowner
column11: at least one unflattering Flavor Flav-esque ""boyyeeeee!"")

column1: VoyAager’s crisper presentation suggests Aa are drawn to the luminous surfaces of pop music
column2: but non-commital when it comes to writing proper pop songs; many of the tracks here feel like preludes or connective interludes setting us up for big moments that don’t always materialize. While the tremorous finale of “Fish Phone” offers an impressive showcase of Aa’s thundering force
column3: the greatest sustained thrill is provided by “Glow Wreath”
column4: which first appeared on Glossy in extended nine-minute form
column5: but is put to far more effective use here as a concentrated five-minute eruption that feels like the peak moment everything is working toward or reeling from. Its tropical
column6: tribal thrust may not help Aa shake the Animal Collective comparisons they attracted early on
column7: but this joyous jam could easily hold its own among the superior tracks on the similarly manic Centipede Hz. And for once
column8: Aa’s shouting-in-tongues hysterics require no decoding: “Celebrate! Celebrate! Celebrate!
column9: ” Atkinson exclaims in the throes of the highest of highs
column10:
and he can be forgiven if it takes him till 2021 to come down.

There are 11 songs on Sun Kil Moon’s astonishing sixth LP Benji
column2: and in nearly all of them
column3: somebody dies. And that’s not including the ones where someone’s on the verge of death or seriously headed towards it. Toddlers die
column4: teenagers die
column5: adults die
column6: and the elderly die. They die of natural causes and in freak accidents. People die alone and people die by the dozens—handicapped children
column7: single parents
column8: grandmothers
column9: serial killers. They die out of mercy and die long before they’re due. Rednecks die as respected men and white collar kids die in disgrace. But more importantly
column10: Mark Kozelek wants us to know that they all lived
column11: loved
column12: fought
column13: fucked up
column14: and often did the best they could
column15: before he sets out to “find some poetry to make some sense of this and give some deeper meaning” to their tragedies. Turns out he doesn’t have to dig very far. Here
column16: Kozelek does away with the metaphor and verbal obfuscation often used to distract an audience from their own joy
column17: sadness
column18: crippling failures
column19: and small triumphs. If listeners find themselves unable to make it through Benji in one piece
column20: it’s because Kozelek all but forces us to recognize how the most emotionally moving art can be mapped directly on to our own lives.

column1: This is a culmination of the jarring shift in Kozelek's work that started with 2012’s Among the Leaves
column2: an erratic
column3: occasionally embarrassing
column4: and fascinating tell-all about a life in music. Whereas early songwriting in Red House Painters and Sun Kil Moon resulted in elegant
column5: poetic lyrics that demanded a <a href=""http://www.caldoverderecords.com/books.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">hardbound
column6: 256-page compilation
column7: all of a sudden he was giving us songs about justifying a case of VD to his girlfriend
column8: picking up water from 7-Eleven
column9: and battling his own boredom with songwriting
column10: all wrapped in songs with titles like “The Moderately Talented Yet Attractive Young Woman vs. the Exceptionally Talented Yet Not So Attractive Middle Aged Man"". It wasn’t a midlife crisis
column11: exactly; it was more like watching your parents negotiate Facebook for the first time
column12: equally excited and overwhelmed that they can share their daily minutiae but unaware of what to keep to themselves.

column1: Benji steps away from the focus on process in favor of songs that elevate exceedingly personal stories into universal displays of humanity. Presenting himself as no wiser
column2: empathetic
column3: or understanding than any of its subjects or his audience
column4: Kozelek has crafted an album that anyone can feel but also one that
column5: paradoxically
column6: is filled with songs that wouldn't make sense if covered by anybody else. The opening “Carissa” is a portal towards the world Kozelek inhabits throughout Benji
column7: all of it painfully real and subject to nature’s laws even as time seems frozen within it. The first line of Benji lays out the record's confrontational realism: “Carissa
column8: when I first saw you
column9: you were a lovely child/ And the last time I saw you
column10: you were 15 and pregnant and running wild.” We learn a few things about her: she’s Mark Kozelek’s second cousin
column11: and in the 20 years since Kozelek’s seen her
column12: she’s had two kids
column13: settled into a nursing job in a nondescript Ohio town and
column14: in general
column15: gotten her shit together—a rarity in a Mark Kozelek song. And we also know that she dies in a fire after an aerosol can explodes in the trash.

column1: That alone doesn’t make “Carissa” stand out
column2: not in the catalog of one of our most prolific miserablists. But unlike Caroline or Elaine or Katy
column3: Carissa has an effect on Kozelek that feels biological
column4: that she’s a part of Kozelek’s flesh and blood and not just a muse
column5: and he renders her story with detail that would be stunning for a novelist
column6: let alone a songwriter. The chorus is sweetly sung and absolutely crushing: “Carissa was 35/ You don’t just raise two kids and take out your trash and die.” He’s right
column7: that shouldn’t happen. Except the same exact thing happened to his uncle
column8: which is detailed two songs later on “Truck Driver”.

column1: Which leads to an important critical consideration: Do these songs resonate because we understand them to be true stories? We have little reason to doubt Kozelek’s authenticity
column2: as Benji is full of proper nouns and historical facts that check out: Google some of the specificities mentioned during his eviscerating sexual inventory of “Dogs” and you find that there is indeed a Tangier and Red Lobster near the Erie Canal in Akron. When he calls his mom in ""Micheline"" and learns of his friend Brett’s death in 1999
column3: he mentions booking a movie role—as the bassist from Stillwater in Almost Famous. At one point
column4: he sings that “the Sopranos guy died at 51/ That’s the same age as the guy who’s coming to play drums
column5: ” and wouldn’t you know
column6: former Sonic Youth stickman Steve Shelley
column7: who played on the record
column8: turns 52 in June. Kozelek’s reaction to both aerosol can-related deaths in his family are basically
column9: “you can’t make this shit up.” But what if he did make this shit up? If so
column10: Benji arguably becomes an even more impressive record—the debilitating emotional response created by “Carissa” and “Truck Driver” are undeniably real
column11: and if the stories are fiction
column12: the guy did his homework.

column1: Regardless of the real names and real events used throughout
column2: nothing feels exploitative
column3: unnecessary
column4: or cruel the way some of the songs on Among the Leaves could. Nor is Benji subject to the navel-gazing self-importance that usually accompanies an aging musician making their “mortality” album. Despite most of it taking place in rural Ohio
column5: people like Carissa and his uncle (“redneck that he was”) are never used as a stand-in for some salt-of-the-earth Middle American archetype or a cheap way to make some dippy point about us all being interconnected and carpe diem.

column1: Instead
column2: Benji trusts in the complexity and power ingrained in anyone’s life story rather than using them for some grand statement that glorifies Kozelek’s own perspective. Most importantly
column3: his storytelling has sharpened considerably. Befitting someone who watches an absurd amount of boxing
column4: Kozelek’s prose has taken on pugilistic bent
column5: where he can go five minutes or more dancing around
column6: softening the listener with sharp jabs before landing a catastrophic body blow. This is best exhibited on the song “Micheline”
column7: which has three acts linked by nothing but their end result
column8: and the one where his grandmother dies is the least tragic.

column1: This is obviously brutal stuff
column2: its pacing
column3: themes
column4: and structure having more in common with cinema or literature than pop music. But Benji is still a piece of entertainment and it's a pleasure to listen to on that level. For one thing
column5: it's the most musically diverse and sonically direct album he’s made since disbanding Red House Painters. He’ll never return to the turbulent sound of the 1990s
column6: though you get raw
column7: gutbucket blues (“Dogs”
column8: “Richard Ramirez Died Today of Natural Causes”)
column9: swanky
column10: horn-laced yacht-pop (“Ben’s My Friend”)

column12: to name a few. And with its chipper harmonies and a fake Nels Cline solo (not Kozelek’s first joke at his expense)
column13: “I Love My Dad” feels like a ribbing at latter-day Wilco

column2: too: The effervescent narrative “Ben’s My Friend” snaps us back into the present day after the happy ending of “Micheline” and follows Kozelek as he suffers through writer’s block
column3: a distracted lunch in a restaurant filled with “sports bar shit
column4: ” and a Postal Service concert where all the drunk kids with their cells appear to be “20 years younger.” He claims he’s too tired for the “backstage hi/bye” with pal Ben Gibbard and he heads back to his hot tub in Tahoe
column5: before revealing the real cause for his meltdown: “I’m content

column7: but it's otherwise quotably hilarious

the only response is to go out and live.

Seen one way
column2: Snowbird’s debut album moon is the return to music for Simon Raymonde
column3: former Cocteau Twins member and founder/head of the Bella Union label
column4: not far now from its 20th anniversary. Raymonde’s last full work was his Blame Someone Else record back in 1997
column5: a pleasant if not deathless effort featuring his own soft
column6: sighed singing. But given his participation not only with the Cocteaus for most of their existence but also This Mortal Coil
column7: it wouldn’t’ve been surprising if he had something more to offer down the road.

column1: Yet Stephanie Dosen
column2: Raymonde’s project partner and the sole vocalist throughout
column3: is the real key to moon’s gentle appeal. With the kind of quietly active resume that reaches back across 20 years and a slew of guest performances and solo releases both
column4: the Wisconsin native ends up being the general focus throughout moon
column5: with Raymonde contributing piano parts that form the overall basis of the songs. There are some further guest appearances to note: Radiohead freaks doubtless are already tracking the presence of Ed O’Brien and Phil Selway; Midlake
column6: who Dosen has recorded with
column7: and Lanterns on the Lake members also take a bow. Yet it’s pretty much the Dosen and Raymonde Show in terms of the overall feeling.

column1: There is definitely an echo of Raymonde’s concluding days with the Cocteaus
column2: for all the time that has passed since—it’s far too much to call moon an actual extension of that act’s lovely final bow Milk & Kisses
column3: but there’s a clear sense of lush gentility at work
column4: with rock arrangements that aim at understatement and mood. Dosen’s singing on first blush extends the connection; anyone who ever loved Elizabeth Fraser’s ear for layered sweetness in those last years of the band

column1: That said the music on that track has a sturdy chug that’s more psych rock mystery than anything else

column4: Dosen herself never sings cryptic or apparently glossolalic lyrics; if her singing softly blends into the arrangements at points
column5: it’s still always understandable enough. If anything
column6: as the album progresses Dosen’s vocal approach
column7: more calmly serene than suddenly melancholy or sharp
column8: suggests another performer entirely
column9: the redoubtable Linda Perhacs. The breathtaking blend of high harmonies that sets the tone from the start of her Parallelograms album with “Chimacum Rain” gets an echo at many points throughout moon

Dancing is not an activity one typically associates with the North Carolina orchestral indie-folk band Lost in the Trees
column2: a group that has traditionally been too focused on going for the emotional jugular to worry much about moving listeners' feet. But dancing
column3: in a light spring rain
column4: is exactly what I found myself doing when they rolled out some new songs at famed Carrboro venue Cat's Cradle's block party last May. Their stolid rock drums were newly tinged with a disco tick-tock; an electronic sequencer pulsed out fleet arpeggios beneath the live musicianship. These surprising changes are reflected on fourth LP Past Life
column5: which should still have enough sentimental grist to satisfy old fans while broadening the band's appeal to people who prefer a little more dynamism in their dolor.

column1: Part of the reason for the change is a reduction in personnel from a sextet to a quartet
column2: and the band also worked with an outside producer
column3: Nicolas Vernhes (Deerhunter
column4: Dirty Projectors)
column5: for the first time. In becoming leaner and less hermetic
column6: Lost in the Trees seems to have freed itself from its habitual pomp. There are still the ringing guitars of indie rock
column7: the vaporous harmonies of choral music
column8: and the vigorous string and piano arrangements of classical. And as always
column9: bandleader Ari Picker's lofty tenor is a pleasure to hear
column10: especially as it rises over the prickling guitar of album highlight ""Daunting Friend"". But while it was always a stretch to call a six-piece ""orchestral
column11: this chamber-music-sized lineup definitely sheds the excess the term might imply
column12: and while Picker is a canny writer for strings and piano
column13: he seems more focused on giving the songs stiff spines than frilly embroideries. The resulting music is refreshingly streamlined and direct.

column1: The atmospheric ""Excos"" opens the album on a familiar note
column2: with shimmering
column3: panning cymbals and a slow curl of piano opening out from the slightly distorted choral lines of Emma Nadeau. But the band's new look quickly presents itself on the title track
column4: an anthem taut with lyrical electric guitar work and a juddering electronic undercarriage. The thick
column5: pumping bass of songs such as ""Lady in White"" and ""Wake"" introduces a facet that has seldom been heard in Lost in the Trees' chaste music—sex—while standout deep cut ""Sun"" shows that they can also bring their new energy to the kind of feather-light songs on which they made their name. The lyrics still strike at grand notes: Angels zip around
column6: light comes out of hearts
column7: and birds
column8: somehow
column9: come out of eyes. But death
column10: still lurking after the difficult memorial album A Church That Fits Our Needs
column11: adds a newly earned gravity and wisdom to the proceedings without being the focus.

column1: Picker remains good at creating a sense of towering scale and charged atmosphere
column2: and the heavenly light that suffuses his music takes on a more humble and terrestrial hue
column3: for the better. Picker sounds revivified
column4: as if he's having more fun
column5: and the feeling is mutual. After they've spent so long swirling high up in the rarified air
column6: it's exciting to hear Lost in the Trees planting their music so firmly in the body
column7: their feet on the ground
column8:
tapping.

Piano Nights
column2: the eighth album by the German band Bohren & der Club of Gore
column3: is functionally the same as their seventh
column4: sixth
column5: fifth
column6: fourth
column7: third
column8: second
column9: and first. The mood is solemn
column10: the tempos are slow
column11: and each note carries within it the suggestion that it might be the band’s last.

column1: In some cases
column2: repetition is a sign of laziness or lack of imagination; in others—like Bohren’s or the Ramones’—it’s a show of commitment to an idea so elegant in its original design that changing it would constitute betrayal. “We always offer our music in the same way and with the same enthusiasm
column3: ” the band’s saxophonist and keyboard player
column4: Christoph Clöser
column5: recently told an interviewer—which is to say with no discernible enthusiasm at all. “If the audience is strong enough to suffer uneventful music
column6: we and the listeners can celebrate as a kind of mass.”

column1: One reason Bohren persists in being so interesting despite their uneventfulness is that their music contains a kind of secret history. Lounge jazz
column2: dark ambience
column3: the languorous adagios of classical-music requiem
column4: and the saturated romance of Italian film soundtracks: All of it is folded into Piano Nights. Heard at a distance
column5: the album can sound uniform and insubstantial; up close
column6: it not only covers a lot of ground
column7: but ground you might not expect to overlap.

column1: For as gentle as their sound is
column2: the band has always played with intensity and conviction. At their slowest tempos a Bohren song feels like a series of notes both disconnected from the ones before it and yet articulated with total clarity
column3: like bright stars forming a constellation in an otherwise dark sky. When I saw the band live in 2008
column4: the tension in the room wasn’t a function of volume or speed
column5: but the contrast between the certainty of the notes they played and the silences that followed. Watching them—four hunched German men in charcoal and black—was like watching horror-movie zombies lumber toward their next kill: Each blow was just a matter of time.

column1: If there’s been an evolution in the band’s approach
column2: it’s mostly sonic. Their earliest recordings were chilly and even brittle; Piano Nights is luxurious in its warmth. Nearly every track is backlit by vaporous ambience; the cymbals seem to ring in slow motion.

column1: The sharpest voice in the mix is usually the saxophone
column2: which Clöser plays with the persistent
column3: exhausted tone of someone trying to explain something they’ve tried to explain a thousand times before—too tired to fight but not tired enough to give up.

column1: Yes
column2: this music gets dull—it’s supposed to. I can’t imagine listening to it all the time for the same reasons I can’t imagine trying to cook an entire meal using only a garlic press. But in their limited pursuits Bohren captures a mood other music either struggles to or just doesn’t bother with: Not sadness (too acute)
column3: not angst
column4: but a sumptuous
column5: all-purpose melancholy
column6: the kind of thing you might experience watching a frozen field from the window of a slow-moving train.

column1: Clöser had used the word “mass.” The highlights on Piano Nights—“Fahr zur Hölle
column2: ” “Verloren (Alles)
column3: ” “Segeln ohne Wind”—feel like church music. The sly
column4: suggestive blue notes of jazz give way to processions of organ and horn. What was once threatening and concealed feels stewarded toward the light. “Triumph” is too corny a word for a band like Bohren & der Club of Gore. But for the first time
column5:
it might fit.
