If all the think pieces in the world couldn’t settle on how exactly the world has changed
column2: let us at least agree that it has changed
column3: in complex ways that become more difficult to parse with every day. In 2012
column4: Daniel T. Rodgers penned a book in which he posited that Western society underwent an epochal crisis of confidence following World War II. “Strong metaphors of society were supplanted by weaker ones
column5: ” he wrote. “Imagined collectivities shrank; notions of structure and power thinned out. Viewed by its acts of mind
column6: the last quarter of the century was an era of disaggregation
column7: a great age of fracture.”

column1: This seems relevant when discussing the ambitions of CYMBALS
column2: a London band who’ve titled their latest and greatest album after Rodgers’ book. When the band first debuted they were on the scrappy side of post-punk
column3: releasing their energy in brief
column4: nervous bursts. On The Age of Fracture
column5: they’ve settled down and drawn out a solemn groove
column6: furthering a sound indebted to bands like New Order and Depeche Mode
column7: acts who sensed that sometimes the best way to solve an existential crisis was to leave it all on the dancefloor. The album opens on a dreamlike note
column8: synths slowly floating in as drum machines layer into a smoky
column9: sublimated release; it sets the tone for “The Natural World""
column10: where singer Jack Cleverly nearly goes hoarse yelping about the trials and tribulations of getting to know someone as the groove snaps like a rubber band. “I don’t know enough about you
column11: ” he sings
column12: “to be kind to you."" It’s an admittal of narcissism given an honest feel through the song’s orgastic form
column13: in which synths interlock and flow into a crystalline river. Because who could lie when they’re moving that freely?

column1: The band is largely concerned with degrees of distance and the ways in which the age of fracture describes not just the geopolitical world
column2: but the interpersonal one. If that sounds like a big pill
column3: well: These songs are much longer than anything they’ve ever done
column4: and it sometimes it feels like a minute or three could’ve been lopped off here and there. “Like An Animal” slows the groove to a crawl as Cleverly intones self-involved lyrics like “Nobody’s looking/ No one cares” in a way that’s reminiscent of Peter Gabriel at his most tortuously ponderous. They’re much better when keeping it simple
column5: like when they ride the stripped down riff on “Erosion” toward crescendoing exultation. There’s propulsion
column6: but a softer type. Take a song like “This City”
column7: which hums along somnambulant rhythms as it considers how to make a weary life feel less trivial
column8: or the interstitial self-titled track.

column1: That’s the realm where CYMBALS work best
column2: when they use understated sonic brushstrokes—a flutter of synths here and there—to deepen the mood. The penultimate song
column3: “The End""
column4: feels characteristic of its title
column5: which refers to the conclusion of a long night spent with someone you barely know. Then
column6: just as the lights turn on to send everybody home
column7: there’s the hopeful denouement: “Call Me""
column8: out of which a burbling bass line anticipates a necessary amount of sleep before the next night out. The range of states is what makes the record convincing: CYMBALS do enough to get you moving
column9: and through that
column10:
thinking about where we are in relation to each other.

Art says what words can't

column5: you feel it

column7: Sincerely Yours

column1: And yet what web presence Berglund does have is meticulously curated
column2: and straight-faced grandiosity is a hallmark of public statements from Gothenburg's ""ultra messiah aka mr yeah aka life aka you."" His debut album under solo alias ceo

column6: post-Internet miniatures often touched on themes of illumination and transcendence. Lead single ""Come With Me""—lush and brash enough for an alternate Top 40

column1: Three-and-a-half years later

column3: all caps now) comes after label signees Air France called it quits and another hometown kindred spirit
column4: Jens Lekman

column6: too

column1: That immersion starts with Berglund's always-impeccable pop songcraft. His feel for melodic turns and lyrical conceits is characteristically keen; when you find yourself humming along to the galloping art-versus-commerce ambivalence of ""Whorehouse""
column2: he's got you on his level. Darker thoughts lurk beneath the gleaming surfaces

column4: for example. So when the day-glo title track returns to an already-plagiarized lyric from the first album
column5: ""Love and do what you will
column6: the effect is something like
column7: if you'll forgive the terrible pun
column8: going through the looking glass.

column2: here at its more atmospheric. The 1980s Mediterranean chillouts of Balearic house still come up a lot as a reference point
column3: and it's a style eclectic enough to make room for almost anything. But beyond that

In the album's wide-eyed viewpoint and bustling intricacy you can also hear an affinity with Japanese pop star Kyary Pamyu Pamyu's psychedelic kawaii-ness. If there's a weakness

column1: Still
column2: with an artist as slyly considered as Berglund
column3: it's tempting to take these space-outs as part of the point. ""OMG""
column4: the album's celestial finale
column5: is also its encapsulation and its peak
column6: juxtaposing reverence with irreverence
column7: a wonderfully goofy boy-meets-girl story with serious-sounding introspection
column8: harp and a choir and a preacher with a pitched-down ""ho"" backing vocal. The full version of the text-speak title phrase is delivered by a female voice resembling an orgasmic version of the main sample in Skrillex's ""Scary Monsters and Nice Sprites"". When Berglund implores
column9: ""Let go forever

column1: What can't be put into words is the alchemical trick that some great artists use to turn their personal idiosyncrasies into popular myths

column7: ""It's better to be lost than to be found."" Not necessarily

column9: ""Who knows
column10:
dude.""

Maximo Park were originally noted for being another winning entry in the mid-00’s-British-guitar-bands-best-described-as-”angular” genre
column3: snapping to-and-fro with wiry songs filled with assertive
column4: wry wordplay. A few albums later

column6: their newest

column1: As a literary exercise
column2: it’s convincing; as a listening one
column3: it’s mixed. The lyrics explore the subtextual minutiae within mostly doomed relationships: shadowy dalliances in foreign hotels
column4: drinks shared in lonely bars
column5: tennis matches held at night where something’s going on but no one is willing to say it. Relationships where sustained
column6: wordless glances are part of the package; you know the type. The music is built to match the tone of singer Paul Smith’s voice: the underwater quality to “Brain Cells”
column7: which is concerned with the pressure of having a fun night when you think you might be going mildly insane; the arena-ready “Midnight On The Hill”
column8: which has Smith wondering where the time goes when so much fun is being had. “I Recognise The Light” finds the band at their pugilistic apex
column9: while “Drinking Martinis” strikes the proper melancholy mood for a song about missing someone you used to drink with.

column2: if nothing else. On one hand
column3: Smith is a smooth enough singer that he can effortlessly drop a word like ""semaphore"" within the flow of a song. On the other
column4: he’s dropping a word like ""semaphore
column5: which begs a mild suspension of disbelief for those who believe rock lyrics should be heard and not seen. Some of these suffer from what you might call Morrissey Syndrome

column4: giving Smith’s fey enunciation a melodic tension that brings his heartache alive. Reviewing their last album
column5: Jordan Sargent wrote that Smith “is still much more concerned with the status of his heart and his bed."" Nothing much has changed here

The Bay Area’s high intensity
column2: sparsely produced ratchet music scene has reached its tipping point
column3: what with locals like Sage the Gemini scoring chart hits without any airplay elsewhere in the country
column4: savvy out-of-towners like Nicki Minaj and Jeezy genuflecting westward as early adopters Drake and Tyga did on “The Motto” and “Rack City”
column5: and artists like J. Lo and T-Pain linking up with ratchet impresario DJ Mustard in search of a renewed relevance. Los Angeles singer/producer Ty Dolla $ign heads up ratchet music’s R&B division; after paying dues producing for Compton stars YG and Problem and featuring on Cali rap records of every stripe Ty finally zeroed in on a sleek
column6: commercially viable sound on his flagship Beach House mixtape series with tracks like “My Cabana”
column7: which crossed a swatch of Skrillex with horns lifted off of the R&B band Mint Condition. Last year’s Beach House 2 took a bigger-is-better approach to the lushly produced
column8: impishly explicit sounds of the first installment
column9: soldering famous guests onto remixes and melding unrelated songs into overlong
column10: drippy epics. Sometimes it worked
column11: but all too often it sounded like it was fishing for hits.

column1: Suitably the mixtape’s least fussy song was its biggest hit. “Paranoid” parlayed a spectral Mustard production into a story about a serial cheater caught in the same club with both girlfriends. With “Paranoid” steadily inching up the charts
column2: Ty’s new label Atlantic is capitalizing on its Billboard Hot 100 traction with a retail EP. Beach House the EP succeeds where the mixtape Beach House 2 didn’t
column3: further commercializing Ty’s sound without sacrificing the meat and potatoes of it
column4: the foul-mouthed
column5: sex-positivity of Ty’s quixotic bedroom capers and the production’s precarious balance between slight
column6: house-informed ratchet music
column7: trap and densely arranged traditional R&B sounds. Ty’s reigned in some of the thornier aspects of his songwriting for Beach House. The needling insistence of nebulous agency jams “Know Y I Came” and “Zone’n” is scaled back
column8: and the cloying misogyny of “Bitches Ain’t Shit” is carved out
column9: too. In their place we get a Dolla $ign focusing on catchphrases and simplicity. “Or Nah” co-opts a bit of goofy Twitter vernacular as Ty and his Taylor Gang boss Wiz Khalifa fire off randy one-liners over the bed creaks from the Trillville classic “Some Cut”. On “Familiar” he effects a staccato drill flow over ominous production from Chief Keef go-to Young Chop and guest verses from Kanye protege Travi$ Scott and Keef underboss Fredo Santana.

column1: Beach House largely avoids the mixtapes’ penchant for winding two-part blowouts
column2: too
column3: barring opener “Work” and the double-shot of “Paranoid” that comprise the EP’s front end. “Work” is an excellent showcase for what Ty can do with a longer composition. It vaults from a spoken word intro from Nate Howard to verses from Ty
column4: a guest rap from Odd Future buddy Casey Veggies
column5: and beat and key changes as the viscous
column6: brass-assisted chipmunk soul of D’Mile and D.R.U.G.S.’ beat crystallizes into ambient trap underneath a blistering verse from Twista. The movements flow naturally
column7: and nothing feels as forced as the cute but tacky song transitions of Beach House 2. On the other hand
column8: chasing it with nine minutes of “Paranoid” is a misstep. The single version replaces the original’s stellar guest spot from Ty’s boy Joe Mo$e$ with a tryhard verse from a B.o.B still new to embracing his inner heel. It’s followed by a remix featuring DJ Mustard in full Fatman Scoop hypeman mode
column9: a comically punchdrunk French Montana
column10: and
column11: for whatever reason
column12: Trey Songz. The song’s economy is its greatest strength
column13: and despite the additional guests and tweaks to the beat on the remix
column14: robbing it of its impactful brevity by playing it twice through only serves to drag it down.

column1: The EP closes with another holdover from Beach House 2 in the underlooked nightcap “Never Be the Same”
column2: where Ty cuts the sex talk to beat his chest about his passage from anonymity to budding fame. It’s also his lone production cut in an EP largely aided by Mustard
column3: Cardo
column4: and Brooklyn producer D’Mile. It leads on a blocky video game synth

column6:
and it’s also proof that Dolla $ign is even bigger than the devilish lechery he’s built his name on.

“My personal definition of rock and roll is people attempting to do something that's beyond their ability to do it well
column2: ” said David First in 2010. He was talking about his band the Notekillers
column3: and the way their instrumental music both carves out lines and spills beyond them. I don’t know if First feels the same about composition or improvisation
column4: two forms that he’s spent as much time exploring as rock'n'roll. But much of his music bears that kind of fearless ambition—a drive to
column5: as he also said about the Notekillers
column6: “do stuff that pushes us to our physical and mental limits.”

column1: As a solo artist
column2: First pushes a wide range of forms: improvised jazz (he played with Cecil Taylor in the early 70s)
column3: sound art
column4: audio-visual experiments
column5: and even an opera. I’m most familiar with his explorations in minimalist composition
column6: collected on an enthralling retropsective of “droneworks” issued in 2010 by Experimental Intermedia
column7: the label run by drone master Phill Niblock. That alone is a lot to take in
column8: but it turns out that amidst all these pursuits
column9: he also applied his caution-averse ways to electronic music.

column1: In between playing with Taylor and forming the Notekillers
column2: First took a class in electronic music at Princeton
column3: where he got to play a Buchla 100 modular synthesizer. It’s a complex instrument
column4: controlled with touch-sensitive metal plates
column5: which makes it more like “finger-painting” (as First puts it) than keyboard playing. The instrument gave First a chance to create the kind of electroacoustic works that previously could only be made by painstakingly splicing magnetic tape. And even though it was only 1976
column6: according to First analog synths were already out of fashion in academia due to the promise of digital
column7: so he basically had the Buchla all to himself.

column1: Judging by the music he made
column2: released as Electronic Works 1976-1977
column3: First dove headlong into the Buchla’s possibilities. Each piece is dizzy with activity
column4: as he constantly shifts gears
column5: discovers new noises
column6: and giddily disrupts his own flow. Unpredictability becomes its own motif
column7: and surreal patterns emerge and vanish incessantly
column8: giving Electronic Works a playful sense of humor. Like electronic pioneer and cartoon-scorer Raymond Scott
column9: First knows how to inject both absurdity and drama into abstract electronics
column10: often in the same breath.

column1: In fact
column2: the best pieces on Electronic Works are the funniest ones. Two tracks that First dubs “Spacey” and “Jumpy”—like outcasts from Snow White’s Seven Dwarves—bounce happily around the stereo space as if chasing own tails. The album ends with another musical character
column3: “Moody”
column4: which is less cartoon figure than dark cloud
column5: fogging its blips and squiggles with wiry leads from First’s guitar. Yet even this track positively bubbles
column6: hopping between sounds like an electronic rabbit.

column1: That spastic
column2: boundless energy is the aspect of Electronic Works that leaves the strongest impression. I rarely remember sequences or even specific individual sounds after I listen. What I’m usually left with is a kind of caffeinated brain buzz; once First’s relentless compositions get neurons firing
column3:
it’s tough to make them stop. That might also be what makes Electronic Works sound undated—the direct effect it has on your grey matter is powerful enough to cut through decades.

Julie Byrne doesn't sing her ice-crusted songs so much as murmur them beneath her breath. And ""finger-picking
column2: while accurate
column3: feels far too percussive a word for her guitar playing; it's more like she brushes the strings with her fingertips
column4: like wisps of hair obscuring her vision. Live clips show Byrne performing to reverent groups of three or four in cafes
column5: where she barely rises above the sound of milk steamers and muffled coughing. Her album
column6: Rooms With Walls & Windows
column7: feels like a secret she's keeping from you
column8: even when it is safely in your headphones. If you are listening while walking the streets of a city or while commuting
column9: I recommend noise-cancellation; someone briskly turning the pages of their magazine next to you could drown her out.

column1: Byrne currently lives in Seattle
column2: but she skipped there like a stone across the country—first Buffalo
column3: then Chicago. On ""Marmalade""
column4: she describes what she's searching for: ""All I want is a brick house with a porch that wraps around/ All I want is land enough for my child to roam.""  The language in her lyrics
column5: once it emerges into your awareness
column6: is strikingly conversational
column7: but not like any one kind of conversation. She alternates between vividly dark imagery—""I lean back like a woman baptized in the River of Styx
column8: on ""Wisdom Teeth Song""—to the breathlessly naïve: ""The Museum of Natural History in its snow
column9: blood
column10: and fur and ivory/ It left me wanting to know so much more about this world"" (from the same song).  Her delivery doesn't make clear if these sentiments belong to her
column11: or if they are bits of life she's picked up listening to others.

column1: She sings everything in the same cloaked
column2: low voice
column3: and over the same skeletal arrangements
column4: which gives even the mundane sentiments a portentous ring. Her version of folk
column5: a whisper bordering on an ambient hum
column6: will be familiar to fans of early Cat Power
column7: or Grouper's Dragging A Dead Deer Up A Hill
column8: as will her ability to mine the uncanny from the everyday stuff lying around. Byrne occasionally tests your personal boundaries for what constitutes ""enough"" happening in a song: Many of her songs are not only two chords
column9: like ""Marmalade""
column10: but two notes
column11: hitting  like alternate condensation drops on your forehead while her lyrics follows drowsily afterward.

column1: Some of the most memorable and indelible moments on her album are when she leaves off of words and hums into the ether—at the end of ""Holiday""
column2: after she has sung ""And I do travel alone
column3: but yours is not a number I can call on the phone
column4: she follows it with a wordless melody that seems to put a full stop on the enigmatic thought. You can hear it again on ""Prism Song""
column5: which follows up the hypothetical scenarios of the lyrics (""If you were a prism with the light passing through"") with nothing but a wordless sigh. Sometimes we locate more meaning in sound than in sense
column6: and Byrne's album sits at the nexus where one melts gorgeously into the other. The album concludes with a few glowing rays of synth
column7: an arpeggiated tonalization that sits in place for about four minutes and dies away. The sounds are distant
column8: foggy
column9: and alluring
column10: like echoes of echoes
column11:
the original sounding long gone.

As far as genre-decrees go
column2: alt-country’s an especially prickly one. The phrase was never really championed by the artists it was applied to
column3: in part because its premise was cumbersome and vague
column4: but mostly because it was tied to a particular moment in which country music was understood—briefly and mistakenly—as inherently mainstream. (That idea
column5: at least
column6: has dissipated: anyone who’s ever spent any time pawing through a Used Country LPs bin or listening to “Drinks After Work” knows that country music
column7: as a whole
column8: is completely insane.) Still
column9: in January 1990
column10: when Uncle Tupelo steered a dented Chevy van to Boston’s Fort Apache South and recorded their debut full-length
column11: No Depression
column12: traditional country music seemed antithetical to contemporary punk-rock
column13: and the notion that the two might comingle—might be symbiotic bedfellows
column14: even—required a deep philological reimagining.

column1: Our musical imaginations have become larger
column2: the membranes more permeable; now
column3: being equally invested in the Minutemen and Hank Williams doesn’t seem remotely incongruous. Still
column4: No Depression
column5: which takes its name from J.D. Vaughan’s “No Depression in Heaven”
column6: a gospel track first made famous by the Carter Family in 1936 and then by the New Lost City Ramblers in 1959
column7: and which later inspired a magazine dedicated loosely to alt-country and its analogues
column8: is a heady reminder that genre hasn’t always been so fluid. It’s also a reminder of how strange and turbulent an act Uncle Tupelo was: Country and punk are both vulnerable
column9: impassioned
column10: tenuous enterprises
column11: and the places where they overlap are especially combustible. Uncle Tupelo is typically evoked in discussions of the two outfits it birthed (Wilco and Son Volt)
column12: but No Depression is a significant record independent of its fallout.

column1: Uncle Tupelo liked to play fast
column2: but even their slower songs are imbued with a kind of frantic inertia
column3: like some wild-eyed goon sprinting across a tightrope
column4: knowing that if he slows down for even a second
column5: he’ll topple. Part of that can be attributed to the experience of being young and loose in the world—Jeff Tweedy and drummer Mike Heidorn were 22 and Jay Farrar was 23 when they arrived at Fort Apache—but the tangling of sensibilities both musical and extra-musical yielded something remarkable: a raw
column6: lonesome clatter
column7: the singular sound of Midwestern kids getting loud and desperate.

column1: There were a handful of other bands doing comparable work (Jason and the Scorchers were blending country and punk rock as early as 1981; in Britain
column2: the Pogues were fusing elements of Irish vernacular music with a rebellious
column3: adolescent ache)
column4: but Uncle Tupelo reached a certain cultural flashpoint first. This reissue—which differentiates itself from a 2003 version by collecting 22 previously unavailable demos and live tracks—proffers a good sense of the band’s trajectory
column5: from the halls and parking lots of Belleville
column6: Ill.
column7: through stints opening for Warren Zevon and the Band. The bonus material is demo-heavy (it includes all of 1989’s <i>Not Forever
column8: Just for Now
column9: five songs from the 1987 demo Colorblind and Rhymeless
column10: and two songs from Live and Otherwise
column11: a self-released tape from 1988)
column12: which will satisfy Uncle Tupelo completists but likely won’t do much for new fans
column13: who might be better served by just listening to the re-mastered record. Farrar and Tweedy
column14: who share most of the songwriting credits
column15: alternate between earnest
column16: romantic confessions (“I woke up to realize it didn’t mean a thing… Give me back that year
column17: ” Tweedy hollers in “That Year”) and a populist
column18: blue-collar righteousness likely nipped from Woody Guthrie (even the cover emulates an old Folkways LP). In both instances
column19: whiskey is fundamental (“I got drunk and I fell down
column20: ” Farrar and Tweedy sing in an especially effortless bit of harmony).

column1: Nodding to their predecessors (and supposed foes) in Nashville—where writing isn’t necessarily tantamount to performance
column2: and songs are constantly reclaimed
column3: apportioned
column4: sold—Uncle Tupelo never eschewed a good cover
column5: and their take on the Flying Burrito Brothers’ “Sin City” is especially doleful
column6: heavy with a particular kind of resignation: Farrar’s voice sounds sodden
column7: acquiescent
column8: like a kid who’s just been hit in the face with a water balloon. “It seems like this whole town’s insane
column9: ” he sings
column10: his voice glum. What Gram Parsons imbued with a mystical
column11: West Coast incredulity
column12: Farrar handles more like a shrug: “The scientists say it’ll all wash away
column13: but we don’t believe anymore.” The sentiment’s sanguine enough
column14: except that Farrar treats the “but” a lot more like “because”: we’ve sinned ourselves into oblivion
column15: and nothing’s gonna keep out the Lord’s burning rain.

column1: Ultimately
column2: worry is the thing that animates No Depression and what
column3: 24 years out
column4: still resonates the most: it’s a part-panicked
column5: part-dispirited
column6: part-defiant reaction to broad social injustices and personal defeats
column7: all the things that make the world seem untenable. The circumstances might reconfigure
column8: but the sentiment remains: life is unfair.

column1: Uncle Tupelo made No Depression for just $3
column2: 500 (the studio’s house producers
column3: Sean Slade and Paul Kolderie
column4: lent Farrar the same 1961 Les Paul guitar J. Mascis jammed on Dinosaur Jr.’s Bug). The band released three more records before splitting—acrimoniously—in 1994. Farrar and Tweedy both went on to lead successful bands
column5: and in the two decades since they parted
column6: reimagining Americana has become its own cottage industry
column7: a fury of wool vests and reconditioned banjos and oiled beards. Alt-country doesn’t mean much anymore because country doesn’t mean much anymore; genre feels like a relic of the record store era
column8: back when hand-labeled plastic dividers still parsed sound into neat categories.

column1: It’s challenging
column2: then
column3: to appreciate the boldness of No Depression
column4: the extent to which the members of Uncle Tupelo insisted on interdependency
column5: on an American story. We don’t have to do that anymore—folks don’t self-identify in the same way
column6: and hardly anyone loves just one genre monogamously—but there’s still something furious and prideful here
column7:
something worth hearing.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20098/homepage_large.31f90674.jpg|Held In Splendor|29971.0|Quilt|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2014-01-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:31.111210|"

For a young rock band in the 60s
column2: the opportunity to make a second LP usually meant getting trippier and more ambitious. And so it goes for Quilt
column3: a young rock band influenced by young rock bands from the 60s. On the Massachusetts trio’s 2011 self-titled debut
column4: the ghosts of the Byrds
column5: Jefferson Airplane
column6: and Mamas and the Papas were summoned via jangly
column7: well-written pop songs that never strayed far from their harmony-rich melodies. On Quilt’s sophomore release
column8: <i>Held In Splendor
column9: band members Shane Butler
column10: Anna Fox Rochinski
column11: and John Andrews grow more expansive in their instrumentation
column12: blowing out their simple psych-folk ditties into strings-laden multi-part suites that build toward thrilling
column13: guitar-heavy climaxes. It’s a clear progression that nevertheless manages to keep Quilt tucked firmly in the milieu of paisley-colored retro pop-rock.

column1: Lesser groups working the same territory tend to lose sight of their songwriting while in pursuit of just the right Rickenbacker guitar sound or the precise vintage of Farfisa organ. The strength of Quilt’s debut was that underneath all of the flower-power window dressing there were strong hooks and disciplined classicist arrangements. The members of Quilt thankfully haven’t lost those qualities on Splendor
column2: even as many of the songs have grown in sophistication. “Tired and Buttered” begins as an aggressively driving rocker that suddenly downshifts into a dreamy shuffle
column3: and then shifts again into a slowly building rager. The gorgeous “Just Dust” glides seamlessly into the instrumental reverie “The World is Flat”
column4: which showcases the understated but magnetic musical interplay between Butler
column5: Rochinski
column6: and Andrews. The closing “I Sleep in Nature” is another shape-shifter
column7: moving from a discombobulated prologue to a jauntily melodic mid-section that’s pure 60s pop whimsy
column8: albeit with a darkly sinister edge.

column1: Where Splendor diverges from Quilt is in the use of three-part harmonies—while they were all over the first LP
column2: principal singers Butler and Rochinski switch off on lead vocals here. Butler is a more conventional “60s psych-rock dude” singer
column3: favoring an aloof croon on songs like the rather pedestrian “Eye of the Pearl”. Rochinski
column4: on the other hand
column5: has emerged as the band’s star. Her delicate and lilting alto is capable of conveying innocence (like on the album-opening “Arctic Shark”) as well as beguiling sexiness
column6: even when she’s singing nonsense like “planetary truth is born of lightning” on “Tie Up the Tides”.

column1: As Tame Impala proved with its 2012 masterpiece Lonerism
column2: psych-rock still has the power to communicate with listeners not already pre-disposed to care about the genre. Held in Splendor is a good example of a record that successfully executes the tropes of psych—it sounds like it could’ve been recorded in 1967 without directly ripping off any artist in particular—without every truly transcending them. In order to do that
column3: Quilt will have to make an even more ambitious third record. Given its evolution thus far
column4:
they are well on their way.     

"|18903.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18903-quilt-held-in-splendor/|7.0|Steven Hyden

This winter marks two full years of Chicago hip-hop attracting national attention. During this period
column2: many people have been eager to assign the city a clear narrative
column3: from the half-dozen or so documentary film crews that have stopped through to the pundits who use Chicago rappers as part of their rhetorical agenda. And while one consistent narrative has emerged—Chicago rap is violent!—the scene has evolved rapidly and dramatically. It's now marked by a fragmented patchwork of genres
column4: microgenres
column5: and individual artist movements—drill
column6: bop
column7: soul trap
column8: acid rap
column9: alternative trap
column10: several types of waves and waviness—that have defied or redefined the narrative completely.

column1: Among the artists who have most resisted easy categorization is Tink
column2: the teenage singer and rapper from the south suburb of Calumet City who has put out four mixtapes of varying tone and quality since early 2012. Her first effort
column3: Winter's Diary
column4: made when she was a junior in high school
column5: introduced her as a sort of potential long-lost member of TLC (never mind that she hadn't even been born during the group's breakout years)
column6: a talented
column7: soft-voiced singer with an ear for contemporary rap and an astute emotional awareness. But her first glimpse of success came that summer with the brash
column8: clever rap of “Fingers Up”. Eager to show she was a double threat
column9: Tink then put out Alter Ego
column10: a mixtape full of technically adept but generic raps that
column11: ""Fingers Up"" aside
column12: abandoned much of the unique viewpoint and subject matter that made her such an immediately electrifying presence.

column1: Playing around in the areas between these two poles has helped Tink retain an edge of unpredictability and cater to a broad audience: She's proved her rap bona fides over and over with surgically precise verses like last summer's widely acclaimed “Versace” freestyle. She's shored up her Chicago credibility through collaborations with Lil Durk and Sasha Go Hard and established herself as part of the wave of successors to drill music by aligning herself with hard-edged lyrical whiz kids Lil Herb and Lil Bibby. She's captured the attention of the internet's avant-garde
column2: spawning collaborations with artists like producer collective Future Brown and New York rapper Junglepussy. And she's continued to stake out a distinctively young
column3: female voice whether she's expressing the frustration of dealing with flaky lovers or playing at and winning that boys' rap game of pretending you're a drug kingpin.

column1: Winter's Diary 2 doubles down on this last point
column2: offering both the most clear-cut perspective and the most accomplished sound of any Tink release yet
column3: delivered with casual charm and easy emotional honesty. The characters in Tink's songs navigate complicated
column4: intimate
column5: and frequently disappointing romantic relationships. They are overtly sexual—take “When It Rains”
column6: a slinky celebration of riding out thunderstorms in bed
column7: which borrows the kind of subject matter normally reserved for grown and sexy album cuts by artists in their 30s (but equally felt by younger people).

column1: They also often find themselves butting up against the gendered expectations of a hip-hop and hustler culture. On the brilliant “Money Ova Everything”
column2: Tink flips the title catchphrase into a couple's joint pursuit
column3: a promise and ultimately a kind of lament. And the back-and-forth of “Talkin' About” with Lil Herb—its lyrical tradeoff and narrative welcome 1990s throwback trope dressed up in modern flows and production—finds a couple arguing about the effects of the guy spending time on the block on their relationship (“I buy my own Prada
column4: man
column5: that's not the problem!” Tink exasperatedly snarls at the suggestion of whose hustling is keeping things afloat). “Dirty Slang”
column6: the clearest pop highlight with its twinkling
column7: synth-driven beat and muscular
column8: Auto-Tuned hook
column9: is a triumphant and flirtatious celebration of a guy who likes hitting the strip club.

column1: Tink's seamless blend of rapping and singing is likely to call to mind Drake or Lauryn Hill
column2: who are similarly interested in dissecting relationships
column3: but the closest sonic equivalent might be Elle Varner
column4: whose taste for R&B laced with acoustic guitars is echoed here. Like all three
column5: Tink has a strong instinct for finding the emotional core of modern crises. This strength is particularly clear when she's discussing heartbreak
column6: as on the arresting
column7: guitar-backed first single “Treat Me Like Somebody” or in the high
column8: plaintive mantra of “please don't break my heart” on “Fight It”. But it also rings true in other contexts
column9: like the romantic
column10: artfully Auto-Tuned “Lullaby” or the carefully spit celebration of intimacy “Your Secrets.”

column1: On the other hand
column2: Tink's singing style
column3: which is slight and breathy
column4: lacks power
column5: and her voice can grate when it gets stuck in the same groove for too long. This type of meandering R&B is fine for building a fan base
column6: but it's almost resigned to always being a hit away from stardom. While Tink's choice in production is mostly smart and inoffensive
column7: her skill set would be immensely well-served by collaborating with an A-list producer. <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column8: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">And it would be a smart move for one to pair up with her
column9: too. Not only does she have a strong and unique perspective
column10: she has the willingness to write her own story that has helped Chicago's recent breakout stars defy the efforts at categorization and speak to a broad audience. A city's scene is made not so much by having many artists who stick to the same sound but by having many who break out of it
column11:
and Tink is a new voice doing exactly that.

"|18979.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18979-tink-winters-diary-2/|7.6|Kyle Kramer

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20138/homepage_large.b7556641.jpg|Native State|31910.0|Jess Williamson|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brutal Honest']|2014-01-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:32.642254|"

“Maybe I am just the devil’s girl
column2: ” Austin native Jess Williamson sang in one of her early songs
column3: each word croaked like something drifted up from the underworld. Williamson’s particular strain of folk is at once earthy and gothic
column4: often seeming haunted by some invisible
column5: vaguely tortured presence—a guitar creaks like an old staircase; the occasional pedal steel lick blows by like a sudden
column6: inexplicable draft. Her songs are loosely structured and rarely have what you’d call verses and choruses; she prefers instead to let them unfurl into strange and twisted shapes. Sometimes she sounds like Angel Olsen or Joanna Newsom
column7: but more often she sounds like a coyote—lonesome and half-rabid
column8: howling into the sparse landscapes of her songs and then pausing
column9: as if she’s waiting for an echo.

column1: Williamson’s debut full-length Native State is only seven songs long
column2: but it unfolds at an unhurried pace that makes it feel expansive. She wrote it shortly after leaving New York City for her hometown of Austin (she describes that change as a “period of turning inward and spending a good deal of time alone”)
column3: and
column4: fittingly
column5: these songs luxuriate in slow rhythms
column6: compositional elbow room
column7: and moments of quiet introspection. The stirring
column8: macabre opener “Blood Song” begins as though it’s being sung by a sleepwalker (“Who can say what’s really real when there’s a veil between what you kinda see and what you kinda feel”)
column9: but it gathers force and vividness as the song moves on. Like Williamson’s most powerful songs
column10: “Blood Song” gives you the impression that you are watching someone weaving on a loom in reverse: as time goes on patterns unravel
column11: solid ground disappears
column12: and by the end the the very bones of the thing lay exposed.

column1: There’s never a shortage of the kind of music Williamson makes. Every generation has its own crop of banjo-wielding mystics singing about astrology
column2: medicine wheels
column3: and long-haired ladies
column4: and—blame so-called hipster culture’s antique shop fetishism
column5: or maybe just the commercial viability of Marcus Mumford—that lane feels particularly crowded right now. But that makes it that much more impressive that Native State stands out among this ever-refreshing crowd. Williamson is particularly good at braiding together nostalgia for the past with a gimlet-eyed (and often bitingly self-aware) view of the present moment. (There’s humor here
column6: occasionally
column7: so subtle and cutting that you might miss it: “I thought I saw something real in Barcelona
column8: in Brooklyn/ But I’ve learned the power now of manic delusions.”) She paints scenes of “moon-bathing ladies” and measures time by Saturn’s orbit
column9: but then chases these lines with expressions of such plainspoken clarity that they almost knock you off your feet: “Here I am at 25 and I can’t sign a lease
column10: ” she admits in the last song. “Mostly I’ve survived off people being nice to me.”

column1: Native State is often quite dark
column2: so the last two songs—aside from “Blood Song”
column3: perhaps the best she’s released yet—pop up like the first shocks of green in springtime. “You Can Have Heaven on Earth” is a warm
column4: banjo-driven ode to nature (“Try as we must to touch what surrounds us/ All of us thinking what we can’t photograph
column5: we can sing”)
column6: but all of the themes of the album really come together in the short
column7: sprightly closer “Seventh Song”. It’s a song about finding a balance between solitude and codependence
column8: between barrelling forward and standing still. Native State is a document of a restless spirit
column9: a wanderer continually searching for the landscape that will best match the thoughts—and the songs—that rattle inside her. But she never romanticizes her wanderlust: She realizes that the very drive that moves her forward could easily result in a lifetime of dissatisfaction. The wisdom of “Seventh Song”
column10: then
column11: is how to find peace in stillness—even if it’s only temporary. You can almost hear the hum of the highway beckoning in the background
column12: but in the album’s final line
column13:
she’s found the thrill of its opposite: “Do you know how holy it is/ Just to sit quietly with someone?”

"|18942.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18942-jess-williamson-native-state/|7.4|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20177/homepage_large.c9afdc5b.jpg|Radio Niger|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sublime Frequencies']|2014-01-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:33.599755|"

A lot of labels have found their niches by delivering the sounds of the world to us by compiling songs that would otherwise be unavailable outside their milieu of their creation. Sublime Frequencies has become one such imprint; their compilations of Southeast Asian pop music in particular are executed with passion and attention to archival and storytelling detail. Before the label got into that game
column2: though
column3: things were a bit more freewheeling
column4: and its compilers and recordists approached sounds not as discrete tracks
column5: or the performers as people with backstories and a place in history
column6: but rather as an ocean of audio to dive into.

column1: That means sounds usually left out of the narrative of global audio history were fair game; the label’s compilations of recordings made off the radio in remote locales were their own brand of audio bricolage
column2: and they could be intoxicating and frustrating at the same time. Radio Niger follows in this tradition. Comprised of recordings of radio broadcasts made by traveler Hisham Mayet in the Saharan country of Niger and edited and sequenced by Alan Bishop
column3: the disc is a swirling collage that captures both captivating music and the sense of play and experimentation with which Nigerien DJs approach their trade.

column1: None of the music is identified. It simply appears as part of the flow of the recording
column2: collaged in among studio and call-in banter in a number of languages. The point of these recordings isn’t to bring us great tracks we might otherwise be missing out on—it's more about the total experience of hearing these sounds and catching a glimpse of what the soundworld of Niger is like a day-to-day basis—but this still merits some discussion. First
column3: what you are hearing is decidedly not what the average Nigerien hears. There is a quantum effect where the observation changes the result
column4: and while Nigerien DJs engage in collage and singing along
column5: both of which are heard here
column6: we don’t get a feel for what a single full broadcast might be like. It is a compressed view. This isn’t a bad thing from an artistic standpoint—the collage is part of the package
column7: and it distills what would otherwise be unwieldy.

column1: The use of the music is more problematic. It is
column2: after all
column3: music somebody made
column4: and to leave it anonymous in favor of a wide-eyed “wow
column5: listen to all of this” approach increases the sense that the musicians playing it are part of some arm’s-length Other and not individuals. That the collage exposes enormous diversity
column6: both sonic and cultural
column7: does little to address this basic flaw. I try to imagine a lawyer for Led Zeppelin hearing one of his client’s songs drifting through a theoretically similar collage made in the Connecticut River Valley and not hitting the “litigate” button
column8: but he hits it every time.

column1: As much as this bothers me
column2: Radio Niger and all of the label’s similar releases do have value
column3: aesthetically and culturally. Niger is a vast and diverse country
column4: monetarily poor but culturally wealthy
column5: and a lot of Americans might only know of it from a reference to yellowcake uranium in a State of the Union Address given by George W. Bush a decade ago. Traditional Saharan string instruments and drums
column6: choral singing and trance music are all part of this audioscape
column7: but they are set next to Auto-tuned pop
column8: Bollywood-influenced songs
column9: rock
column10: and electronic music that more formal compilations often forget exists or try to ignore. The most haunting moment on the disc comes when a bit of spooky
column11: minor-key techno surfaces out of nowhere
column12: and suddenly the world’s hottest desert feels very cold. And that
column13: really
column14: is where Radio Niger succeeds in spite of its flaws: by listening and distilling
column15: it paints a more complete
column16:
human and real picture of audio life in Niger than any other single source.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20020/homepage_large.539df6ed.jpg|Nixon|2417.0|Lambchop|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Merge']|2014-01-29 00:00:00|2000|2016-06-11 16:48:33.802898|"

Nixon is the album when Lambchop became the band people think of as Lambchop
column2: if they think of Lambchop at all: 14 outcasts in denim and pearl buttons
column3: standing onstage and staring at their shoes
column4: playing the pro-social sounds of country and soul with the graceful reluctance of indie rockers too polite to beg for attention but too obstinate to shut up and go home. I can only imagine that Merge’s decision to remaster and reissue the album embarrassed them
column5: then made them feel humbled
column6: then a little bit corny—such are the old-fashioned values of Lambchop. Where some bands use bonus discs to pump out hot
column7: unreleased material designed to chart the depths of the band's creative prowess
column8: Lambchop offer a brief set by singer Kurt Wagner on French radio and call it How I Met Cat Power. Even when it’s about Lambchop
column9: it’s not about Lambchop.

column1: Nixon was released in 2000 and immediately enshrined by the British music press. Uncut named it album of the year
column2: Mojo ranked it 10th
column3: and Q was still doing their lists alphabetically. The band sold out the 2
column4: 500-person Royal Festival Hall (home of the London Philharmonic)
column5: and a Zero 7 remix of “Up With People”—the album’s climactic track—made the singles chart. The NME called Nixon “near to perfect” and the Guardian said that the band was “reinventing American music.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: most people in America continued to have no idea who Lambchop were. (“I don’t think [Nixon] made much of an impression on anyone over here
column3: ” Wagner told a seemingly baffled interviewer in spring
column4: 2001.) Lambchop’s take on America—sly
column5: tender
column6: mysterious but mundane—is less a realist’s portrait than a surrealist’s impression: funnier
column7: more pathetic
column8: more improbable than what actually exists. In 2007 I met a German man named Frank who told me he loved seeing the band overseas because it meant getting to sit in a plush
column9: quiet room while drinking tons of beer and listening to Lambchop
column10: which I guess he imagined Americans were mellow enough to actually do.

column1: Nixon is still an improbable album. The band never sounds like they’re trying very hard and yet every song breaks some convention or another. Despite its showbiz arrangements
column2: the music is tenuous and weird (a contrast that the band toyed with again on 2012's Mr. M)
column3: and Wagner’s falsetto—usually the most vulnerable part of a man’s singing range—sounds less like a Romeo than some karaoke loser scrapping for the mic at last call. He says he regrets ever calling Lambchop a country band
column4: and with good reason: Nixon isn't the music of the people
column5: it's the music of the people who showed up
column6: said hello
column7: stood in the corner and left without saying goodbye. (When an interviewer asked Wagner how he felt about the album’s overwhelming reception in the UK
column8: he said
column9: “I’m not sure that’s something to be proud of. I think there are other things in your life you could be more proud of. Like having kids.”) If there's a connection to country
column10: it's spiritual: Nixon finds its humor in self-deprecation and its soul in things broken and left behind.

column1: Even as a fan
column2: I understand the ways in which Lambchop can seem standoffish and cold. “I’m in the thick of it
column3: ” Wagner admits on “The Distance from Her to There”. “I’ve been a dick with it/ You’ll get used to it.” Against the sumptuous sounds of reverb
column4: jazz chords
column5: and violins
column6: he sketches out images of drunken neighbors and people peeing on railroad tracks. “The kids out in the street
column7: ” goes a line on the album’s opening song
column8: “The Old Gold Shoe”
column9: “take their toys and break them
column10: and look at them and walk away.” There is no poetry here—no embellishment or elevation. This is just the everyday kind of mean you see when you open the window and look outside.

column1: And yet the secret weapon of Nixon—and of all Lambchop’s albums—is tenderness. “The Book I Haven’t Read”
column2: “The Distance from Her to There”
column3: “Up With People”: these are songs that end up insisting that the world is actually a pretty decent place
column4: not just in spite of the banality and clutter
column5: but because of it. After all the broken toys
column6: the disgusting habits
column7: the broken bottles and falling rain
column8: “The Book I Haven’t Read” ends with the line
column9: “We could be—we should be—in love.”

column1: At its heart
column2: Nixon is an album fascinated by the world at its most fallible and ordinary. “And of that sweet
column3: sweet soul
column4: ” Wagner sings on “Up With People”
column5: “Let’s be certain the deliberate monologue/ As sure as if it will fall/ Across you
column6: unto you/ We’ll most certainly leave the doing
column7: the doing undone.” In other words: You’re probably gonna fuck it up.

column1: And yet somehow the song—with its handclaps
column2: high-stepping backbeat
column3: and an ostinato bassline borrowed from the uplifting sound of Motown—plays like a triumph. “We are doing/ We are screwing up our lives today
column4: ” Wagner sings on the refrain. Then
column5: with the showman’s point of a finger
column6: he commands a line of gospel singers who go off behind him like fireworks. “Come on
column7: progeny
column8: ” they wail
column9: and together
column10: Lambchop enters orbit. Laugh if you want—I usually do. Then
column11: when I’m feeling bad
column12:
I draw so close to the song that it starts to sound like a prayer. We all fail sometime. Whether or not we learn to joke about it is up to us.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20140/homepage_large.8ebf10d9.jpg|The Green EP|576.0|Bibio|['Folk/Country'
column3: Stephen Wilkinson
column4: better known as Bibio
column5: often worked at the edge of the subliminal. Blending wobbly electronics with English folk
column6: he split the difference between the detuned gurgle of Boards of Canada and the ethereal emotion of Nick Drake. He usually seemed misty and pensive
column7: as if feeling his own smallness against the vastness of nature
column8: which he recorded to infuse his productions with dusty space and light. But in 2009
column9: something kind of amazing happened. Bibio hopped to Warp and took a J Dilla turn on Ambivalence Avenue
column10: mainlining crunchy soul and juicy funk and richly haunting ballads
column11: suddenly as extroverted as he had once been humble.

column1: Just as he tried to linger in that inspired moment on supplementary album The Apple and the Tooth
column2: Bibio now strings out last year's Silver Wilkinson—the album where he slipped back into focus
column3: however softly
column4: after the confusing Mind Bokeh—with an EP built
column5: from unreleased archives
column6: around album track ""Dye the Water Green""
column7: where lonesome vocals and gently driving acoustic arpeggios subtly give way to a slinky bass and chimes instrumental. Murky and mellow
column8: the song delivers Bibio just about back to where he began: casting nostalgic melodies down a slow river of bending tape. Second track ""Dinghy""
column9: a bright theme for bobbing guitar counterpoint
column10: calls to mind wispy debut album Fi more than recent work.

column1: Like the album from which it was derived
column2: the Green EP is pleasantly moody
column3: but less impactful than Bibio's increasingly anomalous-seeming 2009 epiphany. At six songs
column4: with half of them three minutes or less
column5: the EP floats by quickly despite its consistently restrained tempos
column6: with the close matching of the new material to ""Dye the Water Green"" smudging over divisions between tracks. For about 25 minutes
column7: it sustains a wistful
column8: low-key atmosphere
column9: punctuated by a couple bolder moments—the storm-threatened ballad ""Down to the Sound"" and the ambient folk of ""A Thousand Syllables""—that feel like more than serendipitous single takes
column10: both recalling Ambivalence Avenue's haunting ""The Palm of Your Wave"".

column1: Bibio brings a certain refinement and voice to anything he produces now
column2: but that doesn't change the fact that much of the EP is indisputably ad hoc. There's a stern baritone guitar improvisation on album track ""Wulf""
column3: a nice power-trio style instrumental Bibio overdubbed by himself in someone’s rural cabin
column4: a simple 2006 jam with his friend Richard Roberts of Letherette
column5: stuff like that. It would be unfair to call them outtakes
column6: too much to call them essential new Bibio songs. Green gives no inkling of what his next phase might sound like
column7: but it's a tidy little stopgap release until he probably surprises us
column8: for better or worse
column9:
again.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20132/homepage_large.9a671622.jpg|Divine Ecstasy|30494.0|Supreme Cuts|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dovecote']|2014-01-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:35.644988|"

With their second full-length album
column2: Chicago production duo Supreme Cuts attempt to make a big leap. Their 2012 debut Whispers in the Dark was a strikingly trendy and sometimes engrossing stew of bass beats that seemed more eager to confound than galvanize. There were few rhythms to groove to and no words to sing along with
column3: but on Divine Ecstasy that changes. Alongside a number of vocal collaborators
column4: Supreme Cuts shoot for the anthemic but come up measurably short.

column1: To be clear
column2: these aren’t exactly pop or R&B songs: instead
column3: they sound like remixed versions of nonexistent singles that were at one point accessible. Accessibility
column4: of course
column5: is both subjective and far from life’s only path
column6: but in trying to mold controlled chaos into actual verses and choruses
column7: Divine Ecstasy gets lost in translation. This is no clearer than on the lead single “Down""
column8: which features members of close Supreme Cuts collaborators JODY. The track clearly aims for the skipping headrush of classic booty bass R&B songs
column9: but landmarks like “My Boo” or INOJ’s “Love You Down” work because of the simple but effective interplay between a sweet
column10: clear vocal and a propulsive
column11: heart-racing rhythm. “Down""
column12: on the other hand
column13: is a disastrous mush of too-fast drums
column14: misty keyboards and muddled bass. It sounds like a demo and probably should’ve stayed as such.

column1: Even the songs here that show flashes of congealing eventually end up falling apart into a watery mess. “Cocktails” has a strong vocal performance from the Portland R&B singer Shy Girls that hits a certain ethereal sweet spot where the unintelligibility of the lyrics only highlights the grace of the melodies. But the production is overly busy to the point of tunelessness—it constantly rattles the song out of what could have been an aching and tense ballad. The same can be said for “Envision""
column2: which features Channy Leaneagh of Poliça. The vocal here is not nearly as good
column3: but nonetheless it’s drowned out by a clattering beat. The song
column4: or what could have been a song
column5: completely disintegrates.

column1: Polyrhythms for the sake of polyrhythms is the defining characteristic of Divine Ecstasy. But what Supreme Cuts seem to miss is that the tricky percussion of contemporary R&B legends like Timbaland or Rodney Jerkins always had a place. Timbaland’s drum programming was mind-bending not just because it was almost impossible to understand how it came from a human brain
column2: but because it was always functional. Almost every single song on Divine Ecstasy could have benefited greatly from producers Mike Perry and Austin Kjeultes dialing way back. “Brown Flowers” is case in point: in allowing a stunning vocal from French singer Mahaut Mondino to soak up the spotlight
column3: Supreme Cuts end up with easily the album’s best song.

column1: In ethos and tone
column2: Divine Ecstasy reminds me often of no world
column3: the neo-soul revivalist album from the duo Inc. If there was one major criticism of that record is that there wasn’t enough personality—that Inc. was reverent to a fault without having the skill level of
column4: say
column5: Maxwell. But I liked that inc. let no world speak for itself. They made no extraordinary effort to win you over. The songs were more important than being called ""impressive."" On Divine Ecstasy
column6: Supreme Cuts bash you over the head with every single tool in their box. If you last more than one round
column7:
consider yourself incredibly resilient.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20145/homepage_large.f2cdf314.jpg|Drained of Connotation|31999.0|Stefan Jaworzyn|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Blackest Ever Black']|2014-01-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:36.197597|"

Ask noise-heads which musicians mattered in the 80s and 90s
column2: and Stefan Jaworzyn will likely come up. Three of his groups were among the most unique and notorious in the UK underground: power electronics pioneers Whitehouse
column3: who he spent two short stints with; mammoth noise-rock outfit Skullflower
column4: which he co-founded with Matthew Bower; and free-improv duo Ascension (disclosure: they contributed to a 7-inch I released)
column5: which expanded into the quartet Descension. Jaworzyn also helmed the consistently excellent Shock label
column6: issuing stellar experimental titles by Current 93
column7: Coil
column8: and the Dead C.

column1: All of this activity came to a mysterious halt in the late 90s
column2: when Jaworzyn ceased making music or doing anything else in the public eye (a recent press release claims he stopped to “focus on drinking and cursing.”) His silence persisted until last year
column3: when Shock re-emerged with a flurry remniscent of Jaworzyn’s hyperactive past. Two solo 12"" EPs married his noise sensibilities to something resembling beats
column4: even danceable ones. Between those came an archival collection of early 80s Jaworzyn material
column5: Eaten Away by Shadows
column6: as well as expanded reissues of four early Skullflower titles.

column1: As Jaworzyn was putting together those reissues
column2: he happened upon a tape of solo pieces he made in 1982
column3: recorded at home using a synth and a drum machine. As heard on Drained of Connotation
column4: those tracks show that Jaworzyn’s recent shift to more beat-oriented music isn’t an overnight transformation. But the beats here aren’t rhythms so much as they are loops—repetitive
column5: throbbing figures over which he splashes synth squiggles and dissonant blasts. His approach is just as much one of fascination with electronics and tempos as it is with noise and textures.

column1: In fact
column2: Jaworzyn’s fascination with his electronics is what makes Drained of Connotation both an intriguing listen and a minor curiosity. His devotion to riding out drum machine patterns and allowing synth figures time to fully attack and decay can create hypnotic
column3: brain-freezing music. But little here rises above the level of experiment to become something memorable
column4: something that ascends through motion or tension—in other words
column5: something that picks you up in one place and drops you off somewhere else.

column1: To be fair
column2: crafting musical arcs probably wasn’t Jaworzyn’s goal when he sat hunkered over electronics in his bedroom 30 years ago
column3: so it's misguided to blame Drained of Connotation for failing to do so. But I can’t help but imagine that if he had thought of this material as a potential release at the time
column4: he might have worked on building and layering his sounds. Instead
column5: each piece focuses on a single unwavering drum machine rhythm and one synth sound that hews to a narrow tonal range.

column1: Given that restricted approach
column2: it's impressive how much Jaworzyn does with so little. On the “Psychoanalytically Speaking
column3: You’re Fucked”
column4: ripping noise-bombs detonate unpredictably over a minimal
column5: millitaristic beat. Even more surprising is “I Am Not Going to Make This Mistake Again”
column6: whose slow
column7: uneventful pace becomes a vital pulse when paired with Jaworzyn’s sheets of heavy fuzz and chopping noise. But the line between vital and mundane is thin: take “Pillars of Excrement”
column8: whose monolithic oscillations are nearly as rote as its plodding rhythm.

column1: That inconsistency is understandable
column2: since this is clearly a collection rather than an album
column3: and expecting it to hang together perfectly could be missing the point. What is interesting about Drained of Connotation is the implication there are more uncovered sides to an artist who’s already shown quite a few. Hopefully with Shock’s revitalization
column4: Jaworzyn will continue to reveal even more
column5:
and Drained of Connotation could ultimately rank as an interesting footnote to a substantial second act.

"|18950.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18950-stefan-jaworzyn-drained-of-connotation/|6.5|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20139/homepage_large.5aeaaa05.jpg|In Roses|28840.0|Gem Club|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hardly Art']|2014-01-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:36.697580|"

Boston-area trio Gem Club’s 2011 full-length debut Breakers was mostly recorded in lead vocalist/songwriter Christopher Barnes’ bedroom
column2: and that sort of claustrophobic intimacy was reflected in its narrow stylistic range and Barnes’ minimal arrangements. Breakers was an album of cool
column3: spartan chamber-pop that relied heavily on the use of space to suggest distance and introspection.

column1: New album In Roses goes in a different direction: leaving the familiar terrain of Barnes’ living quarters
column2: the band recorded in California
column3: where they worked out of indie rock journeyman John Vanderslice’s San Francisco studio with local producer Minna Choi. The change of scenery and major upgrade in fidelity is immediately evident; this is a much warmer
column4: richer album than its predecessor
column5: and Barnes’ compositions swell and take new shape from the heat. “Michael” drips with the gentle
column6: starlit romanticism of the Antlers; epic closer “Polly” blooms with the help of a softly rolling organ riff that’s ripped straight from Beach House’s playbook. Throughout the album
column7: strings swoop and flit around with a lightness that’s a world away from the mostly solemn cello melodies found on Breakers.

column1: Barnes also takes major vocal and lyrical steps forward. With the help of vocalist Ieva Berberian
column2: he alternates between swaddling his voice in gauzy layers of harmony (“Idea for Strings”) and sprinkling bright flecks of sound around his lead takes
column3: both new wrinkles to his arrangements. And then there's his newfound lyrical focus and clarity. Much of In Roses grapples with queerness in an honest
column4: emotionally unvarnished fashion
column5: whether through explicit nods to old idols—like the aching
column6: mournful “Soft Season”
column7: an ode to the influential gay porn star and ultimate drug overdose victim Joey Stefano—or raw self-examinations like the aforementioned “Michael”
column8: a requiem for a dead relationship that climaxes with Barnes watching his love physically fading away: “I can see it in your eyes/ It’s in your back
column9: your chest/ It’s emotion rise/ It’s the color back/ I can feel it.” His bruising tenderness pairs well with the album’s poignant orchestration
column10: and his perspective is refreshing and welcome among standard and plentiful heterosexual narratives.

column1: While In Roses is a collection of very successful variations on a theme
column2: it doesn’t represent an uptick in Gem Club’s versatility or range. The band may be employing a more varied palette than on previous listeners
column3: but they rarely break from their basic template of vocals-piano-strings
column4: and save perhaps “Michael” the album doesn’t hold the sort of instantly indelible melodies that might pull new or casual listeners into the band’s sphere. Still
column5: the new splashes of color are welcome
column6:
and they help to lend In Roses a degree of character that wasn’t always present in Gem Club’s earlier music.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20170/homepage_large.a0fd5f46.jpg|Thirtysixtwentyfive|1547.0|Four Tet|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Output']|2014-01-28 00:00:00|1998|2016-06-11 16:48:37.455053|"

Kieran Hebden's been in a reflective mood of late
column2: perhaps triggered by the fact that the benchmark Four Tet album Rounds turned 10 years old last year. Among the collection of archival material suddenly made available has been a stream of a 1999 mix for Gilles Peterson's BBC radio show
column3: a big data dump of remix work
column4: and the 0181 collection spanning 1997-2001. Earlier this year Hebden opened a Bandcamp account
column5: offering streams and cheap downloads of three early EPs and the full-length Dialogue. The material dates back to the late 1990s
column6: a period when Four Tet was more of a side project for Hebden
column7: with his attention mostly falling on the post-rock emulation of his three-piece band
column8: Fridge. With Rounds symbolizing the moment everything zoomed into sharp focus
column9: this work resembles the obstacles he had to navigate to get to that place.

column1: If Hebden's group work sounded like a bunch of guys who had clutched copies of Tortoise's Millions Now Living Will Never Die a little too closely to their hearts
column2: Four Tet hinted at a far wider range of listening happening behind the scenes. All four of these releases came out in the span of a year
column3: but an evolutionary arc emerges over their collected two-hour runtime. Still
column4: there's a lack of clarity
column5: with only subtle allusions to the vision that would ultimately take Hebden out of the small circles he was running in during this era. If that sounds a little harsh
column6: it's a fault he's acutely aware of
column7: explaining in an interview last year that his pre-Rounds work ""just sounds like I've heard some records that are really cool.""

column1: Although Hebden is aware of his earlier shortcomings
column2: he's clearly not intent on shying away from them completely. His Bandcamp page in its current state simply contains these four releases plus a series of images
column3: one of which features a Spotify page compressed and turned upside-down. Needless to say
column4: most of Hebden's music is not available on the service at time of writing. Objections to streaming media aside
column5: what we get here are a series of rough sketches that highlight Hebden's obsessions over a particular period. There are trappings of the time
column6: including shades of trip-hop and the cut-up collage of DJ Shadow
column7: bombastic drum sounds that bear echoes of big beat
column8: and elements of the post-rock grooves Hebden was practicing elsewhere.

column1: These records work as a sort of time capsule. There's a dip into the post-dub sound of the shortlasting illbient sub-genre on the first part of ""Thirtysixtwentyfive""
column2: and it's not a stretch to imagine Hebden coming across artists such as DJ Olive
column3: Doug Scharin
column4: and Techno Animal during his investigations into the outer reaches of post-rock. He also touches on jazz
column5: with a barrage of sax and drum samples providing a neat loop around to Hebden's future collaborations with drummer Steve Reid. The sense of struggle is palpable at times
column6: indicating someone with a wide open mind who knows where he wants to go but falling just short somewhere between conception and execution.

column1: It's striking just how uneven this material can be
column2: with little pockets of inspiration surfacing amid a tangle of material that shows an artist learning his trade. The tranquil middle section of ""Fume"" from the Misnomer EP has some of the itchy ambience and crisp beats that would become a hallmark of Hebden's later work. But over its 10 minute runtime it also works in hackneyed hip-hop samples and screaming sax that doesn't sit well in the mix
column3: ultimately resembling a junior What Does Your Soul Look Like without the same sense of wild exploration. There are other tracks that attempt to pull off the same kind of epic journey-into-sound feel here
column4: but the feeling is of an artist interested in musical transportation without fully having the skills to get there yet.

column1: Hebden's jazz impulses solidify into some of the most satisfying tracks here
column2: notably on ""Chiron"" from Dialogue
column3: which builds off a drum lift from the much-sampled Bernard Purdie
column4: pushing it into a tranquil place that's utterly meditative by its close. Similarly
column5: ""Aying"" from Misnomer (which was tacked on as a bonus cut on the CD version of Dialogue) works as a wonky pile-up of saxophone riffs and jazzy drum fills
column6: gaining a drunken stride that resembles little Hebden has done before or since. It's noticeable that those two tracks are among the shortest over these four releases
column7: with Hebden able to reach greater points of revelation when he got sharper with his editing. He's rarely ventured over the 10-minute mark in his subsequent output; in contrast
column8: the longest track here (""Thirtysixtwentyfive (Part 1)"") last for almost 20 minutes.

column1: The collection signs off with ""Glasshead"" from 1999
column2: which finds a greater sense of purpose than Hebden's prior long-groove efforts. Over 11 minutes he keeps within a narrow frame of sound instead of taking pointless deviations into tiny cul-de-sacs
column3: most of which fit into his self-diagnosed tendency of merely aping other records he liked at the time. ""Glashead"" is far from his best material
column4: but it does hint at a way forward
column5: where all the clutter is stripped from his music
column6: in turn helping to bring out the refinement in his work. Hebden's use of space in Rounds is key to its success. The acres of room between beats in ""Unspoken""
column7: or the way ""Hands"" beautifully drifts into dying embers of glazy electronics
column8: are vital parts of that album. These tracks reflect someone with the ability to deconstruct music history
column9:
but yet to find the fantastical place that talent would take him.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20141/homepage_large.15ed2bae.jpg|Ghettoville|28985.0|Actress|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Werk Discs']|2014-01-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:38.008241|"

After nearly a decade of cryptic transmissions
column3: Darren Cunningham
column4: aka Actress
column5: is packing it in. He's doing this both professionally—alluding to the ""conclusion of the Actress image"" as well as retirement—and artistically. Ghettoville
column6: his fourth album
column7: is a scorched hard drive
column8: a dour drone record that takes his fascinations—Detroit techno
column9: Chicago ghetto house
column10: rap—and repeatedly kicks them in the ribs. This was a calculated move. The album arrived with a press release that sounded roughly like Sarah Connor's opening monologue from Terminator 2: ""The machines have turned to stone
column11: data reads like an obituary to its user."" After three slew-footing albums that played Jenga with established genre rules
column12: Ghettoville is content to wallow in the ruins of the musics its predecessors so fascinatingly deconstructed.

column1: It's difficult to tell how much of Cunningham's end-times blather is bullshit. He's a savvy marketer—he famously referred to Splazsh as ""R&B concrète""—and way funnier than his high-art-golden-boy reputation would lead you to believe. (A recent interview describes Cunningham as lifting up ""a hefty glass of cognac and look[ing] through it at the flames""; let no one accuse this man of not knowing exactly what he's doing.) But if Cunningham is bluffing
column2: the opener ""Forgiven"" is one hell of a poker face. Seven minutes of plodding
column3: gray loops
column4: ""Forgiven"" refuses to pick its feet off the ground
column5: pouting like a child protesting bedtime by moving as slowly as possible. Lacking any hidden alleys or tricky variations
column6: the track ensures that anyone who hears the remainder of Ghettoville really wants to hear it.

column1: Ghettoville's darker
column2: nastier tone is its defining trait
column3: but the album's lack of dynamism is what's truly alarming. Never before has Cunningham built his tracks out of so few ideas
column4: and never before have those ideas seemed so barefaced and plain. The lumpen funk bassline of ""Rims"" recalls Excepter's more staid moments. ""Towers""
column5: featuring a slow
column6: pulsing kick drum and a single
column7: distorted tone played on-beat
column8: is simple and inelegant. ""Time"" plays like a parody of experimental music: six minutes—and it feels like double that—of wintry stasis interrupted by a flat
column9: lifeless voice repeating the track title. It's probably a joke
column10: the type of musical prank Cunningham has laced his albums with in the past
column11: but it's one performed at our expense.

column1: Ghettoville frustrates most when Cunningham offers the type of transfixing delights he's known for. ""Birdcage"" is a taut piece that allows a flute-like melody to worm in and out of a baffling rhythmic stew. ""Gaze"" proves Cunningham hasn't lost touch with the dance floor
column2: as a sweet
column3: light synth pad ushers along a grimy piano riff and a pattering house rhythm. The deranged mumble that passes for a melody on ""Contagious"" is the one thing sickly enough to justify Cunningham's rhetoric. The spectacular closer ""Rule"" dices MC chatter into an undeniable earworm and places it on a bed of grubby organ chords; it stands as Cunningham's finest and most complete reworking of hip-hop.

column1: Cunningham's work has always offered a crucial interactive component
column2: giving listeners the opportunity to unpack the origins of his musical baubles. If you failed
column3: or just weren't up for it
column4: you were still left with something pleasantly cryptic. Ghettoville's leaden
column5: idle tracks reject this interaction
column6: so you're forced to take Cunningham at his word: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/features/update/9310-actress/"">we live in a brittle
column7: addicted world
column8: and this is what a brittle
column9: addicted world sounds like. Ghettoville is a lecture
column10: at least inasmuch as a largely beatless
column11: voiceless work can be. Self-contained
column12: Ghettoville refuses to commune with anything but itself
column13: including the broken and disadvantaged world it purports to represent. Cunningham's perplexing persona has always been overshadowed by his ability to confound us with his records; Ghettoville
column14: disappointingly
column15:
shifts that balance.
