column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20101/homepage_large.dce6ff7c.jpg|Innocence|27743.0|Pontiak|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2014-01-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:38.601420|"

Blue Ridge brothers Pontiak made it through 2013 without a new record
column2: a first for the band since their 2005 debut. The year off not only gave overtaxed fans a chance to replenish their bank accounts
column3: it allowed the hard-working Carney boys a little time to consider their next move. Though by no means a ""comeback"" record
column4: their latest
column5: Innocence
column6: does have a whiff of rejuvenation about it. Innocence serves up to-the-point southern-tinged hard-rock without one iota of pretense; you could call it the most accessible Pontiak record to date
column7:
and the Carneys would be inclined to agree.

In Pontiak's case
column8: however
column9: accessibility leads them down a limited path. As Grayson Currin wrote in his review of 2009's Maker
column10: Pontiak do well by ""bending elemental rock'n'roll into warped shapes… [while] putting the song at the center of the conquest."" Pontiak's always been at their best when they're not just kicking out the jams
column11: but by weirding them up
column12: bringing their exploratory tendencies to bear on their amp-destroying sideburns-and-beer-runs riffage. Jamming 11 songs into barely half an hour
column13: the unusually compact Innocence doesn't give Pontiak much chance to stretch out. Trading off between rowdy
column14: riff-crazy
column15: tricked-out-Astrovan rockers and ambling
column16: lighter-flicking balladry
column17: Innocence is a classic Friday night ridearound record. But
column18: with one too many momentum-killing ballads and a riff or two that plod as much as they push
column19: the leaner
column20:
occasionally meaner Innocence finds the once-daring Pontiak a couple bongloads shy of a breakthrough.

Innocence's opening trio is
column21: by some distance
column22: its finest stretch. The title track is a smoker
column25: axis-shifting grove that piledrives its way directly through your skull. After a couple well-earned ""woos
column26: ""Lack Lustre Rush"" breaks into a snarly
column27: Southern-fried riff equally suitable for radio and your next blunt ride. A searing space-rocker in the Hawkwind tradition
column29: built around long-trail afterburner vocals and a choppy
column30: out-of-nowhere solo. These songs just sound good: taut
column33: bite-sized brawlers. If only the same could be said of the next three songs: organ-driven sidewinder ""It's the Greatest
column35: and brothers-in-arms shuffler ""Wildfires"". Taken on their own
column37: the kind of thing that have been peppering hard-rock records like Innocence for a good four decades now. Taken together
column39: they carve out a considerable mid-LP crater
column40:
sapping any and all momentum built by Innocence's hard-driving opening in a fashion it never quite recovers from.

Mercifully
column41: Innocence's back half does what it can to right the wrongs of its strangely sequenced opening run. Though the proggy ""Shining"" stumbles a bit before finding its groove
column42: most everything else—the Sabbath-conjuring ""Surrounded by Diamonds
column44: and the skull-splitting closer ""We've Got It Wrong""—hits the mark. Still
column45: to get all the way to ""Wrong
column46: you'll have to drag yourself through the dreary ""Darkness is Coming""
column48: oversung go-nowhere energy-drainer that never quite seems to settle on a hook. Without these stragglers
column49: Innocence would be wall-to-wall riffage. But these slower songs aren't just mellow
column51: and their inclusion leaves Innocence feeling lopsided
column52:
a oft-killer rock record with nasty balladry habit.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20149/homepage_large.1b970532.jpg|Wedding Bells EP|30860.0|Cashmere Cat|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['LuckyMe']|2014-01-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:39.226630|"

Cashmere Cat's 2012 EP Mirror Maru meant big things for producer Magnus August Høiberg—it's just that one of those big things was the opportunity to be yet another argument starter regarding what bass music/pop/R&B crossover is actually supposed to accomplish. The star track seems clear enough: remix headliner stars like Lana Del Rey and 2 Chainz
column2: get in the good graces/setlist rotation of Hudson Mohawke and Diplo
column3: cop one of those coveted Grand Theft Auto soundtrack slots
column4: and let the buzz build with the same simmering groundswell that his beats possess. His remixes were fine recontextualizations
column5: supplanting the faster/bigger/now structure of the originals' don't-touch-that-dial immediacy with more pillowy melodies and gentler crests. (And sometimes vice-versa.) Once his handiness with the soft-touch approach to bass music became apparent on Mirror Maru
column6: the inevitable questions followed: is he supposed to be the antidote to pop's love affair with post-rave maximalism? A trendy yet point-missing interloper in R&B's space-soul continuum? Just another in a long line of young artists who's going to have to figure out how to evolve in a spotlight?

column1: All that might reveal itself in time
column2: but meanwhile there's another EP to take in. And Wedding Bells ramps up the twinkly
column3: diaphanous
column4: twee little elements in his arsenal—assuming things like fluttery harp glissandos and shivering-puppy vibes can actually be ramped up instead of
column5: I don't know
column6: squeezed out
column7: like some sparkly novelty toothpaste for kids. The sparse
column8: wistful pianos and juddering
column9: mechanically-jointed percussive elements of Mirror Maru were never all that rough-edged or aggro
column10: but the blissed-out vibes have lapsed into a sighing
column11: glassy-eyed stupor with all signs of intensity held back or just outright muted. Too often the beat plinks instead of thumps
column12: and in the moments where it's given free reign to burst out and get things moving it's countered by synthesized permutations of pan pipes (“Wedding Bells”) or toy pianos (“Pearls”). Dance music doesn't need to be a bow-throwing
column13: sweat-flinging mosh-pit soundtrack
column14: but it's hard to overcome the dissonance between heavy bass and fragile melody
column15: even when it's worth trying. Would things be any better if Owl City copped his style off Girl Unit instead of the Postal Service? Does that question even need answering?

column1: Fortunately
column2: there's still a fundamental groove backing up Cashmere Cat's stop-start dynamics and his wiseass tendency to turn bass drops into safe parachute landings. His percussive sounds—supple and rattling like drumlines
column3: unafraid to let kicks run free—keep Wedding Bells engaging at those times when it's not merely distracting. And there are still stretches of head-tilting weirdness. The borderline non-verbal vocals in “With Me” and “Rice Rain” are manipulated into quavering swoops of synthesized
column4: inhuman unreality to eerie effect. And when those robot-pixie chirps in that latter track are backed up with a healthy dose of bass/snare/clap buildups and breakdowns
column5: that pushes it into surreally giddy turf. Its ultimate destiny seems to be the soundtrack for an Adventure Time dance party.

column1: But aside from its appropriate feel for a good time get-down in a surprisingly cheerful cartoon post-apocalypse
column2: it's hard to get any real emotional connection from these cuts. Balancing precious
column3: twee cheerfulness and dancefloor-blowout impact is tricky enough when the 4/4 bears down on you constantly. When it slips in and out of rhythmic phase
column4: building up to crests that aren't much higher than the valleys
column5: it has all the disorienting chaos of the most pro forma Skrillexian drop without its chemical-floodgate jolt. So the melodies
column6: whether legitimately stirring or just “pretty” in scare quotes
column7: cause more agitation than elation. If this is the sound of an artist's early phase breaking itself apart
column8:
Cashmere Cat definitely has it in him to build the debris back into something deeper and weirder.

Just as rock'n'roll has its shadow canon
column2: the Trout Mask Replicas and SMiLEs that offset the Revolvers and Blonde on Blondes
column3: extreme metal has its own alternate-universe hall of fame. Some especially brilliant specimens
column4: like Gorguts' Obscura
column5: attain cult-classic status via underground word-of-mouth; other fascinating curios—Confessor's Condemned
column6: Ved Buens Ende's Written in Waters—hang in limbo
column7: championed by a few but unknown outside the underground.

column1: Nespithe
column2: the sole LP by Finland's Demilich (pronounced ""demi-lick"")
column3: is one of the latter. It's unmistakably a death-metal record
column4: but compared to what else hit the market around the time of its 1993 release—the year death metal went major label via Morbid Angel's bar-raising Covenant
column5: and a deal between Earache and Columbia that yielded landmarks such as Carcass's Heartwork and Entombed's Wolverine Blues—the record's match of labyrinthine
column6: riff-drunk composition and burp-like vocals registers as outsider art. Even stacked up against fellow Finnish groups Convulse and Demigod
column7: each of whom issued potent debuts filled with relatively orthodox death metal in 92
column8: Nespithe sounds like the work of brainiac obsessives.

column1: Fittingly
column2: Nespithe has a convoluted posthumous history. Several different labels have reissued the album over the years—most recently Spain's Xtreem Music
column3: in 09—and vocalist-guitarist Antti Boman continues to host the album as a free download on his Demilich website. So what's special about 20th Adversary of Emptiness
column4: a new 3-LP/2-CD retrospective package that includes Nespithe as its centerpiece? First
column5: thanks to a new remastering job
column6: the album sounds fuller and clearer than it ever has—a key improvement
column7: given the head-spinning nature of the songs themselves. Second
column8: the package tacks on everything else Demilich ever recorded—not only pre-Nespithe demos but three unissued tracks from a 2006 reunion—along with beautifully grotesque new cover by original Nespithe artist Turkka Rantanen
column9: a comprehensive interview with Boman
column10: and his annotated lyrics. In short
column11: the package is an exemplary geek-out
column12: the perfect epitaph for a band as alien as Demilich.

column1: Nespithe has lost none of its esoteric allure. Boman's vocals are the first element that leaps out. Unlike the traditional throaty death-metal growl
column2: his delivery seems to originate in his stomach. His tone is absurdly deep but also oddly hollow
column3: almost gaseous. Given Boman's lyrical predilections—the songs are filled with accounts of mastication
column4: vomiting
column5: and putrefaction—it's not hard to imagine him taking perverse pride in sounding like a master belcher. His penchant for anagrams (the album title unscrambles to ""the spine""—or ""the penis
column6: if you take a tongue-in-cheek 20th Adversary annotation at its word) and outlandish phrasing (sample song title: ""The Sixteenth Six-Tooth Son of Fourteen Four-Regional Dimensions (Still Unnamed)"") only add to the disorientation.

column1: But what's most impressive about Nespithe is the the way the music itself lives up to these attention-grabbing surface features. Demilich was a band obsessed with riffs
column2: and the maximal deployment thereof; they valued crushing groove as much as relentless complexity. It's telling that Nespithe has its own supercut on YouTube: The album overflows with thorny
column3: blink-and-you-miss-'em gems: a jagged
column4: dazzlingly precise stomp at 1:35 in ""Inherited Bowel Levitation—Reduced Without Any Effort""; the aggro math-rock workout that erupts at the :45 mark of ""(Within) the Chamber of Whispering Eyes""; the astonishing
column5: rhythmic-obstacle-course entirety of the wordless ""Erecshyrinol"" (""no lyrics here"").

column1: Given the intricacy of the material
column2: it's a marvel that Nespithe rarely sounds frantic. The band clearly drilled the songs until they could let their performances breathe. Drummer Mikko Virnes sounds preternaturally composed and firmly in the pocket amid the songs' extreme-prog contortions; Boman
column3: fellow six-stringer Aki Hytönen
column4: and bassist Ville Koistinen synchronize in high-wire acrobatics or fan out in 80s-style attack formations when one of the guitarists steps up for a tasteful lead or rare solo. Without this level of virtuosity
column5: which aligns Demilich with tech-minded contemporaries such as Death and Atheist
column6: Nespithe could have been a frustrating slog.

column1: Another standout feature of Nespithe is its tenuous relationship to death metal. Blastbeats crop up frequently
column2: but angular
column3: brain-bending groove is clearly the band's wheelhouse. In that sense
column4: they seem more closely aligned with the motley progressive-metal/post-hardcore underground of the mid-80s through early 90s than with their any of their subgenre contemporaries. (A telling photo in the liner notes depicts a Demilich T-shirt emblazoned with the slogan ""Forget Sweden!!
column5: signifying that the band felt little kinship with the scene that spawned giants such as Entombed and Dismember.) Nespithe brings to mind Voivod at their proggy peak
column6: American math-rock outliers such as Breadwinner
column7: even the surgically precise morse-code chug of Ozma-era Melvins. As with those bands
column8: Demilich valued insular invention over extremity for its own sake.

column1: Most listeners who catch the Nespithe bug likely end up lamenting the lack of a follow-up. In that regard
column2: 20th Adversary both satisfies fans' curiosity and puts it to rest. The 2006 tracks (one newly written song and two old ones the band never got around to recording) make for compelling bonus material. The excellent new offering
column3: ""The Faces Right Below the Skin of the Earth""
column4: affords the chance to hear the Nespithe aesthetic souped up with modern production values. Contrast this with the wealth of appealingly raw-sounding demo tracks
column5: which illustrate how the band's signature style was in evidence from their infancy
column6: juxtaposed with more primitive death-metal impulses.

column1: Still
column2: the pre- and post-Nesphite tracks support Boman's conviction
column3: reiterated in the interview included here
column4: that another Demilich album might have been superfluous. Above all
column5: 20th Adversary is a tribute to the definitiveness of Nespithe. Demilich's crazed single-mindedenss—their drive to do this one thing really
column6: really well—couldn't be captured better than it was on their sole LP
column7: which retains its power to baffle
column8: enthrall and
column9: yes
column10: exhaust. The music's eccentricity is both its greatest strength and its most obvious limitation. You don't remember songs so much as segments
column11: sensations—the vigor and meticulousness of the whole package. Would a wealth of new
column12: similarly overwhelming music really enhance the Demilich experience?

column1: On the other hand
column2: 20th Adversary's liner notes and interview do just that
column3: mainly due to the window they afford into the character of Boman
column4: a classic deadpan wit. Asked how he arrived at his signature vocal style
column5: he quips
column6: ""So
column7: sometimes things just happen and mankind gets something beautiful to cherish
column8: like my vivid vocals."" Annotating the lyrics for ""(Within) the Chamber of Whispering Eyes""
column9: he writes
column10: ""No
column11: I didn't know the slang meaning of 'whispering eye' back then""; and of his first effort as a lyricist
column12: ""The Uncontrollable Regret of Rotting Flesh""
column13: he says
column14: ""My good friend
column15: Leo Tolstoy
column16: saw them first… and took some inspiration from them to War and Peace."" Boman's kidding aside
column17: 20th Adversary serves as a reminder that the frontman possessed a Lovecraftian gift for dreaming up images of fantastical horror—most memorably
column18: the innocent-seeming backyard ""white stain"" in ""…And You'll Remain… (in Pieces in Nothingness)""
column19: which turns out to be an interdimensional portal.

column1: So will 20th Adversary raise the profile of Nespithe
column2: vault it into the realm of consensus cult classics such as Obscura? It's certainly a possibility
column3: given how convincingly the music speaks for itself. In the larger death-metal narrative
column4: though
column5: Demilich will probably never be more than a bizarre bit player—and one gets the sense that the band is perfectly okay with that. To those who vibrate on its weird wavelength
column6: Nespithe remains a godsend; for them
column7: 20th Adversary is a priceless keepsake. For everyone else
column8:
it's an invitation into one of death metal's most ornate and unforgettable niches.

Dum Dum Girls mastermind Dee Dee has been flirting with
column3: and stepping tentatively back from
column4: full-fledged stardom ever since she introduced herself to us. She has songwriting chops and charisma that dwarf her indie-pop Class of 09-10 peers
column5: and when it all locks together she is capable of stopping time: ""Lord Knows""
column6: from her 2012 EP End of Daze was dramatic enough to make a stroll to the kitchen feel like riding a burning motorcycle off a cliff
column7: and her cover of Strawberry Switchblade's ""Trees and Flowers"" was the sultriest that crippling agoraphobia has ever sounded.

column1: However
column2: she's never made the bold
column3: arresting full-length her EPs tease at. Her new album
column4: Too True
column5: is well-crafted
column6: well-written
column7: and immaculate-sounding
column8: but it's a middle-distance affair
column9: exploring some of the same starry skies that Frankie Rose's last two LPs flitted about in. The songs that let her dip into her dusky lower register raise the biggest goosebumps—mid-tempo ballads like ""Are You Okay""
column10: ""Too True""
column11: ""Trouble Is My Name"". At this level
column12: she can settle into the unfurling
column13: golden lines of melancholy and ache she specializes in
column14: the kind that don't depend on lyrics or context to communicate themselves to you.

column1: Dee Dee's greatest gifts are in sound; her voice
column2: her understanding of how classic pop-rock feels. ""What a vivid sound/ What a vivid sound"" goes the chorus to ""Little Minx"". She sings about ""a lavender haze"" on ""Are You Okay""
column3: which is an apt enough description of her records. Too True
column4: at least obliquely
column5: is a record about sound itself
column6: and the record is sparkling and beautiful
column7: a glittering glaze of guitars and keyboards.

column1: Her songs rarely feel like they're about much
column2: except the other great songs that touch on the same topics
column3: but they are excellent studies. Savoring the details of her craftsmanship is still a pleasure—the middle eight of ""Too True""
column4: the shifts from minor to major in ""In the Wake of You"". ""Too True""'s diaphanous sigh of a chorus and weightless synths sound like they could have come from the last Pains of Being Pure At Heart record
column5: except she double-tracks her vocals into a near-subliminal choir of backing vocals
column6: a touch that feels uniquely Dee Dee. She cares about effort
column7: something that pokes through in one of the only personal-feeling lyrics on the record: ""Why be good?/ Be beautiful and sad/ It's all you've ever had
column8: she sings on ""Evil Blooms"".

column1: She'd rather be good. She could be great
column2: though
column3: and she hasn't found her way there. ""Rimbaud Eyes"" is not a terribly euphonious phrase
column4: and the way she sings it
column5: which sounds more like ""Bloomberg Eyes""
column6: highlights the clunk of the phrasing. The song itself is generic
column7: a driving pop-rocker with no stamp on it to distinguish it as Dee Dee's
column8: or anyone's.

column1: The final track
column2: ""Trouble Is My Name""
column3: features one of her favorite sounds
column4: the fuzzy
column5: watery echo pedal strum of ""Crimson and Clover"". She used it on End of Daze's ""Lord Knows""
column6: where it had a similar eerie power
column7: and it works just as well here. The lyrics are boilerplate
column8: cake toppings—""And you said there was nothing you could do to make your bad turn good""—but they ring like prophecy in her mouth. There are clichés
column9: and there are exalted clichés
column10: and Dee Dee at her best reminds you of this distinction. If she wanted it
column11:
she seems to have the potential to knock out a professional world-beater like the HAIM record. But maybe she's happier in the haze.

column3: underground rap has gone through a number of seismic stylistic movements. A term like “cloud rap” that was an early marker for rappers like Kitty
column4: Main Attrakionz
column5: and even A$AP Rocky already feels dated from a bygone era of 2011. “Hipster rap
column6: ” a similarly small moment used to describe artists as varied as Theophilus London and Das Racist
column7: was quickly forgotten as rappers fought back against the term or simply reinvented themselves to avoid such genre pigeonholing. Cities Aviv
column8: a rapper from Memphis
column9: has never received such a snappy descriptor for his rap-but-not-quite-always-rap
column10: style. Not embraced by the fashion world enough to be “hipster rap” and not within the correct Tumblr reblog circles to fall into “cloud rap
column11: ” he’s existed within his own post-internet lane.

column1: Back in 2011 when Cities Aviv started getting press his music was chiller and more laconic
column2: and lacked the distorted bite that has since taken over his music. A review here of Cities Aviv’s previous release commented that Black Pleasures: “sounds it's angling for a deal with Pendu Sounds or Captured Tracks.” His latest album Come to Life shows that this particular post-punk angularity remains in Cities Aviv’s sonic DNA
column3: as the album continues to embrace projective shouting and aggressive production. The opening track starts with harsh distortion makes it is clear that this abrasive aesthetic has only grown more ingrained within Cities Aviv’s music over the last couple of years.

column1: The first single from Come to Life
column2: “URL IRL”
column3: keeps Cities Aviv’s distorted shouts
column4: but the 1980s styled bounce of the track
column5: makes it one of the most immediate songs since his Modest Mouse-sampling track “Float On”. The upfront nature of his vocals fits closer to his live show
column6: which even with mellower material of 2011’s Digital Lows was done with the intensity of rock set
column7: far from just a rapper just rapping over their own pre-recorded vocals. The rest of the album isn’t as straightforward as ""URL IRL""
column8: but at this point Cities Aviv isn’t a performer on record interested in so recognizable hooks; instead
column9: he enjoys hearing how electronics mash with his own vocals. So even when there's an old dial-up modem on “(View 180) Picture Me Gone” or a drum'n'bass break on “Vibrations”
column10: nothing sounds out of place. That references to old internet technology and titles like “URL IRL” and “CTL1” shows Cities Aviv connecting digital dots and hashing through how it affects everyday life.

column1: In 2012 a rapper
column2: more interested in other forms of vocal projections beyond rapping—let’s just ignore Waka Flocka Flame and DMX for a second—might have been perplexing. But in 2014 the rest of the rap community has finally caught up. The industrial clash and shout-rap of Kanye West’s Yeezus was quickly cited to have come from Death Grips
column3: but that overlooked a cluster of lesser-known rappers that’ve spent the last few years infusing hardcore punk with rap ideas. Performers like B L A C K I E
column4: Antwon
column5: Abdu Ali (who appears on the track here “CTL1”
column6: talking about his own personal meaning of album title’s “come to life”)
column7: and Cities Aviv all have been melding a very B L A C K P U N K aesthetic within rap trappings. They’re rappers only in so far as a being black dude with a microphone and a backing track must be a rapper
column8: instead of maybe being a starting point for their own original style of music. Come to Life shows Cities Aviv putting post-punk
column9: Oneontrix Point Never-like samples (“Realms”)
column10:
and even a little bit of rap into one holistically new blend.

It’s sort of disappointing that Camera Obscura’s Tracyanne Campbell never became much of an ""It Girl
column3: musically speaking. When Amber Papini surfaced a couple years back with her Brooklyn-based trio Hospitality
column4: it felt like there was another feminine voice working in the same modern-twee vein as Campbell. But it was more than that tidy aesthetic that made Hospitality’s 2012 self-titled debut stand out
column5: so much so that they’ve seemingly abandoned the simplicity on their sophomore LP
column6: Trouble.

column1: You can’t blame a band for having aspirations beyond catchy indie-pop about the plight of the 20-something
column2: for moving beyond the lyrical equivalent of the Girls pilot. To be critically applauded for ephemeral toe-tapping must be a frustrating experience for an ex-Ivy Leaguer like Papini; it’s inspired awfully ambitious work in Vampire Weekend
column3: after all. On their debut
column4: however
column5: Hospitality exhibited more cleverness lyrically than cussing over punctuation or chronicling campus life. They were underrated
column6: skill-wise
column7: upon their debut
column8: while simultaneously being touted as a ""band to watch.""

column1: The result is a follow-up that makes a point of showing its listeners the difference between ""beautiful"" and ""cute."" There are moments of real beauty on Trouble: A 90-second trumpet feature that soars brightly over an acoustic guitar line that rises and falls visibly like a burly man’s chest (“Sunship”)
column2: or the sort of instrumental spawned more by a willingness to let things meander than by technical ability (“Sullivan”). On the latter
column3: cymbals crash as if in slow motion
column4: pianos pipe up at just the right spots
column5: Papini’s voice croons
column6: and guitar lines manifest out of thin air. The whole thing moves in and out as effortlessly as taking a breath
column7: whereas other parts of this album are distinctly not easy. “I Miss Your Bones” recalls the squirmy riffs of Television
column8: and as cool as toughness looks on Hospitality
column9: they’ve only reached that place following extensive live touring as a rock band.

column1: There are a few fun
column2: poppier songs here
column3: too. The appropriately-titled “It’s Not Serious” is a welcome respite to the crescendoes and the instrumental wing-spreading abundant on Trouble. Here’s where we get a taste of that Tracyanne Campbell thing
column4: just a hint of life in a time gone by. But unlike Campbell
column5: Papini’s filling in her sharp observations with recycled imagery
column6: singing here of photographs stashed under the mattress and waiting by the telephone for a guy to call. A Brill Building piano line gives the track a sense of time and place
column7: a façade that’s smashed by “Last Words”
column8: a mostly instrumental song more in line with the saxalicious closer on the most recent Bon Iver album than a Phil Spector production. It’s punctuated with 80s-style synths
column9: another prominent addition to Hospitality’s overall sound. Sometimes
column10: like on “Last Words”
column11: it goes a little too far into dated territory
column12: but in general the variety is a welcome addition.

column1: Trouble covers a lot of ground musically
column2: moving through decades and subgenres of pop and rock with each track. But those who listen closely will find a few consistent points of imagery that loosely connect the work: locks and keys
column3: bodies of water
column4: and the telephone. These are things that both connect and separate us from those we love
column5: but for Papini
column6:
the vulnerability that accompanies either letting people in or falling apart without them is the real takeaway.

Our world is an impossibly and perhaps unnecessarily connected one
column2: a place where household cats have Instagram feeds and most details of a life turn up after a deep Googling. No matter how much one attempts to stay off the grid
column3: eventually something comes up. For example: The second page of Google results for “Morgan Delt” includes a character page for Morgan Delt
column4: the protagonist of an obscure 1966 Vanessa Redgrave-starring film called Morgan—A Suitable Case of Treatment. Wikipedia describes him as “a failed irresponsible leftist artist” who’s obsessed with Karl Marx and gorillas; a characteristic quote from IMDB is something like
column5: “[places skeleton on bed] Man is born to sorrow…”

column1: If this is not California native Morgan Delt’s chosen pseudonym
column2: it’s awfully telling of an interesting upbringing. He’s a homegrown musician whose debut self-titled album (which includes much of an earlier limited-edition cassette release) evades convenient pigeonholing. There’s the deal with the name
column3: and then there's this: In one of the few interviews with Delt
column4: the interviewer asks him to explain a song called ""Barbarian Kings"". ""I did have a story in mind with that song
column5: he responds. ""I don't want to say too much about it though because what people imagine is usually more interesting. Your version is better!""

column1: So
column2: let's go ahead and imagine. In this album it’s easy to hear a band like the Byrds
column3: who dabbled with jingle-jangle proto-power pop
column4: fuzzed out martian rock
column5: genteel country lament
column6: and more during a five-year stretch in which members were swapped in and out depending on the mood. Rather than split time between such distinct states
column7: Delt takes his armloads of sources—beyond the Byrds
column8: you might describe the field of influence as sunny and stoned—and blends them into a variegated
column9: melted mess. The result is a carefully built and naturalistic mosaic—you can hear the influences dissolving into each other even as the resulting sounds are crisp and memorable
column10: rather than the half-baked invention of someone with a killer record collection. Listen to the taped-together percussion on opener ""Make My Grey Brain Green""
column11: which rides a scratchy bass line and flowers into something like the moment when Dorothy's black-and-white world goes RGB. There's the Morricone-meets-Jodorowsky acid drone of ""Barbarian Kings""
column12: the cyclical wobble of “Little Zombies”
column13: the way ""Chakra Sharks"" rattles and crashes through a hornet’s nest of guitars into a wailing refrain of ""Bye bye
column14: farewell."" Throughout the album there’s a heightened
column15: eerie quality to his vocals; the feeling is something like an asylum patient waving to a car as it recedes over the horizon.

column1: That's what I hear
column2: at least. The whole album is so impressionistic and free-floating that you'll likely hear something else
column3: as Delt intended. Projecting where he might go from here
column4: it's not difficult to think of a band like Tame Impala
column5: who temper spacey sprawl with more accessible songwriting. Future development doesn't have to be the point
column6: of course; this album <span>is fully-formed from first listen and begs return trips. There's another interaction from that interview that seems relevant: Asked if he believes in God
column7: Delt simply replies
column8: ""No."" If the faithless create their own meaning rather than wait for divine guidance
column9: consider this an album that forces you to create your own attachments and associations. Even so
column10: the artist is always present
column11: elevating Morgan Delt from a wispy whatever into a clear statement of intent: It might not be obvious what you're supposed to hear
column12:
but you're going to hear something.

Currently available as a three-way release between Forcefield Records
column4: Inherent Records
column5: and Anti-Corporate Records
column6: the Knoxville
column7: Tenn.
column8: trio Argentinum Astrum's second full-length
column9: Malleus Maleficarum
column10: is the band’s first studio outing since 2008’s self-titled LP. Patience is a virtue
column11: but that’s about the only unsullied thing about this mangy beast of a recording: Argentinum Astrum have been letting this material ferment for several years now

column14: potent concoction.

column1: The three songs here aim to bridge the gap between doom and black metal
column2: and come awfully close on track one. “I” ambles in with a long
column3: rainy intro
column4: sinking into sludgy Graves At Sea territory out of nowhere before falling into lockstep with correspondingly depraved acts like Dragged Into Sunlight and Lord Mantis. It feels like an older song
column5: written before its creators decided to stretch their legs and try their hand at something different. It’s a strange way to structure an album
column6: but Argentinum Astrum have always shown their disdain for convention. Soon
column7: the great heaving gasps of sludge on “I” collapse onto the brittle minor chords and anguished howls in the twin black metal pieces that complete the recording.

column1: There’s always been a solid black metal component to Argentinum Astrum
column2: but on “II” and “III
column3: ” it takes over completely. “II” is all primal intensity that conjures up associations with Fell Voices (were said Californians unconcerned with the harmonic textures that this band disregard as shimmery melodic frippery)
column4: and its successor follows suit. The lead guitar melodies come crackling with a frenetic melodicism that smacks of Cascadian influence as well as Scandinavian flair
column5: swerving sharply towards an ultimately more abrasive sound. By hammering caustic Second Wave tremolo into the more atmospheric riffs
column6: Argentinum Astrum preserve their ferocity without capitulating to boring
column7: rote grimness. Malleus Maleficarum loses points for originality
column8: but makes up for it in execution.

column1: This “best of both world” approach keeps their take on an age-old tradition fresh and compelling
column2: but not too clean: the production values are subterranean
column3: blanketing the recording in a thick miasma of distortion and soot. It’s a DIY jobbie through and through
column4: but that lack of polish is exactly what these songs cry out for. Malleus Maleficarum’ sounds far more vital choking on ash than blinking glassily through squeaky-clean guitar tones. Some things just work better when they’re dirty; after all
column5: you wouldn’t hand Andy Sneap a pile of Grave Upheaval demos to polish. Argentinum Astrum know their strengths as well as their weaknesses
column6:
and this album is an apt representation of both.

It’s been easy to disagree about the fluid and often conflicting ideology of Against Me! over the years. They were born to the Gainesville
column3: Fla.
column4: scene as anarcho-punks
column5: wearing black and fully DIY; NOFX's Fat Mike offered the band some money and off they went to his Fat Wreck label
column6: a farm league for the majors where bands could slug Bro Hymns to the kids at Warped Tour. Then Sire offered them even more money so they went up to a major
column7: effectively jettisoning any remaining Reinventing Axl Rose ideologues. And finally in 2010
column8: lead singer Laura Jane Grace (who was then known as Tom Gabel) sang her mea culpa/kiss-off to all those who cried “sell outs
column9: ” to those who would go to Against Me! shows and stand there with a middle finger in the air in silent protest wearing studded vests and liberty spikes. She sang on “I Was a Teenage Anarchist” with her own middle finger to the crowd: “You want me to surrender my identity/ I was a teenage anarchist/ The revolution was a lie.”

column1: But identity is a different thing entirely—it's what houses ideology
column2: where ideology goes to gather agency and dig roots. In a rare act
column3: Laura Jane Grace and Against Me! draw a hard line between these concepts with their sixth studio album Transgender Dysphoria Blues. It’s almost kismet for a band who’s been lambasted for not committing to their ideologies to make an album about a real identity crisis. Grace came out as transgender in 2012
column4: and started writing these songs around that period. They were built out from raw acoustic folk punk into 10 songs of slapdash glam punk that carry great urgency
column5: even those songs that don’t directly concern Grace’s journey. She makes all that cis punk sound limp in comparison.

column1: Good news for early adopters of the band: all that Butch Vig lacquer from their last two albums has mostly been scraped off. The record even opens with a little cowpunk shuffle on the title track to firmly mark a departure from the arena stylings of New Wave and White Crosses. Produced by Grace and put out on her own label Total Treble
column2: the band splits the difference between old and new into a compact sound that skews more Sex Pistols than Foo Fighters. It’s comparatively gaunt for Against Me! as of late
column3: but it yields the stage to Grace’s voice
column4: which has never sounded better.

column1: The aggression peaks right at the top
column2: when years of suppression meet the rage in her voice with lines like
column3: “You’ve got no cunt in your strut/ You’ve got no hips to shake” and “They just see a faggot.” It escalates soon after on “Drinking With the Jocks”
column4: where Grace dissembles with and dismantles misogynistic bro culture in about two minutes flat. She sings
column5: “There will always be a difference between me and you” with a little diva flip
column6: the perfect inflection for the album’s key pull-quote.

column1: For every “fuck you” there is an equal and opposite “fuck me
column2: ” where all the anger that’s on the surface of the album starts to crack and reveal deap-seated anxiety flowing underneath. Consider that Grace may
column3: as she's discussed
column4: undergo plastic surgery to be who she wants to be
column5: in addition to taking treatments of estrogen
column6: progesterone
column7: and Spironolactone all while confronting stigmas and thwarting skeptics along the way. While never too overtly stated
column8: displacement and shame color Grace’s growl
column9: especially on the MySpace username as song title “FuckMyLife666”
column10: which incidentally reconnects the band with Fat Mike
column11: who plays bass on the track. It really cuts to hear Grace sing from the judgmental third person: “Chipped nail polish and a barbed wire dress/ Is your mother proud of your eyelashes?” Later in the song
column12: she submits another competitor for Tagline of the Album: “There's a brave new world that's raging inside of me.”

column1: If only Grace could rest her big black margiela boots on these singular moments
column2: these battle cries for trans culture. The songs themselves are never as daring as Grace herself throughout Transgender Dysphoria Blues. You can feel her breath on your face
column3: taking on the jocks
column4: death (on the acoustic “Two Coffins”)
column5: major label execs (“Black Me Out”)
column6: and even Osama Bin Laden. She sometimes spirals into the verbose and clunky lyricism that has followed her around her entire career
column7: as on “Dead Friend”
column8: whose words seem untimely ripped from someone still in the gangly throes of grief.

column1: In detours from the title topic
column2: Grace’s anger is scrawled too hard and too sloppy on the page—see “Osama Bin Laden as the Crucified Christ”. Any of the song’s grander metaphors are lost behind the jingoistic chorus
column3: “You’re gonna hang like Benito from the Esso rafters/ Hang like Clara with her skull caved in.” The eye-for-an-eye
column4: boot-in-yer-ass simile is some distance from throwing shade at Robert McNamera on White Crosses. It’s easy to look past occasionally ineffectual production
column5: staid song arrangements
column6: and static guitar riffs when Grace—as she discovers herself on the album—is anything but ineffectual
column7: staid
column8: or static. But when she addresses politics or mortality
column9: the record falls flat and lapses into gawky extremes.

column1: If Transgender Dysphoria Blues was wholly focused on transgender dysphoria blues
column2: it would push aside so much of what Against Me! has built through the years; even in their shortcomings
column3: they remain who they are. But it's fitting that there are facets of the album that refuse to cohere
column4: that don't quite fit right
column5: that flail about in its too-eager execution. These welts are ultimately part of Grace's journey to the depths of self-discovery
column6: and the journey to Against Me!'s true sound
column7: all while playing to the theme of transformation. Punk has always been about disruption of order
column8: and this new revolution that Laura Jane Grace leads doesn't surrender her identity
column9:
it reclaims it. This revolution is no lie at all.

column10: high cheekbones

column16: and Jeremy Jay's albums flirt dangerously with falling into this trap.

column1: Abandoned Apartments is a shade more nocturnal and forlorn than 2011's Dream Diary. The sound of his records is always immaculate: He has an ongoing fascination with dreams and cinema
column2: and an aesthete's ear for perfect little sounds. There are several such perfect little sounds dotting Abandoned Apartment: The muted tambourine hits opening ""Sentimental Expressway""; the messy guitar solo that airdrops into the last minute of ""Covered in Ivy""; the warm little trill of acoustic guitar opening up ""I Was Waiting""; the ""Cold As Ice"" piano chords beginning ""Graveyard Shift"". Cataloging them
column3: though

column6: and the album slides back out of your attention field quickly.

column2: the first single
column3: is one of the few exceptions. After its opening dusky piano chords

column1: ""The View From the Train Window"" is another exception

column3: burbling bass. Wisps of noise—little guitar leads
column4: glimmering single-note keyboard shimmers—eddy around Jay
column5: who sings a long-breathed melancholy melody. His lyrics are nearly impossible to make out through his bored diction
column6: which swallows the beginning and the end of every word. The yearning phrases that poke through are slogan-like signifiers for mystery
column7: allure
column8: sadness—""Footsteps on a darkened street
column9: ""Sometimes you're so far and so near
column10: ""When I met you in the metro/ Oh your eyes said baby 'Let's go.'"" People do a lot of waiting for trains
column11: a lot of locking eyes in public places. One or two lines happen across resonant imagery —""Blisters from accidents that never happened

column14:
slightly vacant things.

""What you love is made of wind
column2: Tara Jane O'Neil muses a little more than halfway through Where Shine New Lights
column3: her first solo LP in five years. The deeply naturalistic Lights finds O'Neil—ex-Rodan bassist
column4: painter

column6: and tireless solo experimenter—carving scenery out of sound. Yet it's the record's very next line that really gets to the heart of Lights: ""you will not be this shape again."" Lights

column8: is quite possibly the finest merging of the chameleonic O'Neil's song-based work and her more experimental side. But combing through the catalog for comparison-points doesn't quite get at what makes Lights so striking. Lights is a peculiar thing: impeccably designed
column9: with every thrum positioned just so
column10: yet entirely malleable
column11: different every time you come across it.

column1: Lights
column2: like much of O'Neil's solo work
column3: occupies a space between traditional songcraft and more experimental fare
column4: weaving ghostly drones and incidental noises through hushed
column5: unhurried post-folk. Throughout Lights
column6: O'Neil brings the two sides as close as they've ever come before

column8: borderline groovy ""Wordless in Woods""

column10: each note is placed just so. But
column11: for all the precision of the arrangements
column12: Lights is the farthest thing from rigid. O'Neil's been careful to leave space in these songs
column13: to let them unfurl at a ruminative pace
column14: to burrow secrets way down in the mix. It leaves Lights feeling practically habitable
column15: a good place to get some thinking done.

column1: O'Neil casts an optimstic glow over much of Lights
column2: but its tone is always in flux. ""Bellow Below as Above"" is an ominous
column3: shapeshifting
column4: just-before-sunrise dirge that slowly climbs its way into a gnarled sort of beauty. Little instrumental exhalations complicate the haunting Brit-folk of ""Elemental Finding""
column5: while the oblong near-slowcore of ""The Signal
column6: Lift"" unwinds over a bed of whispering cymbals
column7: growing more intense by the minute. O'Neil's a fine lyricist—look no further than ""Elemental Finding""—but much of Lights' vocalizing is wordless
column8: evoking feelings rather than spelling them out. Lights is rarely less than beautiful
column9: but between the often-sparse arrangements and impressionistic singing
column10: these abstractions require patience on the listener's part. Give Lights your total concentration
column11: and it opens up completely; start flipping through your phone
column12: and it vanishes into the air. But it's that very pliancy that makes the album so easy to return to; it's harmoniously balanced
column13: yet as liable to change along with the quality of the light
column14: a distressed folk record on one listen
column15: and a sumptuous
column16: swirling exploratory drone record the next. O'Neil's certainly made her share of enrapturing
column17: enveloping music. But I'm not sure she's ever made one quite as transportive—or
column18: for that matter
column19:
as alive—as Where Shine New Lights.

column1: Thing is

column19: but surely sexy women. Consider Drowners an extreme case of “write what you know

column1: That being said
column2: he’s not the only pretty face in the big city

column1: And for the most part

column7: you know I rarely leave the house

column9: he’s drunk
column10: and he needs to get laid
column11: but he needs to get up and get out first.

The Alchemist and Evidence are old friends—they’ve known each other since the early 90s.  Each is a rapper and a producer
column2: and both are dedicated students of the rap game with a preternatural awareness of the history and context of their art that endows the music they create together with additional meaning. The pair bring that shared understanding to their new project <i>Lord Steppington
column3: a welcome addition to the collection of solid boom-bap rap albums that Alchemist has helmed over the last few years.

column1: Alchemist has been a prolific producer for more than a decade
column2: but as the gangster-rap complex he was once a cog in has evaporated
column3: he's emerged a key player
column4: uniting a host of veterans and young rap nerds alike to create classicist rap music. Starting with <i>Return of the Mac
column5: a 2007 collaboration with Prodigy of Mobb Deep
column6: Alchemist has released a string of solid projects with rappers like Action Bronson
column7: Boldy James
column8: Curren$y
column9: and Domo Genesis. What unites these rappers is a reverence for the art form of 90s rap
column10: combined with a welcome dedication to not taking themselves too seriously. Jokes and skits that reek of weed abound on these albums
column11: which add to the sense that you’re listening to a collection of above-average rappers who feel supremely comfortable making music with one another.

column1: That sense is heightened given the relationship between Alchemist and Evidence. The two share an outsider’s take on rap music (which may have something to do with being two of the only non-black kids in their neighborhood). Since their early days of working together
column2: when Alchemist used to craft beats for Evidence’s group Dilated Peoples
column3: there’s been a sense within their music of striving for credibility. And the way they’ve achieved that credibility is by building an insular world of musical references that’s both dense and possibly invisible to those who haven’t been listening to rap’s odds and ends for the last 10 odd years. Lord Steppington is an album that clowns on Theophilus London’s lips
column4: and Bubba Sparxxx’s country-rap opus Deliverance. It’s an album that refashions the old New Orleans song “Iko Iko” as a mantra full of gangster menace. It is filled to the brim with insider references
column5: so casually delivered in such a non sequitur fashion
column6: that the uninitiated might not even know what was going on.

column1: Not surprising then to hear that this sort of music will work best for those denizens of the rap universe who are well positioned to understand its in-jokes. But Alchemists’ style doesn't rely on stacks of signifiers—he's got that postmodern ability to mine new meaning from old forms and the musicality of Lord Steppington should recommend it to those who might be put off by its rap-nerd bona fides. Alchemist’s beats on the album (Evidence only has one producing credit
column2: on “Byron G”) fuse the iron underpinnings of New York boom-bap with either expansive soul or psychedelic edge
column3: or both. The first track here
column4: “More Wins”
column5: may sound like a simple looped sample
column6: but right before the two-minute mark
column7: the full force of the original song comes in and the track shifts on its axis. Elsewhere
column8: “Banging Sound” (more harmless than the name suggests)
column9: combines disparate elements: a trippy childlike sing-song for a chorus that contrasts nicely with the descending bassline and minimalist snare on the verses.

column1: The raps often sound equally pieced together but their hip-hop-almanac quality makes them feel familiar
column2: comfortable as worn-out clothing. “Step Masters”
column3: for example

column5: Ricky Bobby references nestling nicely besides Evidence’s improvised aphorisms (“I ain’t the mover
column6: I’m the man that you hand the cream.”).  The guest apperances contribute to the album’s happy mixing pot; on “Byron G” (which starts and ends with a sample of Kanye at the 2008 Brit awards)
column7: Domo Genesis spits one of the more tightly wound verses of his still-young career
column8: only to hand the mic off to Scott Caan
column9: who rapped with Alchemist in the Whooliganz  before Varsity Blues jump-started his acting career. Action Bronson
column10: Styles P
column11: and Fashawn all make appearances
column12: and each sounds relaxed
column13: flowing naturally. Even the easily-agitated Blu sounds at home on the album
column14: keeping Evidence and his fellow Dilated Person
column15: Rakaa
column16: company on the mellow track ""Tomorrow"".

column1: These sorts of fun surprises can make Lord Steppington feel like a Saturday morning cartoon

column4: and the jokes are funny. But the album
column5: like so much of Alchemists' recent work
column6: occasionally unleashes a Rembrandt. There are two songs here that astound. The first
column7: “Swimteam Rastas”
column8: is a memoir-esque take on the rap life from a dialed-in Evidence elevated by heavenly chipmunk soul in its middle third. “See the Rich Man Play” is even stronger

Lord Steppington is just the latest remarkably solid offering from Alchemist and co. and the artists involved clearly think of the endeavors as fun and games. Of course

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20063/homepage_large.185e72d6.jpg|Have Fun With God|5231.0|Bill Callahan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2014-01-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:47.698777|"

The last decade or so of Bill Callahan’s music has been a steady process of refinement
column2: stripping away extraneous words and instrumentation and leaving only what’s essential. While this trend doesn’t run in a straight line—2006’s Neil Hagerty-produced Woke on a Whaleheart has a comparatively heavy production touch—he’s mostly done away with reverb
column3: distortion
column4: and processing; his music tends to consist of basic instrumentation presented without adornment
column5: reflecting a confidence that the songs are strong enough to do the work. Last year’s Dream River was no exception
column6: so it was on one hand a surprise that an advance track prior to the record’s release was a ""dub"" version of ""Javelin Unlanding"" called ""Expanding Dub"". Dub essentially involves using mixing and effects as a form of expression; the song matters far less than what’s done to it
column7: which initially seemed an odd way to hear Callahan’s spare music. More surprising still was word that Callahan and his mixer Brian Beattie would extend the idea to the entirety of <i>Dream River
column8: creating a dub version of the record
column9: a la <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_Protection_(Massive_Attack_album)"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Mad Professor’s re-working of Massive Attack’s second album
column10: Protection.

column1: Initial surprise aside
column2: Callahan’s interest in the form makes sense. Classic Jamaican dub from 1970s and 80s is music of great focus and discipline; mixers like King Tubby
column3: Lee ""Scratch"" Perry
column4: and Scientist often created instrument dubs for the B-sides of 7"" singles in a single take
column5: re-working the track and adding effects live while the tape of the original song rolled. So once everything was in place
column6: dubbing a four-minute single would take four minutes
column7: with all of the echo
column8: drop-outs
column9: flanging
column10: and various other effects added in real-time. This approach stands in sharp contrast to today’s standard approach to remixing
column11: which uses non-linear digital editing to allow for endless copying
column12: pasting
column13: looping
column14: and processing. A classic dub doesn’t involve any extending of specific sections—the bones of the song are set and the mixer’s job is to shine light on different elements
column15: foregrounding
column16: backgrounding
column17: and transforming
column18: warping time without changing it. Given that
column19: creating dubs using the tools at hand in Jamaica in the 1970s—often four-track tape machines—required a lot of practice and a tremendous amount of discipline. And the best dub can also feel like a celebration of the individual instrument
column20: as parts fall away and you zoom in on the texture created by a simple bassline.

column1: All that squares with Callahan’s approach to sound
column2: and
column3: however it was actually made
column4: Have Fun With God feels like a live
column5: real-time dub. The tape rolls
column6: and the essential arc of each song is unchanged. In addition to the sense of spontaneity
column7: the arrangements of this record lend themselves well to the treatment. Hand drums
column8: flute
column9: and clean guitar lines all lend sound rich in isolation
column10: and light touches of echo
column11: and Callahan’s voice
column12: so front-and-center on his recordings
column13: works well when single words or even syllables are called out and given light touches of effects. It’s also pleasingly disorienting to hear the music of this word-focused artist transformed in such a way that the words don’t really matter—here they mostly become sounds. With a couple of exceptions
column14: where the tracks playfully focus on a key moment in a song (like the call-out of ""beer"" in the opening ""Thank Dub"")
column15: there’s no attempt to pay the lyrics any particular attention or amplify the song’s ""meaning."" The approach also underscores the fact that there are some nicely tricky little rhythms pulsing under these mid-tempo songs.

column1: So at its best
column2: Have Fun With God works well as an experiment and as a listening puzzle to work through. If you know Dream River well—and it’s hard to imagine anyone else being interested in this record—you’ll hear new things in it after giving this record a couple of spins. It also seems safe to say that
column3: despite its charms and left-field nature
column4: Have Fun With God will be a minor entry in the Callahan catalogue
column5: remembered about as well as his low-key 2010 live album Rough Travel for a Rare Thing
column6:
which is not to say I’m not glad both exist.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20144/homepage_large.0fa40513.jpg|Spaces|28863.0|Nils Frahm|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Erased Tapes']|2014-01-23 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:48:47.895090|"

Tight restrictions are a fundamental component of the music made by Berlin-based composer Nils Frahm. When he plays piano it sometimes feels like his hands are pulling rigid machine-based structures into a lighter
column2: airier place. Frahm is a musician clearly enamored with benchmark figures from the minimalist tradition (Steve Reich
column3: Philip Glass)
column4: artists who cross the jazz and classical worlds (Keith Jarrett)
column5: film composers that lean toward the tropes of early music (Michael Nyman)
column6: and electronic musicians with the lightest of touches (Thomas Fehlmann). Spaces is a live album patchworked together from various recordings
column7: containing songs both old and new
column8: some shortened
column9: some lengthened
column10: some radically different in approach. Some even stay just as they were.

column1: This is an absorbing work
column2: full of pensive moments cut together by music that thrives on dovetailing melodies that can be simultaneously mesmerizing and beautiful. ""Said and Done"" is the most impressive of these
column3: with a hammering piano motif looping for most of its 10-minute duration as Frahm filters it through textures both light and dark. It's giddy at times
column4: the sound of a creator utterly lost to his work. The occasional burst of applause or audience noise is a startling reminder that these aren't studio works
column5: although it's easy to forget that fact
column6: so meticulous are the arrangements. Moments of humor work as a neat buffer throughout
column7: stopping everything from becoming too internalized—the Jarrett-referencing ""Improvisation for Coughs and a Cell Phone"" is a piece bent around the interruptions suggested in its title.

column1: What's fascinating about Frahm's work here is how he plays with time
column2: working strictly within its limits through tiny repeating motifs
column3: but blowing the overall picture up over such a wide canvas that it's easy to forget how long it's taken to get to where he’s going. The almost 17-minute long medley ""For - Peter - Toilet Brushes - More"" is an example of that idea. Plates of coiling synth sound indebted to the new age markers set down by Jean Michel Jarre open up the track
column4: before Frahm glides through bursts of rim-shot percussion
column5: arpeggiated synths
column6: and a return to the strident piano of ""Said and Done"". All the component parts work in miniature
column7: based around fragments of sound and ideas that gradually merge into one despite their wildly different roots. The huge burst of applause at the end is deserved
column8: to say the least.

column1: Something that emerges over time spent with Spaces is a subtly shifting dynamic triggered by the way these tracks are recorded. ""Over There
column2: It's Raining"" ostensibly plays out as a pretty low-key piece of neo-romantic yearning. But a large part of its feeling is derived from the tape hiss that muffles at its corners
column3: giving the sentiment a lack of crispness
column4: lending a sense of love and hope gone stale. Even the most forward-thinking track here
column5: the stunning crisscrossing circuitry of ""Says""
column6: is far from what it seems at first glance. In a recent interview
column7: Frahm outlines it as an example of ""what can you do with one delay and an old synthesizer
column8: no computers."" It's hard to picture that basic working method when lost in its complex tangle of glossy electronics
column9: underpinned by myriad counter-melodies that stretch out to unfathomable depths.

column1: For someone as technically accomplished as Frahm surely is
column2: and with so many unique and divisive ideas in mind
column3: Spaces never succumbs to being a set of exercises set to tape. Part of the beauty is in trying to figure out what he's doing and not quite getting there
column4: but mostly it's easy to forget about the way his music is put together and just lose yourself in it instead. Often the charm is
column5: as the title suggests
column6: in the spaces Frahm so artfully leaves between notes. That's an impressive achievement for any live recording—a place where the sweat and sawdust of real life often impinges a little too heavily on otherworldly material
column7:
where a layer of fantasy is often shorn away in a manner that can be crude and disillusioning. On Spaces there's a power that Frahm hasn't always been able to capture in his recorded work. But the overriding feel is one of joy at listening to a performer demonstrating the infinite elasticity of sound.

"|18949.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18949-nils-frahm-spaces/|7.8|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20122/homepage_large.8f254594.jpg|Brothers and Sisters of the Eternal Son|2221.0|Damien Jurado|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2014-01-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:50.028416|"

Brothers and Sisters of the Eternal Son is Damien Jurado’s 11th album
column2: but more importantly it’s the third piece in a Richard Swift-produced triptych that began with 2010’s St. Bartlett and continued on 2012’s Maraqopa. If those first two are linked by the psychedelic experimentation and other studio stamps unique to the Jurado-Swift partnership
column3: Brothers and Sisters is a no-bones-about-it sequel to Maraqopa; several tracks reference the mythical locale conjured from one of Jurado’s dreams
column4: and one song is even titled “Return to Maraqopa”. The two records begin in strikingly similar ways
column5: too
column6: far-away acoustic guitar giving way to Jurado’s far-away singing.

column1: Brothers and Sisters
column2: though
column3: is yet another leap into territory that Jurado only touched on previously. Jurado has always been a storyteller
column4: and those stories usually happen in the context of a particular song as he zooms in on the details of his characters’ lives and relationships. They are isolated incidents. Not so this time around. Brothers and Sisters zooms out to tell one story
column5: albeit a fantastical
column6: non-linear one cloaked in sci-fi imagery and layers of mystery. Characters and incidents and themes roll out and twist and wriggle their way through the album. There’s nothing like Maraqopa’s “Working Titles”
column7: a story song that can easily and naturally be applied to Jurado himself: a singer hides from an audience that’s “not in tune with your progress” while someone asks
column8: “What’s it like for you in Washington? I’ve only seen photos of Washington.” The references on Brothers and Sisters are sometimes specific but usually not of this world: geodesic eyes
column9: a ship in the sky
column10: zodiac pain
column11: Jericho Road
column12: Saturn. If the concept-album aspect of Maraqopa was a stretch
column13: it’s undeniable this time around.

column1: The religious overtones are more explicit
column2: too. Jurado doesn’t shy away from his beliefs (“I definitely subscribe to the Christian faith
column3: ” he said in an interview about Maraqopa)
column4: and the Biblical references are all over this record. There’s the Christ-evoking title
column5: and on “Silver Katherine” Jurado sings
column6: “I have seen Him… pacing through the sky”; he ends the track singing
column7: “Roll away the stone.” Allegory is everywhere in this dream/vision/hallucination
column8: but it’s not the type of C.S. Lewis allegory in which we’re meant to have an aha moment. Sure
column9: Aslan is Jesus
column10: but I have no clue who Silver Timothy is. Or Silver Donna
column11: Malcom
column12: or Katherine. And don’t count on a big reveal that unlocks a way to understand the veiled “magic number” by the time the album closes. Yet these mysteries are curiously addictive more than they are frustrating.

column1: Jurado has taken many left turns in his career
column2: from the stark
column3: dark folk of Rehearsals for Departure to the toe-tappers on Caught in the Trees
column4: so at this point it shouldn’t be surprising that he continues to take chances. But you probably never imagined Jurado getting quite as funky as he does on the six-minute “Silver Donna”—the clicky guitar line and punchy
column5: multi-tracked falsetto giving it a danceable groove. Jurado’s voice is usually recognizable more for its warble than its punch
column6: and there’s still plenty of well-placed warble here. But this more adventurous stage of Jurado’s career isn’t just studio trickery. He often sounds like a new man
column7: too.

column1: “Silver Timothy” is the strongest track on Brothers and Sisters
column2: and the prominent claves give it a distinct Latin feel. These moments of genre jumbling litter the record as they did on Maraqopa (though I wouldn’t make too much of Swift’s comments about dub and reggae influences; he most likely hears it more than you will)
column3: and the melange works in much the same way. The psychedelia and ghostly sounds make their way onto recordings because of the liberation inherent in Jurado’s work at Swift’s studio (aptly named National Freedom)
column4: but they remain on the final version of the record because they fit. Swift and Jurado didn’t throw everything against the wall in hopes that something oddly beautiful would emerge. They arranged it in such a way that odd beauty is communicated.

column1: In lesser hands the quiet “Silver Katherine” and “Silver Joy” could seem out of place
column2: like an anachronistic return to the spare singer-songwriter fare of Jurado’s early work on an album otherwise engaged in chance-taking. Instead
column3: it’s sequenced as a welcome breather—a respite right before the cloudless chamber-pop fadeout of final track “Suns in Our Mind”. The album ends with Jurado singing
column4: “Over there beyond the words
column5: we are all we dream of
column6: ” a callback to a similar
column7: earlier line: “Words are not needed.” It’s hard not to apply some of these lyrics about language to the album itself
column8: since some of the words crucial to following the action of this story are never even sung
column9: relegated to parentheticals in the liner notes (e.g. “after the accident
column10: ” “return to the crash site
column11: ” “heavy limbs / paper medicine cup
column12: ” “welcomed at the gate”). If anything
column13: though
column14: it shows how comfortable Jurado has become experimenting with new sounds and structures in this partnership with Swift. He has said he used to dread making records
column15: and he doesn’t anymore. The freedom and comfort Swift provide seem to increase Jurado’s confidence on each outing
column16:
and it’s not unfounded.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20021/homepage_large.ea3a1544.jpg|From All Purity|30075.0|Indian|['Rock'
column3: the fifth full-length album by Chicago misanthropes Indian
column4: is that it wields as much power from a distance as it does in close quarters. Let these six tracks rip from your stereo system of choice
column5: take a step back
column6: and you’ll hear a fevered
column7: hostile trip through top-heavy doom and harsh noise. The lulled wallop of “Rhetoric of No” is tremendous
column8: with thunder drums cracking against wide-sky riffs. The death metal shivers that erupt and dissipate throughout closer “Disambiguation” shake the frame
column9: while the reptilian invective of founder and chief screamer Dylan O’Toole slices across any space. Now plug in headphones
column10: and step forward into Indian’s tumult. The mountainous sludge is still there
column11: as is the squall. But the balance has shifted
column12: and the subtleties become evident: In “Directional”
column13: faint
column14: hostile harmonies crisscross with a storm of electronic viscera
column15: sandwiched between the dual guitars that chase O’Toole’s lead and the rhythm section’s trouncing momentum. During “Rhetoric of No”
column16: the drums trace O’Toole’s voice like a vigilante trailing a target
column17: the rhythm emphasizing every shift the leader makes. It’s not complicated. It’s just nuanced
column18: the condition that makes From All Purity more than a loud record with good riffs and belligerent intentions.

column1: During their decade as a band
column2: any change or progress with Indian could best be described as stepwise
column3: despite rather drastic membership changes: Aside from an obvious production upgrade and enhanced self-editing
column4: there’s little difference in style and content from 2005’s The Unquiet Sky
column5: a ricocheting wrecking ball of feedback and distortion
column6: and the new From All Purity. They flirted with rudimentary din then (“Shill”)
column7: again on 2008’s The Sycophant (“Allotriophagy”)
column8: and even added a member credited simply with “noise” on their most recent album
column9: 2011’s Guiltless. On From All Purity
column10: they are once again a quartet
column11: with former Wolves in the Throne Room and Nachtmystium guitarist Will Lindsay re-enlisting to split guitars and vocals with O’Toole. To counterbalance the standard four-piece setup here
column12: though
column13: Indian recruited Mark Solotroff
column14: the mastermind of the destructive Bloodyminded
column15: and Sanford Parker
column16: a producer who has long gone beyond the rote responsibility of plugging in microphones and hitting the big red button.

column1: Their roles are most obvious on “Clarify”
column2: a late-album showcase of sorts for Solotroff’s distorted realities. Indian generally line their riffs with cacophony; here
column3: they invert the approach
column4: bathing enormous amplifier growls with toxic noise that wheezes
column5: gasps
column6: and chokes. It’s a brilliant
column7: caustic burst
column8: but it’s also a smartly retroactive signpost for how the album works as a whole. After hearing “Clarify”
column9: the depth of the rest of From All Purity becomes obvious. Yes
column10: “Rape”
column11: which opens the album
column12: is a malevolent tantrum
column13: suggesting the brittle shapes of Eyehategod and the fomenting wrath of Khanate. But Solotroff lingers just beneath the cresting guitars
column14: feathering their feedback with static tips. And in the passing moments where the song collapses
column15: his electronics shape a sort of Rubicon that the crew summarily dares you to cross. Solotroff appears only on those two tracks and “Directional”
column16: but the idea remains even without him: This is highly involved and evolved doom
column17: with layers and finesse betraying a veteran band. There’s a sustained screech just beneath “The Impetus Bleeds”
column18: creating a sense of inescapable claustrophobia. Ron DeFries plays his bass so loudly that it sounds as though his amplifier is dying
column19: bleeding out beneath the song. And the guitars of “Disambiguation” sometimes mimic a blizzard musically
column20: creating a sound so thick you can’t hear or even think beyond them.

column1: In the era of infinite and instant online content
column2: listeners can rush to judgment with wanton speed. A new song that’s played in some remote club one night can proliferate across the internet by the next morning
column3: with a tantalizing headline attached. Twitter answers with ad hoc ratings and analyses. That creates the pressure to change
column4: setting up a crucible for hyperkinetic evolution that means you’re only as good as the last YouTube video someone posts of a song you’ve yet to finish. Indian
column5: who have existed at least until now on the fringes of their peers’ rising popularity
column6: are a testament to an older
column7: slower mode of growth: Hide away
column8: change slowly
column9: and emerge eventually with something as commanding and well-crafted as From All Purity. This is an album whose every layer seems customized
column10: whose every crease seems deliberate. That calculation doesn’t seem to have mitigated Indian’s power at all. Rather
column11: this is the strongest they’ve ever sounded and the smartest they’ve ever sounded—a blunderbuss paired to a brain
column12:
both fully operational.

column2:
'Galactic Zoo Disk']|2014-01-23 00:00:00|1972|2016-06-11 16:48:52.613621|"

It’s been a decade since Sub Pop’s reissue of Michael Yonkers’ blisteringly fuzzy Microminiature Love—recorded in 1969 and mostly ignored since—turned the Minneapolis obscurity into a cult hero. As later Yonkers albums have come to light
column3: it’s reinforced the perception that Microminiature Love’s raving
column4: avant-garage inclinations were just a blip. At heart Yonkers is a folkie. The decision to move in a less kinetic direction was partly made for him by the 1971 factory accident (and subsequent bungled treatment) that left him debilitated. But the Drag City reissues of two of his early-70s albums—the solo disc Michael Lee Yonkers and the team-up with his former bandmate Jim Woehrle titled Borders of My Mind—show just how much country and folk were part of Yonkers’s idiosyncratic musical worldview.

column1: This is still Yonkers
column2: though
column3: so the stuff is still twisted. As on Grimwood
column4: his first post-Miniature Love album
column5: MLY and Borders were self-released in 1974 despite being recorded somewhat earlier. MLY was tracked in 1971 and 1972
column6: and it continues with diminishing returns the lo-fi vibe he established in Grimwood
column7: which was recorded in 1969. The 60s may have been over
column8: but the trip wasn’t. Awash in the kind of thudding reverb that can only come from living-room walls
column9: the disc is a scarecrow-stark affair
column10: an assembly of acoustic lullabies topped with Yonkers’s goatlike cowpoke vibrato. “His bowels were trembling
column11: ” he croons crookedly on “My Sally
column12: ” and it’s as silly as it is skeletal. It feels more pastiche than anything else
column13: though
column14: and its Johnny Cash rumble rides off from time to time into Rawhide territory. Yonkers’s stab at a murder ballad
column15: “I’m So Glad You Came""
column16: isn’t weird enough to be poignant or funny enough to be weird
column17: but instead inhabits a holding pattern between lighthearted and halfhearted.

column1: Borders fares better. Recapturing some of Grimwood’s quivering psychedelic headspace
column2: it reunites Yonkers with Woehrle
column3: who had been a member of Yonkers’s pre-Microminiature garage combo Michael and the Mumbles as well as the original lineup of The Michael Yonkers Band. Woehrle left the group just before the recording of Microminiature
column4: but the alchemy between the two old friends is gloriously uneven. Relearning each other’s ropes as they go along
column5: each half of the duo contributes songwriting duties. The result is rife with beautifully ragged seams. With Yonkers on feathery guitar and Woehrle on shaky piano
column6: the twosome harmonizes in a near medieval mode on “Elaine""
column7: a “Scarborough Fair” for hungover hippiedom. But it’s the grainy
column8: eight-minute “Lovely Lady Companion” that most tenderly demonstrates Borders’ hushed camaraderie. “Please be with me when I reach the end
column9: ” they sing together into the single microphone through which everything is being captured.

column1: Neither album
column2: however
column3: hits the same outsider heights as Microminiature
column4: let alone Drag City’s other 70s-folk finds such as Gary Higgins’ ghostly Red Hash. Playfully inconsistent
column5: MLY and Borders help complete the sketch of Yonkers’s the traditionalist
column6: someone who dipped his toe into the chaotic 60s avant-garde before realizing he’d rather put away his fuzz boxes and make nice with his guitar. These two albums have more depth and edge than that. Yonkers
column7: after all
column8: has an off-center perspective that fuses gaunt-eyed soulfulness with quirky perversity. But neither fully traps the weird essence of the time
column9: the place
column10: or
column11: one suspects
column12:
the man behind them.
