0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20087/homepage_large.3f77acd5.jpg|Warpaint|28034.0|Warpaint|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2014-01-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:53.149347|"

It's a rare feat to see an indie rock band as stylishly presented as Warpaint is on their self-titled second album. The Los Angeles quartet's 2010 debut The Fool certainly got them to an admirable level of success
column2: albeit one where having either Flood produce or Nigel Godrich mix the follow-up would be a serious coup; nearly three years in the making
column3: Warpaint has both. Acclaimed video director Chris Cunningham is on board as well
column4: contributing the arresting visuals for first single ""Love Is to Die"" as well as the cover art. Judging from the talent involved
column5: this all sounds like a massive
column6: star-making rollout from the second Clinton term and unfortunately
column7: Warpaint plays the part too well. Digging in the used CD crates to exhume hours of rightfully ignored post-OK Computer paranoid androids
column8: catatonic trip-hop
column9: and gluttonous Francophile ambience
column10: Warpaint spends 2014 remembering everything 1999 tried to forget.

column1: But for all of Warpaint’s fashionable aesthetics and packaging
column2: they're a most square thing: a jam band. And not even a jam band in the fairgrounds-conquering sense most understand it
column3: where typical verse-chorus structure serves as a jumping off point for indulgent
column4: technically flashy solos. The thrill of seeing Warpaint’s uncanny
column5: egoless instrumental interplay in a live setting didn’t always translate on The Fool
column6: though the record did serve as a good preview. There
column7: Warpaint went past mere jamming
column8: conjuring music into existence
column9: hazy vistas of desert blues
column10: cavernous post-punk
column11: and disembodied
column12: ghostly vocals
column13: summoned to create alluring mirage rock.

column1: But on Warpaint
column2: the band goes from raising spirits to the embalming business
column3: adding layers and layers of polish to lifeless stiffs. To their credit
column4: they haven't changed their compositional approach; though the sound is vastly more lustrous
column5: expansive
column6: and expensive
column7: each individual player is emphasized in a manner that emboldens the group collectively. In her first record since joining the band
column8: drummer Stella Mozgawa is mixed as a lead instrument
column9: and Lindberg’s bass is often tasked with not just the melodic framework
column10: but the actual melodies. Meanwhile
column11: the vocals of Emily Kokal and Theresa Wayman are given crystalline spaces of their own to act as texture
column12: while their guitars are either padding or swapped out for whooshing synthesizers. It’s a total inversion of pop music
column13: which seems to have been the point.

column1: And like every guitar-based band as of late
column2: Warpaint have stressed that they’ve spent the past four years listening to anything but guitar-based music
column3: seeking out as much R&B and hip-hop as possible. They’ve called Warpaint a mashup with Jay-Z. They also called Warpaint their Dark Side of the Moon. They’re not exactly wrong—the ponderous
column4: bottom-heavy tempos of Warpaint are a triangulation point between space-rock and rap. But while trip-hop has long been derogated as functional lifestyle music

column5: weave
column6: dip and dart

column10: but now that they’re mixed to be a focal point

column1: “Teese” slumps its way towards a chorus that recalls Dot Allison’s “Colour Me”

column1: <div>More troubling than the lack of hooks is the way Warpaint operate in their new
column2: immaculate surroundings like they’re worried about a security deposit
column3: barely leaving a fingerprint on these air-streamed synths

column12: a big-budget rendering of the handcrafted

column1: Even those sympathetic to what Warpaint are doing have all but admitted this album lacks hooks
column2: grooves

column5: as transportive space-rock
column6: it’s not analog enough to be charmingly retro
column7: and certainly not futuristic. The lyrics are symptomatic of Warpaint itself
column8: failing to impress or even engage

time is money and Warpaint is the sound of both disappearing into the void.

column1: This was Nick Drake's existential dilemma: He would rather ponder time than observe the present
column2: would sooner gaze into the sea than engage with the people around him. School friends recall conversations about spirits and ""the little people"" as the only times they saw him animated. The rage he directed at his producer Joe Boyd for his failed career on ""Hanging on a Star"" (""Why leave me hanging on a star/ When you deem me so high""?) was in part the sound of someone realizing that their worldly woes have slowly blotted out their view of the stars

there can never be such a thing as a career. There can only be a legacy.

column2: abstracted

column6: that he was joining their ranks. It was Hutchings who had enthusiastically approached Drake in local pub The Roundhouse
column7: offering to pass his information along to the legendary manager Joe Boyd. Drake's entrance into the business
column8: at least
column9: was effortless and auspicious
column10: and he was joined in the Sound Techniques recording studio by a few of his personal heroes. The warm
column11: rounded upright bass playing is from Danny Thompson
column12: a founding member of the Pentangle. Richard Thompson plays the pearly guitar leads. Listening to “Time Has Told Me”
column13: the first song on his debut album
column14: is to hear to what might very well be the happiest and most fulfilling moment of Nick Drake’s professional life.

column1: Even as a 20-year-old
column2: Drake's vision for his music was strikingly assured. He was nervous
column3: fumbling
column4: and difficult to engage in conversation in the studio
column5: but he knew what he wanted. He calmly insisted that Boyd and John Wood hire arranger Robert Kirby
column6: a fellow student at Cambridge. Bewildered
column7: they obeyed
column8: and were rewarded with the breathtaking string chart for “Way to Blue”. With its clean lines and grave elegance
column9: ""Way to Blue"" suggests the philosophy that would distinguish Nick Drake’s music over the years and damn it during his lifetime: in Joe Boyd’s words
column10: it simply  “was not reaching out to you."" Drake was painfully English
column11: and showiness wasn’t really in his nature. But profundity glowed from his music.

column1: This approach extends to his guitar playing
column2: which was so obsessively perfect it almost escapes comprehension. You will never hear a single string buzz. It's not the sort of virtuosity that quiets a chattering crowd
column3: but once you've attuned to the absolute silence
column4: it quickly grows otherworldly. Even on densely packed fingerpicking runs like ""Day Is Done""
column5: each note sits in the mix like a stone at the floor of a clear pond. He was a frighteningly flawless player
column6: in a way that served to magnify his incorporeality: There is no surviving video of Nick Drake playing live or talking. He died in 1974
column7: but his physicality is as remote to our modern imagination as Gustav Mahler's.

column1: His concerns were similarly otherworldly and timeless
column2: informed by a childhood of English Romantic poets. The futility of knowing the mind of another was a persistent theme in his lyrics
column3: which looked right past people to stars
column4: trees
column5: eternity. “Who can know the thoughts of Mary Jane?” Drake muses. “Who can know the reason for her smile?” His music viewed human behavior and its peculiarities with quizzical detachment
column6: even when the case study is Drake himself: “So I'll leave the ways that are making me be/ What I really don't want to be
column8: he sings on ""Time Has Told Me"". Sizing up the enormity of this task
column9: examining how it might be accomplished—these were not really his philosophical concerns. They overwhelmed him or they simply didn’t interest him
column10: but either way
column11: they came to trip him up
column12: as they do us all.

column1: When it was released in the fall of 1969
column2: Five Leaves Left went unnoticed. Island Records had done it no favors. The packaging was insultingly botched; two songs—""Day Is Done” and “Way To Blue”—were switched in the tracklisting and “Three Hours” was mistakenly titled “Sundown”. But Drake was also complicit; he began his first ill-fated tour behind the faltering album
column3: and between songs
column4: he would tune his guitar for minutes on end to stony
column5: uncomfortable silence. He often walked off dejected before finishing his set. He disappeared into dope smoke
column6: a predilection that was slowly hardening into a crutch. He blew off radio sessions and interviews and slowly began retreating into himself. It was under these circumstances that he ventured back into the studio for Bryter Layter
column7: his second full-length.

column1: Ironically
column2: it was initially conceived as his ""up"" album
column3: a poppy rejoinder to Five Leaves Left. Five Leaves was pastoral
column4: written in the wooded confines of Cambridge. Layter was written in London
column5: and was meant to reflect urbanity. It did
column6: but only from the perspective of Drake's one bloodshot eye
column7: peering out cautiously at the world. Over woolly saxophone on ""At the Chime of a City Clock""
column8: he confesses ""I stay indoors beneath the floors and talk with neighbors only/ The games you play make people say you're either weird or lonely"". Over the peppy horn charts of ""Hazey Jane II""
column9: Drake sings lightly of how it feels ""when the world it gets so crowded that you can't look out the window in the morning."" The city
column10: on Bryter Layter
column11: is one long harsh unpleasant noise occurring outside. Nothing good or stimulating seems to happen there.

column1: The music
column2: however
column3: is brighter—this is the Nick Drake you can hear reflected in latter-period Belle and Sebastian. He rehearsed with a band for the first time
column4: including other members of Fairport Convention
column5: and the result is the most fulsome studio recording he ever managed. Some of the arrangement decisions remain bewildering—the gospel backup vocals
column6: jazz-comping guitar and noodling piano crowding the space on ""Poor Boy"" remain as jarring now as they were when the album was released. On ""Fly"" and ""Northern Sky""
column7: Drake worked with John Cale
column8: and you can hear a more natural dynamic in their collaboration. It's either a shame or a relief they didn't work together longer: ""Fly"" and ""Northern Sky""are the two most affecting songs on Bryter
column9: but it's also likely Cale introduced Drake to heroin.

column1: On Pink Moon
column2: Nick Drake’s final official album
column3: there is one single overdub: the piano part drifting over the title track. The rest is just Drake
column4: his pristine
column5: eerily perfect playing
column6: his mumbling
column7: and silence. Bryter had also sold poorly and received near-zero notices—the most favorable review compared it to ""Classical Gas"". By now
column8: he hardly spoke to anyone; in between takes
column9: John Wood remembers
column10: Drake betrayed neither pleasure or displeasure. He simply sat. Keith Morris
column11: the photographer who shot the album's photography
column12: remarked that working with Drake was ""like working with still life."" The album was recorded in two evenings
column13: by his bewildered crew
column14: who were uncertain of what they were even making. When Drake was finished
column15: he dropped the manila package
column16: almost without a word
column17: at Island Records.

column1: A ""pink moon"" is a baleful symbol
column2: a sign of impending death or calamity. On ""Pink Moon""
column3: it's ""gonna get ye all."" On paper
column4: this sentiment reads like vindictive rage
column5: but on record
column6: it sounds contemplative. Drake's voice never conveyed palpable anger or sadness; he had a slight
column7: gentle voice and upper-class accent
column8: the product of his upbringing
column9: clipped and clean
column10: and his guitar
column11: as always
column12: rang out with a crystalline purity. His music is so consoling that the darkness at its heart is not always accessible. It's almost impossible to hear the emotional abandon in Pink Moon
column13: then
column14: without the taste of his first two albums lingering on your mouth. It's only then that the bone-dry resonance of the guitars registers as slightly alarming
column15: and the backdrop of silence suggests both the purity of Drake's vision and also something darker: like someone who has dropped out of the world
column16: mumbling prophecies.

column1: On ""Place to Be""
column2: he remembers his youth only as a time he ""didn't see the truth hanging from the door""; now
column3: he is ""weaker than the palest blue."" ""Know"" consists of just four lines—""You know that I love you/ You know I don't care/ You know that I see you/ You know I'm not there."" It sounds like a back-and-forth between Drake and the world at large. There is a stillness to Nick Drake's music that bewitches anyone who gets near enough
column4: and Pink Moon is its purest expression. It remains the Nick Drake record most people begin with
column5: and for good reason.

column1: The eleven songs on Pink Moon were not Nick Drake's final recordings
column2: however. In the last year of his life
column3: he would return to the studio
column4: his fingernails long
column5: his hair dirty
column6: his clothes in shambles
column7: to cut beginning tracks for what would have been his fourth album. They went poorly. Joe Boyd recalls that Drake
column8: the flawless technician
column9: was no longer able to play and sing at the same time
column10: so the sessions limped agonizingly while he fumbled through guitar takes and then returned to sing
column11: shakily. These four songs—""Black Eyed Dog""
column12: ""Rider on the Wheel""
column13: ""Tow the Line""
column14: and ""Hanging on a Star""—are the only truly discomfiting records he ever made. On ""Black Eyed Dog""
column15: he sang tremulously over some hammered harmonics about growing old and wanting to go home. Within four months

column1: The most consequential material on Made to Love Magic remain these final tracks. The sundry unreleased tracks
column2: such as the hallucinatory “Clothes of Sand” and the odd
column3: jaunty “Mayfair""
column4: are interesting but inessential. The rest of the album is the usual posthumous footnotes tumble: A version of ""River Man"" recorded when Drake was still at college; a scrapped version of ""Three Days"" from the tentative early sessions of Five Leaves Left; an early alternate take of ""Thoughts of Mary Jane""
column5: with distracted
column6: noodly lead guitar playing from Richard Thompson. There are a handful of performances from Drake's first-ever public concert
column7: the so-called ""work tape"" from his college days. They don't do much to enrich the Nick Drake story.

column1: Family Tree
column2: though
column3: is odder and more interesting. The album
column4: which was only released in 2007
column5: compiles all the known existing home recordings of Nick Drake—music he recorded at his parents' house for fun or to kill time; rehearsals of Mozart trios with his aunt and uncle (he played clarinet). The 28 tracks consist largely of covers and traditionals
column6: including a run through ""All My Trials""
column7: sung with his sister Gabrielle.

column1: Family Tree doesn’t give the world any classic lost Nick Drake music
column2: but it does give the sensation
column3: achieved with a little effort
column4: of what it might have been like to sit in the Drakes' parlor in Far Leys. You can hear the actual clink of actual tea cups in the background of his cover of Bob Dylan's ""Tomorrow Is a Long Time"". You get to hear Nick Drake messing about on guitar
column5: which sounds better than anyone else's. His version of ""Cocaine Blues"" is enjoyable  both because it's a looser and bluesier Nick Drake than we're used to

column1: Family Tree also includes two of his mother's haunting
column2: intriguingly wayward songs. ""Poor Mum"" makes for an odd companion with her son's ""Poor Boy""; ""Joy as it flies cannot be caught""
column3: she sings
column4: searchingly
column5: her voice climbing into a breath-catching question mark. There is an unmistakable hint of the fatalism that trailed her son's music in these recordings
column6: and in ""Do You Ever Remember""
column7: she sings lines that could lead directly into ""Time Has Told Me"": ""Time was ever a vagabond/ Time was always a thief/ Time can steal away happiness/ But time can take away grief.""

column1: This was Nick Drake's existential dilemma: He would rather ponder time than observe the present
column2: would sooner gaze into the sea than engage with the people around him. School friends recall conversations about spirits and ""the little people"" as the only times they saw him animated. The rage he directed at his producer Joe Boyd for his failed career on ""Hanging on a Star"" (""Why leave me hanging on a star/ When you deem me so high""?) was in part the sound of someone realizing that their worldly woes have slowly blotted out their view of the stars
column3: perhaps forever. ""I could have been a signpost
column4: could've been a clock
column5: he mused on ""One of These Things First""; this is the sentiment of someone who barely assented to the burdens of being a person. For such a soul
column6:
there can never be such a thing as a career. There can only be a legacy.

Jack Name's real name is John Webster Adams
column2: but he doesn't care what you call him. The enigmatic L.A. artist has recorded under a lot of names

column4: Fictional Boys
column5: and John Webster Johns. He says that's because he's ""sort of anti-identity."" ""I like the idea of destroying identity... We’re all the same underneath it all anyway."" His moniker
column6: then
column7: feels appropriate—""Jack Name"" somehow manages to sound even more anonymous than ""John Smith."" Throughout his album Light Show
column8: his voice shifts pitch and timbre. Sometimes it's high and squeaky

column10: and sometimes it's completely unintelligible and unrecognizably warped. It's as though he's intentionally making it difficult to pin down one easily definable character behind the music.

column1: Perhaps his elusive nature is there to place stronger emphasis on Light Show's narrative. The album's world is so fully formed and linear
column2: it seems preferable to refer to it is a ""rock opera"" instead of a ""concept album."" Name has said the record is inspired by his aversion to ""the way kids are put on drugs for educational purposes."" It's easy to hear this theme in his symbolism-addled lyrics. Throughout Light Show
column3: there's an implication that one must conform to societal norms
column4: though at the expense of ""diluted feelings."" The central character
column5: however
column6: learns to embrace his ""shadow""—the thing that makes him love dreaming in color and rock'n'roll. These themes are all presented in a world featuring characters that are cartoonishly similar to those from Tommy
column7: The Point
column8: and Yellow Submarine. But Light Show's overall arc follows a sort of Brave New World logic—sometimes it's better to be an individual than to medicate and become a neutral-minded pod person. ""I’ve always questioned the whole idea of ‘chemical imbalance
column9: ’ because I don’t think there’s anything wrong with those kids
column10: Name said. ""There’s something wrong with the world.""

column1: It's an ambitious idea
column2: to write an album-length parable about how attention-deficit medications
column3: antidepressants
column4: and other pharmaceuticals are capable of crushing someone's creative spirit. It's a potentially resonant topic
column5: too
column6: as artists have shared stories about antidepressants' negative (and positive) effects on their artistic drive. And although Name follows this theme with some consistently intriguing and at times abstract poetry
column7: it's the music accompanying his words that makes Light Show a compelling listen. There's a kinetic rock'n'roll drive to ""Do the Shadow"" and cheeseball melodrama in the soaring riffs of ""New Guitars"". When he eases up on the ""guitar rock"" elements of the record
column8: there are moments where he pairs glowing synths with mutant voices for a haunting effect. And since it's not a high flyer like ""New Guitars"" or anthemic like ""Pure Terror""
column9: the buzzing drone of ""Puffy Cheek Town"" keeps the album's soundscape diverse.

column1: ""The shadow"" is a pervasive theme in the album—a ctrl-F search of the lyrics sheet brings up 29 matches across six of the album's songs. In this context
column2: especially in the songs where he references dreams
column3: it's tempting to consider the Jungian definition of ""shadow""—the unconscious elements of one's personality. On ""Do the Shadow""
column4: the narrator realizes he was ""born a rocker"" and embraces his alter ego. ""Trans-America""
column5: a somber track
column6: features two characters (both voiced by Name) who sing about a hollow
column7: sort of anonymous existence that comes with ""painting all my shadows white."" It ends with a simple line about conformity and how it can stifle emotions: ""You care what they say about me.""

column1: This long narrative about status quo
column2: the shadow self
column3: and so on culminates in ""Killing a Shadow""
column4: which (spoiler) is an unsettlingly quiet track where the main character has his coveted shadow sucked out of his body and replaced with light. It's an ending that serves Name's ""there's something wrong with the world"" outlook. But it ends the album with a trudging pace. This downbeat final note
column5: along with the album's chaotic array of voices
column6: require for the listener to be fully invested in the record's narrative. Even though it's got some catchy
column7: immediate songs (""Pure Terror""
column8: ""Do the Shadow"")
column9: this isn't incidental music. It's an album that asks for focus and thought. It's the sort of thing where you could spend a substantial amount of time teasing out the symbolism behind these songs. Name might not care if you know who he is or what he calls himself
column10:
but he's put a lot of effort into his dystopia. You should consider spending some time there.

“No future
column2: ” screamed Johnny Rotten in the Sex Pistols’ 1977 single “God Save the Queen"". In 1984
column3: punk had more need of God’s help. By then the British punk movement had been bashing its head against the establishment for eight years straight. Outside of the cartoonish
column4: spiky-haired nihilist Vyvyan on BBC’s ""The Young Ones""
column5: punk had little to show for it. The chart-storming gains made by the Pistols and the Clash had given way to marginalization and self-caricature. The Exploited’s 1981 anthem “Punks Not Dead” was already a hollow echo. Punk’s founders had moved on to noise
column6: dub
column7: metal
column8: pop. The most visible face of post-punk was not Rotten
column9: nor even Public Image Ltd.’s John Lydon
column10: but a flower-waving crooner named Morrissey. The year George Orwell had so ominously predicted had finally arrived. But instead of being the vanguard of the resistance against Big Brother
column11: punk was something peddled to King’s Road tourists on the backs of postcards.

column1: In the midst of that
column2: Vex’s sole release
column3: Sanctuary
column4: came out. A four-song 12” issued by Fight Back
column5: an imprint of Conflict’s label Mortarhate
column6: Sanctuary was a part of the collective document of a U.K. anarcho-punk underground that had managed to not only survive
column7: but flourish well into the 80s. Conflict
column8: along with the similarly political Crass
column9: was a leader of the scene; Vex was a minor participant
column10: a footnote to a footnote. The band was also short-lived
column11: which was the order of the day. Crass had previously vowed to break up if it ever lasted long enough to see 1984
column12: although it reneged on that promise
column13: later naming their anthology Best Before 1984 in reference to it. “No future” had come to roost. Accordingly
column14: anarcho-punk bands sounded far more dark
column15: desperate
column16: raw
column17: and apocalyptic than anything at the time (at least this side of a new music springing up in Europe that would come to be called black metal).

column1: Vex had desperation to burn. And on Sanctuary
column2: burn it does. Throbbing with ominous
column3: semi-industrial precision
column4: the song slams along to a martial beat and splintery guitars
column5: a dance track for the gleefully damned. Like a tribe of cyborgs
column6: the band turns anger into something almost mystically ritualistic. It’s an approach Killing Joke had already solidly established by then
column7: and the Killing Joke influence on “Sanctuary” is pronounced—as it is on “It’s No Crime""
column8: whose tense
column9: slashing riffs bears a marked similarity to “The Wait”
column10: one of Killing Joke’s most famous songs. Lead singer Scrote also borrows liberally from Jaz Coleman’s robo-goth howl. But where Killing Joke cloaked its anger in code
column11: Vex was more direct. But not by much. The anarcho-punk approach left little room for poetic half-measures
column12: and “World in Action” spews wrathful outrage even as Scrote chants
column13: in an escalating spasm of stereo-panned paranoia
column14: “There is a theory that this has already happened / There is a theory that this has already happened.” “Relative Sadness” sinks deeper into the ethereal
column15: a clanking skeleton of a song that borders on the early deathrock of Theatre of Hate.

column1: Perhaps realizing that a more oblique attack might be better than a frontal assault

column6: dubby
column7: Adrian Sherwood-produced album Uncarved Block. Sanctuary doesn’t go that far. Vex’s final release
column8: though

column10: a song from Fight Back’s 1985 compilation We Don’t Want Your Fucking Law! that combines Scrote’s knack for panicked anthems with dense percussion and steely sheets of atonal guitar.

column2: “Pain”
column3: and “Pressure”—hail from Vex’s 1983 cassette demo. Flat
column4: lo-fi
column5: and corrosive

column11: from Iceage to Arctic Flowers

column13: in England and elsewhere

column16:
atmospheric passion of Sanctuary has taken care of that for them.

Forget that Malcolm Gladwell ""10
column2: 000 hours"" rap for a second—sometimes

column8: but for others

column10: Shy Boys is far from dazzling: tentative one minute
column11: roughshod the next. But these limitations don't seem to be holding Shy Boys' songcraft back. From these rickety arrangements
column12: they've carved out the kind of sly
column13: spiny
column14:
instinctive hooks any seasoned band would be lucky to stumble upon.

The Shy Boys have dubbed their jangly indie-pop ""landlocked surf music
column15: which
column16: as self-styled descriptors go
column17: isn't half-bad. Rumbling staccato riffs and candied Beach Boys harmonies form the foundation of many of these songs
column18: and there's a late-afternoon haze hanging over even the least sunstroked numbers. There's no shortage of turn-of-the-60s pop in the DNA of these songs

column23: their unschooled approach to songcraft mostly keeps mere imitation at bay. Shy Boys is a short album—ten songs in barely 24 minutes—and songs don't waste a lot of time getting to the point. Hooks are shoved front-and-center
column24: pesky things like bridges fall by the wayside

column27:
they burrow their way into your head that much quicker.

Though singer/guitarist Collin Rausch's lyrics all-too-often get swept up in a sea of reverb
column30: singing with a delicacy that carries his message through the thick coating of Vaseline. The swirling
column31: Shins-gone-surf ""Bully Fight""—inspired by YouTube-infamous meanie Richard Gale—finds Rausch throwing his charmingly thin voice around like a guy with some experience with getting picked on
column32: while the jittery ""And I Am Nervous"" pretty much reviews itself. That nervous energy's a big reason for Shy Boys' success; getting through these songs in one piece lends these songs an urgency that leaves slowpoke ballad ""Submarine"" feeling woozy
column34: these songs never seem more than a couple bum notes from falling apart. But
column35: between that verge-of-collapse sound and unforced
column37: Shy Boys operates with a kind of spluttering grace. These unforced
column39: unshakably catchy songs are awfully easy to like
column40:
and their precarious presentation's just gauzy and peculiar enough to hold together after the dozenth listen.

In a few short years
column41: Ervin and the Rausches haven't just learned how to put a couple chords together; they've figured out how to build songs around their encumbrances

column47:
what they don't know isn't hurting them any.

Last September

column3: writer/Pitchfork contributor Jessica Hopper introduced shortlist nominees Godspeed You! Black Emperor by distilling their many achievements down to a single word: “no.” Which is to say

column9: aren’t so much musical—it’s a logical extension of 2010’s Kollaps Tradixionales—but philosophical: This time
column10: it’s personal. The album is less concerned with asserting a specific worldview than examining the difficulties of keeping one’s moral compass steady in a society that’s becoming ever-more indifferent to the things you value—and how one must remain all the more resolute once kids enter the picture.

column1: Menuck and Moss became parents in recent years; that’s their boy Ezra we hear in the new album’s opening seconds
column2: delivering the band’s simple mission statement: “We live on the island called Montreal
column3: and we make a lot of noise… because we love each other!” The experience of new fatherhood factored into some of the songs on Menuck’s scaled-down 2011 solo release
column4: Plays High Gospel
column5: but that intimate perspective is retained here amid Thee Silver Mt. Zion’s orchestro-punk onslaught
column6: with the band’s usual big-picture concerns intensified by the lingering question of what kind of world their children will inherit.

column1: True to the band’s “Memorial Orchestra” and “Tra-La-La Band” suffixes
column2: Thee Silver Mt. Zion albums have always contrasted eulogy with euphoria
column3: but on Fuck Off Get Free the feelings of joy and terror are one and the same. Rather than use violins to embellish their guitar riffs
column4: the album’s monstrous opening track (which
column5: like Kollaps’ “I Built Myself a Metal Bird” is the rare TSMZ song to just charge out of the gates without an extended build-up) fuses the two into the same dissonant frequency. But amid this sound of confusion
column6: Menuck leads the band in a group chant that’s almost nursery-rhyme-like in its simplicity; that album title may seem like a mouthful to read
column7: but it’s surprisingly easy to sing. Fuck Off Get Free’s most exhilarating song is likewise a maelstrom of conflicted emotions: over the course of its 14 minutes
column8: “Austerity Blues” channels screeching cacophony into rousing catharsis
column9: however
column10: Menuck’s triumphant refrain—“Lord
column11: let my son/ Live long enough/ To see that mountain torn down”—is undercut by the implication that the singer won’t be around to see the better world he’s fighting for. And that latent anxiety comes boiling to surface on the raging “Take Away These Early Grave Blues”
column12: which refines the heavy-metal klemzer heard on Godspeed’s 2012 colossus “Mladic” into a more concentrated burst; Menuck coyly acknowledges this otherwise despairing song’s shout-along accessibility when he fashions a hook—“let them sing our/ pretty songs”—that recalls the similarly sarcastic chorus of Nirvana’s “In Bloom”.

column1: But even the album’s actual pretty songs are suffused with grave prophecies: The deceptively gentle “Little Ones Run”—a piano ballad sung by Trudeau and Moss—presents a bedside lullaby that parents can sing to calm down babies during the next extreme-weather eco-disaster (“Wake up darling the moon is gone/ The sky’s a mess and falling down”). Meanwhile
column2: the album’s emotional centerpiece
column3: “What We Loved Was Not Enough”
column4: is a comment on modern-age ennui that could conceivably waltz its way onto the back half of Arcade Fire’s Reflektor (if that album was a little less disco and a little more Dischord)
column5: however
column6: for Thee Silver Mt. Zion
column7: the cost of apathy is more severe than just social disconnection: “There’ll be war in our cities/ and riots at the mall
column8: ” Menuck warns
column9: before repeating his most chilling prognostication four times—“all our children gonna die.” All the while
column10: the rest of the band sings
column11: “and the day has come
column12: when we no longer feel
column13: ” the sweetest of harmonies couching the bitterest of sentiments—i.e. that numbing oneself to atrocities is the only way to endure them.

column1: And yet
column2: amid this procession of devastation
column3: Menuck sees a sliver of a silver lining
column4: when he sings
column5: “kiss it quick and it’ll rise again
column6: ” and the album’s closing track
column7: “Rains Thru the Roof at the Grande Ballroom (For Capital Steez)”
column8: channels that cautious optimism into a dreamlike haze that's equally haunting and comforting. Its title name-checks the Detroit theatre where The MC5 recorded their incendiary 1968 debut
column9: Kick Out the Jams
column10: and the song is introduced by an interview clip in which guitarist Fred “Sonic” Smith issues a statement of purpose that Thee Silver Mt. Zion could easily claim as their own: “Music is a way of life
column11: it’s more than just something you do on the weekend … it’s something you devote your life to.” But more than simply forge a spiritual connection between Thee Silver Mt. Zion and their proto-punk forefathers
column12: the song’s central image—of a once-legendary venue reduced to ruins—serves as a symbol for the loss of radicalism in popular music.

column1: And through that lens
column2: the parenthetical shout-out to Pro Era rapper Capital Steez—who threw himself off a New York City building in late 2012—makes more sense
column3: as a requiem for a kindred
column4: politically outspoken voice silenced before his time. But for all the sorrow couched in Menuck’s trembling tenor
column5: there is a sign of life amid the Grande Ballroom rubble: “The glass in its windows are still breathing
column6: ” he sings
column7: suggesting the same anti-establishment ethos that fuelled a band of Motor City delinquents in the late-60s
column8: and his own cabal of Montreal outsiders in the late-90s
column9: and a teenaged Brooklyn MC in the early 2010s will persist long after he’s gone. Back in 2003
column10: when this once-instrumental band was still literally finding its voice
column11: Thee Silver Mt. Zion asserted their core ideology by naming their third album This Is Our Punk-Rock
column12: and the increasingly aggressive albums released in the interim have made the members’ hardcore roots all the more apparent. But to ensure that the contrarian
column13: questioning spirit of punk endures through future generations
column14:
Fuck Off Get Free reminds us of one of the key principles of hippiedom: teach your children well.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20090/homepage_large.c96d19d9.jpg|Post Tropical|31811.0|James Vincent McMorrow|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vagrant']|2014-01-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:57.459656|"

There's a shot that crops up often in nature documentaries or early in the third act of movies that focus on a character's personal growth: An icicle slowly melts in tentative drips
column2: or a cluster of pine needles covered in snow suddenly shakes off its crystalline burden. It's a shot that communicates things like “time has passed
column3: slowly but surely” and “the character you're about to see has been through some deep contemplation!” But it works because there is something about the stark calm of late winter that seems to match up with those periodic spells of reflection
column4: the slow
column5: occasional seasons we spend gradually and deliberately healing or learning. They stretch on forever and then are suddenly complete. They feel like a dream.

column1: Irish singer James Vincent McMorrow's sophomore effort Post Tropical is an album that seems suited to such seasons. It's a winter album in ways that go beyond its release date
column2: with lyrics about “elements of frost” and “cold air” and taut
column3: pensive songs that carry a pristine stillness. There are spare
column4: open moments of longing vocals over solitary piano notes and stabs of sunny revelations in the periodic horn arrangements and cymbal crashes. Above all
column5: Post Tropical is pretty. It's also the type of music to grow with for a little while as a personal soundtrack
column6: a companion for a few months that one might fondly check in with from time to time later on.

column1: If the album has that intimacy
column2: it's likely because Post Tropical comes as a more personal turn for McMorrow. His first album
column3: Early In The Morning
column4: was a comforting collection of guitar folk that found unexpected acclaim and commercial success
column5: charting well in several European countries and landing McMorrow high-profile performances on Later... With Jools Holland and elsewhere. But the acoustic guitar wasn't
column6: according to McMorrow
column7: what he intended to stake his career on. Inspired by the rediscovery of an old hard drive full of efforts at recreating N.E.R.D. songs
column8: the resulting departure on Post Tropical is an attempt to channel the spirit of the electronic music
column9: R&B and hip-hop that McMorrow likes to listen to.

column1: In practice
column2: the new bent means mostly swapping out the guitars for pianos and horns and using the occasional swatch of electronic drums. Although it does passingly resemble the low wattage D'Angelo tributes that get passed off on many blogs as R&B
column3: to call Post Tropical that does a disservice to both the genre and the album. McMorrow's falsetto
column4: already impressive
column5: gets pushed to new heights that could call to mind Maxwell but are more likely to inspire comparisons to others in the indie and folk sphere like Bon Iver's Justin Vernon or the Antlers' Pete Silberman
column6: particularly given the lyrical tone and a backing template that might feel at home on projects by either of those acts.

column1: That voice is McMorrow's best tool
column2: confessional and energizing whether he's hitting the unexpected climax of “there's no sense at all” on “Glacier” or using it to construct a plaintive mantra at the end of “Red Dust” with the repeated lyric
column3: “sometimes my hands they don't feel like my own/ I need someone to love I need someone to hold.” The tone is pained
column4: but the effect is both beautiful and comforting throughout
column5: particularly in the way the album's songs often build to a single yearning
column6: repeated phrase
column7: like “I remember my first love” or “there is so little light from the warmth of the sun.”

column1: Lyrically
column2: the material is generally more oriented toward pulling emotions out of specific sounds of syllables than cohering into clear narratives or even realistic images (consider
column3: for instance
column4: that last line
column5: from “Outside
column6: Digging”
column7: which sounds right but actually reverses cause and effect between light and warmth we're used to). The overall effect can be a little bit free associative
column8: and it plays into the album's biggest weakness: While these songs are pretty
column9: they don't really stand out as songs so much as meandering compositions that follow a similar
column10: slow crescendo formula. There's nothing with the immediate structure or dramatic pull of a song like Early in the Morning's “We Don't Eat”.

column1: But if the album does tend to drift rather than deliver hits
column2: the drifting is awfully pleasant and particularly accomplished. Songs like “Cavalier”
column3: “Outside
column4: Digging” and especially “Red Dust”
column5: an arresting blend of 808 drum machines and swirling piano
column6: hit such memorable vocal highs that they feel both instantly familiar and starkly refreshing. At the same time
column7: many of the best moments are more subtle surprises: the keening country guitars that swoop through the background of “The Lakes”
column8: the flitter of clarinet that plays atop the plink of guitars at the end of “All Points”
column9: the gorgeous depth of the low horn notes that build to the climax of “Glacier”. With its deliberate
column10: languorous pleasures
column11: this is an album to live with
column12:
settle with and be crisply rejuvenated by.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20050/homepage_large.20dfe341.jpg|Strong Feelings|29391.0|Doug Paisley|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['No Quarter']|2014-01-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:58.038177|"

For Doug Paisley
column2: a tender-hearted stoic from Toronto whose songs land on the sweet spot between Kris Kristofferson and Gordon Lightfoot
column3: the language of country music puts poetry into the mundane heartbreaks and setbacks of daily existence. On his third album <i>Strong Feelings
column4: Paisley seeks refuge in the beauty of the romantic lyrical metaphors that have populated the genre since at least the heyday of Hank Williams. “The ice it breaks the midday sun / in springtime when the river runs
column5: ” he sings in “My Love”
column6: one of the album’s most bracingly pretty numbers. Essentially
column7: Paisley is saying
column8: “Nature tends to stay in motion
column9: so no matter how hard or deeply you love something it’s going to leave you eventually.” But it sounds so much sweeter the way he says it.

column1: Mortality is Paisley’s central theme; every life is overshadowed by the omnipresence of death
column2: every romantic relationship dimmed by the inevitability of eventual separation. This is the subject matter of a zillion country songs
column3: of course
column4: but unlike that other
column5: more famous country singer named Paisley (whose song “This is Country Music” extols the virtues of songwriting limned with the tangible directness of everyday language)
column6: Doug Paisley hears a song on the radio and feels suddenly lifted toward transcendence. “I turned the radio on 25 years ago/ And they were playing your song/ I looked for you on the town
column7: thought I was tracking you down/ But you were there all along
column8: ” he croons on the gently chugging “Radio Girl”
column9: and he’s either addressing an actual woman or equating what he’s just heard grace the airwaves with a long-lost love. In Doug Paisley’s songs
column10: distinguishing between what’s “real” and what’s felt scarcely matters.

column1: After a dues-paying tenure as a classic country covers act and the release of his understated self-titled 2008 debut
column2: Paisley broke through in 2010 with his sophomore effort
column3: Constant Companion
column4: which was helped along by high-profile co-stars like Leslie Feist and the Band’s Garth Hudson. For Feelings
column5: Paisley retains producer Stew Crookes and Hudson
column6: who contributes crisp and cozy organ lines to five of the album’s 10 tracks that are so warm you want to rub your hands over them. (His playing on “Song My Love Can Sing” is by itself the worth the price of admission.) Subbing in for Feist on harmony vocals is legendary Canadian singer-songwriter Mary Margaret O’Hara
column7: who adds another layer of winsome melancholy to “It’s Not Too Late (To Say Goodbye)”. The album’s main musical ingredients—finger-picked guitar
column8: lightly brushed drums
column9: relaxed though subtly emotive vocals—knowingly recall the quietest
column10: most pained cuts on 70s outlaw country records and the twangiest numbers on that era’s rock-leaning singer-songwriter LPs.

column1: Musically
column2: Strong Feelings reiterates Constant Companion
column3: which is fine
column4: because it’s a good formula and Paisley’s songs are stronger this time. (He even musters up something resembling swagger on the steadily rocking “To and Fro”.) It’s a sound that comes wrapped in a warm glow of nostalgia that’s undercut by lyrics revealing the slow poison of lingering too long on your memories. “I turned the ground and found the roots still burning/ A night moon that lingers in a blue sky brings a yearning/ If it takes a waterfall to drown all my doubts/ Sometimes it takes a lie to let me know what it’s all about
column5: ” Paisley says in “Old Times”. Sometimes a song on the radio can feel like self-delusion in the cold
column6: hard light of experience. No matter the short-term pleasure it provides
column7:
life marches inexorably toward an uncertain destination. But Paisley seems content to turn it up anyway and let the music carry him away to a better place.  

"|18853.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18853-doug-paisley-strong-feelings/|7.5|Steven Hyden

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20096/homepage_large.6bded353.jpg|Shelter|5913.0|Alcest|['Rock'
column2:
'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Prophecy']|2014-01-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:58.552204|"

Like Opeth’s Heritage or Darkthrone’s The Cult is Alive
column3: Alcest’s Shelter is the sound of a band that has undergone a decisive yet inevitable metamorphosis. In all these cases
column4: extreme metal was the chrysalis or catalyst; what emerged wasn’t the same as what came before. Opeth shed death metal for bucolic prog; Darkthrone bent black metal toward d-beat crust. Neither came as a total surprise
column5: and neither does Shelter. Alcest have been slowly turning away from the corrosive
column6: ambient metal of their early work—a sound that’s influenced many
column7: most notably Deafheaven—toward an unbroken dreamscape of cushiony shoegaze. Shelter marks that clean break. The French outfit’s fourth full-length is a statement of soft-spoken apostasy that’s unflinching in its resolve. And somewhat less than stellar in its execution.

column1: The friction between ethereality and aggression is what made Alcest’s prior albums
column2: and in particular 2010’s Écailles de Lune
column3: so gripping. Quiet
column4: chiming guitars meshed with thunderous riffs
column5: and liquid-nitrogen synths bled into a bath of warm
column6: soft vocals. Neige
column7: the driving force behind Alcest
column8: has allowed that friction to dissipate. What’s left feels wrung-out. Shelter’s eight songs are among the prettiest Neige has ever composed
column9: with the happy-sad chords and bell-like hook of “Opale” bearing an unmistakable to resemblance to Chapterhouse’s “Breather”. But even Chapterhouse
column10: among the wispiest of shoegaze groups
column11: put more propulsion and surprise into their songs. Throughout Shelter that delicacy never lets up. Some tracks
column12: like “La Nuit Marche Avec Moi” and “Voix Sereines”
column13: muster enough determination to step on a distortion pedal. Beyond that
column14: every element—from Neige’s whispery melodies to the shimmering sameness of the guitar—sticks unswervingly to the path of least resistance.

column1: Shelter leaves no room for the questioning of its shoegaze credentials. Slowdive’s Neil Halstead is brought aboard to sing the lead vocals on “Away”
column2: yet the shoegaze founding father sounds more deflated than dreamy as he moans through the song’s vaguely chamber-folk arrangement. Something is supposed to be evoked here: bemused melancholy
column3: maybe
column4: or wistful longing
column5: or pensive detachment. Whatever it is
column6: it never coheres or connects. At least it’s a break in the fog
column7: even if it only offers a slightly bluer hue of featureless prettiness. The album was recorded in Iceland at Sigur Rós’ studio
column8: Sundlaugin
column9: with Sigur Rós producer Birgir Jón Birgisson
column10: but it doesn’t sound appreciably different than Alcest’s previous output—let alone allow for much internal variation.

column1: The 10-minute closer “Délivrance” nearly reaches escape velocity
column2: a listless spiral of gossamer pop with brief bursts of distorted lucidity. It too collapses under its own lack of weight. Neige has stated in the past that Alcest is a project devoted to realizing in song his visions of otherworldly fantasy and wonder. In chasing that devotion
column3: the songs themselves have been cast adrift. Still capable of great feats of mood and beauty
column4: Alcest have transformed themselves
column5: although not always in the best way. They’ve gone from being a remarkably innovative
column6: influential
column7: and singular force in a subgenre they helped create to being just another shoegaze act. That doesn’t make Shelter a bad album. As an aural analgesic
column8: it goes down smooth and numbs what it needs to. But instead of tearing open the passageway between this world and whatever lies beyond
column9:
it shrinks that portal to the size of a keyhole.

"|18901.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18901-alcest-shelter/|6.6|Jason Heller

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20079/homepage_large.35f3e207.jpg|Edges|31285.0|Graze|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New Kanada']|2014-01-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:48:59.084471|"

Appearing early last year at a time when many formerly “post-dubstep” artists were flaunting their conversions to straight house and techno
column2: the self-titled EP from Toronto duo Graze adopted a more subtle and perhaps challenging strategy: what would a techno that had actually digested the sounds and tactics of the “bass” era sound like? There are several other records that arguably provide an answer to this question whether anyone asked it or not
column3: but it’s hard to think of an example that does so as consummately as Graze
column4: whose six tracks between them drew a detailed map of the hidden paths between the febrile percussion and garage swing of the post-dubstep era and “proper” techno’s motorway velocity
column5: managing to sound simultaneously classicist and inventive in the process.

column1: The verb “digested” is used deliberately here
column2: since the vibe of Adam Marshall and Christian Andersen’s music seems to privilege techno’s sonic preoccupations
column3: even if only by presenting the duo’s more fashionable production tactics (quantised percussion
column4: chopped breaks
column5: lasciviously thick hi-hats) as nothing particularly special or fetish-worthy in their own right. Instead
column6: those conventions are more useful as components to be woven into broader homages to techno’s hypnotic propulsion. And the metaphor of digestion helps to make sense of the duo’s exploration of their blueprint on their latest effort. Edges technically is Graze’s debut album
column7: though given the preceding EP just fell short of 40 minutes
column8: the distinction seems largely academic. And the differences between Graze and Edges even feel like a classic first album/second album progression: Graze offering a fully-formed and distinct aesthetic which its follow-up then strips down to its absolute bare essentials.

column1: As flagged by the cold modernism of the album cover (the sharp right angle where two metal bars meet)
column2: on tracks like “Cold Drop”
column3: “Airror” and “Stack Array” it’s as if Graze are deliberately targeting and exterminating the sense of warmth that once bubbled up through their grooves
column4: now living on only as fossilised remnants. What manages to survive this deliberate purge is the duo’s exacting approach to beat programming
column5: deployed with such precision that it’s easy not to notice just how spare some of these arrangements are. Even when Graze are leaning hard on the steady thump of a kickdrum
column6: the choice feels conscious and precarious
column7: as if at any point the groove might become pulled out of orbit by a latticework of stern
column8: stiff-jointed counter-rhythms and ominous basslines. “Cold Drop” in particular makes a virtue of minimalism
column9: its stentorian groove built around the queasy shudder of a one-note dub bass throb
column10: but it never feels minimal. Instead
column11: the progressive introduction of (a very small number of) new elements takes on an air of occasion and unpredictability
column12: as if the sudden arrival of a threatening
column13: throbbing metallic bass riff was an unexpected new twist in an unfolding melodrama.

column1: There are some exceptions to the new world order. Most notably
column2: opener “Skip/Crush” lives up to its title with a swung groove that seems to flutter against its own confines
column3: its bittersweet synth chords rubbing up against the beat in a manner that feels almost tremulous
column4: while “GoldN” offers a dreamy broken beat scape reminiscent of the first Dettinger album. But as lovely as these moments are
column5: and notwithstanding the success with which Graze tackle more straight-laced rhythms
column6: Edges misses some of the startling charm of the debut EP’s experiments with syncopation. This is less a problem for this album than
column7: perhaps
column8: what Graze might do next: if these qualities get further digested to the point of imperceptibility
column9: then Graze might simply become another good techno outfit. Which is fine
column10: but less exciting than the potential alternative paths you can still hear stretching out from this music.

column1: Graze would do well to give their narrativist impulse freer rein and find out where it takes them: Edges’ most startling and compelling track is “Scrap”
column2: an almost comically Spartan concoction of sharply syncopated programmed beats and slivering synth-bass sludge which imagines a form of minimalist techno grown entirely from the starting point of Cabaret Voltaire circa 1984. Whereas the album’s more resolutely techno efforts make the (familiar) point that a reduced palette of sounds can allow for a more involved listener experience
column3: “Scrap” sidesteps the issue entirely by virtue of its almost impolite rhythmic boldness. Less digestion
column4: then
column5: than symbiotic transformation
column6:
the host and the pathogen combining to form organisms neither could have anticipated.

"|18883.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18883-graze-edges/|7.2|Tim Finney

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20091/homepage_large.ebf5c60d.jpg|Rave Tapes|2801.0|Mogwai|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-01-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:48:59.701852|"

Mogwai operate in a small space
column2: where change decelerates into their music in lightly perceptible ways. Rave Tapes
column3: the band's eighth album outside of their soundtrack and remix work
column4: has been built up for its increased use of electronics
column5: with a debt partially owed to the vintage synth scores that have held a sustained (and seemingly ever-increasing) influence over a huge swathe of underground artists. The first song to be released from the album
column6: ""Remurdered""
column7: certainly hinted that analog sounds would form a more rigorous backbone to their music than before
column8: although they've been dabbling in this area since Rock Action in 2001. In truth
column9: ""Remurdered"" is something of a red herring. If that song feels like a fuller manifestation of ideas that have taken over a decade for Mogwai to reach
column10: Rave Tapes mostly tells a different story—one that digs harder into a place they've consistently circled back to throughout their career.

column1: This is the second Mogwai album in less than a year
column2: following their creepy 2013 soundtrack to the French TV show Les Revenants. That album is among the most introspective work they've ever recorded—no mean feat for a band so inward facing—and it's a tone they've only modestly advanced on for Rave Tapes. It's not hard to pull all the elements together and theorize at how they arrived at the humorous title for the record
column3: which reads as a direct inverse to the morose worldview of the album and a poke at anyone thinking they’ve ""gone electronic."" Still
column4: that's hard to square with a track like ""Master Card""
column5: where the circular guitar motions they so often make remain front and center
column6: and the analog sounds skirting across the surface only serve to keep familiar dynamics intact. The past hangs heavy on the shoulders of these guys
column7: seemingly always keeping them in check even when you think they've reached a point of separation with it.

column1: It's been 17 years since Mogwai’s debut
column2: Young Team. That album emerged with stories of the band members taking on assumed identities and shaving their heads before entering the studio—a totemic representation of their full-blooded commitment to the cause
column3: analogous to going into battle. It isn't hard to figure out who the major influences were on the band back then
column4: but Mogwai had a combative feel that many of their peers shied away from. They had the air of a band that you committed to
column5: that you argued over. There's been a natural fade away from that youthful starting point
column6: as well there should be—it's not really befitting for a group of dads in their late 30s to enter a recording studio like they’re going to bootcamp. But still
column7: there are elements left behind that could benefit from being intact on Rave Tapes
column8: such as the astonishing ebb and flow of ""Mogwai Fear Satan""
column9: or even odd impulses like getting Roky Erickson to guest on a track. Instead
column10: it's hard to see what this offers that we don't already have.

column1: Rave Tapes is the work of an oddly conservative band
column2: turning away from the openness they once embraced. At some point Mogwai got less interested in testing the boundaries of their music
column3: instead settling for being comfortable working within them. The bass-y keyboard grind that emerges at times is a new appendage
column4: but the material it's dressed up in strains under the weight of familiarity
column5: ultimately resembling an exercise in Mogwai box-ticking. So here comes the Codeine-lite vocal piece (""Blues Hour"")
column6: here comes the one with the vocoder (""The Lord is Out of Control"")
column7: here comes the one with the funny title (""Simon Ferocious"")
column8: here comes the one with the sampled spoken word dialogue (""Repelish""). It's hard to shake the feeling that this is a band trapped in their own creation
column9: occasionally looking for somewhere else to go but unable or unwilling to fully get there.

column1: Most groups don't leave behind the core signifiers that bring them attention in the first place
column2: so Mogwai are far from an isolated case when it comes to looping back on themselves. In many ways they're victims of their earlier snottiness and ambition. The screaming guitars of ""Like Herod""
column3: the sheer beauty of ""Helicon 2""
column4: the bratty spat with Blur
column5: the punk nihilism of calling an album Come On Die Young—they don't need to return to such things
column6: but it does make the level of complacency they're operating at now such a baffling and frustrating end game to it all. At this point it feels like there isn't anywhere else they can go with this music
column7: so infinitesimally small are the strides taken toward a better place. Mogwai have worked heavily in the visual realm in the last year
column8: on Les Revenants and a live performance of their Zidane soundtrack. Maybe the cliché about instrumental bands creating ""soundtracks for films that don't exist"" has a grain of truth for them after all. Here
column9:
Mogwai’s cautionary approach all but drowns out the faint echoes of the once brave band struggling to get out from within.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20053/homepage_large.52cddaa1.jpg|Killed by Deathrock: Vol. 1|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2014-01-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:00.293169|"

Though the title hints at the obscure horror-obsessed subgenre of punk
column2: the new compilation series on the ever-savvy Sacred Bones takes after the Killed By Death series of compilations. Those storied records focused around obscure music from the late 70s punk explosion
column3: and they're a clear precursor for the Brooklyn label's newest venture. It's the fruit of a search for weird and hard-to-find music from the same space that founder Caleb Braaten has been undertaking since 2007. The result does for post-punk what Nuggets did for late 60s garage rock
column4: unearthing bizarre bands who produce oddities and competent facsimiles of more popular bands in equal measure. But also like <i>Nuggets
column5: what makes Killed By Deathrock so invigorating is that it's simply so fun—just put it on
column6: let it rip
column7:
and make sure you play it loud.

Whatever idea ""deathrock"" might bring to mind
column8: throw it away—from the opening moments of Your Funeral's ""I Wanna Be You
column9: it's a surprisingly sprightly
column10: even bouncy album that's more hi-fidelity than you'd expect. The jangly guitars on the first track practically pop-out in 3D
column11: and most of the others follow suit
column12: underlining what was either a careful search for the master tapes or simply some remastering wizardry. The compilation's best moments are these buoyant ones—Afterimage's ""Satellite Of Love"" (not a Lou Reed cover) is a meaty anthem with a stellar vocal performance
column13: while fellow Americans Screaming For Emily steal the spotlight with ""The Love""
column14:
whose sly vocal performance could be a precursor for Britpop were it not for the excited drumming and wonderfully cheesy choral synth work.

As with so many post-punk also-rans
column15: the spectre of Joy Division hangs heavy over the compilation (try not to hear ""Transmission"" in the central riff of ""Satellite Of Love""). Peter Hook basslines are the order of the day. Sometimes it's bald-faced
column16: as with Italian obscurities Move
column17: and sometimes it's a bit more clever
column18: like Frenchmen Bunker (later Bunker Strasse)
column19:
who take the production style of Unknown Pleasures and give it a good coat of fuzz. The undeniable pilfering is an artifact of the compilation's nature—it's a collection of pleasing offcuts rather than long lost gems.

Not that there aren't some of those. Germany's Taste Of Decay are more punk than post
column20: and their cheap entry-level distortion feels viscerally satisfying next to the other bands' chillier styles of production. The aptly-named Kitchen & The Plastic Spoons (a short-lived Swedish ""goof band"") sound like Magazine gone mad with wriggly synths and hilariously affected vocals. The latter are an especially weird inclusion
column21: and it highlights the best part of Killed By Deathrock—discovering these strange little bands that time forgot.  Not all of them are worth exploring
column22: certainly
column23:
but bands like Screaming For Emily (and their 1987 album Scriptures) and Bunker Strasse bear further investigation.

None of that would matter if the compilation weren't well-executed. But from the clever artwork to the sound quality
column25: and the urge of so many compilation curators to pack a CD within an inch of its life is forgone in favour of a highly listenable 40-minute album. Considering it spans almost a whole decade
column26: it's remarkably well-sequenced too—you might not guess that Screaming For Emily came a whole seven years later than Kitchen & The Plastic Spoons. Killed By Deathrock is clearly a well-researched labour of love. It might seem a bit slight for seven years in the making
column27:
but hopefully that just means there'll be more down the line.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20062/homepage_large.758a8082.jpg|The Invention of Animals|31956.0|The John Lurie National Orchestra|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Amulet']|2014-01-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:00.918975|"

John Lurie has always had a big personality. If you’ve seen him act in films
column2: all you need to hear is titles like Stranger Than Paradise and Down By Law to be reminded of his distinctive speaking and gesturing. Yet even though he can steal a scene
column3: he rarely comes across as an egotist. In fact
column4: he’s usually a consummate collaborator. Though his most recent pursuit
column5: painting
column6: is a solo venture
column7: he has mostly preferred collectivism
column8: from the no wave films he directed in the late 70s
column9: to his 90s pseudo-nature-show ""Fishing With John"" (in which he bantered masterfully with Tom Waits
column10: Willem Dafoe
column11: and Dennis Hopper)
column12: to his most communal project
column13: the punk-informed jazz outfit Lounge Lizards
column14: whose rotating lineup included at least 30 different members.

column1: This penchant for collaboration extended even to the band that took his name
column2: the John Lurie National Orchestra
column3: who sounded more like a democratic group than a star vehicle. This despite the fact that they were just a trio
column4: comprising Lurie on saxophones and Billy Martin and Calvin Weston—both Lounge Lizards—on drums. That instrumental setup makes Lurie obstensibly the leader
column5: and indeed on The Invention of Animals —a posthumous collection of live recordings and studio tracks used for ""Fishing With John"" episodes—his playing is more free-flowing than the steady
column6: loop-like drumming of his colleagues. But it never feels like Lurie is the commander and Martin and Weston are soldiers following orders. Every sonic element is equally important
column7: and the mesh the three men weave forms both the spine and the heart of each track.

column1: The result of that mesh is a restrained
column2: subdued record. The trio is in no hurry to get anywhere other than where they started
column3: and more interested in stitching patterns together than fighting for elbow room. Filled with repetition and space
column4: this isn’t exactly trance music
column5: but it certainly has a way of making you feel hypnotized. So the tension on The Invention of Animals comes not from rapid shifts in tempo or volume
column6: but smaller
column7: more subtle variations. Playing things this low and understated can be risky; it would be easy for the group to drift into colorless new age reverie. But even the mellowest moments bubble with ideas and energy.

column1: That’s true even in the few instances where Lurie steps out in front of his comrades. Take the ballad-like “Little”
column2: which is practically a Lurie solo. Here
column3: his wistful soprano notes are central
column4: but tiny clicks of percussion in the background are just as crucial
column5: giving charge to a piece that could otherwise freeze. Similar dynamics mark the beginning of Invention’s peak
column6: the closing title track. The build here is particularly mind-bending
column7: as the trio navigate a series of crests by precisely modulating their levels of activity and pressure. Yet that precision never sounds clinical. There’s blood coursing through every second of the piece
column8: in a way that makes it feel half its 19-minute length.

column1: So much blood
column2: in fact
column3: that it’s hard to fathom why the John Lurie National Orchestra isn’t an ongoing concern. Lurie himself has been out of the public eye in recent years
column4: at least compared to his busy presence in the 80s and 90s as an always-interesting actor
column5: director
column6: and musician. If you’re unfamiliar with that latter role
column7: there are some great Lounge Lizards records out there waiting for you. But The Invention of Animals is just as good a place to start
column8:
and hopefully it will help get people talking again about a man who’s carved out one of the most unique American artistic careers of the past four decades.

"|18865.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18865-the-john-lurie-national-orchestra-the-invention-of-animals/|7.5|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20088/homepage_large.5aaded2d.jpg|Fabriclive 73|28648.0|Pangaea|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2014-01-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:02.185086|"

Let's get this out of the way nice and early: Kevin McAuley is the least well-known member of Hessle Audio. He may well be the most idiosyncratic man operating in a trio that hardly prides itself on taking route one
column2: something of a bellwether for the label's more esoteric tendencies. Short of the lung-busting run undertaken by Pearson Sound (née Ramadanman) across 2010
column3: and without the worldie acclaim lavished upon Ben UFO for his ability to satiate crowds of thousands with unheralded obscurities
column4: McAuley has just never had a major moment. A couple of clear-cut chances arose--surging hype following half-junglist
column5: half-mentalist behemoth ""Hex""; the opportunity to usher in Hessle's first definitive full-length--and duly passed--over a year's silence; the thorny and unmoored Release
column6: flaunted as a double EP in spite of its 43-minute runtime. This likely won't raise Pangaea's profile beyond the usual bounce
column7: but you get the sense he's comfortable with that.

column1: Which makes it all the more pleasing that McAuley bites his tongue and chooses to play it straight on the techno-centric Fabriclive 73
column2: a seriously enjoyable
column3: three-dimensional installment in the long-running series that exudes confidence at every turn. The Fabric name doubles up as a seal of quality
column4: imbuing each commercial mix with a lofty expectation
column5: but how jocks wield the weapon varies greatly. Shelved adjacent to recent editions by affiliates such as Oneman
column6: replete with belters to carve up the dance
column7: the contrasts are stark. Even his aforementioned comrades' logs in the guestbook offered more concessions than this: 56 juggled disparate styles but quickly settled on big-hitters (Joy Orbison
column8: Burial
column9: Wiley) while 67 shuffled classic material from Larry Heard and Matthew Herbert into the pack alongside more specialist fare. McAuley simply rolls up his sleeves
column10: tacks a ""No Requests"" sign to the booth window
column11: and kicks off.

column1: Given every mix is a snapshot of something
column2: here McAuley uses his vaunted platform to articulate a compelling case for the state of the UK techno in 2014
column3: facilitating a digestible entry point for those looking to throw themselves headfirst into the trenches. The mix may not shine especial light onto any one trend in particular--you'd need your ears planted pretty firmly to the ground to pick much out of the tracklist--but that represents a key facet of precisely why excitement continues to froth. A scene typecast as cloistered and cagey appears wide open
column4: glowing with a vitality no doubt borne of a brisk influx of new faces
column5: internally migrating from other colonies in droves. Thankfully McAuley avoids cronyism
column6: instead drawing upon a healthy Continental contingent and packing in a multitude of different styles under the genre umbrella
column7: scraping off the extremities and compacting them into his own winding vision.

column1: He opts to tee up one of his own
column2: the hitherto unreleased ""Recreational Slumming""
column3: as if to deliver a pithy
column4: polite bow before getting on with it. Immediately established
column5: that clunking kick thud largely operates as a constant
column6: a tour guide as McAuley applies variegations of light and shade all around it. The opening run bounds through eight tracks in 20 minutes
column7: bearing down through a dense thicket of background detail at speed
column8: often rendering artists as motion blurs: the hollowed atmospherics of jungle repairman Lee Gamble's ""Plos 97"" naturally slides into Hodge's ""Resolve""
column9: a track writhing with unresolved tension; static cracks begin to emerge in Shifted's hardbodied cut before they split open
column10: revealing a floor of swarming
column11: chattering insects in Manni Dee’s “Romantic Self” down the way; in both cases
column12: whole tracks were devoured in between.

column1: McAuley's mixing is fluid
column2: using one-touch bursts of bass to denote new arrivals
column3: employing some intermingling blends but generally delivering rightward swipes off the assembly line once tracks serve their purpose. By lacing rhythms together with dainty flair he keeps a good thrust going
column4: applying the brakes at choice moments when the runaway momentum encroaches on exhausting. One sole misstep comes after the impressively varied midsection
column5: when Adam Jay's dull ""Refraction"" threatens to break the spell
column6: reminiscent of waiting in a lengthy bathroom queue
column7: sound filtering weakly through from the dancefloor; thankfully Pearson Sound's enormous rattler ""Starbust"" lives up to its billing
column8: taking a boltgun and blasting a hole clean through the drywall. Two more of last year’s highlights
column9: Stenny & Andrea's ""Sea (The Time Gate)"" and Pev & Kowton's ""End Point""
column10: are repurposed as memorable bridges
column11: melodies floating above the mass below.

column1: It takes until the Exposure edit of Speedy J's 1992 fistpumper ""Something For Your Mind""—one of only two cuts predating 2011—for a vocal to worm its way in
column2: the infectious refrain slicing through the spine of the mix
column3: a total highlight. From there the frame begins to collapse. Thick
column4: rough-edged stacks topple in quick succession
column5: until the sediment crumbles from beneath
column6: leaving Astronomical Telegram to finally disappear into the sinkhole. Fabriclive 73 is complex and confrontational but resolutely unshowy
column7: an honest indication of the kind of pummeling 3am set you would have heard McAuley bang out over the past 18 months; all told
column8:
a worthy completion of the Hessle triptych and an excellent standalone in its own right.
