column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20115/homepage_large.ec7e601b.jpg|Gay Disco|31915.0|Guerilla Toss|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['NNA Tapes']|2014-01-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:02.750350|"

If you attended a shitty basement party thrown by reasonably hip people at almost any point during George W. Bush's first term
column2: there's a good chance you saw a band that sounded a lot like Boston five-piece Guerilla Toss. Entertainment! was most likely on the stereo
column3: someone was wearing <a href=""http://thequietus.com/articles/03297-lightning-bolt-interview-earthly-delights-the-quest-for-the-sacred-mask"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">a raggedy
column4: technicolor Brian Chippendale mask
column5: and there was probably a guy walking around with his dick hanging out. While it's been some time since anyone's uttered the words ""dance punk"" in any valuable context
column6: Guerilla Toss seem hell bent on stirring up a noisy revival that's more no wave than new wave. Channeling everything from the fractured funk of pre-Echoes Rapture
column7: Black Dice's anti-grooves
column8: and the tinnitus-beckoning mania of Lightning Bolt
column9: their latest LP Gay Disco is a freak-flag waving love letter for a time when the weirdos learned to stop worrying and love getting down in as awkward a fashion as possible.

column1: For an album that sounds as haphazard and caustic as Gay Disco does
column2: each instrument seems designed to play a very specific role. Eschewing a traditional sense of tunefulness
column3: Guerilla Toss bring the back of the band to the fore
column4: relying on Simon Hanes' skronked-out bass and drummer Peter Negroponte's everything-but-the-kitchen-sink thrash to do most of the heavy lifting. Arian Shaifee's guitar (and Ian Kovac's synth work
column5: for that matter) seems like an afterthought most of the time
column6: operating like a sound effects machine rather than an object capable of creating melody (on ""Operate""
column7: it calls to mind a wounded seal pup helplessly honking for its mother). But the most noteworthy instrument of all might be Kassie Carlson's vocals
column8: that range between a tuned-up Kathleen Hanna and
column9: as most are quick to notice
column10: Molly Siegel of Ponytail. Despite how unintelligible her squawking might be
column11: there's an invigorating brattiness that
column12: in a small way
column13: is welcomingly reminiscent of those now-defunct Baltimore art-punks.

column1: If the title wasn't any sort of a giveaway
column2: it's clear that Gay Disco is a record that encourages movement
column3: no matter how spastic it may be. When Guerilla Toss find reliable stretches of groove
column4: like on single ""Pink Elephant"" (an abrasive take on early Gang Gang Dance)
column5: it's easy to enjoy Gay Disco as a functional expression of wiggy
column6: wild energy. Even the nauseous
column7: acidic ""Operate"" feels tailor-made to accompany the undulations of a drunken marionette. But Gay Disco ultimately operates like a series of clumsily threaded distractions
column8: constantly trying to prove its irreverence with vertigo-inducing tempo changes and abrasion for the sake of abrasion. Where a band like Ponytail were able to coax beauty
column9: color
column10: and catharsis out of the wreckage
column11: Guerilla Toss' similarly clamorous approach registers as almost gimmicky.

column1: Heralded for their energetic live shows
column2: it's likely Gay Disco translates much better in person
column3: able to finally make good on its intent to be simultaneously punchy and debilitating. But in the comfort of your own headphones
column4: it's migraine-inducing even at a half hour
column5: a record that should be the furthest thing from your reach even during the mildest of hangovers. To say that it's all a bit much would be an understatement
column6: but neglecting to embrace that on some level would be to miss the point entirely. And still
column7: something here registers as hollow
column8:
as Gay Disco is more a test of patience than an example of eccentric fun.

"|18920.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18920-guerilla-toss-gay-disco/|6.0|Zach Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20028/homepage_large.9eea4ef4.jpg|Bad Debt|30386.0|Hiss Golden Messenger|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Paradise of Bachelors']|2014-01-17 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:03.413464|"

The story of how Bad Debt was destroyed has eclipsed the story of how it was created. M.C. Taylor wrote these songs in the months following the birth of his son in 2009
column2: then he recorded them in the dead of the North Carolina winter on a cassette recorder at his kitchen table
column3: playing softly so as not to wake the household. Taylor was all set to release those recordings as Bad Debt
column4: his first wide release as Hiss Golden Messenger
column5: but the CD stock was destroyed during the London riots of 2010
column6: when his distributor’s warehouse was burned. The opening chords of “No Lord Is Free” sound all the more resolute for cutting so gingerly through the ambient hiss of Taylor’s kitchen.

column1: It’s almost impossible to imagine the magnitude of such a setback for any artist
column2: but especially for one trying to launch a new venture. That story has attached itself like a tall tale to the album
column3: at least for those intrigued listeners who have dug deeper into Taylor’s catalog following the subsequent release of Poor Moon in 2011 and the mighty Haw in 2013. Yet neither story affects how we hear these modest and deeply moving songs three years later
column4: when Bad Debt is finally getting a proper release—with three new tracks—via the Tar Heel State indie Paradise of Bachelors. There are two reasons this tale of tribulation persists: First
column5: it exposes the consequences of that fire and makes very real the sense of monetary and professional loss. Second—and much
column6: much more crucial—that fire seems almost biblical in nature
column7: as though God Himself reached down and smote Taylor. It is a tribulation worthy of Job.

column1: “Are you with me now”? Taylor sing-whispers at the very start of the album. He delivers the line in a hush
column2: even before the guitar enters
column3: and that question resonates as both a gentle invitation to the listener and an invocation of a heavenly host. Bad Debt is an album deeply concerned with the nature of faith and man’s relationship with his Maker. That title pretty much sums up the spiritual dynamic
column4: although who owes what to whom remains mysterious and unresolved. The homespun quality of these recordings is crucial: They are raw and rough
column5: humble and private.

column1: He makes good use of that room. Listening to these dozen songs
column2: you can almost measure its dimensions. That space and the lo-fi recording technology create a rustic reverb
column3: as his strums and singing reverberate quietly against the walls. To that simple palette—which recalls the Tallest Man on Earth at his most reserved or M. Ward at his most forceful—Taylor adds what sounds like a foot tapping against the floor to “Straw Man Red Sun River Gold” and “The Serpent Is Kind (Compared to Man)”. On “Call Him Daylight” his vocals echo slightly
column4: suggesting a conflicted soul. These are subtle flourishes
column5: yet they add urgency and depth to these songs and reinforce the sense of a live performance or a late-night rumination.

column1: That field-recording aesthetic is the musical equivalent of sackcloth
column2: especially compared to the lusher Appalachian folk-rock arrangements on his subsequent albums. Heard in the skewed chronology of the growing Hiss Golden Messenger catalog
column3: Bad Debt may strike some listeners as mere demos
column4: yet there is nothing missing from these performances
column5: no sense of potential left untapped. These songs sound full and finished even in their austerity. Even so
column6: a deep sense of uncertainty pervades every syllable and every strum
column7: as though no question can ever be answer satisfactorily
column8: and it is precisely that spiritual disaffection that separates Taylor from the artists for whom God’s existence and benevolence are givens. Rather than cynical or despairing
column9: however
column10: Bad Debt sounds hopeful
column11: exuding a sense of hushed celebration. These are
column12: after all
column13:
songs sung by a new dad.

"|18834.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18834-hiss-golden-messenger-bad-debt/|8.2|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20049/homepage_large.6e3e2b6e.jpg|Has God Seen My Shadow?: An Anthology 1989-2011|2422.0|Mark Lanegan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Light in the Attic']|2014-01-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:03.961970|"

Well before the Seattle rock scene of the late-80s became fodder for big-screen rom-coms
column2: Marc Jacob-designed runway collections
column3: and ill-conceived trend pieces by easily duped New York Times writers
column4: Mark Lanegan was already plotting a life after grunge. Of all the handsome
column5: long-haired Emerald City singers to front rock bands that sold hundreds of thousands of records in the early 90s
column6: Lanegan ranked a distant fifth in high-school-locker pin-up potential
column7: exuding neither the bare-chested sex appeal of Chris Cornell and Eddie Vedder nor the fashionable misanthropy of Kurt Cobain and Layne Staley. Even within the context of his own band
column8: the Screaming Trees
column9: Lanegan felt like the odd man out
column10: his bronchial drawl serving as a grainy
column11: black-and-white contrast to the band’s kaleidoscopic surges.

column1: In the midst of the Trees' brief run as 90s alterna-darlings
column2: Lanegan refashioned himself as an old soul who wanted nothing to do with a young man’s game
column3: releasing a handful of simmered-down solo releases on Sub Pop steeped in blues and Americana traditions that presented a more natural fit for his slow-and-low singing style. Though it initially counted as something of an anomoly amid Sub Pop’s super-fuzzed roster
column4: Lanegan's 1990 debut
column5: The Winding Sheet
column6: was a harbinger of the label’s post-grunge tilt toward the torn 'n' frayed roots-rock of the Friends of Dean Martinez
column7: Red Red Meat
column8: the Scud Mountain Boys and the like (though today the album is probably most remembered as the record that gave Kurt Cobain the idea to cover Leadbelly). And following the Trees’ official dissolution in 2000
column9: Lanegan’s outlaw ethos would become further entrenched
column10: both on his own increasingly spartan solo releases
column11: and his mercenary approach to collaborating with everyone from Queens of the Stone Age to former Belle and Sebastian chanteuse Isobel Campbell. But despite his considerable C.V.
column12: Lanegan typifies the classic singer-not-the-song conundrum
column13: as he's better known for personifying a certain mysterious vibe—with a fistful of tattoos to go with it—than for his deep canon of black ‘n’ bruised ballads. Even when he’s stealing the spotlight
column14: Lanegan still seems like he’s lurking in the shadows
column15: not so much singing a song as haunting it. So it’s appropriate that Lanegan’s now receiving the sort of elaborate retrospective treatment that most artists don’t get till they’re dead.

column1: Though it spans two discs and 32 tracks
column2: Has God Seen My Shadow? is by no means a definitive compendium of Lanegan’s work
column3: focussing squarely on material released under his own name while steering clear of his countless extracirricular projects and growl-for-hire guest appearances. As such
column4: it’s a rather narrow overview of an artist whose interests and pursuits have proven far more eclectic than this stridently low-key collection would suggest. (Even the gnarlier extreme of his own songbook—like “Methamphetamine Blues” and “Message to Mine”—isn’t represented here
column5: while the chronology also stops short of his most stylistically divergent album to date
column6: 2012’s synth-colored Blues Funeral.) But it also underscores how the popular image of Lanegan as the gruff
column7: gravelly-voiced drifter is so often shaped by the company he keeps
column8: the harsher qualities of his voice and personality amplified by his beauty-and-the-beast match-up with Campbell
column9: or his showdowns against the more dramatic Greg Dulli in the Gutter Twins. The intimate nature of Has God Seen My Shadow? thus illuminates those qualities that often get overlooked in Lanegan’s high-profile pairings: his grace
column10: tenderness
column11: and self-deprecating sense of humour.

column1: The set’s first disc employs an odd
column2: loosely reverse-chronological sequence that groups tracks from each of Lanegan’s solo albums
column3: starting with 2004’s Bubblegum before tumbling deeper into the past. There’s a bit of a Benjamin Button effect at play in the march from the wood-cabin minimalism of “Bombed” and the creaky-door unease of the PJ Harvey duet “Come to Me” back to 1994 release Whiskey for the Holy Ghost’s “Carnival” and “The River Rise""
column4: the sort of mystical psych-folk odysseys you could easily imagine the Screaming Trees cutting for an MTV Unplugged session with a guest string section. But regardless of era
column5: Lanegan’s work has always been tethered thematically to the twin poles of regret and redemption (this guy sings about saving his soul so much
column6: he had to join the Soulsavers)
column7: and Has God Seen My Shadow? is a testament to his unwavering knack for coming up with clever ways to distill his endless bummer into a wickedly evocative one-liner: the seemingly optimistic titular refrain of Holy Ghost’s “Sunrise” is answered with “should’ve covered up my eyes
column8: ” while “One Way Street” (from 2001’s Field Songs) sets an instantly despairing scene when Lanegan intones
column9: “stars and the moon aren't where they're supposed to be
column10: ” before taking a shot of whiskey and lamenting how he “can’t get it down without crying.”

column1: The collection also shows all those Tom Waits and Nick Cave comparisons Lanegan gets saddled with to be somewhat offbase. Neither as wilfully eccentric as the former nor as outrageously provocative as the latter
column2: Has God Seen My Shadow? posits Lanegan more as a patron saint to wounded romantics like the National. His best songs disarm with their simple elegance and plaintive performances
column3: like the downcast doo wop of “Pill Hill Serenade""
column4: the breezy “Kimiko’s Dream House” (a songwriting collab with late Gun Club founder Jeffrey Lee Pierce)
column5: and “Last One in the World""
column6: which could be the best ballad Keith Richards didn’t bring to the Tatoo You sessions. Disc two of Has God Seen My Shadow? presents a random grab-bag of previously unreleased material that ping-pongs between different periods—from a mellotron-swirled 98-era cover of John Cale’s “Big White Cloud” to a vocal version of the chilling 2001 instrumental “Blues for D” to a handful of raw
column7: acoustic tracks recorded with QOTSA cohorts Troy Van Leeuwen and Alain Johannes in the mid-2000s—and while it may be short on revelations
column8: it reinforces Lanegan’s consistency of vision. So it’s ironic that the set closes with a rare letting down of the guard: a live version of the Jackson C. Frank folk standard “Blues Run the Game” (recorded in Portland circa 2000) that gets derailed by sideman Mike Johnson’s short-circuiting guitar. But with some encouragement from the audience
column9: Lanegan regains his composure to finish the song
column10:
putting into practice the philosophy that’s guided his long and winding career for over two decades: the best cure for the blues is to keep on keepin’ on.

I Break Horses’ 2011 debut Hearts was a bold record
column2: even if the Swedish duo's electronic shoegaze was hardly groundbreaking.  There was an underlying brashness in their drive to make a striking first impression at the risk of having little to back it up
column3: as Hearts was frontloaded with “Winter Beats” and the title track
column4: the best songs on the record by an astounding margin and also total outliers from the more anodyne material that followed. All things told
column5: it worked—after M83 dropped “Midnight City”
column6: forever more the canonical electronic shoegaze song
column7: they took I Break Horses on the road as an opening act
column8: surely a sign that an upstart synth-rock band is doing something right.

column1: If I Break Horses are emboldened by their success
column2: it manifests in how the duo are no longer concerning themselves with making a first impression; Chiaroscuro is a muted sophomore record that seeks to dole out its pleasures more subtly and slowly. Just witness the inversion that occurs between the introductory tracks on each record. Whereas Hearts’ “Winter Beats” evolved from Christmas-light arpeggios into a conflagration of digital distortion
column3: the subzero atmosphere of “You Burn” is a constant
column4: putting the emphasis on the first part of the title—someone’s ablaze
column5: but it’s not Lindén
column6: who maintains her typically unaffected
column7: breathy tone. <span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Going forward
column8: I Break Horses continue to hew towards minimal
column9: streamlined electronics that dispatch any tie they once had to shoegaze—if there’s any woozy
column10: pitch-shifting effects
column11: they’re placed on Lindén‘s vocals
column12: more akin to something you’d hear in the hauntological productions of a Tri Angle record rather than Loveless.

column1: As a matter of fact
column2: I Break Horses have pretty much dropped anything that could associate them with rock music. Not that guitars played a prominent role on Hearts
column3: but they’re nowhere to be found here. And while the drums are cranked
column4: Balck isn't trying to recreate booming arena-ready beats on minimalist beatboxes. To go even further
column5: their influences over the past three years seem to be exclusively non-vocal electronic music—“Ascension” and “Berceuse” are indicative of how Chiaroscuro emphasizes the intricate
column6: clattering snares you’d hear in trap
column7: drag or footwork
column8: rather than relying on Lindén to convey the message. Which is sensible
column9: as Lindén’s lyrics don’t lend themselves to deep analysis
column10: anyway. A typical line like “you burn/when words are burning/baby you burn/turn you turn/when the world is turning/baby you turn"" fails to generate even a mock profundity through Lindén's portentous cadence.

column1: But through all this reduction
column2: I Break Horses are left with little that they can call their own. Let’s note that “chiaroscuro” is a concept that has a lot of appeal to the amateur aesthete— after all
column3: it’s a fancy word that encompasses light and shade
column4: black and white. Problem is
column5: I Break Horses are typical in failing to grasp how “chiaroscuro” entails a strong contrast between light and dark as a way of establishing dynamics and volume. “Medicine Brush” and closer “Heart to Know” are meant to be the record’s tentpoles
column6: and instead underscore the album title as a misnomer
column7: spreading billowing synth atmosphere
column8: drizzly treble and murky grayscale over the span of seven minutes rather than the usual four and a half. Within the context of Chiaroscuro
column9: certain gestures emerge as hooks—the cutting punctuations on Lindén‘s vocals during the chorus of “Denial”
column10: a twisting neon synth line throughout “Faith."" But they need to stay within the context of Chiaroscuro to remain memorable.

column1: While Chiaroscuro represents an admirable turn from what I Break Horses were doing on Hearts
column2: the problem is that they’re moving in lockstep with their peers; even if Chiaroscuro doesn’t make the quick-strike
column3: short-impact impression of Hearts
column4: it lacks any means of impressing itself on the listener
column5: something to distinguish I Break Horses from the countless electronic pop bands stuck in that vast netherworld between Chvrches’ diamond-cutting
column6: laser-guided melodies and the pitch black abstractions of pure production acts such as the Haxan Cloak or Holy Other. None of this makes Chiaroscuro anything less than pleasant
column7:
just a record whose middling between arena aspirations and headphones listening feels less of a fusion and more of a compromise.

""I feel like I've led a pretty happy life
column3: Big Ups frontman Joe Galarraga lets slip during a few uncharacteristically chipper seconds of ""Goes Black"". He's not even through with the sentence before he finds a way to bum himself out: ""...how come all I can remember is the strife?"" What's bugging Joe Galarraga? Well
column4: whaddya got? Compulsive self medication
column5: Gen Y apathy
column6: the wastefulness of disposable razors: no matter the subject
column7: Galarraga's got a few choice words on the topic. Throughout Eighteen Hours of Static
column8: the arty Brooklyn post-punkers' howling debut LP
column9: Galarraga and company put the world on notice. For 28 minutes
column10: no grievance goes unaired
column11: and no blood's left unlet.

column1: Not so long ago
column2: Big Ups were just your garden-variety Descendents-worshippers
column3: proudly unsophisticated and gleefully juvenile. Over several singles and EPs
column4: the music quickly grew fiercer
column5: spinier
column6: and Galarraga started singing like his life—and not just his next beer—depended on it. Veering from harrowing Touch & Go-derived post-hardcore seethers
column7: prickly Fugazi-inspired dub-punk
column8: and the occasional dive into detuned grunge
column9: Static is as serious as a severed nerve. Songs slide from denunciatory Shellac-inflected shouts to jittery Guy-and-Ian grooves in no time at all; the clip is manic
column10: the atmosphere subterranean
column11: but through every turn
column12: Big Ups are in total control.

column1: ""With lips and mouths
column2: we can kiss and shout
column3: Galarraga screams a minute into opener ""Body Parts""
column4: and the excoriations start piling up from there. ""TMI"" is the anti-technology screed: ""find it hard to unplug
column5: he mutters
column6: ""so reach for your favorite drug."" ""Atheist Self-Help"" suggests how little time Galarraga's got for organized religion: ""No one's gonna save you
column7: so you gotta save yourself/ there's no fire and brimstone in your own personal hell."" Whether he's equating landfill-clogging waste with our churn-and-burn culture (""Disposer"") or tsk-tsking crust-punks for canine neglect (""Fresh Meat"")
column8: Galarraga's uproar is unrelenting. But
column9: though Galarraga's not the type to take things lying down
column10: he never seems to be shouting just to hear himself scream.

column1: The relentless pace of modern life—and the attendant superficiality of quick-fix culture—is a refrain Galarraga returns to throughout Static. On ""Grin""
column2: he's quick to chastise: ""We all think that we know best
column3: but we're struggling just to catch our breaths."" On ""Goes Black""
column4: he all but stammers ""sometimes I feel like the pace of my life is too fast
column5: and I think about the time that's passed."" Galarraga's heart—to say nothing of his vitriol—seems to be in the right place. But few of the targets of his furor are new subjects for angry young punks
column6: which—given Galarraga's relative lack of nuance—occasionally leaves his ""wake up
column7: sheeple"" routine feeling a little underdeveloped
column8: less a pointed manifesto than the notebook-margin scrawlings of the newly politicized. The gall is there
column9: and the objects of his ire are clear. But unless you're already predisposed to his way of thinking
column10: Galarraga screaming in your ear's not likely to change your mind.

column1: Still
column2: on-record politics don't always have to be coherent to be compelling. And
column3: as serial complainers go
column4: Galarraga's a hard guy to turn away from. As cranked-to-11
column5: motherfuck-a-downstairs-neighbor music
column6: Static works beautifully
column7: and its lean
column8: propulsive 28 minutes seem to fly by in double-time. Throughout Static
column9: Big Ups come across as a band in complete command of their sound
column10: fronted by a guy on the verge of losing it. If Galarraga can learn to better elucidate the ""why?"" and ""what next?"" behind these tantrums of his—to better target his rage without tempering it—Big Ups could really cause some lasting damage. For now
column11:
they're doing just fine by punching at the walls.

Alternate/Endings is Lee Bannon's second album
column2: but it represents something like the fifth or sixth iteration of Lee Bannon. He broke through years ago as one of the most promising producers associated with Joey Bada$$'s Pro Era crew
column3: offering potent but catholic updates of beats forged by the likes of RZA and DJ Premier. Since then he has gotten weirder in familiar ways: offering a self-released EP of TriAngle-style moan-bap and
column4: on his 2012 debut album Fantastic Plastic
column5: stoned West Coast abstractions. Alternate/Endings offers yet another direction
column6: this one inspired by drum and bass
column7: the dark
column8: quick breakbeat music that ruled the UK in the mid and late 90s.

column1: Bannon has expressed a desire to be seen as more than a hip-hop producer
column2: but spiritually the move he makes here isn't large. As a bleak
column3: ever hardening
column4: sample-based music meant to reflect street culture (and often featuring MCs)
column5: drum and bass served largely the same role in the UK that hip hop did in the US (though it matured into a club music instead of pop). All of which is to say that the ingredients Bannon works with on Alternate/Endings—breakbeats
column6: samples from old R&B records and movies—are largely the same elements used to create hip-hop beats.

column1: Drum and bass carries no expectation of an MC
column2: though
column3: leaving Bannon as the sole shaper of Alternate/Endings; artistic agency is something that seems important to him. Bannon's history and geography separate Alternate/Endings from the rash of drum and bass revivalism that has swept the UK in the last two years
column4: but also insulates it from the innovations of producers like dBridge
column5: Addison Groove
column6: and Tessela working in the same stylistic sphere. If Alternate/Endings is unique
column7: it's because its sound is retro while its mood remains present and personal.

column1: In an interview with Resident Advisor
column2: Bannon repeatedly namechecks Goldie
column3: a D&B innovator whose proggy epic
column4: Timeless
column5: stands as a totem of D&B-as-art (as opposed to club music). Bannon's pretensions lie elsewhere—he favors dark
column6: noir-ish breakdowns and seems more interested in atmosphere than rhythm—but he shares Goldie's affinity for capital-a Art. Alternate/Endings functions best as a long piece
column7: allowing its many breaks to dissolve into a slurry of snares and hi-hats
column8: whereupon the album's soiled vocal samples and eerie half-time breakdowns can set the scene.

column1: As such
column2: Alternate/Endings is best when Bannon doesn't go too crazy with the beat science and instead focuses on crafting a mood. Lower-octane tracks such as ""Prime/Decent"" and ""216"" have most in common with Bannon's hip-hop work
column3: and they feel more comfortable than jam-packed scorchers like ""NW/WB"". Bannon stretches his legs on the nine-minute ""Readly/Available"" (like Goldie
column4: Bannon has no use for concision)
column5: allowing a flurry of snares to stew in ambient back-alleys and furtive synth riffs. He finds an identity when he blurs the line between drum and bass traditionalism and abstract
column6: mutant hip-hop.

column1: Alternate/Endings is an oddity
column2: a self-contained offering from a restless producer. Bannon cares little about D&B's past or future—only his own—though his flightiness will make you wonder how much he cares about its present. This is a fine diversion
column3: a stylistic workout that Bannon will not feel—and should not feel—any obligation to expand upon. But it also highlights an inconvenient truth
column4: which is that Bannon has proven much better at reinventing himself than he has at reinventing styles. Bannon can call wherever he rests his head home
column5: be it D&B
column6: hip-hop
column7: or elsewhere. Alternate/Endings is tempting
column8: smart
column9:
and raw enough to make me wish he'd set up camp somewhere more permanent.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19964/homepage_large.9565fe81.jpg|White Light/White Heat|4469.0|The Velvet Underground|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Universal']|2014-01-16 00:00:00|1968|2016-06-11 16:49:05.679526|"

When the Velvet Underground's second album descended on the world in January
column3: nobody was ready for it. The Velvet Underground and Nico
column4: the year before
column5: had had Andy Warhol's imprimatur to promise that its passages of bleeding-raw chaos were art; it had also had the complicated but unmistakable beauty of the songs Nico sang as a lifeline for the tiny mainstream audience that caught on to it at the time. White Light/White Heat didn't have either.

column1: By the time they released it
column2: the Velvets were downplaying the art-world connection (despite the very arty slash in the album's title
column3: and the fact that its black-on-black sleeve was designed by the Factory's Billy Name). Nico was out of the band
column4: although bassist John Cale would continue to work with her for years. And the album was a relentless
column5: screeching
column6: thudding
column7: scoffing assault on the pop sensibilities of its time: six songs with lyrics designed to horrify the bourgeoisie (not that they'd have listened to the Velvet Underground in the first place)
column8: ending with a one-take
column9: two-chord
column10: 17-minute speedfreakout. It clung to the bottom of the album chart for two weeks
column11: disappeared
column12: and went on to become the glorious
column13: tainted fountain from which all scuzz flows.

column1: That's the White Light/White Heat of legend
column2: anyway. For its 45th anniversary—closer to its 46th
column3: but keeping time was never their strong point—it's been reissued in expanded
column4: remastered form
column5: as if what this pinnacle of sloppy noise needed was remastering. As always
column6: the title track
column7: which seems like it should start cold with Cale and Sterling Morrison's backing vocals
column8: sounds like it's had a little trimmed off the top to remove an extraneous sound—although
column9: of course
column10: extraneous sounds are kind of the whole point of this album.

column1: Listening to White Light/White Heat now
column2: it doesn't quite fit the template of its legend. For one thing
column3: Lou Reed's songwriting is often a lot more conventional than it's reputed to be. Strip away the noise and flash and references to illicit drugs and sex
column4: and ""White Light/White Heat""
column5: ""Here She Comes Now""
column6: and ""I Heard Her Call My Name"" are all the sort of simple rock'n'roll readymades that Reed had been cranking out at Pickwick Records a couple of years earlier. (So is ""Guess I'm Falling In Love""
column7: recorded in scorching instrumental form at the White Light sessions
column8: which is practically the same song as the Rutles' ""I Must Be In Love"".)

column1: For another
column2: the live disc appended to this edition is a reminder that the Velvet Underground were radical in a totally acceptable way for their time—that
column3: professionally speaking
column4: they were a party band with an audience of hippies
column5: who appeared on bills with the likes of Sly & the Family Stone
column6: Canned Heat
column7: Iron Butterfly
column8: Quicksilver Messenger Service
column9: and Chicago Transit Authority the year White Light/White Heat came out. The performance
column10: apparently from John Cale's collection
column11: was recorded at the Gymnasium in New York in April
column12: 1967 (two of its songs previously appeared on the 1995 Peel Slowly and See box set). It presents the Velvets as a full-on boogie band
column13: whose set is bookended by the instrumental grooves ""Booker T."" and ""The Gift""—turns out they're slightly different songs
column14: contrary to what VU fans have assumed for the past few decades. The rest of the gig includes what might or might not have been the first public performance of ""Sister Ray"" (it was still a very new song
column15: at any rate)
column16: and one legit addition to the canon: ""I'm Not a Young Man Anymore""
column17: a chugging electric blues that wouldn't have been out of place in Creedence Clearwater Revival's early repertoire.

column1: So once this mysterious black-on-black artifact is demystified
column2: what's left of it? More mystery
column3: it turns out. What possessed Cale to start playing an out-of-time
column4: two-note bass part louder than anything else at the end of ""White Light/White Heat""
column5: and how could he have guessed that that was a great idea? Was the famous split-second pause before Reed's splatterbomb solo on ""I Heard Her Call My Name"" intentional? What the fuck was up with Reed filling in words—""SWEETLY!""—in the middle of Cale's vocal on ""Lady Godiva's Operation""
column6: and why is it still hilarious? Speaking of that song
column7: might lyrics about a delicate hypersexual creature interacting with ""another curly-headed boy
column8: directly followed by a medical horror-show
column9: have anything to do with a curly-headed songwriter who was given electroconvulsive therapy to ""cure"" his bisexuality as a teenager? Why is ""Sister Ray"" way
column10: way more potent than any other extended jam on a simple riff by an American band of the 60s?

column1: It's surprising to hear anything besides the universe catching its breath after ""Sister Ray"" ends
column2: but the first disc of this reissue is filled out with other previously released evidence of John Cale's final months in the Velvet Underground: the instrumental ""Guess I'm Falling In Love""
column3: both versions of the electric-viola showcase ""Hey Mr. Rain""
column4: and the band's thoroughly charming stab at making a commercially viable single
column5: ""Temptation Inside Your Heart""/""Stephanie Says"". There's also a previously unheard alternate take of ""I Heard Her Call My Name"" (not quite as good as the official one
column6: and mostly interesting to hear which of Reed's apparent ad-libs weren't)
column7: and one fascinating curio: an early version of ""Beginning to See the Light""
column8: recorded at the ""Temptation Inside Your Heart"" session. By the time the song appeared on The Velvet Underground in 1969
column9: it had become lither and wittier
column10: and Reed had sharpened a few of its lyrics; this broad-shouldered
column11: clomping version is distinctly not there yet
column12:
but everything the Velvets released on their official albums is so canonical that it's strange and heartening to realize that their songs didn't just spring into existence already perfect.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20086/homepage_large.3829653a.jpg|Keep Doing What You're Doing|31918.0|You Blew It!|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Topshelf']|2014-01-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:06.297748|"

Good songwriting doesn’t always require the absence of lyrical nonsense. Sometimes all you need is one memorable line that lends meaning to the gibberish that surrounds it. Tanner Jones of You Blew It! excels at this kind of songwriting. Take “Match & Tinder”
column2: the first song from the Orlando emo band’s sophomore LP
column3: Keep Doing What You’re Doing. At one point
column4: Jones sings
column5: “I’ll struggle to put your shoes over mine in my head and use it to piece together my confidence.” Immediately after that sentence
column6: he adds this equally inscrutable grab-bag of nouns and verbs: “I can hardly breathe
column7: so I’m scanning for space that lends asymmetry where I’ll put mind over matter to put this matter out of my mind.” Now
column8: I’ve played “Match & Tinder” many
column9: many times
column10: because it has an addictively chunky riff and pleasurably hyperactive drumming and therefore is an excellent example of sensitive-dude melodic punk rock. But I never notice the aforementioned vocab casseroles when I’m listening. Because “Match & Tinder” (and the entirety of Keep Doing What You’re Doing) really boils down to the last line
column11: which is kind of brilliant: “I’m having trouble trying to find the right way to say I feel less than confident.”

column1: Keep Doing What You’re Doing is an “airing of grievances” record—Jones constantly directs his ire at an unnamed somebody who has somehow disappointed him
column2: whether it’s the person with “habits” in “Regional Dialect” or the cretin who has given Jones “the displeasure of enduring your lack of manners” in “Rock Springs”. But the way he delivers these indignities—in a pained
column3: shaky howl that’s constantly fighting to stay above the din of YBI!’s wondrously ringing guitars—is indicative of a guy who’s projecting his displeasure at himself onto others. Even when Jones is pointing the finger
column4: he always sounds like the most vulnerable guy in the room. You know
column5: typical emo stuff.

column1: Since forming in 2009
column2: You Blew It! have survived various lineup changes by zeroing in on the tenets of their genre like a religion. The group is not shy about proclaiming its influences—its Topshelf Records bio directly references emo O.G.s Cap’n Jazz and 00s torch-bearers Algernon Cadwallader
column3: and says “YBI! cherrypicks from 90s emo and indie.” That’s exactly what YBI! did on its 2012 full-length debut <i>Grow Up
column4: Dude
column5: where the band’s fat hooks were submerged (and occasionally torpedoed) by booming
column6: fumbling production. If you’re 35 and grew up on Nothing Feels Good and LP2
column7: <i>Grow Up
column8: Dude will make you feel 15 again. But it will also make you feel like you’re 15 if you’re actually 15. This is the difference between “retro” and “timeless”: Emo will remain eternally relevant because people of a certain age will always have trouble trying to find the right way to say I feel less than confident.

column1: What sets Keep Doing apart from Dude is that
column2: musically speaking
column3: YBI! have grown in self-assurance by leaps and bounds. With the production assistance of scene stalwart Evan Weiss (who also plays bass on the record)
column4: You Blew It! have fashioned Keep Doing into a deeply satisfying
column5: full-bodied
column6: big-tent rock record. There are four credited guitarists in the liner notes
column7: and it sounds like each of them contributed at least one guitar track to every song. “Award of the Year Award” is a perfectly spat gob of romantic petulance—Jones’ one killer line is “You can always consider me a friend
column8: just strictly in the past tense”—set to over-amped power pop. The ballad “’Strong Island” opens with nearly 30 seconds of beautifully strummed power chords that usher in the bass-driven verse like a fanfare. By the closing number “Better to Best”
column9: YBI! is in full-on anthem mode
column10: with a triumphant chorus of ""whoa""’s pushing Keep Doing toward the majestic grandiosity of arena rock.

column1: The bugaboo among some of the scenesters that form the core of YBI!’s audience is that the band has been positioned in the music press as a leading proponent of the so-called “emo revival.” Those that have been paying attention all along understandably bristle at the revival talk. So let’s set that bothersome word aside: What’s really happening is an emo reclamation by a segment of the rock audience that bailed on the genre 10 or so years ago.
For a while
column2: the itch for shouty
column3: earnest guitar music was scratched by records like The Monitor and Celebration Rock
column4: collections that were considered MOR indie
column5: but would perhaps be marginalized in 2014
column6: just as countless other punk and emo records from the past decade have been relegated to the corner. Now
column7: a band like You Blew It! are poised to fill the role for frustrated listeners who can’t find loud
column8: angsty rock'n'roll via traditional indie channels anymore. If this is the music that speaks to you
column9: here is where the action now is. So
column10: forget the emo revival—this is about two subsets of rock fans being pushed together by aspirational emo bands reaching beyond their niche on one side and the eclipse of traditional indie by mainstream pop on the other. Keep Doing What You’re Doing marks the precise point where these audiences meet
column11: get drunk
column12:
and turn it up.

"|18891.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18891-you-blew-it-keep-doing-what-youre-doing/|7.6|Steven Hyden

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20044/homepage_large.a10806a5.jpg|The State vs. Radric Davis II: The Caged Bird Sings|27649.0|Gucci Mane|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['1017 Brick Squad']|2014-01-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:06.448434|"

One of the most important things to know about Gucci Mane’s new The State Vs. Radric Davis II: The Caged Bird Sings—nominally the sequel to his 2009 Warner Bros. LP The State Vs. Radric Davis—is that the stakes are lower. The spotlight on Gucci’s music is also dimmer
column2: thanks to a turbulent year in the trap icon’s personal life; currently
column3: he awaits trial for a gun charge that carries a sentence of up to 20 years. Despite how much happened to Gucci in 2013—he still managed to put out a dozen releases and played the villain in Harmony Korine’s Spring Breakers—you get the sense that no one is expecting much from The Caged Bird Sings
column4: a release that Gucci’s camp plopped on Bandcamp on Christmas Day. For what it’s worth
column5: Gucci delivers something that easily clears the exceedingly low expectations.

column1: Despite the implications the LP’s name might carry
column2: Gucci’s not chasing the pop rap instincts he was on the hit-or-miss The State Vs. Radric Davis
column3: which included his highest-charting hit “Wasted” and “Lemonade”. Here
column4: a producer with a hitmaking pedigree like Bangledesh is nowhere to be found; Instead
column5: Gucci gets ample assists from his usual Brick Squad brethren Young Thug
column6: Peewee Longway
column7: and Young Scooter as well as production from 808 Mafia and Zaytoven (who Gucci is currently suing). The Caged Bird Sings hems something closer to a release like Trap House 3
column8: a workmanlike release with more than a few flickers of life but none of the experimentation Gucci has flirted with in the recent past. Though songs like “Birdman” and “Jackie Chan” contain plenty of Gucci’s marble-mouthed platitudes
column9: it feels generic to the point that not even Migos can reenergize the proceedings (I’d compare it to taking a Five Hour Energy after being awake for 48 hours; too little
column10: too late). In a career where Gucci Mane has covered the same ground
column11: repaving it over and over again
column12: The Caged Bird Sings feels particularly recycled.

column1: But that’s not to say there aren’t a few moments that will keep his audience happy. The fists-flying knock of “Feets” or the uptempo burst “Any Thing”
column2: which features a staccato verse fast-rising Gucci protege Young Thug
column3: serve as good examples of when The Caged Bird heats up. And while the quality of the album's sound suggests more organization and deliberation than what’s usually found on the other end of a download link
column4: it’s difficult to argue that people will remember it. Given his onslaught of just-as-good-if-not-better free material in 2013
column5: I have a harder time imagining that people will be paying for it.

column1: But then again
column2: 2013 is a year that Gucci Mane might rather forget. With Twitter beefs that spiraled into full-on lawsuits and the drama just continuing to pile it’s hard to know when Gucci might be in his zone again. (Throughout
column3:
you get the sense that he’s pretty out of it; he doesn’t even say “BRR!” once!). The Caged Bird Sings isn’t bad; it’s just lifeless.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20094/homepage_large.b3d88cfc.jpg|Audion X|250.0|Audion|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ghostly']|2014-01-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:07.027065|"

Audion is the static
column2: dancefloor-oriented side project of Matthew Dear. Conceived as a bawdy
column3: voiceless take on Detroit techno and New York electro
column4: it was introduced in the middle of the last decade to provide an outlet for Dear's baser desires
column5: namely depictions of raunchy sex and electronic music freed from the need to sound artful or smart. Audion X
column6: offered up 10 years after the release of Audion's sole album
column7: Suckfish
column8: collects 18 tracks from Audion's dozen-plus EPs and that album
column9: and adds two new tracks in anticipation of a sophomore LP
column10: due later this year. Even-numbered anniversaries aside
column11: it's a peculiar reclamation
column12: as Audion records are not particularly influential or coveted. Neither is its style—full-bodied machine funk—resurgent at the moment.

column1: Dear's work as Audion stood out upon release in opposition to his work under his own name. Early albums Leave Luck to Heaven and Asa Breed established Dear as a wunderkind of the micro-house style—an understated
column2: minimal take on techno famously championed by Cologne's Kompakt label. Dear has since proven himself something of a stylistic chameleon
column3: eventually gravitating towards a celebrated electro-pop sound. He delivered some of his most compelling vocal work just last year as a foil to DJ Koze
column4: his ""magical boy."" Back in 2004
column5: though
column6: Audion was everything Matthew Dear was not: explicit
column7: stoopid
column8: forward. Extended club cuts such as ""Mouth to Mouth"" and ""The Pong"" offered Dear a connection to the seminal Detroit techno sound (Dear spent part of his youth in Michigan) as well as to the rowdy electro on offer from tastemakers like Tiga and DJ Hell.

column1: As Audion tracks are largely wordless mazes of rhythmic curlicues and farty bass noises
column2: they earn the debauchery largely through their song titles. Titles like ""Just Fucking"" and ""Your Place or Mine"" feature. The sexiness might mean more to Dear than it does to us: his early work was nuanced and elegant to the point that you can imagine him producing a romping track like ""Titty Fuck"" and finding it sufficiently naughty so as to name it something like
column3: well
column4: ""Titty Fuck"". Audion tracks aren't really about sex
column5: or at least they're no more about sex than lots of other funky machine music. That's okay: sometimes foreplay is wine and movie
column6: sometimes it's sweating next to someone until 4am.

column1: At present
column2: Audion's sound is completely out of step with techno's prevailing trends
column3: which favor harsh
column4: industrial noise and dubby deconstructions. Audion tracks slave themselves to the groove: you won't remember specific drum patterns
column5: and the hooks are short and repetitive so as to inspire maximum grinding. The tracks feel big. When ""It's Full of Blinding Light"" is careening around the room
column6: you're not supposed to think of sound structure or art or music culture: you're supposed to wiggle. Tracks like ""Mouth to Mouth"" and ""The Pong"" are excellent reminders of techno's debt to funk and its unwavering commitment to any riff
column7: bassline
column8: or hook that inspires movement. At its best
column9: Audion offers a rowdier take on the Kompakt/minimal techno sound that ruled the aughts. It's a beefier
column10: fleshier mix
column11: not as slinky as Ricardo Villalobos or as wily as DJ Koze
column12: but brasher
column13: harder
column14: and dumber (by design).

column1: Despite a fetching sound and some killer tracks
column2: Audion X doesn't have much of a story to tell
column3: not even one of artistic progression. Banging
column4: erotic club tracks are Audion's singular purpose
column5: and Audion X offers 18 of them
column6: spanning nearly two-and-a-half hours. Spacey
column7: atmospheric excursions like ""I Am the Car"" can span nearly 10 minutes. Most of the offerings are uniform in tempo
column8: mood
column9: and function. And while Audion X will leave no Audion fan wanting
column10: a bevy of potent remixes were largely ignored. Audion X seems timed to rekindle interest in the Audion project prior to a new album
column11: so it's worth nothing that the two new tracks here—""Motormouth"" and ""Sky""—are excellent. The former
column12: in particular
column13: dices a vocal sample into a mental
column14: infectious mess.

column1: Still
column2: if the purpose of Audion X was to drum up interest
column3: it may have the opposite effect. Audion X is all the Audion anyone will ever need—twice as much
column4: actually. Dear's work as Audion was limited by design
column5: and Audion X repeatedly shoves those limits into your face. Audion X is a stylistic indulgence
column6:
for both its creator and its listeners.

Alongside 2013's spotlight on industry sexism
column2: there was a discussion of raw sexuality in club culture. Within the electronic community
column3: nobody generated fiercer debate on the subject than Nina Kraviz. Operating in a field notoriously given to self-promotion
column4: her tenacity in utilising an obvious USP as a marketable strategy rankled with some. (A now infamous clip in an otherwise self-serious documentary from last March invited heightened opprobrium from all corners.) She also gets flack for an alleged lack of technical finesse behind the decks
column5: but Kraviz has been unafraid to address her critics head on
column6: something that further solidifies her position as a lightning rod for discourse. The resulting publicity works as a natural propellant
column7: of course
column8: but it's overshadowed her output.

column1: Which is maybe unfair: there's a tangible human quality that bleeds through her recorded material and her spirited deep cut sets. From her breakout on DJ Jus-Ed's ""Voices"" in 2009 through to 2012's self-titled debut and collaborations with Apparat and Efdemin
column2: she's keenly played into the assumed role as a Siberian siren
column3: infusing frigid house productions with sultry vocal lines. Nina Kraviz was a solid record that found success in deviations from that twilit formula: both low-bouncing ""Ghetto Kraviz"" and Marcellus Pittmann's edit of ""Working""'s snookerball-clacking beat wound up underground hits
column4: while showstopping finale ""Fire"" positioned Kraviz's haunting double-tracked voice in suspension
column5: a picture of perfect stillness. The close-mic'd whispers and fuggy ambiance were hardly revolutionary
column6: but they displayed a great deal more character than Mr. Jones
column7: her first material in 18 months
column8: a largely charmless double EP that would struggle to justify half its 54 minute runtime.

column1: The execution's fine
column2: it's the ideas themselves that are at fault. Bluntly
column3: Mr. Jones does little of note and takes an awfully long time doing it. As standalone tracks
column4: the majority lack a creative spark—they're repetitive slabs of meandering
column5: boilerplate tech house. While Kraviz's international touring schedule has been extensive
column6: Mr. Jones' lack of ingenuity can't be chalked up to a draining regime given that four of the six cuts are minor cosmetic touch-ups of tracks rooted in a period around a half decade back. Opener ""Desire"" is of the better tracks
column7: but it has an inescapably monochromatic and workmanlike feel. The repeated mantra and carnal moans feel sterile
column8: as if pumped through a tannoy system
column9: sitting atop an unobtrusive rhythmic chug of pistons and gears
column10: and the sound of two cinderblocks shifting in unison
column11: advancing with no resolve
column12: pushing bodies to the grind. It would make a decent bridge on the dancefloor
column13: but a five-minute mixing tail with no real shift-up exposes a lack of substance between the scaffolding.

column1: Kraviz invests renewed faith in her voice as a load-bearing pillar rather than mere atmospheric accoutrement
column2: but having emerged from behind the smokescreen it appears the lustre has faded from her eyes. ""Remember""
column3: the other new number alongside ""Desire""
column4: brings Detroit native Luke Hess on board for some double-barrel techno pummel and hackneyed B-movie dialogue. Spinning a spoken-word tale across the title track
column5: she's present but featureless
column6: shooting for coldwave detachment but landing closer to monotony. Things aren't helped by the simplistic bassline and lack of tension: the components lie neatly next to one another with zero dynamic interplay
column7: so when Nina's voice rolls back after an extended build
column8: any chance of release evaporates. The ""2008 Home Listening Mix""—packaged with three other alternate versions on the digital version—is a lot better
column9: wiping the grey vaseline smear off the mix and letting the beat and chirruping effects fill space properly. The same problem shows up on the nondescript pair of songs padding the end of the EP. These tracks utilise similar tools—sparse claps
column10: mild hiss
column11: vague menace
column12: head-on-desk thud—to little effect.

column1: A welcome exception comes in the form of ""Black White""
column2: a track exploring different terrain with an Afro-Caribbean lilt. The wooden timbres and looser rhythm provide a marked switch-up as the song ramps in intensity before breaking into a groove redolent of the kind of funky house prevalent during its initial inception. Kraviz's restrained yelps find their way through the dark
column3:
working as a tidy accompaniment to the guitar notes bobbing through the hypnotic final third and petite melody set in amongst the chinking percussion. It proves a lone takeaway on an overlong and underdeveloped release.

If you wanted to pick two stories that defined the kind of year Sharon Jones had in 2013
column2: it's easy to single out the first: the pancreatic cancer that struck the singer in the initial run-up to her new album. It's an ailment that grounded one of the most vibrant stage presences in R&B
column3: and it seemed like a cruel rebuttal to a career built on long-due good fortune and a spirit that took on and beat all comers. That she intends to tour again soon after her recent final chemo treatment is a good omen
column4: and with luck the disease will be just a footnote to a long career. The other story of note is the cameo Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings had in Martin Scorsese's The Wolf of Wall Street: there they are
column5: the singer and her group
column6: standing onstage in the role of a wedding band playing James Bond supervillain torch song “Goldfinger” at the reception of a Caligula-minded stockbroker. A movie where a 21st century band plays 1960s music in a scene set in the early 90s—that's the context they found themselves in
column7: and there are few better ways to show off just how unindebted to time they are.

column1: Placing Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings at a certain space in time seems easy aesthetically; few bands' version of 1968 have lasted as long or as effectively as theirs. With a virtuoso versatility that all parties involved have cultivated
column2: it wouldn't be a huge shock—much less a disappointment—if they deigned to cross that Nixon-era threshold and fool around with some “Blow Your Head”/“Funky Worm” synthesizers or put a little B.T. Express-style proto-disco hustle in their backbone. But even if the title of Give the People What They Want invokes one of the more state-of-the-art slices of 70s soul as delivered by the O'Jays
column3: Jones and company stay in their more vintage lane. They might be a bit tighter than they were on 2002's Dap-Dippin'...
column4: and they cut a bit more cleanly through their old-school analogue recording methods
column5: but this is an album built less on advancement than resilience.

column1: And this is an album with plenty of the latter. It isn't a sound anyone should take for granted
column2: since it's been well-established that the blue-flame intensity of Jones' voice and the Dap-Kings' evocative arrangements aren't exactly common stock and would legitimately bring down the house anywhere from Coachella to Wattstax. Both singer and band have gotten so versed in their mixture of classic Southern soul and occasional flourishes of Motown or Philly soul opulence—transitions they make with a masterful smoothness—that even a first listen will make a song feel lived-in
column3: with an “always been there” familiarity that hasn't yet gone threadbare. Even the cover art is a direct nod of a throwback—a more ornate riff on the sleeve of the Chi-Lites' 1971 LP (For God's Sake) Give More Power to the People.

column1: That lets slip another commonality of theirs with vintage R&B—the idea of soul as a vehicle for social commentary. The fun irony of Jones and the Dap-Kings playing the on-screen Jordan Belfort's wedding is that their songs' sense of grievance
column2: justice
column3: and populist power has rarely felt stronger. Opener “Retreat!”
column4: with its martial-march tweak of the Holland-Dozier-Holland that gave us “I Hear a Symphony”
column5: is a massive kiss-off to some arrogant somebody-or-other that can't help but crumble in the face of “a woman scorned”—though any lingering spite is drowned out by the sheer joy of Jones expressing the strength needed to overcome someone else's misdeeds. “People Don't Get What They Deserve” is that rare dose of idealism-deflating reality that doesn't drown in its own bitter cynicism; Jones' sprint-paced rapport with the backup singer Dapettes doesn't sound jaded and world-weary enough
column6: and right on to that. And “We Get Along” holds the prescription to endure—help and relief might be a long time coming
column7: but being able to keep on doing it in the face of strife is a source of inner strength in the meantime. It's implicit gospel that puts its faith in the people.

column1: Give the People What They Want is a pretty short 10 songs
column2: though its breezy half-hour leaves plenty that sticks and plenty more worth revisiting when it doesn't. The collection's balance of rousing barn-burners and slower
column3: sweeter break-up/make-up ballads (like the sun-streaked bliss of “Slow Down
column4: Love”) keeps it moving. And it's all briskly impassioned enough to make most skeptics brush off the old “have I heard this before?” questions
column5:
even if this is one of the more get-what-you-expect albums of the early year. It's like peeking into an alternate reality where an artist like Lyn Collins or Marva Whitney could have a decade-plus career without having to worry about changes in trends—and it's long since been clear by now that Jones belongs in their class. May she remain unstoppable.

For any bilingualists blessed with Swedish and English faculties
column2: Peter Morén's Broken Swenglish Vol 1. will be more of a dynamic experience. Though
column3: others shouldn’t worry about what the title implies: the four songs on the EP are sung entirely in English. They were
column4: however

column6: found across a pair of Morén solo albums from his home country
column7: released outside his main gig singing and playing guitar in Peter Bjorn & John. 2010's I spåren av tåren and 2012's Pyramiden sound good: loud

column1: Morén has said in interviews that he feels more at ease with Swedish lyrics

column8: say

column3: cobblestone streets. Just be careful of this landmine the middle: ""The pressure of lasting a lifetime is too hard for anyone to take/ I wouldn't want you to fake your innermost longings"" because it may rip you right out of the daydream. In the past there’s been some some gems and clunkers in Morén's lyrics

column6: and ""Say My Name"" is just too neutral and static to make you feel.

column1: And there you have it. At four songs and 12 minutes

column4: English-speaking audience. The real fun would be to see how the lyrics shifted

column6: it's hardly something I could comment on. It seems that his Swedish tongue might be more silver than is English. For instance
column7: the Swedish version of ""Going Places"" is titled ""Erik M. Nilsson"" after a little-known Swedish filmmaker
column8: whose name is absent from the remake. It's a good example of the kind of alluring specificity that's absent from <i>Broken Swenglish

which is ultimately a reminder of what the idiom isn't: found in translation.

For the duration of their 16-year existence
column2: from 1993 to 2009
column3: the Lucksmiths had an aesthetic so focused and so unvarying they may as well have been Motörhead
column4: a band with whom they could never be confused. The songs collected on this retrospective are almost totally of a piece: singer/drummer Tali White's tremulous-lad tenor (with its undisguised Australian accent) and pitty-pat percussion; chief songwriter Marty Donald's clear
column5: clean guitar tone; and wry lyrics about various shades of emotional ache
column6: featuring the kind of wordplay that tends to come from people who can both define ""zeugma"" and provide an example (""I can't see the florist for the flowers/ And I can't see the point in hanging 'round."") On a first approximation
column7: ""Jewel Thieves"" is the only one of the 35 songs here that's not about frail male heteroromantic yearning or musing on surroundings or both.

column1: The Lucksmiths were
column2: in other words
column3: the exemplars of a certain kind of deliberately anti-macho indie-pop
column4: and they made no secret of which bands they hearted most: the like-minded
column5: much more short-lived
column6: mostly British acts that had been connected to Sarah Records and the C86 scene. Their fan base was fanatical; their formula was durable. And their Indie 4Eva attitude was largely untempered by their models' and contemporaries' exploration outside their perfumed garden. There's very little on Cartography for Beginners that branches out like the Housemartins' stabs at a cappella gospel
column7: Belle and Sebastian's salutes to Northern soul
column8: or Trembling Blue Stars' bleak eroticism; the horn section on ""The Golden Age of Aviation"" can trace its lineage to New Orleans only by way of the Cure's ""Close to Me"".

column1: They were cloistered
column2: but they were devout. The Lucksmiths' kind of artistic evolution meant a slow
column3: steady improvement in craft—suppler melodies
column4: slyer puns
column5: more carefully wrought observations—so this is the rare decade-plus retrospective where the later songs beat the early ones. (The addition of second guitarist Louis Richter for their last few albums helped a lot
column6: too.) They broke up amicably enough that they played a farewell tour and recorded a farewell single that's close to a career peak (""Get-to-Bed Birds""
column7: the gentlest of valedictions
column8: about staying up too late on New Year's Eve); 3/4 of them went on to start a new band
column9: Last Leaves

One of Disclosure's signatures is their ability to strip their songs to exactly the right number of elements. This is in part an aesthetic choice
column2: but the paring down of each track is a means to an end: the duo’s instant classic debut Settle doesn't sacrifice emotional resonance in the name of efficiency
column3: and it’s in that tension—the weight carried by bare bones—that the album becomes special.

column1: Though unfussy
column2: this formula makes for songs that might very well be difficult—if not intimidating—to remix. How do you chip away at and then rebuild tracks so...just so? Well
column3: Settle: The Remixes argues that if you’re smart maybe you don’t. The truth that hovers over the album is perhaps uncomfortable because of how easy it can be to notice: of all the reworkings collected by Guy and Howard Lawrence
column4: the best of the bunch are the ones that depart from the originals the least. That
column5: too
column6: is to say nothing of the two new Disclosure songs that bookend the 15-track set.

column1: The lineup here is as starry and varied you’d expect for two kids billed on this year’s Coachella poster above Lana Del Rey
column2: an artist who has actual platinum plaques to her name. There are contemporaries (Hudson Mohawke
column3: Baauer
column4: Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs); up-and-comers (Flume
column5: Kaytranada); legends (DJ Premier
column6: Larry Heard); and the London underground (T. Williams
column7: Preditah
column8: Wookie). This time it’s the old guys—the ones
column9: maybe
column10: with the least to prove—who best navigate the balance by undertaking alterations instead of redesigns.

column1: The top remix comes from Chicago house luminary Larry Heard
column2: who handles one of three new versions of “Help Me Lose My Mind” under his Mr. Fingers pseudo-alias. On Settle
column3: the narcotic London Grammar collaboration closes the album with what sounds like a cleanse but is actually shivering at its core—it's an unsettling finish. Here
column4: Heard tips his hand: his is dubbed as a “chillout mix
column5: ” and that it is. He slows the track and replaces the jittery percussion with pitter-patter drums
column6: a slowly tapped out piano chord
column7: and an unhurried shaker. The tracks are quite similar
column8: but where in the context of the original Hannah Reid’s vocals are a quiet plea
column9: they're now soothed. With Heard
column10: she finally manages to let her mind slip away.

column1: The inclusion of DJ Premier may seem odd
column2: but Guy Lawrence has long professed his love for boom bap and the duo do sample a J Dilla beat on Settle. Odder is what comes of Primo’s take on “Latch”
column3: a pop song with the sweep of house but the underpinnings of garage. His version throws obligatory scratches in early but otherwise transforms the song into a piano ballad. Yet
column4: it’s fantastic: Primo’s drums punch exactly like you’d hope
column5: but even better are the hard exhales he weaves into the percussion. This
column6: well
column7: panting is a sly but effective way of emphasizing the original’s headrush of desperation
column8: and though track might feel like a left-turn
column9: DJ Premier is only slightly fidgeting with a finished product—vocalist Sam Smith’s acoustic rendition of “Latch"".

column1: From there
column2: it's a sizable drop-off to the few remixes that are decent but inessential: with his “Voices”
column3: Wookie smoothes the 2-step of the original into a pure house tune; and with his go at “Help Me Lose My Mind”
column4: Paul Woolford summons the tropical euphoria of John Talabot and Pional. The rest aren’t noteworthy
column5: save for a few dispiriting but high-profile exceptions. HudMo’s jagged swoop-and-crash makes for a bad fit with the twirling propulsion of “White Noise”
column6: but worst is Baauer’s grotesquely garish “You & Me”. The remix is clearly designed for the EDM festivals he gets booked for in the wake of “Harlem Shake”
column7: but it's one that eviscerates the original’s delicate space. (Flume’s version of “You & Me” at least heightens the drama.)

column1: Settle: The Remixes is a mostly fine listen
column2: but Disclosure’s two originals do make you wonder why they even bothered. “Apollo”
column3: which kicks off this album
column4: is probably the deepest house track they’ve ever made
column5: and as an open gesture to clubs it more or less invalidates the remixes here (T. Williams’ “Latch” or Preditah’s “Stimulation”) that seem to be tailored towards DJs that might never drop a Disclosure cut. Then there’s “Together”
column6: the Lawrences' collaboration with Nile Rodgers
column7: Smith
column8: and Jimmy Napes
column9: who co-wrote “Latch.”

column1: “Together” is a squeeze of squelching funk—a deft one-off experiment as long as you can ignore how easy it is to hum the chorus of “Suit & Tie” over the guitar lick. Smith sings of relaxing while draining a bottle of Sauvignon: “Let’s unwind together/ Ease our minds together.” It’s arguably a curious song to tack onto the end of a remix album
column2:
the type of project that often causes plenty of headaches while never quite coming together right. Nowadays we call this a subtweet.

It’s the ironic fate of almost any sufficiently forward-looking art to eventually become retro kitsch in the eyes of later audiences
column2: who can laugh at its naive attempts to predict a future they’ve already lived through. Cybotron’s 1983 album Enter
column3: which is widely considered to be where Detroit techno began
column4: isn’t so much forward-looking as it is obsessed with the future as co-creators Juan Atkins and Richard Davis saw it
column5: a vision dominated by the notion that human life would become so intertwined with technology that they’d be essentially inseparable. (The group’s name was a portmanteau of the words “cyborg” and “cyclotron
column6: ” and it was founded on the principle that a computer can be as good or better a musical collaborator as a person. At least part of the reason they played with drum machines in the first place was because Davis found human drummers unreliable.) As such it seems like it would be especially vulnerable to this effect
column7: but judging by its latest reissue (which nearly doubles its tracks with remixes
column8: instrumentals
column9: and non-album singles) the worst damage that three decades have inflicted upon Enter is that some of its features—Davis’ stagey vocals
column10: the Kraftwerkian drum machines
column11: the occasional outburst of heavy metal guitar shredding—have become synonymous with the 80s
column12: or at least how the era’s portrayed in hacky
column13: 80s-themed comedies.

column1: Davis and Atkins’ reliance on electronic sounds is less an aesthetic statement than a revolutionary one. They were among the first American pop musicians to fully grasp that synthesizers weren’t just a modern update of the organ but an entirely new kind of instrument
column2: capable not only of emulating traditional instrumental sounds but obliterating them entirely. Even more importantly
column3: they seem to have understood that this new technology had the potential to dramatically change the relationship between musicians and their instruments: when a person presses play on a drum machine’s pre-sequenced pattern
column4: are they playing the drum machine or is it playing itself?

column1: As diehard technophiles Atkins and Davis had no problem putting their gear front and center in the mix. Aside from their vocals and (on a few songs) John Housely’s guitar you can’t usually tell which parts were played by a person and which were sequenced. Trying to puzzle that out in a time where computer-assisted music making is commonplace enough that we can do it on our phones offers the barest hint of how challenging the concept was then.

But Enter isn’t just a record that should be listened to because it’s important—history aside it’s an intensely pleasurable experience. While you can make out the almost-completed outline of Detroit techno that Atkins and a few other musicians would fill in soon after
column2: it’s not a techno record
column3: exactly. The songs are more pop-oriented
column4: with the verse-chorus-verse structures that techno treated as optional
column5: and as much as Atkins and Davis were trying to emulate Kraftwerk
column6: they were just as heavily influenced by Funkadelic
column7: which comes through in their trippy Afrofuturistic lyrics and in Bootsy-esque bass lines that were far funkier than what Kraftwerk could manage. Neither of them had fully immersed themselves in the man-machine merger that would come to define techno
column8: and there’s a kind of loose warm-bloodedness around the edges that makes the album feel like Davis and Atkins weren’t so much programming machines as trying to teach them the essential concept of funk.

column1: The majority of people who attempt to predict the future end up dead wrong
column2: but Atkins and Davis were pretty spot on about where pop music was headed. Like William Gibson
column3: who was writing Neuromancer while they were recording Enter
column4: they pulled this off by building a future that inspired other people enough to make it a reality. As well as becoming sample material for an untold number of musicians (“Clear”’s blippy synths provide the backbone to Missy Elliott’s 2005 “Lose Control” and Poison Clan’s 1992 “Shake Whatcha Mama Gave Ya”
column5: among others)
column6: it laid out a whole musical philosophy that made more sense the more technology integrated itself into the act of making music
column7: which is partly because of people trying to do what Cybotron was doing. In retrospect it was a self-fulfilling prophecy
column8:
and one that’s only becoming more influential all the time.

It's dicey to try and recapture the spark of a triumph more than ten years past
column2: especially when that particular spark hit at the halfway mark of an already-long career that had reached a major and necessary reinvention point. But here's the funny thing about the rejuvenation efforts Del the Funky Homosapien's undergone over the past six months: after turning in a weary
column3: muddled-sounding
column4: much-belated sequel to his highly revered Deltron 3030 guise
column5: he just popped up and abruptly dropped a no-hype free release that's easily the most consistently satisfying thing he's done since 2000. And it's in a sort of permutation of his style that evokes that very same 2000—not the towering concept-record ambition of Deltron
column6: but a compact reprise of the mocking
column7: unpredictable endorphin rush of Both Sides of the Brain. “Lyrically ill but fun to listen to
column8: nothing super heavy
column9: ” he describes Iller Than Most on that Soundcloud page. It's a bit of an understatement.

column1: For one thing
column2: Iller Than Most is off-the-hinges ridiculous. If your follow-up question to that description is “ridiculous good or ridiculous goofy?” the answer is a straight-up “yes”: Del in peak cartoon taunt mode is all kinds of preposterous
column3: dedicated as much to twisting his own voice into grotesque yet charismatic caricatures of itself as he is to talking smack in more traditional cadence. (Think less “late-period Eminem” and more “peak E-40""). That approach pays off early with the opening one-two of “Leader” and “Boogieman""
column4: where he respectively goes Russell-Crowe-berserk on some ripoff artists and warns oblivious crumbsnatchers to check under their beds. It's like inverted horrorcore
column5: serial-asskicker/supernatural-force rhetoric wrung inside-out to wiseass effect.

column1: And here's another lure for you: Del's production style alone is worth the price of admission (or it would be if there was any admission). For someone who came up on his lyrical reputation
column2: he's also musically minded enough to pull off immediate hooks and find a way to make the one jump out on even the more left-field beats. Tracks range from simple-enough hard-knock minimalism laced with laser-ricochet drums (“Delta Time”
column3: “Militant”) to clanky
column4: shoulder-disjointing squalls (“Robust”
column5: “Bitin' Ain't Samplin'”) that should have fans asking him what his favorite Death Grips track is. The last moments of closer “Land of Immediate Rap Hits” is a blast of gargling decay that makes the ideal playlist segue into your track of choice from Government Plates.

column1: For the most part
column2: Iller Than Most is good old-fashioned self-big-up material
column3: though it's not entirely fair to call something old-fashioned if it's done in a style without much precedent outside Del's corner of the Bay. As one-note as it gets to hear him go on and on about his underground realness (“Robust”) and mano y mano mic scraps (“10 Paces”) and mental fitness (“Mental Fitness”)
column4: it's still impressive how he's still found ways to make those lines stand out more than twenty years after his sophomore album. The monomaniacal rap-battler tunnelvision that fueled 93's No Need for Alarm is the lyrical mode of choice here to seep into the Both Sides vibe
column5: but with the abrupt rubber-voiced u-turns and cranky ad-libs
column6:
it's too fun to feel like being buried under a pile of recycled wolf tickets.

A lot more goes into release dates than ""seasonal appropriateness

column4: but Painted Palms' Forever sure doesn't feel like a January record. The long-gestating debut LP from the San Francisco psych-pop duo is a bright
column5: spangling
column6: decidedly summery affair
column7: all radiant harmonies and warm reverberations. Forever's pleasures are simple
column8: breezy
column9: a little like bringing a parka to the pool: you're supposed to dive right in
column10: not waste a lot of time peeling back the layers. Forever is lush
column11: easygoing
column12: 39 balmy minutes in paradise. But spend too much time in these all-too-pleasant surroundings
column13:
and you can't help but feel like you've been there before.

Cousins Reese Donohue and Christopher Prudhomme planted the seeds of Painted Palms when the pair were separated by a dozen states
column14: gradually building up tracks from the snippets they'd shoot back-and-forth through email. And
column15: though they've both called San Francisco home for a number of years
column16: Forever's shimmering construction is mostly in line with their earlier efforts. Like a lot of young bands
column17: they're certainly not shy about their fondness for the Beach Boys and their legions of sonic followers; especially Animal Collective
column18: and even more especially

column21: in Prudhomme
column22: they've got a singer who serves as their answer to Noah Lennox. On ""Too High
column24: Prudhomme cuts through the track's radar-gun reverb with a swooping
column25: choirboy-in-an-echo-chamber vocal line packed with the long vowel sounds Lennox favors. The similarities don't stop in Prudhomme's throat; between Forever's droning intros
column28:
it's fairly clear just who these guys owe much of their sound to.

Lyrically
column29: Forever concerns itself with a lot of minor communication breakdowns: ""never ever said the things that mattered
column30: ""she didn't understand that I was having trouble in my head."" And
column31: in keeping with the music's endlessly summery vibe

column34: ""I can't tell if I'm high or low."" What there's not
column37: anything lending these songs much in the way of consequence or fervor. That ""never said the things that mattered"" line (from ""Soft Hammer""
