column40: built around strong—if not particularly distinctive—melodies. But
column41: since Prudhomme and Donohue haven't quite yet figured out how to assert themselves above their fairly obvious influences
column43:
they're a little lacking.

Between the carefully plotted reference points and the not-exactly-gripping lyrics
column44: Forever tends to run together over the course of its 39-minute runtime. Still
column46: there's no shortage of takeaways: the bouncy ""Not Really There""
column48: the late-LP one-two of the brash ""Spinning Signs"" and the tender ""Sleepwalking."" Donohue and Prudhomme certainly know their way around a melody
column49: and their careful craftsmanship puts them a notch or two ahead of the oft-slapdash box-ticking of a lot of easily led up-and-comers. But
column50: if they hope to keep it going through the next cold snap
column51:
Painted Palms still need to figure out a way to bring a little more of themselves to the party.

column3: ” says the Gories’ Mick Collins in Eric Davidson’s We Never Learn: The Gunk Punk Undergut
column5: “was to be a band that was so raw and primitive that it would change their definitions of those words.” Mission accomplished. Before breaking up in 1992
column6: the trio of Collins
column7: fellow singer/guitarist Dan Kroha
column8: and drummer Peggy O’Neill set back garage rock by thirty years—which was exactly the point. Disgusted by the polished jangle of much of the garage revival of the 80s
column9: the Gories turned rudimentary musicianship into a fuck-you virtue
column10: making the punk of any era sound like Vivaldi. Until now
column11: the Gories have been documented by studio recordings
column12: including three untouchably savage LPs and a barrage of singles and compilation cuts. The only thing missing was a live album—which has now been rectified by The Shaw Tapes: Live in Detroit 5/27/88.

column1: Recorded at a party in a converted Detroit storefront in the spring of 1988—a year before the Gories’ debut album
column2: House Rockin’—The Shaw Tapes bleeds Motor City tradition. Of the albums many cover songs
column3: four of them are by Detroit artists: the Keggs’ 60s garage-punk scorcher “To Find Out”; Eddie Holland’s punchy
column4: early-Motown R&B stomper “Leaving Here” (although the Gories’ rendition seems to owe more to the Who’s guitar-heavy 1965 version); the Stooges’ primal
column5: sinister “Real Cool Time”; and “Again & Again
column6: ” a rare track by Iggy Pop’s pre-Stooges outfit the Iguanas. “To Find Out” is the only song of the four that the Gories eventually recording in the studio. The rest are pulped to a slovenly blur of brute havoc. As if deconstructing the Detroit rock mythos he’d never stray from (his current band the Dirtbombs included)
column7: Collins howls his head off during a run through John Lee Hooker’s seminal 1948 debut
column8: “Boogie Chillen’”—a song that recounts Hooker’s arrival in Detroit (where the original single was recorded)
column9: and his experience being a stranger who “was walking down Hastings Street”
column10: heard tell of “Henry’s Swing Club”
column11: and dropped in to find everyone “really having a ball.”

column1: That same air of raucous chaos suffuses The Shaw Tapes. The storefront that the Gories played in may not have been Henry’s Swing Club
column2: but it swung nonetheless—that is
column3: if the crowd noise is to be believed. Sweat practically oozes out of the group’s feverish
column4: stripped-to-the-skivvies versions of the Stoics’ nasty
column5: 1967 anthem “Hate”
column6: not to mention a face-clawing brawl with the Yardbirds’ arrangement of Tiny Bradshaw’s “Train Kept-A-Rollin’”. It’s the scabrous renditions of Gories originals
column7: though
column8: that is most gripping. Drawn almost entirely from the body of material that would form House Rockin’
column9: these off-kilter
column10: out-of-tune iterations of “I Think I’ve Had It”
column11: “Charm Bag”
column12: “Sovereignty Flight”
column13: and “Give Me Love” show just how deliberate their demolition was before it became ever-so-slightly contained it. And when Collins busts into the soon-to-be-anthem “Thunderbird ESQ”—an ode to the fortified wine he’s admitted to chugging whole bottles of before going onstage back then—it’s as if the song had always existed
column14: a fossil just waiting to be excavated
column15: cloned
column16: and set loose upon the world.

column1: As blistering and vital as The Shaw Tapes is

column6:
feral gang of throwbacks reinventing a genre by uninventing it.

Back in 2000
column2: Bruce Springsteen debuted a new song called “American Skin (41 Shots)” at a concert in Atlanta. It was
column3: he claimed

column5: an unarmed West African immigrant who was shot 19 times when four New York City police officers mistook his wallet for a gun. The song was a deeply empathetic response to the tragedy
column6: as a famous rock star tried to see the world from the point of view of both the police officers who work rough neighborhoods and the African American residents who find themselves in danger for even the most harmless actions. Even before many people had actually heard it
column7: “American Skin” sparked controversy
column8: as New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani and Police Chief Howard Safir publically condemned both the singer and the song. Particularly egregious was the reaction of Bob Lucente
column9: the head of the State Fraternal Order of Police
column10: who called Springsteen both a “dirtbag” and a “floating fag.”

column1: For his part
column2: Springsteen weathered the uproar stoically. He explained in interviews that the song wasn’t necessarily anti-cop
column3: but he didn’t shy away from making it a permanent addition to his setlists during that tour. A studio version was released to radio stations
column4: but the song wasn’t available commercially until the following year
column5: when it appeared at the beginning of disc two of 2001’s Live in New York City. In the decade since
column6: it has collected dust as a footnote in Springsteen’s late-career catalog—a reminder
column7: when you needed one
column8: that he could still write a powerful and topical song. In 2009
column9: however
column10: he revived “American Skin” and began dedicating performances to Trayvon Martin
column11: and that sad new relevance is ostensibly the reason the song appears on Springsteen’s 18th album
column12: <i>High Hopes
column13: a collection of new recordings of songs that he has been playing for 10 or 12 years. Essentially these are all outtakes from The Rising
column14: Magic
column15: and Working on a Dream
column16: but Springsteen re-recorded them with producer Ron Aniello and sequenced them into a standalone album.

column1: The Boss has a famously deep archive of quality songs from throughout his career
column2: so there’s no reason to scoff at the concept behind High Hopes. Fans have been bootlegging these songs for years now
column3: which means the album is aptly titled: There are high hopes for studio versions of almost all of these songs
column4: especially “American Skin”. The new version
column5: though
column6: has stiff competition. The performance on Live in New York City gains its power from the concert setting
column7: with the E Street Band alternating vocals to create a sense of community and Clarence Clemons’ sax solo sounding like a heartfelt eulogy. The studio version from 2001 duplicates that arrangement
column8: only without Springsteen telling the crowd
column9: “We need a little quiet.”

column1: But
column2: unfortunately
column3: the High Hopes recording of “American Skin” highlights everything that’s gone wrong with Springsteen’s music in the 21st century. It’s garish and melodramatic
column4: with a cluttered arrangement and slick production that distracts from its message. The song open with Springsteen singing ""41 shots
column5: but his vocals are distorted and distant--a cheap effect. There is some industrial percussion that would have sounded dated in 2000
column6: and there is Tom Morello’s guitar solo
column7: which could have been cribbed from some third-tier 80s power ballad. In 2013
column8: the song is too aware of its own import
column9: which means it strains for the same sense of gravity that once came easily. Live
column10: Springsteen was able to play up the contradictions and colliding perspectives fueling the country’s race problems
column11: even implicating himself in the process
column12: but now his outrage has curdled into something like dulled resignation.

column1: Springsteen has struggled in the 2000s to find the best musical vehicle for his thoughts on the state of America. Live
column2: the E Street Band can be a powerhouse
column3: as the sexagenarian continues to exude charisma and energy on stage. The studio
column4: however
column5: is another thing. Nebraska aside
column6: Springsteen has never been a minimalist
column7: but his recent output has been maximalist in all the wrong directions. Rather than the Spectorian wall of sound he perfected on Born to Run and The River
column8: he now dabbles in studio gimmicks that sound both expensive and dated: vocal distortion
column9: caked-on production
column10: pots-and-pans percussion
column11: inert drum loops
column12: a puzzling fascination with Celtic flourishes. On High Hopes the thick arrangements distract from the good songwriting and conceal the bad
column13: often to the extent that it’s impossible to discern which is which.

column1: The result is an album that often sounds salvageable but continually trips over its own ambitions and good intentions. On “Heaven’s Wall” the gospel choir overwhelms the song completely
column2: disrupting the careful cadence of the verses and any nuance the lyrics might carry; rather than righteous
column3: it comes across as self-righteous. “Harry’s Place” is all setting and no story
column4: with details borrowed from an Elmore Leonard novel. Most tragic may be the closing cover of Suicide’s “Dream Baby Dream”
column5: which begins promisingly with Springsteen’s gravelly voice and an accordion mimicking the New York duo’s gutter drone. It’s a quietly powerful moment
column6: but you just know he’s going to do something to ruin it. And sure enough the song builds to a manufactured climax full of corny drum loops and gloppy strings.

column1: Springsteen is too much of a control freak to escape blame
column2: but perhaps most culpable is Tom Morello
column3: who is apparently a member of the E Street Band now. For the last few years Morello has grown seemingly embarrassed by his rap-rock history with Rage Against the Machine
column4: when making his guitar sound like a turntable carried some cultural weight. He does share with Springsteen a few populist heroes
column5: namely Woody Guthrie and John Steinbeck. Otherwise
column6: they apparently have little in common beyond their politics
column7: and Morello sounds awkwardly fitted to these songs. He shreds gracelessly through the cover of the Havalinas’ “High Hopes” and clutters “Heaven’s Wall” with squall and distortion. When his guitar isn’t disruptive
column8: it’s simply superfluous. Often it’s just dumbfounding: his solos on “The Ghost of Tom Joad”—which gets a passable cock-rock makeover that owes a debt to Rage Against the Machine’s cover—sound like David Gilmour sitting in with Cinderella.

column1: An unwelcome presence
column2: Morello is simply the most obvious of many elements on High Hopes that just don’t work. It’s all the more unfortunate given that there are actually some redeemable songs here
column3: along with some brief glimpses of Springsteen the rock'n'roll storyteller. Even as he eclipses 60
column4: he’s one of the few rock veterans still concerned with actually rocking
column5: which he does convincingly on “Just Like Fire Would” and “Frankie Fell in Love”—two negligible songs that you might dismiss on a better album. Here they sound actually feisty and even ribald
column6: with a fire that is squelched on the more serious numbers. I can’t tell if those highs actually redeem the album somewhat or make it even more of a disappointment
column7: but I do know that the out-in-the-streets details of “Frankie Fell in Love” are more humane and meaningful than the grandiose philosophizing of “Hunter of Invisible Game”. Instead of trying so hard to live up to the times
column8:
perhaps he just needs to work on capturing a moment.

“I really wanted to make the worst thing
column2: the thing that even people who liked bad
column3: terrible music wouldn’t like
column4: the stuff that people would ignore
column5: always. Something really
column6: really stupid. Something that is destined for failure.” So Ariel Pink told me back in the summer of 2012 about why—in addition to studying and making art—he started recording music at home while still a disgruntled teenager. And while the phantasmal-turned-flesh band of his Ariel Pink’s Haunted Graffiti started in the early 21st century and metastasized into the Zeitgeist by decade’s end
column7: this 2xCD digs into Pink’s earliest rock dreams
column8: of becoming “the worst thing
column9: ” wherein a wooden Pinocchio wakes up one day to be a real live piece of shit. While his wish might have been that people would always ignore such early experiments
column10: Early Live Recordings proves that qualities such as stupidity and failure can too be destined to become a commodity.

column1: While there are no exact dates to peg either disc one’s project title Gorilla or disc two’s Appleasians to
column2: both recordings appear to predate Pink’s inspired 21st century spurts. The press sheet hints at these 36 tracks being “salvaged from the same scratchpile of crumbling CD-Rs and 8-track cassettes” that also produced last year’s Thrash & Burn set. My guess would be that Gorilla is the documented proof of what Pink described as his first forays into recording
column3: which entailed “an unplugged bass and a three-string guitar recorded through a set of headphones
column4: which (was) used as a microphone.”

column1: They are lo-fi recordings to say the least
column2: heavy on detuned bass
column3: lackadaisical tambourine rattles
column4: and feral growls
column5: all of it couched in tape murk. Opener “Berzerker” has lurching bass
column6: coughs
column7: and feedback that gobbles up everything on the tape. Elsewhere Pink approximates a rabid bark
column8: tries on a dozen different personas as he wails “Why am I so sad?
column9: ” growls out “Nazi love” as if gargling bile
column10: and deploys a plugged nose British accent that might prove paternity to King Krule. There’s also four excruciating minutes of him incanting “by the powers of Grayskull.”

column1: Things brighten considerably on Appleasians
column2: as he fumbles towards lyrics and chords over stains of noise. “Tractor Man” shows the earliest glint of Pink’s pop acumen and glib vocals. Songs like “Something in Your Eye” and “Inside Looking Out” features the chug
column3: stumble
column4: and sneer of an early garage rock single
column5: one that bore fruit on Before Today’s cover of the Ramrods’ “Bright Lit Blue Skies”.

column1: But as the set stumbles along
column2: Pink tips his hand as that mythological unlearned naïf
column3: that unfrozen caveman in modern society. The back half of Gorilla finds him namechecking Can’s gibberish specialist Damo Suzuki and the Germs’ Darby Crash
column4: proof that even in making terrible music that barely approximates either man’s mutterings
column5: he had immaculate taste in both German prog and LA’s scum punk. And on Appleasians
column6: he tackles two totemic 60s primitives
column7: the Godz and the Shaggs. He condenses the epic thud of the former’s “Crusade” to a concise 2:50 while finding the bizarre sweetness of the latter’s “My Cutie”
column8: a deep album cut from their even more obscure 1982 album
column9: Shaggs’ Own Thing.

column1: While excavating the eight Haunted Graffiti albums revealed repulsive and alluring sounds in equal measure
column2: Early Live Recordings' only real crime is that little of it fascinates. Poking about here for the roots of Pink’s omnivorous pop genius ultimately bears little in the way of edible fruit
column3: but he himself has never pretended to be anything otherwise: “I’m not trying to break new ground
column4: ” he said in that cover story. “That’s part of the whole point. The stagnation of things is inherent in my cerebral process.” Stagnant yes
column5:
but consider this to be the cesspool from which a 21st century idiot savant arose.

Roc Marciano works in details rather than large
column3: dramatic brush strokes. Like fellow New York MC Ka
column4: Marciano's voice rarely rises above a conversational purr—you need to really lean in close to get the full effect. He doesn't build narratives as much as construct small
column5: distinct images and then stack them on top of each other. Even his beats are designed to shade
column6: rather than color
column7: his songs. Over the course of his first two albums
column8: he's established himself as one of the foremost purveyors of classicist New York slick-talk
column9: digging into a very specific sound and exploring just how far down he can go. His latest release
column10: Marci Beaucoup
column11: finds Marciano stepping out of the spotlight ever so slightly and instead focusing more on his production chops than his already-proven lyrical skills.

column1: Whereas 2012's Reloaded was a comparatively lighter sonic affair than its predecessor
column2: the bleaker Marcberg
column3: Marci Beaucoup hews closer to the grimier aesthetic of Marciano's debut
column4: where the production felt more off-the-cuff and rougher around the edges. Like that album
column5: the beats on Marci Beaucoup are handled entirely by Marciano
column6: and they alternate between minimalist RZA-esque menace and monochromatic soul. As a producer
column7: Marciano shares the same penchant for bite-sized vocal loops that were J Dilla's bread and butter
column8: and he's able to create a palpable tension by drawing out the hypnotic qualities in them. ""Love Means"" is only allowed to unspool during its brief hook—otherwise
column9: it's all creeping dread masquerading as a serenade. These sorts of little touches can be found everywhere: horns lazily snake into the corners of ""Squeeze""; shouts from what sound like children on a playground litter ""Dollar Bitch""; elsewhere
column10: a single bleat from an ill-timed chop signals the end of each loop on the loping ""War Scars"".

column1: These beats are insistent and physical
column2: even when they're made out of lullabies twisted into unnatural shapes
column3: as is the case with ""Didn't Know""
column4: an example of Marciano's willingness to think outside of the box as a producer. Like every track on the album
column5: a few friends pop by to help out
column6: but only Freeway sounds totally out of his element here
column7: his verse only made worse by the virulent homophobia contained within it.

column1: Because there's not a single track where Marciano raps on his own
column2: Marci Beaucoup feel like a compilation curated by Marciano more than a true solo effort. And as solid as these beats are
column3: they best fit the kind of rappers who operate in a headspace similar to Marciano's
column4: but that's not always who ends up on them. Those with tightly-coiled deliveries fare best—Boldy James scrapes the bottom of ""Trying to Come Up"" as if he hasn't eaten in a month
column5: and Action Bronson adds some much welcome levity to ""456"".

column1: Perhaps unsurprisingly
column2: it's Ka
column3: the rapper who best compliments Marciano
column4: who steals the tracks he shows up on with his blank-faced gravitas. Unfortunately
column5: too many appearances from third-stringers like Knowledge the Pirate and Maffew Ragazino just made me wish Marciano was rapping instead
column6: and a few more solo cuts would've helped alleviate the frequent soggy stretches. As a proper third album
column7: Marci Beaucoup doesn't stack up to its precursors
column8: but as an advertisement for Marciano's services as a beatsmith
column9:
it's much more successful.

It’s tempting to frame the career of Aussie quartet Blank Realm as a steady progression from noisy obscurity to clearer songcraft. It’s also not too difficult: connect the dots between the dark sounds of early CD-R’s
column2: the dense psych of 2010’s Headless Ark
column3: and the damaged rock of 2012’s Go Easy
column4: and you’ll trace an arc sloping toward accessibility. And their latest
column5: Grassed Inn
column6: is their most structured
column7: tune-heavy album—as well as their best.

column1: But things are never that easy with Blank Realm. Sharp tunes have popped up throughout their discography
column2: often sandwiched between denser noises. Take their catchiest song to date
column3: “Falling Down the Stairs.” It’s the second track on Grassed Inn
column4: but it’s actually been in the band’s repertoire for a while
column5: with live evidence dating back as far as two years ago. More importantly
column6: Grassed Inn is far from smooth or streamlined. The band remains unafraid to spill outside lines
column7: hit off awkward phrases and off notes
column8: and continually stretch themselves. They’ll still take energy and impulse over caution or precision
column9: and that gives even their shapliest songs an edge of unpredictability. It also means that
column10: like every Blank Realm album before it
column11: Grassed Inn makes more sense—and sounds better and better—the more you listen.

column1: A lot of that grow-on-you logic comes from the vocals of siblings Daniel and Sarah Spencer. Their high-pitched snarls still evoke the two-headed Stones-licking of Neil Hagerty and Jennifer Herrema during Royal Trux’s prime. The combination gives chugging opener “Back to the Flood” dizzying momentum
column2: and pushes the loping “Bulldozer Love” into a rave-up rush. What’s different this time is Daniel’s more prominent role. His breathy whine leads most tracks
column3: echoed by the silkier purr of Sarah. His knack at tugging at lines
column4: elongating vowels
column5: and yelping words reminds me most of Richard Hell and Lou Reed. Both saw unconventional voices not as weaknesses but weapons
column6: making every syllable expressive instead of falling back on natural talent. Daniel’s similar skills create tension when paired with structured songs
column7: often bending them to match his curvy
column8: spiked path.

column1: As a result
column2: as you get deeper into Grassed Inn and more in tune with Daniel’s probing style
column3: less-overtly catchy tracks become as earworm-ready as “Falling Down the Stairs.” The drum-machine pulse of “Violet Delivery” builds into waves every time Daniel and Sarah overstress the song’s title
column4: while “Baby Closes the Door” coalesces into Flying Nun-style garage-pop
column5: albeit filtered through Sonic Youth-like guitar dissonance. Blank Realm’s endearing slacker side persists too: “Even the Score” sounds like a sleepy Yo La Tengo amble
column6: or a stoner take on the Velvet Underground’s <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I'm_Waiting_for_the_Man"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“Waiting for the Man
column7: ” giving its title a hint of double entendre.

column1: After all that sideways approach to melodic tuneage
column2: it makes weird sense that Blank Realm would end Grassed Inn with a song perhaps catchier
column3: and definitely slicker
column4: than “Falling Down the Stairs.” The lilting “Reach You on the Phone” could almost fit in an 80’s movie soundtrack
column5: its soaring synth seemingly nicked from groups like the Church and Psychedelic Furs. Were the band to make an album of just songs like this
column6: it would be hard to resist their odd shine. But Blank Realm is still bent on mixing the diamonds with the rough
column7:
and on Grassed Inn that particular swirl is at its most intoxicating.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20047/homepage_large.f30d0ef5.jpg|Until the Colours Run|31954.0|Lanterns on the Lake|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bella Union']|2014-01-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:20.016702|"

Lanterns on the Lake’s second album Until the Colours Run is borne of loss
column2: turmoil and doubt on every level: Adam and Brendan Sykes left the UK quintet following their 2011 debut Gracious Tide
column3: Take Me Home
column4: the remaining members were scrambling to finish the record with almost no financial resources. Singer Hazel Wilde has cited the grim economic outlook of her homeland as a main lyrical influence. And so
column5: there you have it—Until the Colours Run certainly doesn’t lack for external drama
column6: serving as both a make-or-break album and a reintroduction.

column1: Marquee indie rock acts like Vampire Weekend
column2: Arcade Fire and probably the National are bands who work outside typical power trio structures while their lyrical concerns trace concentric circles of worry
column3: from personal to societal to political to spiritual. And it’s populist for an ability to establish a relatable foothold lyrically and leave it up to the listener whether they want it to serve as direct commentary or grand allegory. This is progress for Lanterns on the Lake
column4: who generated similar comparisons on Gracious Tide based on Paul Gregory’s string-laden arrangements and production. Until the Colours Run is warmer and more organic than its predecessor
column5: though still squarely within indie rock’s “baroque” settings
column6: nearly every component given a pleasingly faded luster: silvery guitar figures that twinkle
column7: glisten and decay
column8: echoing drums that sound both intimidating and fragile
column9: a sobering layer of reverb over Wilde’s vocals. Whether it’s the all-out
column10: crescendoing assaults of “Elodie” or the one-take piano ballad “Green & Gold<i>""
column11: Until the Colours Run always bears the weight of its struggles
column12: expressing even its joy in antiquated and Americanized imagery of unemployment lines and buffalos; as indicated by the record’s key line of “we’ll drink and sing on the breadline
column13: happiness rarely exists on its own terms
column14: but rather as a counter to exceedingly difficult circumstances.

column1: It’s not to the discredit of LotL that Until the Colours Run lacks unfettered happiness or guileless pop pleasure. More problematic is that it lacks release of any kind
column2: cathartic or otherwise. Thematically
column3: LotL express faded glory and missed opportunities while exhibiting potential with so many rich sounds and potent concepts. Unfortunately
column4: they often lack the things that separate the aforementioned A-listers from the scores of similarly-minded bands
column5: namely
column6: propulsion
column7: hooks and personal detail. Opener “Elodie” whips up a dramatic setting with the same skyward drum rolls and pinging guitars that allowed Explosions in the Sky to corner the market on “cinematic” and “sweeping
column8: ” but the melody and rhythm of the verse never find their footing. It’s indicative of LotL’s most disappointing habit going forward
column9: of introducing an arresting melody or guitar figure that ultimately gets lost in muddled compositions or overbearing production tricks. Based on its title and its position as the penultimate track
column10: you know “Another Tale From Another English Town” is meant as the final pep talk
column11: and “We’ve been sold a thousand lies/we just wanted the quiet life/but they won’t stop until they see us in the ground” certainly sounds like a rallying cry
column12: albeit one that’s universal because it bears no sense of the troubles specific to Wilde or her bandmates.

column1: Unintentionally
column2: “Another Tale” does become emblematic of Until the Colours Run’s unmet ambitions
column3: which ends up recalling the sound of the National less than one of their most oft-quoted lyrics: “let’s not try and figure out everything at once.” It’s sound advice for LotL
column4: not just in regards to their overzealously embellished music
column5: but also as a rejoinder to the record's emotional tenor
column6: a jittery
column7: post-caffeine comedown where you’ve recognized the tasks at hand for the day and they seem just a little too daunting to even begin tackling. If you’re in that mindframe
column8: Until the Colours Run works just fine for an all-purpose wallow
column9:
but it’s simply too ponderous to be the galvanizing social commentary to which it aspires.

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2014-01-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:20.650991|"

Many groups go away then return to us diminished—Goodie Mob
column3: Black Flag
column4: the Stooges
column5: Smashing Pumpkins. We have more or less reconciled ourselves to this phenomenon. But very few bands come back wiped clean of their basic essence
column6: as the Pixies did with last fall's EP-1. Their mystery
column7: their fidgety precision
column8: their peculiar tensed grin
column9: was simply erased
column10: replaced by an utterly indistinguishable modern rock band. The severity of the cognitive dissonance was almost fascinating
column11: or it would have been if the music weren't so brutally anodyne. Had any legendary band returned with new material this limp and attenuated before?

column1: We have another chance to consider the question. EP-2
column2: released this week
column3: dates from the same recording sessions as the first. (There is one more on the way.) The four new songs here are less blank than the four on the first
column4: if only marginally: ""Magdalena"" and ""Snakes"" arouse the faint suspicion that you might be listening to the Pixies
column5: or at least vaguely Pixies-inspired music. The minor-key chorus and stairstep chord progression to ""Magdalena"" is the most harmonically rich moment they've managed since reuniting. Black's lead vocal is muted and sensitive
column6: and it sounds
column7: passingly
column8: like a lesser track from Bossanova or Teenager of the Year.

column1: They are the only moments
column2: however. The appealing
column3: smeary lead guitar line on ""Green and Blues"" introduces a thin
column4: banal rock song
column5: both melodically and lyrically devoid of interesting ideas—the chorus turns on “I'm wasting your time just talking to you/ Maybe best to go on home/I’ll leave you alone.” Black sings of being an alien
column6: a visitor
column7: but his eccentricity
column8: his fundamental strangeness
column9: has never been less evident. The Pixies traded in unpredictability and startling outbursts—they were pixies
column10: for god's sake. Mischief
column11: subversion
column12: and nonsense were part of their job description. Frank's scream used to be vivid in part because it emerged out of nowhere
column13: a teddy bear that suddenly became a golem. On""Blue Eyed Hexe""
column14: he screams like a Brian Johnson imitator over a foursquare riff with no wit or play in it
column15: the clonking woodblock hitting like a kid brother socking you repeatedly in the arm. It is arguably worse
column16: more slow-witted
column17: and painful than anything on the original EP.

column1: The gulf between the feel this music has on the mind and the name on the cover remains jarring. Frank Black has been making more traditional
column2: MOR rock recordings under his own name since the Pixies disbanded
column3: but even his most meat-and-potatoes solo offerings had something—a flutter of vulnerability
column4: a darker streak beneath the riffs that suggested mischief and imagination. When he played with country and roots-rock tropes on quickly assembled
column5: low-stakes creative projects like Paley & Francis
column6: the crooked grin was legible beneath the surface. The songs collected on these two EPs display almost no creative vision or signature.

column1: Black and the remaining original members—Joey Santiago
column2: David Lovering—seem intent
column3: above all
column4: on pushing their brand forward. They recently dismissed Kim Shattuck
column5: the bassist hired in Kim Deal’s conspicuous absence
column6: and hired Paz Lenchantin. In all of this
column7: they are moving with a bracing
column8: almost refreshingly blunt cynicism: the Pixies are a franchise now
column9: and franchises need to keep moving. Fair enough. But even the most mercenary-minded
column10: craven reboot works if there is some evident love of the source material
column11: and this is where these EPs fail so pitifully. These eight songs would be subpar
column12: unremarkable work for a band with no reputation or mythology to live up to; for the Pixies
column13:
they are an increasingly mournful asterisk affixed to a beloved legacy.

column3: 22-year-old Detroit-born rapper Angel Haze tweeted on December 18
column4: “but fuck you.” With that
column5: she did what Twitter agitators like M.I.A. and Young Jeezy have still only threatened—she went against her label and leaked her own album Dirty Gold
column6: which she claimed had been finished for seven months and would only gather dust in the three more before its slated March release. Naturally

column8: and Island/Republic rushed Dirty Gold’s official release date up to December 30. For Haze
column9: it was self-sabotage from a sales perspective (abysmal numbers and Somethin ‘Bout Kreay reminiscences have floated around Twitter this week)
column10: but in a video she posted a few days after the leak
column11: Haze was defiant
column12: heated and seemingly without a trace of regret. Still
column13: the fearless words she lobs at her label (""Yeah
column14: I’m gonna support your dreams
column15: but I’m also gonna fuck with them"") only underscore an unfortunate point: There’s a lot more fire in Angel Haze than you’d know from the often lackluster Dirty Gold.

column1: The initial releases that gained Haze notice—first her brashly confessional Voice EP and then 2012’s head-turning Reservation—mixed an unlocked-diary sensibility with a machinegun flow. Haze was raised in what she’s called a religious cult—and in a strict Pentecostal household where pop and hip-hop were banned until she was 16. Her music displays the hyperactive enthusiasm and ferocious hunger of an autodidact making up for lost time: She often sounds like someone who quickly gobbled up every great record she missed out on in the 90s (early Eminem and Lauryn Hill especially) and wants to spit their teachings back at you as fast and nimbly as she can.
No one will come away from this album doubting Haze’s natural talent
column2: but Dirty Gold lacks the spark and distinct personality of a proper coming-out. In the past
column3: Haze’s most searing lines showed a knack for unflinching detail (2012’s ""Cleaning Out My Closet"" confronted the listener with the vivid realities of sexual abuse
column4: rather than the hazy
column5: comforting euphemisms we usually use to describe it)
column6: but too often the songs on Dirty Gold deal in vague troubles and one-size-fits-all obstacles. It’s a noble intention; she's clearly trying to reach out to the listener directly and make her music as inclusive as possible. But over the course of these 12 songs
column7: so much emphasis on universal ""trials"" and ""struggles"" actually has the opposite effect. ""Don’t give up
column8: she insists. ""You gotta make the decision to be the one difference in your life and turn it around."" Though her heart’s in the right place
column9: too often the big-tent slogans on Dirty Gold pass over you like the sayings on a high school guidance counselor’s bulletin board.

column1: ""Never catch me at the club/ I get high and dance alone
column2: Haze spits on one of the stickier tracks
column3: the strobe-lit single ""Echelon (It’s My Way)"". Though she’s always worn her outsider stance with pride
column4: Dirty Gold shows how it sometimes works against her. Left to her own devices
column5: Haze’s tastes skew maudlin (the first rap song inspired by a Tom DeLonge side project
column6: ""Angles & Airwaves"" makes a possibly intentional case for Haze as rap game Mitch Albom)
column7: but this might not be a problem if she found the right collaborator to prod her in more provocative directions and keep these impulses in check. Dirty Gold’s producer Markus Dravs—who recently won a Grammy for his work with Mumford & Sons and has also produced for Arcade Fire and Coldplay—doesn’t quite have the hip-hop pedigree to give Haze the distinct beats she’s still searching for. For all it boasts of independence
column8: Dirty Gold lifts some pretty obvious moves from recent chart-toppers: The hooky (and hokey) ""Planes Fly"" tries on Macklemore’s heart-on-faux-chinchilla-sleeve look; the hook (sung and written by Sia) on the montage-ready “Battle Cry” will leave you humming its doppelganger ""Love the Way You Lie""; and ""Echelon (It’s My Way)"" feels like an immaculately formatted resume slipped to someone at the A$AP Mob recruitment office.

column1: Dirty Gold is best when Haze puts her pop aspirations aside and just lets it rip. Written as ""a love letter or a piece of advice to [Haze’s] mother when she was [her] age
column2: the ferocious ""Black Dahlia"" has a pointed intensity and features some of the most impressive rapping on the album. And though ""Black Synagogue"" doesn’t bring the heat for its full seven minutes (like many of these songs
column3: it’s bogged down by one too many painfully stiff spoken word snippets)
column4: Haze taps into a raw nerve as she explores her ambivalence about her Pentecostal past. Dirty Gold is a relentless
column5: often exhausting listen—but tacked onto the end of the hour-plus deluxe edition there’s a taunting reminder of what else Haze can do. Though (or maybe because) it doesn’t aspire to any grand statements
column6: Reservation’s menacingly hushed
column7: effortlessly cool ""New York"" remains the most persuasive sermon she’s delivered.

column1: In the weeks leading up to the leak Dirty Gold
column2: Haze unveiled a project called 30 Gold
column3: which found her covering and freestyling over a different popular song each day for a month. Even though she was rapping over other people’s beats
column4: this project revealed more about who Angel Haze is than the limited confines of her proper debut. Her verse over ""Black Skinhead"" showed how arresting her flow can be when she’s given an innovative beat; her autobiographical revision of Macklemore’s ""Same Love"" was much more stirring than the original; even her acoustic cover of Miley Cyrus’s ""Wrecking Ball"" unveiled a grit in her singing voice that Dirty Gold’s production scrubs too clean. All of this (along with her dissatisfaction with the way this record was handled) seems to promise that whatever Haze does next will be more in keeping with her own eccentricities. ""Now you can sing about me
column5: she proclaims on the opening track
column6:
but too often Dirty Gold leaves you wondering how the tune of that one goes.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20070/homepage_large.de1f7d3f.jpg|Try Me|31958.0|Self Defense Family|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Deathwish']|2014-01-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:22.286413|"

Over 10 years and dozens of releases—both under their current name and previously as End of a Year—the post-hardcore band Self Defense Family have built themselves out of perversity. Before the so-called “emo revival” became widely reported on in 2013
column2: frontman Patrick Kindlon and crew had already rekindled the cathartic desperation of Fugazi’s two primary predecessors in the mid-80s
column3: Rites of Spring and Embrace (“End of a Year” being a song by the latter). Emo never really went away—but with End of a Year
column4: it finally came full circle. Kindlon
column5: though
column6: was just as apt to mix black humor
column7: jarring turns of phrase
column8: and pop-culture references into the band’s otherwise open-hearted hardcore. End of a Year’s gradual evolution into Self Defense Family has given Kindlon even more room to stray from emo fundamentalism—and on Self Defense’s official full-length debut
column9: Try Me
column10: stray he does.

column1: So does the group as a whole. Although most tracks on Try Me are taut and concise
column2: they’re built around churning
column3: sprawling riffs that feel far larger than the songs that contain them. On “Tithe Pig” and “Turn The Fan On”
column4: an atmospheric circularity creeps along
column5: and that lurching
column6: mesmeric sameness hits its apotheosis on “Dingo Fence”
column7: 10 minutes of spiraled repetition that recall the ringing
column8: primordial drone of another Dischord Records legend
column9: Lungfish. But this is music for disrupting trances
column10: not inducing them. “All the dumb cocks
column11: they get what they want
column12: ” Kindlon chants with ever-increasing belligerence throughout most of “Dingo Fence”—until he replaces “cocks” with “cunts
column13: ” and then ultimately “cops.” His voice is a raw
column14: blunt bark
column15: except for when it drops into a deceptively intimate lull.

column1: The problem with “Dingo Fence” is its intro. During a too-long intro
column2: Kindlon includes what seems like an impromptu
column3: spoken-word studio rant that dwells on his choice of cock
column4: cunt
column5: and cop that soon appears in the song itself. Flippant and dismissive
column6: Kindlon debates how each word choice might be construed before concluding that “I don’t have a preference. I really don’t. I could give a fuck.” It demystifies the song before it even has a chance to kick in—like watching the director’s commentary before seeing the film—and even if that’s the intention
column7: it drains Try Me’s crowning moments of  much of their power. It’s a wise-ass move more suited to Kindlon’s noise-punk side-project Drug Church
column8: whose 2013 debut Paul Walker—released months before the actor’s fatal car wreck—works better as a spasm of self-deconstruction.

column1: Elsewhere on Try Me
column2: Self Defense locks into a more focused
column3: if no less corrosive
column4: groove. “Nail House Music” is the album’s high point
column5: a lunging
column6: stomping anti-anthem that draws as much from the pulse of Lifter Puller and Wilderness as it does Fugazi. (Kindlon’s refrain of “I found you in the witch elm/ Who put you in the witch elm?” is strongly reminiscent of Guy Picciotto’s “Out of the ashtray/ Into the ashtray” from Fugazi’s “Runaway Return”.) As he’s done on past releases
column7: Kindlon cedes the mic entirely to singer Caroline Corrigan; “Mistress Appears at a Funeral” is a shadowy tale of infidelity framed in Corrigan’s muted
column8: melodic vocals and a gently tense instrumental. And on the mournful “Apport Birds
column9: ” backup singer Kai Stone offsets Kindlon’s choppy
column10: vein-popping philosophizing with breathy whispers.

column1: Try Me’s biggest hurdles aren’t musical—in fact
column2: they’re the absence of music. Clocking in at a combined 39 minutes
column3: the tracks “Angelique One” and “Angelique Two” comprise an interview Kindlon conducted with veteran porn star Jeanna Fine. Kindlon has been upfront about his reasons for splicing these lengthy tracks into the album—foremost among them
column4: his use of Fine’s erotic photos as masturbatory fuel in his youth. In the past
column5: he’s been just as open about his views on sex workers
column6: sexism
column7: and the state of free discourse about such contentious topics in the punk scene. Being confrontational and contrarian is still a part of that discourse for Kindlon
column8: and he walks the walk with “Angelique”. Taken alone
column9: it’s a solid piece of Studs Terkel-esque reportage in which Fine is given free rein to tell the gripping story of her life and experiences in porn. But it imbalances the album
column10: to the point where it’s more of a distraction than an invitation
column11: which is a disservice to Fine’s harrowing narrative. At the same time
column12: it’s a bold move
column13:
one of many on Try Me. That they don’t always pay off only makes it that much braver—and that much more of a welcome deviation from the post-hardcore playbook.

Unless you’re a devotee of the Seattle heavy rock/light metal trio Big Business
column3: you’ve probably never heard of Gold Metal Records
column4: the label behind the release of their excellent fourth album Battlefields Forever. The record
column5: after all
column6: is GM003
column7: or the imprint’s third title. It follows only two short Big Business releases
column8: 2011’s four-song Quadruple Single and a subsequent seven-inch single. But last October
column9: with a mock press release signed by Gold Metal “corporate controller” Richard Smutley and a staged press conference submitted to YouTube
column10: Big Business revealed that they’d issue Battlefields Forever on Halloween on their own Gold Metal Records in a variety of formats—that is
column11: by themselves
column12: without the support of a third or even second party. They’d stream and sell it through their website.

column1: Both announcements were as funny as intended
column2: with jokes about Mötley Crüe drumming and the ghost of “Jeff Goldbloom.” Behind the jocularity
column3: though
column4: there was a fundamental bummer: If Big Business didn’t want to go hunting labels or
column5: in industry parlance
column6: “shopping themselves around
column7: ” they would have to release Battlefields Forever themselves. Their label for their entire career
column8: Hydra Head
column9: announced its closure almost exactly a year earlier
column10: citing both an “imbalance between creative ideals and financial realities” and an asymptotic slide of music sales as primary factors. Suddenly
column11: the force that had done the heavy lifting behind Big Business’s promotion—the mailings and the CD-R’s
column12: the one-sheets and the stuffed envelopes—had fallen
column13: with the responsibility now landed at the feet of the band.

column1: In retrospect
column2: that has not gone well. A quick Google search confirms that drummer Coady Willis
column3: bassist Jared Warren
column4: and new guitarist Scott Martin’s are better at making records than marketing them. Though Battlefields Forever was released nearly four months ago
column5: All Music has yet to list it
column6: much less rate it. Spin has never mentioned it. The album made nearly no year-end lists
column7: despite being out since Halloween. And after the annual flip of the calendar
column8: Pitchfork is finally reviewing it. For a platform that seems to hold almost everything
column9: the internet has nearly made Battlefields Forever seem like a phantom
column10: a rumor that Big Business is still busy.

column1: That disappearance is especially unfortunate considering that Battlefields Forever is as likable and unpredictable as anything they’ve ever done. Willis and Warren have never zigged and zagged stylistically like the Melvins
column2: the other duo they’ve augmented off and on for the last six years
column3: but there’s a patient and patent idiosyncrasy to their sound. No matter how familiar their oversized riffs or refrains first seem
column4: they twist and turn in unexpected ways. On Battlefields Forever
column5: for instance
column6: Martin’s guitar delivers surprising accents and counterpoints. “Heavy Shoes” emerges from a slow bleed of amplifier hum
column7: drums
column8: and voices sprinting suddenly into vivid crisscross patterns. Warren’s low notes are the anchor
column9: but Martin wraps his thin electric lead around the bass
column10: an ornamental leather braid around a very big wooden bludgeon. The wonderfully weird “Trees” starts to feel like a hypothetical game of three-way ping-pong
column11: with various voices bouncing through the mix only to be chased by the instruments. The band starts and stops
column12: roars and drifts
column13: screams and sings
column14: delighting all along with the structural instability of the song’s basic shape. There’s a coruscating instrumental interlude named “Aurum” and a two-minute ripper called “Our Mutant” that suggests stoner metal accelerated by methamphetamine. And “No Vowels” is something of a Big Business prototype
column15: with a riff so wide you want to fall into it and a chorus so casually perfect that it catches without you paying much mind.

column1: But Big Business save the most monumental track here for he parting epic: “Lonely Lyle” shares the story of a shut-in with no intentions of breaking from his fastidious “hourglass.” It starts quietly
column2: voices creeping over chords that suggest Slint. When the drums arrive
column3: though
column4: the song becomes a surge of drama
column5: turning another silly Big Business story into a wake for its own sad subject. Martin chases their lead
column6: inserting his lines between the bass and the drums like a hypeman. This band has never sounded as tough and as tender. Strangely
column7: it suggests the approach and net effect of Deafheaven’s Sunbather
column8: another not-quite-metal record that employed song volume and length to reinforce the weight of their themes. In 2013
column9: “Lonely Lyle” could have had its deserved share of critical and popular company. But
column10: so far
column11: it hasn’t had that public luxury.

column1: Big Business’ last record
column2: 2009’s Mind the Drift
column3: included a paranoid jam called “I Got It Online”. The guitars felt like the wringing of anxious hands. The lyrics—“Can’t even walk down the street/ Too many creeps”—suggested an agoraphobic sort excommunicating himself from the world with the help of Amazon
column4: ebay or
column5: as it turns out in the case of Battlefields Forever

column9: really? But Big Business isn’t some young band and
column10: despite Martin’s inclusion
column11: Battlefields Forever isn’t some staggering reinvention of what they’ve been doing for the last decade. It’s just a very good record that seems to have been ignored because it had neither the proper label structure to let people even know it existed and
column12: for shame

column14: you probably still don’t know Gold Metal Records
column15: or worse still
column16: Battlefields Forever. You can always
column17: at least
column18:
get it online.

There's currently only one live video of Sick Thoughts on YouTube—at publication time
column2: it's got about 175 views and the caption
column3: ""This is my 16 yo nephew tearing the joint up!"" It's a phone video shot vertically
column4: which means the drummer is hidden by black borders. The sound quality isn't great
column5: but you can see Baltimore teenager Drew Owen hunched over his guitar
column6: screaming and churning through some power chords. It's not a thrilling performance
column7: per se—two dudes bashing through some elemental punk rock with less-than-tight drumming and caveman vocals that seem to loosely ape Timmy Vulgar's. But if you listen carefully to the screams coming through the iPhone's microphone
column8: it's clear that there's something ferocious and exciting in this music. Terminal Teen Age
column9: the full-length debut album recorded solely by Owen
column10: takes that raw material and delivers it with force.

column1: The LP is a batch of scuzzy
column2: furious
column3: shit-fi punk rock that arrives at an opportune time. The Oblivians have grown up
column4: the Reatards are gone
column5: and just before they offered a strong reminder of their heydey
column6: members of the Gories released a straight-faced bubblegum album. Now all of a sudden
column7: here's a potent batch of aggro punk from a teenager in Baltimore—under 30 minutes of screaming rock'n'roll with energy that invokes the wide-eyed intensity of Teenage Hate
column8: Soul Food
column9: and Houserockin'. Every track features simple
column10: catchy power chord hooks blown out by fuzz. The drums are overwhelmingly belligerent. At the exact moment when each of Owen's two-minute songs start to feel repetitive
column11: he busts out an impressive guitar solo to put some space between the four-word choruses and unintelligible vocals. When phrases pop out from the fray of noise
column12: they're always cartoonishly negative (On ""Strungout""
column13: for example
column14: he screams ""nothing's left"" and grunts ""please give me death"").

column1: Since Owen's a teenager
column2: and since his album is called Terminal Teen Age
column3: it's easy to infer a few conflicted teenaged narratives from his belligerent negativity. ""I peaked in high school"" is an obvious one
column4: but there are other tracks here that would've been thematically perfect for playing at full blast while I drove out of the high school parking lot in my dad's old Corolla. The ""NO NO NO NO NO"" chorus from ""Can't Take No More"" pretty well embodies the petty frustrations that come from feeling like an adult and being consistently treated like a child. ""Last Day in Hell""
column5: with its scowling vocals and Sabbath-reminiscent guitar solo
column6: is an ideal mantra for kicking off summer break. The tangled emotional realities of teenaged life are also covered by ""Fucked Up Feelings"" and ""I Want Out"". And of course
column7: there's the blind fury of ""Blood Red"".

column1: But the real draw here are Owen's beefy earworm melodies. The gawking teenage lust story in ""Fifteen Minute Love"" is backed by an entirely catchy power chord barrage. ""Getting Real Alone"" steps away from his usual power chord-centric attack for a prominent blues riff. And while the album's strongest moments come from Owen's loud-and-fast scorched earth approach
column2: he also finds some time to cool down. The pace of ""Ain't Nothing to See"" begins with a gradual simmer
column3: but naturally
column4: he eventually kicks up a frenzy of guitar heroics.

column1: Terminal Teen Age consistently teeters on the edge of oblivion
column2: and not just because that's the narrative Owen consistently presents in these 13 tracks. Things consistently threaten to fall apart or become overbearing. Thankfully
column3: he's a student of garage punk's greats
column4: so he knows when to keep things concise and when to force a track into a full
column5: sudden stop. It's an exciting
column6: impressive debut from Owen. Though his Sick Thoughts Bandcamp has been shut down for some reason
column7: on December 27
column8: he recorded and immediately released a metal record under the name Caught—his fourth in two months. Garage punk is a prolific man's game. With bug-eyed weirdness
column9: screaming intensity
column10: and a seemingly effortless knack for crafting hooks
column11:
Owen is definitely poised to join the prolific weirdo fold.

The form and function of the hip-hop mixtape have shifted remarkably over the last decade
column2: so that a medium that used to showcase DJs’ cutting and blending abilities in the genre’s early days is now a umbrella format describing the constant flood of releases meted out in the absence of record company tinkering. You never know what you’re getting until you see a tracklist. When New York Native Tongue veterans Q-Tip and Busta Rhymes dropped the loping disco romp “Thank You” late last year and announced the impending release of the collaborative mixtape The Abstract and the Dragon
column3: the impression among breathless fans was that the pair were finally teaming up for a full project. When the mixtape arrived
column4: of course
column5: that rumor was promptly put to rest. The Abstract and the Dragon isn’t the surprise collection of new material we’d hoped for; it’s more a travelogue of a friendship well into its third decade
column6: a Busta and Q-Tip greatest hits collection compiled by hip-hop journalist Shaheem Reid.

column1: Most of the duo’s legendary pow-wows are present
column2: from the inaugural Leaders of the New School & Tribe Called Quest posse cut “Scenario” to select tracks from their solo careers (“Ill Vibe” from Busta’s debut solo album The Coming
column3: The Big Bang’s new jack rebuke “You Can’t Hold the Torch”
column4: the remix to Q-Tip’s breakout solo single “Viv’rant Thing”). Tying it all together is a series of affable skits featuring Busta
column5: Q-Tip and friends shooting the shit and telling stories behind the songs
column6: like when Busta recounts his reluctance to repeat “Scenario”’s “Rawr rawr like a dungeon dragon” shpiel on Big Daddy Kane’s 1991 “Come On Down”
column7: a big get for him and Q-Tip at the time
column8: only to tack it on after Kane hears his verse and asks “Where the ‘rawr rawr’ at?” The song selection hews a little obscure; lesser known fare like Tribe’s Rhyme & Reason soundtrack spot “Wild Hot”
column9: and “For the Nasty”
column10: a Neptunes collaboration from the NBA Live ‘06 soundtrack
column11: appear
column12: but beloved singles Tribe’s “Oh My God” (which samples Busta’s “Scenario” verse) and the Fugees
column13: Tribe & Busta posse cut “Rumble in the Jungle” do not. But the real draw here is The Abstract and the Dragon’s smattering of exclusives.

column1: Scattered throughout the playlist here are a handful of brand new Busta and Q-Tip recordings and revised takes on classics. Alongside “Thank You”
column2: here remixed by Kid Capri
column3: there’s the follow-up tandem cut “Butch & Sundance”. We also get the mixtape’s title track
column4: a snippet of a new song from Busta’s upcoming E.L.E. 2 album
column5: and “We Taking Off”
column6: all Busta spotlights with Q-Tip handling production. Elsewhere E.L.E. DJ Scratch remixes “Gettin’ Up” from Q-Tip’s The Renaissance
column7: and Busta appends a verse to Tribe’s Midnight Marauders closer “God Lives Through”. The new cuts showcase a madcap chemistry unblemished by the passage of time
column8: Tip’s ineffably slippery flow and beat construction anchoring Busta’s verbal gymnastics as heartily now as they did when they were teenagers.

column1: The exclusives are a welcome addition to a mix largely built out of previously released material
column2: but they also point to the more intriguing forms The Abstract and the Dragon could’ve taken with a little more care. “God Lives Through”’s freestyling-over-each-other’s-deep-cuts ethos is a stroke of genius. “Gettin' Up”’s friends-remixing-our-deep-cuts tack is too. Hell
column3: this thing could’ve just been an EP of the new songs. But The Abstract and the Dragon gestures to all these forms but never settles on one. It’s a good mix
column4:
but fans of either artist could probably construct the vast majority of it out of their own iTunes and will probably end up stripping the 28-song project for the six they haven’t had kicking around their record collection all these years and decades.

When Mouse on Mars broke a six-year silence earlier this decade
column2: they didn't waste any time reintroducing themselves to a musical landscape that looked very different than when they'd released their last collection. The final missive before the long break
column3: 2006's Ipecac-released Varcharz

column1: Much less a comeback album than the latest reinvention from artists that have always prided themselves on new ideas
column2: Parastrophics was louder and bolder than anything they'd done before
column3: a giggly record stuffed with bursts of color and melodies that came as close to approaching ""pop"" as 2004's disarmingly conventional Radical Connector. At the time

column11: possibly

column1: For the shock of the new that Parastrophics carried (and still carries)

column3: warm synth pads
column4: jigsaw glitch textures that only artists who came to prominence in the IDM era would wield in 2012—that made the album unmistakably the work of Mouse on Mars. This reliability is part of what made Parastrophics' tinier idiosyncrasies so endearing
column5: and it's what makes Spezmodia
column6: their new five-track EP
column7: so shocking. Jettisoning most of Parastrophics' sonic jumble for something more explicitly streamlined
column8: the release represents one of the duo's sharpest left turns in the past decade
column9: continuing the melodic refinement that Mouse on Mars have returned to time and again while shaping their taste for aggressive textures into new
column10: more dancefloor-ready molds.

column1: If WOW dipped its toes into what Mouse on Mars could do with the raw materials of bass music's current landscape
column2: Spezmodia is the point of full immersion. Familiar rhythmic structures abound—the stuttered-step figure that opens the title track
column3: the hissy acid-juke midsection of ""Bakerman Is Breaking Bad""—and the synth melodies splattered throughout carry an aggressive brightness
column4: arriving with all the subtlety of a car driving through a storefront window. There are moments of glitch-dabbed madness that break through these deceptively dense works
column5: but here it largely sounds like Toma and St. Werner have taken a vacuum to their off-kilter rhythms
column6: removing the detritus that surrounds them until all that's left is a jagged
column7: impossibly clean shell.

column1: Spezmodia also continues Mouse on Mars' experimentation with vocals—sampled and otherwise—a concern that dates back to the days of Radical Connector. ""I See Dizzy"" kicks open with a blood-curdling scream that's twisted into a rhythmic respiratory voice
column2: while the astounding title track weaves an array of vocal elisions into its upward-building structure
column3: pushing the BPM into the red until a glistening synth melody and fat bass stabs arrive to produce the aural illusion of sounds moving fast while seemingly and simultaneously slowing down. Compared to Radical Connector's most straightforward moments
column4: this material is brutally psychedelic and intense
column5: and such boldness suits them quite well.

column1: The most marvelous aspect of Mouse on Mars' resurgence is that
column2: similar to how their music has sounded to the uninitiated over the years
column3: it doesn't make any sense. As Mark Richardson pointed out in his review of Parastrophics
column4: many of Mouse on Mars' contemporaries have long since bitten the dust
column5: but the duo's constant quest for self-innovation has afforded them just the right amount of relevance
column6: even when it seems like the convergence between their current path and trends in modern music is purely coincidental. They're still tinkering with their sound
column7: and Spezmodia is the latest evidence that it's nearly impossible for Mouse on Mars not to make fascinating
column8:
truly exciting music.

“Luciano Cillio (sic) seems to have released an album almost by accident
column2: spirited away from him as he slept.” So wrote Jim O’Rourke in the liner notes for a limited edition reissue of an album made in 1977 by an obscure Italian musician composer named Luciano Cilio back in 2004. It was the lone album that Cilio ever released
column3: and he took his own life in 1983
column4: at the age of 33. It’s not a casual assessment by O’Rourke
column5: as it actually suggests the deep level of intimacy of Cilio’s sound.

column1: That reissue reinforced that closeness. Originally entitled Dialoghi Del Presente (translation “Dialogues of the Present”) but retitled Dell’Universo Assente (“The Absent Universe”)
column2: it looked like a blank white cover. Only when held in your hands and inspected closely did the near-invisible cover image appear
column3: a hand-drawn spiral in light silver ink. That CD reissue quickly disappeared
column4: but thankfully it now receives a wider reissue some ten years on
column5: both on CD and vinyl from the meticulous Italian label
column6: Die Schachtel.

column1: It’s hard to draw an exact parallel to Cilio’s music. O’Rourke triangulates it somewhere between Nick Drake’s Pink Moon
column2: Bill Fay’s Time of the Last Persecution and the debut album from This Heat. But in its punctilious attention to acoustic instrumentation in space
column3: Dell’Universo Assente comes closest to approximating what the next Mark Hollis album might have sounded like
column4: had Hollis continued along Laughing Stock’s and his 1998 self-titled album’s trajectory
column5: moving away from words and song
column6: ever closer to a distilled sound couched in silence. The effect of Cilio’s music reminds me of Jess Harvell’s line in the above review
column7: stating “how startling
column8: isolated moments of sound
column9: or a formless wash of sound
column10: can wring emotions out of listeners as powerfully as any conventional melody.”

column1: Born in Naples
column2: Cilio studied architecture and music
column3: learned sitar
column4: guitar
column5: and piano yet was essentially a self-taught composer that interacted with progressive rock and experimental theater in early 70s Italy before realizing this
column6: his lone album. Arranged in four movements with an interlude
column7: scored for acoustic guitar
column8: mandolin
column9: strings
column10: piano
column11: woodwinds and percussion
column12: the album is wordless
column13: yet features a lone instance of voice to devastating effect.

column1: The “prima quadro” clocks in near eight minutes
column2: opening with a bittersweet finger-picked guitar figure that—as it slips into a minor key—finds itself shadowed
column3: first by piano
column4: then soon after by cello and string quartet. Fans of Rachel’s or the first Jóhann Jóhannsson album might immediately swoon. But as the strings explore the minor key
column5: near the 2:30 mark
column6: Cilio cagily swaps out the timbre of the bowed cello with Patrizia Lopez’s voice
column7: multi-tracking her until she creates a spine-chilling chorus. At 3:50
column8: Cilio performs yet another aural hallucination
column9: as the female vocal then transmogrifies into a soprano saxophone line. Two minutes after her entrance
column10: Lopez's voice disappears completely; without a single word uttered
column11: body-leveling emotions are nevertheless conveyed.

column1: The second movement puts the woodwinds in a subterranean setting
column2: prepared percussion flitting around the flute
column3: oboe and soprano sax
column4: the string section entering to push everything deeper into the gloom. A lightness appears courtesy of an elegant and lyrical two-minute piano solo that comprises the third movement
column5: while the fourth movement opens with tuned percussion before saxophone enters
column6: reminiscent of a restrained free jazz section
column7: building up speed with the introduction of guitar and other woodwinds. Cilio’s crystalline finger-picked guitar returns for the “Interludio
column8: ” as gorgeous a melody as Robbie Basho or John Fahey plucked
column9: if taken at a slower pace. Cello and woodwinds also arise
column10: but the album soon distills back to Cilio’s lone guitar for the end.

column1: As one might expect that with a title like “The Absent Universe
column2: ” it’s a spare album
column3: its pleasures revealed through careful listening rather than quick snippets
column4: but not a single note or gesture feels out of place. And in recapping the juxtapose of instrumentation
column5: it feels like something is still lacking
column6: that the deep
column7: solemn unnameable emotions conjure by Cilio –which in hindsight feels sorrowful
column8: knowing that this would be his lone statement into such a universe– are scarcely touched upon. Perhaps that is what O’Rourke’s above quote signifies: a sound so intimate as to have not been recorded and pressed to disc
column9: but instead pulled from the subconscious
column10: transmitted instead to each listener individually. Later in the notes
column11: Jim O’Rourke writes of the music as feeling like “this enormous weight that is bearing on its creators
column12: the absolute need to exorcize it from their lives.” Cilio is a heavy listen
column13:
but one that can ultimately feel redemptive.

Backup singers can really impact the DNA of a song
column2: and not always for the better. Take Lefty Frizzell’s <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f2x0fMszj58"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">1950 classic “If You’ve Got the Money
column3: I’ve Got the Time”. In its original format
column4: it was a bare bones country standard typical of the Grand Ole Opry’s golden age: fiddle
column5: pedal steel
column6: Lefty’s voice
column7: and not much else. Then
column9: he released a new
column10: re-recorded version of the song on The One and Only Lefty Frizzell. It sounded overtly glossy thanks in part to a saccharine choir of backup vocalists. The additional voices added needless commercial sheen
column11: only serving to mar and obscure the original’s charm.

column1: Tim Cohen wrote the songs from River of Souls with backup singers in mind. He’s said that the only thing that separates his Magic Trick material from his work with the Fresh & Onlys are the two bands’ personnel. And he’s not overstuffing his latest album with a full chorus; he works with two female vocalists: Noelle Cahill and Alicia Vanden Heuvel. They provide this album’s primary appeal—Cohen’s baritone counterbalanced by two soft female voices. Sure
column2: he could’ve handed “The Store” over to Wymond Miles
column3: Kyle Gibson
column4: and Shayde Sartin
column5: but by using Cahill and Heuvel’s voices instead
column6: the song’s guitar-centric momentum is somewhat softened. And ultimately
column7: this is a very soft
column8: easily handled album. The idea isn’t to add rough edges; just beauty and sheen.

column1: The lead guitars on the album provided by Tom Heyman often stay clear of any raw
column2: ragged garage punk sounds in favor of a tone more similar to Mark Knopfler’s. There are tambourines and unassuming melodies. As Cohen sings “Come Inside”
column3: the backup vocalists come through with a mild
column4: warm echo. This music is meant to be pleasant and palatable
column5: so with that songwriting goal in mind
column6: the additional voices are well-suited to the material.

column1: But for an album that’s already plenty smooth
column2: Cohen goes all in with his lyrics. The album title River of Souls does nothing to steer the listener away from the words “adult contemporary.” It’s close enough in name to Billy Joel’s 1993 album River of Dreams and is the name of a 1993 Dan Fogelberg album. And the song’s messages consistently lean toward the theatrical. On “You Have to Do”
column3: over a languid organ and some “doo-wahhh” harmonies
column4: Cohen offers a bunch of “wisdom” regarding how a man should keep a woman happy. It plays almost like a scene in a mid-20th century musical: A man
column5: intimidated by his love for a woman
column6: asks his wise friend/brother/father for advice. Then
column7: the savvy narrator (Cohen) sings about how his friend should take action
column8: and of course
column9: two women wander into the frame just in time to sing some well-placed harmonies over his instructions.

column1: With buoyant synths on “Salvation”
column2: with Cohen’s soft moan and the echoing harmonica of “Beloved One”
column3: River of Souls is breezy listening. Right when things start to get a little more bold with the soulful stomp
column4: harmonies
column5: and horns of “My World”
column6: the song dissipates into a puddle of meandering guitars that aim for freeform but wind up feeling more like hotel lobby music. “We like pretty girls
column7: ” Cahill and Heuvel airily sing on “Crazy Teeth” over a continuous mid-tempo shuffle that would feel aesthetically appropriate in a transitional “riding from one town to the next” scene of an old western movie. It’s not a cool sounding album by any stretch
column8: but even in the canon of dad rock
column9: it doesn’t stand up. The songs become repetitive
column10: and though the harmonies are well-crafted and the melodies are lovely
column11: there aren’t enough moments that demand attention. After a while
column12: all the sounds on River of Souls run together
column13:
a little bland and verging on formless.

You would think that between his long-standing devotion to funk
column2: soul and psychedelia and his love for all things green
column3: Dudley Perkins would slide in perfectly with the portfolio of psychedelic-funk acts currently staging a renaissance in black music. But on his new album Dr. Stokley
column4: Perkins isn't indulging in rap orthodoxy over funk-infused instrumentals (a specialty of the Odd Future camp and fellow third-eye devotees The Underachievers.) Nor is he interested in the kind of soft-funk odyssey that we saw with Snoop Dogg and Dam-Funk's recent 7 Days of Funk. The new album
column5: Dr. Stokley
column6: devoid as it is of both irony and traditional rapping
column7: is an entirely separate thing.

column1: Dr. Stokley represents a synthesis of Perkins’ career
column2: combining his relatively grounded (and undercooked) early days as the rapper Declaime with the funk
column3: soul
column4: and afrocentric mysticism that he’s embraced in his later years.  The styles combine into a kind of loose declaratory spoken word
column5: a free associative style that often frustrates. Dudley makes many false claims of flow fluency on the album
column6: boasting of a nonexistent rap superiority that can be grating. But when he embraces his stranger sensibilities
column7: it can result in wonderfully left-field songs. ""Geriatrics"" is the best example here
column8: a track that finds Dudley imagining the ideal life as a senior
column9: rapping about being an “Old coot
column10: sipping on prune juice in my best Sunday suit.”  It’s the kind of song that you simply will not find anywhere else
column11: and one of the few reasons to embrace Perkins’ notion of lyricism on its own terms.

column1: That he can remain outside the box even when his influences are in vogue speaks to just how unique a figure Perkins is.  His prominence comes thanks to the 2004 one-off “Flowers""
column2: an acid-drenched soul single delivered over primo production from fellow Oxnard
column3: Ca. native Madlib (
column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">whose production is featured on the Stokley standout
column5: ""State of Emergency."").  Perkins has refused to fade into the history of musical oddities; on the strength of prolificacy and consistently excellent production he has stayed marginally relevant
column6: even as his contributions to his own music become less and less notable.

column1: The real reason to tune into Dr. Stokley are the beats of Georgia Anne Muldrow
column2: Perkins’ artistic soul mate and life partner and the true talent of the collaborative duo.  Muldrow’s 2012 album Seeds
column3: was badly slept on
column4: a worthy cousin of Erykah Badu’s New Amerykah series. It’s clear that Muldrow has taken the lessons she gleaned working with Madlib on that album to new heights on Dr. Stokley.  Her beats are high-fidelity
column5: expertly produced instrumental hip-hop
column6: with hard-edged production that’s occasionally softened when she sings quietly below Perkins’ sermons.  On “Episode” drum snaps meet with the ghosts of soul samples and Muldrow’s own cooing—the beat makes the meat and potatoes gangster story of the track come alive.

column1: Perkins and Muldrow have struggled with multiple setbacks in the past few years including financial issues
column2: Perkins being deported from Canada in the midst of a tour
column3: a home robbery and a long-standing beef with former label Stones Throw
column4: which Perkins has long-insisted owes him money.  Those doses of reality may have affected the cloud-dwelling duo in different ways.  The grit of Muldrow’s latest crop of beats grounds her ethereal style nicely.  But Perkins is better the stranger he is; when he lashes out at rivals or an unforgiving world he comes off as petty
column5: rather than righteous. On “Rhythmic Procedures
column6: ” for instance
column7: he blasts others for violence
column8: hate and consumerism
column9: without ever really delving into the meat of the problems he’s addressing. His complaints begin to loop back on one another
column10: becoming obnoxiously repetitive.

column1: Perkins and Muldrow are both releasing music through Mello Music Group now
column2: an indie label whose flagship artist
column3: the DC producer/rapper Oddisee helps classify their sound
column4: as a kind of crunchy
column5: east coast alternative to Stones Throw.  The label’s investment in Perkins is worthwhile
column6:
if only to get at Muldrow. The instrumental album of Dr. Stokley might have stood as one of the better beat tapes of last year. But Dudley’s presence above the noise makes for a confused and ultimately less satisfying record.
