Nearly three years after his breakout moment
column2: the sounds of Mike Volpe have infiltrated spheres of music large and small. The suburban New Jersey producer
column3: who's toiled away in earnest for several years now as Clams Casino
column4: emerged in 2011 with a cinematic
column5: handcrafted sound that possessed a glowing radiance despite its density. What Volpe was doing felt
column6: especially in the realm of hip-hop
column7: new—a word that the genre's prized as a perpetual goal since DJs started siphoning the energy of New York City streets for block parties. Hip-hop took notice.

column1: You can hear the ghostly
column2: amniotic thrum of Clams Casino's style in the strongest work by Drake and Noah ""40"" Shebib
column3: two artists who made one of the only albums to sell more than a million copies in the U.S. last year. UK producer Evian Christ
column4: first heard as the latest in a legion of bedroom producers to ride Volpe's coattails
column5: was one of the many cooks in the kitchen that brewed Kanye West's energizing latest LP Yeezus
column6: where the fuzzy belches and moaning yawps associated with the strongest Clams Casino material ripped the sky open on the sex-drenched
column7: electric ""I'm In It"". (The wave of Clams Casino imitators was once at such a high tide that an entire genre was formed out of the lazily drawn
column8: tab-tripping micro-phenomenon that followed—""cloud rap""—but like so many cultural fads in the internet age
column9: its prevalence was mercifully brief.)

column1: Volpe first gained recognition producing tracks for impressionistic rapper-turned-Tony Robbins-type Lil B
column2: but the artist that's most closely aligned himself with the Clams Casino sound is A$AP Rocky
column3: who drenched himself in Volpe's sticky fog for his star-making 2011 mixtape LIVELOVEA$AP. An artist who's expressed ambition despite possessing particularly unshowy skills as a rapper
column4: Rocky has proven himself adept at capturing the zeitgeist with the eager eyes of a child trapping lightning bugs in a jar. So even though his alignment with Volpe's star was well-timed
column5: it was unsurprising to see the Harlem rapper set his eyes on bigger prizes for last year's major label debut LongLiveA$AP.

column1: The ""big songs"" from that album still possessed the same slightly woozy
column2: off-center charm that Volpe had previously lent Rocky's music
column3: but the credits behind those sounds—Hit-Boy
column4: Skrillex
column5: Shebib—weren't Volpe's. Some may interpret this development as bigger producers ripping off one of the decade's most fascinating sonic developments in underground hip-hop
column6: but the truth is more straightforward. Like Lex Luger and many others before him
column7: Volpe came
column8: saw
column9: innovated
column10: permeated
column11: and was appropriated until his and the genre's sonic DNA were more or less one. The lifespan of new sounds in hip-hop is incongruous and more often than not brutally curt towards its creators
column12: but bemoaning it is a waste of time. This is simply how things work.

column1: Regardless
column2: Clams Casino's presence has far from diminished
column3: especially in Rocky's case: his production credit appeared on two
column4: admittedly minor LongLiveA$AP songs—""LVL"" and the Santigold-featuring ""Hell""—which appear in instrumental form on Volpe's third instrumental mixtape in three years
column5: released for free on Twitter just before 2013 came to a close. The central talking point around Clams Casino beats has been that they tend to sound even better without the rappers that were originally featured on them
column6: and that's no different here: ""LVL"" and ""Hell"" represent Volpe in his element
column7: with his trademark mix of dramatic percussive touches and distorted melodic crescendos coming together potently.

column1: The A$AP brand appears once more on Instrumental Mixtape 3: the gaping instrumental for ""Freeze""
column2: an A$AP Mob posse cut featuring Jim Jones that appeared on 2012's roughshod mixtape Lords Never Worry. The second and previous installment in Volpe's instrumental mixtape series was arguably his strongest and most congruent
column3: as well as the most reliant on the A$AP brand's involvement. As Rocky's star rises
column4: it's unclear if the creative connection between his crew and Volpe will continue—on A$AP Mob member Ferg's 2013 LP Trap Lord
column5: the latter was nowhere to be found—but the connection clearly yields success
column6: as the A$AP-associated cuts on Instrumental Mixtape 3 are the strongest and most impressive
column7: most Clams-esque
column8: of the bunch.

column1: The other non-originals that make up Instrumental Mixtape 3 suggest that Volpe spent most of 2013
column2: if not laying low
column3: then slightly receding from the hip-hop world. (In our Rising interview in 2011
column4: he bemoaned that ""the beats just sit around for months"" when he works with other artists; considering that issue is magnified in the upper echelon of hip-hop
column5: it's safe to assume that there's Clams Casino productions out there that we haven't heard
column6: and may never hear.) There are a few beats for Mac Miller
column7: two of which appeared on last year's Watching Movies With the Sound Off
column8: and a beat ripped from a collaboration with DOOM; save for the twinkling
column9: uh
column10: euphoria of ""Youforia""
column11: these productions are minor works in the Clams Casino oeuvre
column12: slight and thinly developed detours not dissimilar to the low points of the first Instrumental Mixtape
column13: when Volpe's sound was still crystallizing.

column1: Speaking of: ""Crystals""
column2: taken from the soundtrack to the mega-popular video game Grand Theft Auto V
column3: structures its decay around an arpeggiated synth nearly identical to the one that pops up in Burial's ""Loner"". ""Pull Me Down""
column4: a co-production with alt-R&B also-ran Mikky Ekko (aka the other voice in Rihanna's treacly
column5: ubiquitous ballad ""Stay"")
column6: fares much better
column7: as an easy beat and lightly plunked piano keys give way to a languid guitar line that adds a lovely
column8: aqueous touch to the instrumental's final third.

column1: Alongside an upbeat re-do of Volpe's contribution to 2011's forgettable Adult Swim Singles Program contribution ""Wizard""
column2: there are three previously unreleased Clams Casino solo productions here
column3: one of which proves to be a keeper: ""Cry for Me""
column4: with a pounding rhythm and vocal sample that trips over itself amidst off-kilter synths and a sample of what sounds like children screaming. The track's reminiscent of his ebullient beat for Lil B's ""Unchain Me"" that appeared on the previous Instrumental Mixtape installment; that collection also contained his greatest beat to date
column5: ""I'm God""
column6: and although the highlights on this installment are impressive
column7: the lack of a ""big track"" along with a slightly higher duds-to-keepers ratio ultimately make it the weakest of the three collections.

column1: Upon the release of Instrumental Mixtape 3
column2: Volpe took to Twitter to announce that it would be the last installment in the series
column3: and that's probably for the best. It's been nearly three years since he released a solo outing as Clams Casino

column6:
the strongest moments of Instrumental Mixtape 3 confirm that Volpe is in complete possession of his own sound for him to do with it what he sees fit.

As Chicago’s King L continues to orbit around one of rap’s most fertile and focused-on cities
column2: it becomes clearer that he is floating alone. Even from the beginning of Chicago’s rap renaissance
column3: he was slightly off of the scene’s center—older than the GBE teenagers and with lyrics that were far more knotty and playful than what came to be classified as drill music. The new face of the city is Chance the Rapper
column4: and the sound of the underground is “bop
column5: ” ringtone rap’s super-pop third wave. King L has splashed around in the bop scene
column6:
but as his new mixtape Drilluminati 2 emphasizes his music is very self-contained. 

It is perhaps a testament to Louie that this remains true even after his starring turn on Yeezus
column7: where he handles the opening verse and hook of the shrieking “Send It Up"". It was never expected that popping up on Kanye’s most unforgiving album would materially change the music of the man who helped influence its sound
column8: but Drilluminati 2 is also reminder of how much of Louie’s essence was contained in just that one feature. “Send it Up” is evidence of his sharp eye for concepts: “We can send this bitch up
column9: it can’t go down” is not precisely a revelation but in its simple
column10: brain-burrowing sloganeering it almost feels like one. It is the type of memorable line that seems to sprout up almost at random from Louie’s tangled flows— “Tattoos how they break the news
column11: ” from the same song
column12:
is another. 

The best of Drilluminati 2 extends that formula. The strongest track is “I Might""
column13: which cycles through the same concept as if the song is one long hook: “I might rock the Rollie
column14: I might rock the Breitling/ I might cop the foreign and don’t even drive it.” Another is “Terrific""
column15: which positions the ephemera of Louie’s life as the song’s title. This sort of songwriting is the province of someone like Gucci Mane and most recently Future
column16: who is now a superstar thanks in part to his ability to push an idea (“you ain’t even know it
column17: ” “I’m just being honest”) to its logical extreme. Louie is not yet on that level
column18:
but on Drilluminati 2 he once again displays an ability to come up with these little thoughts that end up rattling around in your brain.

Maybe it’s no surprise then that the tape’s biggest misstep is “Tony""
column19: a blatant rip-off of Future’s own “Tony Montana"". Louie
column20: too
column21: raps in a bastardized version of the Cuban gangster’s sneering accent
column22: and while it is an example of his willingness to experiment with his delivery it’s much too similar to a song that is already another rapper’s calling card. It’s the only track here that is outright regrettable
column23:
but over Drilluminati 2’s 13 tracks there are only a select few that really stand out.

One of those is “O.D.B.” and its anti-gravity Auto-Tune chorus that splits the difference between Chief Keef’s stoned-to-Saturn mumblings and Lil Durk’s fluttering menace. But it’s the tape’s final offering that is arguably the most interesting. “Hella Band$” is a pure bop song with a truly anthemic chorus sung by Leek. It's a crossover track only in the context of Chicago house parties
column24:
but as Louie struggles to find his footing in the wider hip-hop world it suggests that maybe his music doesn’t always need to be quite so askew.

column2: 'Global'
column3:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['All Saints']|2014-01-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:29.865143|"

Harold Budd's music exists in that misty place between ambient
column4: new age
column5: and minimalist composition
column6: where everything is gentle and nothing lasts for long. Over the past 40-plus years
column7: he's released about 30 albums. Some are solo
column8: some are collaborative; some are studio and some are live; some are improvised and some are structured. He famously worked with Brian Eno on the second of Eno's landmark ""Ambient"" series (Ambient 2: The Plateaux of Mirror)
column9: and less famously made an album with the Scottish dream-pop band the Cocteau Twins
column10: neither of which have any immediate common ground other than the fact that Harold Budd plays keyboard on them.

column1: Despite the variety of Budd's collaborations and circumstances
column2: his music has always had a quietly recognizable style: intimate and intuitive; fragile but warm; seductive but just a little bit mysterious
column3: like the soft tinkling of a presence in the next room. (In a 2005 interview with the UK paper the Independent
column4: he joked that his music tended to feel slow and searching because he usually recorded it drunk.)

column1: Wind in Lonely Fences is a 2xCD retrospective compiled by All Saints Records and released alongside three vinyl reissues of older Budd albums (The Serpent (in Quicksilver)
column2: Abandoned Cities
column3: and Through the Hill) and a seven-album box set called Buddbox. I'm writing about Wind here not only because it's the most convenient inroad to Budd's career
column4: but because it's an ambitious project in its own right: with as many albums as Budd has to choose from and no responsibility to things like radio hits
column5: the job of the compiler becomes an unusually creative one.

column1: Starting with 1970's ""The Oak of the Golden Dreams""
column2: Wind moves chronologically
column3: ending with a track from his 2011 album In the Mist. Progression is obvious
column4: especially early on. ""Dreams""
column5: which was improvised on an old Buchla modular synth
column6: has more in common with the dense ragas of Terry Riley than anything Budd composed in the 80s
column7: and even 1978's ""Bismillahi 'Rrahman 'Rrahim""—from one of my favorite Budd albums
column8: The Pavilion of Dreams—shows a willingness to indulge in vast
column9: almost jazzy pieces of music that he'd give up within a few years. (A sap at heart
column10: I wilt at the sound of an erotically played saxophone.)

column1: Budd's music got smaller and more peaceful
column2: but also more opaque
column3: culminating in the work he's best known for: The Plateaux of Mirror and the Pearl (also with Eno and his protégé
column4: Daniel Lanois). Soft
column5: sparkling but always just beyond the edge of discernible pattern
column6: Budd's pieces with Eno are like keyholes to dark rooms that Budd—in his reserve—never lets you into. It's this tension—between gentleness and threat
column7: between intimacy and uncertainty
column8: between the thrill of a hint and the human desire to see the whole picture—that makes them seductive on first listen but so easy to play on subsequent ones. Also worth noting is a track from Budd's 1981 album The Serpent (in Quicksilver)
column9: which at 20 minutes long barely constitutes an album
column10: but is my favorite Budd release right now—a series of miniatures less high-minded and delicate than his Eno collaborations
column11: but earthier and more generous too
column12: tapping into a history of jazz
column13: Americana
column14: and even country music that he rarely touched again.

column1: The second half of Wind is spottier than the first—the textures less rich
column2: the mood less sustained. ""Soft pedal
column3: an airy
column4: meandering piano technique of Budd's own division
column5: is supplemented by even more reverb
column6: which can be as much of a crutch as an aid. And while I've had my swings of passionate involvement with the Cocteau Twins
column7: Budd's collaborations with both the full band and with guitarist Robin Guthrie have never really held my attention. (Guthrie's guitar sound—somehow both chilly but indistinct—has always sounded best to me when set against the sturdy backbeat of a drum machine. Against Budd he sometimes sounds like water cut with water.)

column1: Even Budd's less interesting pieces have a toughness to them that I find surprising and unexpected. Having held myself off from making nature metaphors in a review about low-key instrumental music until now
column2: I'll make one: the icicle: small but sharp
column3: seemingly transparent but impossible to see through
column4: delicate but chilly to the touch. Wind doesn't measure up to Budd's best albums and can't
column5:
but that's not what it was meant to do. It's a primer to a composer too often cited as a footnote and too modest to correct the record. 

"|18889.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18889-harold-budd-wind-in-lonely-fences-1970-2011/|7.8|Mike Powell

Of the meagre information available about Finnish producer Ukkonen
column2: perhaps the most telling is a snippet tucked away in a rare Q&A
column3: detailing a fascination with perspective and movement borne of extensive childhood train travel. It makes sense: the overarching theme binding all his output to date has been a resolute inability to remain fixed. Every component is in motion
column4: subtly playing off one another as they glide around. Following a string of EPs
column5: 2012's The Isolated Rhythms of… inaugurated the project with an under-the-radar gem
column6: a cobblestone assortment of spatial
column7: pulsating techno. Constantly metamorphosing
column8: the album featured passages of unfurling splendor
column9: thumping crusted loops
column10: flashes of sleazy electro
column11: neo-classical interludes and stretches of Gas-eous uplift
column12: often all stitched into the same 16-minute track. That approach has been tempered somewhat on The Ancient Tonalities Of…
column13: which swaps out some of the left-turns for a more moderate palate and sharply defined set of parameters.

column1: This sophomore album rests primarily on patterns of tones
column2: timbres and textures instead of usual songcraft
column3: with an impressive attention to detail on levels both micro and macro. Ukkonen goes about attacking Tonalities with an unconventional approach on everything from the rhythmic core
column4: crafting loops to guide the music but not affixing them to time signatures
column5: as on ""Three Durations"" which alternates between beat cycles of 11
column6: 13 and 15
column7: to the utilization of effects
column8: side-chaining drums then removing them entirely from the mix. If it all sounds technical
column9: well
column10: it is<i>
column11: but requires less of a locked-in mindset than at first glance. Largely the music works with some variation of soft-feel synths and drifting banks of bass
column12: set against submerged thrums
column13: coated in a pearly veneer. It is understated and cool
column14: as if to consciously fulfill the ""arctic house"" tag placed upon Ukkonen along the way.

column1: The tracks draw from the same frosty wellspring
column2: but deviate enough to avoid homogeneity: peculiar tribal chants find their way through through the descending spectral light on ""My Euouae""
column3: mirrored in part by the distant rattle of stretched drumskins and exotic chirrups on ""Nine Vjetar""
column4: seemingly set on a deserted Aztec battlefield; ""Viva Las Huelgas"" unassumingly dips into a fluttering breakbeat with little forewarning
column5: one of the few cuts to bare teeth; many tracks have an improvised jazz feel
column6: discombobulated but organic
column7: scattering sparse piano notes out like Easter prizes against formless fragments of percussion. But for someone who clearly spends a lot of time laboring over how every element speaks to one another
column8: the flow of the record as a cohesive whole is lacking—a coterie of hermetically-sealed avant-garde experiments that court appreciation
column9: but not necessarily attachment.

column1: That said
column2: Ukkonen retains a knack for delivering moments of disquieting beauty. The two strongest tracks
column3: ""Iraupen Kuus"" and ""Eighteen Pitches""
column4: both fall somewhere in the middle of Kompakt's crushed-ice prettiness
column5: Border Community's pastoral glow
column6:
and the enveloping analogue warmth of Warp's ambient outposts. What Ukkonen now needs to master is learning when to let people in from the cold.

"|18819.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18819-ukkonen-the-ancient-tonalities-of/|6.9|Gabriel Szatan

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20076/homepage_large.502db36c.jpg|Clapper Is Still|31963.0|Way Through|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Upset the Rhythm']|2014-01-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:30.963190|"

On the Internet
column2: there is absolutely no shortage of writing that uses music as a starting point to discuss personal trauma
column3: soul-searching and what it all means. Nostalgia and actual
column4: factual history are now one
column5: and this hazy middle ground between memory and reality has produced enough navel-gazing essays to save an entire generation of neurotic critics close to $65 billion in therapy bills. Nothing is more personal than our own lives. Nothing is less personal than our own lives. The Internet's made it a whole lot easier to explore and expose inner demons and a whole lot harder to create in a vacuum.

column1: In Clapper Is Still
column2: Way Through
column3: the London-based duo of Christopher Tipton and Claire Titley
column4: made a record with a completely transparent process that doesn't feel dashed off or incomplete. Each homespun song plots a course through England's history
column5: from abandoned towns steeped in forgotten customs to the ghosts that haunt rolling green hills. On their website
column6: the duo post a back story for each song. It's a hodgepodge of material
column7: coming in the form of links
column8: selfies taken in the places they're writing about
column9: longer field recordings
column10: mini write-ups that are loose but informative. It's all good information that glows with a real love for the subject matter
column11: but it's not necessary to your enjoyment of the record
column12: and often feels like an additional overwhelming layer to an already complicated album.

column1: Take ""Imber & Tyneham"". Because of the information on their site
column2: I know that it's about two villages that suffered vastly different fates after World War II. Tyneham became a ""heritage destination amongst a still active army range"" and Imber ""remain[ed] strictly out of bounds training ground for urban combat."" The song vibrates with chaos and constant upheaval
column3: Tipton's guitar restlessly moves from staccato pound to blurry
column4: damaged strumming that eventually gives way to a field recording of bells knocking together. Even without knowing those facts
column5: there's a sense of military urgency to the song. It sounds like a frantic march.

column1: Way Through describe themselves as ""pastoral punk
column2: and it's fitting. All of these songs are noisy but warm. ""Roughting Linn"" is upbeat and so thin you can virtually see all its moving parts
column3: while ""Haxey"" is built on a pop-punk template
column4: with a riff anthemic enough to be a Blink-182 castoff
column5: except it's about something called ""the Haxey Hood
column6: which is a really old drinking game that involves throwing a leather hood in the direction of a village's public house. The custom has been around for close to 700 years. Not exactly the ode to teenage love that Tipton's riff tricks you into thinking it is.

column1: The best moments on Clapper Is Still come when the idea of the concept is apparent
column2: even if the backstory isn't. ""Wharram Percy"" begins with a car door slamming
column3: Tipton and Titley's trip through their country's collective history is coming to an end. It's a strong emotional moment
column4: a heavy sigh after a series of songs that have completely muddled the historical with the personal. Tipton sings pure ghostly desolation
column5: evoking the eerie beauty of abandoned villages: ""Powerlines flank
column6: ditches and banks/An echo of a village
column7: a melancholic margin/ You can relive everything."" That last part feels like Tipton is laying out what he and Titley have been trying to do over the course of Clapper Is Still. We have
column8: collectively
column9: spent the last few years pulling inspiration from what we already know
column10: but listen closely
column11:
Way Through are showing us a new approach.

"|18880.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18880-way-through-clapper-is-still/|7.4|Sam Hockley-Smith

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20017/homepage_large.178e3505.jpg|Wig Out at Jagbags|26519.0|Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2014-01-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:49:31.530544|"

By now
column2: Stephen Malkmus has released more music as a solo artist than he did with his old band Pavement. This might surprise people like me
column3: who given a few beers and a tolerant audience will still lapse into vague
column4: sentimental reminiscences about seeing Pavement in late 1999
column5: a few weeks before Malkmus got onstage in Brixton with handcuffs around his mic stand
column6: telling the audience—in a rare moment of disclosure—that the cuffs were a symbol. This
column7: it turns out
column8: is how a poet breaks up a band.

column1: In retrospect
column2: their breakup marked a moment when indie-rock's narrative started moving away from the sloppy
column3: casual grace of the 90s toward bands like the Strokes and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs
column4: who wore tighter jeans
column5: had more conventional sex appeal
column6: and played like there was something at stake. The irrelevance of Malkmus's solo career was a foregone conclusion.

column1: All things considered
column2: he's taken it well
column3: turning out albums at a regular clip
column4: none of them exceptional but none bad either—and crucially
column5: none that suggest that he's fixated on the past. They're fussier than Pavement albums
column6: with intricate guitar parts and carnival-like shifts in rhythm that Pavement would have either found too showy or just too much of a chore to play. There's more focus on the fineries of production and arrangement
column7: too. (You won't find trombones on Pavement albums.)  They're also goofier
column8: which some listeners might find awesome
column9: but I find a little annoying. Free from the intensities of being pretty much any age under 30
column10: he now seems like what his critics always claimed he was as Pavement wore on into the late 90s: A smart dude horsing around.

column1: I listen to these albums with a kind of passing happiness
column2: surprised by how easily Malkmus can still make me smile
column3: vaguely saddened by the idea that a smile is probably the most complex emotional response he'll get from me. Wig Out at Jagbags isn't all that different in spirit from 2011's Mirror Traffic
column4: which is to say that it's less jammy and long-winded than either Real Emotional Trash or Pig Lib but essentially the product of the same mischievous brain. Most of it sounds sort of like 70s guitar-rock rendered as some kind of ergonomic desk toy: compact
column5: brightly colored
column6: unlikely to stir the depths of the soul but nifty nevertheless.

column1: If Malkmus' post-Pavement career deserves more—or more serious—credit
column2: it's for introducing a persona that hasn't really existed before: Male without the tediously burdened spirit of masculinity
column3: arty but not pretentious
column4: sensitive but too good-natured to make a fuss when his feelings got hurt. Even in Pavement days he was regarded as a kind of golden boy—the sweet liberal-arts alternative to Kurt Cobain
column5: the stoner diarist beloved by jocks in part because he was everything they assumed stoner diarists weren't: funny
column6: low-key
column7: averse to competition but still knowledgeable about sports. ""We were raised on Tennyson and venison and the Grateful Dead
column8: he sings on ""Lariat"". This is the Malkmus of both Jagbags and Mirror Traffic: Steeped in Victorian poetry but still knows his way around a grill.

column1: And as with  Mirror Traffic
column2: Jagbags is obliquely concerned with aging. ""I don't have the stomach for your brandy
column3: I can hardly sip your tea
column4: he sings on the slow-burning ""Independence Street"". ""I don't have the teeth left for your candy/ I'm just busy being free."" Later come the lines
column5: ""Shanghai'd in Oregon/ Cinnamon and lesbians/ The power lines revolt in time / I've been tripping my face off since breakfast/ taking in this windswept afternoon."" Malkmus is 47 now
column6: closer to getting his AARP card than to graduating college. Once the wistful 25 year old with a heart full of unspeakable sentiments
column7: now he's the handsome middle-aged guy next door borrowing a pinch of weed to get him through this cookie-baking session for his son's end-of-the-season soccer party. He has never resisted age but has never seemed younger
column8: and in the occasional la-la-la still shimmers with the charm of a boy.

column1: At the heart of his music is still an inimitable bittersweetness—the light shrug that follows the realization that in time all things will die and pass. His best songs have always felt like ballads
column2: regardless of tempo. There are some of those songs here: ""Lariat""
column3: ""Houston Hades""
column4: ""Independence Street."" But the sweetest and bitterest moment is near the end of ""Rumble at the Rainbo""
column5: a two-minute rave-up that starts like a mock-punk throwaway and ends on the line
column6: ""Can you remember the thrill and the rush? You're not out of touch. Come tonight you'll see: No one here has changed and no one ever will."" The performance is stupid and flamboyant
column7: a duckwalk across a stage that only exists in his mind. Anyway
column8: he was probably kidding. But as with most modest hearts
column9:
his best jokes have always been the ones he tells at his own expense. 

"|18822.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18822-stephen-malkmus-and-the-jicks-wig-out-at-jagbags/|7.0|Mike Powell

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20034/homepage_large.837a682f.jpg|L.I.E.S. Presents: Music for Shut-Ins|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Delsin']|2014-01-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:32.337451|"

Ron Morelli isn't here to make friends. After two years and change of simmering in obscurity
column2: the sometimes-producer
column3: mostly-curator's Long Island Electrical Systems imprint enjoyed a profile-raising 2012
column4: emerging as one of the most thrilling American dance labels in a field that's typically dominated by European voices. The chatter surrounding L.I.E.S.' quiet climb served as a reminder that the New York City's still an embarrassment of riches when it comes to forward-thinking producers and DJs.

column1: So when 2013 rolled around
column2: Morelli did what any misanthrope enjoying a taste of low-level success would do: he left NYC
column3: abandoning the city <a href=""http://www.junodownload.com/plus/2011/09/26/label-focus-long-island-electrical-systems/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">he once referred to as an ""overrated cesspool
column4: moving himself and the L.I.E.S. name to a new home in Paris. An interview with FACT around the release of last year's dark
column5: misshapen solo debut Spit (released by fellow enfant terrible Dominick Fernow's Hospital Productions) found Morelli in top grouchy form
column6: the choicest quotes drenched with negativity: ""People are terrible and always have been. That's the harsh truth since the dawn of man...We're all going to die alone.""

column1: Granted
column2: Morelli's antisocial causticness shouldn't be surprising to anyone who's familiar with L.I.E.S.' loosely drawn aesthetic
column3: which amounts to various strains of dance music filtered through layers of psychedelic grit and static sludge. The level of interest directed in the label's direction these days is partially owed to good timing
column4: as noise musicians have increasingly turned their ears towards the dancefloor with results similar to L.I.E.S.' more inscrutable output.

column1: More often than not
column2: dance culture can't help but ascribe eye roll-worthy nomenclature to emerging sounds and scenes
column3: which explains why you've probably heard L.I.E.S. releases referred to as ""outsider house
column4: a term not-totally-seriously coined by distant-relative noisenik and Hessle Audio boss Ben UFO. (As curious labelings of American DIY-dance phenomena go
column5: the term is certainly less embarrassing than what we were stuck with two years ago.) The title of L.I.E.S.' second label-summating compilation
column6: Music for Shut-Ins
column7: may or may not playfully allude to its reputation for fringe-originating dance music. If so
column8: it's another example of the label's overlooked sense of humor; the booklet art for 2012's American Noise comp took a yellowed image of a shish kebab
column9: cast a phallic shadow on a mushroom
column10: and drove the whole pointed stick straight through a gesticulating Skrillex's mouth.

column1: L.I.E.S. release music at a constant clip that
column2: unless you're the type of listener that lives this shit for real
column3: is nearly impossible to keep pace with; the swarm of sounds is so persistently overwhelming that it can (and occasionally has) come across as
column4: well
column5: just a lot of noise. So the label's compilations have functioned less as a way to keep tabs on its general direction
column6: instead providing a somewhat incomplete but necessarily concise method of appraising what its artists have been up to as of late. It is
column7: from a label run by a human being who has gone on record expressing a hatred of humanity
column8: a considerably generous gesture.

column1: Compared to the label's other long-playing excursions in 2013—a platter of rudimentary synth experiments courtesy of Brooklyn producer Marcos Cabral
column2: the murmured nightmares of eerie-techno duo Shadowlust's Trust in Pain—Music for Shut-Ins approaches a perverted accessibility insofar that the L.I.E.S. catalog's lack of sonic approachability can occasionally come across as overstated. There are moments of flat-out gorgeousness—the skipping placidity of ""northeast"" producer Samanthas Vacation's eponymous side-long single
column3: Berlin resident Florian Kupfer's distant
column4: emotive soul-house jam ""Feelin'""
column5: D.C. duo Beautiful Swimmers' jungle-infused ""The Zoo""—laid up against purely psychedelic workouts that carry their own iridescent beauty
column6: like Beau Wanzer's trapped-in-the-mainframe ""Crush of Lust"" and L.I.E.S. regular Vereker's analog tunnel-chaser ""Rosite"".

column1: Taken in small chunks
column2: Music for Shut-Ins is as bewildering and exciting as its predecessor
column3: a reminder of why L.I.E.S. have thus far escaped falling trap to faddish notions
column4: remaining as engaging now as they did when no one was even talking about them. At two and a half hours
column5: though
column6: it's a slog as a front-to-back listen
column7: particularly in the opening moments of the 2013-collecting first disc. This is fine
column8: though
column9: as the purpose of compilations like these aren't so much as to be listened to as proper albums as they are to literally compile
column10: to properly round up singles that
column11: especially considering L.I.E.S. low-profile method of releasing their white-label releases
column12: would otherwise dissolve in the low-bitrate ether of YouTube rips.

column1: American Noise and Music for Shut-Ins share an identical structure: one disc of appraising the L.I.E.S. oeuvre thus far
column2: and another disc of new material. Whereas American Noise had two years and change of material to draw from
column3: Music for Shut-Ins takes its previously released work from just over a year's worth of releases
column4: which drives home L.I.E.S.' increasingly impressive track record of releasing forward-thinking dance music. The second disc of American Noise suggested that the label's sonic future would further embrace fragmentation
column5: and as such
column6: anyone coming to Music for Shut-Ins looking for hints on where L.I.E.S. is or will be should look elsewhere. Above all else
column7: Morelli and company have demanded that we expect nothing but the unexpected
column8:
and the pleasurably gnashing dissonance of Music for Shut-Ins' past/present collision suggests that the L.I.E.S. label's what's-next surprises are far from growing stale just yet.

"|18839.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18839-lies-presents-music-for-shut-ins/|7.8|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20019/homepage_large.260baf60.jpg|There’s A Dream I’ve Been Saving: Lee Hazlewood Industries 1966–1971|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Light in the Attic']|2014-01-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:32.781706|"

The word “sunshine” appears with clockwork regularity throughout There’s a Dream I’ve Been Saving: Lee Hazlewood Industries 1966-1971—as well it should. The four-disc box set chronicles the output of Hazlewood’s California-based LHI label during the prime of the hippie era
column2: and it’s steeped in the bright
column3: balmy Hollywood atmosphere from whence it came. The first two discs comprise Hazlewood’s own solo output for LHI
column4: namely the albums Cowboy in Sweden
column5: Forty
column6: The Cowboy & the Lady (with Ann-Margaret)
column7: and Requiem for an Almost Lady; the last two discs collect songs by the label’s Hazlewood-picked roster of pop hopefuls
column8: including obscure folk-rockers like Ray Chafin to Gram Parsons’ legendary country-rock pioneers
column9: the International Submarine Band. Sunshine is everywhere: Alongside Hazlewood’s “Little Miss Sunshine” sit Suzi Jane Hokom’s “Come on Sunshine
column10: ” Arthur’s “Sunshine Soldier
column11: ” Joe Cannon’s “Warm Miami Sunshine
column12: ” and the Shacklefords’ “California Sunshine Girl.” Each of these tracks is indeed summery in its own way
column13: as is most of There’s a Dream. But there’s one thing that neither this collection nor Hazlewood ever forgets: The brightest sun always casts the darkest shade.

column1: Hazlewood launched LHI in 1966 after solidly establishing his music-industry bona fides—first as the writer/producer behind a string of twangy Duane Eddy hits
column2: then as the mastermind who turned Nancy Sinatra into a name to rival her father’s with 1966’s “These Boots Were Made for Walkin’"". Flush with “Boots” cash
column3: he established a Hollywood headquarters for LHI that sought to spin Hazlewood’s idiosyncratic
column4: against-the-grain sensibility into gold. That never happened. By 1971
column5: the label had all but disintegrated without producing a single major hit
column6: at which point Hazlewood retreated into the cult-status hinterland for many years before enjoying a revival prior to his death in 2007. The rise and fall of LHI mirrors that of the 60s counterculture so precisely
column7: it’s hard not to draw parallels. But the label
column8: like its leader
column9: never fully engaged the Age of Aquarius
column10: opting instead to skirt its fringes. It wasn’t for a lack of ambition on Hazlewood’s part. He wanted to release bestselling records
column11: plain and simple—his own included. But the freewheeling
column12: spontaneous environment he fostered at LHI favored serendipity and cronyism over solid business sense.

column1: On the plus side
column2: that loose environment produced some enduring gems. LHI’s first signee was the Sunset-Strip-by-way-of-Amarillo outfit The Kitchen Cinq
column3: and its upbeat
column4: tambourine-rattling single from 1967
column5: “Need All the Help I Can Get
column6: ” may as well have been a prophecy: The group would struggle along without much promotional backing from LHI
column7: switching from the propulsive psychedelia of “Need” to the Association-esque sugariness of “I Want You""
column8: a later single released after the band had been urged by Hazlewood to change its name to A Handful. That said
column9: “I Want You” is a gorgeous piece of extravagantly harmonized pop—as is the output of another early LHI prospect
column10: Honey Ltd. The girl group moved to L.A. from Detroit in hopes of securing a record deal
column11: and the result was a string of releases—like the sumptuous single “Tomorrow Your Heart”—that highlighted the quartet’s silky
column12: trippy romanticism
column13: utterly distinct from the standard-issue Phil Spector lushness.

column1: Hazlewood’s eye for the ladies was legendary. Even as he continued his run of success with Nancy Sinatra (as heard on their epochal 1967 duet “Some Velvet Morning”)
column2: the verging-on-40 Svengali courted a 20-year-old singer named Suzi Jane Hokom—both creatively and personally. Her output for LHI is some of the label’s best
column3: as heard here on tracks like the aforementioned “Come on Sunshine""
column4: a flutes-and-reverb-laced confection that recalls “These Boots Are Made for Walkin’” with its opening line
column5: “I want to take these heavy boots off from my feet.” Hokom’s throaty

As Cologne’s Kompakt ran out the final length of its yearlong 20th anniversary victory lap in 2013
column2: it did so with the faint whiff of a label whose later output has been rendered slightly stale by repetition. This is a familiar paradox for lots of iconic imprints in their golden years
column3: especially those whose worldview is more constitutional than searching: the more blueprinted and carefully curated an aesthetic
column4: the more difficult it is to evolve. Over the last 20 years
column5: Kompakt’s make a mark on dance music
column6: honed its neatly-defined output down to pure science and put a tidy frame around it’s history. What next?

column1: If not for DJ Koze’s inspired 2013 breakthrough LP Amygdala (which actually came out on his own label
column2: Pampa)
column3: one could make the argument that it’s been years since any of Kompakt’s old guard have hit paydirt. Although perfectly pleasant
column4: Michael Mayer’s late 2012 full-length Mantasy failed to move the needle
column5: while fellow tentpole Superpitcher’s been mostly MIA since 2010. Even the label’s once-lauded compilations like Total and Pop Ambient have suffered from serious quality-control issues of late. Justus Köhncke doesn’t get the column inches of a Mayer or a Superpitcher
column6: but he’s one of the Kompakt’s longest-serving and most representative artists. Justus Köhncke & The Wonderful Frequency Band is his first full-length since 2008’s Safe & Sound; as unfair as it is to the artist
column7: it’s tempting to look to it as an indicator of the label’s current health.

column1: Sadly
column2: that narrative remains unresolved. Although TWFB boasts a characteristic mix of mid-tempo house
column3: techno
column4: disco and kitschy pop
column5: it’s hardly a definitive statement. As with all of Köhncke’s work
column6: it’s also infused with a whimsy that could be mistaken for indifference. That whimsy plays best when it’s applied to disco; in addition to boasting the greatest three-word distillation of Kompakt’s worldview yet
column7: opener “Flitter Und Tand” (translation: “frippery and kitsch”) houses a slinky bassline and a charmingly goofy spoken word refrain that ranks among Köhncke’s most endearing and infectious moments. Likewise
column8: lead single “Tell Me” is a particularly strong vintage of the aerodynamic disco-house hybrid for which Köhncke (and Kompakt) have come to be known. Tellingly
column9: the album’s standout moment feels miles away from Köhncke’s comfort zone; the singer-songwriterly “Wonderful Frequency Band” boasts gently picked acoustic guitars and pianos
column10: a swelling chorus
column11: and absolutely nothing in the way of a 4/4.

column1: But that sort of boundary pushing is in short supply here. Even at it’s best
column2: TWFB is mostly just a well-crafted collection of genre exercises; a few too many tracks
column3: like the motorik double whammy of “Das Selbstgespräch” and “Idee
column4: Prozess

column8: but no metaphor
column9: however offbeat
column10:
is deep enough to substitute for real surprise.

The combination of Faith Coloccia and Alex Barnett advances an intriguing stockpile of resources. With the bewitching project Mamiffer
column2: Washington state’s Coloccia has made majestic and often sinister slow music
column3: ethereal stuff that treats audible danger with grace and mere prettiness with suspicion. For Coloccia
column4: Mamiffer is only a key line on an impressive dossier of projects and co-conspirators. Elsewhere
column5: she’s joined Finnish jesters Circle to compose an album around a church’s ancient organ
column6: added instruments to Boris records
column7: and launched the impressive multimedia imprint SIGE Records with husband and frequent collaborator
column8: ISIS co-founder Aaron Turner. Though Barnett’s résumé hasn’t pushed his name beyond experimental circles
column9: the Chicago multi-instrumentalist’s skill sets are rich. With the improvisational trio Oakeater
column10: he’s navigated sidelong trips through acerbic drone and junkyard sounds. (Oakeater tellingly issued a split with kindred sculptors Yellow Swans in 2011.) Under his given name for the last several years
column11: Barnett’s also released ponderous synthesizer-and-drum machine songs
column12: music that sounded like vaguely sinister scores for suspense films not yet made.

column1: Retrieval
column2: the debut issue from the pair
column3: stocks a wealth of variegated sound within its 39 minutes. Recorded and edited during two sessions in the Pacific Northwest
column4: Retrieval sees Coloccia and Barnett revisiting multiple facets of their output: There’s Coloccia’s alien coo and Barnett’s mysterious electronics
column5: his aggressive throb and her more placid expanses. Warped samples of AM radio transmissions comingle with soporific beats
column6: and Motorik clicks ride beneath lurid keyboard nightmares. The music is of a fashion with Oneohtrix Point Never’s most radiant moments and Prurient’s least caustic. The minimalist melody of opener “Harbor” eventually pulls back like curtains to reveal a lupine wail and a background of sculpted static. “Hallway” patiently stacks and removes a dozen layers
column7: from a low-note hum and granulated keyboard sighs to astringent squeals and a wraithlike rhythm. Retrieval succeeds by grafting the styles of two very distinct musicians
column8: with their skills nested as a series of alternating concentric circles.

column1: But these seven pieces linger largely in a hazy middle distance
column2: with their movements so subtle and sometimes miniature that they feel observed from across a great divide even when intently observed. That short beginner “Harbor” comes off like a prelude
column3: with the series of rests intimating an ellipsis that leads to more pressing material. But “Switch”
column4: which follows
column5: hovers in much the same tentative realm. Near-harpsichord arpeggios and eerie electronics gradually introduce a metronomic beat
column6: painted by neon tones that arrive and disappear with cardiopulmonary regularity. Even “Retrieval”
column7: the album’s humming near-finale
column8: depends upon the expectation of something more. Its sound moves in steady arches that again extend an introduction. Barnett and Coloccia seem forever to eschew the main event
column9: never really turning any of Retrieval’s foreboding atmosphere into veritable drama. The eight-minute “Hallway” comes closest by instigating a soundclash against atonal noise bursts and comforting organ chords. By its end
column10: though
column11: even the album’s centerpiece feels as though it needs to be moored to some greater action. Delivered on repeat
column12: restraint can start to feel like hesitation
column13: a compositional crutch for avoiding controversy. Retrieval is a hypothetical soundtrack that feels lean without its filmic counterpart
column14: a small record of instrumental ideas that stop just short of execution.

column1: Next year
column2: Coloccia’s SIGE will release a new LP by Oakeater and reissue a 2010 cassette split between that three-piece and Mamiffer. Hopefully
column3: then
column4: Retrieval is only the proper start of the working relationship between Barnett and Coloccia
column5: in spite of their geographical distance and otherwise rather active recording schedules. On these seven tracks
column6: each elicits many of the best aspects from the other’s musical palette. Even if the first draft feels minor and overly impressionistic
column7: it suggests a beguiling synthesis of horror and harmony
column8: unease and atmosphere. If together they can move beyond mere suggestion
column9:
Coloccia and Barnettt are capable of music that cowers with beauty.

Should Beyoncé choose to settle in the world of Adult Contemporary one day

column3: an album that playfully extolled the virtues of marriage
column4: crafting a role for herself in that sphere with the ambitious grace of a good politician. Imagine the fun she had requesting the big hair and bigger fur to help President Obama ring in his second term
column5: or in gussying herself up like Marie Antoinette to promote an international arena tour called The Mrs. Carter Show. The hedge-betting deals with Pepsi and H&M
column6: the (now-defunct) lifestyle blog/newsletter à la Gwyneth Paltrow's goop
column7: the reunion with Destiny's Child
column8: the exquisitely dull autobiographical documentary—she's seemed entirely poised to join Jay Z on his cloud of moneyed middle-age.

column1: In retrospect
column2: the adult gloss feels like an elaborate foil to the trouble she’d been cooking up in private all along. Beyoncé
column3: her fifth solo album
column4: repositions the singer as the Houston-bred Yoncé
column5: a woman lustier and surlier than B
column6: more playful than Bey
column7: fiercer than Sasha but softer and more natural than the lot. The album is brassy but elegant
column8: its post-coital breath smelling faintly of cheap liquor sipped from a crystal flute. It finds Beyoncé shifting gears to pull off her most explicit and sonically experimental music to date
column9: exploring sounds and ideas at the grittier margins of popular music.

column1: It’s tempting to read Beyoncé’s hard edges as an attempt to ride the success of Rihanna or Miley Cyrus’ risqué agendas—but to do so would be to look past the album’s true provocations. Beyoncé pushes boundaries not because it sells sex at every turn
column2: but because it treats a power-balanced marriage as a place where sexuality thrives. At a time when when young people are gripped by an ideological fear of monogamy’s advertised doldrums
column3: Beyoncé boldly proposes the idea that a woman’s prime—personal
column4: professional
column5: and especially sexual—can occur within a stable romantic partnership. Monogamy has never sounded more seductive or less retrograde as when dictated on Beyoncé's terms. The innuendo can be bawdy and overblown—""Can you lick my Skittles/ That's the sweetest in the middle"" on ""Blow""—but sincerely so. And who would allow Jay Z’s instantly infamous breasts/breakfast line anywhere near the stargazing boom of “Drunk in Love” but someone truly infatuated with him? What’s more is that the erotic themes don’t feel out-of-step with the album’s more decorous moments
column6: like the stadium-filling “XO” or “Blue”
column7: its requisite treatise on motherhood. In Beyoncé’s world
column8: there are illicit doors to be unlocked in the halls of tradition and vice versa.

column1: The record reverberates with the energy of a conservative pop star navigating trends without grasping for them. Its crew of 44 writers
column2: producers
column3: and directors skews heavily toward the hip-hop realm and incorporates niche talents
column4: something Beyoncé tried on 4 when she teamed with artists like Switch and pulled visual ideas from little-known European choreographers discovered via YouTube. It's the collective effort of an all-star team with a deep bench
column5: with contributions from mainstays like Pharrell and The-Dream
column6: to fresh faces like Chairlift's Caroline Polachek
column7: a creative director from streetwear brand Supreme
column8: and a practically-unknown producer named Boots.

column1: Beyoncé’s best songs often reject traditional pop structures in favor of atmosphere—she may have taken some cues from her sister Solange
column2: who now leads a particular wave of <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/news/52734-solange-announces-rb-compilation-featuring-cassie-kelela-sampha-jhene-aiko-more/"">collaborative
column3: left-field R&B. The record
column4: her darkest and lushest yet
column5: has a tendency to echo
column6: stop abruptly
column7: or place two separate songs in the space of one. Its most bracing moments are also its toughest and weirdest
column8: like ""***Flawless""
column9: a two-part growler that makes feminist TED Talk fodder sound legitimately menacing. Timbaland and Justin Timberlake join The-Dream on ""Partition"" in service of the mean-mugging Yoncé
column10: who snarls and bares her teeth as though the most revered rapper of all time is nobody but her little husband. At the center lies Beyoncé’s practically unfair abilities as a performer—you get the sense that Lady Gaga or Ciara could no sooner pull off the scale or quality of Beyoncé than you or I could pull off a suitable rendition of any of its songs in a karaoke bar.

column1: Beyoncé has loosened up her delivery
column2: too
column3: in a way that highlights her elasticity and shows her pop-cultural antennae tuned to the right channels. Who could’ve predicted that some of the most infectious snippets of pop music in 2013 would not arrive by way of anthemic chorus or assembly-line arrangement
column4: but in Beyoncé’s ad-libbing? You already know the ones: Surfbort
column5: she grunts on “Drunk in Love”
column6: slinging a hashtag like it’s the name of a line of Ikea chairs
column7: the single word serving as both shorthand for woman-on-top and a neat summation of an entire era of trends in rap cadence. You’d also be hard-pressed to find an internet-savvy person in America who hasn’t been possessed by the idea that he or she woke up like this
column8: brain emblazoned with Beyoncé’s half-second I’m so flawless I gave myself a seizure dance. She's achieved the rare feat of validating meme culture by capturing its sneaky potency and delight rather than falling into its cheap
column9: dehumanizing traps. This is a “visual album
column10: ” sure
column11: but it’s also a package of modern codes and discreet campaigns
column12: a field of meaningful virtual dioramas. In this sense Beyoncé has a newfound spiritual ally in Drake (Worst! YOLO!)
column13: —he shows up on Beyoncé on the bruised ""Mine""— her only peer to successfully streamline an internet-rooted mindset into a large-scale pop arena and seek profundity in the process.

column1: Which is all to say that Beyoncé has delivered on the promise she inadvertently made by dropping an album and its expansive visual counterpart late on a Thursday night in December on iTunes
column2: free of traditional fanfare. Call it a coup or just another victory for her mammoth PR apparatus
column3: but consider the alternatives: The strategy probably would have failed if the quality wasn't there
column4: and the album could not have achieved such an impact without its rogue—in spirit
column5: at least—method of distribution. Beyoncé was unleashed upon the world in a way that could only succeed right now
column6: with an aim to make the audience consume it the way it would have long ago. It’s a line that could be ripped straight from the mouth of an investment-drunk tech startup founder
column7:
but it’s true: Beyoncé seized the powers of a medium characterized by its short attention span to force the world to pay attention. Leave it to the posterchild of convention to brush convention aside and leave both sides feeling victorious.

column2: Pt. 4
column6: writers

column8: fellow humans:  Do you struggle with creeping boredom? Do you fight nagging suspicions that you've accomplished your goals and they failed to satisfy you? Do you cast about listlessly for motivation and inspiration in low moments? Have you ever guiltily killed an hour or three on Twitter?

column1: Whoever you are

column6: Today & Tomorrow
column7: a compilation surveying a career so packed with highlights that you could quibble about its many omissions. Now

column1: At any rate

column5: and 6

column7: History

column1: To say
column2: then

column7: the IAMSU!-featuring breakout hit from from last year.

column1: But that's about it: If you're plumbing for deeper quibbles with this project

column3: he shows us ""hundred round drums that look just like a curled-up snake
column4: and on ""Rep Yo District"" he tells us the jewels on his neck ""look like baby tongues."" His details are so specific they nearly hurt your eyes: ""Granny bedridden"" are his two opening words on ""Do What I Gotta Do""
column5: a song that also mentions needing to show up at your parole address. A character on ""Off The Block"" goes to jail ""on purpose just so he can get a decent meal."" In the middle of the hard-knock-life mob number ""Throwed Like This""
column6: he throws in that his family uses ""a broom
column7: not a vacuum

Danny Brown and Schoolboy Q show up on ""All My Ni**az""; Rick Ross (who offers the #peakRoss quote: ""My jacket's expensive/ It's made out of lizards"") and French Montana (who offers the #peakMontana: ""Can't you see I'm high? Stop talking in my ear"") on ""Champagne"". Houston legend Z-Ro drops in

column6: Kool John

Old and new styles coexist comfortably in 40's music in a way they don't elsewhere: The most audaciously ""off""-sounding beat on the project

is a fountain of youth.

Around the time Kevin Costner was conceiving 1995’s Waterworld
column2: the overblown film project that would entail him having webbed feet and chugging his own piss
column3: two African-American sci-fi freaks were constructing their own aquatic world. But rather than swim in a tank off the coast of Hawaii to the tune of $175 million
column4: the waters Gerald Donald and the late James Stinson navigated as Drexciya were firmly kept within the impoverished confines of Detroit’s city limits.

column1: Across a series of singles
column2: EPs
column3: and conceptual full-lengths released on labels like Underground Resistance
column4: Warp
column5: Rephlex
column6: and Berlin techno imprint Tresor
column7: Drexciya conjured a world more evocative than Hollywood could fathom
column8: and at a fraction of the budget. The fourth and final volume of Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller series (the Dutch imprint Clone’s necessary reissue/rescue of Drexciya’s long out-of-print catalogue) proves that their releases are deep enough to warrant sequels with little dip in quality.

column1: For those not familiar with the backstory
column2: Stinson and Donald (operating under a cloak of anonymity) conceived of the mythic Drexciyans: a water-breathing humanoid race descended from the pregnant slave women cast overboard during trans-Atlantic deportation. Their mutant strain of electro
column3: funk and techno—conjured on analog electronics and recorded directly to tape—is fittingly brutal. Even with forebearers like Kraftwerk and Cybotron
column4: Drexciya’s sound remains singular.

column1: Alongside a slew of unreleased tracks (at least six contain the word “Unknown” in them)
column2: some of their spikiest electro crops up here
column3: from the severely phased
column4: drillbit synths of “Aquatic Bata Particles” to the frantic
column5: alarm-sounding “Mantaray”. While in hindsight Drexciya’s lineage to Detroit electronic music is evident
column6: there’s also a latent sense of anger
column7: fury and powerlessness to these tracks
column8: one that at times makes me think of the duo as descendants of that “lost” Detroit act
column9: Death. There’s as much of punk’s fury as techno’s pulse to be felt here.

column1: If there’s been a downside to this otherwise excellent reissue series
column2: it’s that Clone has scrubbed clean the dystopian Afrofuturistic backstory that attended each Drexciya release
column3: those sub-aquatic realms of stingray battalions
column4: Aquabahns
column5: Lardossen cruisers
column6: and Darthouven Fish Men are left to the imagination
column7: as well as that institution only managed via sci-fi tropes. But in absorbing both the punishing stingray whips and distressed synths on the seven-minute “Hydro Cubes
column8: ” Drexciya seems to anticipate the sort of repugnant tones Kanye West reveled in just last year to create Yeezus’s “sorrowful and furious headspace."" But while Kanye proclaimed himself a god
column9: Drexicya wondered if god was virtual reality. Nearly 20 years earlier
column10:
Drexciya were creating something equally livid and misunderstood.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20011/homepage_large.60404fbe.jpg|A Fallen Empire|31925.0|Kerridge|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Downwards']|2014-01-06 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:36.962700|"

The music of Berlin-based Brit Samuel Kerridge bears a pitch-black complexion that firmly positions it alongside an entire strain of current electronic music. Elements of industrial
column2: drone
column3: noise
column4: and club culture all find equal weight in Kerridge's world
column5: just as they do with similarly minded peers such as the Haxan Cloak
column6: Raime
column7: and the Blackest Ever Black label. It helps that original artists from some of those disciplines have surfaced again
column8: apparently rejuvenated. William Bennett from Whitehouse is throwing out incisive techno in his Cut Hands guise
column9: while the dark wave electronics of Throbbing Gristle's Chris & Cosey were manifested to satisfyingly bracing effect in the Transverse and X-TG records. That's some tough company to keep for anyone punching the ""gloom"" setting on their sampler
column10: although Kerridge's approach—building steadily through a series of EPs and signing to Peter Sutton and Karl O'Connor's longstanding Downwards label—hints that he's in this for the long term.

column1: The atmosphere of Kerridge's debut full-length
column2: A Fallen Empire
column3: is immediately detectable without hearing a single note of the music inside. The cover features a man in his death throes
column4: clutching his neck and about to fall. Song titles include ""Black Sun""
column5: ""Straight to Hell""
column6: and ""Death is Upon Us"". The shifts in tone throughout are slight
column7: but significant. Some tracks deviate further into outright noise than others
column8: with ""Black Sun"" floating away on overlapping waves of shrill sound at its close. Elsewhere
column9: Kerridge amplifies the industrial influence; ""Straight to Hell"" is all metallic D.A.F. drums pummelling away over grinding electronics. The mood is somewhere between sleazy and downcast
column10: alternately embracing a misspent evening and its bitter aftermath. There are nihilistic thrills aplenty
column11: but to dismiss A Fallen Empire as just that would be missing a layer or two of significance. Kerridge appears just as interested in meditative blackout
column12: steering this album into small circles of introspection at key points.

column1: It’s when A Fallen Empire steps off the brutalist treadmill that it gets most interesting. ""Scare Tactics"" taps into outright paranoia
column2: drifting close to the surveillance society neuroses of Photek's classic drum and bass cut ""The Hidden Camera"". It's a wise move by Kerridge to take on these different shades
column3: making A Fallen Empire stand apart from his peers' current race into the shadows. The consequential downside is that some of the more somber material doesn't stretch far enough away from things happening elsewhere
column4: with tracks such as ""Heavy Metal"" and ""Disgust"" edging a little too close to the area so expertly dominated by the Haxan Cloak on Excavation. Still
column5: it's rare that a track passes without a suitably degraded loop holding the attention
column6: or with a brain-battering beat set in motion with the intent to trounce all around it. The central figure that surfaces in ""Disgust"" suggests a primitive machine endlessly ticking away
column7: its original purpose long since forgotten.

column1: A recent interview with Kerridge pinpointed the moment where he discovered electronics
column2: at the age of four when his parents immersed him in the U.K. acid house scene. On the surface it's an odd juxtaposition to the music he makes now
column3: where the traditional feel-good vibes of clubland are trampled underfoot. But read a little deeper into that interview
column4: or into the history of illegal raves
column5: and stories of guns
column6: violence
column7: and strongarm police tactics are never far away. A Fallen Empire is brutal at times
column8: lonely at others. It resembles a sober wake up call after years of the come-together sloganeering that forms a significant part of club culture. Perhaps it's a stretch to imagine this album as the inevitable consequence of a kid being immersed in a scene that ostensibly promoted peace and togetherness
column9: only to find a gun waved in his face. But Kerridge's story isn’t so different from that of Margaret Chardiet
column10: the New Yorker recording brutal noise as Pharmakon
column11: whose punk obsessive parents introduced her to the mosh pit at a young age. Like Chardiet
column12: there’s a grain of experience here
column13:
a sense that this music is coming from an uncomfortably personal place.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20033/homepage_large.349092e5.jpg|Hallelujah All the Way Home|31952.0|The Verlaines|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Flying Nun']|2014-01-06 00:00:00|1985|2016-06-11 16:49:37.651955|"

The Verlaines deal in moments big and small
column2: both structurally and thematically. Graeme Downes formed the band in New Zealand in the early 1980s
column3: where they signed to Flying Nun and quickly became an important part of the label's history. Their music subsequently went in and out of print
column4: becoming a valuable secret shared between friends
column5: all caught up in Downes' fascination with labyrinthian song structures
column6: literate pop
column7: scratchy guitar sounds
column8: and occasional string and horn flourishes. The music made by the Verlaines is neither difficult nor accessible
column9: instead ending up in a fuzzy middle ground where both those impulses are indulged
column10: giving their work a strange kind of weight all of its own.

column1: Captured Tracks is issuing Hallelujah All the Way Home
column2: the band’s first album from 1985
column3: and the 1987 compilation Juvenilia
column4: as part of its broader Flying Nun reissue campaign. It's a moment of vindication for Downes
column5: who has toiled under the Verlaines name on and off for years
column6: while also holding down a day job as a lecturer in music at the University of Otago in New Zealand. Still
column7: it's most likely to end up as a treat for the devoted
column8: a reward for years of allegiance. There's even a Verlaines tote bag available for anyone buying both albums in one package—an item that fans of the Dunedin scene
column9: after years spent trawling used record stores looking for Flying Nun artefacts
column10: can't ever have dreamed of materializing.

column1: ""Death and the Maiden"" from Juvenilia is the natural starting point for the uninitiated
column2: with its post-Buzzcocks guitar sound
column3: an odd stop-start section
column4: a dreamy chorus
column5: and a complete change of tact at the midway point. It even includes a helpful explanation of the band's name (taken from Paul Verlaine the poet
column6: not Tom Verlaine the Television frontman). Comparisons can be drawn between this work and similarly minded musicians who circled around the Postcard scene in Scotland around this time
column7: even if Downes wasn’t necessarily aware of them. There are shades of the post-punk awkwardness and Beefheartian rhythms of the Fire Engines
column8: and a sense of influences stretching into soul in a manner akin to the material on Orange Juice's The Glasgow School.

column1: What both these albums capture is the excitement of being in a band and discovering that you're onto something
column2: even if the audience for it in the outside world isn't there yet. Juvenilia is well named— it could work as a title for either of these records—with Downes spitting out lyrics about drinking and love and alienation and hope. Over the extraordinarily lopsided rhythms of ""All Laid On"" he sings of dreaming despite it all
column3: while on ""The Lady and the Lizard"" he needs to ""just be alone all day."" It's an unnervingly accurate embodiment of the conflicting emotions felt when you're still trying to make sense of the world. Or
column4: as Downes puts it in his notes to Juvenilia
column5: the sound of a band ""desperately trying to make some noise that made life more meaningful.""

column1: A common thematic trope of both Hallelujah and Juvenilia is the way they both gallop through styles and strange deviations
column2: being quite unafraid to take a turn into unexpected territory. Hallelujah dips into a folk lament (""Don't Send Me Away"") and follows it with the furiously incisive ""Lying in State"". Juvenilia positively drifts into the beautiful
column3: drumless ""Wind Song""
column4: while purposefully awkward tracks such as ""Angela"" (from the Chris Knox-recorded Dunedin Double EP) are executed with a breathless enthusiasm. The clumsy seal on these songs
column5: whether deliberately designed or part of a learning curve
column6: works so well as a mirror of the teenage fumbling the lyrics address
column7: adding to the feel of someone stumbling through life
column8: not sure where to turn next
column9: simultaneously perplexed and in awe of everything around them.

column1: The Verlaines' subsequent career was suitably diverse
column2: hitting a high on the more inward looking 1987 album Bird Dog
column3: enduring a rocky period in the 90s
column4: and a reformation in the 2000s. Downes' 2001 solo album Hammers and Anvils is the highlight of his later work. Fortunately his wit and skill for a quick turn of phrase never abandoned him—a 2003 compilation album of Verlaines material issued by Flying Nun was suitably named You're Just Too Obscure for Me. As that title suggests
column5: Downes is of no doubt about his place in the world. ""It was music that was on the cultural fringes when we wrote it
column6: and it still is
column7: he said in a recent interview. Still
column8: his modest stories come with all-encompassing themes and the occasional grandiose notion
column9:
all beautifully hobbled by the Verlaines' wonderfully inexpert approach.

"|18838.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18838-the-verlaines-hallelujah-all-the-way-home-juvenilia/|7.6|Nick Neyland
