column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20013/homepage_large.0c4740e7.jpg|Rival Dealer EP|4806.0|Burial|['Experimental'
column2:
'Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2013-12-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:38.310817|"

Few electronic artists from the last decade have been pigeonholed like William Bevan. Since the London producer behind Burial gained widespread attention with 2007's epochal second album
column3: Untrue
column4: listeners and critics alike have spoken of ""the Burial sound""—pitched-down vocal samples
column5: rustling noise
column6: blocky garage rhythms in perpetual decay—as if it were straight gospel. This is partially Bevan's fault: four years passed before any new solo material saw release
column7: which allowed plenty of time for Untrue's singular aura to seep into the collective consciousness. As imitators big and small have lined up to pay respect
column8: the phrase ""sounds like Burial"" escaped the connotation of wishful thinking and started sounding almost like
column9: well
column10: an insult.

column1: Insulting because
column2: as this decade so far has proven
column3: one person who doesn't sound like Burial anymore is Burial himself. 2011's Street Halo EP
column4: which followed a 12"" collaboration with Four Tet
column5: offered a few engaging structural tweaks to Untrue's formula
column6: but it was the collab EP with Massive Attack that followed later in the year
column7: ""Four Walls"" b/w ""Paradise Circus""
column8: that hinted Bevan was ready to explore truly new territory. Essentially a pair of Burial edits of songs from Massive Attack's 2010 LP Heligoland
column9: each cut pushed past the 11-minute mark and embraced a proggy
column10: amorphous structure that was worlds away from the contained environments of previous Burial releases. If the Massive Attack edits suggested a shift away from the past
column11: 2012's astounding pair of EPs
column12: Kindred and Truant/Rough Sleeper
column13: broke free of any previously set constraints
column14: as Bevan wielded his newfound appreciation for side-long track lengths and added splashes of sonic color—arpeggiated synths
column15: chunky house motifs
column16: rickety windchimes
column17: bursts of beatific melody—to his established palette of blues and grays.

column1: Over the last few years
column2: the only consistent aspect of Burial's music is the frequency of when it's been released—typically and almost too fittingly
column3: in the dead of winter—so the excitement that arrives with the announcement a new Burial release in 2013 is no longer ""It exists!
column4: but ""What is this going to sound like?"" Rival Dealer arrives almost exactly a year after Truant/Rough Sleeper
column5: but the stylistic leaps made on this new release are more jarring and revelatory than anything in Burial's catalog. It's unquestionably his strongest release since Kindred
column6: and his most satisfying statement of purpose since Untrue.

column1: The seismic stylistic shift that Bevan's made on these three tracks—two of which
column2: true to recent form
column3: run well over the 10-minute mark—is immediately apparent on the opening minutes of Rival Dealer's title track
column4: when a distorted vocal sample of adult-contemporary cheeseball Gavin DeGraw's ""More Than Anyone"" (<a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6s4iSwWqRIc"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">yes
column5: really) gives way to a furious drum break
column6: making for Burial's most straightforwardly uptempo move to date. The rhythm simultaneously sounds crisp and hissing
column7: eventually disintegrating in a blare of police-scanner noise before everything goes truly pear-shaped with a monstrous
column8: buzzing bassline
column9: as a woodblock rhythm from the Untrue days clicks and clacks below the chaos. In the few interviews that Bevan has given throughout his career
column10: he's outlined Burial's conceptual aims as a tribute to the rave music he didn't get a chance to grow up with but experienced second-hand; the unbridled intensity of ""Rival Dealer"" is arguably his most explicitly rave-y move yet.

column1: ""Rival Dealer""'s final
column2: impressionistic third is the one section on Rival Dealer that dips into familiar Burial territory
column3: with meditative synths and stray vocal samples briefly interrupted by a radiant saxophone line. It's a necessary comedown after all the preceding intensity
column4: as well as a teaser for what follows: ""Hiders"" and ""Come Down to Us""
column5: the EP's following two cuts
column6: are the source of Rival Dealer's most mind-blowing moments
column7: as well as being the closest that Bevan's come to total accessibility since Untrue's earwormy lead single ""Archangel"". The EP's other side-long epic
column8: ""Come Down to Us""
column9: takes cues from the crawling sense of pacing established on the Massive Attack edits
column10: with a rhythm so slow it barely registers on the BPM scale stretched across 13 minutes
column11: as a slinky sitar-like figure and piping synths give way to a sparkly
column12: unnervingly sentimental soft-rock melody
column13: the sounds of drizzling rain coating the whole thing.

column1: If ""Come Down to Us"" is Bevan laying out conventional melodic forms across his template of psychedelic sprawl
column2: ""Hiders"" is 2010s-Burial in miniature form
column3: his only sub-five-minute solo cut of the decade thus far and one of the only true standalone tracks in his catalog (not an insult—he's a deep-listening artist at this point). It opens with an anthemic synth figure that starts and stops several times
column4: returning each time with varying fidelity
column5: before a splashy arena-rock drumbeat crashes through the ambience
column6: stepping in time with the cascading synth figure and a vocal sample that seems to hover just slightly above everything else. The beatific
column7: neon ""Hiders"" is Bevan's take on the more loved-up element of rave music—if ""Rival Dealer"" is a tip to the days of Kool FM
column8: then this is more along the lines of the stuff spun by DJs like Scott Hardkiss and Danny Rampling—but even those without a lick of dance history know-how will be wowed by ""Hiders""' magnificent aura
column9: a down-to-the-buzzer entry as one of 2013's most surprising musical moments.

column1: Rival Dealer has some of the most immediate music from the Burial project
column2: but it's worth noting that this is also a noisy
column3: dissonant work. Tape hiss and static smother large sections of the EP
column4: and Bevan seriously tips the scales when it comes to one of the staples of Burial's style
column5: as well as rave music at large—the vocal sample. He liberally applies voices all over the three tracks
column6: both as a structural anchor and to create a pleasing cacophony; during ""Rival Dealer""'s coruscating midsection
column7: he throws in a sample of New York rapper Lord Finesse's ""You Know What I'm About"" in a showoff-y
column8: very un-Burial fashion. Burial has often been praised for restraint; the wild-eyed
column9: play-anything nature of Rival Dealer shatters that notion for the better.

column1: Speaking of vocal samples: a theme that runs through Rival Dealer
column2: upheld by the many voices that dot its landscape
column3: is self-acceptance. Phrases concerning sexuality and personal reflection abound—""This is the moment when you see who you are
column4: ""It's about sexuality
column5: it's about showing a person who you are—to me
column6: this is who I'm about
column7: ""This is who I am
column8: ""Who are you?"". ""Come Down to Us""
column9: in particular
column10: ends with an extended lift of a passage from transgender filmmaker Lana Wachowski's painfully moving speech while receiving the Human Rights Campaign Visibility Award last year.

column1: Some have already speculated that Bevan's framing here is intentional
column2: possibly speaking to his own personal experiences. Whatever the case
column3: ""Come Down to Us"" is Rival Dealer's nucleus
column4: as its titular vocal sample appears throughout the EP. The fact that such guesswork takes place to begin with is evidence of how
column5: after nearly a decade of making music
column6: William Bevan continues to fascinate and create intrigue. Here
column7: he provides plenty of exciting material to pore over until he returns
column8:
further changing our perspective on an artist we're still just starting to understand.

"|18820.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18820-burial-rival-dealer-ep/|9.0|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19927/homepage_large.a94c5180.jpg|BOOT!|7563.0|The Thing|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thing']|2013-12-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:38.875387|"

Swedish/Norwegian trio the Thing play free jazz that you can stage dive to. Though the group—saxophonist Mats Gustafsson
column2: drummer Paal Nilssen-Love
column3: and bassist Ingebrit Håker Flaten—initially came together in 1999 as a tribute project dedicated to trumpeter/out-music legend Don Cherry
column4: they quickly evolved and found its own identity
column5: performing improvised music that’s informed by the urgency and simplicity of garage rock. If you line up a list of the Thing’s cover selections—songs by the Cramps
column6: the Sonics
column7: and PJ Harvey—against their roster of collaborators—weirdo-luminaries like Jim O’Rourke
column8: Peter Brötzmann
column9: Merzbow—you can get an idea of where their sensibilities lay.

column1: Boot! is the Thing’s sixth full-length album and it’s among the group’s finest efforts at pairing bludgeoning physicality with heady free jazz chops. The record opens with a high-volume re-think of “India”
column2: from John Coltrane’s 1963 album Impressions. Here spiritual jazz is recast as raw and sludgy stoner rock
column3: with Flaten and Gustafsson dropping the lead melody down a few octaves and delivering the notes in loose
column4: creaky unisons before dropping into a savage free-for-all. So long as you are acquainted with and sympathetic to the work of Geezer Butler
column5: the song will retain some of Coltrane's meditative spirit.

column1: The original compositions on Boot! work the band’s extensive vocabulary of skree and pummel. The Thing’s reputation is based on loud and heavy blowouts
column2: but they also make expert use of dynamics. Over the course of 10 minutes
column3: “Reboot” shifts from rigid pounding to quiet saxophone squawks
column4: to a pummeling groove that recalls the heavier work of experimental-minded Dutch punk band
column5: the Ex. On the title track
column6: Flaten and Gustafsson play a series of long and hoarse honks
column7: establishing a grinding
column8: doomy tempo while Nilssen-Love gradually builds steam in the background.

column1: The Thing frequently appropriate contemporary rock tunes into their repertoire
column2: but their approach is markedly different than that of
column3: say
column4: pianist Brad Mehldau re-working Radiohead’s “Exit Music (For a Film)” or the Bad Plus covering Nirvana’s “Smell’s Like Teen Spirit”. In those re-thinks
column5: jazz players expand and complicate the harmonies of the songs' melodic hooks. The Thing are more likely to look to the rhythmic thwacking of a power chord for inspiration. On Boot!
column6: they steer clear of rock and roll covers
column7: but the fuzz
column8: grit
column9: and energy of the music are still very much a part of their sound. Heavy riffs are treated as scaffolding for excursions into free improvisation—a mechanism through which Gustafsson
column10: Nilssen-Love
column11: and Flaten can access a heightened level of bombast
column12:
a place where the guitar is always on fire.

"|18735.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18735-the-thing-boot/|7.7|Aaron Leitko

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19897/homepage_large.dbcb7724.jpg|The First And Last Days Of Unwelcome|31818.0|Lumbar|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Southern Lord']|2013-12-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:39.441325|"

The worst thing about the remarkable The First and Last Days of Unwelcome is that its seven roaring songs will likely prove to be the first and last work of Lumbar
column2: the trio of metal veterans who gathered just to make it. Aaron Edge
column3: the group’s leader
column4: is familiar enough with short-lived bands. During the last two decades
column5: he’s jumped between at least a half-dozen acts
column6: from the distended anthems of the trio Brothers of the Sonic Cloth to the pugnacious sludge of Rote Hexe. He played in the earliest versions of metalcore militants Himsa and
column7: of late
column8: he’s drummed in his wife’s spry punk duo Blood Buddies. Lumbar is Edge’s collaboration with two frontmen—Yob’s Mike Scheidt and Tad Doyle
column9: frontman for the grunge-plus band that took his first name and Edge’s bandmate in the aforementioned Brothers. Edge wrote and recorded the music and penned the lyrics; during one long weekend in Seattle
column10: they added their voices. And with that
column11: the project is probably finished.

column1: But this isn’t a one-off necessarily by choice: Not long after Scheidt and Doyle agreed to join the project
column2: Edge spent 40 anguished days in bed
column3: getting up only to use the bathroom or to stretch his legs. In 2011
column4: the marathon runner
column5: distant cyclist and graphic designer began experiencing pain in his hands
column6: which he attributed to his exercise style. He made some adjustments to his regimen and equipment and carried on
column7: although the pain slowly metastasized. Finally
column8: in early January of this year
column9: the discomfort overwhelmed him. “My hands and feet feel as if they are asleep and crushed under heavy weight every minute of every day/night
column10: ” he has said. “I could no longer shift my gears on the bike
column11: could not hold drum sticks while playing in my wife’s band
column12: could not do dishes or other chores around the house.” Two months later
column13: a neurologist diagnosed Edge with multiple sclerosis. He worked through bouts of depression
column14: thoughts of suicide
column15: and days of agony. In May
column16: he was well enough to enter the studio with Scheidt and Doyle. The pair sang lyrics he’d mustered while he’d been stranded in bed
column17: words that cursed his symptoms and demanded an escape. In honor of the three spinal taps Edge endured for a diagnosis
column18: they took the name Lumbar. Edge says he’s currently not writing new music and that this may very well be Lumbar’s first and final album.

column1: While Lumbar’s creation myth is compelling
column2: the music does not slink at all in its shadow. With seven tracks and a runtime of less than 25 minutes
column3: The First and Last Days of Unwelcome is a confident and decided trek through doom metal. Many of Edge’s projects have ventured into this territory before
column4: but this combination works better than the bulk of his past. Scheidt and Doyle—a singer and a screamer
column5: respectively—animate these songs wonderfully
column6: adding gusto to Edge’s grievances. Scheidt and Doyle earn the most obvious name recognition here and give this harrowing tale voice. But Edge’s role in building these songs himself drives the bulk of Unwelcome’s success. Despite the record’s brevity
column7: these numbers manage to both honor and upend their clear slow-metal precedents. On the side of reverence
column8: “Day Six” works from the same looming vantage as Sleep; the electric lead hangs in a haze of distortion
column9: with the theme doubled by bass and beaten by a ringing snare drum and splashing cymbal. Scheidt wrestles the worry from Edge’s lyrics of damaged viscera and dashed expectations
column10: his ascendant and piercing tone adding a theatric bravado to the suffering. His power suggests Messiah Marcolin time at Candlemass’ helm. Likewise
column11: the bass and guitar mirror one another during “Day One”
column12: rendering the riff as a tumescent march sizable enough for Electric Wizard. The song opens with a tough-guy quote from The Twilight Zone
column13: fulfilling at least one other genre requisite.

column1: Perhaps more interesting
column2: though
column3: is the stuff that inverts or otherwise works against methodical and monolithic doom. Especially in the record’s middle
column4: Lumbar offers surprising reappraisals of mood and form. “Day Three” cuts and loops what could be a sliver of a solo from a hair-metal hit and pits cascading chords against it. Doyle screams in the background
column5: doing his best to fight through the furor. This text-painting ingenuously underlines Edge’s predicament—that is
column6: how best to fight through the noise that’s masking what used to be your vivacity. “Day Four” opens in a down-tuned tantrum. A minute into it
column7: the guitars yield and extend the sort of arid lines that might populate an Ennio Morricone score. They hang over a hi-hat beat that starts to feel like techno
column8: all up-and-down motion and hard divisions. And with foreboding noise and gasped vocals filling whatever crevice they can find
column9: “Day Five” pushes toward the claustrophobic atmospherics of Sutekh Hexen or the less guitar-focused experiments of Sunn O))). These tracks are no less foreboding than their more customary counterparts
column10: no less connected to the suffering of Edge’s perspective. They simply reveal different angles of it.

column1: Southern Lord released The First and Last Days of Unwelcome
column2: making it one of the most widely available releases of Edge’s long career. He’s worked there for several years as the art director
column3: after all
column4: designing layouts and logos for the label’s releases. But this shouldn’t be mistaken as nepotism or as a charity case of any sorts. With or without Edge’s troubles
column5: the music on Unwelcome would be plenty compelling. But his story became the prime motivation for Lumbar
column6:
the engine for three old friends coming together to finish an extraordinary entrance that unfortunately serves as an exit. 

"|18705.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18705-lumbar-the-first-and-last-days-of-unwelcome/|7.7|Grayson Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19983/homepage_large.d695e193.jpg|Fair|31822.0|Bryce Hackford|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Prah']|2013-12-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:39.994702|"

Bryce Hackford likes to stretch out. This six-track debut album from the Brooklyn-based producer may look more like an extended EP on the surface
column2: but the one-hour-17-minute runtime puts it far in excess of most standard LPs. Hackford is naturally drawn to the trancey side of house music
column3: where repeating motifs circle across vast dimensions of time. He's also interested in rock dynamics
column4: sometimes veering toward krautrock and the blissful velocity of Spacemen 3's landmark Playing with Fire. Some of the material on Fair orbits various paths taken by artists on the L.I.E.S. label
column5: especially as Hackford roots his sound in house traditions
column6: noise
column7: and choppy production values. Dusting the overall sound with a grainy texture is a wise move
column8: creating a sense of unity in an album that fractures in many directions.

column1: Something Hackford doesn't lack is ambition
column2: even if it is executed in a manner that makes his music feel purposefully small. On ""Slow Emotion"" he channels the kind of wide open spaces Panda Bear likes to cover
column3: although the general tone is closely aligned to the fuzzy haze-pop of Flying Saucer Attack. Still
column4: Fair has the same air of exploration as Person Pitch
column5: matching the way it can grind the life out of three-second loops without losing any intensity. Hackford isn’t as stylistically cohesive as Noah Lennox
column6: instead dropping low-rent club bangers with a debt to the initial IDM boom (""Another Fantasy"") then taking a wayward turn into the twilight feel of Nite Jewel's Good Evening (""Heart to Beat""). It makes sense that Hackford has played with Arp and Delia Gonzalez
column7: who have both taken a similarly zoned-out approach to electronics.

column1: The structurally sound work in the first half of Fair is let go in its back end
column2: with Hackford ending the album via two songs in excess of 20 minutes per piece. It's here that Hackford loosens his brain
column3: with the 22-minute ""Run-On Cirrus"" approaching the masterful build his former charge Gonzalez worked out with Gavin Russom on the minor DFA classic ""El Monte"". The difference here is that ""Run-On Cirrus"" digs deeper into an ambient tradition
column4: drifting into sheets of synth that resemble Vangelis channeling the Orb's U.F.Orb. He takes a step further into the calm on the following 27-minute piece ""Modern Propeller Music""
column5: almost losing all sense of self entirely in its echoing guitar figures. Here
column6: Hackford demonstrates a knack for knowing when not to play
column7: removing the compression from his work but retaining the mesmeric force from his more compact structures.

column1: Fair latches onto sounds that are emerging elsewhere at present
column2: including traces of the ultra-compact work of the the Black Dog's Bytes on Laurel Halo's excellent Chance of Rain
column3: the lingering influence of vintage sci-fi soundtracks
column4: and the loosening of borders between noise and techno. Hackford's inevitably going to be aligned with the mini boom in scruffy house
column5: but there's enough scope here to suggest he can survive when the walls come tumbling down
column6: especially as he's been at this since 2007 and has branched out to work on projects such as Rhys Chatham's A Crimson Grail. That recording
column7: as part of 200-strong guitar orchestra assembled by Chatham
column8: taps into the same kind of audacity Hackford gets caught up in as he goes deeper into Fair. There are strict limitations and open-ended thinking here
column9:
on a work that's more interested in the constant process of evolution than finding a place to comfortably land.

"|18789.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18789-bryce-hackford-fair/|7.0|Nick Neyland

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19999/homepage_large.e85ee215.jpg|Saâda Bonaire|31906.0|Saâda Bonaire|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks'
column3: one of EMI’s A&R men—notorious for going over budget on recordings—went well over schedule with singles from two of his artists. One was Tina Turner
column4: on her way to 80s multi-platinum success with “Private Dancer”
column5: which the company was willing to forgive. But the other act
column6: Saâda Bonaire
column7: which featured two model-esque non-singers Stefanie Lange and Claudia Hossfeld
column8: had their lone single released
column9: only to be immediately dropped from the label
column10: never to be heard from again.

column1: As this unexpected reissue from Captured Tracks (released under their new Fantasy Memory subsidiary) reveals though
column2: Saâda Bonaire was the concoction of Ralph “Von” Richtoven
column3: a Bremen club DJ who fancied himself a Svengali
column4: never mind that his vision for the group included upwards of 20 musicians at any one time who didn’t speak the same language—much less played the same musical scale—backing up his non-musical fiancée
column5: Stefanie Lange and her friend
column6: both women clad in Bedouin wear. For a group that had one single
column7: this reissue unearths an entire album’s worth of material
column8: produced by dubmaster Dennis Bovell in Kraftwerk’s Cologne studios. As the aforementioned names might attest
column9: it makes for a curious early 80s mutant sound.

column1: When Richtoven first conceived of the group
column2: he had a local German reggae band he managed enter a studio to cover both J.J. Cale’s “Ride Me High” and James Brown’s “It’s a Man World” (unfortunately these covers were left off this reissue). He then set about overdubbing some Kurdish folk musicians he met via a Turkish Communist community center
column3: adding his fiancée and her friend last. Trainwreck though it might scan
column4: the results were intriguing to say the least
column5: convincing EMI to let them record some more.

column1: Enter that none-hit wonder
column2: “You Could Be More As You Are”
column3: which remains a curious beast: rubbery reggae bass
column4: growling gong hits
column5: synth stabs and jerky rhythms from hand drum and drum machine
column6: featuring an assortment of whistles
column7: saxophones
column8: Turkish saz
column9: and ney flute
column10: all of it topped by the icy monotones of Lange and Hossfeld
column11: who recall their memories of a German friend who sold her body for money at a young age
column12: hit every club every night
column13: and died too soon. It was idiosyncratic in their native Germany in the age of Neu Deautsche Welle groups
column14: yet somehow became a club hit in Greece
column15: and soon after became a holy grail for Balearic DJs around the world
column16: where it fetches upwards of $170 a copy online.

column1: It’s unfortunate that the album never saw the light of day back in the early 80s
column2: as Saâda Bonaire had plenty of kindred spirits from that era. Over the percolating congas
column3: pliant basslines
column4: upstroked guitar
column5: and saz licks of “More Women”
column6: they sound a bit like Tom Tom Club. The snappy and spare “Heart Over Head” finds a middle ground between the Flying Lizards’ cover of “Money” and Soft Cell’s take on “Tainted Love”. The synth bass on “Invitation” emulates Imagination’s dancefloor smash “Just An Illusion”
column7: though it’s shot through with ney flute and a vocal delivered as if Lange and Hossfeld were instead auditioning for that notorious Calvin Klein Obsession commercial.

column1: The presence of Bovell
column2: the Barbados-born
column3: yet London-based dub producer who produced Linton Kwesi Johnson’s iconic 70s reggae albums as well as post-punk classics like the Slits’ Cut and the Pop Group’s Y
column4: helps tie together what should have been a total mess. It’s easy to hear post-punk’s DNA here and from the vantage point of 30 years
column5: one can imagine how Saâda Bonaire might have been an influence on the icy minimal wave sound
column6: the talk-sing grooves of Peaking Lights
column7: not to mention the vocals of Glass Candy’s Ida No. In another dimension
column8: maybe Saâda Bonaire’s multi-culti dancepunk tracks would have influenced someone like M.I.A.
column9: or else their gender-bending lyrics could have been behind the Knife’s Shaking the Habitual. Alas
column10:
this rescued album can only show that Saâda Bonaire could have been more than they were.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20010/homepage_large.a61ee51a.jpg|Because the Internet|30074.0|Childish Gambino|['Rock'
column3: and you can watch him tire of a medium just as he appears to get good at it. He caught the small screen bug after a stint as a writer for “30 Rock” and skated off to join the ensemble cast of NBC’s “Community” in 2009. With “Community” approaching what might be its twilight
column4: Glover jumped ship this year to become the star and showrunner of his own loosely autobiographical FX sitcom “Atlanta.” He hasn’t had much time for stand-up since 2011’s hour-long special Weirdo. In a sense
column5: his rap career
column6: hatched in 2008 after plugging his name into an online Wu-Tang rap name generator and receiving “Childish Gambino” as a result
column7: has been his most enduring project. It has also been his most troubled.

column1: Early Childish Gambino releases like 2008’s Sick Boi carried the playful “Just fucking around
column2: sorry!” vibe of a rap career started on a lark but buckled under too much squeaky voiced Lil Wayne worship. Gambino later linked up with “Community” composer Ludwig Göransson for Culdesac and EP
column3: proudly twee-as-fuck offerings that pondered Glover’s outsider upbringing over increasingly plush instrumental settings. But as the beloved “Community” awarded Glover’s musical exploits a higher profile
column4: the pridefully uncool sloganeering of songs like Culdesac’s “Different” crystallized into spite. Gambino seemed to draft Camp
column5: his nerd rage nadir of a debut studio album
column6: as a piss and vinegar shower for his doubters. It spent more time thumbing its nose at the backpackers
column7: racists
column8: and dismissive women that gouged out the massive chip on Glover’s shoulder than it did
column9: you know
column10: trying to be a good rap album. The 2012 follow-up mixtape Royalty tried to recover by calling in buddies from Black Hippy
column11: Wu-Tang Clan
column12: and more to boost Gambino’s hip-hop cred
column13: but he ended up getting creamed every step of the way by his more talented friends.

column1: This year Donald Glover got weird. He announced a new album
column2: the clunkily titled Because the Internet
column3: and launched into a promotional campaign that included a confessional series of Instagram posts about depression and fear
column4: frank talk about mortality in interviews
column5: an introductory prelude-cum-making-of-featurette titled “Clapping for the Wrong Reasons
column6: ” an installation at the new Rough Trade NYC store
column7: and
column8: finally
column9: a 76-page
column10: four-act screenplay that shares a title with the album. The star of Because the Internet is “the Boy
column11: ” the future estranged son of Rick Ross who gets his kicks trolling celebrities online and hosting mansion parties that only serve to amplify a nagging loneliness. The story tracks the Boy’s helpless
column12: irrational descent to his own undoing. Viewed through the lens of the album and screenplay
column13: Gambino’s pre-release antics may have even been part of a long con to tease the themes of the project out into the real world.

column1: If you’re fleet enough of a reader
column2: the sequential song prompts in the screenplay reveal the album to be less of a stand-alone release than the full-fledged audio component to a daring multi-platform media project whose audio and literary wings collude to complement and even explain each other. “II. Worldstar” begins as a blippy trap number and takes a hard left on a found-sound fight sequence before landing on a psychedelic chamber jazz coda all because of a club night gone wrong in the play’s first act. Unfortunately
column3: as the play begins to lurch with purpose the album resolves to allow the screenplay to do the heavy lifting. The third and final acts of the album are ill-served by the hairpin shifts in action they’re meant to soundtrack
column4: and in the process
column5: we get a series of jerky
column6: very literal advance-the-plot numbers like “The Party” and “No Exit” followed by over-long
column7: mournful fare like “I. Flight of the Navigator” and “II. Zealots of Stockholm (Free Information)”
column8: songs that are well-timed and appropriate in the context of the multi-platform project but don’t make much sense without the screenplay. It’s all very ambitious
column9: but experiencing Because the Internet as the artist intended requires an hour of fully plugged in attentive reading
column10: embedded Youtube clip viewing
column11: and listening.

column1: On its own
column2: Because the Internet’s album component breaks a number of Childish Gambino’s poor rap habits. Glover’s mic skills have radically improved since the last few outings
column3: and his delivery is quite often formidable. The bouts of Kanye
column4: Drake
column5: and Lil Wayne tribute that assailed earlier efforts are mercifully absent. He seems to have found his own voice. Royalty’s injurious guest overload is scaled back in service to showcasing Gambino’s newfound mic control
column6: so that all of the guests here are assigned hook detail. Chance the Rapper
column7: Azealia Banks
column8: Problem
column9: and Mystikal all creep into the picture alongside <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29817-lloyd/"" target=""_blank"">Lloyd
column10: Miguel and Jhené Aiko
column11: but barring the Aiko spot on “Pink Toes”
column12: Gambino takes all the verses. It’s a blessing and a curse; Gambino’s gotten rather good at the physical act of rapping
column13: but he can still be a Christmas ham with the wordplay. The album is a minefield of wacka-wacka punchlines
column14: facepalm-inducing hashtag raps and clever-until-you-really-think-about-it puns in spots
column15: hampered periodically by gunk like “In the garage/ I had a menage/ I murdered the vag
column16: ” “I got no patience
column17: cause I’m not a doctor/ Girl
column18: why are you lyin’? Girl
column19: why you Mufasa?
column20: ” “Yeah
column21: you got some silverware
column22: but really
column26: I’m a Smart Guy.” (If you’re Smart Guy Taj Mowry
column27: and Tia and Tamera are in your bed
column28: you’re not getting any action. They’re your sisters.)

column1: With Gambino’s wordplay ping-ponging from caustic wit to message board snark
column2: the enduring strength of the album is its production. Gambino and Göransson handle the bulk of it here alongside usual suspect Stefan Ponce and alley oops from twin act Christian Rich and Flying Lotus associate Thundercat. Because the Internet’s production team not only ensures the sounds are pretty
column3: spacey
column4: and jarring in all the right places
column5: but they also effortlessly nail the album’s Dark Side of the Moon/Wizard of Oz synchronicity gambit. “III. Telegraph Ave. (‘Oakland’ by Lloyd)” kicks off with a tinny fragment of a Lloyd song bellowing out of a radio station and opens up into a full blown Gambino R&B showcase. (Glover might be a better singer than a rapper now
column6: as tracks like “Telegraph Ave.” and the curt
column7: exquisite “III. Urn” regularly bear out.) Following in lock step with the screenplay
column8: you learn that it’s a Secret Life of Walter Mitty style bout of impassioned karaoke to a song that nails the protagonist’s station in life a touch too closely. It’s not only the album’s best song; Gambino’s hook writing nearly bests guys we’d previously thought him to mimic
column9: and he slides masterfully into and out of a cogent sixteen on the back end. It’s also a fulfilling payoff for bothering with the totality of Gambino’s project in the first place
column10: a gobstopping execution of a lofty idea.

column1: When the parts here come together you can catch a glimpse of Glover’s ambitious plan fully realized
column2: but these moments run scarce the further into the project you trudge. This is saying nothing of the risky outlying assumption that everyone interested in the new Childish Gambino album is also interested in (or aware of) the new Childish Gambino screenplay you’re meant read online alongside it. Because the Internet is a nobly expansive attempt at plumbing the catacombs of social media for meaning and exploring the gap between the performative avatars we present as our online selves and the offline realities of our lives
column3: but like the Twitter hounds and comment section warriors it speaks to and about
column4:
it could ultimately do well with a little less multitasking.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20009/homepage_large.4c380eb2.jpg|Remainderer EP|1445.0|The Fall|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cherry Red']|2013-12-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:41.867413|"

Even by the Fall’s notoriously prolific standards
column2: 2013 has been a busy year for whatever poor sod has to update the band’s discography on Wikipedia. The past few months have seen the release of a spirited if sloppy full-length
column3: Re-Mit; at least two live albums (the latest of which is simply called Live
column4: presumably because Mark E. Smith has run out of titles); and now
column5: that relatively rare beast in the Fall canon
column6: an EP of all new material. And despite the leftovers its title implies
column7: The Remainderer is actually being touted by the band’s label as “a bridging point” between Re-Mit and yet another new album coming in 2014.

column1: Of course
column2: it’s strange to hear any Fall release described in relation to what’s come before and what will come after. The Fall don't so much logically evolve on an album-by-album basis as randomly mutate. Even in those rare periods of line-up consistency—as Smith has enjoyed with his current charges for the past five years—the sound
column3: form
column4: and quality of any particular Fall record seems to be a matter of pure happenstance
column5: dependent on nothing so much as how many pints were swilled on the way to the studio
column6: or if all the players involved had a proper breakfast. Of course
column7: we all know that Mark E. Smith is the Fall
column8: but the Fall is not just Mark E. Smith
column9: and
column10: as ever
column11: their success is dependent on those magical moments when Smith’s free-ranging ramble serendipitously interlocks with his group’s wandering rhythms and pin-prick riffs.

column1: More than anything
column2: The Remainderer is an encouraging sign that stability has yet to ossify into stagnation with this ongoing iteration of the band
column3: who formidably exercise their elasticity over the course of these six wildly divergent tracks. But we’re eased in on familiar footing
column4: with an inviting title track that tumbles down the stairs like a cousin to “The Classical”
column5: and thus feels very much like the sort of Fall song Pavement would’ve tried to rewrite in their Gary Young days; only Smith’s recently developed affinity for frog-throated
column6: guttural grunts betrays it as a product of 2013. It’s a mode of vocaliziation that
column7: for better or worse
column8: Smith is dead-set on embracing in his golden years: “Amorator!” is less a song than a slurred
column9: spoken-word spiel set to a droning
column10: unwavering punkabilly skitter; “Touchy Pad” is a tortured
column11: tuneless duet with keyboardist/wife Elena Poulou
column12: despite its tasteful
column13: acoustic-based arrangement. And though “Rememberance ‘R’” is hardly the first Fall song that wants to be “I Wanna Be Your Dog”
column14: it actually gets more interesting once a wheezing Smith steps away from the mic
column15: and has engineer Simon “Ding” Archer let loose with a rant about some unnamed reunited rock band’s sense of entitlement.

column1: But when Smith actually takes the time to hork out whatever loogie is lodged in his esophagus
column2: he’s in top form: the car-crash medley of “Say Mama/Race With the Devil” makes for a great
column3: grease-stained companion to the Fall’s <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ef_W4uc66lM"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">better known
column4: more polished Gene Vincent cover
column5: while “Mister Rode” boasts a classic Smithian see-saw chorus—“I got a name!/ I got a face!”—over a pleasingly meandering
column6: bass-battered groove that builds into a surprisingly dramatic (by Fall standards) fuzzed-out finale. Ultimately
column7: the only thing that really connects The Remainderer to Re-Mit is a similar
column8: slightly above average hit-to-miss ratio
column9: though the abbreviated format works to its advantage. At the very least
column10:
you now know what to get for the miserable bastard on your holiday shopping list.

"|18816.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18816-the-fall-remainderer-ep/|6.9|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20000/homepage_large.105e796d.jpg|The Love Champion|31907.0|Ian Isiah|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['UNO']|2013-12-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:42.339838|"

Underground electronic music artists used to admire the futuristic finesse of modern R&B from a distance
column2: making endless bootleg edits of tracks to fit into their DJ sets. More and more
column3: though
column4: they're getting in on the game themselves. Hotly-tipped NYC label UNO and heretofore unknown singer Ian Isiah are the next entrants
column5: with a mixtape full of beats that'd turn Tricky Stewart's head and charismatic vocals drowned in AutoTune. Backed up by a host of well-loved producers like Sinjin Hawke
column6: Brenmar
column7: and ShyGuy
column8: it's hard not to see parallels with Kelela's Cut 4 Me. Isiah is another relatively new singer finding his personality in music cribbed from a thriving underground he's long been associated with (in this case
column9: loosely
column10: NYC's GHE20 G0THIK crew). Lacking Kelela's smouldering personality and her clever songwriting
column11: Isiah instead resorts to a loving pastiche of artists like The-Dream and Trey Songz—which
column12: when it works
column13: is hard to deny.

column1: The first we heard from Isiah was April's stark ballad ""Mindfuck""
column2: but that one didn't predict the brittle AutoTune-core of The Love Champion. Subtlety evidently isn't part of Isiah's vocabulary
column3: and it's difficult to gauge how self-aware he is of his own absurdity. Chanting ""pop that juicy on me"" like a mantra on ""Sweat""
column4: he sounds too earnest to be joking. Thankfully for him
column5: that earnestness ends up his saving grace—his honey-hued voice manages to elevate most of his cringe-worthy phrases. When he croons ""trippin on the x/ makin' sweet sex"" over a near-silent backdrop on ""Private Party""
column6: it's more sensual than its blunt language should be able to get across. But then not even he can save the awful ""Dynamite""
column7: a mess of a song centred around trills of ""booty
column8: booty/ you a cutie"" that feel like they were flown in from the bridge of a different track.

column1: Isiah finds a sweet spot with AutoTune on Love Champion that's gently experimental without descending into Lil Wayne-esque blubbery
column2: though it could still get on your nerves if you're not one for its inhuman tones. The way he cascades and layers his vocals on tracks like ""Showtime"" or the stunning ballad ""So High"" is surprisingly bewitching
column3: like an art in itself. Not to mention that he's a capable singer on his own
column4: mining an entirely different vibe than Future's warbly emo-rap—but like that rapper and his hordes of imitators
column5: the plugin also gives those ballads an alien
column6: almost otherworldly tin. His battle cry ""I just wanna be high with you"" sounds almost transcendent here.

column1: As much as Isiah relies on his trusty studio helper
column2: however
column3: The Love Champion leans even harder on his cast of producer friends
column4: who offer up a gently progressive selection of beats that sway and dip perfectly with his voice. Sometimes it's hard to tell to who's supposed to be the star—more often than not he's given a prime amount of space for his elaborate countermelodies
column5: but a slinky Sinjin Hawke percussion drop or Brenmar break is never that far behind. UNO's secret weapon Gobby even shows up on the gorgeously gossamer title track
column6: one of the relentlessly weird producer's prettiest productions.

Patricidal Lust
column2: the second full-length from Vastum
column3: is a record about sex
column4: but the Bay Area death metal group don't discuss it in the way most metal bands that broach the topic do. For instance
column5: the album didn't spring from the mind of Blackie Lawless before he bound himself to the law of God
column6: speaking of himself as a carnivorous animal conquering his scantily clad prey. Nor does it resemble the drugged-out rape fantasies and over-the-top depictions of Cemetery Rapist and legions of other “pornogrind” bands
column7: who take the lack of subtlety in metal and beat it into absolute zero. And Lust is certainly not among the many revenge stories that a great deal attempted
column8: but only Type O Negative's Peter Steele had any skill in visualizing (“freelance gynocology” from “Unsuccessfully Coping with the Natural Beauty of Infidelity” is still one of the funniest phrases of all time).

column1: Instead
column2: Daniel Butler
column3: Vastum's vocalist and lyricist
column4: takes a grisly look at erotic tension at its most extreme. The results are more squeamish than Cannibal Corpse's “Fucked With a Knife”. In “3 AM in Agony”
column5: he speaks from the point of view of a sexual assault victim
column6: whose “object of my affection
column7: the source of my agony” is sleeping nearby. The perpetrator is “unaware that his friction creates the sensation of a thousand interstitial blades down my center.” Just reading those lines is unsettling; Butler's oration makes it feel almost too real. The title track shows Butler entering the darkest corners of his imagination
column8: opening with “Spill your seed into my father's tears/ his suffering all over my body” and then laying into said father's guts for discomforting warmth. By making even the most disgustingly surreal seam somewhat plausible
column9: Vastum's lyrical content goes beyond most bands of their ilk.

column1: Lust's overall lyrical outlook could be summed up in the last lines of “Incel”: “Mere echos of delight/ A distant mockery of joy/ unconsummated acts consume body and mind/ A prison of what could but never will be/ Hopeless ugly destructive self.” A subject normally discussed with glee and passion
column2: turned into a never-ending labyrinth of loss and uncertainty. These themes are galvanized by Paolo Girardi's artwork. Girardi
column3: who's having a banner year (Lycus' Tempest being his crowning achievement)
column4: is the ideal visual counterpart—he's a classically influenced Francis Bacon
column5: blurring the line between fine art and heat-stroked
column6: pill-popped hallucination.

column1: Vastum is often spoken in relation to their sister band
column2: Acephalix
column3: primarily because the groups share Butler
column4: bassist Luca Indrio
column5: and until recently
column6: guitarist Kyle House (Adam Perry
column7: who drummed on Lust
column8: also left the group before the album's release). Carnal Law
column9: Vastum's debut
column10: was often described as a “slower Acephalix” and while that's true to some extent
column11: on Lust the band make strides to carve an identity for themselves. Swedish influences are evident
column12: but while Acephalix were often dubiously lumped in with “Entombedcore
column13: ” Vastum take more from Grave and Dismember's less breakneck aspects.

column1: Guitarist Leila Abdul-Rauf
column2: who also plays in the Bay Area groups Hammers of Misfortune and Amber Asylum
column3: is more apt to let a solo ride than hurry to the next verse
column4: and <span style=""font-style: normal;"">Vastum's rushes come more from stretching riffs out
column5: as evident on the thunderous opening to “Repulsive Arousal”. (Combined with a buried tremolo riff and chanting
column6: that track resembles diSEMBLOWELMENT at their finest.) While Butler has long shed the punk from his approach
column7: his voice isn't touched with reverb the way it is with Acephalix. Vastum's style works in the tandem with the lyrical content. There's more space for reflection
column8: or disgust
column9: or
column10: as the band would probably want it
column11: both. “Agony” deals with the most immediately physical lyrics
column12: and as such
column13: it's the fastest track on the record.

column1: Lust was one of the last albums that Bay Area metal and punk stawart Jeff “Jef Leppard” Davis worked on before his death last year following a motorcycle accident. Greg Wilkinson took over production following Davis' death
column2: and he honors Davis' style by creating an old-school metal atmosphere with modern volume. Lust
column3: in addition to being one of the most interesting metal releases of 2013
column4:
serves as a artistically fulfilling coda for Davis' handiwork.

The first thing beckoning you towards Blue Rider is its atmosphere—spacious
column2: cool
column3: distant. Zachary Cale's mesmerizing finger-picking
column4: drawing on open-string drone and country blues tunings
column5: wanders restlessly around a clean
column6: well-lit place of a mix
column7: synths humming like 3am refrigerators and chiming guitars confusing your sense of middle distance. It is a misty
column8: gorgeous record
column9: a space that feels wonderful to roam around in.

column1: The second is the delicacy and exquisite loneliness of Cale's guitar playing. He has said in interviews that he'd rather not be aligned with folk music—""To me
column2: folk music is something sacred
column3: something that people today don’t have any business singing
column4: he told the blog Underneath This in March—but the virtues of his playing are folk virtues
column5: especially the ability to serve as his own rhythm section. Every one of Blue Rider's songs  appears to feature at least three guitarists simultaneously; it's all Cale
column6: working live. You are forcefully reminded
column7: listening the counter-layers of something like ""Hold Fast"" or ""Wayward Son""
column8: that acoustic solo music is only as simple as you make it.

column1: At the center of the crystalline tangle sits Cale
column2: a singer-songwriter who's been hiding in plain sight for awhile—Blue Rider is his fourth album. He's less quizzically arch than Destroyer
column3: less cryptically moody than Cass McCombs. But there is a similar inscrutable poetry in his music
column4: and the impassive Blue Rider is his most beguiling collection. He has some of Bejar's vocal timbre and some of McCombs's tilted-dog's-head relationship to language: The way that McCombs asked
column5: teasingly
column6: ""What does it mean to be a man?"" repeatedly on ""Big Wheel"" is the way that Cale sings lines like ""Lover
column7: for you my heart beats strong."" He speaks them haltingly
column8: as if he is testing the words in his mouth as much as he is puzzling over their meanings.

column1: Cale sings these lines through a half-closed mouth
column2: his consonants blurring into the soft curves of the sound
column3: which means that a wry line like ""Well
column4: the past is still the past
column5: he can visit anytime/ Nothing's really changed except a few road signs"" (""Hold Fast"") might initially slide past you unnoticed. But Cale's imagery flashes sharp and dreamlike across his songs once you tune to it—""Shadows walk across a jagged sky
column6: he sings on ""Hangman's Letters""
column7: a dark
column8: alarming image. On ""Noise Of Welcome""
column9: he muses ""What does it mean to die in my dreams?"" It's a question with a day-tripper's ring to it
column10: but Cale has built the perfect environment for languorous thoughts like this. Blue Rider is short—eight songs
column11: 35 minutes—but it slows everything down around it while's playing
column12:
coaxing half-formed feelings out of their corners and giving them space to exist.

“This song is about dope.”
[“Yeahhhhh
column2: ” an audience member interjects.]

column1: “It’s about what happens when you start getting high
column2: and you find out that people you thought you knew
column3: you don’t know anymore
column4: because they don’t get high and you do.”

column1: That banter
column2: dripping with irony and accompanied by shrieking scrapes of a piano’s strings
column3: forebodingly introduces the finale of the latest Neil Young archival release
column4: Live at the Cellar Door. “Flying on the Ground is Wrong”
column5: one of Young’s earliest songs
column6: is a typically 60s piece of pharmacological us vs. them
column7: a bittersweet song about how the squares just don’t understand the new mind-expanding potential of drugs. But even if the audience didn’t quite pick up on it on this December night
column8: it’s not exactly a celebration anymore for Young by 1970.

column1: The first line of “The Needle and the Damage Done”
column2: which would start appearing in setlists the next month
column3: is “I caught you knocking at my cellar door.” If the song is in fact referencing the famous
column4: tiny D.C. club
column5: it’s most likely not about these 1970 shows
column6: but rather the 1969 run with Crazy Horse and the worsening heroin addiction of guitarist Danny Whitten. But amidst an accumulation of dark
column7: druggy vibes
column8: this solo acoustic set catches Young in a bleak
column9: hollow mood
column10: rudely awoken from the hippie dream his audience still wants to believe.

column1: If this all sounds familiar
column2: it’s because only seven weeks separated the Cellar Door shows and another Archives release: the superb January 1971 set at Toronto’s Massey Hall Young freed from his vaults six years prior. A full seven of the 13 songs on Live at the Cellar Door also appear on the Massey Hall release
column3: but these two shows still exist on opposing sides of a notable chapter break in Young’s career and life. While Massey Hall looked forward to his commercial peak of Harvest
column4: showcasing then-unheard songs such as “Heart of Gold” in their infancy
column5: Live at the Cellar Door is mostly looking back to his previous two albums
column6: After the Gold Rush and Everybody Knows This is Nowhere
column7: and his late work with Buffalo Springfield.

column1: Between the two shows
column2: Young threw out his back on his ranch
column3: picked up a painkiller habit
column4: and started his turbulent relationship with actress Carrie Snodgrass (as chronicled in “A Man Needs a Maid” on Harvest). So the Massey and Cellar Door releases offer a sort of before-and-after experiment around this busy holiday break
column5: even if the Live Archives chronology is getting so crowded in this era that this latest release had to be jimmied in as Volume 2.5.

column1: But Live at the Cellar Door stands alone as an unexpected glimpse of Neil Young
column2: piano man. Between songs
column3: Young makes a long speech in praise of the venue’s “nine-foot Steinway
column4: ” an instrument that provides as much of the accompaniment here as guitar. “I’ve been playing piano for about...almost a year
column5: ” he says
column6: and whether that’s a joke or not
column7: his rudimentary keyboard approach mirrors the crude immediacy of his electric guitar work more than his subtle acoustic touch.

column1: On the Buffalo Springfield track “Expecting to Fly”—an elegy to the 60s written before the decade was even finished—Young punctuates the chorus with loud discordant pounds that trail off into the silent club’s darkness. The other piano reinvention
column2: surprisingly
column3: is “Cinnamon Girl”
column4: which even Neil obsessives probably have never heard in this arrangement. “That’s the first time I ever did that one on the piano
column5: ” Neil says—and possibly the last time as well.

column1: Paired with the equally gloomy Massey Hall
column2: these sibling live sets show Young peeking over the edge of the 60s into the dark chasm of the next decade. It’s frustrating that the Archives series continues to pace along this precipice instead of taking the plunge into the next rich stretch of Young’s career: More material from the Harvest tour that begat the tormented Time Fades Away? The haunted/stoned Bottom Line show from 74? The short-lived Ducks? But even if it holds the most value for the Neil obsessives interested in the small differences
column3:
Live at Cellar Door provides another glimpse at a darkly formative time in his long career.

column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Graveface']|2013-12-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:45.485006|"

Cover albums should at this point come with low expectations. You think of things like filling contracts
column3: overcoming writers block
column4: maybe doing a favor for an old friend. And Sometimes you get a couple of decent songs out of it. But hearing that Xiu Xiu would be covering songs identified with Nina Simone on a new release
column5: it was hard not get excited. There’s an obvious spiritual connection between the artists
column6: a sense of fearlessness and deep belief in the transformative power of expressing raw emotion. Looking at the titles
column7: I could close my eyes and almost hear how some of these songs would play out. Sure
column8: it would be a challenge. Nina Simone is giant
column9: an artist of great complexity whose music is hard to grapple with and harder still to summarize
column10: so there would be the question of which Nina Simone to cover: the jazz belter
column11: the ethereal balladeer
column12: the bold activist
column13: the shattered lover
column14: the gifted interpreter of the American songbook. But you could imagine Jamie Stewart finding a way to channel his frayed edges and matchless intensity into something powerful that would highlight something about Simone’s many-faceted approach.

column1: Alas
column2: it was not to be. Nina is a low-key release that is not ""the new Xiu Xiu album"" but it’s still hard not to be disappointed at this wasted opportunity. If it were too abrasive or too faithful
column3: that would be one thing
column4: but Nina is guilty of an even deeper sin: These interpretations shed no light on Simone’s artistry and add nothing to the force of these songs. The strangest thing of all is that the failure is due almost entirely to Stewart’s vocal conception. He doesn’t have the widest range as a singer
column5: but he has found ways to circumvent his limitations and find modes of expression to suit his songs. And he also has a deep bag of effects—shrieks
column6: cries
column7: howls
column8: and even an engaging croon that hints at blackest goth and the androgyny of new pop. But for whatever reason he chose to sing these 11 songs almost entirely with a pinched
column9: trembling whisper that makes melody irrelevant while not offering any compensatory emotional gestures. It’s a deeply theatrical register
column10: sounding put-on and ""artificial"" in a way that has to be intentional
column11: but it never signifies. You keep waiting for the songs to lurch in an unexpected direction but they never do; Nina is a low simmer that never comes close to approaching a boil.

column1: There are a few things to recommend here. One
column2: Stewart’s song selection is pretty good
column3: even if he never finds a way to do much with them.""Wild Is the Wind"" and ""The Other Woman"" are brilliant tunes that Simone owned
column4: and her versions of ""Don’t Explain"" and ""Pirate Jenny"" are essential versions of frequently covered classics. So just hearing the songs he chose—most of which
column5: incidentally
column6: Simone did not write—and trying to hear how he connects them to her interpretations and tweaks lyrics here and there to personalize them holds some parlor game interest. And the arrangements by drummer Ches Smith are distinctive and varied
column7: moving between music-box twinkle
column8: Tom Waits-style junkyard jazz
column9: and harsh atonal bleats. There's an interesting sound here
column10:
a shell of an idea. But there is ultimately very little melody or personality for the arrangements to support and the record winds up sounding weirdly conservative.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19967/homepage_large.56c3ff55.jpg|School Daze|31867.0|Patrick Cowley|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dark Entries']|2013-12-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:49:46.017500|"

Few musical legacies are as haunted by the spectre of sex—its pleasures and its consequences—as that of disco producer Patrick Cowley. It begins with the sound itself: the shimmering
column2: orgasmic post-Moroder synth patterns of Cowley’s early 80s dancefloor anthems like “X-Factor” and “Get A Little”
column3: and of course the tantric splendour of his 1982 remix of Donna Summer’s “I Feel Love”. Sex also is the music’s thematic preoccupation
column4: to the point of fixation
column5: reflecting the deep interpenetration of disco and gay bathhouses in late 1970s San Francisco
column6: Cowley’s transplanted home: “Menergy” celebrates “the boys in the bedroom/ lovin’ it up/ shootin’ off energy.” In 1982
column7: Cowley was one of the first public figures to pass away from complications associated with AIDS (before it was even known by that name)
column8: a tragic denouement partly captured in the disoriented and shadowed electro-disco of his final album
column9: Mind Warp. It’s fitting
column10: then
column11: that the first concrete attempt to canonise Cowley as an electronic music auteur and innovator comes in the form of a compilation of soundtrack work for gay pornographic films. School Daze collects
column12: for the first time on CD
column13: instrumental work dating from 1973 to 1981
column14: given by Cowley to gay porn production company Fox Studio
column15: the majority finding their way into the films School Daze and Muscle Up.

column1: The standard line on Cowley is that he is a post-Moroder producer
column2: bridging the gap between 1970s euro-disco and 1980s Hi-NRG. It’s a neat story
column3: but there have always been loose ends that it cannot make sense of
column4: like Cowley’s astonishing production work for Sylvester’s 1979 track “I Need Somebody To Love Tonight”
column5: a visionary collision of burbling synthesisers and lilting dub (available footage of the film School Daze features a mind-altering
column6: woozy instrumental remix not included here). Further complications were offered by the reissue of Cowley’s late 1970s work with Jorge Socarros as Catholic
column7: all jerky synthetic new wave whose fusion of Roxy Music and Kraftwerk anticipates the early work of Simple Minds. School Daze completes the picture by tying together all these threads and taking them somewhere else again
column8: suggesting that Moroder was not the origin for Cowley
column9: but the streamlined destination. The “1973-1981” timeframe is as bewildering as was the “85-92” in the title of Aphex Twin’s first Selected Ambient Works: even if this music all had originated from the early 80s
column10: it would for the most part sound amazingly ahead of its time.

column1: There’s a handful of tracks in modes you might expect—“Zygote” is adrenalized cosmic disco
column2: while the title track offers corpulent funk-rock—but School Daze mostly consists of expansive
column3: meditative soundscapes whose ambiguous titles (“Nightcrawler”
column4: “Out of Body”
column5: “Tides of Man”) capture their simultaneous evocation of the intimate and the intergalactic
column6: the immediacy of bodily sensation and the depths of deep space. A few deserve special mention. The 16-minute “Seven Sacred Pools” is luxuriantly expansive ambient dub that could fit onto Orb’s Adventures Beyond the Ultraworld
column7: its heart-murmur bass and multi-tiered synth melodies embracing and decoupling in an eerie underwater consummation. The forbidding “Journey Home” is scraping metallic techno in slow motion
column8: weaving together machinic sound effects with a recurrent didgeridoo bassline with exacting precision. The chiming
column9: swirling “Primordial Landscape” starts off shadowy and restless
column10: fusing Caribbean bounce with funereal dirge
column11: before ascending to the ceiling with iridescent chime loops that prefigure Manuel Göttsching’s proto-techno masterpiece E2-E4. But whereas the electronic music which Cowley flashes forward to is mostly preternaturally bright and sharp
column12: the arrangements here feel flushed and hazy
column13: shadowed by the torpor of dope and the blood-rush delirium of amyl nitrate.

column1: It’s not necessary to frame School Daze by the use to which these compositions originally were put
column2: but it helps. In The Rise and Fall of Gay Culture
column3: Daniel Harris writes that gay pornographers of the 1970s “believed they were filming two people
column4: not in the act of fucking
column5: but of merging
column6: of coalescing
column7: a process that involved the dissolution of their separate physical identities as they melted together
column8: losing their definition as individuals.” Cowley’s music here captures exactly that vibe
column9: its slow tempos
column10: meandering arrangements
column11: and persistent sense of disorientation and self-alienation evokes the world of San Francisco bathhouses rather than dancefloors. To listen is to step down those same long
column12:
dark tunnels: physical spaces of random encounters and depersonalised unions; psychological spaces of intoxication and longing.

Ron Morelli has spent the last three years building the L.I.E.S. label into a paragon of noisy
column2: Made-in-the-U.S.A. club music. It's a role that
column3: between managing a prolific release schedule and selecting producers out of what amounts to a little black book of underground dance misfits
column4: requires a bit more creative agency than your average label head. Spit
column5: Morelli's first music under his own name
column6: appears hell-bent on separating the man from the hailstorm of narrative and praise surrounding his label. It arrives via Hospital Productions
column7: 36 minutes of ill-at-ease industrial simmer whose length
column8: construction
column9: and tenor defy the type of romantic
column10: back-to-basic engagement that L.I.E.S. inspires.

column1: There is nothing nice about Spit. The album title was inspired by a neighborhood Morelli lived in
column2: one in which hookers would ""smoke cigarettes
column3: read the paper
column4: talk on their cell phones
column5: and spit. They would spit...a lot."" So not just spit
column6: but ""hooker spit
column7: which should give you a window into the tension
column8: claustrophobia
column9: and foulness that infect Morelli's music. Spit is dark
column10: more so than the glut of industrial-leaning techno and eerie machine music Morelli has dug up for L.I.E.S. Those works often had expanse on their side: they're long
column11: winding tracks that
column12: however noisy
column13: could engender mystery or psychedelic escape. Spit
column14: in comparison
column15: trudges through its eight tracks: fed up
column16: exhausted
column17: grim. When asked why he didn't release his album on his own label
column18: he responded tersely: ""Dom[inick Fernow
column19: head of Hospital Productions] simply proposed I make a record for him. If he did not ask
column20: then I would not have done it."" Ok
column21: then.

column1: This sense of duty and drudgery comes to life on scraping
column2: hissy tracks such as ""Sledgehammer II"" and ""Slow Down"". Ugly
column3: metal-on-metal machine music
column4: Spit is rhythmic in nature
column5: but not as dance-oriented as much of the L.I.E.S. output. I don't think the tired
column6: delayed claps and barely-there acid bassline of ""Modern Paranoia"" want to make anyone dance; they're exhausted
column7: it was a long day
column8: they need a beer and a shot. They're very much at home with the noir-ish menace of Hospital Productions-affiliated acts like Vatican Shadow and Silent Servant.

column1: If you squint hard enough you can find some playfulness in Spit
column2: in the way pitched toms hop around in the background of ""Crack Microbes"" or in ""Director Of…""'s garbled
column3: beatless trip. The album's centerpiece
column4: in placement if not tone
column5: is ""Fake Rush""
column6: a nervy
column7: light-on-its-feet stew of rhythmic oscillations. Were it not for its bit-reduced crunch and battery-acid exterior
column8: ""Fake Rush"" could've come from one of London's many young bass manglers
column9: especially as it clocks a heart-racing 140 bpm when it's not wandering around drunkenly in half-time.

column1: It's hard to truly love an album that seems a constant threat to shiv you
column2: though
column3: and while Spit's economy prevents it from careening into pure aggression
column4: it remains irritated throughout. This feels by design
column5: and it's easy to read Spit as a reaction to all of the love poured on L.I.E.S. of late. More likely
column6: Spit represents another of Morelli's inspirations
column7: after several collaborative projects. (On the process of making the album
column8: he offers
column9: ""[Y]ou’re working in a tried and true format and throwing your own shitty take on what has been done by the masters years ago."") There's enough on offer that its tone can be forgiven
column10: perhaps
column11: but there are going to be plenty of nights when Spit just wants to be left alone
column12:
and you'll be inclined to grant it as much.

The second LP from geographically split duo Ævangelist marks the highlight of a busy two years. It all began with a 2011 EP
column2: spilled into a well-received 2012 debut
column3: and saw the emergence of two shorter releases earlier this year before culminating in the unique horror that is Omen Ex Simulacra. Not a bad track record for a pair forced to surmount the distance between Oregon and Illinois in order to achieve their thoroughly apocalyptic vision
column4: especially given the unassailable quality of their burgeoning discography. Their second album continues in the same vein as its more organic-minded predecessor
column5: but sees the band retreat even deeper into madness. Multi-instrumentalist and noisemonger Matron Thorn (Benighted in Sodom
column6: Bethlehem) and vocalist Ascaris (Shavasana
column7: ex-Velnias) have ramped up the intensity to an almost uncomfortable level.

column1: At first blush
column2: Ævangelist seem fairly straight forward; fundamentally a black/death metal band
column3: crossing the former’s atmospheric shudder with the latter’s blunt-force approach. If only it were that simple; black/death bands are par for the extreme metal course
column4: but a band like this one only rears its ugly head once in a long while. Anaal Nathrakh’s ""Total Fucking Necro/Codex Necro era

column8: Ævangelist walk alone. From opener “Veils” muffled
column9: threatening first moments of factory noise
column10: disembodied screams
column11: and clattering electronic drumbeats until the lurching dread of “Abysscape”

column13: fear
column14: and naked aggression.

column1: The electronic and industrial elements are even more pronounced this time around

column3: largely homogenous save for unexpected horrors like the violent scrapings of violin on “Seclusion” that render once-beautiful strings into wailing captives. The inhuman percussion is never far out of earshot

column1: The most organic aspect of the recording
column2: the vocalist
column3: lay buried
column4: corpselike
column5: beneath the surface. These vocals are impressive and commanding. Ascaris snarls and gags like a rabid animal
column6: varying his range from subterranean guttural roars to grotesque howls. His voice
column7: as demonic and burdened by effects as it may be
column8: is the closest thing to humanity that Ævangelist are willing to offer. They eschew the occult ephemera of so many others in favor of the much more frightening gods of emptiness

column10: and despair. The hell they inhabit was created by an uncaring and blood-drunk shadow
column11: but their end-time visions are not biblical; they prophesize that most wretched of ends

column1: For all its intensity

R. Kelly never really went away
column2: but in 2013 he has crept back into pop culture nonetheless. He spent the summer headlining large summer festivals
column3: basking in the glow of fans singing his discography back to him. He managed to—if even for a moment—usurp Daft Punk at Coachella during the encore of Phoenix’s closing set
column4: belting out the opening notes of “Bump N’ Grind” to a dead silent crowd waiting for a curtain to drop and reveal a giant pyramid. He would then appear on the remix of the Frenchies’ “Trying To Be Cool” and later on tracks by Justin Bieber (“PYD”) and Lady Gaga. The latter collaboration—the deliciously slinky “Do What U Want”—was a runaway hit that led to appearances on SNL and the American Music Awards
column5: both of which were easily Kelly’s most high-profile television looks in half a decade.

column1: It has been a fun year for the 46-year-old
column2: an unexpected and smooth resurgence at a time when it looked like he was content to rest in the soft embrace of R&B radio and sold out 5
column3: 000 capacity theaters. The nightcap is his 13th solo album Black Panties
column4: which tosses aside the classic soul of his previous two albums (2010’s Love Letter and last year’s Write Me Back) for a deep dive into the sounds of contemporary bumping and grinding. For much of the past 10 years
column5: Kelly’s career has been defined by trying to balance his traditionalist roots with a desire to continually update his sound. He has more or less been able to maintain that balance
column6: like on TP3 Reloaded or Double Up
column7: two albums that feature a number of regrettable collaborations (The Game? Kid Rock??) but also a handful of his most indelible tracks. But we also saw the singer reek of desperation on 2009’s Untitled
column8: a drab and misguided album slathered in AutoTune that is inarguably the low point of his career.

column1: Black Panties establishes a third position. There is no “I’m a Flirt (Remix)” or “Same Girl” or “Trapped in the Closet” here
column2: standout singles that rejigger his entire career. There are also few if any profoundly novel album cuts—be it anything as truly outlandish as “The Zoo” or effortlessly tuneful as “Kickin’ It With Your Girlfriend” or “Freaky in the Club”—that quietly register as some of his best work. Instead
column3: Black Panties is thematically coherent and consistently listenable
column4: not unlike Love Letter in that sense
column5: though of course different in just about every other.

column1: The album is almost exclusively about pussy—which
column2: duh
column3: R. Kelly. No one has sung as prolifically about pussy as the man whose debut album sports a nearly seven minute long song called “I Like the Crotch On You""
column4: and perhaps no one will in our lifetimes. On the one hand
column5: Kells reinforces his identity here: for him
column6: comparing pussy to a cookie (on
column7: well
column8: “Cookie”) is not a one-bar metaphor. It is instead an entire song in which he sings about “lick[ing] the middle like an Oreo.” This is the power of R. Kelly: it will be impossible to eat an Oreo for a while without thinking of cunnilingus. He has fundamentally altered your existence.

column1: There is also something undeniably great about a song like “Marry the Pussy
column2: ” in which Kelly gives the song’s subject an entire persona: “Pussy talk to me/Pussy sing to me/ Yeah
column3: so much joy it bring to me.” With a song like this
column4: Kelly allows himself to be more human than the rest of us. It is not ridiculous that he wants to marry a pussy—that level of carnality exists somewhere in all of us
column5: male or female. His brilliance is in routinely bringing out into the open the things that—with good reason!—stay in the darkest corners of our minds. In disrupting the social order
column6: maybe his music helps preserve it as well.

column1: But
column2: in the context of his own discography at least
column3: Black Panties isn’t as gleefully absurd as we’ve come to expect from him. It’s not exactly that every R. Kelly song needs to construct an entire fable (TP3’s “Sex Weed” is a good example of him losing the plot)
column4: but that at its best his dirtiest tracks have the frission of the legitimately unexpected—each song has the potential to be its own developed story
column5: or to shock the public anew. With Black Panties
column6: what you see is mostly what you get.

column1: What we get is a pretty good modern R&B album
column2: but it’s also one that feels just a bit fossilized. With its undulating synths
column3: abundance of screwed vocals and slowly churning tempos
column4: Black Panties sounds suspiciously like the-Dream’s first two albums. Tracks like “Throw This Money On You” (which is still pretty great) and “Genius” (which is not) sound ripped almost wholesale from the album in which the-Dream wrote a song called “Kelly’s 12 Play""
column5: where he obsessively details fucking to Kelly’s debut album. At times
column6: listening to Black Panties can be like watching the snake eat its own tail. There are also a number of tracks in which Kelly collaborates with current stars like Migos (“Show Ya Pussy”) or DJ Mustard (“Spend That”)
column7: and though none come off anywhere nearly as poorly as his song with OJ Da Juiceman
column8: there is also an instant loss of individuality that renders them a bit useless.

column1: Black Panties concludes with “Shut Up
column2: ” in which he condemns critics
column3: haters and ex-friends who declared his career dead. Considering his numerous past transgressions with minors
column4: the song (which is actually about his vocal surgery) is rather tone-deaf
column5: though that is not exactly a new development either. But it does end the album on a defiant note that is as jarring as it is energizing. The Pied Piper of R&B finds himself head over heels in love with pussy
column6: yet he refuses to settle down. Or maybe
column7:
that is precisely why he won't.
