“When the preacher and the congregation reach their peaks
column2: ” says Amiri Baraka
column3: writing about traditional gospel music in his canonical 1963 book Blues People: Negro Music in White America
column4: “their music rivals any of the more formal Afro-American musics in intensity and beauty.” The “more formal musics” of which Baraka speaks are blues
column5: jazz
column6: and R&B
column7: three styles that sprang partly from gospel in post-Emancipation America. But when Blues People was published
column8: those secular styles—and in particular R&B—were reaching a tipping point. Former gospel artists like Sam Cooke and Aretha Franklin had opened the floodgates for spiritual singers to cross over into the pop market
column9: an exodus that decimated the ranks of the gospel industry. That gospel had become an industry in the first place owed much to various DJs
column10: promoters
column11: and labels like Nashville’s Nashboro Records.

column1: If the new four-disc anthology I Heard the Angels Singing: Electrifying Black Gospel from the Nashboro Label
column2: 1951-1983 proves anything
column3: it’s Baraka’s claim that gospel could hold its own against its rivals in terms of intensity and beauty—especially when Nashboro was reaching its own peak. The label was launched in 1951 by jukebox vendor and vinyl retailer Ernest L. Young
column4: who piggybacked on Nashville’s thriving gospel scene (the Grand Ole Oprey’s legendary first home
column5: the Ryman Auditorium
column6: first served as the stomping ground for many of Nashboro’s gospel hitmakers). Three of Nashboro’s first singles—the Silvertone Jubilee Singers’ “Since Jesus Came into My Heart""
column7: The Skylarks’ “There Must Be a City"" and the Cross-Road Singers’ “Sing till the Power of the Lord Comes Down
column8: ” all from 1951—already show a range
column9: from skeletal
column10: guitar-and-harmony testimonials to get-happy boogie to striding proto-doo-wop.

column1: Nashboro hit its stride
column2: though
column3: in the late 50s
column4: when rock ’n’ roll augured a new era in the adaptation and acceptance of so-called race music. Branching out quickly to sign acts from all corners of the U.S.
column5: the label grew to prominence by sidestepping the limitation of being a strictly regional label—before Motown and Stax proved just how internationally profitable a regional identity could be—and by proactively poaching artists from other gospel labels. Gospel became a business
column6: and Nashboro navigated these deeper waters without diluting their output. One of the label’s cornerstone groups
column7: Philadelphia’s the Angelic Gospel Singers
column8: are represented
column9: albeit sparsely
column10: by the 1958 organ-drenched hymn “I’m Getting Nearer
column11: Pt. 1”; meanwhile another of Nashboro’s top outfits
column12: Miami’s the Consolers
column13: weigh in with their 1957 rendition of “This May Be The Last Time""
column14: an infinitely more bouncy and upbeat take on fatalistic resignation than the Staple Singers’ atmospheric
column15: Rolling Stones-approved version.

column1: The rise of R&B-infused rock ’n’ roll—not to mention R&B itself—in the early 60s resulted in a feedback loop with gospel. By the end of the 60s
column2: though
column3: that loop had become a one-way street; gospel now struggled to catch up and remain relevant in the face of a predominantly churchless youth culture. But rather than sounding like compromise
column4: Nashboro’s output from the 60s split the difference between gospel and soul. Foregoing the word of God altogether
column5: Jonathan Greer’s 1968 instrumental “Gospel Train” relied instead on an exultant
column6: predictably locomotive chug that bristles with fervid devotion. As Nashboro settled into its old age in the late ’70s and early ’80s
column7: tracks like 1973’s “Jesus is My Keeper” by the Morning Stars of Savannah circled the wagons
column8: drawing strongly from the Impressions’ decade-old
column9: gospel-fueled hit
column10: “People Get Ready.” By the time 1977’s “It’s Time to Serve the Lord” showed the Bright Stars to be a lightly funky
column11: would-be alternative to a wave of secular R&B that proffered the discotheque as church
column12: Nashboro’s gospel had begun to smell of mothballs—but that doesn’t detract from the stately grace of Willie Neal Johnson and the Gospel Keynotes’ “Bless Me
column13: ” the 1983 song that closes I Heard the Angels on an uncharacteristically lush
column14: sumptuous note—a silky
column15: soulful
column16: orchestrated ballad that predicts the gospel-pop crossover that Isley-Jasper-Isley would enjoy two year later with “Caravan of Love"". Nashboro wouldn’t survive to witness that major-label coup
column17: but it couldn’t have happened without the groundwork Nashboro laid.

column1: Not that Nashboro itself didn’t shelter its share of future stars. The Jewel Trio—whose 1958 single “Too Late"" is included here
column2: transferred from 45 with a hair-raising aura of chanted pleas and crackly groove-dust—features a young Canzetta Staton
column3: yet to find fame on her own as Candi Staton. And Lou Rawls pops up on no less than three tracks by his group the Chosen Gospel Singers: “Trouble of This World’s Condition” from 1956
column4: “Lord Shine on Me” from 1958
column5: and “Let Your Life Speak Out” from 1962. All showcase Rawls’ tender growl
column6: but it’s the last of the three that employs propulsive percussion and lunging passion in a way that makes Rawls’ defection to the secular world all but preordained—as is I Heard the Angels’ success as a single
column7: searing
column8: dynamic sermon
column9:
preached at whatever congregation will have it.

So you own a guitar and live in the greater Bay Area. Great
column2: ok
column3: let's get you started. Basically
column4: here are your two options: You can plug that into something (keep it cheap) and warble angrily. Or
column5: you can go acoustic and warble gently. Some people around here
column6: like David Novick

column8: he plays abraded
column9: candy-colored garage rock. But last October
column10: he slipped 100 copies of this little self-titled record into the world
column11: under an imprint called Sun Sneeze. It was a small psych-folk Valentine
column12: an ant's cough in the vast universe; recorded on four and eight-track
column13: it was so muffled it barely seemed to exist. But it radiated a strange
column14: beatific energy
column15: the kind that is supposed to be native to this little patch of lysergic territory Novick's tilling

column17: clearing his throat somewhat
column18: is reissuing it

column1: In any case

column3: done while he was still negotiating how the phases matched up with the changes. Nope; that's it.

column1: This home recording technique usually tricks us into hearing amateurism—it's an aesthetic

column4: emerging from beneath the sonic horse blanket
column5: is inventive
column6: fluid
column7: and often beautiful. The instrumental ""Silver"" builds in layers

column12: you can hear his fingers thinking.

column1: David Novick runs seven songs and less than a half hour
column2: a quickly dissipating smoke ring that you are just getting a whiff of by the time it passes. Novick seems like a devotee of the late-60s British folk underground

but it commands you to lean forward to catch more.

Lately it’s not difficult to find a record with Robert Beatty’s name on it. His art's adorned the cover of scores of albums in the past few years
column2: from the underground electronics of the Spectrum Spools label to bigger indie releases by Oneohtrix Point Never and Peaking Lights. His solo project Three Legged Race put out an excellent debut full-length called Persuasive Barrier earlier this year
column3: followed by another strong effort from his long-term noise trio Hair Police. But until now nothing featuring Beatty’s own music has been released under his given name.

column1: It’s interesting
column2: then
column3: that he chose Soundtracks for Takeshi Murata to be the first official Robert Beatty album
column4: since it’s essentially a collaboration. He made all the music himself
column5: but crafted it to accompany the films of “digital video glitch pioneer” Takeshi Murata. Having to keep Murata’s images in mind would presumably force Beatty to react and stretch
column6: depriving him of complete control. To some extent that is the case: the music here has a less defined and distinct personality than that of Three Legged Race.

column1: But in a way
column2: that’s why it makes sense to label it as the work of Robert Beatty. Where Three Legged Race focuses on a narrower range
column3: Soundtracks for Takeshi Murata gives a greater sense of what Beatty is capable of sonically and thematically. And where Persuasive Barrier was often about restraint
column4: the music here is bigger and broader
column5: painting aural images in bolder
column6: thicker colors. There are solid drones
column7: dense atmospheres
column8: undulating synths
column9: and sound effect-like events that grab attention. There is some restraint too–one track
column10: “Escape Spirit Videoslime”
column11: plays like distant space transmissions–but most of Soundtracks is right up front
column12: ready to fill your ears.

column1: It’s also ready to fill your eyes
column2: or at least the ones in your mind. Beatty
column3: who also makes films and installations along with his prolific cover artwork
column4: has a visual sensibility that’s as strong as his musical instincts. Here that comes across in the way images and motion seem to leap from his sounds. In opener “Cone Eater”
column5: whirring tones and low rumbles conjure a silvery
column6: metallic skyline
column7: while on “Untitled (Silver)” (whose Murata film can be seen here) voice-like echoes and jolts of noise evoke a surreal
column8: burned-out war zone.

column1: What’s particularly impressive about that vividness is the way Beatty achieves it without mimicking Murata. It must’ve been tempting to cut up sound busily in response to Murata’s glitches
column2: but Beatty opts to dole it out in waves
column3: responding more to the fluidity of Murata’s films than their activity. That’s clearest in the album’s centerpiece
column4: a 20-minute accompaniment to Murata’s “Untitled (Pink Dot)”. Starting with a simple
column5: nursery-rhyme-like pattern of notes
column6: Beatty slowly fills the track with ripples and repetitions until it becomes epic
column7: somewhere between the expanses of a deep-space sci-fi film and the sleepless minimalism of Terry Riley.

column1: That kind of vast sound makes Soundtracks one of Beatty’s most widescreen works
column2: but it’s also–paradoxically
column3: perhaps–relatively limited in its potential appeal. Where Three Legged Race often offers hooks here and there to latch onto
column4:
Soundtracks is more suited for listeners inclined toward abstraction. But as an indication of how limitless Beatty’s palate is–and how much further he could take his music–Soundtracks for Takeshi Murata is as valuable as anything he’s done.

Hardly anyone starts out as a minimalist—at least
column2: not a good one. Whether working in music

column7: vividly fluttering shapes from the merest scraps of musical information—a plucked string
column8: a smear of organ

column1: In recent years

column3: the style sounds more like deceptively simple psychedelic pop (Moondog is frequently invoked by way of comparison) than dance music. 2010's Kokning was soft and shaggy

column4: chimes
column5: and scatted claps. The following ""Assistenten"" has a nice taut build around an off-center pulse

column7: and the final three pieces feel like more than practiced vamps. ""Setter"" braids together stuck string figures
column8: shivery drones
column9: and jittery percussion into one striated mass. On ""Totem Expose""
column10: wowing frequencies bore urgent rhythms through a metallic noise cloud that gradually turns inside out
column11: ending as an organist's hymn. And mesmerizing finale ""Nestor"" sends a filtered curlicue slowly arcing through a cold cosmos of rangy
column12: oblique counterpoint. Though less fleshed-out and essential than Kokning or its predecessor
column13: the delightful Feil Knapp
column14:
this final entry in Torske's ""to boil"" trilogy (counting last year's Oppkok remix 12"") has more than enough simmer to warrant the concept.

“This isn't a comedic tribute to talkboxes and widebrims; there's no Snoop Dogg descending a foggy staircase through a faded VHS haze here.” That's how the last paragraph of my review of Dâm-Funk's Toeachizown kicked off

column3: depending on your comfort level) was a funny throwback showcase on video

Would Snoop warbling those same kind of come-ons over some of Dâm's vamp-heavy slow-roller instrumentals really sound that ridiculous?

column1: 7 Days of Funk makes it immediately clear that it doesn't. Far from ridiculous
column2: it's actually the most natural thing in the world

column11: and contemporary nu-funk that helps the music work on all these different levels. And with both artists' stated mission to do this project as a fuck-the-radio labor of love—home-recorded and assembled quickly
column12: with a rush owing more to easy inspiration than stressful deadlines—the easygoing nature shines

He pulls off romantic appeals without sounding syrupy (“I'll Be There 4U”) and breakup ruminations without sounding antagonistic (“Faden Away”)—the kind of unflappable ease that still sounds satisfied with his vet-status years instead of bored by them. He's not Nate Dogg or anything

column5: and Dâm's typical propensity to let rhythms and riffs soak for a bit before taking off into solo turf keeps it moving.

column1: It's a strong mode to be in
column2: but 7 Days of Funk doesn't change or challenge things—it's a brief LP
column3: even accounting for bonus tracks
column4: and with everybody firmly in a comfortable lane there's not much surprise. There's Steve Arrington again
column5: following up Higher with an engagingly quirky spotlight turn on “1Question?” that makes Snoop sound like a guest on his own track. Toeachizown highlight “I Gots 2 Be Done Wit' U” repurposed and given a new squiggly outro solo for “Do My Thang”. And the smooth-rolling vibe is so seamless and immersive that even the slightest deviation from it sounds jarring—Kurupt's verse on “Ride” is perfunctory though not terrible
column6: and yet over that backdrop he sounds so far out of the pocket you'd need a chain wallet to bring him back. This isn't the out-of-nowhere clash of strange bedfellows that some people might imagine from a “Snoop on Stones Throw?!” expectation—in fact
column7: it feels practically inevitable. Without the element of surprise or clashing styles forced to compromise
column8: though
column9: all you've got is a solid record that does exactly what you'd hope it does
column10: nothing you think it shouldn't
column11:
and not quite enough to make you feel like they've explored every idea they could.

If there's anything like a normal year for Bob Pollard fans
column2: 2013 wasn't it. These past 12 months did offer a fine new EP and an okay-enough album—their fourth since early 2012—from the reunited Guided by Voices. But it's become increasingly clear that a classic on par with the lo-fi legends' peak-era material might've been a little too much to ask for. Then there was the late-summer tiff between Pollard and drummer Kevin Fennell
column3: whose unsuccessful attempt to peddle the beaten-to-shit drumkit he'd recorded many GBV classics on got him publicly shamed and subsequently fired by his old pal Bob. Bursts of drama notwithstanding
column4: shows were few and far between
column5: and side-hustles have been scant and largely of little consequence. The lone bright spot came this summer
column6: when Pollard issued the rich
column7: graceful Honey Locust Honky Tonk
column8: instantly cementing itself as one of the best records under his own name. Now
column9: Pollard's closing out this weird year with Blazing Gentlemen
column10: a headier
column11: rockier counterpoint to the unfailingly sweet Honey Locust.

column1: For a guy who's made records every which way
column2: the approach Pollard took with Gentlemen's construction is especially peculiar. Instead of appliquéing words onto melodies
column3: he built these songs from the lyrics up
column4: scouring his notebooks line-by-line for titles and lyrics
column5: then writing melodies—and then chords—around those. Pollard's always been a collagist—sometimes quite literally—but this method feels especially piecemeal; every few lines
column6: the underriding melody seems to shift
column7: leaving behind any sense of continuity. Much of Pollard's best work has taken a similarly attention-deficient tack
column8: although Gentlemen's disjointment is at the micro level
column9: all mismatched segments and jarring transitions. And
column10: given the wide range in quality between one segment to the next
column11: your time with Gentlemen's spent waiting around for the good part
column12: only to find it gone before you've been properly introduced.

column1: Ramrodding through 16 songs in 32 minutes and change
column2: Gentlemen may be the least classically pretty Pollard in ages; ballads are scant
column3: distortion's applied liberally
column4: and while the fidelity's fairly high and the instrumentation consistent
column5: the collection—throwing Honey Locust's carefully considered lushness in stark relief—opts for the quick and dirty. Pollard and Gentlemen cohort Todd Tobias—together
column6: responsible for every sound you hear on the record—have certainly arranged a plaintive melody or two in their day
column7: but Gentlemen largely leaves these overexcitable songs to their own devices. Opener ""Magic Man Hype"" is held together by sheer inertia
column8: rumbling through chord after oddball chord. The title track matches a sludgy verse to a towering chorus
column9: which would be fine
column10: if an out-from-nowhere bridge didn't pop up to derail the forward motion. ""His passionless kisses are real hits and misses
column11: Pollard sings on ""Blazing Gentlemen""
column12: and that pretty much sums it up: song for song
column13: Pollard records are typically a hodgepodge
column14: but the eternally jumpy Gentlemen whittles that inconsistency down to a second-by-second basis.

column1: Whenever Pollard can keep an idea in his head for more than a minute at a time
column2: Gentlemen starts to click. The cowbell-imbued ""Faking the Boy Scouts"" sports the set's stickiest hook; sure
column3: its verses are a tad on the jittery side
column4: but unlike much of Blazing Gentlemen
column5: they at least seem to be acquainted with the chorus that follows. ""Tea People"" is one of those effortlessly catchy
column6: totally stupid stompers only Pollard can get away with
column7: and again
column8: its verse and chorus seem to have been in the same room before. But for every song that seems to have been conceived as a piece
column9: there are two more assembled from whatever they had lying around. ""Tonight's the Rodeo"" is elegant enough at first
column10: but its chorus—all three seconds of it—is given neither time nor space to develop itself as anything but a nuisance. The lyrics are just as scatterbrained as the music
column11: notebook dumps turned not-so-exquisite corpses; Pollard-logic is never an easy path to follow
column12: but Gentlemen gets your head spinning in a fashion that'll have you swearing off the stuff the next morning.

column1: Are two half-formed ideas as good as one complete thought? Gentlemen seems to think so. But
column2: for all of Gentlemen's nervy shapeshifting
column3: its fitful thrills never quite make for a satisfying whole; it's too restless
column4: too scattered
column5: too gangly. Even the record's more-consistent-than-usual sound can't help hold these spasmodic
column6: shapeshifting songs together for more than a couple minutes at a time. Some fans will no doubt revel in Gentlemen's endless discrepancies; after all
column7: part of being a Pollard obsessive is learning to take the bad with the good. But
column8: on Gentlemen
column9: the bad and the good are so manically intertwined
column10: it gets to be a little tough telling them apart. Gentlemen's about as interesting as middling Pollard records get
column11: but it's middling all the same
column12:
a fittingly abnormal end to a most unusual year.

The records put out by the New York-based RVNG are often notable for the tight focus behind them. If there's a thread that links the label's eclectic past and present roster—including artists such as Julia Holter
column2: Sun Araw
column3: Stellar Om Source
column4: and Holly Herndon—it's in the clarity of vision they all possess. When an RVNG album arrives
column5: the music on it usually feels fully formed
column6: even if it's part of a musician's earliest output. There's room for experimentation too
column7: notably on the label's series of FRKWYS releases. Gardland are the Australian duo of Alex Murray and Mark Smith
column8: who release electronic music by an array of artists on their own Hunter Gatherer label. Here on Syndrome Syndrome
column9: their debut album
column10: there's a freeform feel that has more in common with the FRKWYS work than RVNG's regular releases.

column1: Most Gardland tracks are open-ended
column2: resembling fragments of ideas that could easily double or halve in length and not necessarily end up in a different space. Syndrome Syndrome offers a full set of immaculately sequenced instrumental works
column3: most of which bear dark surface textures that glide over understated beats. This is techno as a head trip rather than something to dance to
column4: although it's possible to trance out to the cheap acid burbles of ""Magicville""
column5: or feel a surge of energy in the unexpected callback to the ""clonk"" sound of Sweet Exorcist's ""Testone"" on ""One in None"". Essentially most of the material here is resolutely backward looking
column6: recalling the downtempo bleeps and beats of IDM
column7: all shaped by a duo who have a clear affection for those times.

column1: ""Nothing But Not Zero"" is the archetypal Gardland track. It begin with an abstract sound repeated and contorted over and over while a beat builds behind it
column2: ultimately drifting into quieter terrain following a great pile-up of noisier elements. Only occasionally is there a real sense of purpose behind the music
column3: with Murray and Smith seemingly just trying stuff out to see how it fits with their wide-open structures. With a runtime of over an hour (including bonus tracks) it makes Syndrome Syndrome a trying proposition at times
column4: especially when the ideas start to circle around on themselves. On a track like the rippling ""Katarakt"" there's clearly some excellent editing at work
column5: with each part expertly cut in place. It's too bad that kind of thinking didn't stretch to the overall album
column6: which could have benefited hugely from the trimming of fat.

column1: Part of the stated intent behind Hunter Gatherer is to embrace music with ""flaws and idiosyncrasies
column2: chance and spontaneity."" Syndrome Syndrome more than meets those goals
column3: although its brightest moment comes tucked away in the bonus cut ""Reak""
column4: a relatively straightforward piece of slamming techno that dispenses with most of what came before and simply heads to the dancefloor. There's a stronger sense of design at work there
column5: coupled with a feeling of joy that’s strangely absent elsewhere
column6: considering how powerfully it emerges at the end of the album. It lends an imbalance to the record
column7: adding to the feeling that Syndrome Syndrome is more a testing ground for ideas than a fully developed project
column8: especially as Murray and Smith have only been making this music for a year. Syndrome Syndrome offers some rewards
column9:
but it may have been a fraction too soon for them to make their first move.

"|18648.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18648-gardland-syndrome-syndrome/|6.3|Nick Neyland

Inquisition’s last album
column2: 2011’s Ominous Doctrines of the Perpetual Mystical Macrocosm was hailed as an instant classic
column3: and rightly so. The Seattle black metal duo had been quiet for several years before its release; since then
column4: though
column5: they've thrown themselves into the business of being a full-time band. Their recent signing to major indie Season of Mist is a satisfying notch on the bedpost for vocalist/guitarist Dagon and drummer Incubus
column6: who've reacted to their alliance with a “big label” by changing nothing whatsoever about their music or their approach towards occult exploration. Fans never expected them to react any differently
column7: and the great wailing and gnashing of teeth that usually accompanies the announcement of a beloved underground band stumbling into the spotlight has been absent. After all
column8: as even the webboard warriors seem to know
column9: a new album is another opportunity for the band to stalk in and show everyone else how it’s done.

column1: Obscure Verses for the Multiverse picks up where its predecessor left off. As usual
column2: Dagon’s guitar work blends seamlessly with Incubus’ drums
column3: and they remain merrily bass-free. Like some bizarro-world version of (until recently) bassless grind savants Pig Destroyer
column4: they’ve hit upon and perfected a formula that would leave a lesser band sounding flat and soulless. Inquisition built their reputation upon a small selection of ironclad riffs and dynamic devices—every note follows a predetermined script
column5: one that they’ve had memorized for decades
column6: and it works.

column1: Consider “Darkness Flows Towards Unseen Horizons”. A characteristic down-tempo melody opens the song
column2: which hurtles immediately into a relentless blast
column3: then back again. The band’s fondness for a good mid-song tempo shift has become one of their calling cards
column4: and an Inquisition tune bereft of its appearance feels a bit off-kilter. Groove-laden tracks like “Master of the Cosmological Black Cauldron” and “Inversion of Ethereal White Stars” are beefy head-nodders that feature some of Dagon’s best guitar work as he manipulates and torments his strings into all manner of eerie tones. Outside of his propensity for note-bending
column5: it’s worth noting the man’s uncanny knack for molding a gloomy shred of melody into an improbable earworm. While there are no obvious “hits” like on Ominous Doctinres
column6: the album is still about as catchy as a pure black metal record has any right to be. A triumphantly powerful melodic break forms the centerpiece of a “Spiritual Plasma Evocation”
column7: a track that despite its lack of ravens or winterdemonry
column8: emphatically gives legs to the Immortal comparisons that have dogged the band for years.

column1: The songs’ carefully cultivated atmosphere and aim towards an organic-sounding production leaves plenty of room for Dagon’s esoteric tales of space
column2: time
column3: and the Devil to unfold. This album is focused even more heavily on the cosmic and the metaphysical than past efforts
column4: and the lyrics are an absolute trip. As the title track goes
column5: ""Only darkness in the skies/ When you came light was shined/ Wisdom from cosmic snakes of dimensions you create/ Spawning humans as a slave serving kings of astral thrones."" Here’s hoping you can understand them
column6: though
column7: since Dagon’s infamous vocals are in full display.

column1: His froggy croak may sound like a direct descendent of Abbath’s own strangled ribbeting
column2: but comes from a far more evil place; it’s the former’s effort to sound as inhuman and alien as possible to accompany their occult cosmic ceremonies. In truth
column3: though they began life as a thrash band
column4: Inquisition still predates Immortal by several years. While the two bands developed and released their first important works during the same time period
column5: it’s worth noting that Dagon was already croaking up a storm before Abbath even donned the paint. It seems almost passé to make a reference to the Norwegian demons here
column6: but the parallel between the two entities’ melodic make up (not to mention that voice) is undeniable.

column1: As the story goes
column2: Inquisition originally formed while Dagon was living in Colombia in 1989
column3: predating the famed Second Wave’s most active period and ensuring that the band’s early days would be spent learning from greats like Reencarnación
column4: Blasfemia
column5: and Parabellum. They’ve been there since the beginning
column6: and will be here making outstanding records long after the rest of their peers have given up the ghost. Dagon’s 1996 move to the United States only aided them in their mission
column7: and now
column8:
it seems as though this cult favorite is finally beginning to reap the rewards of a lifetime of hard graft and black magic.

The first sound on Step Brothers 2 is Starlito arguing good-naturedly with Don Trip over which one of them should go first. (The track is song is called ""Paper Rock
column2: Scissors
column3: suggesting how they settled the issue.)  The two rappers—Starlito from Nashville
column4: Don Trip from Memphis—enjoy a bond unusual among solo artists and particularly unique among rappers. (I recommend reading some interviews with the two of them if you need to feel good today.) The two met in 2010
column5: when they were both were fairly recent castoffs from major labels; Don Trip had a cup of coffee on Interscope
column6: while Starlito submitted his talents to the ruthless Cash Money grinder for years. Both of them were in the throes of building the kind of midlevel regional careers that ensures you'll always have fans but might never have money. They clicked.

column1: The mixtape they made
column2: 2011's Step Brothers
column3: took its title from the then-three-year-old Will Ferrell/John C. Reilly vehicle. ""[I was drawn to] the concept of the camaraderie between two strangers that were so quirky in their own regard that they wouldn't gel with anyone else
column4: Starlito told The Fader. It was the most popular thing either of them had ever released; fair or not
column5: they learned the world paid more attention to them together than to either of them alone.

column1: Other rappers might have rushed out a sequel within six months
column2: to strike while the iron is hot. But Lito and Trip are shrewd and deliberate
column3: which means that Step Brothers 2 is out now
column4: two years later
column5: and unlike its predecessor
column6: it's available for retail. They spent money on beats from Drumma Boy
column7: Sonny Digital
column8: and other in-demand producers
column9: and honed their songs and concepts. What you don't get this time around: the bottled-lightning sound of two rappers falling in love with each other's ideas in real time. What you do get: Two of the most honest writers in rap working together at maximum comfort and confidence.

column1: As with the first Step Brothers
column2: Lito and Trip largely don't bother with hooks. ""No chorus but it's goin' on like four minutes
column3: Starlito says wryly on ""Paper
column4: Rock Scissors
column5: and many of these songs just go on and on
column6: in the best and most exciting sense
column7: both rappers dreaming up vivid phrasing and rapping for audiences of one. ""My ink pen drip icicles
column8: Don Trip says on ""Paper
column9: Rock
column10: Scissors"". ""Servin
column11: servin like we never heard of cops/ Prefer to handle my business personally -you want this work or not?"" raps Starlito on ""28th Song"". They elbow out the beats
column12: blotting out the empty spaces
column13: rap for 32 bars or more; they have too much to say
column14: and it's exhilarating.

column1: For the friendly-competition purposes of Step Brothers 3
column2: I'll observe that Lito gets Trip on this one
column3: just barely. Trip makes his way from point A to B by stringing sometimes-dumb puns together
column4: as in ""Life is sweet
column5: but still sucks
column6: like a Sno Cone"" (""4x4 Relay"")
column7: while Lito raps in gorgeously accumulating run-on sentences
column8: dotted with musical phrasings and internal rhymes. Following along with the long ""O"" sounds in a stretch of rhyme like ""On the low I been unfocused
column9: I'm just hoping no one notices/ Trying to play my cards right
column10: but things got wild as the Joker is/ The things I love I kill for
column11: call my bluff with no poker chips/ got this chip on my shoulder which/ Brings me to this lick I'm about to hit"" (from ""Caesar and Brutus"") points you toward the subtlety of Lito's writing
column12: which never halts the force of his rapping.

column1: Starlito has had a quietly triumphant year; Step Brothers 2 is his third stellar full-length of 2013. His musing
column2: wry style has gathered resonance as he's developed as an artist
column3: and this year
column4: every off-the-cuff thought he shared cut to the bone. On Funerals & Court Dates from last winter
column5: he talked ruefully about not finishing college
column6: simply because ""shit's expensive."" On Cold Turkey from this summer
column7: he told us to call our grandmother to ""see how her day went. ""This advice come with experience
column8: you ain't gotta take it
column9: he shrugged.

column1: It's this unforced honesty he shares with Don Trip
column2: whose biggest song
column3: ""Letter To My Son""
column4: was a powerful lament about struggling to visit his child that lingered over details like court-appointed visitation rights. His adlib is a high-pitched
column5: braying cackle
column6: the sound of someone's soused uncle laughing at his own off-color joke; he's a good foil for the subdued Starlito
column7: who can get lost in his own mind occasionally. Step Brothers 2 was financed by the tour that the two rappers booked themselves
column8: without a team of promoters. Hopefully
column9:
it will inch the career of both rappers a little further up the ladder.They deserve a dedicated cult fanbase in every major American city.

If Mastodon never get around to a greatest hits package
column2: Live at Brixton will do the trick. Captured at a February 2012 gig in London
column3: Brixton finds the Georgia prog-sludge mainstays barreling through 23 choice cuts from their five good-to-classic LPs
column4: 2002's Remission through 2011's The Hunter
column5: a typically remarkable performance from a band whose live prowess rivals their in-studio wizardry. Like most overviews
column6: the song selection's arguable
column7: the impact of even the highest highs altered in their uprooting. But Brixton does the same rep-cementing
column8: catalog-calcifying work a good hits comp is supposed to
column9: further solidifying Mastodon's spot among the greatest big-ticket metal bands going.

column1: Some bands make records; from the start
column2: Mastodon have been turning out capital-A albums. From Leviathan's seafaring to Crack the Skye's out-of-body postmortems
column3: they're three for five on concept LPs; even their 2002 debut Remission hinges loosely around that most classically metal of the Aristotelian elements
column4: fire. Skye
column5: with its overlong runtimes and a particularly convoluted concept
column6: sagged a little under the weight of its own pretensions: no easy feat for a band whose best album gave a close read to a 19th century novel about whaling. The Mike Elizondo-produced Hunter was a hard swing in the the other direction: reeling in the complexities of their previous work
column7: Hunter felt concise yet rudderless
column8: occasionally slick to the point of sterility. Brixton
column9: understandably
column10: is heavy on the then-new Hunter material. But onstage
column11: stripped of Elizondo's radio-ready production and slotted in amidst the burlier stuff from their earlier classics
column12: it feels redeemed
column13: finding a heft and grit they couldn't quite locate in the studio.

column1: I first saw Mastodon in early 2004
column2: warming up for Clutch at some shithole club several months before Leviathan's release. Even then
column3: they seemed 15 feet tall. The show at the 4
column4: 000 capacity Brixton was
column5: at the time
column6: their largest-ever headlining gig. They make the most of it
column7: tearing through 97 mostly uninterrupted minutes for a ravenous crowd. Live and on record
column8: Mastodon's strength lies in playing the angles; they're progressive but accessible
column9: hard to pin down yet instantly recognizable
column10: hooky without sacrificing aggression
column11: ""literary"" without getting too nerdy with it; I'm told Troy Sanders is easy on the eyes. Onstage
column12: they aren't the kind of band to blow shit up
column13: or waste any time with banter; at Brixton
column14: they perform with minimal (albeit effective) lighting in front of a large Hunter banner
column15: and only speak to the crowd as the encore-capping ""Creature Lives"" winds down. These songs—particularly the pre-Hunter numbers—are performed with mystifying precision
column16: holding close to their recorded counterparts; a particularly fiery solo from Brent Hinds leads ""Circle of Cysquatch"" into ""Aqua Dementia""
column17: and he sneaks some bonus guitar harmonics on ""Sleeping Giant""
column18: but where extras are concerned
column19: that's about it. Still
column20: just seeing these knotty songs through an hour and half of entanglements is more than enough with got several thousand watts—and the screams of 4
column21: 000 devotees—helping them. The video portion of Brixton spends a not-inconsiderable amount of time behind Brann Dailor
column22: and with good reason; in a band with no shortage of virtuosos
column24: batteramming Dailor's the best of the bunch
column25: and he seems to get a good hour into Brixton without breaking a sweat.

column1: There's not much point in rehashing the finer points of the songs from Leviathan and Blood Mountain
column2: Mastodon's take-your-pick classics
column3: both generously represented here; suffice it to say
column4: even after dozens upons dozens of listens
column5: their technical prowess and continued unpredictability still astonish. The Remission material—""Where Strides the Behemoth"" and ""March of the Fire Ants""—feels particularly fierce
column6: a grinding
column7: thrashing
column8: death metal-imbued ruckus fine-tuned on their early singles and all but perfected on that first LP. They pare down Skye to just ""Ghost of Karelia"" and its title track
column9: mercifully leaving the 10+ minute slogs and the why-would-you-do-that banjo of ""Divinations"" for another night.

column1: Again
column2: though
column3: it's Hunter that benefits the most in Brixton. Those songs—rife with classic-rock affectations
column4: finely tuned harmonies
column5: and uncharacteristically pristine production—felt compromised on record. Onstage
column6: they're brought surging to life; the tempos seem turned up a few notches
column7: the production tics are largely lost to the full-on assault
column8: and Hinds and Sanders lend the vocals a gruffness more in line with their earlier work. Hunter detractors (and I count myself among this group) would be right to expect a dip in energy and/or quality when those songs start up
column9: but that's only slightly true; the newer songs help play up the Georgia roots in the older material
column10: while the pre-Hunter wildness ramps up a forward motion even ""Bedazzled Fingernails"" can't seem to scratch.

column1: Brixton's still dogged by a few of the issues plaguing almost every live album. Turns out
column2: 97 minutes is a hell of a lot of Mastodon
column3: and since they're not exactly the most demonstrative band
column4: getting through the whole thing in a single sitting's not easy without running to the fridge for another beer. Flattering as these performances are to The Hunter
column5: after a few spins of Brixton
column6: the next time you've got an hour and a half to spend on sludge
column7: you're more than likely going to return to that familiar Leviathan/Blood Mountain twofer. But
column8: as a celebration of Mastodon's impressive catalog and incredible live prowess
column9: Brixton can afford to be a little overgenerous. They've been one of metal's sharpest
column10: flat-out exciting bands for more than a decade now
column11: and Brixton plays to their strengths while bowling over any minor missteps from their recent LPs. Brixton ends with the Dailor-sung lighter-flicker ""Creature Lives""
column12: arguably the weakest of The Hunter's weak spots. A few seconds in
column13: the band are joined by then-tourmates Red Fang and the Dillinger Escape Plan
column14: helping lead the crowd in a massive singalong. It's a real brothers-in-arms moment
column15: exactly the way the song—oddly out of place on record—was meant to be heard. It's a triumphant moment
column16:
the last of many on Brixton.

column2: it was when they donned those gleaming silver and gold visored masks circa 2001’s Discovery—perpetuating themselves as androids dreaming electric sheep-- that they struck a chord. It proved to be a schtick they continued to milk into the present

column1: This curious decade
column2: wherein progressive rock musicians and studio whizzes obtained futuristic synthesizers and otherworldly effects to imagine new cosmic vistas (or else they just went and checked out Star Wars at their local Cineplex and saw the future of music)
column3: gets documented on the new compilation Cosmic Machine: A Voyage Across French Cosmic & Electronic Avantgarde (1970-1980). Within this set’s shiny silver carapace lie the roots of acts ranging from Daft Punk and Justice to Todd Terje
column4: Lindstrøm and any number of analog synth enthusiasts working on 21st century electronic music.

column1: At its most interesting
column2: Cosmic Machine shows the mercenary-like tendencies of these European musicians
column3: changing from tweed to chiffon to tinfoil as the trends occurred. The warbling soft focus synths that open the set come from Patrick Juvet
column4: a Swiss pop vocalist who finally achieved chart success only when he began copping space disco moves later in the decade. Same goes for composer Didier Marouani
column5: who dabbled in French chanson and pop balladry before adding starbursts
column6: analog squelches and melancholic vocoders to 1979’s “Temps X"".

column1: Which isn’t to suggest that everyone represented here was just cashing in. Prolific soundtrack composers like François De Roubaix
column2: Alain Goraguer and Jean-Jacques Perrey kept abreast of such trends and technology
column3: folding these extraterrestrial tones expertly into their works. One of the set’s surprises comes from Serge Gainsbourg—always known to push both envelopes and buttons—contributing an anxious slice of instrumental synth pop that brings to mind the throb of early Suicide as much as it does New Romanticism.

column1: Some of the sounds here are glorious
column2: fusty fromage
column3: for synth aficionados and few others
column4: as on tracks such as the Rockets’ “Rocket Man” and Pierre Bachelet’s “Motel Show"". But where the set excels is in showing how the booming percussion of progressive rock would soon become breaks fodder
column5: be it in the huge kicks of Jean-Michel Jarre’s “Blackbird” and Cerrone’s tom-delirious “Générique (Début)"". In hindsight
column6: the arrival of disco’s 4/4 backbeat tightened up almost every experimental synth noodle on here
column7: making a star out of the likes of the aforementioned Cerrone and turning Space’s arpeggio-heavy “Magic Fly” into a NYC club staple for years.

column1: Another name for the set could have easily been “The Roots of Daft Punk” as the duo’s sense of play comes through in almost every one of the set’s twenty tracks. One track entitled “Aqua”—featuring synths as airy as popcorn
column2: ludicrous vocodered vocals and perky live drums—in particular seems to presage Daft Punk’s own muse. Credited to DVWB
column3: it turns out to be the handiwork of Daniel Vangarde
column4: a famous French session musician/arranger/ producer responsible for an innumerable amount of French music from the 1970s and 80s. But of course
column5:
he’s best known for being the father of Thomas Bangalter.

Let’s do a little bit of word association: “Long Island Sound.” What does that phrase mean to you? Is it a body of water? Or
column2: does it encompass Taking Back Sunday
column3: Straylight Run
column4: Brand New and perhaps Glassjaw? After Bleed American broke emo onto alternative rock formats in the early 2000s
column5: the aforementioned Islanders (and assorted New Jerseyans) took things to a colder
column6: edgier place on the East Coast: more rooted in punk
column7: but with slicker
column8: sharper production
column9: more verbose and venomous. And at least in their earliest incarnations
column10: these acts had an discomforting tendency to invert the previously accepted gender dynamic
column11: using their lyrics to make preemptive strikes rather than penning postmortems of heartbreak. So the above will probably do a lot to frame your opinion of Iron Chic
column12: because the Huntington Station quintet aren’t hiding their lineage—they recently opened for Garden State spiritual brethren Saves the Day and their second LP (and first on punk stronghold Bridge Nine) The Constant One is filled with bracing
column13: explosive hooks
column14: unresolved sexual and spiritual tension and very meaningful “whoa”s. But it fortunately lacks any accusatory overtone
column15: and welcomes far more people than it initially lets on: underneath the pop-punk veneer is one of the most flat-out fun indie rock guitar records of recent vintage.

column1: This isn’t complicated stuff
column2: burly
column3: beery and well-meaning like Iron Chic themselves even when they’re worrying themselves into a state of hypnosis (“Wolf Dix Rd""). Their reference points are not esoteric: the dashboard-pounding opener is titled “Bogus Journey”
column4: a Game Boy chiptune rendering of “Spooky Action at a Distance” serves as its own intro and the most meta moment involves “Hey Jealousy” karaoke. And though I’ve only heard things about what an Iron Chic show is like
column5: I’ve still heard things: dudes in flannels not so much singing along with Iron Chic as singing back at them
column6: with much gesticulating
column7: finger-pointing
column8: fist-pumping and so forth. These are the stories you hear a lot these days as community-galvanizing pop-punk and emo are getting more attention
column9: and typically
column10: you need a preface on the band’s roots and ideals to get the full picture of why kids lose their shit. The Constant One is a rare time where you can say “it leaves nothing to the imagination” as a compliment. Or
column11: to frame it another way
column12: Iron Chic are holding nothing back and do their damnedest to make you feel less alone if you happen to be in the parts of the country they haven’t reached yet.

column1: The Constant One unwittingly serves as its own listening guide: Jason Lubrano‘s vocals are often doubled or tripled
column2: if not group-hugged by the 15-deep “Iron Chic Solid Gold Singers.” Even solo
column3: there’s a throat-straining grit and grain that still makes it sound like he’s ad-libbing over himself. Either way
column4: you’ve learned how a group chant of Iron Chic lyrics sounds like
column5: so go ahead and shout along in your car or your cubicle. Because they’re fun as hell anyway—“I don’t...I don’t fucking know!” “You had a heart of gold/ I know because I fucking sold it!” “get high/ say ‘fuck the world’ when we’re done with that!” “I can’t feel a fucking thing!” The lack of a Parental Advisory sticker should be inexplicable
column6: except for the fact that The Constant One spends 40 minutes recalling the exact opposite of parental advisory; I’m pretty sure the first time your folks let you fend for yourself over a weekend
column7: you heard the pick slide on “Bogus Journey” the moment their car left the driveway.

column1: Quite often
column2: “pop-punk” gets used to describe something that’s actually indie rock (see: Swearin’
column3: Japandroids)
column4: which can trigger a lot of negative biases amongst people who are fairly certain they’re not into the former. The difference lies in tone: pop-punk evokes palm-muted power chords with clean distortion and nasal vocals
column5: whereas indie rock is most associated with shambling
column6: jangly and fuzzy guitars with drawling vocals. Iron Chic gives you both. At their core
column7: each of The Constant One’s ten proper tracks builds on revved-up progressions of three or four chords
column8: spaced out for broad melodies and strummed almost exclusively in air-guitar accommodating 16th notes. During the relative jams of “Spooky Action at a Distance”
column9: “Bogus Journey” and “Wolf Dix Rd.”
column10: you get J. Mascis and Doug Martsch leads shaved and bathed—they’re not quite riffs
column11: not quite solos and they can melodically support the song for minutes at a time. Though it’s sonically aligned with the likes of axe-wielding party/shit-starters Diarrhea Planet or So So Glos
column12: Iron Chic are more sincere than snotty
column13: thus their closest analogue is probably Japandroids—while I sorta hope they tour together at some point
column14: I also worry about some sort of class action suit from ticketbuyers who whoa’d themselves into weeklong hangovers.

column1: Because while The Constant One is metric tons of fun
column2: it’s kinda the same variety of fun throughout. Even on the most puritanical melodic pop-punk/emo records of this sort
column3: you’ll get a token ballad
column4: your “Freakish”
column5: your “New American Classic""
column6: your “Hear You Me”
column7: your “The Devil In My Bloodstream” and it’ll probably be the sixth song. Perhaps the first minute of “A Serious House on Serious Earth” counts
column8: but the outliers on The Constant One are actually faster than what surrounds them. The constancy can make things a little blurry towards the end
column9: and without the spoken word samples and goofy titles
column10: it’d be tough to remember which song went was about the end of the world and which one was about the Gin Blossoms (that would be “True Miserable Experience”). Which makes a lot of sense for a record that all but affixes a foam dome to your head
column11: so it's a same quibble. Look
column12:
it ain’t gonna change your life. Not by itself.  It just serves as a potential soundtrack for a night that you’ll remember for the rest of your life if you can remember it the next day.

It’s tempting to call any instrumental music “cinematic.” Without literal words to hook onto
column2: most brains–or at least mine–fill in the blanks with images
column3: especially since we’ve all seen so many movies do exactly that. But “cinematic” has become such a cliché that lately I’ve tried to block images out of my head when I listen to wordless music
column4: in hopes that I’ll absorb and think about the sounds on their own–or at least not call them “cinematic”. I keep trying to do that with Noveller’s No Dreams
column5: and I keep failing.

column1: I doubt that Sarah Lipstate
column2: who records as Noveller
column3: would have a problem with that
column4: nor would she object to No Dreams being described as “cinematic.” She’s been working with film about as long as she’s been a musician
column5: and lately she’s ramped up that side of her art significantly
column6: crafting soundtracks for feature films and performing live scores on Radiolab’s tour. So she must have had some moving images in mind when she created the evocative
column7: picture-worthy sounds on No Dreams.

column1: What makes No Dreams more than just “cinematic” is the way Lipstate straddles the line between literal and abstract. Her sounds drift from moments that conjure vivid mental movies to something more amorphous and undefined—more visceral than visual. According to press materials for No Dreams
column2: these songs explore “blurred perception of reality and hallucination in the twilight of sleep and awakening.” The result is intoxicatingly hazy music
column3: more fit for a half-remembered nightmare than a movie
column4: with images flickering in and out of focus inside Lipstate’s shadowy soundscape.

column1: Previously
column2: Lipstate built her soundscapes just with guitar and effects
column3: but this time she’s added synth
column4: beats
column5: and other instrumental elements. Perhaps that’s why her music sounds a little denser and darker now
column6: but really
column7: those added elements are more accents than features. Guitar is still the only star of her show
column8: and on No Dreams’ best tracks it becomes a kind of God around which other sounds congregate. On tracks such as the harrowing “Mannahatta” and the mournful “Gathering the Elements
column9: ” Lipstate coaxes high
column10: celestial tones from her strings
column11: at times making them sound like a kind of interplanetary bagpipe. That move becomes a motif
column12: as many tracks crest whenever she ascends into trebly drone. It doesn’t quite create the narrative thrust that the last Noveller album
column13: Glacial Glow
column14: possessed. But it ties album into a focused
column15: cohesive sonic whole.

column1: That brings up another cliché that I’m tempted to use to describe No Dreams. It’s as much atmospheric as it is cinematic
column2: as much an environment to get lost in as a soundtrack to imagine pictures to. At this point “atmospheric” is an even more hackneyed descriptor than “cinematic
column3: ” but sometimes clichés are right. Sarah Lipstate creates miniature musical worlds
column4:
places that you feel like you’ll never leave long as the record is playing. Maybe her continually-strong work as Noveller can give some clichés a good name again.

For more than 40 minutes

column8: Wolf Eyes
column9: and
column10: in some capacity
column11: Locrian

column13: then

column1: What’s more
column2: the time between Within the Walls and 2006’s Magnetism has only seemed to condense the band’s strengths

column7: who often hurls them out beneath the dominant tongue. Two scripts in two different languages might sound disorienting

column14: Reyes lurks beneath him and then occasionally jumps in front

column16: oblivion
column17: and unavoidable anguish. The sound is a nightmare. They complement and contradict one another throughout the record
column18: constantly reinforcing the music’s tumult.

column1: Within the Walls alternates between long
column2: ponderous poems shouted into or against the noise vortex and five ruthless bursts of pugilistic feedback and static lasting between nine and 68 seconds each. Bloodyminded has often used this see-saw technique in the past
column3: onstage and offstage

column5: meant to break up the verbose musings as much as it to show the group’s sonic willpower. More than anything

column8: a group whose very power and antagonistic nature could make their records monolithic and paradoxically sedate. But once again

column10:
even if that requires a vivid recollection and recombination of the past.

column1: Based on that metric

Make a sound big and resonant enough and you might drown out squabbling

The reaction many people have to hearing Chatham for the first time is some variant on ""I didn't know this existed."" ""This"" being an idea about the uniting power of pure sound

column14: a dynamic sense. To use a metaphor from an earlier age of media

You might think about any number of things while the piece continues chiming in your headphones for the remaining 10 minutes—you might think about groceries that you need to pick up on the way home

On paper
column2: Brooklyn-based electronic duo Ejecta seem to fit the criteria as the next hip thing. Singer/songwriter Leanne Macomber also plays with Neon Indian; multi-instrumentalist Joel Ford is one-half of production team Ford & Lopatin. Their debut album
column3: Dominae
column4: is stuffed with plenty of shiny
column5: slinky sounds to score a neon-lit nightclub or a contemplative after-dusk drive. Making note of such an obviously appealing creative pedigree with a reflexively raised eye—they played their first concert during last month’s CMJ Marathon
column6: by the way—wouldn’t be out of the question for listeners who’ve become deadened to the relentless cycle of new bands you've just got to hear. But Ejecta go beyond surface poise and artifice by building a complex world out of an imagined narrator’s deepest longings
column7: imbuing an at-times generic sound with real emotional weight.

column1: At face value
column2: Dominae mostly follows a template: Macomber’s voice is usually locked in at “breathy
column3: ” each song can usually be described as “synthpoppy
column4: ” and if you close your eyes
column5: the whole thing might zip by as an amorphous lump of gliding synthesizers
column6: electronic squiggles
column7: and percussion bounces. But Ejecta is more than a name that sounds like it could’ve been yanked from any number of medium talent trip-hop acts from the 90s—it’s a character
column8: one who Macomber has described as a release valve for her deepest impulses and someone who must always appear nude to further double down on that transparency. It makes sense when you focus on her lyrics
column9: in which she admits feelings of shame
column10: elation
column11: lust
column12: and despair. The exact scenario of what's got her twisted is sometimes vague
column13: but the lack of descriptive detail creates a distance befitting of powerful emotions reduced to their essence. (One might suggest that Macomber hardly needs to invent a character to project this kind of nakedly honest songwriting
column14: but a sales pitch is a sales pitch.)

column1: Where the concept of Ejecta best manifests itself
column2: though
column3: is in Macomber and Ford’s wholehearted embrace of sounds that might scan as completely cheesy if paired with more banal sentiments. Two examples are the glistening introduction to “Mistress”
column4: which sounds like an outtake Styx might’ve recorded on some beautifully coke-dusted summer night
column5: or the sparkling disco of “Jeremiah”.  If you’ve yet to be convinced of the spiritually purifying effect a synthesizer can have
column6: this might not be the record to do it
column7: but what the duo accomplish with a tonally consistent palette is at times astonishing. “It’s Only Love” navigates the complex balance of power and intent in any complicated relationship as Macomber finds the midpoint between coy and chilly over a crystalline instrumental. “Afraid of the Dark” opens on her voice as she solemnly narrates what sounds like a bittersweet breakup—again
column8: the details are vague—and slowly builds momentum until you can imagine the band in blurred
column9: beatific motion as she repeats a phrase that might function as Dominae’s thesis: “This warm heart's afraid of the dark/ Never gonna stop
column10: I’m never going to conquer.”

column1: Through the album
column2: Macomber sings of love as an almost physical currency
column3: something that’s taken or given with intentions that aren’t always on the level. There’s more to admitting your deepest desires and fears than just saying them out loud
column4: of course
column5: and the record’s most affecting moments are when it fully commits to its confessions—when you can believe that she
column6: or Ejecta
column7: is singing as truthfully as possible without drowning. It might take a moment to sink in
column8:
but it's there.

With the release of his 2011 debut LP GLAQJO XAACSSO

column4: probing him for his views on the album

column9: the Hum
column10: the finer points of 5th century Sanskrit linguistic theory
column11:
and so on. 

All of this points to a personality type that
column12: if not entirely birthed by the web
column13: certainly seems to be in plentiful supply in the internet age; a personality type that shone through on the album itself
column14: too. Many comparisons were made between GLAQJO XAACSSO and golden era Warp

column16: house
column17: and techno—he displayed a similar urge to push the parameters of these styles to the edge of chaos

column22: as with those Wiki links
column23: what we were dealing with was a diverting but rather shallow engagement with the subject matter at hand.

column1: Perhaps it’s just that patten’s music doesn’t benefit from prolonged exposure. Certainly
column2: condensed into 23 minutes on the EOLIAN INSTATE EP
column3: the producer’s signature style is far more palatable. The tracks on this

column5: are a touch more incisive
column6: although in other respects it seems that little has changed for patten in the past two years. The sound remains much the same—a pulverised form of electronica tempered with a subtle melodic glow—and passing comparisons can still be made to Actress’ heat-warped techno
column7: or Flying Lotus at his most fervidly psychedelic.

column1: In places the familiarity is welcome. Opener ""Aviary"" starts out near-impossibly dense and heads upwards from there
column2: patten piling on ever more layers of gauzy texturing. ""Obsidian Alms (mid-saccade)""

column4: pushes this logic even further. But elsewhere it becomes clear that

column1: Fortunately

column6: finally
column7:
that everything-all-the-time isn’t the only way to go.

Daniel Fisher—who records as Physical Therapy—has established himself through work as a rogue remixer and his associations with internet-savvy
column2: visually inclined misfits like Elite Gymnastics and Mykki Blanco. These details have obscured the fact that his productions are rather conventional. A stylist at heart
column3: his excellent ""Drone On"" predicted this year's trendy return to jungle. Non-Drowsy
column4: a free
column5: seven-track EP
column6: marks the launch of Fisher's new label
column7: Allergy Season
column8: and sees him mining the abundant melodicism of early 90s house and garage
column9: itself a popular inspiration for his contemporaries.

column1: Fisher's greatest strength is his easy way with melody
column2: and the rhythmically simple
column3: luxe grooves that he carves out on Non-Drowsy are fine showcases for this talent. Simple
column4: staccato basslines
column5: reverberating vocal samples and gassy pads are neatly deployed and retracted. The album feels like classic dance music even when its direct antecedents are difficult to place. I think this might have been the point: to recreate and explore without ever getting too personal. The approach works best when Fisher chops up vocal samples into micro-melodies
column6: as on ""Coffee"" or during the end of ""Huminbeen"". It's an approach that recalls both old-school sample scientists like Marc Kinchen as well as contemporaries like Four Tet. The haunted
column7: tense piano chords that dominate ""Leonia"" and the queasy synths that oscillate in the background of ""4:21"" are excellent facsimiles. Nothing on Non-Drowsy sounds out of place.

column1: This approach highlights one of the chief frustrations of listening to Non-Drowsy: it never feels explicitly retro or modern. It's a slippery album
column2: one that's agreeable when it's on but fails to leave an impression. The tracks get no help from their mastering; Non-Drowsy is sonically mushy
column3: its mids and highs bleeding into one another
column4: its bass and drums failing to provide any real punch or grit; the arrangements glide by unmolested. This is a problem in part because the era and style of dance music that Non-Drowsy references was often expertly produced
column5: its frequencies and arrangements optimized for maximum dancefloor impact. And while it's possible that this was done for effect—as a commentary on club music
column6: or on the listeners who push it through plastic earbuds and muffled laptops—it doesn't aid the music (and your mileage on the validity of that theory will and should vary).

column1: But Non-Drowsy isn't disappointing because it's not perfectly executed club music. It's disappointing because it's difficult to reconcile the creativity that Fisher displays in his videos
column2: remixes
column3: and (admittedly bad) album artwork and the polite
column4: uninteresting dance tracks on offer. Recognizing that Fisher has talent and maybe a unique voice is easy; finding that voice in Non-Drowsy is hard. Fisher remains a young artist—Non-Drowsy is just his second conventional release
column5: and it's a free seven-track EP—so some growing pains are to be expected. Fisher has worked hard to present himself as a batshit urban cowboy with great taste and cool friends; the moment he starts sounding as such should produce some pretty interesting tracks
column6:
in whatever style has caught his fancy that day.

Watch any live footage of Gang Gang Dance and your eyes will eventually fall on Brian DeGraw

His group's desire to pull so many styles into their music calls for that level of detail—without it they'd be wading through a morass of overlapping genres with no central unified force to lean on. bEEdEEgEE is DeGraw's solo guise

column9: if slightly predictable
column10: array of styles. It doesn't add much to what DeGraw has achieved elsewhere

column1: In a sense SUM/ONE suffers because of the higher standards DeGraw has already set. A track like ""Overlook"" is a decent halfway point between stuttering rhythms and sunshine pop

Of all the groups who first got together on the campus of Wesleyan University in the early 00s
column2: Francis Farewell Starlite’s pop project Francis and the Lights was the most unstuck from time. Starlite’s pop is poised and unhurried
column3: without being particularly flashy; vocally

Though it’s been some time since Francis and the Lights delivered the promising 2010 debut It’ll Be Better—an album stocked with pop gems like “Knees to the Floor” that would have slayed in a different era but were hard to tack to a contemporary style—it’s a release that holds up because of that same timelessness. Save for some production work on Drake’s Thank Me Later—the slow-burn “Karaoke”—and the occasional high-concept performance piece
column8: it’s been a quiet couple of years for the Lights.

column1: Though Francis’ new EP Like a Dream is a brief outing—four songs that clock in
column2: collectively
column3: a few ticks shy of 14 minutes—it serves as  a satisfying end to the silence. Though nothing here approaches surefire radio smashes or really anything that’s going to hit you like a load of bricks

column6: funkier atmospheres he's inhabited so far. Though something like “Like a Dream” is a breezy track whose complete lack of edge might rub you the wrong way—”This could be in a commercial!” a coworker brightly remarked—its gentle electric throb gets in your head.

column6: unfortunately.) “If They Don’t Come Tomorrow” is another example of Francis treating his vocals more than his audience might be used to

column1: Though it’s dangerous to think of these pocket-sized releases as “appetizers
column2: ” Like a Dream is something that certainly primes the listener for the main course. Though it’s all relative when it comes to Francis’ tight
column3: deliberate sound

column6: Like a Dream also succeeds in re-injecting Francis into the conversation when the timing is a little better—though many soldiers have entered the borderlands of R&B and singer-songwriter pop in recent years

it plays like a pleasant dream you can't quite recall.

Chris d'Eon has impeccable timing. The Montreal singer/songwriter/producer arrived on the scene back in 2010 with his proper debut LP Palinopsia; the record's mix of swirling synths and emotive crooning captured a few zeitgeist points in North American underground music culture—the still-going integration of R&B signifiers
column2: the return of new age and kosmiche's starry-eyed tranquility

column12: Arc of Fire does feel like a distinctive

column16: along with his dorm-room-bull-session conceptualism
column17: are largely absent here. (The latter element isn't entirely gone: the name Kallisti references an element of Greek mythology that represents
column18: according to a press release
column19: ""Vanity
column20: discord
column21: and chaos
column22: the knowledge of which proves inessential in enjoying what d'Eon's done here.)

column1: The Kallisti project may be rooted in genre pastiche
column2: but d'Eon wears these new-for-him sounds quite well
column3: making Arc of Fire his strongest and most cohesive release yet. The inescapable rush and psychedelic rhythms packed into the EP's most engaging moments
column4: tempered with a few gorgeous melodic passages
column5: suggest that d'Eon is a capable student of the sub-genre of dance music that he is so dutifully referencing. Arc of Fire is the second release for NORELATION

column7: an imprint that has made a name for itself in 2013 with an increasingly intriguing roster of producers making dance music that falls far left of center

column9: eraser-in-your-ear techno favored by Gobby. Arc of Fire scratches a similarly niche itch
column10: but its straightforward approach to the past is less ingenious by design than other releases on the label. (If anything
column11: there's more in common here with the artists responsible for NORELATION's first release
column12: defunct California duo LOL Boys
column13: who similarly struggled to carve out an individual voice during their short
column14: intermittently intriguing run.)

column1: Arc of Fire may lack fresh ideas
column2: but d'Eon does pull a few surprises out of his bag—notably
column3: on ""Millennial""
column4: which features the collection's boldest sample choice: the chorus to Backstreet Boys' 1998 mega-hit ""I Want It That Way"". d'Eon chops up the once-ubiquitous single's chorus

column1: As a whole

An irritating development in North American experimental electronic music over the last several years—especially in regard to those young artists who fall into the ""bedroom producer"" grouping—has been a willingness to shift from style to style

new-sounding.

For whatever reason

But with Warwick’s chintzy synths deployed for live performance—not to mention his glasses and his shirt tucked-into his khakis—perhaps it’s simply a matter of high school bullying the geekiest kid in the classroom carrying over into adulthood.

If you’re checking résumés
column2: the New York quartet Vaura probably seems daunting. Two of its members
column3: bassist Toby Driver and guitarist Kevin Hufnagel
column4: have logged recent time in some of heavy metal’s more dense and complicated units. Hufnagel counters Luc Lemay in the relaunched version of Gorguts and plays guitar with perpetually knotty instrumental trio Dysrhythmia. Driver
column5: meanwhile
column6: is the mastermind of the ever-recondite Kayo Dot and a survivor of the wonderfully exploratory maudlin of the Well. The pedigree of the band’s other half—drummer Charlie Schmid and leader
column7: vocalist and guitarist Josh Strawn—is less metallic but nevertheless impressive and important: They both played in the lightly gothic Religious to Damn. That band’s hypnotic rock mirrored
column8: at least in part
column9: Strawn’s chilling post-punk standouts in Blacklist. So
column10: just how intricate and truculent can Vaura be?

column1: No matter what the credits might suggest
column2: The Missing—Vaura’s second album in as many years and first for Profound Lore—is not altogether intimidating
column3: either stylistically or technically. Sure
column4: there are blast beats and wave-of-treble black metal guitars. There’s some doom lurch and even a touch of industrial disorientation. And the compositions aren’t exactly simple. “Passage to Vice” is a Rube Goldberg contraption of rhythms
column5: with pianos and drums
column6: guitars and vocals bouncing off of one another at just the right angles and moments to bloom into a chorus. During a late-song break
column7: “Incomplete Burning” sprints down a spiral staircase of complication
column8: colorful riffs wrapping like quickly growing vines around the structure. The eight-minute closer moves through slinking post-rock and pulsing New Wave
column9: with Strawn lifting lyrics liberally from Ovid’s Metamorphoses. But there’s a core of incandescent pop at the center of The Missing
column10: too
column11: an anchor that pulls its songs together as Vaura bridges post-punk and black metal
column12: feathered atmospherics and cavalier dexterity. Though The Missing is intense enough to remind you of its members’ respective histories
column13: it is at times disarmingly catchy and surprisingly bright.

column1: There’s perhaps no better summary of Vaura’s success here than “Passage to Vice”
column2: a tune so metrically poised that every piece seems to move in reaction to another. But Strawn speak-sings his way through the verses and stretches out in the hooks. He handles the words with the sort of cool aplomb that suggests the best work of Pinback. Gloom notwithstanding
column3: you’ll want to follow him through the various slinks and soars
column4: to sing along. And there’s “The Fire”
column5: which shrieks open after a lengthy introduction with the most aggressive guitar layers and drum blitzes on the album. The beat is heavy during the verses
column6: but it flares upward as it enters the chorus
column7: dual guitars retrenching the obsidian escalation—that is
column8: the parts you’d normally expect to be the most abrasive and potentially off-putting only bolster Strawn’s exquisite refrain. It’s not a novel technique
column9: as you can hear similar moves from most every atmospheric black metal act. It does
column10: however
column11: illustrate Vaura’s aim of accessibility on The Missing. Alternately
column12: “Incomplete Burning” eases up on its torrent of drums and guitars as it enters the chorus
column13: finding an unexpected middle point between metal and mid-90s college rock. It does not sound altogether unlike the Gin Blossoms’ “Hey Jealousy”.

column1: Selenelion
column2: Vaura’s very good 2012 debut
column3: was a touch longer than The Missing
column4: in part because it incorporated more disparate elements. There was downtrodden folk and a little Sonic Youth-style squall
column5: unabashed deathrock homage
column6: and a touch of tech-metal maul. It felt almost like a DJ mix of its members’ interests
column7: pivoting from one look to another competently
column8: but without too much worry about making it all work as a whole. The Missing not only better integrates these elements but dispatches with some of the more superfluous ones. There’s no folksy interlude
column9: and there are no unnecessary solos. As the record pushes toward its more doleful back half
column10: Strawn’s gothic past wedges toward the spotlight
column11: especially on the excellent and gray “The Things That We All Hide”. It doesn’t feel abrupt. Rather
column12: without those previous distractions
column13: all of these pieces fit into a more cohesive picture
column14: and the melodies ring out that much clearer.

column1: Watching the rollout of reactions to The Missing has offered an intriguing look at the expectations placed upon artists because of their past. To wit
column2: Metal Sucks dismissed The Missing outright for its seeming omission of heaviness
column3: decrying its “fake smoke and eyeliner
column4: lacking any of the blood and sweat and grit that infuses raw life into metal.” But at Echoes and Dust
column5: a reviewer commended the hints of the National and U2 nestled into its heaviness. Writing for Decibel
column6: Adrien Begrand lauded its ambitious mix of post-punk and black metal and Strawn’s “high-gloss 1986-87” gothic tendencies. He called it a “challenging listen
column7: ” though
column8: but here I am mentioning Armistead Burwell Smith IV
column9: the Gin Blossoms
column10: and Mogwai. The Missing
column11: then
column12: seems like a meticulous collage
column13: where the parts that mean the most to you are the parts you’ll find the fastest. Maybe there won’t be enough metal or enough solos or enough eyeliner
column14: or maybe there will be too much of all of it. I sometimes wish it dipped down into mid-tempo trods a bit less. Still
column15: on <i>The Missing
column16: Vaura’s stylistic composite is decisive and deliberate
column17:
putting those pedigrees to use in a surprising and somehow entirely sensible fashion.

column3: What The…

column1: The dwarfing of Black Flag's output by their legend is nothing new. At this stage

column6: the music retains the power to shock. Could this scrappy SoCal punk band really have produced

column1: Henry Rollins became Black Flag's poster boy

column11: Hor

column13: and nearly all completely ignored by both the punk orthodoxy and the jam-band and electronica scenes he began looking to for inspiration. That trend continued right up through 2012

column1: It's in this context that the flawed yet fascinating What The… begins to makes sense. The record's designation as a Black Flag comeback feels completely arbitrary. Sure
column2: its contents bear a superficial resemblance to phase-one Black Flag: it is
column3: in the most general sense
column4: a record of brief
column5: blaring ill-tempered punk songs. In reality
column6: though
column7: it's simply another Greg Ginn brainspew—the latest dispatch from a mercurial
column8: hyperprolific genius who has never had much use for self-editing. Consider this Robert Pollard-ian statistic: on February 26

column12: totally unrelated records—the latest dispatches from the Royal We and Mojack

column16: In My Head

The names Ginn assigns to his projects—even something as seemingly momentous as a new incarnation of Black freaking Flag—are just details; the point is the unforgiving pace
column18: the neverending assembly line that is his creative mind.

column1: Still
column2: to an extent

column6: drummers Robo and Bill Stevenson
column7: frontmen Rollins and Keith Morris—counterweighted and clashed with Ginn's snarling riffs and frayed leads

column10: uninspired rhythm section—Ginn himself on bass
column11: appearing under the Dale Nixon pseudonym he used on My War
column12: and his longtime collaborator Gregory ""Drummer"" Moore—is another story. But iffy execution isn't the main culprit. The record's greatest weakness is its stunted vision: What The… contains flashes of brilliance
column13: but there simply aren't enough good ideas here

column16: 42-minute record.

column1: To its credit

column3: seemingly willfully grating album with a madcap
column4: almost cartoonish feel
column5: epitomized by Ginn's theremin
column6: which turns up frequently as a kitschy accent. The style of the record might be called punk
column7: but it's a punk that feels distinctly 90s
column8: with loud
column9: funky
column10: extroverted bass and swaggery
column11: cornily danceable cadences. (For a representative sample

column1: As baffling as the record's aesthetic is
column2: it yields a handful of really good songs. These make up roughly a third of the album's 22 tracks; issued as an EP
column3: they would've made a much stronger impression than the precariously bloated package that is What The... The crowning jewel is ""The Chase""
