column5: vicious Ginn riffs
column6: each crisper and more catchy than the last. The guitarist's instrumental expression once seemed like the work of an antisocial sadist
column7: but here
column8: as is often the case on What The…
column9: it registers more as the expression of an unflappable stuntman—closer to Dick Dale than Sonny Sharrock. Ginn is similarly incendiary on ""Down in the Dirt""
column10: where he combines spiky eccentricity with no-nonsense rhythmic drive

column12: his lines act as a kind of shadow lead vocal

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Reyes is the unlikely star. For much of the album
column3: he capably portrays the malcontent manchild that is the immortal Black Flag Narrator; on certain tracks
column4: though
column5: he puts his own stamp on the role
column6: summoning a histrionic swagger that's well-suited to the material. On ""Now Is the Time""
column7: he practically croons

column9: egged on by Ginn's raunchy crunch

column11: verging on Glenn Danzig's curled-lip machismo.

column1: Convincing moments aside
column2: the experience of listening to What The… is mostly a matter of sifting through numbing tedium in search of the next misshapen Greg Ginn pearl: the masterfully scribbly solo in ""My Heart's Pumping""
column3: the noxious noise bridge in ""Slow Your Ass Down""
column4: a series of strangulated stun bursts in ""Lies"". Ginn and Moore's rhythm section is a constant stumbling block. They have exactly two settings—a leaden half-time strut and a cowpunky double-time bounce—and zero dynamic range. The record's lopsided mix
column5: in which a deafening field of guitar drowns out the bass and already puny-sounding drums
column6: only foregrounds this deficiency.

column1: Much of the musical material is equally rickety. Too many songs here feel like aggregations of quirky
column2: tossed-off riffs. Tracks like ""I'm Sick""
column3: ""This Is Hell
column4: and ""Wallow in Despair"" are at once so busy and so inert—borderline nauseating in their repetitiveness and indistinguishability—that their titles seem meta. As any fan of mid-to-late-period Black Flag knows
column5: Greg Ginn has never been one to shy away from an aural staring contest; on What The…
column6: though
column7: the perversity of the music often sounds like the result of rushed songwriting rather than purposeful provocation.

column1: The same is true of the lyrics. To peg them as generally bad is close to an objective statement of fact; to single out representative examples seems almost cruel. Henry Rollins shouted innumerable clunkers during his tenure in the band
column2: but lines like this
column3: from ""Blood and Ashes
column4: represent a new low: ""Will you concede to my carnal desire?/ Or will you condemn me for what I aspire?"" Then there's the spoken monologue on ""Lies""—""I live with my anxiety and my angst/ I'm okay with my fear and my doubt/ It's just that I despise what you possess""—which could easily pass as a Fred Armisen-style parody of overserious hardcore. It could be the case that Ginn and Reyes are putting their listeners on throughout What The…
column5: satirizing the staleness of punk rock's middle-finger stance. But it's more likely that the antisocial bluster Reyes yowls on ""The Bitter End""
column6: ""Get Out of My Way""
column7: and countless other songs here was—as much of the music on What The… seems to have been—simply the first thing that came to mind.

column1: In a way
column2: the saddest thing about What The... isn't its glaring shortcomings; it's the fact that
column3: in spots
column4: the record shows real potential. The handful of strong songs have heart and spunk and direction—about as much as one could hope for from the renewed collaboration of two ornery vets such as Ginn and Reyes. Given some time to jell
column5: this version of the band might've eventually developed its own special chemistry
column6: added its own wrinkle to Black Flag's convoluted timeline. But in light of Reyes's departure
column7: What The... will forever be remembered as a stillborn curiosity
column8: a memento of the year that the Black Flag legacy exploded.

column1: It'll be interesting to see what Ginn's next move is
column2: but chances are
column3: whether he's operating under the Black Flag name or one of his countless other brands
column4: his M.O. isn't going to change much. (Case in point: on the same day as What The... drops
column5: Ginn's SST imprint is re-releasing the Good for You LP with no fewer than 29 bonus tracks.) Will the inevitable meteoric thrills be worth the equally inevitable stretches of boredom and bafflement? That's for each listener to decide. Just as it always has
column6:
this target keeps on moving.

so to speak—just as long as they don't drop it.

On “My Beloved”
column2: the opening track on Emily Jane White’s fourth album
column3: you can hear each breath she takes. “You are the master!” she declares on the bridge
column4: punctuating each syllable with long inhalations and slurring one line into the next with a whispery exhalation. The effect is like hearing a guitar player’s fingers slide across strings: It reinforces the idea of the voice as a physical instrument
column5: limited by the body that creates it and unadulterated by any studio adjustments. Including and accentuating those breaths is an easy yet effective vocal technique to convey intimacy and spontaneity
column6: as though you could play “My Beloved” again and it might sound subtly
column7: eerily different.

column1: “Spontaneous” is the key word there. Blood/Lines is White’s fourth album in four years. She pieced these nine songs (eleven
column2: if you count the two bonus tracks on the U.S. version) from more than one hundred song sketches penned during a 22-month period
column3: and she recorded them with a small group of collaborators that includes Marissa Nadler. Those are her ""oohs""in the background of “Faster Than the Devil”
column4: adding a lush cushion for the thundering two-note guitar line and White’s race with her own demons.

column1: By its very Frankenstein nature

column3: prizing sustained melancholy over concise arrangements. And yet
column4: that rocky quality only reinforces the volatile emotions embedded in her lyrics and underscores both the vulnerability of her vocals and their prickly resolve. Those two extremes
column5: along with her downcast arrangements and breathy vocals
column6: have earned White endless comparisons with Hope Sandoval and PJ Harvey

column1: Blood/Lines is best when White finds different ways to achieve that darkly dramatic sound. She drapes these songs in a heavy tapestry of reverb
column2: which threatens to swallow the instruments whole. As a result
column3: the guitar sounds especially sinister
column4: the cello sloshes like rising water
column5: the piano needles and cajoles the listener. The synths and especially the chimes
column6: on the other hand
column7: come across as rote
column8: obligatory: shorthand for easy melancholy. “Wake”
column9: one of the more musically involved numbers
column10: stops cold to indulge some doo wop vocals on the bridge
column11: and the transition is jarring in the best way: unexpected
column12: yet apt
column13: which throws the song in sharp relief. Rather than explore those contrasts
column14: however
column15: the song simply reverts to form
column16: building gradually to a fairly predictable organ-drenched climax.

column1: On its lengthy intro “My Beloved” lets every instrument—guitar
column2: cello
column3: piano—take turns with the lead
column4: as if each is an actor taking a bow. It’s another way to reinforce the live quality of the music
column5: and the friction it creates between the distancing reverb. White alternately invites listeners into her world and keeps them at arms’ length
column6:
and that toggling between direct confession and emotional opacity illuminates the best moments on Blood/Lines. She comes across like an artist who makes music by constantly calculating what to give her audience and what to withhold.

column4: or cartoonish. It's subdued
column5: earthy
column6: and oddly calming. He can spit out lyrics with an effortlessly cool repose
column7: occasionally spilling his words with a Bolan-esque warble. It's a voice that sounds really good next to a loud acoustic guitar—since it's more reserved
column8: the vocals and instrumentals consistently have equal footing.

column1: As the first outing recorded under his own name
column2: Wot puts Donovan in two difficult positions. Not only does it have to live up to the catalog and reputation of his old band
column3: but it's a singer/songwriter album being released by Drag City—the label that puts out Callahan and Oldham records. Occasionally
column4: Donovan will sing something like ""roll away the stone
column5: and his well-tread imagery tends to land with a thud. Perhaps the idea here was to write songs that are earnest and universal like old country ballads. ""Still in Town""
column6: for example
column7: is a complete heartbreaker akin to a George Jones song. Sometimes
column8: though
column9: his sentiments are packaged too tidily; it's difficult to pinpoint the central character and beating heart behind Wot. It's consistently sonically impressive and captivating
column10:
especially when he ushers in a horn section or backs an instrumental track with a haunting whistle. But Wot doesn't feel like an especially personal outpour—it's a well-crafted record that's lyrically dwarfed by the old emoting masters.

"|18659.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18659-mike-donovan-wot/|6.4|Evan Minsker

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19847/homepage_large.b16512c6.jpg|CAPS LOCK|31764.0|Capsule|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Japan'
column2:
'Unborde']|2013-12-03 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:08.107545|"

Since beginning his career in the late 90s
column3: Japanese producer Yasutaka Nakata's maximalist take on electro-pop has turned two acts (techno-pop trio Perfume and model-turned-performer Kyary Pamyu Pamyu) into household names and chart staples in his native country. Capsule
column4: his personal outfit alongside singer Toshiko Koshijima
column5: racked up critical accolades while his more mainstream projects changed the nation’s pop landscape. Recently
column6: his influence has spread across the sea—North American artists Grimes and Passion Pit cite his sound as an inspiration
column7: while his fill-every-second-of-the-track approach predicted the booming EDM sound (popular producer Zedd has mentioned Nakata in interviews).

column1: Caps Lock
column2: Capsule’s 14th studio album and first for Warner Music Japan
column3: could have been his opportunity to jump into the EDM scene he helped shape and turn the spotlight on himself. Instead
column4: he’s made an album thematically structured around a computer keyboard. This is Nakata’s most spacious creation yet
column5: a recording that finds the usually manic Nakata taking time to let ideas develop slowly and indulge in some experimentation. He’s chasing down his own artistic ideas—after spending so long developing others—and ends up with a muted full-length. It isn’t his best work
column6: but it’s among his most interesting.

column1: Nakata's decision to mix things up isn’t a huge surprise
column2: however. Capsule has always been a shifty group sonically
column3: originally working with the globe-hopping sounds of Shibuya-kei
column4: a late-90s style popularized by Cornelius and Pizzicato Five. Those artists jumped to pounding
column5: club-friendly electro-pop
column6: which the pair explored up until the more headphone-friendly Caps Lock. Nakata has included one excellent gateway into his music here with “Control""
column7: a busy number highlighting the cornerstones of his production style. Save for a sparse intro
column8: “Control” bounces forward on a cascade of synthesizers and Koshijima’s digitally warped vocals. He even stuffs in some laser sounds
column9: a nod to his earliest constructions.

column1: Yet nearly everything else on Caps Lock finds Nakata entering new territory. Whereas nearly all his past work burst into life right away
column2: the songs here take their time to develop. “Delete” and “Space” start as minimalistic chugs
column3: Nakata introducing new sonic elements slowly as each plods ahead. His newfound interest in delayed gratification is intriguing
column4: but Nakata still needs to work on finding a climax
column5: as both “Delete” and “Space” press forward without ever reaching a real payoff. It brings to mind the similarly aimless work of (frequent Capsule comparison) Daft Punk on the Tron: Legacy soundtrack.

column1: Nakata also shows off a newfound interest in sampled sounds on Caps Lock. A ticking clock appears during the first leg of “Delete” and plays a more prominent role on “Esc"". The latter track is the most left-field work he’s ever done
column2: less a song and more a field recording of a haunted attic complete with footsteps and whispers. “12345678” places sampled sounds of floorboard creaks and a car horn into a more conventional song structure
column3: and this collage approach makes for an interesting three-minute experiment. Unfortunately
column4: the song lasts just over six minutes
column5: and Nakata’s charming approach soon turns tiring.

column1: Of all the changes to Capsule’s music on this album
column2: the only big misfire is Nakata’s decision to rely on Koshijima’s voice less in his final mixes. She only appears on half of the songs here
column3: and in two instances she’s reduced to nothing much more than single-syllable topping
column4: her addition failing to add much to either “Delete” or “Space"". It’s not that Koshijima boasts great chops—every singer Nakata has worked with gets put through layers of digital manipulation. Yet the processed singing fits in seamlessly in Nakata’s buzzing tracks
column5: and add warmth to his songs. The two best songs on Caps Lock are the ones that let Koshijima linger; on a song like “Shift""
column6: Nakata slices up his singer’s words thin but also rearrange them into catchy android speak.

column1: Caps Lock is the sound of a producer who has spent the last few years dealing almost exclusively with the demands of pop songwriting getting the chance to dump a bunch of ideas out of his head at once
column2: resulting in an album that’s all over the place. It’s a strange
column3: albeit brave
column4: album
column5: given Nakata's current visibility. Caps Lock isn’t the easiest entry into his music
column6:
but features enough great moments to hopefully make people dig into his rich past.   

"|18654.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18654-capsule-caps-lock/|6.1|Patrick St. Michel

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19953/homepage_large.324bfb36.jpg|Live From KCRW|26031.0|Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bad Seed Ltd.']|2013-12-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:08.634089|"

Upon its release last February
column3: Push the Sky Away immediately asserted itself as an outlier amid the Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds catalogue. It was the rare album of theirs to favor vaporous
column4: smoke-ring ambience over the band’s notorious gavel-crushing wallop
column5: and drifting
column6: abstract lyricism over Cave’s usual scripture-scaled narratives. But it’s not like this risky low-key detour hurt their live draw: the Bad Seeds’ spring 2013 tours saw them selling out soft-seaters worldwide
column7: and a recently released 2014 itinerary sees them returning to many of the same markets at even bigger venues. Of course
column8: it helped that Cave and co. amplified and adrenalized Push the Sky Away’s hushed tones with the assistance of guest string sections and children’s choirs
column9: thereby placing the new material on equal footing with the old warhorses. But to prove just how on their game Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds were in 2013
column10: the band offer us a portrait not of a typical night on the job
column11: but of what they can do when chillin’ on a day off.

column1: Live From KCRW was recorded last April during the week separating the Bad Seeds’ two appearances at Coachella (where Cave
column2: Warren Ellis
column3: Martyn Casey
column4: and Jim Sclavunos also pulled double duty with the their bastard-son band Grinderman)
column5: before a small studio audience at the station’s famed Santa Monica studios. And though the Bad Seeds discography is hardly lacking for concert documents—this counts as the fourth—Live From KCRW is
column6: much like Push the Sky Away itself
column7: something of a wild card among them. The Bad Seeds are without a doubt one of the most consistently exhilarating live acts in the biz
column8: a band worthy of any discerning rock fan’s bucket list. But they’re also guilty at times of being a predictable one. Their setlists tend to showcase whatever new album’s being promoted alongside a familiar greatest-hits revue of their most canonical songs from the 1980s and 90s; to see the Bad Seeds on tour this year
column9: you’d think Push the Sky Away was their first album since 1997
column10: their shows rarely touching upon the totemic works released in the interim.

column1: So Live From KCRW is distinguished not just by its loose
column2: casual vibe—with Cave good-naturedly honoring audience requests
column3: provided they’re “on this very short list”—but by its welcome variations from the standard Bad Seeds script with a healthy selection of deep cuts that don't get aired out that often. It begins with Push the Sky Away’s hazy-headed pocket history of modern civilization
column4: “Higgs Boson Blues”
column5: whose Miley Cyrus name-drops elicit audible giggles from the studio attendees. Its appearance here underscores just how perfectly Cave predicted her year
column6: with the line “Hannah Montana/ Does the African Savannah” standing as an almost biblical prophecy of twerk-gate. And the song establishes a marked contrast here between the playful audience interaction and the solemnly reverential readings of some of the most understatedly devastating songs in the Cave songbook. The four Push the Sky Away selections find complementary counterparts in the sublimely sinister Your Funeral My Trial standout “Stranger Than Kindess”
column7: the hymn-like title track to 2001’s No More Shall We Part
column8: and two selections from Cave’s other “quiet” album
column9: The Boatman’s Call: the bittersweet anti-anthem “People Ain’t No Good” and an absolutely stunning “Far From Me” that allows more room for Conway Savage’s funereal organ lines to shine
column10: transforming it from a simple break-up song to a requiem for the ruined relationship chronicled within.

column1: The set’s meditative spell is broken only by the farewell dusting of the old Henry’s Dream rager “Jack the Ripper”
column2: which is revelatory not just as a display of the Bad Seeds’ bruising muscle
column3: but how much effort it takes to flex it. In concert
column4: the Bad Seeds routinely perform with all the cocksure confidence of a band that’s seemingly never had an off night
column5: but the amusing 90 seconds of banter that precede “Jack the Ripper”—wherein Cave confers with his mates about the proper chords and key—betrays a rare
column6: up-close glimpse of the volatility at the root of their imposing sound. At the same time
column7: Live From KCRW shows that the Bad Seeds’ power isn’t entirely dependent on volume. The set’s highlight is a skeletal
column8: piano-based rendition of signature showstopper “The Mercy Seat” that shirks the original’s stormy
column9: cinematic sweep to take us deeper inside the fragile psyche of the song’s electric-chair-bound protagonist; he may claim he’s “not afraid to die
column10: ” but the repeated
column11: intensifying incantations of the chorus make his underlying sense of panic all too palpable. It is therefore no coincidence that
column12: instead of a performance shot
column13: the record's front cover photo shows Cave sitting by his lonesome in the studio amid a sprawl of equipment and road cases. The recordings within reveal the rationale: Even when the Bad Seeds perform in stripped-down mode
column14:
there is still much heavy lifting to do. 

"|18760.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18760-nick-cave-the-bad-seeds-live-from-kcrw/|7.8|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19961/homepage_large.f6c7dfd7.jpg|Touch Five|3038.0|Phill Niblock|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Touch']|2013-12-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:09.389831|"

Phill Niblock’s music asks a lot of you. First
column2: it wants your time: most of his albums are long (the five he’s made for Touch include three 2xCDs and a 3xCD set) and so are the individual pieces (of the 47 currently in my iTunes
column3: 28 last over 20 minutes). The music itself is also demanding
column4: comprising held tones without percussion or anything else conventionally used to mark time. (Niblock doesn’t actually play any instruments; instead he picks notes
column5: records musicians peforming them
column6: then edits and layers the results into drones.) Things change and progress
column7: but it’s slow and subtle; you might not notice unless you skip around a track. So not only do you have to commit substantial time to a Niblock piece
column8: you have to hang in when it feels like it’s taking a lot more.

column1: Early on
column2: Niblock made another demand: that you listen to his music at massive volumes in large spaces that create rich overtones. This wish meant that
column3: as critic Bill Meyer put it
column4: “It makes no more sense to play [Niblock albums] on earbuds or little computer speakers than it would to look at a reproduction of a Rothko on your mobile phone screen.” At first
column5: this restriction kept Niblock from making records altogether. He started composing in the early 1970’s
column6: but didn’t release his debut album
column7: Nothin' to Look at Just a Record
column8: until 1982. As he explains in the liner notes (reproduced in Superior Viaduct’s reissue)
column9: he didn’t want to “relinquish control
column10: ” but acquiesced in order to “reach all of the people that I would like to have experience the music.” He also added
column11: in bold: “PLEASE PLAY THIS RECORD LOUD.”

column1: So why are Niblock’s drones worth this much time and effort? What makes them better than others? It seems like it’d be an easy question
column2: since minimalist drone on the surface is pretty uncomplicated. Yet
column3: paradoxically
column4: the simplicity of tones and apparent lack of change makes drone tricky to analyze. With most other music
column5: you can point to hooks or shifts or moments that give a song unique power. With drone
column6: pretty much the most you can say is that it moves you.

column1: For me
column2: that’s always been true of Niblock’s music. There’s a thrust to his drones; they never float or drift
column3: always moving forward and often at high speed. Technically
column4: that’s an illusion
column5: since the music doesn’t have measurable pace. But on Nothin' to Look at
column6: both sidelong pieces sound like they’re in perpetual motion. Sometimes they roll in waves; at other points they pulse like a buried heartbeat. There’s also a sense of ascent
column7: especially on “A Trombone Piece”
column8: which scales a sonic wall. That’s bit of an illusion too
column9: since Niblock pre-planned his edits before he spliced the tapes
column10: and thus could only guess at their effects. But I imagine he feels it too when he listens to his final compositions.

column1: Once Niblock traded his tape splicer for computer software
column2: he began to compose while editing rather than writing the pieces beforehand. That’s how he constructed the first disc in his new album
column3: Touch Five
column4: which contains two tracks: “Feedcorn Ear”
column5: played on cello by Arne Deforce
column6: and “A Cage of Stars”
column7: which utilizes Rhodri Davies’ harp. Both are enveloping pieces whose only overt difference from what Niblock made 30 years ago is fidelity. They’re clearer and more detailed—easier to hear and focus on—than the rougher tracks on Nothin' to Look at. But they’re just as moving.

column1: Even more exciting is Touch Five’s second disc
column2: which uses a newer Niblock process: scores performed by musicians rather than created from their recordings. “Two Lips” is actually two scores with 20 parts total
column3: all “distributed randomly amongst the musicians.” So the permutations could be infinite
column4: especially since the piece is presented three times by three different guitar quartets. It’s not hard to hear the basic differences between the Zwerm Quartet
column5: the Dither Quartet
column6: and the Coh Da Quartet. What’s more complex is how each lineup creates a different atmosphere. The way each version conjures feelings and images (Niblock himself is a filmmaker
column7: sometimes making films to accompany his music) shows how multi-dimensional his compositions are.

column1: Which ultimately is what makes Niblock’s demands not only worth it
column2: but somewhat irrelevant. You don’t have to accept any of them to enjoy his music. I’ve spent lots of time listening to his work on earbuds or computer speakers
column3: and jumping around tracks rather than listening to each in full. Yet I’ve never left feeling unmoved. His drones are potent because they’re adaptable–whatever time or effort you put into them
column4:
you’ll always get something back.

"|18767.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18767-phill-niblock-nothin-to-look-at-just-a-record/|7.4|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19991/homepage_large.13430502.jpg|Harlem River|31668.0|Kevin Morby|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Woodsist']|2013-12-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:10.456131|"

Considering his career
column2: Kevin Morby’s own shift from buzz band sideplayer to existentially peripatetic frontman is an interesting one. Once upon a time
column3: the Kansas City-bred musician was based in Brooklyn
column4: playing in groups like Woods and the Babies. Now
column5: he lives in Los Angeles and has written Harlem River
column6: a love letter to New York City that transforms its eponymous subject's long stretch of water into a metaphor for a wandering heart.

column1: Within Woods’ discography
column2: Morby's bass-playing wasn’t necessarily meant to suggest the existence of a richly detailed interior. Meanwhile
column3: the Babies were formed from an inside joke and have been self-described as a party band. Harlem River has the same emotional looseness as those groups
column4: but its instrumental texture is more focused: it’s made up of intricately plucked acoustic guitars
column5: shimmering organs
column6: and electric guitars cutting through the negative space like a foglight. And
column7: given the proper room to breathe
column8: Morby’s voice reveals its lazy-day Kansan cadence
column9: sounding not unlike Cass McCombs
column10: Kurt Vile
column11: or any guy with a guitar who’s got something to tell you.

column1: What Morby has to say is unspecific
column2: but no less true. On “Miles
column3: Miles
column4: Miles
column5: ” he alludes to the darkness the song’s protagonist has come from
column6: while offering a wishful portrait of the place he’d like to be. The title track is slow and ponderous
column7: Morby’s voice reduced to a muted creep as he seeks answers from a path showing no end. On “Slow Train”
column8: he sings of not wanting to be destroyed by his temperament while wondering if he’s already missed his chance at redemption. That title
column9: borrowed from the most spiritual of Bob Dylan albums
column10: is surely no coincidence. The song features Cate le Bon
column11: a similarly-minded singer who on her most recent album offered the mournful admission: “I forget the detail/ but know the warmth.” That
column12: more than anything
column13: functions as an explanation of Morby’s creative ethos.

column1: Harlem River is mostly concerned with different shades of subtlety
column2: which makes the rare overt moments stick out like an anarchy patch on a wedding dress. This is an album which references Easy Rider and Bob Dylan and has the temerity to sing a song called “Wild Side” (which is largely concerned with walking) in a recognizably Reedian drawl. That also means Morby’s perhaps quixotic intent to refashion himself as a 60s-era nomad is sometimes undercut by the limitations of his arrangements: the repeating breakdown in “Wild Side” is rhythm-disrupting brittle
column3: and the cowpoke shuffle of “Reign” is a little too on-the-nose in its attempt to tell a modern outlaw tale. But those moments aren’t too distracting. Morby largely succeeds at taking us on his journey
column4:
imploring that the big ""Where am I going?"" question isn't so daunting so long as you keep collecting suggestions.

"|18796.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18796-kevin-morby-harlem-river/|7.0|Jeremy Gordon

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19990/homepage_large.3ec4ce57.jpg|Moods of Future Joy|28086.0|Guido|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tectonic']|2013-12-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:11.035923|"

In a recent Rising feature
column2: Anthony Naples accurately remarked that 18 months was ""a lifetime"" in the hyper-accelerated domain of electronic music. By that metric
column3: Bristol's Guy Middleton—who records as Guido—is knee-deep into a third reprise since his debut full-length dropped. While that particular strain of dubstep has fallen so far out of fashion in the interim as to be a virtually non-existent facet of the wider conversation
column4: this affords favorable conditions for a follow-up. Neither long-since-advanced compatriots nor the decomposing remnants of a scene connive to make the sophomore effort look like a sore-thumb relic. On <i>Moods of Future Joy
column5: the only thing Guido is up against is himself. But that amounts to a tougher battle than expected.

column1: Anidea was graceful
column2: accessible
column3: infectious
column4: and above all immensely fun; a superb record that still stands up as perhaps the peak statement of a short-lived era. The marriage of surging bass swells and enormous hooks
column5: sketched in tones cribbed from R&B and bastardised P-funk
column6: radiated color and not just the ""purple"" sound with which it become synonymous. That tag came to hamstring Gemmy and Joker
column7: fellow Bristolians in the triumvirate
column8: whose blatant desire to shift away resulted in ill-fortune—total stasis in the case of the former
column9: misguided crossover hybrids aimed at U.S. gamers in the case of the latter—something unwisely attempted in the sagging middle of Moods with the third rate TNGHT blare of ""NRG"". During the heat of widespread interest
column10: when sparkplug Joker was leading the pack with jagged bombast
column11: Guido appeared more content to mosey behind
column12: eyes fixed toward the sky
column13: conjuring up moments of opulence
column14: clarity and downright loveliness. Those exist here
column15: but are populated more sparsely
column16: and often take dull slogs to prise out.

column1: Traditionally
column2: Guido's classically-attuned ear has helped push his songs beyond the limitations of a relatively rudimentary digital setup. The healthy balance struck between floor-filling and after-hours appeal is an uncommon trait when juxtaposed with the sawtooth aggression of his then-peers. So it's disappointing to find Moods padded with a clutch of amateurish numbers that wouldn't warrant more than brief pause during any given Soundcloud trawl. The aforementioned ""NRG"" is one; the underwhelming ""Midnight Savannah"" another. Both vocal tracks prove to be missteps: Lead single 'Green Eyed Monster''s snaggy synth and lowpass scree make an awkward fit for Emma-Lou's undercooked contributions
column3: and ""Letting Go"" would provide better support for her thin voice were it not for the lack of dynamism
column4: letting flat beats topple weakly.

column1: Guido's approach to embellishing tracks has lost some of its nuance
column2: supplanted by a more clumsy approach to gluing certain elements together. Full-bodied percussive timbres
column3: subdued pads and an echo-drenched guitar lead all build to a thrilling climax on ""Afrika Pt.2""
column4: but only after a leaden UK funky beat is allowed far too much time to calcify while nakedly exposed
column5: negating the final triumph. It's a recurring problem
column6: weakening other strong set-pieces across the board. The grin-inducing bridge on ""Heartful Dodger"" evokes sinking into Super Mario pipes
column7: but only as an escape mechanism from vocoder'd lyrics that fall worrying close to Chromeo's whiny talkbox. Confusingly
column8: the same cheap effect is utilised in a similarly irritating manner on ""Lucky Git""
column9: distracting from a bouncing bassline and pensive synth lead that wouldn't sound out of place in an unearthed 2-step treasure from 1997.

column1: Only two cuts really shine outright
column2: and its no coincidence that both map out a softer deviation. Grandiose tom rolls bring the immensely cheery lead on ""Same Road"" crashing through stained-glass windows
column3: working in a classic Guido lineage that feels like a familiar hand on your shoulder. It shares a dainty atmosphere with the germane standout ""Kalm""
column4: a billowy number that melds a gooey centre with hobbling
column5: plucked strings that leave delicately textured contrails as they fade. It would round proceedings off tastefully
column6: but the serenity is allowed no time to manifest before the thick
column7: adventurous ""Squeaky Jungle"" storms through. It's a decent track in its own right
column8: but a perplexing choice to close the album out.

column1: Nothing on Moods of Future Joy is overtly bad
column2: but there's scant to get especially excited about. Guido is still an adept producer with a canny knack for a pleasing melody
column3: but treads water far more than he should. On Moods Of Future Joy he settles for a middle ground
column4: diluting a winning formula. In doing so
column5:
he repositions the remaining streaks of brilliance as frustratingly slippery.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19811/homepage_large.98abc616.jpg|Everlast|31733.0|Perera Elsewhere|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Friends of Friends']|2013-12-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:11.606708|"

LA label Friends Of Friends continues its crusade into Berlin with another signing
column2: this time singer-songwriter Perera Elsewhere. She's easily the label's most surprising addition yet
column3: though her smoky atmospherics are of the mood music variety preferred by many of the crew. A member of downtempo trio Jahcoozi (alongside producers Robot Koch and Oren Gerlitz)
column4: you might otherwise recognize her sultry tones from Modeselektor's ""Silikon
column5: back when she went by given name Sasha Perera. But on Everlast
column6: her solo debut
column7: she mostly abandons the smooth electronica of her past in favour of a gothic atmosphere that actually kind of sounds like it was recorded in a frigid castle
column8: her vocals echoing through chambers of cold stone.

column1: Perera has the kind of breathy
column2: sighing tone that complements well-groomed
column3: trip-hoppy electronic music—the kind you'd expect to hear in the background at a public place
column4: unobtrusive and pleasing to the ear. But laid naked on <i>Everlast
column5: there's a spooky and beguiling quality to it. The album opens with the bluesy strum of ""Drunk Man""
column6: where her vocals are appropriately slurred so you can just barely make out the words. Her quiet voice is accompanied by steady drums and a distinctly wooden thump of a bassline—earthy sounds with sanguine accents that feel like a deliberate reaction to the perfect production of her other work. It's not very often you hear of an expat in Berlin who tries so hard to sound acoustic.

column1: Not that the production is an afterthought; every element is touched with some level of reverb and so neatly placed that you'll wonder which are judiciously-chosen samples
column2: and which were actually played by hand. Hard-panned multitracking and other stereo spectrum tricks makes the Gonjasufi duet ""Giddy"" captivating in spite of its stupor
column3: and pitch-shifting on ""Shady"" lends it an ethereal feel underpinned by implacable noises that sound like guitar strings being melted and stretched like taffy. She even plays off a  ghostly
column4: masculine version of herself on ""Carousel
column5: whose simple chorus echoes the bare desperation of Neil Young's Ditch Trilogy—it's amazing the amount of emotional mileage she can get out of merely repeating and enunciating a single word
column6: especially when she's doing it over guitar chords that drip with anguish.

column1: Indeed
column2: as thoughtful as the production on Everlast might be
column3: it's simplicity that's key. Album highlight ""Dreamt That Dream"" isn't much more than a few mantra-like phrases stuck together and rolled off Perera's tongue almost carelessly
column4: but it proves intoxicating in the album's walk-in freezer of an echo chamber. It works the same magic on the heavy-handed political didactic (and first single) ""Bizarre"". Her lyrics (""money's running everything/ the same ten families that run the show/ friends with the president and friends with the Pope"") amount to high-school-level social commentary
column5: but set against a distant synth whine and decisive acoustic guitar
column6: it's like a 60s protest song dressed up in modern clothes.

column1: Most of all
column2: Perera Elsewhere’s debut is a defiantly quiet record in a scene of maximalism; compare it to the oversaturated landscapes of her labelmates Shlohmo or Groundislava
column3: or the rhythmic attack of Salva
column4: and she's an obvious outlier. But not that much of an outlier; Friends Of Friends has always had a knack for finding artists whose sense of pathos borders on maudlin but usually end up on the right side of the divide. The same goes for Everlast
column5: where even the most earnest moments
column6: like the baroque ""Light Bulb"" or the self-consciously trippy ""Bongoloid""
column7: become captivating thanks to her unforgettable voice and cultivated ethereality. It’s a short but penetrating record of far-away
column8: foggy reveries that’ll burrow its way into your consciousness until it haunts you
column9:
one breath after another.

"|18618.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18618-perera-elsewhere-everlast/|7.8|Andrew Ryce

Hardcore Thee Oh Sees fans get this glint in their eyes
column2: sometimes
column3: that stirs a certain reflexive distrust in me. ""What's the one I need?"" I will ask
column4: seeking to get a hold of a discography as pervasive as mist. ""Oh
column5: they're all good
column6: comes the too-often
column7: earnest reply
column8: as my heart sinks. They're all good? That's not an answer; that's a ""Keep Out"" sign. There are mediocre Beatles LPs
column9: unnecessary Miles Davis records
column10: lesser works by Mozart and Beethoven. How can they all be good?

column1: For their devoted followers
column2: though
column3: Thee Oh Sees have become the only band they'll ever need. This is a tremendous achievement
column4: requiring a demented level of commitment
column5: both to a glass-eating touring and release schedule and to a narrow aesthetic. Dwyer's got both
column6: in spades
column7: and it has brought him to where he is now: ""It took me 35 years
column8: but I was able to make art for a living
column9: he told Evan Minsker in 2012. The Singles Collections are a periodic Hoover vac-ing of the couch-cushion change that tumbles from view during John Dwyer's frantic music dispersal
column10: but they are also a service to people on the sidelines like us. They make an excellent tasting-platter way to engage with a band that usually demands steak-for-two (for one) levels of commitment.

column1: If you can make generalizations about John Dwyer's output with Thee Oh Sees
column2: it's that he likes the sound of bad feelings
column3: cheerfully expressed
column4: and he's drawn to explore the spot where vamps harden into palsies. You can hear both of these preoccupations at work in the ten songs here (plus one live cut)
column5: collected from Flexi discs
column6: split 7""s
column7: artist compilations
column8: and elsewhere. A few of the songs on this collection are recognizably ""singles"" in tone and form— ""Ugly Man
column9: ""Wait Let's Go
column10: ""Always Flying
column11: ""Devil Again"" all have at least three chords
column12: run four minutes or less
column13: and have ""ba-ba-ba"" choruses. But most of them head directly into that kinked-up corner of the song that repeatedly pulls at Dwyer's imagination
column14: the spot where the song's narrative action swings shut and the groove hinges open.

column1: The vamp is where the action is for Dwyer
column2: and Thee Oh Sees have as many different ways to vamp as the National have to sound regal
column3: as Richard Pryor had to say ""motherfucker."" ""What You Need"" is jerky and brittle
column4: evoking the neural-damage sense of ""rocking."" ""Burning Spear"" creaks and protests like a rusty mattress coil. ""FB12"" rides a repeating bass-note octave like a low-grade migraine. The vamp is Dwyer personified: A mixture of mania and stasis
column5: a way of pacing while standing still. For Dwyer
column6: it's a reason for living.

column1: It's also a template: If you are given to maintaining a breakneck and frankly absurd creative clip
column2: keeping a mental catalog of vamps proves handy—a few of the biggest
column3: boldest lines are already down when you start working. The album concludes with two ten minute pieces—""Block Of Ice (Live at the SF Eagle)"" and a live version of ""Destroyed Fortress"" from 2009's Help—that boil Thee Oh Sees all the way down to their purest essence. The drums thump a back beat with the determination of a toddler wielding a toy hammer
column4: the bass line jigs in place
column5: and Dwyer rips open his guitar to the skies. The idea of ""song"" disintegrates
column6: and the long straight line of the vamp takes over. For him and for his faithful
column7:
it's a gathering place. 

"|18783.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18783-thee-oh-sees-singles-collection-volume-three/|7.8|Jayson Greene

house']|2013-11-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:12.897596|"

It's not hard distinguishing the work of Grouper's Liz Harris from that of Jefre Cantu-Ledesma on their collaborative debut
column3: Event of Your Leaving
column4: a fact that speaks to the singularity of their respective approaches. Formulating a signature musical language is especially impressive within the abstracted terrain of ambient drone and wordless dream-pop
column5: where they've each made some of the most distinctive sounds of the past decade. Harris
column6: with her analog and oft-depressed toolbox of charcoal drones
column7: acoustic strums
column8: and ethereal singing
column9: has arguably been the most prominent artist working in this realm. But Cantu-Ledesma
column10: also of San Francisco post-rock band Tarentel since the 1990s
column11: is a fixture in his own right
column12: having delivered around two-dozen releases for labels like Type
column13: Blackest Rainbow
column14: and his own
column15: Root Strata. Cantu-Ledesma's drones are dense
column16: bright
column17: and harsh
column18: most cohesively captured on 2010's compulsively listenable Love Is a Stream—a properly mesmeric attempt at teasing the ecstatic essence from Loveless-style shoegaze noise
column19: amping his deconstructions into the red while capturing the blissed out totality of real love.

column1: Event of Your Leaving
column2: a project in-process for at least two years
column3: proves just how complementary these seemingly conflicted aesthetic spirits can be. Where Harris makes subtle
column4: interior
column5: and dread-laced music that often sounds buried underground—it can feel embedded with existential questions of mortality and death
column6: and did so explicitly on this year's The Man Who Died in His Boat—Cantu-Ledesma makes blown-out
column7: skybent music
column8: with the affect of something heavenly pouring down. Where Grouper works with images of the natural world and somber moods
column9: Cantu-Ledesma's beaming washes of pastel-shaded white noise are optimistic; his song titles have included ""White Dwarf Butterfly"" and ""Stained Glass Body""
column10: carrying the romance of a love poem or emergency meditation. Grouper's music can recall the tapestry of William Basinski's decaying tape loops
column11: but Cantu-Ledesma's radiates as if possessing regenerative power. If Grouper is the inexplicable feeling just after loss
column12: Cantu-Ledesma's is recovery. Both produce emotionally overwhelming drone abstractions with unconventional beauty. They use idiosyncratic tones to articulate things that are unspeakable.

column1: This duality is absolutely crushing on Side A. Cantu-Ledesma's blistering noise allows crevices of space to fill in and contribute a certain brightness and color
column2: as if poking holes so that rays can shine through
column3: while Harris' drones ground the sound. It is damaged and euphoric
column4: and often sounds as if there is a steady wind churning through while the sun beams down
column5: capped with the somewhat confounding angelic or supernatural aura that is quintessential of Grouper. The repetition of 13-minute opener ""In Stellar Orbit"" is like a massage for your brain cells—the gentle
column6: circling abrasion underpinned by light and occasionally skull-piercing noise
column7: gorgeous and grating as it floats off. ""Blood Moon"" is the energetic epitome of the project
column8: reaching the record's visceral peak while simultaneously managing to amp its grace. The defining characteristics of Cantu-Ledesma's sound are here
column9: coupled with layered drones that could be a distant choir.

column1: A noticeable sadness marks Event of Your Leaving's second side. The cinematic title track is the record's shortest
column2: and seems to function like an overture. The light is drained as a swell of downcast drones are marked by minor piano keys and oscillated vocal parts that recall Grouper's earlier records. The flecks of piano are brighter on ""In Held Company"" and there are sublime negotiations throughout
column3: between the severity of the austere instrumentation and featherlight vocals—and later
column4: between the track's considerable white space and a soliloquy of drone. An anxious
column5: distressing rumble permeates the record as it closes
column6: and though the album imposes no narrative
column7: there is an undeniable trajectory from innate hope to total loss of vitality. Event shows this process with no resolution
column8:
just honest closure fading into silence.

"|18784.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18784-raum-event-of-your-leaving/|7.9|Jenn Pelly

The wholeness of Shearwater’s aesthetic is an admirable quality
column2: and one that lets people know right off the bat if the band's “not their thing.” Even before you hear Jonathan Meiburg’s operatic vocals
column3: the ornate
column4: orchestral arrangements give you the suspicion that his concerns are birds
column5: snow leopards
column6: horses
column7: and golden archipelagos. This makes a Shearwater covers album an intriguing proposition and also a risky one: can anyone else’s songwriting survive in these conditions? So it’s even more interesting that this collection is called Fellow Travelers; sure
column8: it’s taken from Trotsky
column9: but all the same
column10: it lets you know who Shearwater see as not only their role models
column11: but also their peers. Coldplay and St. Vincent? Sure. Xiu Xiu? Well
column12: Meiburg has collaborated with Jamie Stewart in Blue Water White Death. Folk Implosion? Um.

column1: But any discussion of Fellow Travelers needs to begin with “I Luv The Valley OH!” It’s not only the definitive Xiu Xiu because it’s the best song Jamie Stewart has written. It’s also a song that couldn’t be written or performed by anyone besides Jamie Stewart
column2: at least not effectively. Even beyond the music itself
column3: a perverse mocking of glimmering
column4: hopeful alt-rock
column5: the vocals are sui generis Xiu Xiu where you can’t tell if it’s a legitimate cry for help or Stewart prank calling the suicide hotline. If you don’t have his track record
column6: it’s a lot tougher to pull off lines like “there’s a razor
column7: make a million billion threats” and “my behind is a beehive/ there's a buzz in my backside
column8: ” while slipping into incorrect French. Shearwater’s take is over-the-top in its own way—it just turns “I Luv The Valley OH!” into a goddamn stadium anthem with swooping bass and a constant
column9: reverbed kick drum replacing the erratic
column10: mortar rounds that punctuated the original. Sheared and watered down
column11: the palpable danger of Stewart’s performance is replaced with cocksure pomp—while the exclamatory cry of the title in the original is one of the most harrowing
column12: cathartic yells ever caught on tape
column13: Meiburg’s haughty
column14: oratorial style makes it sound like high school Shakespeare or just any old “oh”. I think Meiburg’s heart is in the right place here
column15: but you take Jamie Stewart out of “I Luv The Valley OH!” and you’re just left with a song that has a nice melody.

column1: As it turns out
column2: Shearwater can somehow take the edge off a Coldplay song as well. “Hurts Like Heaven” was indicative of Coldplay’s pure-pop ambitions on Mylo Xyloto
column3: giving Chris Martin’s vocals Autotune tweaks and the rhythm section a blinding sheen. Here
column4: it’s a pretty
column5: weightless piano ballad that’s closer to the stereotyped ""Coldplay"" that gets played for cheap laughs in major motion pictures. On the other hand
column6: St. Vincent’s “Cheerleader” and Folk Implosion’s “Natural One” are given straight
column7: respectful covers
column8: but once again make a great case for the necessity of character. “Cheerleader” loses its lyrical bite without the context Annie Clark had created throughout her body of work
column9: and while “Natural One” was included in the most absurdly grim movie about teenage sex ever made
column10: Lou Barlow managed to capture the occasional fumbling and pure lust behind it all. A key line is “when mama’s not around
column11: there’s no telling what we’ll do when we’re free.” Meiburg’s imperious vocals can evoke the mating rituals of majestic condors
column12: but not that.

column1: When Shearwater don’t have to compete with an original's familiarity or strong personality
column2: Fellow Travelers succeeds by doing a service for overlooked artists. In its original form
column3: David Thomas Broughton’s “Ambiguity” was the sort of thing that typically becomes an artist-beloved lost treasure
column4: a gut-wrenching sentiment wrapped up in a six-minute
column5: static-laced avant-folk song. It benefits from Shearwater’s immaculate
column6: harp-led arrangement
column7: which foregrounds the melody and lyrics. The same goes for Baptist Generals’ “Fucked Up Life”; Shearwater’s fellow Dentonites list a litany of relatable punishments and while it’s not that far off in subject matter from  “I Luv The Valley OH!”
column8: Meiburg’s performance is much more suited to the source material.

column1: Most revelatory of all is “Tomorrow”. It was the second single from Clinic’s 2008 LP Do It!
column2: which found the band well into a stage of their career that Shearwater is just entering: where you’re perceived to have a “thing” and that thing is kinda taken for granted. If you didn’t recognize “Tomorrow”
column3: it’s much easier to spot its Clinic tics after the fact—the circular bassline
column4: the pinch melody. The cover here gives a mutual benefit
column5: opening up Shearwater’s sound in subtle ways while putting a focus on Ade Blackburn’s actual songwriting acumen
column6: which is rarely given a close reading.

column1: Shearwater never sound like a band that does things for the hell of it
column2: though you can understand how they’d benefit from Fellow Travelers regardless of the outcome. Last year's Animal Joy showed a band trying to let loose
column3: just a little
column4: even if they can’t truly sound like anyone else as long as Meiburg is at the lead. But it did at least show the group trying to rock
column5: trying to groove. Fellow Travelers can be seen as Shearwater showing their scratch work
column6: and while great cover albums can be a revelation or an embarrassment
column7: most end up right around here: which is to say
column8:
admirable and flawed. Few things can be tougher for an artist than to purely express themselves. Expressing what they like about another artist is often one of them.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19951/homepage_large.f2a0dfe1.jpg|Desert Skies|311.0|Beachwood Sparks|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Alive']|2013-11-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:14.007562|"

Before they joined forces in the mid 1990s
column2: the members of Beachwood Sparks 1.0 were in a lot of bands that didn’t sound anything like Beachwood Sparks. Bassist Brent Rademaker was in Further
column3: who sounded so much like Sonic Youth that Lee Ranaldo guested on their debut. Josh Schwartz and Tom Sanford were in an act called Winter Kills that cribbed its slack from Pavement
column4: while Chris Gunst did time in the horribly named hardcore band Strictly Ballroom (which also featured Jimmy Tamborello). Playing in Beachwood Sparks was a means of “shaking loose the indie rock shackles
column5: ” writes Rademaker in the liners to Desert Skies
column6: which the band recorded in 1997 as its debut but is only now getting around to releasing. Theirs was a very calculated and deliberate move to West Coast country pop; trading Dinosaur Jr for the International Submarine Band and Stephen Malkmus for Gene Clark was an emancipation of sorts from the strictures of indie-rock distortion and obscurity. Their music featured pedal steel and peaceful easy choruses
column7: not to mention vintage western shirts
column8: rodeo denim
column9: and well-worn Wallabees.

column1: These five dudes—along with percussionist Pete “Sleigher” Kinne—embraced both the music and the lifestyle with the fervency of acolytes. They were not only defining themselves
column2: but also defining in even more emphatic terms what they were not. Beachwood Sparks was not another indie rock band. They had something like a mission
column3: and it went well beyond
column4: as Rademaker writes
column5: “to get high and play music; and to get high and listen to music.” They were reviving Los Angeles as a rock-and-roll town
column6: shifting the focus from post-STP trend jumpers to a scene rooted in the region’s pop history. Whatever subversive quality that goal might have possessed in 1997 is lost in 2013—not only because L.A. has a pretty bustling indie scene but also because the Beachwoods has seemingly sparked so many other acts
column7: some great
column8: others not so much. Cosmic American music has never sounded quite so earthbound as it does this far into the twenty-first century.

column1: At the tail end of the twentieth
column2: however
column3: the members of Beachwood Sparks were only just learning the language of West Coast country pop. Steeping themselves in Gram Parsons
column4: Buffalo Springfield
column5: and Bradley’s Barn-era Beau Brummels
column6: they had not yet figured out how to put their own stamp on the music
column7: or even what they’re stamp would sound like. Instead
column8: at this stage they were primarily mimics
column9: more intent on re-creating a particular sound than on putting it toward sturdy songs. On “Make It Together""
column10: the theremin sounds like it has quote marks and a footnote attribution to “Good Vibrations.” Dutifully
column11: the guitars chime and riff like the Byrds; the voices harmonize like CSN&Y. Only on the four relatively lo-fi bonus tracks does the music retain any real urgency or revel in its rough edges.

column1: On the other hand
column2: should we expect anything more than that from any band at this stage in its development? There is something commendable about the rambunctious energy they bring to the title track and the reasonably spacey “Canyon Ride”
column3: even if it’s routinely undermined by the retreating vocals and their crate-digger reverence. Despite their L.A. origins
column4: Beachwood Sparks isn’t a troupe of actors staging a period piece. They’re trying to revive this style of music
column5: to prove it can say as much in 1997 as it did in 1970. Opinions vary as to whether or not the band ever managed to make this sunbaked sound their own. Sixteen years after these initial sessions—ten of which they spent on hiatus—they remain a surprisingly divisive band
column6: with detractors accusing them of imitating rather than innovating. Desert Skies does absolutely nothing to answer that criticism
column7: but it does provide a useful point against which to measure their later efforts. Compare this release to last year’s The Tarnished Gold
column8: which was heavy with comedown melancholy
column9:
and it’s not hard at all to see how far they’ve come.

CREEP seemed to fade away before they really got started. The Brooklyn-based duo of Lauren Dillard and Lauren Flax showed promise with their 2010 single ""Days""
column2: only to find their momentum diluted by a minor controversy and an affiliation with a fly-by-night genre. That song was a joint effort with Romy Madley Croft from the xx
column3: who was the first in a string of collaborators to come on board with Dillard and Flax to help flesh out the band's sound. CREEP have surfaced intermittently over the last three years
column4: often as remixers

column6: Alejandra Deheza of School of Seven Bells)
column7: on an oft-delayed album that plunges into the darkness and never looks back
column8: pulling in a mix of old and new tracks on the way down.

column1: If nothing else
column2: Echoes is a timely release
column3: coming at a point when artists such as Arca
column4: FKA twigs
column5: and DropxLife are developing a potent strain of 21st century trip-hop. Where those artists take the genre as a starting point
column6: CREEP remain fully immersed in the sound
column7: siphoning off some of its dingiest moments as a primal source. As such
column8: Echoes is more Mezzanine than Blue Lines

column10: and with a different guest vocalist on each
column11: it's a surprisingly coherent and linear album. ""Days"" doesn't sound out of place from (presumably) more recent recordings
column12: such as the mournful ""Vertigo""

column1: In among the shade there's a sense of drama forcing through the fog
column2: with most tracks shaped by sparse arrangements and echo-y vocals. It has the unfortunate effect of making CREEP sound like they're trying too hard to make a bold statement with every turn they take
column3: perpetually searching for a spine-chilling moment that's just beyond their reach. Mostly the execution is lacking—the beats on ""Empty Church"" are ghostly thin
column4: the synths on ""Jessica King"" are set to the ""plume of smoke"" preset for the nth time
column5: the Sia-featuring ""Dim the Lights"" rubs stodgy strings up against a too-predictable music box sound. The guest vocalists occasionally shine despite their surroundings. Tricky's turn on ""Call Her"" is particularly notable
column6: reaching whispery Maxinquaye peaks while Deheza works up perfectly floaty harmonies behind him.

column1: What binds the original trip-hop artists
column2: who were reluctant (to say the least) to be grouped together under the banner
column3: was a sense of people digging deep into introspection
column4: often reaching a point that was uncomfortably personal. There was a grit to what they were doing
column5: a sense of beats that had been labored over for months
column6: of samples that had been endlessly tweaked through the night. Echoes
column7: despite its long gestational period
column8: resembles the work of a couple of ""Twin Peaks"" freaks playing trip-hop dress up
column9: even going so far as to channel David Lynch collaborator Julee Cruise on ""The Key"". Their best moment is still the skittering ""Days""
column10:
but sticking a song from 2010 on an album from 2013 feels like the actions of a band who are coming up short of ideas on how to move forward.

column3: “The Fall” seemed to appear out of nowhere
column4: a tantalizing
column5: faceless wisp of sultry R&B without a bio blurb’s worth of context. As details slowly congealed leading up to the release of Rhye’s excellent debut album Woman this past March
column6: many listeners were introduced to Michael Milosh
column7: the man—and yes
column8: many were reluctant to believe
column9: that’s totally a dude—who was effortlessly braiding his voice through Robin Hannibal’s silky tracks. Milosh has been producing and releasing his own music for nearly a decade via L.A.’s Plug Research
column10: a label with an aesthetic of high-polish adult contempo grooves personified by the Toronto transplant. That same voice is in peak form on Jetlag
column11: but if you discovered Milosh via Rhye
column12: don’t expect to hear it surrounded by the same kind of sultry soul. Left to his own devices
column13: Milosh prefers chillier confines.

column1: First
column2: a word on that voice
column3: which—stay with me here—reminds me of no less than Michael McDonald
column4: in a specific and positive way. The two evoke different types of soul—McDonald’s furry baritone is a simulacrum of church-trained 60s and 70s belters while Milosh’s lithe countertenor owes much more to the hushed tones of Quiet Storm legends Sade and Anita Baker—but they’re equally transfixing
column5: in a way that suggests an uncannily human android programmed to the “soul” setting. Each voice doesn’t sound like the product of training as much as something that automatically emanated the first time they set themselves to try and sing. Much in the same manner that McDonald manifested his alien instrument as a radiant background production cog on Steely Dan’s infinitely layered productions
column6: Milosh prefers to highlight the otherworldly affects of his voice. At several points on Jetlag
column7: he ceases singing words and simply weaves his wordless croon amidst the other ProTool layers
column8: creating the sensation that you’re driving past his voice as it sits on the side of a highway at night. Milosh’s skill in twisting and stretching his voice is his greatest gift as an artist. The way he and Hannibal gently interweave layers of these feather-light sighs at the start of “Major Minor Love""
column9: for instance
column10: is a highlight of the Rhye LP.

column1: Milosh’s crisp electronic soundscapes work mainly as contrast
column2: immaculate bedding designed to melt away as his warm voice slithers in. At his best on Jetlag
column3: Milosh builds up his tracks in the simple interest of pulling them back to let the vocal take over. The first minute of “Hear in You” is a perfect example of this. The first minute of the song is pieced together from the Junior Boys/Apparat template of chilly electro-pop
column4: but merely serves as walk-on music for the dramatic reveal of the track’s simple hook
column5: on which Milosh stretches a syllable—the “ohhh” at the end of “know”—at just the right time
column6: for just the right duration
column7: and repeats it over and over. The effect is a specific kind of listening pleasure
column8: of the late-90s/early 2000s post-Portishead/Massive Attack moment
column9: when groups like Zero 7 and Morcheeba boiled off trip-hop’s sense of danger
column10: leaving it with a glut of sticky mood. When songs from that “chillout” moment of electro-R&B are done well—like Zero 7’s shimmering “Destiny
column11: ” say—they nail a perfect middleground between passion and propriety. “Hear in You” finds itself in that orbit
column12: as does “Don’t Call It”
column13: on which Milosh dips into his more gutsy lower register amidst what sounds like an adult-contempo remake of Radiohead’s Amnesiac.

column1: The passion and yearning of “Destiny” was of a particular sort
column2: Sia Furler opening the song by admitting to watching porn in her hotel dressing gown. This style of longing for human contact to counteract the cold
column3: sterilized distance of travel is all over Jetlag
column4: recalling another turn-of-the-century groove-based album: Thievery Corporation’s The Mirror Conspiracy
column5: a cosmopolitan soundtrack for a specific kind of jetsetting rich guy—“Smooth Operator”s trust-funded step-son. Jetlag draws from this DNA
column6: though Milosh evokes a starker
column7: more purposefully mundane scenario: a design firm executive coldly shuffling a leatherbound portfolio through people movers in stark-white airports
column8: and glassily staring into the near distance. It’s impossible for Milosh’s voice not to signify desire
column9:
and Jetlag is an album on which the glow of intimate passions arises from immaculate interior design.

Mick Turner’s music rocks and lurches
column3: yaws and tacks like a small boat in choppy water. Throughout his career as a band member and solo artist
column4: but especially on his new album <i>Don’t Tell the Driver
column5: the Australian guitarist favors listing rhythms and loose meters that suggest unrehearsed spontaneity but also tribulation
column6: peril
column7: even a touch of seasickness. “All Gone""
column8: which opens <i>Driver
column9: builds from a hard rustle of drums and shakers
column10: then adds a scrambling guitar riff that sounds like it’s trying to shake itself free of the undertow. It’s a compact
column11: concise musical drama
column12: impressionistic in its action yet specific in its desperate
column13: determined mood. It’s not difficult to imagine the story
column14: such as it is
column15: unfolding within the frame of the seaside landscape on the album cover
column16: which Turner himself painted.

column1: Best known as one third of the Melbourne-based instrumental band the Dirty Three
column2: Turner also has also hired out (with Dirty drummer Jim White) as a backing band for such artists as Cat Power
column3: Nina Nastasia
column4: and Nick Cave. Over the course of a twenty-five-year career
column5: he has learned to strike a very careful balance: On one hand
column6: he has developed a distinctive playing style
column7: one that draws from a range of styles
column8: yet he can become dutifully invisible behind a charismatic vocalist or lead instrumentalist. As a solo artist
column9: he proceeds slowly but not hesitantly; Don’t Tell the Driver is his first in six years. In between projects
column10: he worked on these songs for about four years
column11: recording in fits and starts at Big Moth Studio in Melbourne. Yet the album never sounds labored or unfocused.

column1: Turner has hinted
column2: perhaps in jest
column3: that Don’t Tell the Driver is intended to be a “post-rock opera
column4: ” which is way too much clever concept than the music can shoulder. Its emotional palette is too subdued to be described as operatic
column5: and if there’s any narrative stretching between these eleven songs
column6: it’s implied rather than stated
column7: conveyed through that musical lurch than through the usual plot points and sung exposition. Driver is
column8: however
column9: his most vocally oriented solo album to date
column10: featuring Melbourne-based musician and visual artist Caroline Kennedy-McCracken on nearly half the songs. Even as she settles into the protagonist role
column11: her voice proves far more interesting as a musical instrument than as a device to convey lyrical meaning. On “Here’s a Way”
column12: she toggles between a traditionally melodic verse and a chorus bends her syllables and dissolves them into the hums and moans of the music
column13: creating a starkly dreamy contrast. On the title track
column14: however
column15: Kennedy-McCracken breaks the words down to their barest syllables and sustains her notes steadily
column16: mimicking the straight brushstrokes of the horns to suggest a moment of calm amid the storm of music.

column1: Thanks to the presence of McCracken and classical vocalist Oliver Mann
column2: who sounds like Neptune himself on “Over Waves""
column3: it’s easy to forget that Driver is a guitar player’s album. Turner often takes lead
column4: but just as often he hangs back in the tangle of music. His playing is subtle and varied
column5: ranging from pensive electric notes to knotted acoustic rhythms. The aptly titled “The Last Song” builds patiently to a series of crests and troughs
column6: pitting Turner’s shimmery guitar against Ian Wadley’s frayed snare rhythms
column7: yet the mood is not triumphant or climactic but reflective. In fact
column8: the song seems to fall apart in the process of playing it. Perhaps that what Turner means when he calls Driver a post-rock opera
column9: yet overall it plays as something much less ambitious yet much more useful to a listener. It’s a fluidly cohesive album that develops its music themes—that nautical lurch
column10:
that calming lull—over eleven carefully yet imaginatively arranged songs.

Gabriel Fulvimar lives in Burger Records. If you’re familiar with the Fullerton
column2: Calif.
column3: garage-rock stronghold
column4: pretend you aren’t and put yourself in the position of a person who only knows that the Gap Dream frontman is living inside of a record store that also happens to be his label's office. And not even one of those 90s mega-chains like Tower or Sam Goody that could pass for a luxury apartment. It’s not even Amoeba. It’s the kind of place that tends to thrive in the current economy
column5: a nationally recognized local joint that caters to a faithful and specific demographic. But consider the logistics: does a Burger Records patron that’s just looking for an Unkle Funkle cassette run the risk of bumping into a shirtless
column6: hungover Fulvimar if he happened to have a long night? Does he have a security deposit? Are you liable to find an opened box of Cookie Crisp in the vinyl section?

column1: Jokes aside
column2: Fulvimar’s current home address is the first step in establishing a narrative that steers you towards an optimal conclusion: the guy literally lives inside of a record collection! And it’s true
column3: his new LP Shine Your Light does span the gamut of styles you’d expect from a “record store guy”
column4: i.e.
column5: Beach Boys
column6: Eno
column7: Can
column8: Velvet Underground
column9: and tons of forgotten bands that were influenced by them. More importantly
column10: you get the sense of what kind of guy would actually go through the hassle of living in such a place
column11: as Shine Your Light aligns Fulvimar’s musical ambitions with a total lack of personal ambitions
column12: doling out endearing songs about arrested development and short-term solutions that end up causing more problems in the long run.

column1: As with Burger alums King Tuff and Ty Segall
column2: you can apply the general tag of “loner power-pop” to Gap Dream
column3: though unlike the aforementioned
column4: it’s Fulvimar’s main thing rather than an aspect of his overall M.O. You can sense his ear for the canon: the unwholesome “Love Is Not Allowed” perverts the preciousness of round-like harmonizing in the style of Here Come the Warm Jets
column5: the more rhythm-focused tracks make lo-fi approximations of T. Rex’s pretty vacancy
column6: and you can hear a fake-it-til-you-make-it Kinks homage on “Shine Your Love”
column7: where a regal horn chart is hilariously impersonated by MS-DOS synths more suited for King’s Quest. But for the most part
column8: he’s more of a melody-first guy who demonstrates ingenuity over innovation and you never lose sight of how low the stakes are. The tools are crude and minimal—vintage drum machines
column9: even more vintage keyboards
column10: and underlying fuzz-rock guitars that put him well within Burger’s wheelhouse (or
column11: garage).

column1: Meanwhile
column2: though Shine Your Light was inspired by Fulvimar leaving a go-nowhere life in Ohio after receiving an invitation to hole up in Fullerton
column3: well...he’s arrived and “go-nowhere” means something a bit different. Judging from the majority of the lyrics
column4: it appears that just about any personal intrusion or interaction with the outside world is too much for him to handle and he’d rather kick it alone. A new pair of boots gets Fulvimar in the mood to strut a little on “Fantastic Sam”
column5: which is still presumably named after the sub-Supercuts hair salon chain. One song later
column6: he admits on “Immediate Life Sentence” to getting out of the house for no other reason than to move his feet. He spends the rest of it haranguing a woman who tries to socialize him
column7: snarling “you’re the kind of girl that wants to kill all my time
column8: ” even if the petulant tone makes him sounds like a guy who’s an expert time assassin. Note how the cruelest indignity is paying $7 for a beer
column9: at which point Fulvimar vows “I don’t need to get laid that bad/ I’ll just stay home and get high.” Two songs later on “Shine Your Love”
column10: that misanthropy has metastasized into full-blown nihilism—his voice curdles into a bratty snarl of “there is no past and there is no future
column11: ” and he proceeds to get blotto on a bottle of gin that itself probably cost $7.

column1: More life-reflecting than life-altering stuff for sure
column2: but the approachability (if not admirability) of Fulvimar’s P.O.V. establishes a personality that serves as a hook when the songs themselves don’t do much to distinguish themselves. Shine Your Light never gets oppressive
column3: though during its final third
column4: it does suggest what living in a record store might be like after the novelty wears out—kinda lonely
column5: a little bit stuffy
column6: and leaving you subject to others trying to tiptoe around
column7: “you’re gonna move out eventually...right?” That remains to be seen
column8: but for the time being
column9: Gap Dream is Fulvimar’s means of  “trying to find a chill spot just to organize my mind.” The song from whence it came is
column10: naturally enough
column11:
“Chill Spot”. Consider it his way of saying “mi casa es su casa.”

Since forming a few years ago at Oberlin College
column3: the dance duo Teengirl Fantasy have kept their fingers on the pulse of dance music's trends and subtly shifted accordingly. Nick Weiss and Logan Takahashi's subsequent successes
column4: from an irreverently dance-y 2009 CD-R to a couple of solid full-length releases
column5: can be largely attributed to this ability. Their records—including the foggy 2010 debut 7AM and 2012's more new age-y Tracer
column6: which featured assists from Kelela and Laurel Halo—offered glimmers of potential and delivered the occasional standout (three years later
column7: ""Cheaters"" is still something to behold)
column8: but in 2013
column9: it still feels like they're searching for their own individual sound.

column1: Released in anticipation of their third album
column2: their new EP
column3: Nun
column4: finds them continuing this trend. Using Tracer as something of a launching pad
column5: Nun finds Teengirl brightening familiar color pallettes in more noticeably energetic ways and heading in an even more dance-oriented direction with a look not dissimilar to the aesthetic developed by the UK label Night Slugs. ""Eric""
column6: in particular
column7: is a zippy track with cascading twinkles and manic
column8: breaking drums; it's one of the most futuristic-sounding tracks Teengirl Fantasy have made.

column1: Nun also marks the first time Weiss and Takahashi have put out a release without any vocal contributions. While their integration of the human voice into their aesthetic is one of their stronger suits (see their re-work of Mariah Carey's ""Touch My Body"")
column2: their atmospheric lushness is enough here to stand on its own. The title track
column3: for instance
column4: is a fragile-yet-limber piece that
column5: with aqueous bell tones and drainspout plunks
column6: provides a heady but subtle little dancefloor treat.

column1: All that said
column2: to call the 13-minute Nun an EP feels a little disingenuous—it's more a double-sided single padded with two toss-offs tagged as ""bonus"" cuts. Those bonuses make for nice daydreams
column3: and are certainly pretty
column4: but they're ultimately inconsequential atmosphere exercises. So
column5: as a band that's built a modest career on ""promise"" as opposed to ""execution
column6: it's safe to file Nun under ""for fans only."" But
column7: judging from the proper tracks ""Nun"" and Eric""
column8: it also suggests that
column9: once again
column10:
Teengirl Fantasy deserve a bit of space on your radar.
