Cali rapper Nocando’s Hellfyre Club is an assemblage of West Coast art rap luminaries connected to Project Blowed
column2: a long-running hip hop workshop that served as a proving ground for 90s and aughts L.A. aesthetes from Freestyle Fellowship and Abstract Rude to Pigeon John. Nocando’s Hellfyre squad includes long time Project Blowed affiliate Busdriver
column3: Midwest emigre Open Mike Eagle
column4: and newcomer milo alongside a cadre of MCs and producers from in and around Blowed and L.A.’s beat scene. They've connected for Dorner vs. Tookie
column5: the latest in a series of collaborative mixtapes showcasing a groupwide penchant for tongue-in-cheek self-flagellation and confessional storytelling that quite often metes out both at once.

column1: The four MCs at Hellfyre Club’s core are responsible for the bulk of the songs here
column2: and Dorner vs. Tookie is as much a case for their individual talents as their recombinant interplay. Nocando brings the hysterics
column3: Busdriver is the ace technician
column4: Open Mike Eagle’s a whiz with matching easy-going hooks to intimate personal reflection
column5: and milo is the resident free associative poet. Each shines on a solo cut or two
column6: but it’s when they pair up that the mixtape starts to cook. Busdriver and Nocando reunite as Flash Bang Grenada on “Pet Alligators”
column7: which imagines the 10 Haters of their 2011 debut multiplied a thousandfold and ticks off the ridiculous ephemera they’d blow their money on if they struck it rich (giraffes
column8: exotic birds
column9: big cats). Dorner vs. Tookie routinely weaponizes rap braggadocio against itself
column10: most snarkily on the Mike Eagle solo cut “Qualifiers”
column11: where the competition is advised: “We the best mostly/ Sometimes the freshest rhymers/ We the tightest kinda/ Respect my qualifiers.”

column1: Dorner vs. Tookie’s operative mode is humor
column2: but its darts are often stealthily laced with pathos. “Manchester” bounces a chorus about not being impressed with other rappers’ on-wax grandstanding off of verses from milo and Nocando about maybe not being all that conventionally cool themselves. Mike and Busdriver’s “Degrassi Picture Day (Hellfyre Jackets)” is all about dressing up and feeling fresh... for an elementary school picture day. (“My wallet’s bulging
column3: 25 bucks/ I’m coming home with that envelope from Life Touch!”) At first pass it plays like a send up of swag rap’s gear obsession
column4: but the childhood reminiscences in Mike’s verses are too pure to work in service only to sarcasm. Likewise for “Apologies”
column5: Mike’s interlude of affirmations where his asking penance for minor infractions like copying a buddy’s haircut and holding onto unused beats too long runs both silly and contemplative
column6: a twelve step retribution campaign for tour bus indiscretions.

column1: Hellfyre Club’s songwriting retains fluidity despite the disparate voices at work throughout
column2: but there's still the odd speed bump in the tracklist. Barring the early posse cut “DVT”
column3: the bruisers here can grate. “We On” and “Give a Fuck” both drag the mixtape down around the midsection. Neither’s wound too tight
column4: and purposefully so
column5: but it’s one of few areas on Dorner vs. Tookie where you can feel the crew straining for laughs rather than confidently teasing them out of the listener.

column1: Even so
column2: Dorner vs. Tookie is far less of a bumpy ride than its label comp mixtape format lets on. It owes its cohesion both to the years of experience racked up by Nocando's band of brothers both together and apart and a spate of productions that adorn these offbeat musings in blippy
column3: drippy soundscapes. Hellfyre Club's rappers and producers actually get each other; they're a fully functioning unit
column4: not a dream team of hired guns
column5: and their collaborations carry a spirit of fun and competition borne out of genuine chemistry. It's a lesson to the vanity label curating rapper barons of the era. You can buy your roster
column6:
but your money's not guaranteed to make them click.

"|18738.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18738-hellfyre-club-dorner-vs-tookie/|7.5|Craig Jenkins

Dan Bejar’s songbook is the sum of clearly discernible influences: the rich characterizations and narrative ramble of Dylan; the obtuse wordplay and meta-musical musings of Stephen Malkmus; the excitable affectation of a young David Bowie. And yet
column3: it’s not an exaggeration to say that no one sounds quite like Dan Bejar—in classic sum-is-greater-than-the-parts fashion
column4: he’s emerged over the past 15 years as one of indie-rock’s most unique and idiosyncratic voices
column5: forging an identity so distinct
column6: he’s even spawned dopplegängers and Twitter lyric generators. His latest release offers further edification
column7: by proving that Bejar's peculiar presence is unmistakble even when he’s singing someone else’s songs in a foreign tongue.

column1: Five Spanish Songs is just that
column2: though there’s a more altruistic impetus to this endeavor than that throwaway title would suggest. Traditionally
column3: when Anglo pop acts opt to record in another language
column4: the motivation is usually opportunistic
column5: a calculated attempt to engender goodwill—and
column6: it follows
column7: sell more records—in overseas countries. (“<a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nVF-WyrwPI8"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Sie Liebt Dich yeah
column8: yeah
column9: yeah!”) Five Spanish Songs is
column10: likewise
column11: a means to promote an underappreciated artist in an untapped market
column12: but that artist isn’t Bejar: more than try to make Destroyer a star in Spain
column13: the EP serves as a North American introduction to Seville songwriter Antonio Luque
column14: a prolific Gainsbourgian cult-hero whose long-running band Sr. Chinarro originally recorded the tracks Bejar covers here.

column1: The EP also presents an opportunity for Bejar to celebrate his own Spanish heritage
column2: which has never really factored into his work before (though
column3: given his tendency to overstuff his songs with verbiage to the point of bursting
column4: it makes sense that he'd want to reconnect with a culture where the words for things like “heart
column5: ” “nap
column6: ” and “thanks” unfurl over multiple syllables). Bejar’s reverence for Luque is evident through his measured
column7: carefully considered diction
column8: which is less flamboyant than it once was
column9: though several degrees warmer than the hushed sing-speak tones heard on 2011’s Kaputt. But if Bejar is faithful to the originals’ melodic structures (despite boasting a voice that’s naturally higher than Luque’s weathered croon)
column10: he takes great liberties with their presentation
column11: dressing up each song in a familiar Bejarian guise.

column1: The beatific opener “Maria de las nieves” is a languid
column2: moonstruck lullaby worthy of Destroyer’s Rubies
column3: while presenting Bejar with a new mysterious female muse to join all the Jackies and Christines that populate his songs. “El rito” is transformed from a breezy folk serenade to a glitter-rock fist-pumper that would be right at home on the New Pornographers’ next tour setlist. And though Bejar closely follows the upward
column4: string-swept arc of Luque’s tense
column5: Tindersticksian turn “Babieca”
column6: the added luster and bluster suggest the after-hours discotheque decadence of Kaputt imported to a yacht race on the Mediterranean.

column1: And yet even in its less flashy gestures—the busker-ready ditty “Del Monton”
column2: and the melancholic acoustic strip-down of the sprightly
column3: Smiths-ian jangle-pop number “Bye Bye”—Five Spanish Songs never feels like an vanity-project indulgence
column4: but rather a clear
column5: concerted effort on Bejar’s part to communicate why Luque’s songs are so special to him. The overall meaning of these tunes may fly over the heads of non-Spanish speakers
column6: but hey
column7: that’s the case with a lot of Bejar’s English songs
column8: and as with those
column9: certain turns of phrase pop up from the conversational crossfire and knock you out with their stunning clarity; at times
column10: it almost feels as if Luque wrote perfect
column11: scene-setting lines like “Si
column12: la fiesta terminó” in anticipation of Bejar’s sardonic delivery. To that end
column13: even if your familiarity with Spanish doesn’t extend beyond reading the menu at your local taco joint
column14:
the experience of listening to Five Spanish Songs is really no different than that of any other Destroyer record. 

"|18769.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18769-destroyer-five-spanish-songs/|7.9|Stuart Berman

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19851/homepage_large.dd3f86eb.jpg|Purple Snow: Forecasting the Minneapolis Sound|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2013-11-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:19.345888|"

Regional funk and R&B compilations have been flooding the reissue market for ages now
column2: and yet in all that time
column3: it's taken until this year for even the deepest-digging reissue label in the business to get to the foundation of one of the most vital scenes in funk lore. The chart-topping
column4: synth-heavy pulse that came out of the Twin Cities in the 80s still seems
column5: even to most music fans short of the local veteran scenester
column6: to be an abrupt fluke of auteurist proficiency and creativity
column7: largely credited to the braintrusts of everything-man superstar Prince and the songwriting/production juggernaut of Jimmy Jam Harris and Terry Lewis. The groups these three names cut their chops with have been hinted at by music historians
column8: and the peers they shared a scene with got some acknowledgment here and there. But little of this information has ever really been put into the wider context of what Minneapolis sounded like before the Minneapolis Sound. How could the scene that gave us 1999 and Control have such an underknown history where its pre-eighties R&B roots are concerned?

column1: Thanks to the deep knowledge base and research that went into Numero Group's Purple Snow compilation
column2: it's made clear just why that is—and why
column3: in a fairer world
column4: it shouldn't have been the case. A large metro area split between the rival identies of Minneapolis and Saint Paul
column5: the Twin Cities had plenty of pitfalls for touring bands. It's a long drive to just about everywhere—more than 300 miles to Milwaukee
column6: 400 to Chicago
column7: and 700 to Cincinnati. Staying home
column8: meanwhile
column9: meant a relatively small support group to break bands on a wider scale before they had the buzz to go national. Booking for funk and R&B bands was constrained to a small circuit of clubs
column10: including venues like the Nacirema and the Cozy Bar
column11: that had vanished by the time First Avenue served as the setting for Purple Rain. There weren't any nationally-distributed
column12: Minneapolis-based indie labels that supported the sound on the level of the garage-pop powerhouse of Soma in the 60s or the punk/new wave stronghold of Twin/Tone in the 80s. What few radio stations supported the format were low-wattage and under-the-radar
column13: while the local press was more fixated on finding the next breakthrough folkie to emerge from the campus coffeehouse circuit like Bob Dylan a decade before.

column1: By now
column2: that one Chris Rock joke might be coming to mind—that the only two black people in Minnesota are Prince and (the now late) Kirby Puckett. Which is hyperbole
column3: of course
column4: but not by much. Despite the presence of strong black communities in both Minneapolis and Saint Paul dating back generations

column6: the same year Prince released his debut album For You

column8: 000 blacks here.” The music scene wasn't much easier—more than one musician in the liner notes to Purple Snow mentions that groups couldn't get booked unless there were at least a few white faces in the band. Between prejudice
column9: lack of resources

column12: even as limited resources meant stiff competition.

column1: For the better part of the 70s

column3: experimentation
column4: personnel crossover
column5: community outreach
column6: and evolution—but not a signature style. Most of the material on Purple Snow that dates from the early-mid 70s pre-synthesized
column7: pre-disco funk era could come from just about anywhere

column9: albeit with tighter budgets and dimmer spotlights. Haze

column1: And then there's the Family—not to be confused with the mid-80s Prince offshoot of the same name that recorded “Nothing Compares 2 U” five years before Sinead did. A tight-knit crew of musicians who changed their name from Black Magic after some interloping Chicagoans (and
column2: more damagingly
column3: the media) mistook their community center homebase for a turf-war locale
column4: the Family—here billed as Music
column5: Love & Funk—contribute a sweaty yet sophisticated Ohio Players-caliber seven-plus-minute jam called “Stone Lover”
column6: recorded in 1976. By then
column7: Spike Moss and the neighborhood resource that was The Way community center had become a nexus for North Minneapolis youth to hone their playing

column1: One of the voices to jump in on that cut was one Prince Nelson
column2: then a teenager on the verge of dropping his last name as he got his session-rat studies in at Chris Moon's busy Moonsound Studios. And if there's one thing that Purple Snow makes clear
column3: it's that Prince was practically everywhere in the scene during the late 70s
column4: a prodigial player who learned from everybody and subsequently lent his credits to groups like the Lewis Connection (background vocals and guitar on the silky slow jam “Got to Be Something Here”) and 94 East (the pool-party smoothness of “If You See Me""
column5: where his taut chicken-scratch lead guitar riff barely reveals the virtuoso lurking beneath the hired-hand pro). It's a bit odd to hear him primarily in the context of just another piece of a bigger puzzle
column6: even if his burgeoning talent is attested to frequently in the album's liner notes. (A Minnesota Daily quote
column7: inspired by observations of him at work at Moonsound: “He's got his program pretty well worked out and the wheels are in motion... it's only a matter of time.”) But it goes a long way towards explaining just how and why he managed to dominate the Minneapolis scene: not merely with outrageous style
column8: crossover aspirations

column1: The only artists to rival Prince's proficiency at the time were
column2: of course
column3: Jimmy Harris and Terry Lewis. As inseparable as their identities have become
column4: Purple Snow makes a point of outlining how divergent their parallel paths really were before they joined forces at the turn of the 80s. Harris put drumming first—he did gigs with his father
column5: “Cornbread” Harris

column12: not prescient enough to find an audience—though they more than held their own in warmup gigs for disco-soul bands like Pleasure and Brass Construction.

Fatefully

Inc's “Funkytown”—one of the first hits for the Minneapolis Sound and one of the last of the disco era—another identity change for the band was necessary. As fate would have it

Dixon & J.O.Y.'s 1980 electro-gospel curiosity “You're All I Need”—wasn't enough. So the man his DJ gig christened Jimmy Jam became Flyte Tyme's second keyboardist. The Flyte was eventually grounded

column16: would notch a string of hits that early indie cuts like the squiggly get-down jams “Borrowed Time” and “Do You Dare” promisingly anticipated while proving that his success as a performer wasn't entirely dependent on Jam/Lewis. And Andre Cymone's minimalist

column1: Then again
column2: few shadows were harder to escape than the one of Minnesota itself. Longtime residents and scenesters might flip through the booklet of Purple Snow and note the way these artists positioned themselves among local landmarks—Prophets of Peace lined up among the lavish foliage of the Como Park Conservatory; 94 East lounging in the shadows of Charles Ginnever's jagged modernist sculpture 'Nautilus' outside the Walker Art Center; Mind & Matter raising disco fingers to the sky perched atop the mushroom-like brutalist platforms of Peavey Plaza. And whether the emergence of the Minneapolis Sound in the 80s changed all that is still somewhat uncertain; alt-country and bluegrass acts currently overwhelm up-and-coming R&B and hip-hop artists in sheer number and opportunity. But the precedent that Purple Snow traces led to something special: a situation where a core of artists were given an inch and wound up taking a mile—not out of greed

but of necessity.

Jensen Sportag’s debut album Stealth of Days is a sonic hybrid that stands out for its audaciousness even in the context of a dance music scene striving for experimentation. (I recently found out that “ambient gabber” is an actual thing that people are making
column2: as mind-bendingly improbable as that sounds.) What’s notably bold about what the duo (Austin Wilkinson and Elvis Craig of Nashville
column3: Tennessee) are up to isn’t that it hasn’t been done before—it has
column4: a bunch. What makes it a real aesthetic risk is that in the past it’s been done so badly.

column1: At its most basic
column2: Stealth of Days is R&B from the period during the late 70s and early 80s where the form first fell hard for synthesizers mixed with the smooth
column3: chilled tones of the more self-consciously tasteful end of the late-90s dance music boom. Wilkinson and Craig like to cite the clean-lined works of Ryuichi Sakamoto and Christian Fennesz as inspirations. A lot of musicians who were working in the late 90s attempted exactly the same thing
column4: and ended up producing the kind of generic
column5: enervated electronic soul that you mostly hear as background music at restaurants that are trying way too hard to project a hip atmosphere.

column1: One of the things that keeps the album from following a similar formula is the pair’s ability to steer just shy of the point where tastefulness starts to suffocate a record. Stealth of Days is full of little touches that keep things slightly unbalanced
column2: and therefore compelling. The album-opening “Rain Code” puts a choppy beat behind a satiny R&B vocal melody. “Six Senses” piles layer upon layer of grainy reverb and delay over a two-step beat that in other hands might sound blandly crisp
column3: and occasionally spaces out into brief ambient passages. Throughout the bass synths are dialed a notch or two past “funky” and just into “rude.”

column1: There are actually enough interesting little quirks like these that you can easily get distracted from the fact that Stealth of Days is at heart a pop record. The compositions are complex
column2: and so fastidiously arranged that you might get sucked into trying to pick out some kind of flaw. Sometimes it’s a little harder to overlook—on “Light Through Lace” and the late-album standout “Under the Rose” you can hear Ryuichi Sakamoto’s influence in the crystalline textures and immaculately composed percussion
column3: but strip all that away and the the tracks on Stealth of Days sound pretty much like they could be New Edition songs.

column1: During the recent CMJ Music Marathon
column2: Jensen Sportag was booked to perform live at the Cascine Records showcase
column3: but Craig was too sick to perform. Instead
column4: Wilkinson simply DJed their original compositions alongside remixes that they’ve done for other acts. You could tell that it was a hastily assembled fix
column5: and the fact that Wilkinson wasn’t blending the tracks but rather pausing between them to introduce each one made it an awkward experience. Still
column6: for the most part people were content to stand and watch
column7:
instead of bailing for something else. It really is that absorbing.

The Rise and Fall of Paramount Records: Vol. 1 (1917–1932) arrives like a family of nested matryoshka dolls. Sent by post
column3: the 22-pound compendium comes in a wide and thick cardboard box
column4: with the name and address of Paramount’s parent enterprise
column5: the long-extinct Wisconsin Chair Company
column6: branded on the side for the sake of authentic anachronism. Inside

column8: the project’s operational partners

column1: The hinged-and-clasped oak Cabinet bears Paramount’s iconic medallion on the outside
column2: an eagle with its wings spread and head cocked
column3: talons locked into the label’s name and positioned in front of a grooved record that suggests a morning’s rising sun. The set smells of varnish and glue and furniture—sweet but a little sour
column4: too. Clasp popped
column5: five distinct layers of wonder follow: a batch of six marbled brown LPs housed in an old-fashioned wooden binder; a velum envelope containing replications of ephemera from the earliest days of the recording industry; a hard-cover volume that tells the story of that troublesome start and its biggest stars; and a phone-book sized catalogue that does its best to detail nearly every performer included and
column6: for the first time ever

column1: The littlest doll
column2: wedged into a specially cut hole in the green felt platform that lines the box
column3: is a tarnished brass flash drive
column4: playfully dubbed a Jobber-Luxe. The contraption is crafted to look like the reproducer-and-needle assembly of one of the Wisconsin Chair Company’s Vista Talking Machines
column5: the reason they got into the nebulous and uncertain business of selling records
column6: anyway. It is the ultimate fulfillment of the set’s creative anachronism. The drive contains 800 songs culled from Paramount’s first decade
column7: a fitful and suddenly fertile period that
column8: in many ways
column9: shaped the landscape for the rise of a recording industry anchored on jazz
column10: rock ’n’ roll
column11: and country music. Taken together
column12: these recordings are no less than one blueprint of what has become American music.

column1: Through scrupulous research
column2: audacious design
column3: and ostentatious packaging
column4: this two-volume collection’s first installment does precisely what the best box sets intend to do—add proper deference and context to music that remains vital and significant. Retailing for $400
column5: The Rise and Fall is no doubt expensive
column6: especially considering that there’s a second and complementary volume forthcoming. But at once
column7: it’s a history lesson
column8: a dance hall
column9: a bandstand
column10: and a smoky blues parlor
column11: all tucked neatly into one sturdy box. This is the Cabinet of Wonder
column12: indeed.

column1: The Paramount Records story is one of American entertainment’s great musical curiosities and catalysts. The label started slowly and without certainty
column2: publishing cheap singles so that the people buying monolithic turntables from the Wisconsin Chair Company would actually have something to hear. The label operated with eternal economy
column3: using talent scouts instead of investing in field recording equipment
column4: forgoing demos
column5: and working in cheap studios where even some of the best takes were of mediocre quality.

column1: But the real jolt to the company—and the reason this set so closely mirrors the sound at the start of its country’s music industry—came with the arrival of Mayo Williams. A proud and cunning black man and former professional football player
column2: Williams had gone to Brown and worked a stint as a salesman for the blues-and-jazz-heavy record label Black Swan. When Paramount purchased Black Swan
column3: he traveled to Wisconsin from Chicago in 1923 to ask for a job; he emerged as a talent scout
column4: a talent manager
column5: and the true pioneer of the short-lived empire that pushed Paramount toward the front of the emerging “race records” industry—that is
column6: recording black music to sell to black listeners.

column1: “There’s 14 million Negroes in our great country and they will buy records if recorded by one of their own
column2: because we are the only folks that can sing and interpret hot jazz songs just off the griddle
column3: ” Mamie Smith’s impresario
column4: Perry Bradford
column5: had said in 1920. Mamie had happened upon a hit for Okeh; the year Williams arrived in Wisconsin
column6: Bessie Smith had done the same at Columbia. Williams’ professed specialty had become a suddenly hot commodity and his subsequent discovery
column7: advocacy
column8: and management of his artists made stars that
column9: in turn
column10: made movements. With Blind Blake and Blind Lemon Jefferson
column11: Ma Rainey and Ethel Waters
column12: Williams turned Paramount into an artistic institution if only by sheer commercial willpower. Williams left the company in 1927
column13: the year that this volume—which documents the rise of Paramount just before its Depression-abetted fall—ends.

column1: The structure and sound of many of the songs found throughout The Rise and Fall and within the archives of Paramount’s peers proved foundational to the shape of modern music. But pondering the historical implications of Papa Charlie Jackson’s acrid wit and aggressive playing or the twinkling roar of Jimmy Blythe’s piano runs the risk of ignoring this set’s most incredible invitation: to let these songs simply play (on vinyl
column2: in iTunes
column3: or through the customized and customizable playlists included on the Jobber-Luxe) and to immerse oneself in some incredible
column4: make-or-break performances. It’s tempting to get lost in the high-design grandeur of the Cabinet of Wonder
column5: but this music—gathered piecemeal from the collections of enthusiasts all over the world
column6: fighting always through a scrim of static on these remastered recordings—is the raison d’être
column7: the heart of a box alive with history.

column14: too.

column1: Allow that
column2: and the Wonders come quickly. Jelly Roll Morton and Ma Rainey

column5: they share a childlike sense of rhythm
column6: with Bell starting and stopping and bounding between tinny notes in fits of whimsy. His voice is not as heavy or as haunting as those of his Southern contemporaries
column7: giving it a singsong approachability. There are two 1924 tunes from Ukulele “Bob” Williams
column8: where social provocation supporting the then-jailed Marcus Garvey and Republican public policy takes the guise of jaunty little numbers for four strings and a jubilant voice. The Norfolk Jubilee Quartette delivers wonderfully woozy harmonies
column9: particularly on the stepwise and springy “Pleading Blues” or their torpid and bass-anchored “Swing Low Sweet Chariot”. Over swiveling horns and simple piano

column13: ” she purrs
column14: pointing a direct arrow toward the radio dial nearly a century later.

column1: But The Rise and Fall is not just a glob of music. One of the most carefully considered sets I’ve ever seen

column3: many of these sessions
column4: songs
column5: and musicians still hover in a cloud of mystery. Who played what on a session? When were they recorded? What songs are still left to be discovered? Thanks to an encyclopedic ream of research done by some of the most dedicated names in this particular act of audio archeology
column6: The Rise and Fall works in earnest to tell the stories behind it all. The set includes hundreds of advertisements rescued from the era and recreates in toto a 1924 Paramount catalogue and The Paramount Book of Blues
column7: a 1927 guide to the label that featured several laughable dossiers of the artists and bunches of sheet music.

column1: Aside from hours of intrigue
column2: such materials also make it clear that not much has changed during 90 years of the music industry: Just as Third Man proprietor Jack White and Black Keys singer Dan Auerbach feud in public now
column3: so did diametric vixens Alberta Hunter and Ethel Waters then. Just as big labels seek the next trend on which to turn a fast dime now
column4: Paramount’s pursuit of black musicians stemmed from surprise hits on other labels then. And just as social media now attempts to lure listeners via must-click-here promotion
column5: Paramount’s illustrated advertisements in the Chicago Defender and its insistence that it had discovered singers then practically demanded that regular folks spend more on their records than anything else in life. “Race’s Favorite Stars on Paramount
column6: ” read one 1923 promotion. “Every Christian home will prize this record
column7: ” read another
column8: stopping just short of suggesting that not buying that particular Norfolk Jubilee Quartette single would guarantee eternal damnation. The music industry
column9: it seems
column10: always begot high stakes.

column1: In the beginning and
column2: really
column3: throughout most of the label’s history
column4: the executives at Paramount and its parent company did not seem to understand the important trove they were building. During half of the era covered in this volume
column5: for instance
column6: the label released lots of baubles and bores
column7: patriotic songs and symphonic recordings that simply didn’t excite like what came later. The possibility of music hadn’t occurred to them. And even when Williams was leading the race record series to dizzying sales and helping fuel the sound of a nation now suddenly listening
column8: he wasn’t on salary. Otto Moeser
column9: the president of the whole operation
column10: once instructed Williams to take the freight elevator to a meeting in a lavish Chicago hotel. This was the 20s
column11: after all
column12: and Williams was a black man marketing records to black customers. That same oblivion resulted in the incomplete records and the destruction of the label’s archives when it went belly-up
column13: a scene vividly limned by Scott Blackwood in the wondrous liner notes. Such retrospective ignorance makes the trove of The Rise and Fall that much more remarkable
column14: valuable
column15: and edifying. This is almost-lost history
column16: faithfully restored.

column1: But Third Man and Revenant seem to have the opposite—if notably less problematic—quandary: They truly understand the cultural and historical cachet of what they have gathered
column2: and they present it with a clear respect. That’s something that Paramount itself

column4: certainly did not. But now

column6: lavishly packaged and highly priced so that mostly only the rich old men who already have an enthusiasm for this stuff will have access to it. It’s a reissue cycle that seems to push the music only another decade or so away from extinction. These Cabinets of Wonder
column7: however impressive
column8: will slowly but almost certainly become Coffins of Disuse
column9: limited to the 5
column10: 000 people who hoard them.

column1: “If people only want the songs
column2: there are probably are other sources for most of it
column3: ” Dean Blackwood
column4: who co-founded Revenant with his management client and friend John Fahey in the mid 90s
column5: told me recently. “This is more about people with a fascination for the tactile and sensory world. That just can’t be replicated in the digital realm.”

column1: But it doesn’t need to be that way. With a sigh
column2: Blackwood adds that selling the 5

column5: then
column6: not pad the income a bit by making the music accessible to those who can’t plunk down a car payment on a box set

column8: such as the one provided to the press for this release? If the point of this labor is to give the music included both reverence and eternal life

column10: is there any better end than making sure as many people as possible hear it? Why save something only to let it sink into sure atrophy?

can you?

Most people in bands don't stick together for 21 years in the business without having at least some carnage wreaked upon their lives. Tindersticks have reached that milestone this year
column3: albeit with a lengthy hiatus behind them and a few ex-members tossed to the roadside along the way. Such drama
column4: if it can be called that
column5: is perfectly fitting for this band
column6: who seemed to arrive with a weight of experience on their shoulders after forming from the ashes of Asphalt Ribbons in the early 1990s. On their earliest singles Tindersticks were a mesh of low production values and awkward transitions
column7: while their vision for the band was strung somewhere between the underground and the orchestra pit. It's a feeling that remains intact despite higher production values and work with actual orchestras. There's an awkwardness to Tindersticks' confessionals that make their songs deeply personal despite the grander scope they sometimes operate within.

column1: This album
column2: a series of reworkings of previously recorded tracks
column3: plus a couple of solo compositions by singer Stuart Staples
column4: skips the earliest period of the band altogether. None of those nascent singles feature
column5: nothing from their imperious first album is picked over—if this is a birthday celebration
column6: it's one that quietly slips the yellowing baby pictures into a bottom drawer. The overhauls are light
column7: for the most part. Sometimes there's a touch of confidence in Staples' vocal that wasn't there before
column8: or a horn part replaces a string section. The presence of multi-instrumentalist Dickon Hinchliffe is missed
column9: as it has been since the lineup change in late 2006
column10: but sometime collaborator Terry Edwards makes a more than capable replacement
column11: scattering trumpet and saxaphone over a handful of songs to bring out an extra dimension or two.

column1: Tindersticks suffered from being so fully formed on their inception
column2: making a debut album that continues to tower over most of their output. Their ""imperial phase"" (to borrow a Neil Tennant-ism) continued through their second record
column3: taking in highlights that included a couple of superior live albums. Things begin to taper off after that
column4: only recovering on the surprise return to form with last year's The Something Rain. The earliest work featured here is from their second record
column5: the highlight of which is a subtly tweaked ""Sleepy Song"" that maintains the original's cacophonic bloodrush of instrumentation in its final third. Tindersticks often face Nick Cave comparisons
column6: but the gloomy bedsit pining of a song like ""A Night In"" highlights a contrast between the two. Cave may have been cheated by love
column7: but he's also cocksure and successful at it. Staples is all crumpled suits and apprehension
column8: consigned to his fate instead of rising above it.

column1: What's most interesting about Tindersticks' career arc is how they retain their sense of vulnerability throughout. Even a track like ""Say Goodbye to the City""
column2: originally from 2003's Waiting for the Moon
column3: has the air of someone spilling a cheap cup of tea over a moth-eaten Ennio Morricone sleeve as they attempt to emulate him in a gloomy North London practice space. There's a touch more swagger to this version
column4: but Staples hasn't lost the frailty in his voice. This is a band that appropriated popular paintings found in U.K. thrift stores for their earliest record covers
column5: and there's still an aspect of that mindset at work
column6: a feeling of rummaging through borrowed memories and once treasured artefacts. No matter how big they aim there's always a remnant of their origin story tugging at their sleeve
column7: bringing them back to Mike Leigh territory even when they’re reaching for Leone.

column1: For Across Six Leap Years Tindersticks convened in Abbey Road
column2: along with a host of guest musicians. There's a little extra room in the sound
column3: giving keyboard player David Boulter
column4: always the most dapper member of the band
column5: a chance to shine. The subtle chime of his Rhodes playing beautifully underpins the band's second stab at Odyssey's ""If You're Looking for a Way Out""
column6: while tingling dual piano motifs on ""What Are You Fighting For?"" help lift an otherwise by-the-numbers Tindersticks tune. If there's a criticism here it's in the way these songs don't stray far from the original pieces
column7: instead working as tasteful updates that add a dab of cohesion that was never needed in the first place. It's a treat for fans
column8: which is really all a project like this is ever going to be. But it also highlights a continuity in their work
column9: where Staples' small
column10: sad stories don't usually end up in a better place
column11: or any place other than where their protagonist started out. Instead
column12:
Tindersticks simply grapple with how it is to be.

Most experimental music is at least a little absurd. Unlike conventional songwriting
column5: whose intentions are usually pretty clear
column6: the any-sound-goes approach often provokes the question “why are you doing this?” For some artists
column7: seriousness of intent and dedication to craft are self-evident answers. But others also see the question as a chance to play
column8: to be humorous or ridiculous or twisted or confusing. In other words
column9: to laugh and make you ask again. At its most absurd
column10: that kind of experimental music is like a trippy cartoon
column11: dizzyingly unpredictable and fearlessly free. That’s why John Zorn found so much inspiration in Carl Stalling
column12: whose zany mash-up compositions scored many Warner Brothers cartoons.

column1: Absurdity has shown up in the individual work of experimenters C. Spencer Yeh
column2: Okkyung Lee
column3: and Lasse Marhaug
column4: so their collaboration as part of Software’s SSTUDIOS series seemed likely to spark humorous fireworks. It did: Wake Up Awesome is a bubbling
column5: restless sonic fun house
column6: filled with comic samples
column7: oddball turns
column8: surreal transitions
column9: and enough activity to power a jet engine. It’s not novelty music—many moments
column10: especially those involving Lee’s expressive cello improvisations
column11: are as compelling as the gravest experimental music. But the trio is unafraid to sound novel
column12: silly
column13: or absurd—and that’s what makes listening to them so much fun.

column1: Their attitude is evident right on the surface
column2: in tongue-in-cheek song titles like “Serious Cat’s Milk”
column3: “The Mermaids of Extended Technique”
column4: and “Tonight We Sleep Like Empty Hard Drives”. Those recall the goofy monikers of early Boredoms songs
column5: and in fact some of the music evokes Boredoms too
column6: minus the psycho shrieks of Yamataka Eye. Both groups create a sense that anything could happen
column7: and that the participants are always eager to surprise. In the case of Yeh
column8: Lee
column9: and Marhaug
column10: that eagerness creates moments that might make you laugh out loud. On “Anise Tongue and Durian Wet Dream”
column11: a sample that sounds torn from a rickety player-piano loops around drools and gargling
column12: while synth squiggles in “Mission: Possible” sound like Pac Man dying. Perhaps funniest is “Throw Down the Fishcake”
column13: whose messy percussion is like a pile of overlapping punch lines.

column1: What makes Wake Up Awesome more than just a joke is the way the trio mixes laughs with tension and drama
column2: sometimes simultaneously. That’s most evident in Lee’s cello
column3: which seems able to emit any tone and convey any emotion imaginable. On the aforementioned “Mermaids
column4: ” she scrapes out chilly notes that match the grind of Ghil
column5: her excellent solo album from earlier this year (which Marhaug helped conceive and record). On “Ophelia Gimme Shelter
column6: ” her slow lines are mournful
column7: while on “Mission: Nothing” similar figures are majestically stoic. Cut those moments with Yeh and Marhaug’s punchy interruptions and jarring juxtapositions
column8: and you get a record that can sound like multiple albums playing at once.

column1: That effect was one of the promises of sample-heavy experiments like turntablism
column2: which seemed capable of smashing hundreds of styles into seconds of music. But outside of the hyper-cut ""plunderphonics"" of John Oswald
column3: much of it stuck to a narrow sonic range
column4: and got predictable pretty quick. Yeh
column5: Marhaug
column6: and Lee avoid that fate by leaning on their well-honed improvisational skills
column7: injecting gravity into Wake Up Awesome’s airy playfulness. Thus an album spilling with ideas still manages some containment—though when the final track cuts off abruptly
column8: you get the sense that
column9: like kids at recess
column10:
this trio stopped playing only because they had to.

Title Fight are from Kingston
column2: Penn.
column3: an erstwhile coalmining town in the northeast part of the Keystone State that uses Wilkes-Barre as its metropolitan reference point. Though its punk scene is vibrant and tight-knit
column4: to the point of being kinda quaint
column5: a band looking to break out on a national level needs an almost pathological level of ambition. Of course
column6: you need great songs as well and Title Fight have plenty of those. But as a melodic punk band that functions within a realm that doesn’t have much use for typical signifiers of compositional ambition
column7: their drive is trickier to quantify
column8: a “most likely to succeed” kind that can smack as careerism in the wrong hands. The quartet are productive
column9: they respect their elders (Quicksand/Rivals Schools’ Walter Schreifels produced their proper debut LP
column11: they roll with the winners (collaborators and tourmates such as Balance & Composure and Touché Amoré)
column12: they’ve been on three different labels amenable to their sound at the time and they tour relentlessly. That and they have no time for bullshit—Title Fight’s Twitter account has over 32
column13: 000 followers and zero ""followings""
column14: which makes them look far more focused than antisocial.

column1: So
column2: it’s interesting to see their Spring Songs EP called “ambitious” by onlookers
column3: as if that's a new quality for Title Fight. In a way it’s backhanded
column4: suggesting that their previous influences such as Lifetime or Jawbreaker or Saves the Day were necessarily stepping stones to the trad indie-rock sound captured here. But it’s worth keeping in mind that Title Fight are still barely out of their teens
column5: and you know what? That’s not an atypical listening progression for someone who’s growing up right along with Title Fight. And so Spring Songs does manifest a new kind of ambition
column6: which is the band staking out different territory and hoping their fans come along.

column1: The arrangement makes for a tidy introduction: two songs on two sides
column2: split equally between their two vocalists
column3: Ned Russin and Jamie Rhoden.  Moreover
column4: half of Spring Songs finds the vocals lunging out from the newly warm and analog production
column5: the other have them more nestled within the handsomely textured
column6: melodic guitar leads. The permutations allow Title Fight the ability to show just how little they needed to change their overall approach to edge into a new aesthetic. The Rhoden-led “Be A Toy” susses out the musical currency existing between early-90s Merge and mid-90s pop-punk as well as the emotional underpinning—I mean both cohorts were accused of being “slackers
column7: right? And “Be A Toy” finds common ground in a line like “do you regret being used/are you used to it yet?”
column8: trying to get your rocks off while feeling like crap. Meanwhile
column9: “Blush” counters with the rawer-voiced Russin raging over sour guitars for an effect that’s hooky and also jagged—it’s probably what A&Rs had in mind when trying to find that bridge between Nevermind and Dookie.

column1: In most aspects

column3: these would all be among the longer tracks on previous LPs Shed and Floral Green. Yet
column4: it’s their tightest
column5: most hook-focused songwriting yet. The spare
column6: midtempo “Receiving Line” gives Russin’s lyrics more sonic space to be heard and as a result
column7: a typically topical Title Fight song allows the listener more freedom of interpretation. You sense the emotional tenor when Russin sings “we drove my car that weekend/ 100 miles barely speaking
column8: and with an understated economy of words
column9: he gives just enough inside information to pique interest rather than full disclosure “‘I’m sorry for your loss’/you probably get that a lot/we didn’t have to talk/you probably get that.”  “Evolution” feels like the proper term here
column10: as Title Fight are simply teasing out certain aspects that were present of their previous two LPs
column11: particularly Floral Green. And if there are any qualms to be had
column12: it’s in the sense that you’ll be hearing these again soon

column1: But Spring Songs does leave a lot to the imagination and not simply in the matter of “what will the next Title Fight album sound like?” Here we have a rock band on an independent record label
column2: whose sound and work ethic are unmistakably punk. And yet
column3: you’re more likely to hear electro-pop or major-label bands such as Chvrches or Haim called “indie” more often than Title Fight. How is that? Is it because most of time
column4: genre tags are used to described the perceived fanbase than the music itself? If that's the case
column5: Title Fight really are going indie rock on Spring Songs. But even if it reaches people who aren't familiar with their past work
column6:
Spring Songs helpfully shows Title Fight as pretty much the same thing they've always been: an ambitious band that makes very good songs.

It is easy to see the feather-voiced R&B singer Jhené Aiko in the lineage of female artists whose music hinged on the paradoxical power of vocals that felt like an outgrowth of a whisper. There is Cassie
column3: the one-hit wonder who eventually achieved near-idol status amongst electronic producers enchanted by the icy sensuality of her music
column4: and there is Brandy
column5: whose voice is much richer but who nonetheless found her songs being clipped and looped by the same sort of producers (Burial
column6: James Blake). There is someone like Ciara and
column7: of course
column8: there is Aaliyah
column9: revered now like a goddess thanks to the crushing emotionality of a voice that put her far out of step with the divas of the 90s.

column1: It is even easier to see how the recent adoration for these singers—not just from British boys clicking through Logic
column2: but also from stars like Drake (who has an Aaliyah tattoo) and Chris Brown—may have provided a perfect incubator for an artist like Aiko
column3: whose music attempts to hit you in precisely the same way. And it is true: the sustained interest in this sound has likely contributed to her rise
column4: which culminated in Sail Out debuting in Billboard’s Top 10 debut. But more importantly
column5: as the sound of popular rap has continued to take on a form (in mood if not always in sound) mutated from Kanye West’s 808s & Heartbreak
column6: Aiko’s malleable and far from overpowering voice has become a frequent accompaniment.

column1: In 2013 she has starred on Big Sean’s hit single “Beware""
column2: snaking her way through the track’s ample empty space
column3: and on Drake’s “From Time""  joining Alicia Keys
column4: Nicki Minaj and Rihanna as the only women to appear on any of his albums. (She is also currently opening for Drake on his American tour.) Despite not being a megawatt name
column5: her inclusion on Nothing Was the Same almost felt like a foregone conclusion: no current vocalist—male or female— better accentuates the damp throb of Drake’s music. If you lie in bed at night in a pitch black room aglow only with the light of an iPhone
column6: Aiko’s voice is the one that might feel the most appropriate.

column1: But being asked to help solidify the mood of a song is an altogether different task than carrying an entire project. Aiko has been around the industry for almost a decade
column2: signing a record deal with Epic as a teenager and eventually surfacing on a number of Black Hippy projects
column3: a pairing that makes perfect sense when you consider that Kendrick Lamar would eventually build a track out of a Janet Jackson sample. But in that time she’s put out only a single full-length
column4: the 2011 mixtape Sailing Soul(s)
column5: which nonetheless featured contributions from Kendrick
column6: Drake
column7: Miguel and Kanye West. Sail Out is Aiko’s first release with the world watching.

column1: Though it is easy to grasp the broad appeal of Aiko’s music
column2: it’s harder to decipher whether the songs are more appealing than the mere atmosphere they create. One issue she doesn’t have is establishing a clear point of view: on Sail Out
column3: she sings exclusively of contentment being just out of her grasp
column4: be it because a relationship is fractured emotionally (“3:16 am”
column5: “WTH”) or by distance (“The Vapors”)
column6: or because she has to continue with the motions required of her profession (“Bed Peace”). Regardless
column7: there is an unavoidable longing at the heart of this EP
column8: one that seems connected to her fixation with weed. On “Bed Peace” she sings of a desire to wake up in the middle of the day and light a blunt
column9: but the idea of intoxication is a metaphor she returns to often. On “WTH” she steps back from a sputtering relationship and realizes that she ""might've got way too high"" and on “The Vapors” she links drugs and sex
column10: repeatedly singing “Can I hit it again?”

column1: It doesn’t seem like a coincidence that there is also a distinct numbness to Sail Out. The production—handled by Fisticuffs
column2: a duo that worked heavily on Miguel’s first album—is downtempo and unobtrusive
column3: with percussion coming from drums that are no louder than a snap or a clicking lighter and keyboards that offer a soft bed for Aiko’s vocals. Those vocals are often emotionless; Aiko sings with a medicated distance
column4: never getting too up or too down even when she sings of despair.

column1: It is here where Sail Out is likely to leave some cold. Vocalists like Cassie or Aaliyah were able to convey a spectrum of emotions within a limited vocal range
column2: summoning strength or giddiness or compassion when necessary. Aiko has yet to display this ability
column3: and Sail Out leaves you searching for emotion where it isn’t. Instead there is a glazed-over blankness to her delivery that does these bare-by-design songs little favors.

column1: The EP’s best track is also its outlier. “Bed Peace” is powered by a bouncy
column2: bright guitar strum that blossoms into a chorus of fluttering keyboards
column3: radiant backing vocals
column4: and screwed vocals that bob and weave with Aiko’s own singing. It is the most fully developed track
column5:
but more importantly the bliss seems to draw her into easing smoothly into a higher register. It is a subtle shift that feels too much like a revelation.

It feels appropriate that Logos took so long to produce an album. After all
column2: he makes music with supreme restraint that seems to unfold with an almost meditative calm

column3: Wen
column4: Inkke and countless others—Parker doesn’t bring a youthful vigor to bear on the form. In fact

column1: Dubstep singles credited to Logos appeared as far back as 2008

Its conceptual conceit was simple—Parker took Wiley’s remarkable and oft-referenced Eskibeat sound and jettisoned it into the cold void of space—but the results were surprisingly rich and absorbing. Cold Mission is Parker’s first solo release since that EP. So while it is
column3: in a sense
column4: one of the first major LPs to emerge from recent currents in grime—and certainly the best—it also belongs to an earlier moment. Parker’s focus on space and the careful application of pressure seems inspired by dubstep. He also invites parallels with other producers who grew to prominence after the style’s demise: ""Ex 101""'s gorgeous warped chords are strongly reminiscent of Jam City’s ""Club Thanz""
column5: for example.

column1: Mostly
column2: however
column3: Parker works at the coalface of grime. ""Surface Area (Main Mix)""
column4: with its shattered glass percussion and fanged bass pulses
column5: follows Kowloon in its ultra-minimalist deployment of grime signifiers. The drums function more as interjection than propulsion

column9: downpitched strings and hovering-UFO bass. In each case Parker’s treatments manage to be both incendiary and wonderfully graceful. It’s like observing some sort of martial art in action
column10: deadly but balletic.

column1: It’s a hackneyed comparison
column2: but Parker’s sonics often evoke rainswept urban dystopias of the Bladerunner variety; or
column3: more specifically
column4: Vangelis’ soundtrack to that film as channeled through the Akai samplers of countless jungle producers (think Dillinja’s evergreen ""The Angels Fell""). Often

column10: furtively

column3: unmistakably his own. The only flaws in Cold Mission

column10: feels almost painfully literal compared to the artful abstraction found elsewhere. ""Wut It Do""
column11: meanwhile

column15: glistening

Cold Mission should give us all cause for optimism.

column5: nearly matches it with a synth ripple that tears the air. The second set of tracks has a more linear ascent: the drifting “The Redeemer” leads to the quivering
column6: horror-film-worthy “Open Drawer
column7: Full of Masks""

When Soundgarden released Screaming Life
column2: their 1987 debut EP

column9: Soundgarden had the catchiest songs
column10: the sexiest frontman in Chris Cornell
column11: and the most conventional approach to making music. Catchiness
column12: sexiness
column13: and conventionality were all things grunge would eventually
column14: if briefly
column15: pretend to refute. From the start
column16: though
column17: Soundgarden’s music envisioned—if not promised—a nation of arenas full of flannel.

column1: Screaming Life is proof. Along with its 1988 follow-up
column2: the Fopp EP

column9: “Fopp” and “Kingdom of Come”—have more in common with what was truly going on in alternative metal circa 1987 and 88: Jane’s Addiction
column10: the Cult
column11: and even Living Colour
column12: each of whom sought to expand the tropes of metal by cross-pollinating it with other styles—not to mention weaving a shroud of alluring otherness in the face of bad-boys-next-door like Mötley Crüe or Poison. The fact that “Fopp” is a thickened cover of the Ohio Players’ 70s funk classic shows that
column13: in a parallel universe
column14: Soundgarden could just have easily turned into Faith No More.

column1: But they didn’t. Soundgarden wound up drawing from a broad palette while avoiding the funk-metal trap that so many of their contemporaries succumbed to. Even their breakthrough albums—1991’s Badmotorfinger and 1994’s Superunknown—owe more to progressive rock and psychedelia
column2: respectively
column3: than to grunge. Some of that structural oddness and swirling murk can be heard on Screaming Life
column4: albeit sporadically. If anything
column5: Screaming Life comes on like gothic Led Zeppelin. “Hunted Down” is cavernous and “Immigrant Song”-like in its pseudo-mythic chug
column6: while “Tears to Forget” echoes the metallic gallop of “Communication Breakdown”. Cornell’s voice veers from Robert Plant majesty—steeped
column7: though
column8: in deeper shadows—to a scalding screech that he’d soon ditch in favor of a more melodic wail. “Entering” starts out with a drumbeat that resembles
column9: of all things
column10: Bauhaus’s “Bela Lugosi’s Dead” before morphing into lesser groove-rock aerobics. Finally tapping into the Black Sabbath wellspring that came to be a grunge stereotype
column11: Soundgarden turns “Nothing to Say” into a ringing
column12: doom-laden drone. “Little Joe” is Screaming Life’s lone disposable track
column13: another foray into stiff-necked quasi-funk that feels squishy and unformed
column14: as do Cornell’s monotone histrionics.

column1: He’d get better from there
column2: as would all of Soundgarden. Not that you’d know it listening to “Kingdom of Come”—a would-be party anthem complete with douchey double entendre that wastes the talent of Kim Thayil

column6: let alone during its stunning major-label years. Soundgarden would go on to become the most challenging of the mainstream grunge titans; 1996’s Down on the Upside is every inch as dense and harrowing as In Utero. But in 1987

column10:
hesitant half-triumph.

Excepter have been known to meander. The Brooklyn group’s 10-year career is studded with songs that lope and drift. They often float around some elusive target for a while before landing on it—or
column4: just as often

column6: the tactic is mind-bending. It sneaks hooks
column7: melodies
column8: and climaxes past your brain’s pattern-detector
column9: directly warping your passive receptors like a drug. Even when direct hits aren’t scored
column10: the group’s wandering can be fascinating on its own

column1: You might expect Excepter’s new EP
column2: Christisland
column3: to be another step along this dizzy path
column4: since its two songs both last over 10 minutes. And to be sure
column5: these aren't tight compositions with crystal clear goals. But they both center on simple
column6: relatively straight-forward beats that persist from beginning to end. It’s not a totally new move for the band
column7: but usually with pieces this long they shift gears a few times
column8: fusing disparate parts or diverging into tangents. In that way Excepter is kind of an electronic jam band

column2: it turns out. Both tracks on Christisland pile many sounds on top of their pulses
column3: which are like heartbeats in the middle of a hurricane. Side one’s title track is the windier and wetter of the two. The group pelts its beat with whirring chords
column4: slippery synths
column5: overlapping babble
column6: and skewed percussion darting around the beat. At points it replicates the sky-seeking build of Excepter’s live shows
column7: but it doesn’t really feel live

column1: On the flipside
column2: “Beargarden” plays like the come-down after “Christisland”’s summit climb–or perhaps like the next morning’s hangover. Slow
column3: creepy
column4: and dense
column5: it has a distinctly nightmare-ish vibe. Yet a rising organ-like tone makes it also hymn-like
column6: as if the horror movie it’s soundtracking was set in a big
column7: cavernous chruch. At times
column8: the trudging beat and stirring chords converge so snugly that “Beargarden” becomes one of the most conventional-sounding things Excepter has done.

column1: Still
column2: Christisland is perhaps best appreciated by aficionados
column3: who’ll hear echoes of Excepter’s previous work haunting both tracks. Typically
column4: the band themselves have already moved on: a full-length due in January features shorter songs and clearer
column5: more present singing. Perhaps Excepter doesn’t get enough credit for how often they vary their attack
column6: something that’s easy to miss inside all improvised meandering. From that perspective
column7: Christisland may ultimately rank as an intriguing side-step. But when it’s actually playing
column8:
it sounds like feet firmly planted in new turf.

column1: And hell

column3: too. You can’t be this premeditated with knowing what people think about you and if it wasn’t clear that a) there is a joke and b) Death Grips is in on it
column4: there’s a song called “This is Violence Now (Dont get me wrong)”. Remember when MC Ride namedropped Magical Mystery Tour curiosity “Blue Jay Way” and Santana’s Abraxas on The Money Store?  If not
column5: the first song on Government Plates is a Bob Dylan reference. If a Dadaist Death Grips nursery rhyme sounds hilarious in concept
column6: that’s because “Birds” is pretty much just that. Ride sneers “I cop this attitude at all times
column7: ” in a posh
column8: flippant accent
column9: the kind attributable to someone vapid enough to say “I cop this attitude.”

column1: An awkward one-off upon its original release
column2: “Birds” serves as a pivot for Government Plates
column3: the point where “new Death Grips” starts to become Death Grips doing something legitimately new. Some parts of Government Platesare actually pretty and not in that perverse
column4: S&M way. And during the second half
column5: they get awfully close to proper dance music
column6: or at least its rigorous structure and of course
column7: this formalism makes for even more interesting tension. <span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">“Feels like a wheel” is Death Grips’ take on HI-NRG drum and bass
column8: which is to say
column9: it focuses less on emotional ecstasy than the artificial components and side effects of the club drug
column10: the toxic chemicals and fried nerve endings. The only intelligible lyric is “let me live my life
column11: ” which turns the title into a double entendre
column12: it could mean “rolling” or just being stuck. “Im overflow” about sums up how Death Grips react to stability and yet it hinges on Ride’s most straightforward battle rapping
column13: punctuated with a yell of “hot shit!’

column1: Government Plates isn’t here to teach you a lesson. When Death Grips are overt about what they think
column2: they often come off like bratty teenagers
column3: acting out against people who want to help them. Unlike the blunt
column4: confrontational NO LOVE DEEP WEB
column5: Government Plates lets you think for yourself and even if it doesn’t have an agenda
column6: that doesn’t mean it’s nihilistic.  It’s music that doesn’t care about how you feel
column7: just how you react to it. All the same
column8: it doesn’t exist in a vacuum and when Death Grips interact with the public
column9: they can produce something elemental
column10: in a literal sense where the periodic table can take violent turns: oxidation
column11: sulfur fumes
column12: nitrous
column13: horrible fluorescents and neon
column14: fossil fuel. Or
column15: maybe a hydrogen bomb
column16: with all of its attendant amorality: Death Grips provide the power
column17:
you provide the politics.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19945/homepage_large.01491d15.jpg|I Want to See Pulaski at Night|356.0|Andrew Bird|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Grimsey']|2013-11-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:31.673781|"

It’s hard to think of Andrew Bird’s new EP as an EP. It’s an appropriate seven tracks
column2: arranged to be reasonably cohesive across a half-hour
column3: and concerned only with a handful of musical ideas
column4: which it teases out intelligently and patiently. So far so good. Bird fashioned the release around a single song
column5: “Pulaski at Night”
column6: which he wrote but did not want to hold until he had enough for a full-length. Instead
column7: he composed a handful of instrumentals to form lengthy prologues and epilogues to “Pulaski”
column8: comparing it to soundtracking a film. So think of the EP as the director’s cut of the main song. Or an extended mix. Or a short suite. Think of it as an EP
column9: however
column10: and it feels slight—never quite the sum of its parts.

column1: “Pulaski at Night” is prime Bird: tightly crafted
column2: lyrically witty
column3: understated yet sophisticated in its arrangement of loops and plucks and thrums and whistles. “I paint you a picture of Pulaski at night
column4: ” he sings on the chorus. “Come back to Chicago
column5: city of light.” The galloping violin strums give that sneaky hook its subdued grandeur and steady insistence
column6: Bird’s bow tracing the topography of the Midwestern landscape. It sounds as though he’s trying to erase the many miles between him and the person he’s addressing
column7: who is clearly far away. At one of his Gezelligheid shows last winter
column8: Bird explained the song’s origins and specified which Pulaski inspired him
column9: but there’s something so teasingly vague about the song's shadowy “you” that it’s better left unexplained. On its own
column10: the song could be about a departed friend
column11: a distant lover
column12: or every fan who isn’t in the town Bird is playing that night.

column1: If “Pulaski at Night” is Bird at his most dependably and stalwartly Romantic
column2: the rest of the EP is just Bird. There is
column3: admittedly
column4: a warm familiarity to the plaintively whistled theme of “Lit from Underneath”
column5: to the staccato plucks of “Hover 1”
column6: to the evocative bowing on “Hover 1”. As well
column7: a few unexpected flourishes illuminate some of these songs
column8: such as the loose-limbed raga rhythm on opener “Ethio Invention No. 1” and the quickly fading notes that arc across “Logan’s Loops”. At times that familiarity curdles into predictability
column9: and nothing else carries the sense of purpose and longing as the title track. Not that Bird needs to reinvent himself on a minor release like this one
column10: but an EP is an ideal medium for indulging new experiments and rethinking one’s approach. The most innovative and intriguing aspect of Pulaski is not its music
column11:
but ultimately its not-quite-definable form.
