column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19878/homepage_large.e96073c8.jpg|Watching Dead Empires in Decay|31677.0|The Stranger|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modern Love']|2013-11-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:32.384314|"

There's a track on the new album by the Stranger
column2: the latest project in a long list of many from James Leyland Kirby
column3: titled ""About to Enter a Strange New Period"". As a literal reflection of Kirby's musical shifts
column4: it couldn't be more appropriate. This is
column5: after all
column6: a guy who has recorded under the names Notorious P.I.G. and Billy Ray Cyrix. He's best known for two projects—the bizarre cut-ups he conducted as V/Vm
column7: and his work as the Caretaker
column8: whose An Empty Bliss Beyond This World repurposed old 78 rpm recordings to beautiful effect. The latter was a triumph of content over concept
column9: suggesting there's more to Kirby than the arch prankster
column10: laughing into his sleeve while smearing blood and vomit over memories of Chris de Burgh.

column1: The Stranger picks at a thread Kirby started on the Caretaker records
column2: once again returning to an area that loosely grapples with memory
column3: loss
column4: and fear. His work has peers—even the idiosyncratic approach to V/Vm wasn’t too far removed from artists such as Stock
column5: Hausen & Walkman and Kid606—but Watching Dead Empires in Decay is his first record that feels like it's slotting into a scene instead of operating on its fringes. It's cast into a similar shadow to the one artists like the Haxan Cloak and Raime are working under
column6: and Demdike Stare before them. The Stranger's music carries a similar air of reimagined nightmares
column7: depicted as places full of precipitous surfaces and figures endlessly plodding through violent terrain.

column1: By working in this area Kirby is continuing his fascination with memory
column2: arguably taking it even further out into the abstract than he has before. Where Bliss was all faded glamor and ruminations on a time long passed
column3: Dead Empires dwells harder on the darker subconscious
column4: giving it a tactile edge that replaces the suggestive ambience of the Caretaker material. There's also a greater reliance on drama and narrative. The way the skeletal beats of ""Spiral of Decline"" build is suggestive of a particularly unpleasant turn in a movie
column5: and the standout ""Where Are Our Monsters Now
column6: Where Are Our Friends?"" is driven by powerful slabs of electronic noise that highlight Kirby's ear for suspense.

column1: Where Kirby succeeds over some of the lesser artists currently plowing this field is in the detail he lends to his work. There's a grain to his samples
column2: perhaps inspired by his work with surface-noise textures on Bliss. ""We Scarcely See Sunlight"" is driven by sparse layers that resemble someone bashing pipes in a dank basement
column3: but it's the swirl of hiss around the sound that gives it an air of menace
column4: with Kirby repurposing lo-fi for his own evil needs. On ""Ill Fares the Land""—a title that taps into the current horror fad for mining old English folklore for chills—he heads in the opposite direction and floods the track with sound
column5: piling up chaotic layers of pistons to the point of combustion.

column1: There's some beauty here
column2: although it’s decidedly muted in tone. Kirby just leaves faint traces of it trailing through tracks—a spindle-thin keyboard riff
column3: or a sample of strings rising and falling. Dead Empires isn't an album that deals in hope much
column4: instead approaching the chaos and confusion of memory and scattering it into the open. There's something more human here than the work of
column5: say
column6: Raime
column7: whose world is far colder than that of the Stranger. Kirby's fondness for disorder is a perfect fit for this type of material. Dream states rarely make sense until you plunge deep into them
column8:
and Dead Empires throws up thousands of different routes to get tangled up in on the way down there.

"|18686.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18686-the-stranger-watching-dead-empires-in-decay/|7.6|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19882/homepage_large.7ec2e4e4.jpg|Get There|31806.0|Minor Alps|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Barsuk']|2013-11-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:32.605444|"

Pairing Juliana Hatfield with Nada Surf’s Matthew Caws makes sense. Both had brushes with mainstream success as MTV-approved alt-rock acts in the 90s. Both eschewed any laurel-resting and stretched those fleeting moments of pop-culture prominence into lengthy careers that have creatively eclipsed (or at least matched) their early work—so much so that they’re now known by many more for their output in the aughts than those angsty beginnings. Both have chipped away at that angst over the years
column2: mellowing and polishing as they’ve matured. The pair’s new band
column3: Minor Alps
column4: is a predictable stroll along that same well-trod road
column5: and their debut
column6: <i>Get There
column7: files down any remnants of jagged alt-rock edges even further.

column1: Caws and Hatfield have similarly thin but satisfying voices
column2: and they blend remarkably well—so well
column3: in fact
column4: that they chose to double each other on almost every line of every song. There’s no sense of “This one’s his song” or “This one’s her song” on Get There. They co-wrote all the lyrics and played all the instruments
column5: minus some drums. It’s a true collaboration. The vocal blend
column6: though
column7: is a little too perfect. Caws and Hatfield fortify each other’s shared strengths without filling in the gaps. At first it’s a fun novelty. Putting the singers in front of the mic at the same time
column8: all the time
column9: creates one mega-smooth vocal
column10: but the subtleties that can only materialize when someone sings alone
column11: out in front of a song
column12: are lost.

column1: Then there’s the formula factor. Minor Alps seem content to peddle pleasant but not particularly memorable pop-rock. Quiet verses lead into louder choruses with big drums and whitewashed guitars as Caws and Hatfield repeat a phrase that
column2: depending on the song
column3: becomes either more meaningful with each cycle (e.g. “Lonely low”) or collapses under the weight of repetition (e.g. “I don’t know what to do with my hands” and “If I wanted trouble I could find it”).

column1: It’s never a good sign when a band sounds like they're in a rut on a debut
column2: but the formulaic aspect alone doesn’t damn the collection. Some formulas work just fine. This one works well enough to be genial background music
column3: but not enough to keep your ears cocked for 11 songs
column4: especially when Get There is so lyrically spotty. “Maybe the phone will ring/ and then I’ll get to answer i-i-it” grates the most. It feels especially lazy and forced since the line doesn’t even need to rhyme. It’s hard to know why Hatfield and/or Caws didn’t rework i-i-it. There are other throwaways
column5: too
column6: like
column7: “I really gotta get to you/ I really don’t know what to do.”

column1: “Mixed Feelings” attempts to inject punk energy into the middle of the record to mixed results (a welcome change of pace yet still feels neutered)
column2: but the best parts of Get There are the mellow moments
column3: which also tend to coincide with Minor Alps breaking up the anonymous guitar/drums/bass sounds with computerized beats and other digital detritus. Lead-off track “Buried Plans” initially got me excited about this record with its drum-machine groove
column4: gorgeous harmonies
column5: and loose structure. Caws channels Elliott Smith on the lovely fingerpicked
column6: acoustic number “Maxon”
column7: singing on his own (albeit briefly) about an amble to the store for a 9-volt battery
column8: which turns into a meditation on transition and the pace of life. “I should hurry but I take my time
column9: ” he sings. “It keeps the panic level low.” An unhurried
column10: casual nature is part of what makes Get There’s softer material pretty
column11: but it could also be the thing holding Minor Alps back from writing truly great
column12:
uptempo rock songs. Upping the panic level and injecting urgency would help Minor Alps feel more like a rock band and less like a side project formed over afternoon tea.

"|18690.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18690-minor-alps-get-there/|4.9|Joel Oliphint

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19810/homepage_large.64d61bfc.jpg|Serpents Unleashed|5920.0|Skeletonwitch|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Prosthetic']|2013-11-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:33.290600|"

After a decade as a band
column2: five albums
column3: and enough miles logged in tour vans and planes to have circumnavigated the Earth several dozen times
column4: Athens
column5: Ohio metal diehards Skeletonwitch finally have their anthem. “More Cruel than Weak”—the longest song on their new and best album to date
column6: Serpents Unleashed—builds
column7: much like the band’s career has
column8: in a slow
column9: stepwise fashion. Gentle electric guitars duet around a distant drone
column10: falling in and out and eventually adding a touch of menace just as a steady cymbal splash rises to meet them. The full kit kicks in
column11: and the quintet holds steady for a moment. Then
column12: in prototypical Skeletonwitch form
column13: they rage
column14: plowing delightedly headlong through an uneven mix of thrash
column15: black
column16: and death metals. “This darkness gives me reason
column17: ” growls Chance Garnette
column18: his voice lathered with experience. “From this evil I draw strength.” Skeletonwitch swivel around a laser-edged riff and lean hard into chest-quaking
column19: double-kick drum runs. Garnette continues with his perfect series of power-of-metal credos: “If I must go down
column20: I will go down fucking hard
column21: ” or “Triumph only comes to those who possess the will/ to confront
column22: annihilate the enemy.”

column1: If all this sounds very serious
column2: know that Garnette’s braggadocio scans more like a smile than a threat. (Remember: Their name is Skeletonwitch
column3: which begs as much of a grin as a wince.) In fact
column4: though Serpents Unleashed overruns with lyrics about “crush[-ing] the weak and feeble” and commands to self-immolate
column5: Skeletonwitch seem to thrive on the fun they have as a band. Their mix of Immortal and Exodus
column6: Amon Amarth and Iron Maiden is nothing if not excitable
column7: never more so than on this fifth record. This music has become their lifestyle
column8: after all
column9: the thing that’s kept them on the road most of every year for most of the last decade. “More Cruel than Weak” feels like an internal memo that’s been made public
column10: a reminder to stay mean while smiling and vice versa. All of Serpents Unleashed seems to chase that aim: The dual
column11: often-dueling leads of Scott Hedrick and Nate Garnette are zealous and excitable
column12: with solos that shoot out like solar flares and synchronized leads that feel like well-timed high fives. The rhythm section is equally emphatic; drummer Dustin Boltjes
column13: who stands out on his second album with Skeletonwitch
column14: finds a groove and then abuses it
column15: racing to add extra hits in unexpected spaces. During the early-album pairing of “I Am of Death (Hell Has Arrived)” and “From a Cloudless Sky”
column16: he pivots from black metal sustains to classic hard rock patience
column17: never forsaking the pneumatic precision that’s become a hallmark.

column1: In the best way
column2: Skeletonwitch have begun to flirt with artlessness
column3: delivering their distillation with a chutzpah that makes you hope they never try anything else. Despite that consistency
column4: Skeletonwitch have changed producers for each of their albums
column5: working with grunge survivor Jack Endino for 2009’s Breathing the Fire and major label veteran Matt Hyde on their most recent album
column6: 2011’s Forever Abomination. The results of those changes have been minimal; they sounded a bit slicker and streamlined on Forever Abomination
column7: and they seemed to have a slightly wider stylistic range on its predecessor. “We show up ready to go
column8: ” Hedrick admitted to Invisible Oranges late last year. “Typically very little gets changed in the studio.” But working with Converge guitarist and amplified egghead Kurt Ballou seems to have afforded Skeletonwitch’s sound extra depth. During the turnaround of “Beneath Dead Leaves”
column9: for instance
column10: Evan Linger’s bass pops like it never has before. The looming
column11: mid-tempo throb that precedes the inevitable barrage of “Unending
column12: Everliving” provides not only a break in the hyperactivity but shows that
column13: for a band so locked into an approach
column14: they can convincingly (even if only momentarily) push out of it
column15: too. There’s more space between the guitars as well
column16: giving the riffs and counters more room to work. These are simple touches
column17: sure
column18: but they stretch the bounds of Skeletonwitch just enough to notice.

column1: Skeletonwitch have forever been known as a “live band
column2: ” a fitting if somewhat unbecoming turn for an act whose records have served mostly as advertisements for incredible live shows. On stage
column3: Skeletonwitch are fun and somewhat jocular
column4: a band that laces punishment with personality. In the studio
column5: though
column6: that’s generally been lost in the relentless of their 40-minute barrages. Serpents Unleashed doesn’t really amplify that aspect of the band
column7: either
column8: and their preferred form of power does occasionally blur into its own monolith. But it does add force and pacing
column9: tweaks that help these 11 songs stand independently of the need to see them played live. That’s an added bonus
column10: then
column11:
to Skeletonwitch’s familiar and unfussy sound. 

"|18617.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18617-skeletonwitch-serpents-unleashed/|7.5|Grayson Currin

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19946/homepage_large.e1dbdfbe.jpg|Jamaica Plain EP|19785.0|Kurt Vile|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Care in the Community']|2013-11-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:34.007578|"

It's become part of Kurt Vile's small mythology
column2: insofar as he has one: The few post-high school years he lived in Boston
column3: away from his childhood friends in Philly. This brief purgatory—spent discovering John Fahey
column4: driving a forklift to make ends meet
column5: and wondering where all his friends had gone—was a formative
column6: fertile period
column7: the years in which he discovered and honed his inimitable finger-picking style and zeroed in on the wry
column8: cosmic loneliness that would become his defining sound. He came back to Philly from what he once called his ""weird little exile"" with his first fully formed songs intact.

column1: The Jamaica Plain EP is an artifact from those earliest days. It's a collaboration with Robert Robinson
column2: whose solo home-recording project
column3: Sore Eros
column4: concerned itself mostly with sad
column5: blobby tangles of finger-picked guitars and tape manipulation. You can hear some of these same interests in Vile's earliest work
column6: specifically the water-logged instrumental pieces that dot 2008's Constant Hitmaker. Vile has mostly left his interest in extreme tape manipulation and soggy lo-fi charm behind him
column7: but the Jamaica Plain EP offers a brief and fitfully pretty glance backwards.

column1: Its three songs are inchoate
column2: modestly lovely
column3: and largely inconsequential
column4: hinting at a time when Vile was starting to figure out his aesthetic. On ""Serum""
column5: Robinson's vocals poke their way through a mix of acoustic guitars
column6: ambient electronics
column7: and tape hiss
column8: blurred together and melted down. The title track has sleepy slide guitar that feels like an early sketch of the little waiting-room-of-the-soul painted on ""Goldtone"". The solo guitar piece ""Calling Out of Work"" is closest to the Vile we recognize today—the chord progression is meandering and gently sad
column9: the electric guitars at the top of the track trail occasionally into firefly wisps. It goes on
column10: unnecessarily
column11: for six minutes
column12: but the late-summer-sky light rays of Vile's breakthrough Hitmaker peek through
column13: in shafts and glints. That said
column14: it's hard to imagine who to recommend it to: ephemera and early works can be interesting
column15: even if they're unsatisfying or mediocre
column16: if they help add to our sense of the artist
column17: suggesting a larger puzzle about how they became great.

column1: it's a big world out there (and i am scared)
column2: an EP of newer material
column3: is pocket lint
column4: to put it bluntly
column5: dug out of the corners of the masterful Wakin On A Pretty Daze. Vile's a prolific songwriter; there are usually three or four revelatory songs from each album that hit the cutting room floor. His 2011 EP So Outta Reach
column6: drawing on the Smoke Ring For My Halo sessions
column7: gave us a lot of extra meat to chew on—his cover of Bruce Springsteen's ""Downbound Train""
column8: for instance. There is less to dig into on it's a big world—are you excited at the prospect of owning a version of Wakin's ""Never Run Away"" with synth strings
column9: with two reprises? How about an extended version of that album's ""Snowflakes""
column10: or an instrumental version of ""Airbud""? No?

column1: To be fair
column2: there are two bona-fide new Kurt Vile songs on it's a big world out there. ""Feel My Pain"" sounds like a working draft that he later pried apart into two
column3: better songs—""Was All Talk"" and ""Pure Pain""—when he realized it wasn't working on its own. ""The Ghost of Freddie Roach""
column4: meanwhile
column5: is peak Vile
column6: six slowly unfurling minutes of a coughing drum machine and guitars upon guitars upon guitars—guitars murmuring to each other
column7: guitars strumming off in a corner to themselves
column8: high chiming solos that move so slowly and aimlessly over the top of the mix they blur into texture. It's an ocean of sound
column9: one that Vile seems to summon as effortlessly as yawning by now. It's not quite enough to justify both of the appearance of these globs
column10: half-heartedly tossed out onto the pile at the end of a release year
column11:
but it's close.

The Weeknd's House of Balloons is one of the more influential records of this decade
column2: but thanks to Solange Knowles
column3: “alt-R&B” would have happened without it. The sonic aesthetic she’s pieced together—a crackling experimental streak with potent pop hooks—is deeply pleasurable
column4: and though she hasn't recorded anything as monumental as House of Balloons
column5: people have increasingly taken notice. It's unknown whether or not Solange was attempting to claim the credit she’s owed while curating her Saint Heron compilation
column6: but listening to it
column7: it certainly has that result. Although most of its songs are previously released
column8: she’s assembled them into a coherent piece that transcends the usual odds-and-sods nature of the compilation format. It's an aesthetic manifesto of a specific corner of a rapidly expanding scene—the Flex Your Head or No New York of ambitious
column9: minimalist R&B that possesses considerable mainstream ambition and appeal.

column1: Those loose parameters contain a broad range of sounds and styles. B.C. Kingdom’s album-opening “Lockup” and Kingdom’s “Bank Head” (featuring vocals by Kelela
column2: whose “Go All Night” also appears) both give off a stiffly robotic funkiness—the latter through a juddering bass synth
column3: and the former via the tasteful application of Robocop noises. Sampha’s “Beneath the Tree” is a jazzy piano ballad set to drum programming that combines elements of two-step
column4: footwork
column5: and Burial-style found-sound beats. Jade de la Fleur’s “Jaded” has the brutally stripped-down arrangement and smoky paranoia of a top-tier Tricky song. Spanish producer Pional's remix of South African artist Petit Noir's “Noirse"" clears away the comp’s nocturnal moodiness with bright
column6: syncopated staccato melodies passed down from township music.

column1: Despite their different approaches
column2: the tracks all share a few basic commonalities: deep bass unimpeded by fussy arrangements
column3: stoner-friendly electronic textures
column4: and a willingness to borrow from pretty much any musical style that can project stylishly understated sexiness
column5: whether it’s post-dubstep or 4AD-style atmospheric goth. Above all
column6: these songs are also song-focused—the artists assembled here may all have deep experimental streaks
column7: but they never ignore pop’s pleasure principle
column8: and there are hooks all over the place on this near-flawlessly sequenced compilation.

column1: Solange wrote and co-produced her own wryly titled contribution
column2: “Cash In”
column3: and the track's one of the most aesthetically conservative songs on the compilation
column4: featuring a straightforward beat
column5: a relatively lush arrangement
column6: and the kind of gracefully building
column7: inspirational melody that slow-jam R&B hits are made from. It's the one song on Saint Heron that I could see getting radio rotation
column8: a swaggering
column9: graceful power move. It may have taken her a while to get to the point where she can pull such a gesture off
column10: but in this insurgent territory
column11:
Solange reigns supreme.

If you were up front during a Magik Markers show in 2004
column3: singer Elisa Ambrogio might have handed you her guitar. And there you'd be
column4: effectively on stage improvising in the eye of a violent noise jam with Pete Nolan going ape on his drums and former bassist Leah Quimby punching her bass beside you. You would’ve been apart of Magik Markers’ unformatted anti-songs
column5: whose structure and shape could hardly be charted in the moment. They'd maybe make more sense later on one of the over 50 releases they put out on LP
column6: cassette
column7: and CD-R and hawked at the merch table after the show. There was a time when Magik Markers didn’t put much stock into the idea of “songs
column8: ” whether as a dialectical comment on performer vs. audience
column9: as an act of political dissidence
column10: or because they simply loved making noise music.

column1: Truth is
column2: they were just being honest. Read any interview with Ambrogio over the years
column3: and one of the recurring themes is an all-eclipsing necessity to tell the truth with her music. Earlier this year
column4: she said
column5: “…telling the truth has the potential when done right to communicate a massive experience: the smaller and more precisely an honest human thing is rendered
column6: is the more common it becomes.” This is somewhat tautological (few artists ride hard for “lying”)
column7: and it’s hardly a revelation in the big scheme of creating art
column8: but the decade-long journey from the early days of Magik Markers to Surrender to the Fantasy is largely about mapping how they express themselves as performers and songwriters. And while intentions can be dubious
column9: what emerges in Magik Markers' first album in almost four years is their formerly hidden songcraft
column10: at once small and precise.

column1: Surrender has been fermenting on two-inch in the years following 2009’s Balf Quarry. Recorded partially in J Mascis’ Attic in Amherst
column2: MA
column3: partially at Ambrogio's dad’s basement in the band’s hometown of Hartford
column4: CT
column5: and at many East Coast practice spaces in between
column6: the band takes the focused quality of their recent output and at long last adds warmth. For all the different environments that Ambrogio
column7: Nolan
column8: and new bassist John Shaw recorded in
column9: they managed to sedate chaos into 45 minutes of form and shape. These are more “songs” like the band has been making since 2007's BOSS
column10: but for semantic’s sake
column11: the band hasn’t been writing “songs” since BOSS so much as they’ve been better at whittling down what they’ve always done
column12: being sure to leave all the knots and lathe marks in the final product.

column1: They've finally and cautiously surrendered themselves fully to melody. Ambrogio opens the album on “Crebs” singing sweetly
column2: “Everything about me feels so free” and the following songs stick pretty close to that sentiment. It's a natural step-though
column3: and if you factor in Ambrogio’s bare songs as 200 Years (her collaboration with Six Organs of Admittance's Ben Chasny) and the band's recent friendship with labelmates/tourmates/split-EP-mates Sic Alps
column4: the math checks out. “Mirrorless” has a cool desert look
column5: riding on red-eyed fuzz and reverb
column6: while the beautiful ""Young"" features little more than an acoustic guitar and a cello. The tenor of these songs are a far cry away from when Ambrogio sang
column7: “This gun was made to pull the trigger” in 2007.

column1: All the violence and spit of early Magik Markers now manifests itself in subtler ways than broken amplifiers and feedback squalls. They dip into amphetamine-surf rock with ""Bonfire""
column2: fully booted Neil Young explorations in ""Acts of Desperation""
column3: and shredded Shaggs via closer ""WT"". The heart of the album
column4: however
column5: beats in the near-seven-minute treatise ""American Sphinx Face"". Like Patti Smith and Kathleen Hanna before her
column6: Ambrogio's fearless stream of conscious delivery is a coil of surrealism
column7: politics
column8: and intense love. Whereas much of Surrender takes a more conventional lyrical approach (the pointed platitude of ""Youth"" goes
column9: ""The worst part about being young/ Is thinking nothing ever comes”)
column10: Ambrogio's words on ""American Sphinx Face"" are delivered unsung
column11: unadorned behind some proto-Markers psych-improvisation. ""I intend to be loved and see how it goes
column12: she says dryly. As the noise of the song grows wider and wider
column13: Ambrogio sharpens her tongue: ""In America every man is a king/ No good king but a dead king."" The towering song gives shape and meaning to the tender pieces that surround it.

column1: The risk to explore more ""pedestrian"" forms—to lay bare songs into the common world of structure
column2: hushed melodies
column3: and harmonies—gives Surrender a varied topography. The tiny moments of vulnerability in Ambrogio's voice or Nolan's barely-there drumming are buoyed by their noisy nature and their surreal sketches. More than any Markers record before it
column4: the trio seem to be communicating deep within the subconscious
column5: tapping into soul that's been hiding behind the noise for years. Surrender could be viewed as a kind of acquiescence to plots and narratives
column6: the kind Ambrogio was so opposed to when she started the band
column7:
back when chaos ruled. But to me this is leaning closer toward a more universal expression told in the Markers' own way—a set of honed truths that communicate on grand scales.

“If an artist is ever going to carve out a new territory their work needs to be different at the seed-level
column2: different before the start.” This statement from New Zealand’s Olly Peryman touches on one of the most interesting aspects of his work: its provenance. From one perspective
column3: Peryman’s music as Fis is an offshoot of the contemporary drum and bass scene
column4: taking up a set of propositions set out by dBridge and Instra:mental’s Autonomic project at the turn of the decade and coming back with fascinatingly illogical conclusions. From another
column5: Peryman is a singular figure whose avant-garde rhythmic constructs have converged only briefly with a wider movement.

column1: Peryman’s activities so far have lent weight to the former theory. Discovered after handing a CD to the boss of New Zealand’s bastion of innovative drum and bass
column2: Samurai Records
column3: the producer has since released music on Samurai’s experimental sublabel
column4: Horo
column5: and dBridge’s Exit Records. His work tends to occupy the 170bpm tempo range common to the style
column6: and explores
column7: however obscurely
column8: the same highly poised interzone between frenetic doubletime and its halftime counterpart. Often
column9: too
column10: his claustrophobic grooves bear traces of the DnB’s well-worn signifiers: the clipped snarl of a Reese bass
column11: submerged echoes of ragga rudeness.

column1: But the recent Homologous EP felt like Peryman was in the process of uncovering an altogether new rhythmic grammar. The producer has long ignored the quantizing function of his music software
column2: preferring to work off-grid; lately
column3: he says
column4: his rhythms have been drawn from “what I hear and see from my body during meditation.” Appearing through Void Coms—a new label in which Peryman has a hand—and accompanied by an Yves Klein-derived manifesto about achieving a state that is “void of worldly influences
column5: ” the EP was still distinctively
column6: inimitably FIS—but it was difficult to claim any link to drum and bass.

column1: The appearance of Peryman’s latest
column2: the Preparations EP
column3: through Brooklyn label Tri Angle
column4: further complicates matters. Suddenly it’s tempting to hear parallels with the darker fringes of the label’s trans-genre roster: Vessel’s scorched techno perhaps
column5: or Howse’s dreamy footwork abstractions. Certainly
column6: there is a forlorn melodicism to some of Peryman’s music which may initially have caught label head Robin Carolan’s ear—although it’s only a fleeting presence on the Preparations EP.

column1: In fact
column2: this EP hinges around a rather old FIS production
column3: and one that finds him at his most conventional. ""DMT Usher""
column4: which received a vinyl-only release through Samurai Horo in 2012
column5: is Peryman’s equivalent of a crowd pleaser
column6: centred around a single downsliding bass tone that sputters and wheezes like a damaged strimmer. As always with a FIS production
column7: the thrill is in the small things: the uncanny weft of the sounds
column8: the micro-rhythmic push and pull of the percussion. But
column9: arranged according to fairly rote build-and-drop dynamics
column10: the track isn’t his most thrilling work.

column1: Better is ""Mildew Swoosh""
column2: which pushes that halftime-doubletime dichotomy to a breaking point: pulling one way is the scrabbling insectoid percussion and scintillating synth arp; against them
column3: drifting
column4: somnolent pads. But Peryman really thrives when he explores greater extremes of abstraction. ""Magister Nunns"" and ""CE Visions"" are ominous beasts
column5: their grooves buried
column6: protean
column7: and beset by spumes of cavernous reverb. The former
column8: in particular
column9: seems to crumble as it hits the air
column10: as if we’re hearing Disintegration Loops-style tape degradation in time lapse. It makes for an exhausting listen
column11:
but since when was starting from scratch easy?

How to Stop Your Brain in an Accident
column2: Future of the Left's fourth studio album
column3: is built on political
column4: pugilistic rage: The guitars hack and slash while the bass and drums pummel over every lyric. The thing that'll gall most Lefties is that this album is all but absent of synths
column5: which lends an unrelenting aggression. This isn't an new move; although their last record had a handful of great keyboard moments—the glitchy noise of ""Failed Olympic Bid""
column6: the electronic blasts of ""Polymers Are Forever""—Future of the Left have been steadily moving away from the ""synth"" part of synth-punk for years now
column7: refining the menace of the guitar/bass/drums setup. Apart from the acoustic reprieve on ""French Lessons"" or the gothic-country of ""Why Aren't I Going to Hell?""
column8: How to Stop Your Brain is like a flurry of damning punches bludgeoning your face. It's their toughest
column9: meatiest record to date.

column1: Future of the Left's constant is Falco's voice
column2: sung in an impish sneer
column3: casting himself as the mischievous Puckish figure
column4: the only one who knows what's really goin' on
column5: though you are never sure what's sincere and what's sarcastic. Wit has always been part of Future of the Left's appeal
column6: but it's also the kind of distancing sneer of someone you've always wanted to impress
column7: but on some level
column8: know you never will. The sneer of the smartest guy in the room.

column1: Here
column2: that humor is very much intact. On ""Singing of the Bonesaws""
column3: Falco's vocal twists into the voice of a 1960s BBC newsreader
column4: matter-of-factly reporting the decay of civilisation as if reporting the weather. Reportedly it was written in the span of a lunch-break and it sounds as much
column5: playing out like a lucid stream-of-consciousness diatribe over a simple rhythm that shames just about everyone. But once it's beaten you into submission
column6: you begin to feel capable of throwing a few punches of your own
column7: and How to Stop Your Brain offers up one hell of a hit list: record companies
column8: the music industry hype machine
column9: the pedos who run the BBC and sleazy
column10: aging DJs.

column1: If the album has a coherent theme
column2: it's laid out in the opening track: ""I'm just a man/ A simple thing."" The album has something to say about what it means to be masculine in 2013
column3: and boy
column4: men do not come off looking great. On ""Donny of the Decks""
column5: the bruised meat of the issue is churned through the grinder of a slimy radio DJ well past his prime. Elsewhere
column6: ""The Male Gaze"" asks ""The passing train has left me behind/ If you turn into an object on the second night/ Will my eyes get used to it? / Will your heart compete with it?/ After failure."" To talk about sex in these primitive ways—hunter and hunted
column7: conquest and conquered—it's all so barbaric
column8: but to deal with all the sex on here
column9: you have to approach it on its own level.

column1: The album never really judges. Instead
column2: it draws pathetic portraits of these sex-crazed worms and allows them to condemn themselves with their descent into sexual irrelevance. It's a particularly skilful form of torture and one Future of the Left do with frustrating regularity. They've all the trappings of a Band Who Could Be Your Life
column3: from the name to their defiant energy to the state-of-affairs type lyrics. But their songs provide no model for a better society
column4: no scripture
column5: and no guilty verdict.  Even ""She Gets Passed Around at Parties""
column6: a fairly straightforward story mirroring that 37-dicks scene from Clerks in which an insecure guy has to deal with his loved one's former promiscuity
column7: doesn't make a call either way. Instead
column8: Future of the Left know that we're all our own worst enemies
column9: the most elegant engineers of our own miserable downfall
column10: because we're the only ones who know how pathetic we truly are.

column1: For however much of the album concerns itself with the festering axe wounds of our society and the confused lunks trying to crawl their way into 'em
column2: it also doubles down on Future of the Left's trademark firebomb-throwing brutality. It's nasty and explosive and full of bile
column3: a hard rockin' bare-knuckle blow to the temple that'll lay you flat out. In other words
column4: How to Stop Your Brain in an Accident is just the thing for the modern man
column5:
those confused and angrily impotent brutes.

It's not easy to establish a distinctive voice in the realm of house music
column3: but since John Talabot's arrived on the scene
column4: he's done just that. The Barcelona producer's spent the last four years crafting and refining his own prismatic take on the dance sub-genre
column5: fusing psychedelic sprawl with a sense of pop-like pacing in a way that has established his position as a crossover artist in an area of music that is typically a niche concern. Interestingly
column6: his headier work has gained just as much
column7: if not more
column8: attention than his more streamlined material: ""Families""
column9: his 2011 single with Los Angeles electro-pop auteur and Glasser mastermind Cameron Mesirow
column10: may be Talabot's most pop-refined cut to date
column11: but it's ""Sunshine""
column12: the hypnotizing 2009 single that served as his breakout moment
column13: that still stands as one of his most widely beloved tracks.

column1: Anchored around a sample of impassioned chanting that crests beautifully as tinkling bells swirl and lope around it
column2: ""Sunshine"" bears resemblance to minimal techno legend Ricardo Villalobos' masterful 2008 single ""Enfants (Chants)""—but that comparison could prove potentially misleading. What Talabot does isn't minimal
column3: nor does he skew in the other
column4: more boisterous direction; he's all about control
column5: knowing when to let his vat of sounds gorgeously overflow and when to bring the pot down to a tight
column6: focused simmer. Last year's astounding debut LP ƒIN
column7: then
column8: was a demonstration of his steady hand and mind
column9: a jade-textured record that alternately—and sometimes
column10: simultaneously—shimmered and pulsated with iridescent light.

column1: Mixes don't always explicitly reflect a producer's artistic flair
column2: but Talabot's entry in !K7's long-running DJ-Kicks series is different. An album-length stitchwork of euphoric moments and rich textures
column3: the 75-minute mix proves that everything this guy touches can't help but turn mossy
column4: earthy
column5: groovy. Considering how much of this mix is other people's work reflected in Talabot's own visage
column6: the overall continuation here of the sounds found on ƒIN is impressive and
column7: for the impatient
column8: quite handy. As Philip Sherburne noted in our review of that record
column9: ƒIN was the result of Talabot undergoing a nearly decade-long transformation as an artist
column10: so who knows when we'll get the follow-up to that record—dance artists typically work in the singles format
column11: so long-players typically are not a priority—which makes this DJ-Kicks mix a capable
column12: reflective stopgap release.

column1: In terms of selection
column2: the mix is not too surprising taste-wise
column3: a balanced breakfast of deep-house pulsers and percolating techno jams that keep the mood nice and steady. One track in particular
column4: though
column5: is worth highlighting for its revelatory nature: Mancunian dub-techno crawler Andy Stott's uneasy remix of British shoegaze outfit Maps' ""I Heard Them Say""
column6: the first arguable peak that appears early in this DJ-Kicks installment. When I first heard this remix upon initial release
column7: I was unimpressed—possibly because endless replays of Stott's commanding 2012 LP Luxury Problems has raised expectations for Stott-branded material a little too highly—but Talabot breathes new life into the track here
column8: as it slithers and leaves a trail of glowing slime that sticks to the mix's opening third. The remix's inclusion also draws a previously unseen analogue between Stott and Talabot
column9: two artists working with distinctly different approaches that nonetheless share a love for dipping their own contractions in layers of drowsy
column10: clattery haze.

column1: Artists from Talabot's Hivern label make appearances throughout
column2: providing seemingly unreleased cuts and showcasing the collective's ear for glistening melodic dance music: Danish producer Round's ""Glass"" provides a particular moment of bliss with a classic structure and a slight sweep of tones
column3: while Franc Sayol's Mistakes Are Okay project offers up the moody ""Night Watcher"" to serve as a darkly shaded interstitial cut. In the end
column4: though
column5: Talabot himself steals the show
column6: bounding past DJ-Kicks' tradition of the compiling artist offering up an exclusive track by putting forth three new cuts he had a hand in.

column1: There's ""Anagrama""
column2: the tropical
column3: woozy track from his and Genius of Time member Alexander Berg's Tempel Rytmik project
column4: and the slyly anthemic ""Sideral""
column5: a result of Talabot's team-up with Swedish producer Axel Boman (as Talaboman). The true stunner of the three
column6: though—as well as possibly the big highlight on the mix—is Talabot's own ""Without You""
column7: a big-room jam that wraps layers of shiny
column8: winsome synth work around a muted vocal line like a barbershop pole. The track's yet another pristine example of Talabot's sense of pacing
column9: as he dampens the beat midway through before bringing it back again to reinforce ""Without You""'s strong melodic backbone.

column1: John Talabot's DJ-Kicks entry isn't the flashiest mix you'll encounter this year
column2: and there's plenty of room for debate as to whether it ranks in the upper echelon of the series' many installments. Similar to ƒIN
column3: though
column4: it's an immersive experience that grows richer with every listen
column5: as new details emerge from the throbbing green slurry that binds the tracks together. Talabot's ear for songs that walk the balance between trippiness and accessibility is his greatest gift
column6: but this DJ-Kicks mix proves that his hidden strength is a keen sense of structure. The constant chug
column7: a push-and-pull that gives as good as it gets
column8: is not unlike pumping blood—and if you're in the right mindset
column9: a deep listen to this solid collection will give you life
column10:
too.

 There’s a moment during the commentary packaged with Throwing Muses new album Purgatory/Paradise
column2: after drummer Dave Narcizo offers up a particularly ribald interpretation of “Slippershell”
column3: where Kristin Hersh stops and laughs away the credit: “Sure. God wrote it.” From almost anyone else
column4: that would come off ridiculous
column5: a megalomaniac’s humblebrag
column6: but from Hersh it’s part of the origin story
column7: the one that’s been repeated in everything written about Throwing Muses from the 80s onward. Hersh has always held that she’s not a songwriter so much as a woman accosted by songs; her role
column8: she says
column9: is more like a transcriptionist
column10: or a vessel. Anything an outside audience might hear in them
column11: the story goes
column12: is coincidental. But Throwing Muses’ music never sounded like it sprung from any outside source so much as one that’s deeply personal­­. The chords lurch like feelings would; and the lyrics make internal sense. A track like “Fish” becomes far less surreal when you know that it’s referring to an actual fish nailed to an actual cross on Hersh’s actual apartment wall
column13: but even then it’s like listening in on a few minutes of monologue

column15: where the bits of dialogue

column17: and the rest of the stuff of someone else’s inner life may well be a foreign language. There are plenty of Throwing Muses tracks that are oblique—and a lot more than the band gets credit for that are needle-direct—but few that explain themselves.

column1: If this sounds at odds with finding a large audience

column4: ” which is both farther from the truth and closer to the practical reality. Hersh released solo albums on a fairly steady schedule
column5: but Throwing Muses released only one more record: the triumphant Throwing Muses. That was in 2003. Hersh formed another project
column6: 50 Foot Wave
column7: around this time
column8: but their last two EPs were released for free and quietly—as quietly
column9: that is
column10: as is possible for a band whose founding principle was “Throwing Muses
column11: if they were faster
column12: meaner and also swore a lot.” Hersh’s last solo album
column13: Crooked
column14: was self-released in 2009 nearly as quietly
column15: supported mostly by house shows and smallish acoustic concerts. And though demos of Purgatory/Paradise existed online as early as 2007 (a few were meant for Crooked)
column16: the audience they found was largely the same fans who crowdfunded the record. (Hersh was among the first to adopt the pay-what-you-want and subscription models Kickstarter and its ilk would later make inescapable.) While Throwing Muses did tour behind 2011’s Anthology compilation
column17: it would have taken close attention to think new material was forthcoming.

column1: Purgatory/Paradise
column2: as it turns out
column3: is the Muses’ first album in 10 years
column4: and “the work [the band] can die after releasing
column5: ” as Hersh jokes early in the commentary. (“We’re really looking forward to death. We work so hard to be allowed to die!”) But while 2003’s Throwing Muses was a comeback album in the familiar sense

column8: it most resembles Red Heaven or Limbo
column9: the forcefully aloof deep cuts of the Muses’ discography—but a shattered version
column10: “like someone reached over our heads with a Looney Tunes mallet and slammed it into our record before we could stop him
column11: ” Hersh wrote. (Like Crooked
column12: Purgatory/Paradise was devised both as a record and as a book

Some of them are reprises; sometimes the reprises come first. Some tracks are lopped-off bridges or choruses
column15: or thoughts beginning with “and.” It’s even more disorienting for cuts like “Static” whose uncut versions have been around long enough to memorize. This doesn’t necessarily seem odd for a band whose songs tend to skitter into loping girl-group choruses halfway or careen through dozens of chords that wouldn’t normally touch or scare-quote the entirety of some kid’s anarchy pamphlet as an intro

column17: recorded what they thought that sounded like
column18: then lost half the data to a defragmenting snafu.

column1: Not that Purgatory/Paradise is difficult or inaccessible. The beginning fakes you out with the almost stately folk of “Smoky Hands”
column2: but it’s just scene-setting before a song accosts you: a crash
column3: then “Morning Birds”
column4: an onslaught of shredding then pathos that’s as wrenching as anything on the first Muses record. “Sunray Venus”
column5: the single
column6: comes shortly after
column7: and it’s as joyous as “Morning Birds” is visceral. Like Wild Flag’s “Romance”
column8: it’s an exuberant ode to band chemistry that plays out like the Muses rediscovering all their hits (“leaving
column9: that is limbo—hey
column10: I remember you!”) and comes with a splashy video full of wordplay and intertextual Easter eggs. Later on is “Sleepwalking”
column11: a college-rock throwback where everything from the guitar lines to the glaze of the vocal processing seems imported from 1992. It’d be shameless if it weren’t so huge (and self-aware; the band calls it their “RC Cola song”)
column12: and it’s easy to imagine it on Doolittle or Last Splash—or for that matter Throwing Muses again; you can even trace out where Tanya Donelly’s harmonies would go.

column1: But that’s the second version of “Sleepwalking” you hear: the first version is what would ordinarily be end of the song
column2: a one-minute acoustic hangover. Songs come and go like this
column3: or more specifically moments: bassist Bernard Georges’ sly lead on “Cherry Candy”
column4: the spy riff and ballroom pirouette of a drum fill that introduces “Film” or the piano waltz it becomes halfway
column5: the panflutes of “Folding Fire” (if any instrument’s unexpected on a Throwing Muses album
column6: that would be it)
column7: certain melodies that recur or slip into the wrong tracks. The album
column8: to its credit
column9: rarely feels indulgent—only the two aimless “Curtains” stand out as possible edits—and the more you listen
column10: the more a method emerges from the muddle.

column1: Purgatory/Paradise
column2: more than any of Hersh’s records to date
column3: is an album about loss
column4: which might account for its fracturing. The closest thing to a traditionally built song is the bitterly determined “Milan”
column5: about a neighborhood in New Orleans where Hersh's house was destroyed after Hurricane Katrina. Everything else is tentative: memories listed in order of disapperance. Sometimes the loss is literal
column6: as in “Static”
column7: written for a close friend who died; the arrangement tiptoes at first
column8: then plunges straight into denial. Sometimes it’s almost funny: “Terra Nova”
column9: about the Muses’ first breakup
column10: is aimless and resigned
column11: melodies delivered like shrugs
column12: until it breaks out the “Bittersweet Symphony” strings. Sometimes it’s not funny at all
column13: as on “Quick
column14: ” a song built uneasily atop a cello dirge
column15: or “Bluff
column16: ” which is a curious lilting minute at first until its essay turns hazy into heartbreaking: “If you watch your friends carefully
column17: sometimes you'll notice their features beginning to change: curling up into themselves
column18: looking within rather than without
column19: their senses dulled.” (The more I listen
column20: the more it seems like a direct companion to “Flooding”
column21: the saddest song Hersh has ever recorded.)

column1: Purgatory/Paradise isn’t an easy listen—expected enough from a band that’s repeatedly referred to the recording process as being “on a [desert] island"". If Throwing Muses didn’t explain themselves before

column9: “It is not un-beautiful to be in pieces
column10:
as long as those pieces are fully realized.” It may be impossible for Throwing Muses to write anything that isn’t.

With the passing of Lou Reed
column2: we’ve been consistently reminded of the Velvet Underground’s geographic
column3: spiritual
column4: and financial disconnect from the dominant hippy-dippy rock bands of the day
column5: most of which hailed from California. But now that rock‘n’roll itself has become evermore disconnected from the contemporary popular-music landscape
column6: the similarities between the New York and San Fran schools of late-60s psychedelia are more pronounced than the differences. Sure
column7: the Velvets favored viscera over virtuosity
column8: but they ultimately shared the same goal as their Pacific nemeses: to explode the parameters of the pop song through improvised
column9: trance-inducing experimentation. But in case that connection isn’t explicit enough
column10: we have Wooden Shjips
column11: a band that
column12: for the past six years
column13: has been gradually folding the musical legacies of the east and the west
column14: and the under- and overground
column15: into one another. And Back to the Land marks the moment when they perfectly intersect.

column1: The band’s fourth album heads further into the earthier direction of its 2011 predecessor
column2: West
column3: and casts even more radiant rays of Golden State sunshine onto the band’s once-foreboding hypno-drone-rock. Its eight songs still adhere to Shjips’ trusty game plan—get to the jam
column4: stat. But if they’re sticking to the same procedural formula
column5: they’re changing the inputs to achieve a more harmonious balance of light and dark
column6: crossbreeding left-field figureheads with right-of-the-dial mainstays: the oscillating psych-blues swing of “Ruins” puts the Can in Canned Heat; “Ghouls” rides the Modern Lovers’ “Roadrunner” to the corner of Haight-Ashbury; “In the Roses” imagines Suicide headlining Monterrey; “Servants” flips the old rumor about Iggy Pop replacing Jim Morrison in the Doors by having the Lizard King front the Stooges.

column1: However
column2: the Shjips' firm grasp of their influences and inflexible M.O. essentially negates the possibility of this band ever really surprising you. All of these songs basically begin in full swing
column3: and from the first moment
column4: you can easily predict how they’re going to play out—formalities like verses and lyrics merely represent toll booths that are quickly bypassed en route to the open road. And yet
column5: for a band that obviously wants to steer clear of pop-song structures
column6: Wooden Shjips’ freewheeling guitar odysseys do little to disrupt or reshape their surroundings
column7: and the more easy-going
column8: smooth-sailing energy in effect here means the songs rarely make the leap from pleasant to powerful.

column1: So it’s doubly ironic that the most conventionally rendered track on Back to Land is also its most revelatory: With the closing “Everybody Knows”
column2: Wooden Shjips embark on their maiden voyage into melancholic (if still fuzzed-out) balladry
column3: and it’s a rewarding one at that. As usual
column4: frontman Ripley Johnson’s words are barely decipherable above the song's Crazy Horse haze
column5: but the affecting
column6: crestfallen feeling he invests in his performance cuts through loud and clear. Whether this breakthrough portends a change in course remains to be seen
column7: but
column8: at this point in their consistent-to-a-fault career
column9:
it's encouraging to hear Wooden Shjips draw the emotion out of their motion.

Even those dumb tchotkes we own can take on a greater meaning simply by virtue of how long we’ve owned them. Sometimes it’s a small wooden cabinet filled with thimbles or spoons
column3: or little magnets of all 50 states permanently fused onto the fridge door
column4: or a binder full of basketball cards I can’t let go of just yet. For Cate Le Bon
column5: it may be something as simple as collection of coffee mugs that as time wears on becomes a museum on a shelf
column6: endowed with tiny memories of the past. The Welshwoman sings on Mug Museum's title track
column7: “I forget the detail/ but remember the warmth.”

column1: Le Bon’s understated and modest third album is in part a lament to the erosion of memories
column2: all told with remarkable detail. These are small
column3: graceful songs with deceptive amounts of depth
column4: due in no small part to the circumstances surrounding writing the album. While in Wales last winter just as Le Bon was ready to move on from her 2012 album CYRK
column5: her maternal grandmother died. The songs on Mug Museum were written during that time of reacclimation after grief
column6: as Le Bon struggled with her loss and how affected her maternal role in her family.

column1: Le Bon navigates these uncertainties with both poise and a kind of performed confidence
column2: like someone just pushed her out on to the stage from the wings. Inspiration notwithstanding
column3: it’s the most spritely album she’s released
column4: though the songs themselves remain room-sized and unadorned. The band behind her
column5: featuring guitarist H. Hawkline and White Fence drummer Nick Murray
column6: hit at some familiar folk garage signposts from her previous albums. Mostly
column7: they're a tight
column8: scrappy Euro beat band from the 60s held together by a dusty organ underneath
column9: but sometimes they adopt more metro Television sound
column10: or a carefree California psych group.

column1: The main focus though is Le Bon
column2: whose voice grows more and more singular and versatile with each release. The Nico comparisons still linger on perhaps only because the two are just biologically similar in their yawn-to-song delivery. But where Nico’s voice was alluring in a kind of siren way
column3: Le Bon’s is more curious and diverse. Sometimes she sounds like the shyest member of a folksy sylvan choir and other times she rears up and belts out a high soprano note at the climax of “Duke”. These precise melodies are often performed without precision
column4: or at least without consonants—something about her thick Welsh accent and tipsy elocution just makes her voice swirl around words rather than really land on them. When she sings
column5: “split me like timber
column6: ” or
column7: “beat me like egg yolks
column8: ” on “I Can’t Help You”
column9: it’s less the emotion behind the sentiment and more the joy in hearing the words spill out.

column1: And Le Bon revels in her language. For Le Bon
column2: who is one of a small percentage of people in this world who can speak Welsh and frequently sings in it
column3: her love for words rarely feels ostentatious
column4: and her gentle delivery rarely makes her words intrusive. There’s several simple turns of phrases on Mug Museum that are just captivating: the subtle transpositions in the chorus of “I Think I Knew”
column5: sung in a classic duet format with the well-paired Perfume Genius. There’s the tangled and desperate ""Mirror Me"" where she sings
column6: ""Mirror me/ Like you want me to be/ Like I want you to see me"" (a knowing inversion of Nico
column7: perhaps?). And there’s the emotional climax
column8: “Sisters”
column9: where Le Bon
column10: now powerful in her lower register
column11: proclaims
column12: “I won’t die/ I’m a sister”
column13: coated with denial and stuffed with subtext. We finally get a good look at her fear of mortality and sororal dread
column14: and even then
column15: it’s all boiling under her cool and collected voice.

column1: The pen gets away from Le Bon a few times on the record
column2: most notably on “Wild” where the band and Le Bon play with aggresive dissonance and purple prose
column3: respectively. They don’t work especially well trying to fill spaces
column4: they work better at sounding isolated in them. That’s what Le Bon does best: delicately amplify the tiniest moments that would otherwise go unnoticed. From H. Hawkline's erratic
column5: trashy guitar on late-album psych highlight “Cuckoo Through the Walls”
column6: to the creaking of the piano stool on the final track
column7: Mug Museum accumulates hundreds of pieces of Le Bon's life to form an imperfect whole. By the end as Le Bon sings alone above a rusty piano
column8: it sounds like she’s surveying the artifacts around her
column9: her questions and worries laid out in great detail in the nine tracks that came before it. Most of Mug Museum is bare and direct
column10: quaint and unassuming
column11:
but Le Bon makes a rather grand occasion out of it—she's a master curator and consummate immortalizer.

“Workmanlike” is a funny word. It can mean dependable

column1: Like their contemporaries in KEN Mode

column1: So then

Whores could benefit for putting their perspective a little higher in the mix. Nobody can really be the Melvins—we're still figuring out how much of their success is persistence

The Beatles mythos is a sum of historic locations: the Cavern Club
column2: the Ed Sullivan soundstage
column3: Shea Stadium
column4: the Maharishi’s Indian retreat
column5: the Apple Records rooftop. And yet there’s a place crucial to the band’s history that’s often left out of the narrative
column6: probably because it doesn’t make for the most exciting Rock Band backdrop: BBC Radio studios. The lasting images of Beatlemania are ones of constant motion: of airplanes and tarmacs
column7: of screaming teens chasing the band down the high street
column8: of limousines that act as decoys for other limousines. But in the midst of all that hysteria
column9: the Beatles managed to record 52 BBC radio programs over the course of 1962 to 1965
column10: and though they were mostly born out of promotional obligations
column11: the frequent shows allowed the band to engage with their fanatical fans from a safe distance. The BBC was where The Beatles could perform for an audience of millions without struggling to hear themselves sing over primitive concert-hall P.A.s
column12: and where—via mailed-in requests—they could interact with their many admirers without worrying about being trampled by the mob.

column1: This much was evident on 1994’s Live at the BBC compilation
column2: which functioned as a hermetically sealed time capsule of the Fab Four at their most innocent and fun-loving. The only evidence of the intense pressure the band were under at the time could be gleaned from the tracklist—with demand for new Beatles recordings far outstripping supply
column3: the band’s BBC playlists were stacked with as many Reeperbahn-tested covers as Lennon-McCartney originals. Vol. 2 offers a similarly proportioned mix
column4: with the now-familiar variations in fidelity that go with it. And it actually works within an even tighter timeframe than its predecessor
column5: which reached far enough into ’65 to feature the proto-psychedelic jangle of “Ticket to Ride.” Vol. 2
column6: by contrast
column7: sticks to 1963-64; the tracklist reaches as far as Beatles for Sale cuts “I’ll Follow the Sun” and “Kansas City/Hey-Hey-Hey!” but stops short of showcasing the more reflective
column8: emotionally invested songcraft that would define that album
column9: and the Beatles catalogue from that point forward.

column1: Like most sequels
column2: the new compilation presents a case of diminishing returns: where the first BBC collection yielded 30 songs that never surfaced on any of the Beatles’ proper albums
column3: the new set features but two (in the form of Chuck Berry and Tony Orlando covers) and about one third of the tracklist overlaps with the first set (albeit with the recurring tracks pulled from different sessions). But
column4: approached on its own terms
column5: Vol. 2 is still a pleasure to behold. While it’s designed to evoke a bygone era when congregating around the living-room radio was British-household ritual
column6: the grab-bag sequencing and strategically stitched between-song banter lend the collection a frenetic
column7: cut-and-paste momentum that’s remarkably attuned to modern listening habits.

column1: Here
column2: the Beatles sound less like legends-in-the-making than four school chums goofing off on an extended holiday
column3: giving shout-outs to various Liverpool landmarks
column4: playfully jousting with their straight-man hosts
column5: and accepting offers of jam butties from listeners. And
column6: further to this demystifying process
column7: the recordings serve as a reminder that
column8: like any aspiring group
column9: the Beatles were initially a sum of obvious influences: the dirty lo-fi rip through “I’m Talking About You” serves as a test run for “I Saw Her Standing There”; a winsome rendition of Buddy Holly’s “Words of Love” points the way to “Do You Want to Know a Secret"" And yet
column10: when you hear the band’s obvious affections for 50s hot-rod rock ‘n’ roll and Everly Brothers-style harmony-folk collide into perfectly formed pop salvos like “She Loves You""
column11: “From Me To You""
column12: and “I Want to Hold Your Hand""
column13: it’s still hard to believe such a pure
column14: crystalline sound could be produced by four exhausted guys playing live off the floor into mono mics. These songs may not form the basis for Cirque du Soleil revues or elaborate jukebox musical films
column15: but
column16: as fans from Billy Childish to Kurt Cobain to Alex Kapranos have attested
column17: there’s a case to be made that The Beatles peaked as a band in 1964.

column1: In the absence of a rare-cuts windfall
column2: Vol. 2’s most novel attraction is a series of one-on-one interviews conducted with each individual band member over the course of 1965-66
column3: a good year removed from their most breakneck period. But beyond all the deliciously prophetic anecdotes—John pondering the place of politics in his life
column4: George positing that the future of music lies in more sophisticated production
column5: Paul recounting his experience attending a Stockhausen gig—the interviews are emblematic of a moment when not only were the Beatles maturing
column6: so too was the very medium of music journalism; while the interviews are dotted with celebrity-tabloid-level queries like “how big is your house?” the conversations eventually drift into deeper ruminations on familial responsibility and
column7: given the expected short shelf life of pop groups at the time
column8: what the lads plan to do when the Beatles go bust. But even when faced with this more personal line of questioning
column9: the Beatles sound as relaxed
column10: confident
column11: and in their element as when they were knocking out “There’s a Place” or “The Hippy Hippy Shake” earlier in the set. Though The Beatles’ regular BBC visits would become much less frequent as the band embarked upon their most sonically adventurous phase
column12:
these sessions underscore the impetus behind it: this band was always so much more comfortable in the studio than on the road.

One of the best things about Seattle label Light in the Attic’s new new age compilation I Am the Center is that it doesn’t try and pretend that new age music was something that it’s not. Look at the album’s cover illustration and you’ll see an angel-like creature carrying an orb of yellow light through the clouds; open the gatefold and you’ll see what appears to be a bird made of stars launching itself out of the ocean. Press play and be delivered into over two hours of mind-numbingly mellow music with titles like “Unicorns in Paradise” and “Tien Fu: Heaven’s Gate”. The structures are simple and the textures are light. Focusing too hard on it is like trying to remember a dream you just had: It will do nothing but piss you off. But like the right color paint on the walls or a thoughtful arrangement of lamps
column2: good new age music feels both peripheral and essential: Something made not to be focused on as much as to remind people listening to it that focusing is only one way to experience the world.

column1: Center starts in 1950
column2: about 25 years before the term “new age” existed in any kind of widespread way
column3: and leads up to 1990
column4: when the genre had devolved into factory-like repetitions of itself. (Steve Vining
column5: who took over the pioneering label Windham Hill from its founder Will Ackerman
column6: once said that running it was more like running Proctor & Gamble than running a record label.) The picks here focus on private presses: Essentially
column7: DIY labels operating outside conventional channels of marketing and distribution. If there’s any argument being made by Light in the Attic here
column8: it’s that new age wasn’t just a multimillion-dollar industry engineered to relax middle-aged Americans rich enough to afford CD players in 1982 (when they cost the equivalent of about $1
column10: but an underground scene as self-reliant and countercultural as the ones surrounding newer labels like Oneohtrix Point Never’s Software or Los Angeles’ Not Not Fun—labels whose artists have recast aspects of new age as a form of punk
column11: or what Lopatin once called “quiet noise.”

column1: Like any genre
column2: the sound of new age varies. Some of the tracks here are acoustic; some are all electronic. Some—like the keyboardist Stephen Halpern or Brian Eno collaborator Laraaji—suggests a quiet
column3: person-to-person connection that way a folksinger with a guitar might. Others—a like Iasos and Constance Demby—make cavernous music seemingly designed to remind us that we are but specks of dust in a cosmos too awesomely infinite for our mortal brains to ever possibly comprehend. (Iasos insisted that his first album was not made by him but through him; Demby once invented an instrument called the “space bass” that she has described as “a transdimensional communication device”—gestures that both assert new age ideas about spirituality but also reassert very old-fashioned ones about how the self can dissolve when it comes into contact with the sublime.)

column1: Personally I prefer the less grandiose stuff
column2: but the variety of I Am the Center is one of its best attributes: Instead of pigeonholing the genre by turning it into something overly specific
column3: Center shows how artists with totally different approaches to sound and style can still be grouped together. Crucially
column4: it does this without trying to stretch the Venn diagram of new age to include artists or styles with more cultural cache
column5: like 70s classical composition or drone—music that shares new age’s interest in spirituality and repetition but that tends toward an intensity that
column6: in the context of new age
column7: seems damningly unchill. What you end up with is a compilation that stays true to its genre while also doing everything it can to demonstrate how varied that genre can be.

column1: When I was a kid
column2: I suffered intense anxiety problems
column3: which my mother tried to help me combat with a variety of cures: Exercise
column4: homeopathic medicine
column5: counseling
column6: religion
column7: and eventually
column8: new age music. While other kids were being subjected to the Beatles on car trips
column9: I lay on the carpeted floor of my room listening to cassettes with titles like Celestial Journeys and Inner Sanctum II: Reclaiming the Inner Sanctum. A few years later
column10: when I started to get into punk and hardcore
column11: I realized the best new age music wasn’t all that different: There was a similar purity of purpose
column12: a similar rejection of societal values
column13: and a similar unwillingness to bend
column14: either toward more concrete rhythms—which can sometimes turn new age into chintzy
column15: synth-heavy instrumental pop (e.g. the ubiquitous Kitaro)—or toward more complex compositions that might have leant their makers credibility but compromised the essentially relaxing quality that good new age promised never to disturb.

column1: Still
column2: I write this knowing that new age is among the most easily ridiculed genres of music that exists. Its practitioners can be somehow pretentious and weak-minded
column3: ludicrously abstract and yet as sure of their discoveries as a scientist. “Music helps to concentrate oneself
column4: ” the liner notes to I Am the Center start. “To bring oneself to an inner state when we can assume the greatest possible emancipations. That is why music is just the thing which helps you too see higher.” The words—a quote from Thomas de Hartmann—say it all
column5: which is to say that they don’t really say anything. Then comes the voice of Yoga Records founder and Center’s compiler
column6: Douglas Mcgowan: “So many declarative statements to make on the subject of new age
column7: and so little time. And yet
column8: ” he goes on
column9: “we do have the time
column10: and the best new age music shows us this.” It’s the kind of subtle
column11:
canny move new age acolytes aren’t exactly known for making: Accepting the occasional goofiness of what they do while reasserting its value at the same time.

To a small but cultishly devoted audience
column2: Brad Laner is famous for his work with the recently rejuvenated Los Angeles group Medicine
column3: which was responsible for some of the only lasting American contributions to the mostly British-dominated 90s shoegaze movement. Fewer listeners still know that since then he’s proven himself to be one of the only guitar heroes of the time who has fully embraced and adapted to the new technologies and techniques of the modern digital era. The album Medicine released earlier this year
column4: To the Happy Few
column5: was the first Laner recording I’d heard since 1995’s Her Highness
column6: and while it stayed true to the fundamental sheets-of-guitar-noise spirit of the band’s earlier stuff
column7: Laner’s production work (he’s produced all of the band’s albums) seemed heavily influenced by contemporary electronic music
column8: and helped make the album a happily surprising success.

column1: Laner’s well-regarded as a guitarist
column2: but while he’s technically virtuosic
column3: what he plays tends to pale in comparison to what he does to the signal leaving the instrument’s pickups. During Medicine’s first run that was running it through chains of overblown distortion and delay effects. Since then he’s expanded into digitally manipulating the sound
column4: chopping it up and glitching it out in ways that resonates with the twitchier edges of the dance music scene. Like Brian Eno
column5: who he’s worked with in the past—and whose influence would be easy to pick up on anyhow—Laner combines an appreciation of rock’s formal outlines with a compulsion to fill them with the most whacked-out futurist noises he can make.

column1: Considering the way that Medicine has always prioritized texture over melody
column2: you might expect Laner’s solo material to push even further out than his primary project. However
column3: Nearest Suns
column4: like his previous two solo outings
column5: draws its inspiration from the peak of rock’s baroque psych-pop days
column6: with Sgt. Pepper’s and Pet Sounds looming large over most of its songs. On “Nearly Hospital High
column7: ” he recreates the way that some of Paul McCartney’s Sgt. Pepper’s-era material sounds like a swinging
column8: big-band pop number just barely able to keep its head above a torrent of psychedelic flourishes. With its base of handclaps
column9: hand drums
column10: and acoustic guitar topped by multitracked vocal harmonies and backwards electric guitar licks
column11: the album opener “Be Gone” feels like a campfire singalong with a cheerful hippie acid cult
column12: but the computer-precise sequencing of the rhythmic elements and the squelching guitar distortion flickering between the speakers also adds an unexpected ravey element.

column1: Stylistically
column2: it’s well-trodden ground that Laner’s covering here. Sgt. Pepper’s and Pet Sounds have formed the bipartite god to several consecutive generations of psych-pop auteurs
column3: and even the slightly transgressive tactic of contrasting their fairly well-mannered melodies and harmonies with intensely ugly distortion has been done pretty much to death. But Laner’s a decent songwriter
column4: and even the compositions that don’t really work
column5: like the Tropicalia excursion “Summer Rudder""
column6: are worth hearing just for their production
column7: which in this case involves chipper analog synth sequences set against fractally fuzzed-out guitar leads.

column1: Nearest Suns gets more interesting when it takes its attention away from psych-pop’s Big Two and some of the self-consciously retro flourishes that they entail. The best song on the record is also its simplest
column2: composition-wise. “Equals Sky” has just one droning chord that shifts between acoustic guitar arpeggios
column3: Laner’s vocal harmonies
column4: and heavily modified electronic noises that at times resemble a tape delay on the fritz. Behind the spare melodic elements there’s a weird rhythmic part consisting of some kind of John Cage-like prepared drum fed into a sampler and chopped up into an unstable loop that constantly seems ready to collapse. Without Laner’s production there isn’t much to the song
column5: but the way he arranged and recorded it gives the track the feel of a musician and his gear in a tight symbiotic relationship
column6:
all falling apart together.

When you mock something
column2: it's because you love it
column3: helplessly and truly: No one understands this truth better than teenagers
column4: particularly teenage boys. Fernando Almeida and Benke Ferraz of Boogarins were in high school when they recorded their debut
column5: and they spend its duration lightly teasing every record in their collections
column6: reproducing it note-perfect faithfully while tweaking its nose. Every stumbling drum fill
column7: fuzz blurt
column8: vocal affectation
column9: and slightly detuned guitar chord on As Plantas Que Curam is the sound of two boys punching psych-pop in the arm
column10: tipping its chair back with their feet because they're mad they can't stop thinking about it.

column1: Their spirit remind you of another breakout 2013 band with a goofy name: The currently-beleaguered
column2: possibly-shipwrecked Foxygen
column3: whose still-great We Are The 21 Century Ambassadors of Peace and Magic did a similar pirouette between mockery
column4: pastiche
column5: and loving tribute. Like Foxygen
column6: the kids in Boogarins have spent several years in thrall to the sounds of 50-year-old records
column7: and they have also self-recorded their efforts
column8: paying close attention to how they might achieve the just-right abraded sounds.

column1: That they assembled an album that sounds this good while working in their parent's basements says a lot about their talent. They have good taste in other people's records
column2: but they also have the innate musical smarts to pull similar sounds out of their own: Boogarins is rich
column3: heavy
column4: and sonorous
column5: the guitar tones sensually warm and the vocals and drums sent through several treatments to blur them and lift them off the ground. On ""Eu Vou""
column6: the vocals swim through liquid silence
column7: tiny rippling mouth pops and a faraway synth the vocal track's only distant companions. It might be their tribute to Marble Index-era Nico; it channels a similar empty vastness.

column1: Almeida and Ferraz are Brazilian
column2: and it is impossible to listen to the album' opening track
column3: from its title of ""Lucifernandis"" to its gonzo
column4: slightly out-of-time opening riff and not think ""Os Mutantes."" That group's gently antic spirit
column5: and their secret sweet-tooth genius with pop melodies
column6: presides over Boogarins like a loony-uncle figure who won't ever quite leave the garage.  There are a million other little touches of songwriterly wit and grace on the album
column7: imported from other sources: the quote of the Kinks' ""Lazy Old Sun"" that strings together ""Hoje Aprendi de Verdade""
column8: the lift of what appears to be the guitar line for Wilco's ""I'll Fight"" on ""Doce."" Almeida and Ferraz know good melodies when they hear them.

column1: Even when they borrow material
column2: though
column3: they use the quotes like jumping-off points
column4: self-imposed challenges to craft their own memorable songs around them.  Their ear for melody is much stronger and more sophisticated than most bands their age—the sleepy guitar line winding through ""Erre"" has been restarting itself endlessly in my mind ever since I heard it. Even their one-minute-long
column5: doodled sound experiments
column6: like ""Canção Perdida""
column7: float by on a pretty melody. There is a sense that the classic-rock heritage they are wading around in is a big
column8: thrilling game to them
column9: each song a Sudoku puzzle for their songwriting. There is a goofy
column10: loose feel to As Plantas Que Curam
column11:
but it's a feint. Almeida and Ferraz aren't goofs; they're connoisseurs.

column1: Starring the kind of battered-but-resilient souls who stroll through the city in the dead of night
column2: the impressionistic song has Hynes switching between a low and high singing voice
column3: subtly accentuating the androgynous characters within. It's mysterious
column4: desperate

column6: he offers
column7: possibly taking the purview of a woman who feels like a man
