column9: inhabiting their travails with grace
column10: all while a disco pulse and smoky saxophones harken back to his beloved 80s
column11: when Times Square was a misfit's home away from home. The outcasts that live inside of ""Uncle Ace"" are Hynes' people. As the London-raised
column12: New York-based 27-year-old has hopped from project to project and style to style over the last 10 years
column13: he's maintained the air of an outsider. With Cupid Deluxe
column14: he channels those vagabond emotions into something universal and inviting—an album that tenderly details various heartaches through the language of longing.

column1: Growing up
column2: Hynes was bullied and beaten up enough to end up in the hospital on more than one occasion. He first directed his angst into Test Icicles' spazzed punk as a teen before moving onto Morrissey-style tragic confessionals with Lightspeed Champion. His first album as Blood Orange
column3: 2011's Coastal Grooves
column4: traded in Lightspeed's orchestral folk-pop for slick new wave and funk
column5: streamlining his once-unwieldy songwriting in the process. But it wasn't until he co-wrote and produced two songs from last year—Solange's ""Losing You"" and Sky Ferreira's ""Everything Is Embarrassing""—that he found the most suitable vessel for his melancholic odes to expired love. Both tracks are propelled by springing 80s beats that are tugged down by minor chords and wounded lyrics; the upbeat drums suggest good times past
column6: making the reality-check vocals hit that much harder. Given the blaring nature of modern pop
column7: the subtlety of these hollowed-out songs was genuinely refreshing; not just ""indie"" for the sake of it
column8: but affectingly human.

column1: Cupid Deluxe largely (and winningly) follows the formula set forth by those modest hits
column2: while bringing them forth on a full-length scale. Across the album
column3: Hynes sings
column4: writes
column5: produces
column6: and plays guitar
column7: bass
column8: keyboards
column9: drums
column10: synths. But this is hardly a solo act. In fact
column11: one of the record's greatest strengths lies in its pitch-perfect deployment of guests. Not only does each member of the Cupid Deluxe team seem to fully understand the overarching wistfulness of the whole
column12: but many of them show off heretofore unheard facets of their talent. While Hynes' girlfriend and Friends frontwoman Samantha Urbani and Kindness leader Adam Bainbridge exhibited tentative skills with their respective groups' debut albums last year

column2: Dirty Projectors' David Longstreth and Chairlift's Caroline Polachek have never sounded more soulful. Typically ominous rap producer Clams Casino contributes light
column3: skittering drums to the Longstreth showcase ""No Right Thing""
column4: which could fit snugly into any Vampire Weekend setlist. Even the set's two rap cameos
column5: from Queens' Despot and London's Skepta

column1: Especially Hynes

While everyone from Madonna to Lady Gaga has taken inspiration from these events—one of the few safe havens for participants to revel in their true selves without having to worry about the judging eyes of society—they often focus on their more outrageous or empowering aspects (see: ""Vogue""). But Dev Hynes' music is more suited to the film's beautiful and wrenching quiet moments

or anywhere in between: Heartbreak is real. It won't stop.

One of the great anecdotes of the Minneapolis rock scene is the story of how
column3: Bob Dunlap—a janitor at the famous club First Avenue
column4: the stomping ground of the Replacements during their early years—was asked to join the band following the departure of founding guitarist Bob Stinson. So as not to muddy things
column5: Paul Westerberg gave Dunlap a new nickname: Slim. Thus the legend of Slim Dunlap
column6: “the replacement Replacement
column7: ” was born. But that admittedly minor legend—plus the shadow of Stinson
column8: who died in 1995—has obscured a couple of significant facts: First
column9: the Replacements’ albums with Dunlap might not have that ol’ Bob fire
column10: but they’re largely excellent. Second
column11: Dunlap was an experienced
column12: even pioneering guitarist and songwriter on his own long before pushing a broom around First Avenue that fateful day in 87.

column1: Songs for Slim: Rockin’ Here Tonight is a new 2xCD tribute to Dunlap’s music—that is
column2: his work outside the Replacements. In an ideal world
column3: such a compilation would come about simply because Dunlap is Dunlap. Sadly
column4: though
column5: its impetus is less happy: In 2012 the notoriously sweet and humble guitarist suffered a debilitating stroke. The Replacements came out of retirement to raise funds for Dunlap’s medical bills with their Songs for Slim EP—which in turn led to a full Replacements reunion

There are two covers to Poliça’s Shulamith floating around. The first is a pixelated smudge

The late Jason Molina began his career by enduring constant comparisons to Will Oldham. The analogy became a lazy one
column2: but its basis is understandable. Molina’s debut single under his Songs: Ohia moniker
column3: 1996’s “Nor Cease Thou Never Now”

That association endured—up to and including a 2002 collaboration between Molina and Oldham (plus Appendix Out’s Alasdair Roberts) called Amalgamated Sons of Rest. But there are two other singing-songwriting contemporaries of Molina that make for equally apt comparisons: Ryan Adams and Elliott Smith. Adams’s Gold came out in 2001
column7: and its unabashed ode to heartland-fueled classic rock emboldened a generation of punk-and-indie shitkickers to embrace their FM-radio roots. Smith had turned increasingly away from indie rock and toward a more organic classic-pop sound in the late 90s and early 00s—that is
column8: until his suicide in 2003 cut that evolution short.

column1: That year also marked the release of Molina’s best and most pivotal album: The Magnolia Electric Co.
column2: which showcased his own strong shift toward rock populism. Imbued with a dust-under-the-fingernails weariness
column3: the album is so representative of Molina’s sound and spirit
column4: he subsequently took Magnolia Electric Co. as his new band’s name. Molina’s work on Magnolia wasn’t as cryptically oblique as Oldham
column5: as stadium-sized as Adams
column6: or as harmonically polished as Smith. It was
column7: perhaps for the first time in his recording tenure
column8: pure and full Molina. But the album installed itself into the American songwriter landscape circa '03 in a way that closed the circuit among his peers and secretly
column9: quietly willed a pocket of the zeitgeist into being.

column1: The 10th anniversary of The Magnolia Electric Co. is upon us
column2: hence the obligatory 10th-anniversary reissue. The album would have called for the deluxe retrospective treatment even if Molina hadn’t died earlier this year
column3: of organ failure related to his long struggle with alcohol. The respectful euphemisms have flown. The bottom line
column4: however

column6: nor is it a drinking record. While legions of alt-country troubadours have drained the tear-in-my-beer song of much of its traditionalist proof

column9: and savagely focused.

column2: but for the rest of Magnolia Electric Co. the band. What once was jittery and hesitant in his delivery is now howlingly powerful; gone is Songs: Ohia’s push-and-pull between intimacy and stridency. In its place is red-blood

column8: handing out the men’s room key and smiling crookedly to hide her missing teeth.

column3: Spencer Krug's life changed. In that two year span

column1: In his work with Wolf Parade and Sunset Rubdown

column4: producer Richard Swift helps Tennis grow. “Dimming Light” starts with a sour riff that evokes Mac DeMarco
column5: but ends strong with straightforward piano layered atop a tense synth line; hearing its arrangement
column6: it's easy to imagine Swift coming in and taking over. Even with his own music
column7: Swift tends to wear his vintage influences on his sleeve. If this guy can make the new Shins groove
column8: he shouldn’t have too much trouble infusing 1970s flavor to Tennis’ Brill Building aesthetic from a decade earlier.

column1: But Tennis aren’t Fitz and the Tantrums or anything quite so gaudy. Moore
column2: Riley
column3: and drummer James Barone work within their limitations to create an EP that offers subtle twists to their throwback thing. What sounds to be bassoon immediately funks up “Cured of Youth”
column4: while Moore actually gets an opportunity to belt on the standout track. Organ lines
column5: too
column6: are peppered throughout the EP
column7: but never overpower. “100 Lovers” sees Moore recalling an ex who was a real heartbreaker
column8: her astutely noting
column9: “100 loves will make you bold
column10: 100 more will make you cold.” It’s the stuff of 60s Girl Group gold
column11: but it goes to show you that while the music can progress
column12: the lyrics won’t necessarily follow.

column1: At their worst
column2: narrative-heavy buzz bands like Tennis are the indie rock equivalent of YouTube novelty songs. Lyrics about coconut groves are precious
column3: sure
column4: but it’s hard to feel like there’s a future in that. It’s not to say blissed-out guitar pop isn’t a viable path—look at where Beach House have masterfully taken their sound—but Moore will never have Victoria Legrand's vocal depth. She’ll always sound sweet and innocent
column5: better cooing atop a retro riff than leading listeners into dark corners. Moore sounds positively determined on the EP’s single and strongest song
column6: “Mean Streets”
column7: but when she chants the line
column8: “Born and raised on the mean streets/ That’s where she learned how to keep the beat
column9: ” it’s hard to imagine she’s speaking autobiographically. Only so much change can be achieved over two LPs and one EP.

column1: To liken Tennis to the liquid state of being would be insulting
column2: but they do seem to take on the shape of the container they’re in. Essentially
column3: each producer adds something new to the sound. Maybe by the next LP
column4:
they’ll have built something with real dimension.

With their strong second full-length Wait to Pleasure
column2: Montreal trio No Joy transcended the faithful shoegaze revivalism of their 2010 debut Ghost Blonde and follow-up EP Negaverse by yanking melodies out of their thick
column3: fuzzy guitar stew and operating with previously unforeseen refinement and clarity. Jasamine White-Gluz and Laura Lloyd pushed their vocals to the front of their compositions
column4: turning amorphous layers of sound into reasonably intelligible
column5: catchy hooks; on standouts like ""Hare Tarot Lies"" and ""Wrack Attack""
column6: their silvery
column7: melodic guitar lines scrubbed away sludge
column8: leaving behind straightforward dream-pop songs. The band's new EP
column9: Pastel and Pass Out
column10: is meant to coincide with an upcoming trek through Europe
column11: and over the course of its three songs No Joy extends the new accessibility of Wait to Pleasure into a surprising spryness with structure
column12: brevity
column13:
and dynamism.

The EP's playfulness begins with its title. Pastel and Pass Out is the perfect tagline for No Joy c. 2013: they're a band equally comfortable with soft-hued palettes and brutal knockout blows
column14: like Mike Tyson waking up early on a dewy April morning to paint with watercolors. Lead single ""Last Boss"" conveys this message with impressive efficiency
column15: as it moves from a simple marriage of melody and motorik chug into slugging
column16: squealing riffs into a final
column17: meditative section in just over three minutes. The band makes thoughtful use of volume and space to chop the song into these three discrete parts
column18: and in doing so they amplify the size of the difference between said parts; we hear guitars massing like dark clouds on the horizon towards the end of the song's first minute
column19:
and in the next second we're thrown into the eye of the storm.

The other two songs on Pastel and Pass Out take the two faces of ""Last Boss"" and blow them up into distinct tracks in their own right. ""Starchild is Dead"" subjugates a rather pretty guitar lead with incredibly dense
column20: crunchy waves of noise
column21: the kind that compel listeners to zip over to cleaner songs just to make sure their headphones aren't broken. The arrangement's weight
column22: and the appeal of the plumes of the melody that finally rise from the arrangement
column23: are reminiscent of the chewiest work done by No Joy's shoegaze ancestors; when a single note escapes and starts roaring and squealing above the din
column24:
there's almost something classical about it.

Meanwhile
column25: EP closer ""Second Spine"" benefits from thoughtful sequencing and the band's understanding of rhythm and momentum. Coming on the heels of two ferocious performances
column26: the band establishes tension with little more than slight upticks in rhythmic intensity
column27: channeled through drum and bass volume. When the chorus comes and goes without a crushing wall of guitar sound
column28: it becomes clear the listener has been subject to an artful feint
column29:
one that elevates a simply pretty song into an interesting one. 

Perhaps the most impressive aspect of Pastel and Pass Out is its economy: it takes No Joy less than twelve minutes to refine and expand on the musical ideas they first presented on Wait to Pleasure earlier this year. With two sets of full-length albums and accompanying EP extensions
column30:
the band has established a dependable pattern of step-wise growth; Pastel and Pass Out is a small but strong release that should tide fans over until No Joy's next major statement.

There are many ways of loving hip-hop
column2: but there's one in particular that most fans go through at some point that involves thinking really hard. Listen the right way
column3: and the music turns into this fantastic puzzle
column4: or maybe an equation that works out just so: Hook the beat up
column5: convert it into hip-hop form
column6: write a rhyme
column7: etc. There's a specific kind of hip-hop that tends to fit this mindset best
column8: in which the lyrics are geared in equal parts toward head and record scratching
column9: the beats put you in a zone
column10: and the only possible reaction is turn to your (perhaps equally stoned) friend and say ""that's dope.""

column1: That style is one that the Los Angeles-based label Stones Throw excels in
column2: and MC/producer Jonwayne is more or less the label's archetypal practitioner. Coming from an electronic background inspired by hanging out as a teenager in L.A.'s beat underground during the rise of artists like Flying Lotus and the Gaslamp Killer
column3: Jonwayne has spent the last couple years staking out a claim as an MC with his series of Cassette mixtapes. His vibe is that of the friendly slacker dude who seems to always be hanging around in high school parking lots or dorm common rooms
column4: eager to talk your ear off about some obscure psychedelia band or Wu-Tang deep cuts. With his proper debut
column5: Rap Album One
column6: he's upfront about what he's offering
column7: cutting a Silent Bob or Dude-like figure in press photos and using a picture of a saltine cracker (wink
column8: wink) as his album cover.

column1: Pretty much everything about Jonwayne's approach to rap can be summed up in his lines from ""You Can Love Me When I'm Dead""
column2: in which he explains
column3: ""this is rap shit
column4: recite banter with high standards/ cold-blooded art like a salamander on fine canvas."" His lyrics are clever and exactingly written
column5: full of dense internal rhymes
column6: and carefully thought-out punchlines. Although he offers some biography
column7: particularly on ""The Come Up Pt. 1 and Pt. 2""
column8: mostly he sticks to lyrical-bread-and-butter stuff that can't really be begrudged.

column1: But while Wayne may be a rapper who seems primarily interested in technique
column2: he's not a very technically interesting rapper. Almost all of his verses are delivered in a monotone
column3: and he rarely varies his flow to sound any way other than steady and studiously composed. He raps slowly and deliberately
column4: often taking a pause between bars
column5: in a way that makes lines land like stoner proclamations or Deep Thoughts. Lyrics like ""Shoes in the closet/ My stomach's got too many knots to justify tying laces and looking sharp"" seem profound but end up revealing themselves as aimless upon closer inspection. On the song ""Yung Grammar""
column6: the sort-of funny idea of screwing down a hook about grammar skills is immediately undermined by the revelation that there's basically nothing that sounds more boring screwed than a list of the parts of speech.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: though
column3: it's these types of experiments that yield the album's best results. Much of ""You Can Love Me When I'm Dead"" is simply a piano riff that leans heavily on the instrument's rarely used low end and a drum machine with the phrase ""every time I grab the mic I rock it just like that"" being scratched in different ways. It sounds cool
column4: and it's easy to zone out to
column5: a trip to the traditionalist rap fan's subconscious. On ""Zeroh's Song""
column6: by far the album's best and most interesting cut
column7: rapping is more or less abandoned as snatches of sung phrases flit in and out of the track. Wayne blurts out the screwed-down phrase ""they went back to moon!""
column8: and counts in a sinister voice over meandering synthesizer plinks. It's totally weird and fun
column9: connecting the dots between Animal Collective
column10: DJ Screw and Chance the Rapper
column11: the moment when the album feels the least deliberate and the most playful.

column1: The upside to Wayne's exacting approach throughout is that the production sounds fantastic
column2: a clear indication of where his roots lie as an artist. His sound is minimal
column3: in many cases relying on just piano and subdued drum pattern—live he uses just a sampler and a mic—which works to vivid effect. ""Sandals""
column4: for instance
column5: relies almost entirely on hi-hats
column6: a perfectly calm match for Wayne's low-key style. While the rapping on Rap Album One can feel bogged down in thought
column7: the production benefits from the almost mathematical approach (things get literally mathematical on the vinyl version
column8: which
column9: at 45 RPM
column10: is designed to sound screwed down when played at a normal 33 ⅓ RPM). The album may be hard to connect to on anything other than a cerebral level
column11:
but sometimes that's the best way to connect.

The Special Edition is no longer special. These days it’s easy to feel skeptical about words like “deluxe
column3: ” “expanded
column4: ” “rebooted
column5: ” or any other focus-grouped synonym—particularly when they’re attached to the name of a record you could have sworn came out a few months ago. Blame the ever-accelerating nostalgia cycle
column6: the desperate marketing tactics of a wheezing industry
column7: or the everyone-on-the-team-gets-a-trophy mentality of our youth; probably just blame all three. But whatever the reason
column8: we’ve gotten to a place where albums have Frankensteinian titles like Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded - The Re-Up
column9: and the extra
column10: wait-wait-there’s-more material on these revamps often feels obligatory
column11: forced
column12: and better off back in the vault.

column1: Leave it to Grizzly Bear
column2: though
column3: to be an exception to the rule. The Brooklyn-based craftsmen of sepia-toned chamber pop have a history of putting out non-album releases that are much better and more meticulously arranged than they need to be. Take
column4: for example
column5: their 2007 Friend EP: Judging from the tracklist
column6: it might have seemed like an “expanded” version of the previous year’s breakthrough Yellow House. Friend featured alternate takes of old songs
column7: a few covers (some by the band themselves and some by contemporaries like Band of Horses and CSS)
column8: and a self-recorded demo. But when you listened
column9: it was clear that this was much more than some half-assed stop-gap between proper albums. Friend now feels like an essential release in Grizzly Bear’s catalogue
column10: home to a live staple (their creepy
column11: cavernous reconstruction of the Crystals’ “He Hit Me”) and a pivotal moment in guitarist Daniel Rossen’s evolving and increasingly distinct style. The EP’s electric version of “Little Brother”—a six-minute
column12: six-string supernova of a song—remains one of his finest recorded moments with this band.

column1: Shields: Expanded feels like something of a throwback to Friend
column2: thanks in part to the refreshingly pragmatic way that Warp is releasing it. There is an “expanded edition” that contains the original album along with the bonus material
column3: but people who already have Shields can just buy the 12” Shields: B-Sides (and people who don’t care about vinyl can simply buy the extras digitally). Shields was recorded after Grizzly Bear took their first short hiatus; after the time apart (Rossen and bassist Chris Taylor put out solo records; founding vocalist Ed Droste did some traveling)
column4: they reconvened in Marfa
column5: Tex.
column6: for what would be an unexpectedly discouraging recording session. They worked on about 20 demos there
column7: but none made the record. Shields: Expanded collects the best of these previously unheard Marfa tracks
column8: which amount to captivating sketches
column9: rather than scraps.

column1: The swooping “Taken Down” is driven by Rossen’s babbling-brook finger-picking and an anguished vocal from Droste; “Everyone I Know” is an even sparser evocation of the same mood. Shields wasn’t exactly an upbeat record
column2: but what’s surprising is how dark—at times even violent—these Marfa tracks are. Is this the sound of a band thrashing out their frustrations with an inert recording session
column3: or their anxiety about trying top their past work? “Will Calls”
column4: the best of the demos
column5: definitely seems to be raging at something. Like a rougher-hewn version of Yellow House’s gorgeous finale “Colorado”
column6: it wrestles between soft
column7: somnolent moments and the closest thing Grizzly Bear can come to a genuine freak-out. The chorus—Droste’s unvarnished yelps and Rossen’s joltingly loud guitar—feels like a satisfying exorcism of bottled-up rage.

column1: The last three songs here are remixes and they’re decidedly hit-or-miss. I’m not sure the world needed to hear what a Lindstrøm remix of the effervescently proggy “Gun-Shy” would sound like
column2: and the results are about what you’d expect: The neon-plastic track sounds like an unused instrumental the Norwegian disco producer had lying around
column3: with Droste’s vocal track placed overtop about halfway through. Liars’ take on “A Simple Answer” fares a little better: Fragmented loops of “ahhs” and “oohs” build a misty
column4: fogged-window atmosphere that dissipates once—pretty unwarrentedly—a driving beat interrupts two-thirds of the way through. Luckily
column5: though
column6: there is one straight-up gem in the bunch. Nicolas Jaar doesn’t remix “Sleeping Ute” so much as toss it into to a zero-gravity chamber and watch each element drift around gracefully
column7: asking you to examine it anew. Grizzly Bear’s music is as much about the notes as the spaces between them—and the dust mites floating ethereally in those spaces between. Jaar gets this; and given how carefully his own music conjures space
column8: he’s an intuitive choice for this track. It’s enough to make you wish that he and Darkside collaborator Dave Harrington would give Shields the same full-album treatment they recently gave Daft Punk’s Random Access Memories.

column1: Shields: Expanded doesn’t stand on its own quite the way that the bar-setting Friend EP did. But as far as “deluxe editions” go
column2: it’s so refreshing you (almost) want to call it special: Consistent from start to finish (especially if you end on the Jaar remix)
column3: exactly as long as it needs to be
column4: and revealing without being unflattering. For fans
column5: it will come as something of a relief. If the infamous Marfa material that the band thought disappointing was actually this good
column6:
then Shields: Expanded is a comforting assurance of how hard it would be for a Grizzly Bear record to actually suck.

There’s the Phil Elverum you may know
column2: writing vaporous sometimes violent songs as Mount Eerie
column3: the hermetic man shrouded in a low fog that hangs somewhere in the Pacific Northwest
column4: releasing music filled with ghosts and shapes of dreams and nature
column5: fully lo-fi
column6: totally analog
column7: having once spent a winter in a secluded cabin in arctic Norway and having once droned the words “My blood flows harshly” under his erstwhile moniker the Microphones
column8: sending chills down the arms of those who heard it. Then there’s the Phil Elverum who does Lil Wayne at karaoke wearing flip-flops. The guy who tweets great jokes
column9: who draws bizarre comics like the ones you find in the back of zines
column10: who owns and operates a record label that put out a 7” of his last two Mount Eerie records Clear Moon and Ocean Roar playing simultaneously over each other—the Phil Elverum who’s shown with a couple of doughnuts on the Pre-Human Ideas cover art. Though his catalog may paint him as a Thoreau figure who draws mana from the trees and moss
column11: Elverum is a man wild with contradictions
column12: just like anyone.

column1: On last year's remarkable song “Through the Trees Pt. 2”
column2: Elverum sang a simple non sequitur: “Mountains and websites.” These words could serve as a subtitle to the collection of songs on Pre-Human Ideas. To be clear
column3: these aren’t new songs. (Well
column4: they're sort of new.) These are instructional demos Elverum made entirely on GarageBand
column5: also seen on the cover art
column6: specifically for the musicians on Mount Eerie’s 2012 tour. All of the vocal parts are sung by Elverum and filtered through an Auto-Tune setting
column7: including the female vocals once sang by Allyson Foster on several cuts off Clear Moon
column8: now put through a “female voice” pitch-shift preset. The bulk of the album comprises songs from Clear Moon
column9: but includes three other songs from his back catalogue
column10: and two analog organ drone pieces that bookend the album
column11: which were “previously buried in other songs.”

column1: Recontextualizing songs is familiar territory for Elverum
column2: whose immense catalog essentially functions as a big flow-chart
column3: with overlapping narratives of nature and mysticism
column4: remixes and rereleases
column5: part ones and part twos. Pre-Human Ideas inserts a previously unheard digital element into Elverum’s ecosystem
column6: with hopes that it will cohabitate with the analog. It’s good
column7: too
column8: that these songs are variations on the familiar
column9: and not entirely new compositions
column10: which would just be too jarring. Remember
column11: this is the first time Elverum has ever multi-tracked anything on a computer
column12: written drum parts and guitar parts that are just MIDI loops
column13: and the first time he recorded vocals on his laptop using the tiny microphone on iPhone earbuds while at a layover at the Frankfort airport in Germany. Talking about this album is not unlike talking about Mount Eerie guitar tabs.

column1: Elverum has also rewritten lyrics and added new sections songs
column2: most notably on “House Shape” and the Eleven Old Songs track “I Say ‘No’”. Though here
column3: especially
column4: it’s less about the content of songs and more the texture of them. These remakes can sound like Cocteau Twins coded an album in MS-DOS
column5: or perhaps more toward what Justin Vernon has been playing with in his adventures out of the cabin and into the Auto-Tune. The perversion of the natural has already been made by Kanye co-opting Bon Iver’s “Woods” into his own global pop oeuvre. But Elverum never wants to work on grand levels. These are insular songs that speak mainly to each other
column6: all breathing the same air of Elverum's home in Anacortes
column7: WA.

column1: The efficacy of these digital reinterpretations differ. There are some bits of goofiness on here
column2: particularly the chintzy horn sounds on the otherwise remarkable version of “Lone Bell”
column3: and even though there’s a whole new form and bridge to “House Shape” it still feels too precise and inhuman. It’s best to approach these songs with a cautious soft focus
column4: because close listening too often reveals that
column5: yes
column6: these are at heart didactic GarageBand demos and that cymbal sounds stupid. But if anything
column7: it’s more enlightening than your average remix album
column8: or a set of actual demos or alternate takes that would normally be fodder on Disc 2 of a reissue. I may not prefer the pared down
column9: pixelized version of “No Inside
column10: No Out” to the skittering analog version
column11: but I do prefer that ringing in Elverum’s ear to be “deep and wide” followed by a crash of digital doom guitars as opposed to its original lyrics “faint and high” followed by a tinnitus/dissonance drone on the end of “I Say ‘No’”. Your mileage may vary.

column1: Most importantly the songs remain fluid. There’s never a feeling that these are cheap 8-bit remixes
column2: but rather these are experiments in how close can the digital approximate the spirit of the analog. Elverum said in an interview earlier this year that he was frustrated with people’s perception of what actually is ""wild
column3: and frustrated that he came off as romantic and pastoral. :That is what I'm actually trying to make songs about
column4: he said
column5: ""the definition of nature that's the wild inherent sides that we have inside us. Our inherent wildness.” Pre-Human Ideas is a step toward breaking the barrier between disparate environments—mountains and websites—all by creating something using a simple computer program. Meditate on that during the organ prologue and epilogue here
column6:
and better know Phil Elverum.

Luke Temple already had two LPs to his name when he formed Here We Go Magic in 2009
column2: and that band's self-titled debut is
column3: by most measures
column4: a solo record; only on closer ""Everything's Big"" does Temple find himself backed by a full band. Over three subsequent LPs
column5: Here We Go Magic became a proper band
column6: subject to all the checks and balances that go along with group democracy. To hear Temple tell it

column8: his first solo LP since Here We Go Magic's launch—his 2011 effort Don't Act Like You Don't Care was recorded before the release of HWGM's debut—never would've made it as a Magic LP; had Temple tried to inject Fool's synth-heavy dalliances with reggae

column1: Fool's little more than drum machine
column2: bass

column4: and Temple's boyish
column5: Paul Simon-ized vocals. This relatively spartan setup finds Temple sounding looser and more relaxed than he has in quite some time. Here We Go Magic's precision plinking occasionally leads to a kind of fussiness; though frequently gorgeous
column6: their everything-in-its-right-place presentations occasionally outshine their underlying melodies. From the start

column16: strutting ""Florida"" is another winner

column18: fastidiously arranged back catalog

column21:
and they lead him to intriguing places.

There's an undercurrent of bitterness behind ""Those Kids"" keeping it from quite reaching the heights of the songs that precedes it. Describing a meeting with an MTV bigwig
column22: Temple expresses frustration that his music hasn't caught on with either the gatekeepers or the titular youths. ""Kids"" closes with a chorus of backup singers mewling ""they're all such idiots""; it's a little unclear whether he means the Viacom brass or the young people he's not reaching

column29: can be a somewhat inscrutable lyricist. But even his more innocuous wordplay's vastly preferable to the oddly-pitched tangents that pepper Good Mood Fool. And closer ""Hardest Working Self-Made Mexican"" is certainly the set's strangest digression. The industrious immigrant at the center of the song is broadly drawn
column31:
which leaves whatever point Temple hoped to make feeling muddled.

Marital post-script ""Sue"" is lovely

""I liked the idea of making a record called Caramel
column3: Connan Mockasin told NME. ""Then I made the whole record around what I thought a record called Caramel would sound like."" It might not be an especially deep concept
column4: but take a listen: His Caramel sound quickly introduces itself. The album's title track begins with a deep voice
column5: which is pitched down and smoothed out for a flirtatious monologue in the vein of Barry White. ""Oh
column6: and what is this?"" Then
column7: there's a coy giggle before Mockasin delivers a gentle
column8: melodic howl (""ah-oooooo"") over a soulful
column9: beatific
column10: far-away synth. ""Welcome
column11: this is Caramel album
column12: the voice says. In a stereotypical universe
column13: this is the moment where you're prompted to pick up the album's sleeve. Welcome. Take a moment to study Connan's platinum hair
column14: pencil-thin mustache
column15: and averted gaze. There he is
column16: dressed all in white
column17: swaddled in pillowy fabric. His stainless world is both unsettling and fitting; everything on ""Caramel"" shines. Each new instrument seems to come out thick and globby
column18: gradually dribbling out with an adult contemporary sheen.

column1: The 30-year-old New Zealand psych pop virtuoso recorded his sophomore album in a Tokyo hotel
column2: and this time around
column3: he's feeling sultry. He closes out the bridge of ""I'm the Man
column4: That Will Find You"" by cooing a mostly unadorned falsetto. After one careening moment of calm
column5: he moans and launches into the belted chorus with its slinky R&B groove. It's the perfect sort of pause to force anticipation in a love song—a calm before a storm
column6: a gaze before a conversation. Throughout Caramel
column7: he's ready to employ sonic examples of human emotion (like sobbing and moaning)
column8: and he doesn't make those details subtle. As he proved on Forever Dolphin Love
column9: he's not afraid to go theatrical. Like a cartoon madman
column10: he delivered a warbling
column11: wide-eyed plea on that record: ""Please turn me into the snat"". The title track of that album featured over 10 minutes of cluttered
column12: kinetic
column13: continuously shifting music. Connan's clearly got it in him to create a sizable
column14: at times unsteady odyssey.

column1: Caramel is an album that demands patience. With a concept in mind
column2: Mockasin seemed to be taking his time
column3: playing the long game
column4: establishing a gradually mutating mood. His broad view seems especially evident with his five-song ""It's Your Body"" suite—16 minutes with one abstract narrative wherein Connan forces the listener to slow down for a few lengthy slow jams. It takes over two full minutes of soporific minimalism to break into the primary melody of ""It's Your Body 1"". Then
column5: things come to a standstill with the respectively loud and quiet (and equally stagnant) instrumentals on ""3"" and ""4""
column6: which feel similar to the dragging mid-section of ""Why Are You Crying"". Thankfully
column7: there are moments where Connan springboards into some well-executed
column8: catchy grooves
column9: like on ""Do I Make You Feel Shy"" and ""I'm the Man
column10: That Will Find You"".

column1: At the end of the ""It's Your Body"" suite
column2: the melody resolves into that familiar beatific synth line from the title track. There's a petite voice repeating the words ""thank you Connan Mockasin"". The subsequent reply is loud
column3: bursting out in that same voice from the title track: ""Ahhhh. You're very welcome."" The echo from that last word is intentionally overemphasized
column4: ending with two very blunt repetitions: ""COME. [beat] COME."" Then
column5: album closer ""I Wanna Roll With You"" kicks in with some cartoonishly sexual moans. It's tempting in that moment to nudge Connan toward the novelty bin
column6: but he never quite makes it there. Instead
column7: he occupies a similar space as Ariel Pink—a guy with offbeat sonic inclinations
column8: a loudly absurd sense of humor
column9: and a knack for writing ultra-weird soul songs. From the hair to the warped yacht rock soundscapes
column10: comparisons to Ariel seem inevitable. Both men are weirdos and self-recorded savants whose careers will likely continue to take them to far-out
column11: primary colored spaces.

column1: When the moans clear away on ""Roll With You""
column2: Connan delivers some quiet
column3: mournful vocals (followed by
column4: yes
column5: a spoken word monologue where he says
column6: innocently
column7: ""Please
column8: roll with me""). The word ""caramel"" is most readily embodied by this music's sensual
column9: flirtatious leanings. Unfortunately
column10: sometimes it seems to just mean ""slow""
column11:
i.e. the pace of swimming through caramel.

Thanks to the name-checking done by indie acts like Stereolab
column2: Sonic Youth
column3: Tortoise
column4: and Radiohead in the 90s
column5: the German duo NEU! finally had their sonic blueprints resonate beyond the confines of their decade and their home country of Germany. The yin-yang dynamic that defined Neu!—drumming madman Klaus Dinger and the more meditative guitarist Michael Rother—couldn’t last forever
column6: and each man’s subsequent solo work continued in diametrically-opposed directions
column7: Dinger’s La Dusseldorf project manic and thunderous
column8: Rother’s solo albums placid and elegant.

column1: Back in 2009
column2: duo Gerhard Michel and Gordon Pohl released Hand in Hand
column3: their first album as Musiccargo. Much like fellow Germans Kreidler
column4: Michel and Pohl were indebted to their countrymen’s influence (their website calls Michel “a student of Klaus Dinger”). Their debut emphasized electro with a krautrock drive underneath it
column5: courtesy of Pohl’s sequencers and hardware. A smattering of remixes followed
column6: but in the intervening four years
column7: Musiccargo have stripped away all of that electro sheen.

column1: Judging by the cover and artwork for their second full-length Harmonie
column2: they now seek to bathe everything in pure white light. Released by England’s Emotional Response imprint (which was responsible for last year’s sterling Secret Circuit compilation)
column3: Michel and Pohl favor austerity here
column4: the warmth of acoustic instruments over components
column5: organic over the electronic
column6: or—if they must use such devices—analog versus digital
column7: the drum machines mostly replaced by a real kit. There’s a clarity and intensity to every track here like bright eastern light in a parlor. One song title translates as “The Sun Shines On Everybody
column8: ” and that may very well be the duo’s intent this time around.

column1: And yet where the assumption might be that Musiccargo would use the drums to conjure the now-departed spirit of Dinger
column2: Harmonie both succeeds yet underwhelms because it instead relies on the sensibilities of Rother. Or rather
column3: they emphasize the measured over the manic
column4: not quite striking a balance. The nine opening minutes of “Domino” begin with audible human breath and windswept sounds
column5: and slowly
column6: carefully
column7: cautiously begin to add more. Bird calls can be heard through the open space of the track and the wordless exhalations and clean
column8: skyward guitar lines of Michel recall Rother’s side of NEU! 3
column9: all proto-new age breathing and music as ocean waves
column10: rising and falling. It’s a well-crafted and gorgeous piece
column11: each gesture emphasized
column12: but the track proceeds at the turning of a screw.

column1: The sizzling cymbals of “La Era” also give the impression of breath
column2: but at least here the track is quicker to escalate and reach the simmering (courtesy of more clanging percussion and plucked guitar) over the course of its eight minutes. More percussion bubbles up on side-ending “Das Buch” suggesting that the duo may soon be back to their danceable ways come the album’s back half. But “Tip Top” continues at the same measure
column3: with more droning electronics low in the mix
column4: chimes
column5: and the most tactful use of a drum machine.

column1: The incessant floor toms and electronic drones of “Sol Lucet Omnibus” bring to mind another krautrock act: Faust with minimalist composer/violinist Tony Conrad for a one-off album back in 1973. Backwards guitars and voices swirl
column2: but the pacing never quickens. It mesmerizes
column3: but also gives the impression that Harmonie operates better as a holistic listen than one of discreet “songs
column4:
” and it’s more satisfying when processed in such a manner.

Contrary to popular belief
column2: Swans are not a noisy band. Noise is a dissonant irritant
column3: something that makes you wince momentarily and prompts you to plug your fingers in your ears as a defence mechanism. However
column4: a Swans concert presents a symphony of cacophony from which even deafness provides no relief. Because Swans deal not in noise
column5: but loudness—a gusty
column6: wall-crumbling
column7: tectonic-plate-shifting loudness that doesn’t so much give you a headache as an ulcer. As I discovered during a show last fall
column8: even when you’re taking a mid-show piss in a bathroom that’s two storeys and several walls removed from the venue stage
column9: Swans are still the most punishing band you’ve ever experienced.

column1: But for all the abuse and misanthropy they project in concert
column2: Swans consistently reward their fans’ tolerance with great acts of generosity. Compiled from the band’s 2012 world tours
column3: Not Here/Not Now is the fourth release and second double-live album that Michael Gira has issued since reviving the Swans name in 2010
column4: and like the previous concert document—2012’s We Rose From Your Bed With the Sun in Our Head—it’s a limited-edition
column5: hand-crafted package that will help fund the next Swans studio opus. (And given that we got The Seer out of the last deal
column6: it’s no surprise that Not Here/Not Now’s first run sold out almost immediately. Though you can still donate to the cause by ponying up $500 for something even better than a mere record: a new Gira song written in your honour.) But Swans live albums have come to represent more than just fancy souvenirs for charitable fans. They’re opportunities for Swans enthusiasts to observe the band’s ever-evolving aesthetic in action: Of the songs featured on Not Here/Not Now
column7: only three have appeared on previous recordings. And any worries that Swans are showing too much of their hand are defused by the fact that new Swans songs rarely make it from the stage to record in the same form
column8: and
column9: once officially released
column10: mutate even further in subsequent performances.

column1: So if you’re wondering if you need another version of “The Seer”
column2: the answer is: hell yes. After debuting as a brawny
column3: pulsating rocker on We Rose and then transforming into the exotic
column4: cinematically rendered 32-minute centerpiece of its 2012 namesake album
column5: “The Seer” reappears on Not Here/Not Now as an oozing piece of toxic sludge that just gets thicker and nastier over its marathon 44-minute runtime
column6: with two new songs bubbling up from its miasma: the scorched-earth psychedelia of “Bring the Sun” and “Toussaint L’ouverture”
column7: a maniacal Francophone rant couched in an opium-den ambiance reminiscent of the comedown on Sonic Youth’s “Expressway to Yr. Skull”. But even those developments feel natural compared to what’s happened to “Oxygen”
column8: a song that first surfaced as an acoustic meditation on Gira’s 2010 solo album I Am Not Insane
column9: but has been unrecognizably reworked into a gut-punching
column10: Jesus Lizardian rumble. (The original describes Gira’s experience with asthma; the new version feels like it.)

column1: You can get a pretty good idea of where Swans are heading on their upcoming album from the lone 80s-era track that figures here: the Holy Money-era sludgefeast “Coward” is the perfect complement to the bone-crushing heft of new 10-minute dirge “Just a Little Boy”
column2: which sounds even more like how you’d imagine a Melvins cover of David Bowie’s “Station to Station” would sound than the Melvins’ actual cover of “Station to Station”. And that’s just the third-longest new song unveiled here: the stormy 16-minute opener “To Be Kind” sees Gira gravely repeating the title with the solemn cadence of a cantor
column3: as if the sentiment expressed within was an impossible ideal; “She Loves Us!” deviously appropriates the title of a bygone Beatles hit in service of a 15-minute maelstrom that builds up a drum-battered drone into a mutant stoner-metal groove.

column1: By comparison
column2: the sand-swept drift of “Nathalie Neal” can’t help but feel like the least momentous of the new-album previews on offer here
column3: but it serves as a logical bridge out of these caustic concert recordings into Not Here/Not Now’s pair of lo-fi acoustic-demo denouements. More than just expose the psych-folk underpinning of Swans’ seismic sound
column4: the rough sketches for “Kirsten Supine” and “Screen Shot” offer a disarmingly intimate glimpse into Gira’s songwriting process
column5: complete with his play-by-play
column6: strum-by-strum commentary. After nearly two hours of being subjected to Swans’ highly orchestrated onstage onslaught
column7: these human
column8: off-the-cuff moments come as a great relief; in sharp contrast to the authoritative
column9: stentorian presence Gira casts in concert
column10: the demos present him in charmingly self-deprecating mode
column11: questioning himself about what direction he should steer the song into
column12: or even if it’s any good to begin with. Just as the double-tracked vocal incantations and needling acoustic jabs of “Screen Shot” approach peak hypnotic intensity
column13: Gira stops the song cold and admits
column14: “I have no idea where it’s going to go from there… but we’re going into the studio in a couple of weeks and we’ll figure it out.” Given Swans’ recent track record
column15:
those words feel less like glib reassurance than a distant early warning of what’s to come.

"|18712.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18712-swans-not-herenot-now/|8.2|Stuart Berman

In order to realize his brutal musical vision with Yeezus
column2: Kanye West enlisted a congregation’s worth of collaborators with a highly diversified range of skills: honeyed indie crooners
column3: European EDM wunderkinds
column4: luminary rock producers
column5: M.I.A.’s former fiancé. Another helping hand was lent by Mike Levy
column6: the French producer who records and performs as Gesaffelstein. He worked on the bruising
column7: stadium-ready “Black Skinhead” and the raucous
column8: emergency-lit “Send It Up” alongside label mate Brodinski and sonic grandfathers Daft Punk
column9: among others.

column1: A quick glimpse at Gesaffelstein’s professional mythology is all it takes to understand the heart of his appeal to West: a shared interest in art and fashion
column2: a personal aesthetic possessed of palpable intensity and ripe with darkness and violence
column3: and an eye towards intellectual concerns broader than music. (It’s captured neatly in his chosen moniker: Gesaffelstein is a portmanteau that combines the German word “gesamtkunstwerk
column4: ” meaning “universal artwork
column5: ” and Albert Einstein
column6: an inspirational figure.) His debut album Aleph fuses those pre-existing aspirations to ideas about style that feel directly derived from his work with West
column7: with its cover—a jewel case containing a gold disc
column8: the case overlaid with complex patterns reminiscent of circuitry—serving as the most obvious hat tip.

column1: It’s a testament to Levy’s talent
column2: and to the strength of his sonic identity
column3: that Aleph merits comparison to Yeezus in terms of its thematic consistency and coherence. From the ferocious spoken introduction that marks opener “Out of Line” (one of several appearances by Parisian vocalist Chloé Raunet) to the slowly rising sirens echoing throughout “Perfection”
column4: this is an absolutely relentless record: there’s no sunlight to be had on Aleph. Levy specializes in two types of songs: fiery
column5: raging bangers meant for the dank club at the end of the world
column6: and meditative mood pieces that bubble and loom while you’re fighting through the next morning’s hangover. Thoughtful sequencing choices help to amplify the magnitude of the difference between the members of these phylums
column7: and have the added benefit of lending Aleph a natural-seeming cycle of attack and release. When doom-soaked
column8: muscular lead single “Pursuit” glides into the ominous
column9: slowly shifting “Nameless”
column10: it’s as if we’ve been given a well-earned breather after enduring the intense assault of the former.

column1: It’s a trick Levy pulls multiple times without diluting its effect
column2: made possible by the tonal differences between the album’s higher-octane tracks: “Send It Up” relative “Hellifornia” pairs a trunk-ratting hip-hop rhythm with a howling
column3: DEFCON 1-level screech
column4: while “Duel” earns its combative title by pitting a furious
column5: hyper-kinetic beat against a friction-fried synth that refuses to let up. While the album’s dark
column6: dance-ready techno cuts certainly demand their fair share of attention
column7: Levy takes advantage of the album’s quieter moments and displays surprising levels of subtlety and restraint. With its eerie guitar melodies and digital choruses of the damned
column8: the title track could slot neatly into a collection of outtakes from the Drive soundtrack; mid-album counterpart “Wall of Memories” fares even better
column9: bulging and warping underneath a haunted piano line. By making room for both potential floor-filling wrecking balls and quieter
column10: spookier moments on Aleph
column11: Levy sets himself up as the sort of transcendental figure who can fill up festival EDM tents full of drop enthusiasts while simultaneously appealing to listeners who consider themselves more nuanced consumers of contemporary electronic material.

column1: If Aleph has a weakness
column2: it's the album's lack of concision. At around an hour
column3: this is a lengthy
column4: demanding record
column5: and the relentless push that constitutes a major part of its excitement in small blocks renders it somewhat exhausting when ingested as a whole. While some of the strongest songs—the stomach-churning “Hate or Glory”
column6: the piston-powered techno workout “Trans”—are tucked near its conclusion
column7: it takes an effort to make it to the finish line. The importance of brevity is a lesson Levy didn't pickup after working on Yeezus
column8:
a similarly dark record that clocks in at a brisk 40 minutes. A distillation of the sounds and themes contained within Aleph into an equally slim package would render his next record truly fearsome.

"|18747.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18747-gesaffelstein-aleph/|7.8|Jamieson Cox

Bryce Dessner's day job as a guitarist in the National requires him to work in big
column2: sweeping rock-song arcs
column3: but he's also a classical composer
column4: and in his side work—working on commssions for the American Composers Orchestra
column5: collaborating on David Lang records—you can hear a furiously complicated musical mind chattering. Dessner's sensibility as a composer is furtive
column6: urgent
column7: intense—nothing at all
column8: in other words
column9: like his rock band. The National's sound has always been mellow and rich
column10: a rock band as a foaming
column11:
blooming cup of pour-over coffee. Dessner's sensibility churns like stomach acid. 

Aheym
column12: Dessner's collaboration with contemporary- classical hip-uncle figures the Kronos Quartet
column13: is the result of a working relationship that dates back a few years. Three of its four pieces were written specifically for Kronos
column14: and the title track has been a fixture of their concerts for a few years now. ""Aheym"" begins with all four members digging into their strings and producing hard
column15: sinewy sforzandos
column16: or sudden
column17: violent accents
column18: before subsiding quickly into an agitated
column19: seething hum. The cello plays lopsided arpeggios
column20: each one nervously edging forward
column21: while pizzicato prickles tension higher. It is fierce
column22:
vivid music.

The rock-friendly post-minimalism of Bang on a Can looms heavy over Dessner's work
column23: but that's less a statement on Dessner's originality than BOAC's sheer ubiquity. BOAC's long-running All-Stars summer program is the feeder college largely responsible for populating the indie sphere with conservatory rockers like Dessner in the first place. But they aren't the only audible reference point:  ""Little Blue Something"" traces lightly bowed figures in the cello against warm surges from the rest of the ensemble
column24: and the effect is like a more earthbound Arvo Pärt. Pärt's touch pops up multiple places
column25: like in the spidery refractions of harmonics that cloud the air in the thirteenth minute of ""Tenebre""
column26:
or the way sobbing vibrato bowing condenses from a dry mist of harmonics on ""Aheym.""

It's only with the final piece
column28: that the tension in Dessner's work recedes. The piece is a setting of a poem by Chilean poet Vicente Huidobro
column29: sung by the Brooklyn Youth Chorus. Opening with just the chorus
column30: the piece nudges into dewily picked guitars and some piano
column31: offering the only glimpse of a sound world related
column33: to Dessner's band. The textures glow softly
column35: and the ensemble dances inventively between minimalism and something like recognizable song form. There is no obvioustime-stamp on the work
column36: which keeps surging in new directions
column37: making interesting new things happen. Dessner is part of a chummy coterie of musicians
column38: like Annie Clark of St. Vincent and Dave Longstreth of Dirty Projectors
column39: and sometimes the air inside the clubhouse can get a little thick. But Dessner's mordant vision is uniquely his; these are real

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19924/homepage_large.e73b04b0.jpg|Who Is William Onyeabor?|31843.0|William Onyeabor|['Global']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Luaka Bop']|2013-11-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:50:57.360936|"

In 2005
column2: David Byrne’s globe-trotting label Luaka Bop—after investigating the sounds of Brazil
column3: Cuba
column4: and the like—released World Psychedelic Classics 3: Love's A Real Thing - The Funky Fuzzy Sounds Of West Africa. Along with the likes of the breathtaking Éthiopiques series and Strut’s relentlessly funky Nigeria 70 set from 2001
column5: the compilation helped spur a revival in African music from the continent’s “Golden Age
column6: ” that time in the 1960s and 70s when European imperialism was for the most part eradicated
column7: artists and culture flourished
column8: and before many of these nations’ leaders turned despotic. That renaissance has continued on into the present moment
column9: from the work of imprints like Analog Africa
column10: Soundway
column11: and Awesome Tapes from Africa (to name just a few of many active reissue labels)
column12: even as Africa’s embarrassment of riches has turned into a glut of sorts
column13: a decidedly First World problem to have.

column1: In those intervening years
column2: Luaka Bop tried with little success to track down William Onyeabor
column3: whose “Better Change Your Mind” appeared on both their comp and the Nigeria 70 set. Little info could be found about the man
column4: though the reports varied wildly: he studied cinematography in Russia
column5: he self-financed his own movie
column6: he was a titan of industry in his native Nigeria with a flour mill
column7: he had business interests in Sweden. About the only thing for certain was that Onyeabor self-released eight albums from 1977-1985 at an annual report clip
column8: before disavowing music for Christianity. Since then
column9: Onyeabor’s music has been bootlegged while original copies can go for upwards of $500 online.

column1: Previous decades have led to re-appraisals of the likes of King Sunny Ade
column2: Ali Farka Touré
column3: Youssou N’Dour
column4: Salif Keita
column5: and Fela Kuti
column6: and Luaka Bop’s handy new set Who is William Onyeabor? (the first legitimate reissue of his music) posits the man for a 21st century audience
column7: where his sonic sensibilities seem best suited. While those aforementioned African icons gained renown on the world music circuit for their guitar work
column8: their distinct voices
column9: their rhythmic innovations
column10: Onyeabor favored an instrument rarely heard from the African Diaspora
column11: the analog synthesizer.

column1: An array of keyboards can be seen on the cover of Onyeabor’s final album Anything You Sow and across the man's discography
column2: they evolve from serving as accompaniment to becoming the primary instrument. “Something You Will Never Forget” features a crisp backbeat
column3: Afrobeat horn skronk
column4: and Onyeabor’s organ in roller rink mode
column5: the most conventional song on the set. But on opener “Body and Soul” (a longtime dancefloor staple) Onyeabor tickles the keys then warps them until they sound like an inter-dimensional portal in the midst of the song’s slinking groove. It happens again five minutes into his biggest “hit
column6: ” “Atomic Bomb” a heavily wah-wah’d keyboard doing its best Bernie Worrell when-the-Mothership-lands impression.

column1: All but one of the comp’s nine tracks comes in under six minutes (with three topping the 10-minute mark)
column2: and most of the songs are structured similarly
column3: at times making the set feel same-y. A steady
column4: boxy drum rhythm (some utilizing drum machine)
column5: smatterings of guitar
column6: a bevy of female back-up singers doing call and responses with Onyeabor’s naïf yet endearing English lyrics
column7: but central to each track is Onyeabor’s synth work. The closest comparison to this set might be that of Indian guitarist-turned synth enthusiast Charanjit Singh’s 1982 album Synthesizing: Ten Ragas to a Disco Beat
column8: which no doubt sounded like a rinky-dink curio during its time
column9: but in hindsight was revealed to have anticipated acid and techno by a number of years so that by the time of its reissue it sounded downright revelatory to 21st century listeners. Similarly
column10: Onyeabor’s strange use of the synthesizer as embellishment presages that of any number of outsider electronic music producers by three decades. It’s little wonder that the likes of Four Tet
column11: James Holden
column12: Caribou and more have already been buzzing with their accolades for the man and the weird funk of “Fantastic Man” could easily be mistaken for a modern Dam-Funk track.

column1: Whereas Sunny Ade’s singular guitar tone could be as mighty and rippling as a river and Fela Kuti and Tony Allen’s Afrobeat was a force of nature
column2: Onyeabor’s music often times sounds warbling and flimsy
column3: economical and tinny. Some of this might come from the set drawing on vinyl sources rather than master tapes
column4: but knowing of the man’s imminent Christian conversion
column5: it’s not a stretch to see parallels between Onyeabor’s organ tone and those of private-pressed religious records. Onyeabor’s sound is as homemade and insular as anything on last year’s Personal Space compilation
column6: as strange and extraterrestrial as that of Sun Ra. Who is William Onyeabor? doesn't provide any answers its own posited question
column7:
but the mystery and wonder of the man’s music remains intact.

"|18732.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18732-william-onyeabor-who-is-william-onyeabor/|8.6|Andy Beta

It's been 14 years since the last Luscious Jackson album
column2: and the world mostly hadn't been clamoring for a reunion. They had some terrific moments in the 90s—seek out 1993's deliciously murky In Search of Manny EP—but rarely shook off their reputation as a satellite of the Beastie Boys. (Grand Royal released all of their original records
column3: and drummer Kate Schellenbach had been the Beasties' original drummer.) When the group lost keyboardist Vivian Trimble in 1998
column4: then punched out after releasing the unspectacular Electric Honey
column5: they seemed to have stuck around exactly long enough.

column1: Bassist Jill Cunniff and guitarist Gabby Glaser both released solo albums in 2007; sometime around then
column2: they got together to work up some children's music
column3: but couldn't find a convenient way to release it. Last year
column4: they ran a crowdfunding campaign to make a new Luscious Jackson album—this one. (The children's album
column5: Baby DJ
column6: will apparently be out soon.)

column1: The 2013 edition of Luscious Jackson sounds less like a band than like friends who used to be in a band together. Glaser and Cunniff recorded their parts of Magic Hour in New York
column2: and Schellenbach's drums were added in Los Angeles. (Trimble's sitting this one out again.) Their best songs of the '90s
column3: from ""Daughters of the Kaos"" to ""Naked Eye""
column4: often seemed like constellations of new and borrowed hooks that miraculously fit together into songs. This album
column5: though
column6: is pretty obviously a creation of Pro Tools (which Cunniff learned in order to record it). One track after another cycles through mix-and-match riffs and catchphrases for a few minutes
column7: then evaporates when its three minutes are up. At least their new material doesn't suffer from reunion bloat: all but two of the album's ten tracks clock in under 3:15.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: a lot of Cunniff and Glaser's lyrics these days are about the durability of their partnership. ""We're better together
column3: you and me
column4: goes Magic Hour's first song; another one features the lyric ""we go back but we can't go back/ but we can go on."" There are a handful of likeable
column5: more or less interchangeable let's-party tunes
column6: most of which involve some nifty guitar playing from Glaser. (""So Rock On"" is the one that the Beasties' Adam Horovitz contributed to
column7: and involves the ""woo-hah"" cadence that Busta Rhymes lifted from the Sugarhill Gang; ""Show Us What You Got"" is the one with an old-school syndrum breakdown; ""Are You Ready"" is the one that mentions Dancing with the Stars.) There's also a novelty song
column8: the ass-watching anthem ""#1 Bum""
column9: which wears out its welcome in a hurry.

column1: Magic Hour isn't saddening or frustrating in the way that cash-in reunions can be (and the band's clearly not doing it to cash in). It's just a return to very familiar territory without the urgency and mystery of Luscious Jackson's 90s-era music--the Lollapalooza Nation equivalent of
column2: say
column3: a new Winger or Y&T album. For the most part
column4:
it even sounds like it was fun to make; if only it were as much fun to hear.

"|18692.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18692-luscious-jackson-magic-hour/|5.6|Douglas Wolk

Early in his career it seemed like we had Action Bronson pinned down: he was a talented writer with a vivid imagination and an unshakable food obsession who sounded a little too much like Ghostface for his own good. But he has since found his own voice
column3: most notably on the revelatory first edition of Blue Chips. Where Ghostface was a deliriously inscrutable writer playing the role of a wily narrator unspooling street narratives
column4: Bronson is a larger-than-life character in his own songs. He eats tacos in foreign countries and fixes college football and NBA games alike
column5: and in unmooring himself from the grim realities that ground the classic 90s New York rap his own music sprouts from
column6: Bronson’s art began to flourish.

column1: But there is still a balance the Queens MC must navigate
column2: which became obvious on June’s Saaab Stories
column3: a seven-song collaborative EP with the producer Harry Fraud. The Bronson character revels in worldly luxury but also in the slimy underbelly of gangster fabula
column4: one in which women are uniformly paid for their services and rendered as objects. This was driven home by the album’s bizarre cover
column5: in which two models were posed as props in compromising positions. But the problem runs deeper: there is a distinct distastefulness to Bronson’s music
column6: and it is accentuated nearly to the point of disgust when the production become steely and dark
column7: as it is across most of Saaab Stories and 2012’s Rare Chandeliers
column8: a project helmed by The Alchemist. These beats bend his stories back toward the reality of a group like Mobb Deep
column9: a dynamic that does not cast a flattering light on the imagined vulgarities that punctuate Bronson’s writing.

column1: The initial Blue Chips—with the producer Party Supplies sourcing samples from YouTube and stitching them together with the seams showing—was tonally perfect. At its best
column2: the world Bronson creates is colorful and comical
column3: and in Party Supplies he has found a partner eager to bring that characteristic to its literal endpoint with a crackling production aesthetic that casts the rapper as the star of a rogue Saturday morning cartoon. With the just-released Blue Chips 2 they don’t tinker with the formula
column4: and the result is a sequel nearly as good as its predecessor.

column1: Party Supplies’ light
column2: humorous touch also seems to enliven Bronson’s writing
column3: extracting out of him scenes that are as cinematic as they are ridiculous. When he raps
column4: “Swimming trunk
column5: 30k in arm’s reach/ I’m on the boat in the water like a swan’s feet” on “The Don’s Cheek” I can picture the ripples in the water slowly emanating. I want a line like
column6: “Speaking Arabic in Greece/ Grown men turn the keys to cheese as I water ski Belize” extracted and fleshed out to an entire HBO series. When Bronson is peaking as he often is on Blue Chips 2 there’s stuff like this all over the place: “Play your poker on the riverboat/ Hit the ace
column7: long rifle in my bitch’s coat/ Flip off the balcony
column8: knife to the throat/ Ice in the Coke/ Coke on the table
column9: wildin’ out in Roanoke.”

column1: Where punchline rappers can falter is in prioritizing the joke instead of something larger
column2: turning rap into a bastardized version of stand-up comedy. Bronson is not immune to this himself
column3: but on Blue Chips 2 his one-twos (“Shoot eagles on the Jack Nicklaus course/ Porsche with the triple exhaust”) become little dioramas
column4: and eventually over the course of an hour he constructs a mutated version of the world we recognize—this is the escapism not of Rick Ross
column5: but of Pixar. The punchlines can stagger individually
column6: but when the album ends it can take a minute for the mind to readjust itself to reality.

column1: The first collaboration between Party Supplies and Action Bronson was “Contemporary Man""
column2: a four-minute one-off in which the two recreate rap’s culture of radio freestyles but with instrumentals of 80s classics like “Sussudio” and “Sledgehammer"". The track is wedged into the middle of Blue Chips 2
column3: and it comes off as the guiding spirit of a project that also features Bronson rapping over the Champs’ “Tequila” and Tracy Chapman’s “Give Me One Reason"". As a jukebox cypher
column4: “Contemporary Man” was the first hint that Bronson might be a bit more than just another witty New York rapper.

column1: But more than anything
column2: the song—and concurrently the album that now houses it—is just a whole lot of fun. Bronson
column3: for whatever reason
column4: only seems to hit this note with Party Supplies in his back pocket. But when he does
column5: his music is not only a blast
column6:
but undeniably distinctive.

Sébastien Tellier is still best known in the States as the louche
column3: besunglassed Frenchman whose 2008 album Sexuality layered the electro-disco sound that was big in Paris at the time with thick dollops of a particularly retro kind of theatrical sleaziness distilled from early-VHS-era pornography. But while he certainly excels at the role of the Eurotrash slimeball
column4: he actually has a far broader range than that. A devotee of Serge Gainsbourg
column5: Tellier has inherited the master’s ambitious genre-hopping habit (as well as his arch-Gallic oleaginity)
column6: and aside from house-y synthpop he’s recorded Gainsbourg-style baroque pop
column7: slightly skewed takes on contemporary radio pop
column8: an album of piano ballads
column9: and a film score.

column1: For his new Confection
column2: Tellier returns to his role as a composer for film in spirit
column3: if not in actual fact
column4: and combines it with Sexuality’s pursuit of bygone erotic aesthetics. Long story short
column5: it sounds like the soundtrack to a 70s French porn movie that
column6: as far as I can tell
column7: doesn’t actually exist.

column1: If it did exist
column2: it would probably look a lot like Emmanuelle
column3: the X-rated blueprint that a decade of soft-focus European (or at least “European”) erotica was based on
column4: as well as the highest-grossing French film of 1974. Confection is reminiscient of Emmanuelle’s soundtrack
column5: composed by Pierre Bachelet
column6: which at its most compelling parts combines French pop crooning
column7: 70s soft rock
column8: and syrupy strings in a way that’s nearly as good as any of the movie’s visuals when it comes to evoking a certain luxurious
column9: but seedy
column10: erotic sensibility.

column1: “Adieu” opens the album with cloying strings
column2: a swooningly romantic piano
column3: and wordless vocals by a female opera singer
column4: all moving at a decadently slow pace that heavily suggests Vaseline lenses
column5: gratuitous slow-motion
column6: and proudly unmanaged body hair. The music is schmaltzy
column7: tacky stuff
column8: and Tellier piles it on deliriously
column9: reaching for the point where it tips over from simple camp into the realm of the sublimely sleazy
column10: and frequently surpassing it. At a time where musicians from the nether reaches of the electronic music underground all the way to the top of the Hot 100 are pushing an agenda of radical minimalism
column11: Confection is a fantastically decadent album. Most of the songs are festooned with gooey strings
column12: and the ones that aren’t
column13: like the brief solo piano piece “Curiosa"" still ooze melodrama.

column1: However decadent as the songs sound
column2: they still pale in comparison to the depravity of the album itself
column3: whose purpose is hard to pin down. While it’s certain to thrill the avid fans who over the years have formed a small cult around vintage porno soundtracks
column4: the average listener’s likely to simply be baffled. It’s not a dance record by any stretch
column5: and there’s really only one track
column6: “L'amour naissant""
column7: meets the accepted standard for an actual pop song
column8: with a drumbeat and vocals and everything.

column1: And if Tellier intended it to function as mood music for some kind of retro-Euro-porn sexual encounter
column2: he probably shouldn’t have tossed in a waltz arranged for solo analog synthesizer halfway through—its creepy
column3: circus-like vibe and squelching electronic tones are almost guaranteed to spoil the mood.

column1: Confection’s overall theme is indulgence
column2: and there’s nothing more indulgent than an artist using a whole album to explore a personal obsession that only a fraction of his fans will be capable of enjoying. It feels like a very French-pop-star gesture
column3: extravagant and essentially useless
column4:
and perversely enjoyable for exactly those reasons.

"|18714.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18714-sebastian-tellier-confection/|6.3|Miles Raymer
