The saxophonist Matana Roberts had to start big. She had a story to tell
column2: after all
column3: and it was an important one
column4: a saga that she said would take a dozen albums
column5: lined together in her Coin Coin series. More or less
column6: the odyssey is that of her extended family’s ascent in North America
column7: from Transatlantic servitude through the Jim Crow South and onto her present role as one of the most exciting new spirits in contemporary music. And so Coin Coin’s first episode
column8: the 2011 album Gens De Couleur Libres
column9: featured 15 other musicians
column10: collected from Montreal bands such as Land of Kush and A Silver Mt. Zion and assembled in the Hotel2Tango
column11: where Roberts recorded live in front of an audience. The audacious set pitted shrieking
column12: incensed post-bop against moody
column13: mournful atmospherics
column14: plaintive balladry against electrified indignation. This aggressive hodgepodge of styles—“panoramic sound quilting
column15: ” Roberts calls it—suited her cause: to revisit her ancestor’s days as slaves in the South
column16: being sold on the auction block and forced to find a new faith
column17: and then to press on. The material was stormy and angry
column18: beautiful and forlorn
column19: a wide beginning for an admittedly lengthy trip.

column1: Mississippi Moonchile
column2: the second installment of Roberts’ Coin Coin series
column3: is consistently smaller. This time
column4: for instance
column5: the ensemble backing Roberts is only a quintet
column6: culled from the improvisational ranks of New York and Boston. It’s a relatively traditional group
column7: too
column8: with her alto saxophone often dovetailing or countering the trumpet of Jason Palmer. Bassist Thomson Kneeland and drummer Tomas Fujiwara make for an adaptable rhythm section
column9: capable of effortless undulation and knotty zigs. Pianist Shoko Nagai possesses similar versatility
column10: her careful
column11: cloudy chords sometimes giving over to spastic
column12: assailant lines. (There’s an opera singer
column13: Jeremiah Abiah
column14: here
column15: too
column16: but more on that in a bit.)

column1: And if Gens De Couleur Libres was an envelope of eternity
column2: with no clear beginning except for time itself
column3: Mississippi Moonchile focuses on the life of Roberts’ grandmother
column4: a poor Southern girl who grew up in an era of keen turbulence that spanned the Great Depression
column5: World War II
column6: and America’s crawl toward civil rights. Roberts interviewed her grandmother about growing up in that time and place. She speak-sings excerpts of the testimony off-and-on throughout these pieces
column7: integrating the memories with Bible verses
column8: recognizable colloquialisms
column9: and civil rights dialogue. The net effect suggests <a href=""http://www.theguardian.com/books/2003/nov/15/fiction.jamesbaldwin"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">James Baldwin’s first novel
column10: Go Tell It on the Mountain
column11: in which the young
column12: black author used a mix of history and fiction to trace the relatives he knew back to the Southern slaves he did not. Baldwin had the written word for his mission; Roberts
column13: a fitting emissary
column14: has a century of jazz.

column1: Neither the size and standardization of this ensemble nor the focus of Roberts’ timeline make Mississippi Moonchile less audacious than its predecessor. Instead
column2: this set runs uninterrupted for 49 minutes through 18 tracks
column3: a compositional feat made more impressive by the way the suite moves so fluidly between the segmented past of its jazz predecessors. Roberts is a meticulous and comprehensive composer
column4: but this music ricochets with the intensity of free jazz and dives smoothly into Sunday afternoon sessions. Mississippi Moonchile boasts impeccable melodies and excoriating variations
column5: cantering rhythms
column6: and debilitating breakdowns. Here
column7: it’s possible to trace the influence of Count Basie and Albert Ayler
column8: John Coltrane and Louis Armstrong
column9: the Art Ensemble of Chicago and Mahalia Jackson
column10: all on the same reverent level. On “Woman Red Racked”
column11: she twists an antediluvian Southern blues into a surreal call-and-answer; for the closer
column12: “Benediction”
column13: she turns the familiar words and tune of a praise song into a soul-settling balm after a gauntlet of assailant horns and unsteady drums. That continuum approach—blurring ancient history into the rather recent past
column14: and pulling both at once into the present—fits Roberts’ widescreen vision of history and of herself. That is the core of the Coin Coin effort: This work is neither about Roberts nor her family. It’s about anyone who’s ever tried to understand how they arrived in their own peculiar position.

column1: That
column2: of course
column3: is no easy proof
column4: which is where Jeremiah Abiah
column5: the operatic tenor
column6: comes in. His bellow is deep but dynamic
column7: stretching upward in crescents and dipping low to add textural density to this album’s otherwise acoustic sound. Interview transcripts and pinball approach notwithstanding
column8: he is the esoteric addition—and
column9: arguably the most important one. After listening to Mississippi Moonchile a few times
column10: try to imagine the same material without him: no distended vibrato passages during “Confessor Haste”
column11: no expressive paroxysms during the brief “All Nations”
column12: no ruptured moans during the valley of “Lesson”. The music seems too clean and too clear that way
column13: as though this aggregate of American anecdotal and musical history is now a complete lesson
column14: a lecture meant simply to be studied and redelivered later on an exam.

column1: But Roberts knows better than that. Remember
column2: this is her family
column3: and even she quotes her grandmother time and again saying
column4: “There are some things I just can’t tell you about
column5: honey.” Indeed
column6: for all the seismic variety here
column7: that admission of the unknowable serves as this record’s leitmotif—we can hear about the hardships (the need for rain and the dearth of education) and the small joys (the fruits and the arrival of plumbing)
column8: but we can never really know them entirely. Abiah imparts an intentional opacity
column9: then
column10: a means to push this part of the story to an obfuscated end. Roberts doesn’t want us getting too comfortable with this history
column11: as though we’ve dealt with its perils. “You can use these stories and narratives as a way to express a past but also a present
column12: ” she told The Wire earlier this year
column13: speaking about the subversive ways slavery still exists. “And
column14: what’s really interesting
column15: what I hope to parlay the work into more
column16: is using it as a platform [to address] these other forms of slavery that are continuing on.” That is
column17: we’ve got our own problems to worry about now. With <i>Coin Coin
column18:
Roberts—a history buff with a bold vision for the moment—has 10 more volumes to approach them.

In the time that they’ve performed together under the name Nguzunguzu
column3: Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda have proven themselves intellectually curious musicians. On the assortment of EPs
column4: remixes
column5: DJ mixes
column6: and singles the duo’s released over the past four years
column7: they’ve displayed a preoccupation with exploring how disparate elements act when they’re combined: organic sounds blended with laser-precise sequencing
column8: Chicago footwork with Angolan kuduro
column9: experimental ideas with floor-filling beats. They’re good at it
column10: too
column11: showing an eye not just for the synergy the mixes produce
column12: but also for the interesting bits of friction they create.

column1: Lately they’ve been investigating a different set of contrasts. It seems like as their work making beats for other artists has taken off (recent clients include Kelela and Le1f)
column2: they’ve been able to satisfy their traditional pop urges
column3: and so given the opportunity to do something under their own name
column4: they’ve decided to let their headier ambitions run free. On this seven-song EP
column5: Skycell
column6: the experiment yielded mixed results.

column1: Like a number of their contemporaries on dance music’s leading edge (the-Drum and Ryan Hemsworth among them)
column2: Pineda and Maroof have started to allow their compositions to stray further from the typical 16-bar intervals of build and release that largely define the genre. The songs here unfold gradually
column3: settling into more organic-feeling configurations than the cycles of loops that shape most other kinds of electronic dance music. The songs on Skycell move up and down like dance tracks usually do
column4: but they also move subtly in other dimensions
column5: like the shifts in the rhythm’s center of gravity that give their beats a woozy kind of 3-D effect
column6: and melodies seem to come and go as they please.

column1: This strategy offers major benefits
column2: like the cinematic scope that comes along with it
column3: intimating that there’s some kind of narrative lurking behind the music. You don’t need the EP's suggestive title and CG cover art to get the feeling that there’s some sort of science-fictional aspect to Skycell. A majority of the songs here have at least one part that sounds like something straight off a multiplex soundtrack: the spy-movie piano riff underpinning “Vision of Completion”
column4: or the jittery little string figure in “Harp Bell” that replicates the anxious crackle of a crisply edited heist scene.

column1: Then again there are some negative consequences as well. While its cinematic qualities are entertaining
column2: the more soundtracky moments can be distracting
column3: and don’t always hold up to repeat listens. And the tracky repetition that Pineda and Maroof have largely abandoned here can actually be a good thing
column4: especially when it comes to dance music—it’s easier to dance to a song when you have an idea of where it’s going.

column1: Skycell remains an impressive listen
column2: though
column3: and the sci-fi elements contribute to that. One of Nguzunguzu’s trademarks is their ability to make sequenced
column4: programmed music sound like a living
column5: breathing thing. The tone of their samples
column6: which often incorporate acoustic
column7: round-edged analog synths
column8: and field recordings (or at least exceptionally good reproductions)
column9: is a large part of that. But
column10: additionally
column11: there’s something about Skycell’s synthesis of the technological and the biological that approaches the uncanny—for some reason
column12: the chirping bird that shows up halfway through “Tumultuous” made me think of the human-engineered replica animals in Blade Runner
column13: where the biological and technological combine to make something that’s not quite either. It’s a creepy feeling
column14:
one that's fascinating enough to keep revisiting.

Sixteen years separates The Album and The Second Album. That's a preposterous amount of time
column2: even when you consider everything that the two members of epochal Bay Area indie rap duo Latyrx have been up to in the interim. Lyrics Born has lent his good-natured conversational virtuosity to a string of adequate-to-great solo albums (great-to-adequate if you're going chronologically). Lateef the Truth Speaker's gruff fluidity
column3: meanwhile
column4: was typically paired with specific one-producer one-offs and/or short-lived supergroups—think Maroons or the Mighty Underdogs. But consider everything that's happened in underground hip-hop over that stretch: labels have risen and fallen
column5: more than a dozen different movements
column6: regions
column7: subgenres
column8: and styles have infiltrated each other
column9: and the Solesides/Quannum collective that launched some of the best hip-hop records of the late 90s has largely receded into the background. Why that is owes a little to the fickleness of enduring fashionability in hip-hop
column10: even the alt-rap sectors—but long-term inspiration isn't a common commodity
column11: either.

column1: That could explain why The Second Album feels so scattered and frantic. Lateef and Lyrics Born would sound pretty good just going on cruise control
column2: letting their acrobatic
column3: complementary flows hold the weight and making even workaday lyrics seem spectacular. To their credit
column4: they don't come across like the complacent types who would resort to slacking like that—but ambition without inspiration can lead into some pretty ridiculous places
column5: all hacky-sack silliness and earnestness so overbearing it actually sounds false. It doesn't matter how trendy their blend of political indie-minded lyricism and lighthearted
column6: rib-poking internal punchlines is or isn't; what matters is that the strain to outdo themselves drives them to undo themselves instead. It's the difference between getting lifted by good-vibe sunshiney rap
column7: and getting thrown by constantly being asked if you're having a good time.

column1: This overreach grates because it doesn't allow much room for nuance
column2: or setup
column3: or much breathing room at all
column4: really. The way opener “Arrival” muddles its comeback narrative/populist defiance in Hooray for Everything stream-of-consciousness leaves behind the mildly buzzy vapor of what could either be a call to arms or a frozen yogurt commercial. That vagueness is ramped up by a scattered sociopolitical POV that takes loose feints at broad issues: gun culture's drawbacks
column5: tragedies and consequences are yammered out to empty rapidfire effect in “Reload""
column6: and the obvious punchline of “The Power of Rumor (Leonard Is Lost)”—a mysterious posted message that leads to riots and media overkill turns out to be for a lost cat—builds a cautionary tall tale out of frivolous hyperbole that's as funny as a cinderblock to the foot. Even when things divert more towards the day-to-day ordinary
column7: like the pseudo-virtuoso rap-about-rap-about-rap “Deliberate Gibberish” (“Look at little ol' me/ I'm a unicorn king/ And my heart on my sleeve/ And a card up my sleeve/ Tell me what does that mean?”) or the unrequited love lament “Electric Chair” (“We're so close I see my reflection in your brown eyes/ Yet so far apart I might as well be on an asteroid”)
column8: there's this weird sense of the lyrics trying to be deadly serious and lightheartedly amusing at the same time
column9: while failing at both.

column1: With that in mind
column2: the production almost seems like an afterthought
column3: even if some of the names hold promise. Anticon vet Jel provides some decently low-end-reliant futurist space-funk on “Arrival” and “Reload
column4: ” the instrumentals of which would've fit in well with the solid Late Pass album he dropped earlier this year. And bringing in tUnE-yArDs to give Merrill Garbus' swirling loop-driven builds a more explicit hip-hop context was an inspired move
column5: even if the relative minimalism of “Watershed Moment""
column6: with its sparse vocal harmonies and reliance on a stark drum loop
column7: is a better fit than the manic “O Superman” gasps on “Deliberate Jibberish”. But those two producers' divergent styles are already enough at odds with each other
column8: and filling out the rest of the production slate on The Second Album with similarly grab-bag sounds keeps things frustratingly scattered.

column1: The album's home stretch gets the most ridiculous with it: the Decemberists' Chris Funk fiddles around with gothic bongo breaks on “Sometimes Why?”
column2: Future People's generic indie-electro-pop runs through “Every Man for Himself”
column3: some low-key riffage from Living Colour's Corey Glover is the only sign of life in the emo-hop trudge of “Electric Chair""
column4: and the closing “Gorgeous Spirits (Aye Let's Go)” is grotesque caricaturized circa-'06 hyphy that doesn't do justice to Lateef
column5: Lyrics Born

The more the triumphs of Eminem’s world beating Slim Shady/Marshall Mathers/Eminem Show trilogy recede into memory
column4: the more each subsequent release struggles to strike a tone that leverages an audience raised on the crass iconoclasm of “My Name Is” and “Kill You” with the aging
column5: now sober father of three behind the music. As such
column6: Em’s last decade worth of albums has suffered under jarring shifts in tone. After showing his first signs of wear with 2004’s patchy Encore
column7: Eminem rebounded with 2009’s Dre-beats-and-horrorcore-rhymes retrenchment Relapse. Relapse sold well but its serial killer shtick was uninspired
column8: as Eminem openly admitted on the next year’s “Not Afraid” (“That last Relapse CD was ‘enh’”). 2010’s Recovery maneuvered out of Relapse and Encore’s chum bucket humor by detailing the artist’s struggle to overcome a long-simmering prescription drug dependency. Serious Eminem proved a drag despite Recovery couching its penitent 12-step dispatches in rivulets of the usual Slim Shady chicanery
column9: so here we are staring down a once-more radioactive blonde Eminem’s Marshall Mathers LP 2.

column1: The Marshall Mathers LP 2 is an album-length bout of moral recidivism
column2: Recovery’s motivational rehab narrative ditched wholesale for a second helping of the celeb-hating
column3: self-deprecating juvenalia of Eminem’s beloved third album peppered with samples of and references to the source material. Opener “Bad Guy” is a sprawling epic that finds the brother of “Stan”’s titular obsessed fan hatching an elaborate revenge plot
column4: and “Parking Lot” inexplicably revisits the heist in the middle of “Criminal” to inform us that the getaway driver split
column5: and the shooter died. “Rap God” revisits a crass joke about the 1999 Columbine school shooting initially censored on the first LP’s “I’m Back”. Old nemeses like Insane Clown Posse
column6: Everlast
column7: and the Backstreet Boys are lampooned as well. But MMLP2 revisits more than just the characters and stories of the first installment. It also revels in its predecessor’s worst behaviors
column8: bandying about misogyny and gay slurs as if Eminem’s conciliatory 2001 Grammys performance with a pink polka dot suited Elton John never happened.

column1: “Rap God” is a gobstopping display of Eminem’s champion technical prowess that’s waylaid in every verse by brazen homophobia. “Love Game”
column2: the hotly anticipated team up with Kendrick Lamar
column3: is similarly assailed by lunkheaded chauvinism
column4: both in Eminem’s gross rendition of a woman giving him oral sex and Kendrick’s barbs about a guy who “drowned like an abortion” and a clingy ex for whom “chlamydia couldn’t even get rid of her.” Elsewhere two songs are dedicated to crucifying the mother of his children and anyone else foolhardy enough to get involved with him. (“Bitch
column5: you complain when you listen to this/ But you throw yourself at me/ That’s what I call pitching a bitch.”) Earlier in his career
column6: Eminem delivered similarly gutbucket content with the shock of incredulity that anyone would find it offensive. It was an error of youthful carelessness. But in 2013
column7: in the wake of the message of redemption he feverishly pitched us just an album ago
column8: Eminem’s return to ruffling feathers carries the stink of desperation.

column1: The only salvation for a lot of these songs is Eminem’s alchemical control of rhyme and diction
column2: but even that can be a liability. Thirteen years after the original Marshall Mathers LP
column3: the grating cadence-over-substance ethos of “The Way I Am”
column4: once a stilted outlier on an album packed with otherwise limber wordplay
column5: has now become the rule. “Legacy” pulls all manner of cockamamie pronunciation gymnastics just so Eminem can end every line with the same rhyming syllables
column6: and the song’s decision to dispense with proper word accents and splay sentences haphazardly across the middle of lines makes for a flow that comes across overwrought and labored even as it plays Frankenstein with conventional word choice and rhyme patterns. Filler words frequently clutter lines just to make the rhymes look more dazzling
column7: and in the process we end up with well-executed but empty lines like “I been driving around your side of this town like nine frickin’ hours and forty five minutes now” from “Bad Guy” and “The day you beat me pigs’ll fly out of my ass in a saucer full of Italian sausages” on “Legacy”. Play half of these songs alongside even the clunkiest Marshall Mathers LP cut
column8: and the god of rap’s powers appear noticeably diminished.

column1: MMLP2 does step out from under the shadow of its predecessor in its choice of collaborators. Dr. Dre sits this one out
column2: appearing as an executive producer but steering clear of any actual grunt work. In his place we get a spate of productions from Eminem himself (often aided by pop heavyweights like Alex da Kid and Emile) alongside a newly in-demand Rick Rubin. MMLP2’s production mostly hews toward the expected stadium rap sounds
column3: but the Rubin cuts award the album a measure of old school rap-rock flair. Unfortunately what sounded like invention for the 1986 Beastie Boys often plays like butt rock in the hands of 2013 Eminem. “Berzerk” turns Billy Squier’s “The Stroke” into questionable back-to-basics posturing
column4: and “So Far…” grinds Joe Walsh’s winding 1978 epic “Life’s Been Good” and Schoolly D’s “P.S.K. (What Does It Mean?)” into fodder for Eminem’s middle-aged finger-waving. (“Fuck I gotta do to hear this new song from Luda
column5: be an expert at computers?”) “Rhyme or Reason” cleverly flips the “What’s your name?/ Who’s your daddy?” refrain from the Zombies’ “Time of the Season” into a tongue-lashing for an absentee father
column6: and “Love Game” makes good use of Wayne Fontana and the Mindbenders’ “The Game of Love”
column7: sexist lyrical putrefaction aside
column8: but by and large
column9: Eminem and Rubin are not a match.

column1: Eminem is a titan with wordplay
column2: but MMLP2 once again finds him at a loss for how to apply his talents. For three albums in the early aughts he devilishly rewrote the rules of pop music to shoehorn hip-hop into the national spotlight
column3: but here he’s winded
column4: struggling to keep up with modern pop conventions
column5: genuflecting to trap on “Rap God” and EDM on “The Monster”
column6: dragging his biggest competitor Kendrick into one of the worst songs of his young career
column7: and soldering on hooks from singers of varying anonymity wherever applicable to ensure this patchwork monstrosity is too big to fail
column8: all of this under the guise of a return to form
column9: his second in three albums. Eminem’s too talented a rapper with too good a Rolodex for this to flop
column10: but damned if Marshall Mathers LP 2 doesn’t give it a go. The lesson here
column11: if there’s one to be gleaned from this 80 minutes of cold
column12: clinical lyrical acrobatics
column13: is that rap sequels are a lot like trying on old prom clothes: chance one if you dare
column14:
but the only thing you’re liable to display is how much you’ve let yourself go since your glory days.

The term “transatlanticism” was coined by Ben Gibbard to define the incomprehensible emotional gap between two lovers separated by comprehensible distances—the continental United States
column2: an entire ocean
column3: or
column4: most likely
column5: just a couple floors in your freshman dorm. In the 10 years since Death Cab For Cutie released their finest record
column6: the title has taken on an unintended resonance in regards to their career. On one side of their fourth of seven studio albums
column7: there are three modestly performed and admirably successful LPs released on Seattle indie label Barsuk. On the other
column8: three exquisite-sounding and wildly successful LPs released on New York City major...Atlantic. Death Cab’s aesthetic hadn’t really changed all that much
column9: and yet how do you span the distance between the uber-#feelings video for “A Movie Script Ending” and two #1 albums (Codes and Keys hit #3)
column10: Grammy nominations
column11: platinum sales when they meant something
column12: huge festival slots

column1: Up until 2001's The Photo Album

column4: their blood didn’t run particularly hot either
column5: even when Gibbard sang about abusive parents

column7: or hatred for his future hometown of Los Angeles. On <i>Transatlanticism
column8: well
column9: not much really changed. But Walla in particular found countless ways to work around it. We all know Summer Roberts’ “it’s like one guitar and a whole lot of complaining” wisecrack helped Death Cab far more than it ever hurt them
column10: but what always bothered me was the idea that they ever sounded like one guy. Death Cab songs are nearly impossible to accurately recreate in a solo performance and if the rinky-dink demos (hear “We Looked Like Giants” and the title track with 8-bit drums!) included in the reissue prove anything
column11: it’s that.

column1: Walla takes advantage of all the band’s moving parts
column2: ensuring each one has its own distinct sonic character and turning Transatlanticism into a downright indulgent listen
column3: a grand buffet of texture and tone. On the whole
column4: the band creates perfectly detailed sonic dioramas—from the piano punctuating the pregnant quietude of “Passenger Seat”
column5: you feel a frozen forest night in the middle of winter. “The New Year” captures explosions off in the distance and the ambivalence of wondering why you can’t relate to them. Within these ornate arrangements
column6: a clever addition sneaks in towards the end and steals the song—the xylophone that rearranges the melody of “Title and Registration”
column7: the combination of handclaps and slashing guitars on “The Sound of Settling”
column8: and especially the percussion
column9: whether those of new drummer Jason McGerr or the mechanistic electronics (beyond its profile boost
column10: the concurrent musical influence of Gibbard’s work in the Postal Service tends to be overstated).

column1: It reveals much of their work leading up to Transatlanticism as test runs—the simple Death Cab + drum machine format of “Coney Island” or the Stability EP are upgraded to complex
column2: mixed-meter rhythms on “Lightness” and “Death of an Interior Decorator”. On “Bend to Squares”
column3: “Title Track”
column4: “Styrofoam Plates” (and later
column5: “Marching Bands of Manhattan” and “Bixby Canyon Bridge”)
column6: Death Cab developed a trick where they’d build and build and build without ever exploding into pure catharsis. The consuming title track unapologetically goes over-the-top
column7: giving you a safe and sound drop on the most sincere
column8: intense FaceTime conversation ever: those glistening guitars and the endless
column9: upward ramp of the drums convey enough infinite sadness as is
column10: and then a church choir comes in to goad the listener: will these two EVER just make out already?

column1: Walla was expanding his scope and ambition
column2: intersecting with Gibbard
column3: who was doing the same as a writer. It didn’t initially seem that way: though this record gained Death Cab many
column4: many new fans
column5: it lost some older ones as well
column6: and in our original review of Transatlanticism

column8: taking issue with the increased generality of Gibbard’s lyrics. And there’s truth to that
column9: as Transatlanticism is full of compact ways to express the same ideas that Death Cab songs would earlier obfuscate with bigger words or dense metaphor: “So this is the new year/ and I don’t feel any different
column10: ” “I need you so much closer
column11: ” and of course
column12: “She is beautiful

column14: I think you’d be hard-pressed to find anyone else capable of pulling off Gibbard’s more typically elliptical concepts. A disastrous wedding “felt just like falling in love again” to the lonely empty nester on “Death of an Interior Decorator”. “Title and Registration” begins with a silly joke and it’s revealed as a defense mechanism as Gibbard recalls how the dumbest thing (like
column15: “searching for some legal documents”) can unearth a wellspring of repressed feelings. It’s a phenomenon that can cause you to lose hours at a time
column16: and “Title” sums it up perfectly in four minutes.

column1: As a result of pulling all those heartstrings
column2: short of the Decemberists
column3: no band has become an easier target for people who want to assert their “I ain’t with that indie bullshit” masculinity. Granted
column4: Death Cab For Cutie’s music never sounds sexual
column5: and you can’t really call it “rock music” as something derived from “rhythm and blues”—hell
column6: they’ve always been an awkward fit into “emo” as a musical ideal
column7: since that entails some basis in punk and Death Cab clearly have nothing of the sort. And that’s fine
column8: as Gibbard sought to create the definitive songs about the span of a romantic coupling rather than a sonic approximation of it. Whereas the previous albums dealt with mundane
column9: household affairs—reading the unemployment pages
column10: sharing cigarettes
column11: “We Laugh Indoors”—a lot more’s at stake this time out
column12: emotionally and physically. Death Cab thrashes desperately throughout “We Looked Like Giants” while Gibbard recalls both the thrall of hormonal
column13: visceral lust and the painful recollection of the liminal moments spent around jukeboxes and magazines. Wavering sonar beeps cloak low-key amorousness on “Lightness”. And
column14: oh man…""Tiny Vessels.”

column1: A common criticism of Death Cab (and really
column2: its fanbase) is that wimpiness served as a cover for passive-aggressiveness or a safe haven from actually acting on emotions or impulses and risking rejection—if not outright misogyny. “Tiny Vessels” doesn’t exactly negate that criticism
column3: it just forces the issue by putting it right out there. Though he'd reconfigure the “I spent two weeks in Silver Lake” line after his divorce from Zooey Deschanel
column4: that's an exception
column5: as one of Gibbard’s strengths is that his lyrics can be rich with personalized detail without sounding personal. That said
column6: his vocals always lead you to believe that the narrator at least kinda looks like him and it's startling to hear Gibbard detail the kind of callous sexual conquest people think they're escaping by getting into the indie crowd.

column1: The entire band is in peak form on ""Tiny Vessels""—a glancing
column2: sour note in the introductory guitar harmony precedes the unsympathetic admission that you're no different than the narrator
column3: that ""you'll tell her that you love her but you don't."" Time-elapse layering of shockingly distorted guitars raise the drama during the bridge as he “wanted to believe in all the words that I was speaking/ As we moved together in the dark.” That gets most of the attention
column4: though it’s the spellbinding third verse where all of it clears out
column5: leaving plangent
column6: echoing drums that house the monstrous
column7: hollowed-out sentiment of Gibbard’s lyric—that of a total jerk who’s very aware of the thoughts and feelings of the other person
column8: but chooses not to stop himself. It’s understandable that many people either can’t or choose not to acknowledge both sides of “Tiny Vessels”
column9: and every time a Death Cab live crowd turns it to a singalong (and it’s usually one of the loudest)

column1: We’ve gotten this far

column3: and Transatlanticism in particular
column4: from a completely objective standpoint feels kinda insincere and wholly inaccurate (and everybody knows it). From a lot of the descriptors above
column5: “indulgent
column6: ” “consuming
column7: ” etc.—you can assume that
column8: yeah
column9: I was completely obsessed with Transatlanticism back in 2003. It was in a way that should be embarrassing in retrospect
column10: but why judge your younger self like that? If the “little brother/sister music” tag often applied to Death Cab is going to stick
column11: at least remember the times when your world was that small where new love (or a broken heart) filled its entirety and thensome. Or maybe that a new love shrinks your world to the point where there isn’t room for anything else. Note the central simile in “We Looked Like Giants”

column1: I mean
column2: I can bust out a map and point out the mountain passes of Virginia’s I-64 that I’d brave after skipping early classes or talk about the resonance of “Title and Registration” in relation to the November day in 2003 I spent getting my automotive legal documents in order or how I first heard the title track on the way to a college reunion

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19903/homepage_large.934b8952.jpg|Process|30205.0|Yvette|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Godmode']|2013-11-06 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:02.974068|"

This past weekend
column2: YouTube hosted its first-ever music awards show as a self-congratulatory nod to the role it's played this past decade in facilitating the breakthroughs of our most famous pop stars and novelty-hit atrocities alike. But for music fans who came of age in the pre-internet era
column3: the site has served a more practical
column4: psychologically mollifying function: It’s helped verify the occurrence of events that
column5: for decades
column6: we thought we had simply hallucinated.

column1: For instance
column2: thanks to YouTube
column3: one can confirm that: a) Joan Rivers did indeed have a late-night talk show in the 80s; b) Suzanne Somers was its occasional fill-in host; and c) one night in 1987
column4: U.K. post-punk godheads Wire were her musical guests. They didn’t even perform their accessible dance-rock crossover single of the time
column5: “Ahead”
column6: but the impenetrable
column7: pummelling The Ideal Copy bonus track “Drill.” And instead of just offering up a simple post-performance wave and handshake
column8: Somers actually tried to engage the notoriously stoic group in egreiously idle chit-chat as if she were still hanging at the Regal Beagle. The clip stands as a time capsule of alternative rock’s painfully awkward early encounters with the mainstream
column9: and even today
column10: when indie bands can seemingly go from Bandcamp to Letterman in a mouse-click
column11: it’s hard to imagine such a deviously dissonant anti-pop gesture being allowed to play out anywhere near a network-television soundstage. But if there is to ever be another underground-spawned art-punk band to find itself enduring awkward small talk with a television host
column12: my money is on Brooklyn’s Yvette.

column1: Yvette are a two-piece band
column2: but sound like an army—both in their blitzkrieged aggression and the militaristically disciplined manner in which they deploy it. They’re an industrial act in the truest sense of the term
column3: transforming scabrous raw materials into beautiful
column4: glistening
column5: chrome-plated objects that cast an uncanny allure. Theirs is a noise molded into the contours—if not the sound—of pop music
column6: offering an accessible entry point into a world of ugly brutalism. But if Yvette approach their music with assembly-line precison and expediency
column7: their output is hardly identi-kit. Process
column8: their full-length debut
column9: may list 11 tracks on its artwork
column10: however
column11: those markers seem almost arbitrary; rather
column12: the album feels like a series of fragmented outbursts compacted together into a 33-minute piece that frequently shifts course and reanimates into new shapes without warning
column13: often within a span of a single song.

column1: Produced by Godmode Records co-founder/Pitchfork contributor Nick Sylvester
column2: Process proffers a spectacular collision of live
column3: in-the-room clarity (Rick Daniel’s foreboding cymbal taps practically leave cut marks on your skin) and grotesquely manipulated sonics: synths squiggle like screeching guitars; guitars get blown out into bass frequencines; bass lines hum and drone like synths. With harshly rendered sonics and ticking-time-bomb beats swirling around the 360-degree mix
column4: the songs immediately establish a claustrophobic sense of impending doom: The siren-like pulses of “Cuts Me in Half” sound like a contaminated science-lab counting down to self-destruct mode; the otherwise straight-forward post-punk charge of “Attrition” is rendered as a warped
column5: fun-house-mirrored death trip. And Yvette are students not just of Wire’s coldly futurist sound and disaffected lyricism
column6: but their sense of pacing
column7: too—even in songs that rarely crack the three-minute mark
column8: there are extended rhythmic builds that suddenly yield to acclereated
column9: white-knuckled climaxes.

column1: But perhaps the most unnerving sound of all on Process is found in Noah Kardos-Fein’s atypically smooth (for a spastic-noise-punk-band) voice
column2: which mostly retains an eerie sense of calm amid the tribal-percussive thumps and mutating discord that threatens to consume him; in the midst of the Liars-like onslaught of “Carbon Copy”
column3: his double-tracked harmonies have the power to freeze the song into a dead stop
column4: only to shatter its structure and liquefy into something new. And given that Kardos-Fein’s mantras-as-manifestos adhere to a melodic logic (if not consistent verse-chorus-verse structures)
column5: Process carries with it the possibility of Yvette evolving into something even more ambitious and imposing. The last two pieces
column6: in particular
column7: offer compelling evidence of what this band is capable of when they temper their shifty impluses and see an idea through to its logical conclusion: the instrumental “Absolutes” is the album’s longest song and
column8: not coincidentally its most fully realized
column9: a gonzo air-raid attack of a track that violently unleashes all the pent-up tension the album’s accrued to that point; it clears the way for the ice-age aftermath of “Radiation”
column10: a thundering drums and drones jam that—even the absence of a proper chorus—exudes a cavernous
column11: concert-hall grandeur. At this point
column12: a Leno appearance for Yvette may seem highly unlikely
column13:
but don’t count out Fallon.
